desc: The presence of any abnormality of the genitourinary system.
name: Abnormality of the genitourinary system

desc: An abnormality of the genital system.
name: Abnormality of the genital system

desc: An abnormal functionality of the genital system.
name: Abnormality of reproductive system physiology

desc: A decreased functionality of the gonad.
name: Hypogonadism

desc: Decreased functionality of the male gonad, i.e., of the testis, with reduced spermatogenesis or testosterone synthesis.
name: Male hypogonadism

desc: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is characterized by reduced function of the gonads (testes in males or ovaries in females) and results from the absence of the gonadal stimulating pituitary hormones: follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
name: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

desc: Decreased functionality of the female gonads, i.e., of the ovary.
name: Female hypogonadism

desc: Reduced function of the gonads (testes in males or ovaries in females) associated with excess pituitary gonadotropin secretion and resulting in delayed sexual development and growth delay.
name: Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

desc: An abnormal functionality of the male genital system.
name: Abnormal male reproductive system physiology

layperson: Functional abnormality of male internal genitalia
name: Functional abnormality of male internal genitalia

desc: Incomplete maturation or aberrant formation of the male gametes.
name: Abnormal spermatogenesis

desc: Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen.
name: Azoospermia

desc: Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from a defect in the production of spermatozoa in the testes. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy.
name: Non-obstructive azoospermia

desc: Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, resulting from post-testicular obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. This can be differentiated from obstructive azoospermia on the basis of testicular biopsy.
name: Obstructive azoospermia

desc: Absence of any measurable level of sperm in his semen, due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality diagnosed with hypo-gonadotropic-hypogonadism. The diagnosis is made on the basis of low LH and FSH levels and low or normal testosterone levels.
name: Pretesticular azoospermia

desc: Reduced count of spermatozoa in the semen, defined as a sperm count below 20 million per milliliter semen.
name: Oligospermia

desc: A type of low sperm count where ejaculated semen contains less than 100,000 spermatozoa per ml. With cryptozoospermia, the sperm count may fluctuate and a zero sperm count in the ejaculate may be initially measured. If sperm are observed in a second semen sample following centrifugation, the diagnosis of cryptozoospermia can be made (and azoospermia can be ruled out).
name: Cryptozoospermia

desc: Maturation arrest (MA) is defined as germ cells that fail to complete maturation. Uniform MA is characterized by spermatogenic arrest at the same stage of spermatogenesis throughout the seminiferous tubules. MA is subcategorized into early MA, in which only spermatogonia or spermatocytes are found, and late MA, in which spermatids are detected without spermatozoa.
name: Spermatogenesis maturation arrest

desc: A type of maturation arrest in which only spermatogonia or spermatocytes are found.
name: Early spermatogenesis maturation arrest

desc: A type of maturation arrest in which spermatids are detected without spermatozoa.
name: Late spermatogenesis maturation arrest
synonyms: Maturation arrest of spermatogenesis at spermatid stage

desc: An anomaly of the mobility of ejaculated sperm.
name: Abnormal sperm motility

desc: An abnormal reduction in the mobility of ejaculated sperm.
name: Reduced sperm motility

desc: A lack of mobility of ejaculated sperm.
name: Nonmotile sperm

desc: Abnormality in the process of ejection of semen (usually carrying sperm) from the male reproductive tract.
name: Abnormal ejaculation

desc: The emission of semen and seminal fluid during the act of preparation for sexual intercourse, i.e. before there is penetration, or shortly after penetration.
name: Premature ejaculation

desc: The emission of semen and seminal fluid into the bladder instead of through the penis during orgasm.
name: Retrograde ejaculation

desc: Difficulty of a male in achieving orgasm.
name: Retarded ejaculation

desc: Inability to ejaculate.
name: Anejaculation

desc: A problem occurring during any phase of the male sexual response cycle that prevents the individual from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity
name: Male sexual dysfunction

desc: Increased desire for sexual activity on the part of a male.
name: Increased male libido

desc: Reduced desire for sexual activity on the part of a male.
name: Decreased male libido

desc: Inability of a male to reach orgasm.
name: Male anorgasmia

desc: A multidimensional but common male sexual dysfunction that involves an alteration in any of the components of the erectile response, including organic, relational and psychological.
name: Erectile dysfunction

desc: Inability to develop or maintain an erection of the penis.
name: Impotence

desc: Impotence (inability to develop or maintain an erection) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
name: Autonomic erectile dysfunction

desc: A painful and harmful medical condition in which the erect penis doesn't return to its flaccid state, despite the absence of both physical and psychological stimulation, within four hours.
name: Priapism

desc: An abnormality of the ovulation cycle.
name: Abnormality of the menstrual cycle

desc: Prolonged and excessive menses at regular intervals in excess of 80 mL or lasting longer than 7 days.
name: Menorrhagia

desc: Absence of menses for an interval of time equivalent to a total of more than (or equal to) 3 previous cycles or 6 months.
name: Amenorrhea

desc: Abnormally high variation in the amount of time between periods.
name: Irregular menstruation

desc: Pain during menstruation that interferes with daily activities.
name: Dysmenorrhea

desc: Infrequent menses (less than 6 per year or more than 35 days between cycles).
name: Oligomenorrhea

desc: First period after the age of 15 years.
name: Delayed menarche

desc: Bleeding at irregular intervals.
name: Metrorrhagia

desc: Frequent menses; menstrual cycles lasting less than 21 days.
name: Polymenorrhea

desc: Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals.
name: Menometrorrhagia

desc: A problem occurring during any phase of the female sexual response cycle that prevents the individual from experiencing satisfaction from the sexual activity
name: Female sexual dysfunction

desc: The persistent of recurrent difficulty, delay in, or absence of attaining orgasm following sufficient sexual stimulation and arousal.
name: Female anorgasmia

desc: Recurrent or persistent genital pain associated with sexual intercourse.
name: Dyspareunia

desc: Recurrent or persistent involuntary spasms of the musculature of the outer third of the vagina that interferes with vaginal penetration, and which causes personal distress.
name: Vaginismus

desc: Dminished sexual desire in female.
name: Decreased female libido

desc: Elevated sexual desire in female
name: Increased female libido

desc: The growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus.
name: Endometriosis

desc: Abnormal growth of endometrial cells (which are normally limited to the uterus) within the cervix.
name: Cervical endometriosis

desc: Any anomaly of ovarian function.
name: Abnormal ovarian physiology

desc: Amenorrhea due to loss of ovarian function before the age of 40. Primary ovarian inssuficiency (POI) is a state of female hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. It can manifest as primary amenorrhea with onset before menarche or secondary amenorrhea.
name: Premature ovarian insufficiency

desc: A failure to collect oocytes after an apparently normal controlled ovarian hyperstimulation cycle for in vitro fertilization.
name: Empty ovarian follicle

desc: Any deviation from the normal sexual drive or desire for sexual activity.
name: Abnormal libido

desc: Elevated sexual desire.
name: Increased libido

desc: Decreased sexual desire.
name: Decreased libido

desc: Inability of individual to reach orgasm.
name: Anorgasmia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the genital system.
name: Genital neoplasm

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a gonad.
name: Gonadal neoplasm

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the testis.
name: Testicular neoplasm

desc: The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the testis.
name: Testicular gonadoblastoma

desc: Testicular adrenal rest tumor (TART) is a abenign tumor of the testis. TART generally occurs multiply and bilaterally within the rete testis. Histologically, TART resemble adrenocortical tissue, which led to the name. The tumous are not encapsulated and consist of sheets or confluent cords of large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
name: Testicular adrenal rest tumor

desc: A Malignant mesothelioma of the testis.
name: Testicular mesothelioma

desc: The presence of a teratoma of the testis.
name: Testicular teratoma

desc: The presence of a seminoma, an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the testis.
name: Testicular seminoma

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Leydig cell.
name: Leydig cell neoplasia

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the testis with origin in a Sertoli cell.
name: Sertoli cell neoplasm

layperson: Precocious puberty with Sertoli cell tumor
name: Precocious puberty with Sertoli cell tumor
synonyms: Precocious puberty with Sertoli cell tumour

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the epididymis, an duct that transports spermatozoa from the testis to the vas deferens.
name: Epididymal neoplasm

desc: A cystadenoma, an epithelial tumor, that originates within the head of the epididymis.
name: Papillary cystadenoma of the epididymis

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ovary.
name: Ovarian neoplasm

desc: The presence of a gonadoblastoma of the ovary.
name: Ovarian gonadoblastoma

desc: The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary.
name: Ovarian papillary adenocarcinoma

desc: The presence of a fibroma of the ovary.
name: Ovarian fibroma

desc: The presence of a teratoma in the ovary.
name: Ovarian teratoma

desc: An cystic ovarian teratoma composed of dermal and epidermal elements and containing tissue components including hair, teeth, bone, thyroid, and others.
name: Ovarian dermoid cyst

desc: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.
name: Ovarian carcinoma

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from the ovary and is composed of granulosa cells, Sertoli cells, Leydig cells, theca cells, and fibroblasts.
name: Ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor

desc: A sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary. Thecomas range from small tumors to large solid or solid-cystic masses of up to 15 cm. They are unilateral in over 90 percent of cases and are rarely malignant. Thecomas are stromal tumors made up of cells that resemble theca cells, lutein cells and fibroblasts. They are traditionally classified within the sex cord-stromal tumor category of ovarian tumor types.
name: Ovarian thecoma

desc: Juvenile granulosa cell ovarian tumor (JGCOT) is a rare sex cord stromal tumor, occuring most frequently in premenarchal girls or young women. In contrast to adult granulosa cell tumor, JGCOT has a high mitotic index and more aggressive tumor growth. Microscopically it is seen as diffuse and regularly distributed neoplastic cells with a wide cytoplasm and pleomorphic hyperchromatic nucleus. Follicle formation, in various sizes and shapes, is important in JGCOT. Call-Exner bodies are infrequently seen in JGCOT in contrast to the adult type.
layperson: Juvenile type ovarian granulosa cell tumor
name: Juvenile type ovarian granulosa cell tumor
synonyms: Juvenile type ovarian granulosa cell tumour

desc: An aggressive granulosa cell tumor that arises from the ovary.
name: Malignant ovarian granulosa cell tumor

desc: The presence of a dysgerminoma, i.e., an undifferentiated germ cell tumor of the ovary.
name: Dysgerminoma

desc: The presence of a gonadoblastoma, a neoplasm of a gonad that consists of aggregates of germ cells and sex cord elements.
name: Gonadoblastoma

desc: The presence of a teratoma.
name: Teratoma

desc: A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumour size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone.
name: Cardiac teratoma

desc: A teratoma arising in the sacro-coccygeal region.
name: Sacrococcygeal teratoma

desc: A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma located anterior to the sacrum and entirely inside the body (Altman type IV).
name: Presacral teratoma

desc: A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma that is predominantly external and projects from the sacrococcygeal region and presents with distortion of the buttocks.
name: Altman type I sacrococcygeal teratoma

desc: A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma that is predominantly external but has a large intrapelvic component.
name: Altman type II sacrococcygeal teratoma

desc: A type of sacrococcygeal teratoma that is predominantly intrapelvic with a small external, buttock mass.
name: Altman type III sacrococcygeal teratoma

desc: A teratoma located within the mediastinum (the cavity between the pleural sacs that contains the heart and all of the thoracic viscera except the lungs).
name: Mediastinal teratoma

desc: A teratoma located in the craniofacial region.
name: Craniofacial teratoma

desc: Epignathus is a teratoma originating from the upper jaw, usually connected with the sphenoid bone or hard palate.
name: Epignathus

desc: A teratoma arising in the nasopharyngeal region.
name: Nasopharyngeal teratoma

desc: A gestational or non-gestational neoplasm composed of neoplastic trophoblastic cells [NCIT:C3422].
name: Trophoblastic tumor

desc: A malignant, trophoblastic and aggressive cancer, usually of the placenta. It is characterized by early hematogenous spread to the lungs and belongs to the far end of the spectrum of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a subset of germ cell tumors.
name: Choriocarcinoma

desc: A type of undifferentiated germ cell tumor that may be benign or malignant.
name: Germinoma

desc: The presence of a germ cell tumor of the cerebrum.
name: Cerebral germinoma

desc: A neoplasm that affects the male reproductive system.
name: Male reproductive system neoplasm

desc: A cancer of the prostate.
name: Prostate cancer

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the male external genitalia.
layperson: Neoplasm of the male external genitalia
name: Neoplasm of the male external genitalia
synonyms: Neoplasia of the male external genitalia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the scrotum.
name: Neoplasm of the scrotum

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the penis.
name: Neoplasm of the penis

desc: A neoplasm that affects the female reproductive system.
name: Female reproductive system neoplasm

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterus.
name: Uterine neoplasm

desc: The presence of a leiomyoma of the uterus.
name: Uterine leiomyoma

desc: The presence of a leiomyosarcoma of the uterus.
name: Uterine leiomyosarcoma

desc: A carcinoma of the endometrium, the mucous lining of the uterus.
name: Endometrial carcinoma

desc: A tumor of the uterine cervix.
name: Cervix cancer

desc: Carcinoma that originates in the Fallopian tube. It may be located in the wall or within the lumen as a growth attached to the wall by a stalk.
name: Fallopian tube carcinoma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the female external genital tract (vulva).
name: Vulvar neoplasm

desc: A cancer that originates in the squamous cells that line the surface of the vulva.
layperson: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva
name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva

desc: A type of vulvar cancer that originates from melanocytes of the vulva.
name: Vulvar melanoma

desc: A cancer arising in a cell of the Bartholin gland, a racemose gland located slightly posterior to the opening of the vagina.
name: Bartholin gland carcinoma

desc: An adenocarcinoma arising in the vulva.
name: Vulvar adenocarcinoma

desc: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) is widely accepted as the precursor lesion of vulvar squamous cell carcinoma (VSCC). VSCC arises via either a human papilloma virus (HPV)-associated pathway, or more commonly, via a mechanism independent of HPV, often being linked to chronic inflammatory conditions such as lichen sclerosus (LS). Accordingly, two distinct subtypes of VIN are recognised: the HPV-associated high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion/usual VIN (HSIL/uVIN) and the non-HPV-associated differentiated VIN (dVIN). HSIL is clinically identified by its multifocal, warty appearance and on histology by conspicuous cytological and architectural atypia. Differentiated VIN, on the other hand, often produces ill-defined lesions, and on histology, notoriously mimics non-neoplastic epithelial disorders (NNED), particularly LS. As a result, dVIN is rarely identified in advance of a diagnosis of invasive malignancy, despite being the precursor lesion of the majority of VSCC.
name: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the vagina.
name: Vaginal neoplasm

desc: A type of adenocarcinoma originating in the vagina and characterized by large cells with moderate to abundant clear cytoplasm.
name: Vaginal clear cell adenocarcinoma
synonyms: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina

desc: A type of adenocarcinoma originating in the cervix and characterized by large cells with moderate to abundant clear cytoplasm.
name: Cervical clear cell adenocarcinoma

desc: A structural or developmental anomaly of any of the tissues involved in the genital system.
name: Abnormal reproductive system morphology

desc: An abnormality of male external genitalia.
name: Abnormality of male external genitalia

desc: Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XY genetic gender.
name: Ambiguous genitalia, male

desc: An anomaly of the testicle (the male gonad).
name: Abnormal testis morphology

desc: Testis in inguinal canal. That is, absence of one or both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
name: Cryptorchidism

desc: Absence of both testes from the scrotum owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
name: Bilateral cryptorchidism

desc: Absence of a testis from the scrotum on one side owing to failure of the testis or testes to descend through the inguinal canal to the scrotum.
name: Unilateral cryptorchidism

desc: Wasting (atrophy) of the testicle (the male gonad) manifested by a decrease in size and potentially by a loss of fertility.
name: Testicular atrophy

desc: Accumulation of clear fluid in the between the layers of membrane (tunica vaginalis) surrounding the testis.
name: Hydrocele testis

desc: The presence of more than two testes.
name: Supernumerary testes

desc: Underdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.
name: Hyoplasia of the Leydig cells

desc: Hypertrophy or overdevelopment of the interstitial (Leydig) cells of the testis. These cells produce testosterone.
name: Hyperplasia of the Leydig cells

desc: The deposition of calcium phosphate microliths within the seminiferous tubules.
name: Testicular microlithiasis

desc: A testis that is located at the upper scrotum or lower inguinal canal and that can be made to descend completely into the scrotum without resistance by manual reduction but returns to its original position by the cremasteric reflex.
name: Retractile testis

desc: Formation of excess connective tissue in the testicle.
name: Testicular fibrosis

desc: A condition which is considered to be due to the subsequent atrophy and disappearance in fetal life of an initially normal testis. In the presence of spermatic cord structures is evidence of the presence of the testis in early intrauterine life. When associated with a blind-ending spermatic cord, this entity is named as his absence of a testis in an otherwise normal 46XY male is usually unilateral and is assumed to be a consequence of intrauterine or perinatal torsion or infarction.
name: Vanishing testis

desc: A collection of pus within a testicle. Ultrasonographic features include shaggy, irregular walls, intratesticular location, low-level internal echoes, and occasionally, hypervascular margins.
name: Intratesticular abscess

desc: Multiple foci of adipocytes within the testicular interstitium, usually presenting as multiple bilateral ill-defined hyperechoic intratesticular lesions of different sizes but generally with maximum diameter of 4 mm.
name: Testicular lipomatosis

desc: Having only one testis in the scrotum.
name: Monorchism

desc: An abnormality of XY sexual development characterized by the absence of both testes at birth.
name: Anorchism

desc: An abnormal bulge or lump in a testis. A testicular mass has a long differential diagnosis including testicular torsion, epididymitis, acute orchitis, strangulated hernia and testicular cancer.
name: Testicular mass

desc: An anomaly of the size of the testicle (the male gonad).
name: Abnormality of the testis size

desc: The presence of abnormally large testes.
name: Macroorchidism

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the testes.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the testes

desc: Reduced volume of the testicle (the male gonad).
name: Decreased testicular size

desc: Testis not palpable in the scrotum or inguinal canal.
name: Absent testis

desc: Testicular inflammation.
name: Orchitis

desc: Testicular torsion is when the spermatic cord to a testicle twists, cutting off the blood supply. The most common symptom is acute testicular pain.
name: Testicular torsion

desc: Penile length more than 2 SD above the mean for age.
name: Long penis

desc: Ventral, lateral, or ventrolateral bowing of the shaft and glans penis of more than 30 degrees.
name: Chordee

layperson: Partial development of the penile shaft
name: Partial development of the penile shaft

desc: Abnormally small penis. At birth, the normal penis is about 3 cm (stretched length from pubic tubercle to tip of penis) with micropenis less than 2.0-2.5 cm.
name: Micropenis

desc: Length of penis more than 2 SD below the mean for age accompanied by hypospadias.
name: Microphallus

desc: Lack of recognizable penile structures.
name: Absent penis

desc: Penile width more than 2 standard deviations (SD) below the mean for age. Alternatively circumference of the flaccid penis more than 2 SD below the mean for age. Alternatively, apparently decreased penile width for age.
name: Narrow penis

desc: Rotated position of the glans, with or without the penile shaft, of 30 degrees or more.
name: Torsion of the penis

desc: Ventral skinfold extending from penis to scrotum.
name: Webbed penis

desc: Distance between left and right side of the flaccid penis at the attachment to the skin above the pubic symphysis more than 2 standard deviations above the mean for age.
name: Wide penis

desc: Multiple pigmented macules located on the skin of the penis.
name: Penile freckling

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the urethral opening (meatus) of the penis.
name: Male urethral meatus stenosis

desc: A displacement of the external urethral orifice from its normal position (in males normally placed at the tip of glans penis, in females normally placed about 2.5 cm behind the glans clitoridis and immediately in front of that of the vagina).
name: Displacement of the urethral meatus
synonyms: Displacement of the external urethral orifice
Displacement of the male external urethral orifice

desc: Displacement of the urethral opening on the dorsal (superior) surface of the penis.
name: Epispadias

desc: Abnormal position of urethral meatus on the ventral penile shaft (underside) characterized by displacement of the urethral meatus from the tip of the glans penis to the ventral surface of the penis, scrotum, or perineum.
name: Hypospadias

desc: Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the perineal region.
name: Perineal hypospadias

desc: A severe form of hypospadias in which the urethral opening is located at the junction of the penis and scrotum.
name: Penoscrotal hypospadias

desc: Location of the urethral opening on the inferior aspect of the penis.
name: Penile hypospadias

desc: A mild form of hypospadias in which the urethra opens just under the corona glandis.
name: Coronal hypospadias

desc: Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the scrotum.
name: Scrotal hypospadias

desc: Hypospadias with location of the urethral meatus in the middle of the inferior shaft of the penis.
name: Midshaft hypospadias

desc: The male foreskin cannot be fully retracted from the head of the penis.
name: Phimosis

desc: Congenital lack of the skin of prepuce of penis, that is, of the double-layered fold of skin and mucous membrane that covers the glans penis.
name: Congenital absence of foreskin

desc: Reduction in length of the ventral (lower) skin of prepuce of penis.
name: Ventral shortening of foreskin

desc: The foreskin becomes trapped behind the glans penis, and cannot be pulled back to its normal flaccid position covering the glans penis.
name: Paraphimosis

desc: Two penile structures, separated from the tip to the base of the shaft.
name: Bifid penis

desc: A partial or complete positional exchange between the penis and the scrotum, with positioning of the scrotum superior to the penis.
name: Penoscrotal transposition

desc: Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In male pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is male (XY) and the external genitalia are imcompletely virilized, ambiguous, or complete female. If gonads are present, they are testes.
name: Male pseudohermaphroditism

layperson: Smaller than typical growth of scrotum
name: Scrotal hypoplasia
synonyms: Smaller than typical growth of scrotum

desc: Midline indentation or cleft of the scrotum.
name: Bifid scrotum

desc: Superior margin of the scrotum superior to the base of the penis.
name: Shawl scrotum

desc: Increased size of the ridge of tissue that extends along the midline of the scrotum.
name: Prominent scrotal raphe

desc: Congenital absence of the scrotum.
name: Absent scrotum

desc: Increased pigmentation (skin color) of the scrotum.
name: Scrotal hyperpigmentation

desc: Anomaly of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
name: Abnormal scrotal rugation

desc: Increased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
name: Increased scrotal rugation

desc: Decreased number or density of the folded ridges (wrinkles) of skin of the scrotum.
name: Decreased scrotal rugation

desc: A varicocele is a widening of the veins along the spermatic cord, leading to enlarged, twisted veins in the scrotum, and manifested clinically by a painless testicle lump, scrotal swelling, or bulge in the scrotum.
name: Varicocele

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the scrotum.
name: Scrotal pain

desc: Additional scrotum, or part of a scrotum in an abnormal location.
name: Accessory scrotum

desc: Scrotum in a position other than the usual position inferior to the base of the penis.
name: Ectopic scrotum

desc: Apparently small scrotum for age.
name: Small scrotum

desc: Underdevelopment of part or all of the male external reproductive organs (which include the penis, the scrotum and the urethra).
name: Hypoplastic male external genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the urethra, i.e., of the tube which connects the urinary bladder to the outside of the body.
name: Abnormality of the urethra

desc: Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra.
name: Urethral atresia

desc: Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra in males.
name: Urethral atresia, male

desc: Congenital anomaly characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra in females.
name: Urethral atresia, female

desc: Obstruction of the flow of urine through the urethra.
name: Urethral obstruction

desc: Abnormal narrowing of the urethra.
name: Urethral stenosis

desc: Narrowing of the urethra associated with inflammation or scar tissue.
name: Urethral stricture

desc: A type of urethral stricture affecting the fossa navicularis, which is the spongy part of the male urethra located at the glans penis.
name: Fossa navicularis urethral stricture

desc: A type of urethral stricture affecting the pendulous urethra, which is straight and fixed to the corpora cavernosa.
name: Pendulous urethral stricture

desc: A type of urethral stricture affecting the bulbar urethra, which is the part of the urethra that traverses the root of the penis.
name: Bulbar urethral stricture

desc: The presence of an abnormal membrane obstructing the urethra.
name: Urethral valve

desc: A developmental defect resulting in an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra.
name: Congenital posterior urethral valve

desc: The presence of a diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urethra.
name: Urethral diverticulum

desc: The presence of an abnormal connection between the urethra and another organ or the skin.
name: Urethral fistula

desc: The presence of a fistula between the vagina and the urethra.
name: Urethrovaginal fistula

desc: An abnormal connection (fistula) between the rectum and the urethra.
name: Rectourethral fistula

desc: Urethra more open or expanded than normal.
name: Patulous urethra

desc: Dilation and elongation of the penile urethra associated with absence or hypoplasia of the corpora spongiosa and cavernosa.
name: Congenital megalourethra

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the urethra.
name: Neoplasm of the urethra

desc: A rare birth defect in women where the urethra and vagina both open into a common channel.
name: Urogenital sinus anomaly

desc: The prolapse of the female urethra into the vagina.
name: Urethrocele

desc: Inflammation of the urethra.
name: Urethritis

desc: The presence of female external genitalia in a person with a male karyotype.
layperson: Female external genitalia in individual with 46,XY karyotype
name: Female external genitalia in individual with 46,XY karyotype

desc: Lack of external genitalia in a male or female individual.
name: Absent external genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the female external genitalia.
name: Abnormality of female external genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the clitoris.
name: Abnormality of the clitoris

desc: Two clitorides located side by side.
name: Bifid clitoris

desc: Supernumerary clitoris.
name: Duplicated clitoris

desc: Hypertrophy of the clitoris.
name: Clitoral hypertrophy

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the clitoris.
name: Clitoral hypoplasia

desc: An anomaly of the labia, the externally visible portions of the vulva.
name: Abnormality of the labia

desc: Increase in size of the folds of skin between the outer labia.
name: Enlarged labia minora

desc: Undergrowth of the outer labia.
name: Hypoplastic labia majora

desc: An anomaly of the labia minora, the folds of skin between the outer labia.
layperson: Abnormality of the inner vaginal lips
name: Abnormality of the labia minora
synonyms: Abnormality of the inner vaginal lips

desc: Fusion of the labia minora as a result of labial adhesions resulting in vaginal obstruction.
name: Fused labia minora

desc: An anomaly of the outer labia.
name: Abnormality of the labia majora

desc: Overgrowth of the outer labia.
name: Hyperplastic labia majora

desc: The outer labia are sealed together.
name: Fused labia majora

desc: Marked rugae formation of the skin of the labia majora.
layperson: Exaggerated rugosity of the labia majora
name: Exaggerated rugosity of the labia majora

desc: Ambiguous genitalia in an individual with XX genetic gender.
name: Ambiguous genitalia, female

desc: Hermaphroditism refers to a discrepancy between the morphology of the gonads and that of the external genitalia. In female pseudohermaphroditism, the genotype is female (XX) and the gonads are ovaries, but the external genitalia are virilized.
name: Female pseudohermaphroditism

desc: Underdevelopment of part or all of the female external reproductive organs (which include the mons pubis, labia majora, labia minora, Bartholin glands, and clitoris).
name: Hypoplastic female external genitalia

desc: Varicosity of veins in the vulval region.
name: Vulval varicose vein

desc: A genital phenotype that is not clearly assignable to a single gender. Ambiguous genitalia can be evaluated using the Prader scale: Prader 0: Normal female external genitalia. Prader 1: Female external genitalia with clitoromegaly. Prader 2: Clitoromegaly with partial labial fusion forming a funnel-shaped urogenital sinus. Prader 3: Increased phallic enlargement. Complete labioscrotal fusion forming a urogenital sinus with a single opening. Prader 4: Complete scrotal fusion with urogenital opening at the base or on the shaft of the phallus. Prader 5: Normal male external genitalia. The diagnosis of ambiguous genitalia is made for Prader 1-4.
name: Ambiguous genitalia

layperson: Gonadal tissue inappropriate for external genitalia or chromosomal sex
name: Gonadal tissue inappropriate for external genitalia or chromosomal sex

desc: The presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues either in the same or in opposite gonads. Affected persons have ambiguous genitalia and may have 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes or 46,XX/XY mosaicism.
name: True hermaphroditism

desc: A gonad that contains both ovarian follicles and testicular tubular elements.
name: Ovotestis

desc: Underdevelopment of part or all of the external reproductive organs.
name: External genital hypoplasia

desc: An abnormal pigmentation pattern of the external genitalia.
name: Abnormal genital pigmentation

desc: One or more brown punctate macules on the skin of the genitalia.
name: Freckled genitalia

desc: Localized or generalized increased genital pigmentation.
name: Hyperpigmented genitalia

desc: Localized or generalized decreased genital pigmentation.
name: Hypopigmented genitalia

desc: An anomaly of the adnexa, uterus, and vagina (in female) or seminal tract and prostate (in male).
name: Abnormal internal genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the female internal genitalia.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of female internal genitalia
name: Abnormal morphology of female internal genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the uterus.
name: Abnormality of the uterus

desc: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the uterus.
name: Aplasia/hypoplasia of the uterus

desc: Underdevelopment of the uterus.
name: Hypoplasia of the uterus

desc: Aplasia of the uterus.
name: Aplasia of the uterus

desc: An anomaly of the neck of the uterus (lower part of the uterus), called the uterine cervix.
name: Abnormality of the uterine cervix

desc: Congenital absence of the cervix.
name: Cervical agenesis

desc: A cervix that shows a painless dilation and shortening during the second trimester of pregnancy with resultant recurrent pregnancy loss or delivery is considered incompetent
name: Cervical insufficiency

desc: Cervical ectropion occurs when eversion of the endocervix exposes columnar epithelium to the vaginal milieu
name: Cervical ectropion

desc: Abnormal growth of tissue projecting from a mucous membrane of the endocervix.
name: Cervical polyp

desc: Inflammation of the uterine cervix.
name: Cervicitis

desc: Cervical dysplasia is the precursor to cervical cancer. It is caused by the persistent infection of the human papillomavirus (HPV) into the cervical tissue. Affected cells develop morphologic features with immature basaloid- type squamous cells and mitotic figures in the upper half of the cervical epithelium.
name: Cervical dysplasia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the uterine cervix.
name: Cervical neoplasm

desc: A precancerous condition characterized by dysplasia of the cervical epithelium. Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 1, 2 and 3 based on its relationship with the prognosis. CIN 1 is mild dysplasia, which is mostly observed because it disappears as part of its natural course. CIN 3 includes severe dysplasia and carcinoma in situ, and management involves treatment because it is highly likely to develop into invasive cancer.
name: Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the uterus
name: Abnormal uterus morphology

desc: The presence of a bifid uterus.
name: Bifid uterus

desc: The presence of prolapse of the uterus.
name: Uterine prolapse

desc: The presence of a bicornuate uterus.
name: Bicornuate uterus

desc: A malformation of the uterus in which the uterus is present as a paired organ as a result of the failure of fusion of the mullerian ducts during embryogenesis.
name: Uterus didelphys

desc: An anomaly of the inner mucous membrane of the uterus.
name: Abnormality of the endometrium

desc: Inflammation of the inner lining of the uterus (endometrium).
name: Endometritis
synonyms: Inflammation of the inner lining of the uterus

desc: Adhesions or scar tissue that form inside the cavity of the uterus.
name: Uterine synechiae

desc: An abnormality of the uterus characterized by a normal uterine outline but with an abnormal T-shaped uterine cavity with narrowing cavity due to thickened lateral walls with a correlation 2/3 uterine corpus and 1/3 cervix. The abnormlaity is said to resemble the letter T in hysterosalpingographic imaging.
name: T-shaped uterus

desc: A uterus that has a single horn, with a banana-like shape that may or may not have a secondary rudimentary uterine horn.
name: Unicornuate uterus

desc: An abnormality of the ovary.
name: Abnormality of the ovary

desc: The presence of one or more cysts of the ovary.
name: Ovarian cyst

desc: An abdominal mass formed by bleeding into a follicular ovarian cyst or corpus luteum cyst.
name: Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst

desc: A cystic tumor of the ovary, containing thin, clear, yellow serous fluid and varying amounts of solid tissue.
name: Ovarian serous cystadenoma

desc: A cyst of the ovary that exhibits deposition of calcium salts.
name: Calcified ovarian cyst

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ovary.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the ovary

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the ovary.
name: Hypoplasia of the ovary

desc: A developmental disorder characterized by the progressive loss of primordial germ cells in the developing ovaries of an embryo, leading to hypoplastic ovaries composed of wavy connective tissue with occasional clumps of granulosa cells, and frequently mesonephric or hilar cells.
name: Streak ovary

desc: Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the ovary.
name: Aplasia of the ovary

desc: Undescended or ectopic ovaries are characterized by the attachment of the upper pole of the ovary to an area above the level of the common iliac vessels.
name: Ectopic ovary

desc: An inflammation of the ovary or ovaries.
name: Oophoritis

desc: Any structural abnormality of the vagina.
name: Abnormal vagina morphology

desc: Congenital occlusion of the vagina or adhesion of the walls of the vagina causing occlusion.
name: Vaginal atresia

desc: The presence of a vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication. The septum is longitudinal in the majority of cases.
name: Septate vagina

desc: The presence of a longitudinal vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication.
name: Longitudinal vaginal septum

desc: The presence of a fistula of the vagina.
name: Vaginal fistula

desc: The presence of a fistula between the vagina and the rectum.
layperson: Abnormal connection between rectum and vagina
name: Rectovaginal fistula
synonyms: Abnormal connection between rectum and vagina

desc: The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to the vagina.
name: Vesicovaginal fistula

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the vagina.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the vagina

desc: Aplasia of the vagina.
name: Aplasia of the vagina

desc: A failure to develop of the upper vagina.
name: Aplasia of the upper vagina

desc: A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina.
name: Aplasia of the lower vagina

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the vagina.
name: Hypoplasia of the vagina

desc: A narrowing of the vagina owing to scar formation.
name: Vaginal stricture

desc: Vaginal adenosis is defined by the presence of metaplastic cervical or endometrial epithelium within the vaginal wall, thought to be derived from persistent MÃ¼llerian (synonymous with paramesonephric) epithelium islets in postembryonic life.
name: Vaginal adenosis

desc: Hydrometrocolpos is an accumulation of uterine and vaginal secretions as well as menstrual blood in the uterus and vagina.
name: Hydrometrocolpos

desc: A congenital disorder where the hymen (a membrane that surrounds or partially covers the external vaginal opening) does not have an opening and completely obstructs the vagina.
name: Imperforate hymen

desc: A sensation of itching in the vagina.
name: Vaginal pruritus

desc: Inflammation of the vagina that can result from a spectrum of conditions that cause vaginal and sometimes vulvar symptoms, such as itching, burning, irritation, odor, and vaginal discharge.
name: Vaginitis

desc: Distention of the vagina caused by accumulation of fluid due to congenital vaginal obstruction.
name: Hydrocolpos

desc: Persistent vaginal dryness.
name: Vaginal dryness

desc: Accumulation of blood in the vagina usually due to vaginal obstruction.
name: Hematocolpos

desc: The vagina ends in a blind pouch or sac rather than being connected to the internal genitalia.
name: Blind vagina

desc: The presence of a hernia of the vagina.
name: Vaginal hernia

desc: Anterior vaginal wall prolapse with bulging of the bladder into the vagina.
name: Cystocele

desc: A Rectocele results from a tear in the rectovaginal septum (which is normally a tough, fibrous, sheet-like divider between the rectum and vagina). Rectal tissue bulges through this tear and into the vagina as a hernia. There are two main causes of this tear: childbirth, and hysterectomy.
name: Rectocele

desc: An abnormality of the fallopian tube.
name: Abnormal fallopian tube morphology

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the fallopian tube.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the fallopian tube

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the fallopian tube.
name: Hypoplasia of the fallopian tube

desc: Aplasia, that is failure to develop, of the fallopian tube.
name: Aplasia of the fallopian tube

desc: A fluid filled sac located in the Fallopian tube.
name: Fallopian tube cyst

desc: A twisting of the Fallopian tube. Sudden onset with sharp, colicky pelvic pain associated with nausea, vomiting, bowel, and bladder symptoms is the usual presentation.
name: Fallopian tube torsion

desc: The presence of a supernumerary Fallopian tube.
name: Fallopian tube duplication

desc: An abnormality of the male internal genitalia.
name: Abnormality of male internal genitalia

desc: An abnormality of the prostate.
name: Abnormal prostate morphology

desc: The presence of inflammation of the prostate.
name: Prostatitis

desc: The presence of non-malignant hyperplasia of the prostate.
name: Benign prostatic hyperplasia

desc: A lump detected in the prostate. In this context, mass is a general term for a lump or growth that may be caused by the abnormal growth of cells, a cyst, hormonal changes, or an immune reaction.
name: Prostate mass

desc: An abnormality of the epididymis.
name: Abnormality of the epididymis

desc: The presence of inflammation of the epididymis.
name: Epididymitis

desc: A smooth, extratesticular, spherical cyst in the head of the epididymis.
name: Epididymal cyst

desc: A structural anomaly of the secretory duct of the testicle that carries spermatozoa from the epididymis to the prostatic urethra where it terminates to form ejaculatory duct.
name: Abnormal vas deferens morphology

desc: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the vas deferens.
name: Absent vas deferens
synonyms: Congenital absence of the vas deferens

desc: Abnormal closure or blockage of the vas deferens.
name: Atretic vas deferens

desc: Unusual gonadal development in a person with a 46,XY male karyotype, leading to an unassigned sex differentiation.
name: Gonadal dysgenesis, male

desc: Unusual gonadal development in a person with a 46,XY male karyotype, leading to a more female sex differentiation.
layperson: Gonadal dysgenesis with female appearance, male
name: Gonadal dysgenesis with female appearance, male

desc: Absence of sex glands (gonads are the organs that produce gametes; testis in males and ovary in females).
name: Agonadism

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in gonadal tissue.
name: Gonadal calcification

desc: Joining of the spleen and a gonad during embryological development.
name: Splenogonadal fusion

desc: Congenital occlusion of a tube in the genital tract.
name: Genital tract atresia

desc: Abnormality of the female genital system.
name: Abnormality of the female genitalia

desc: Abnormality of the male genital system.
name: Abnormality of the male genitalia

desc: Anomaly of primary or secondary sexual development or characteristics.
name: Abnormal sex determination

desc: Development of the reproductive system is inconsistent with the chromosomal sex.
name: Sex reversal

desc: Any structural anomaly of a reproductive cell.
name: Abnormal germ cell morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of a reproductive cell

desc: A structural anomaly of a male reproductive cell.
name: Abnormal male germ cell morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of sperm.
name: Abnormal sperm morphology

desc: A structural abnormality of the sperm head.
name: Sperm head anomaly

desc: Any structural anomaly of the acrosome resulting in a round sperm head.
name: Globozoospermia

desc: Spermatozoa with very small cranial ends devoid of any nuclear material, that is, lacking a typical sperm head.
name: Acephalic spermatozoa

desc: Increased size of the head of sperm.
name: Macrocephalic sperm head

desc: A reduced amount of the enzyme acrosin in the sperm head acrosome. The acrosome is an organelle in the anterior half of the head of spermatozoa, and acrosin is a protease that contributes to the digestation of the zona pellucida in the fertilization process.
name: Decreased acrosin in sperm head

desc: Decreased size of the head of sperm.
name: Microcephalic sperm head

desc: Sperm with cigar-shaped heads that gradually dimish in diameter (taper).
name: Tapered sperm head

desc: A structural abnormality of the sperm neck.
name: Sperm neck anomaly

desc: A structural abnormality of the sperm mid-piece.
name: Sperm mid-piece anomaly

desc: A structural abnormality of the sperm tail.
name: Sperm tail anomaly

desc: Sperm cells lacking flagella.
name: Absent sperm flagella

desc: Sperm cells with abnormally short flagella.
name: Short sperm flagella

desc: Sperm cells whose flagella are twisted (coiled).
name: Coiled sperm flagella

desc: Any anomaly of meiosis, a type of cell division that reduces the number of chromosomes in the parent cell by half and produces four gamete cells.
name: Abnormal meiosis

desc: Failure of oocytes to proceed through the stages of meiosis with stoppage at the first metaphase stage.
name: Oocyte arrest at metaphase I

desc: An abnormality of the urinary system.
name: Abnormality of the urinary system

desc: Congenital absence of the normal opening of a structure of the urinary tract.
name: Urinary tract atresia

desc: An abnormality of the upper urinary tract.
layperson: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract
name: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract
synonyms: Abnormality of the upper urinary tract

desc: An abnormality of the ureter. The ureter is the duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder.
name: Abnormality of the ureter

desc: A structural abnormality of the ureter. The ureter is the duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder.
name: Abnormal ureter morphology

desc: A ureterocele is a congenital saccular dilatation of the distal segment of the ureter.
name: Ureterocele

desc: The distention of the ureter with urine.
name: Hydroureter

desc: A developmental anomaly characterized by the presence of two, instead of one, ureter connecting a kidney to the bladder.
name: Ureteral duplication

desc: A partial duplication of the ureter where the duplicated ureters fuse to a single ureter before their insertion into the bladder.
name: Ureter fissus

desc: A complete duplication of the ureter, where the duplicated ureters have separate insertions into the bladder.
name: Ureter duplex

desc: Incomplete duplication of the ureter.
name: Bifid ureter

desc: A developmental defect defined by the failure of the formation of the lumen (tube) of the ureter.
name: Ureteral atresia

desc: A developmental anomaly of the ureter.
name: Ureteral dysgenesis

desc: A developmental disturbance with extreme ureteral dilatation.
name: Congenital megaureter

desc: Failure of the ureter to undergo development.
name: Ureteral agenesis

desc: Underdevelopment of the ureter.
name: Ureteral hypoplasia

desc: A functional abnormality of the ureter. The ureter is the duct by which urine passes from the kidney to the bladder.
name: Abnormal ureter physiology

desc: Abnormal (retrograde) movement of urine from the bladder into ureters or kidneys related to inadequacy of the valvular mechanism at the ureterovesicular junction or other causes.
name: Vesicoureteral reflux

desc: Obstruction of the flow of urine through the ureter.
name: Ureteral obstruction

desc: The presence of a stenotic, i.e., constricted ureter.
name: Ureteral stenosis

desc: Blockage of urine flow from the renal pelvis to the proximal ureter.
name: Ureteropelvic junction obstruction

desc: Blockage at the level of the bladder and the ureter caused by stenosis of the ureteral valves or failure of a narrow juxtavesical ureteral segment to dilate due to segmented fibrosis or localized absence of muscle.
name: Ureterovesical junction obstruction

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the ureter.
name: Neoplasm of the ureter

desc: A growth protruding from the mucous membrane of the ureter. Ureteral polyps can be attached to the ureter by a broad base or a thin stalk.
name: Ureteral polyp

desc: An abnormality of the kidney.
name: Abnormality of the kidney

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the kidney.
name: Renal neoplasm

desc: A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
layperson: Cancer starting in small tubes in kidneys
name: Renal cell carcinoma
synonyms: Cancer starting in small tubes in kidneys

desc: The presence of renal cell carcinoma in the renal papilla.
name: Papillary renal cell carcinoma

desc: A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma in which the papillae are covered by large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and nuclear pseudostratification.
name: Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2

desc: A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma that is characterized by small cuboidal cells covering thin papillae with a single line of uniform nuclei and small nucleoli.
name: Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1

desc: A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron.
name: Clear cell renal cell carcinoma

desc: The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney.
name: Renal cortical adenoma

desc: The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis.
name: Renal pelvic carcinoma

desc: A sarcoma of the kidney.
name: Renal sarcoma

desc: A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that are native to the kidneys.
name: Renal hamartoma

desc: A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements.
name: Renal angiomyolipoma

desc: The presence of an embryonal neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children.
name: Embryonal renal neoplasm

desc: The presence of a nephroblastoma, which is a neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children.
name: Nephroblastoma

desc: Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney. Nephroblastomatosis represents a complex abnormality of nephrogenesis and has been defined as the persistence of metanephricblastema into infancy and childhood.
name: Nephroblastomatosis

desc: Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney, anywhere within a renal lobe (a portion of a kidney consisting of a renal pyramid and the renal cortex above it).
name: Intralobar nephroblastomatosis

desc: Abnormally persistent foci of embryonal immature blastema located in the superficial cortical region (perilobar).
name: Perilobar nephroblastomatosis

desc: Congenital mesoblastic nephroma is a type of kidney tumor that is usually found before birth by ultrasound or within the first 3 months of life. It contains fibroblastic cells (connective tissue cells), and may spread to the other kidney or to nearby tissue.
name: Congenital mesoblastic nephroma

desc: A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm.
name: Renal oncocytoma

desc: A malignant tumor that arises from the transitional (urothelial) epithelial cells lining the urinary tract from the renal calyces to the ureteral orifice.
name: Renal transitional cell carcinoma

desc: Any structural anomaly of the kidney.
name: Abnormal renal morphology
synonyms: Structural anomalies of the renal tract

desc: A congenital anomaly of the urinary tract, in which the kidney is duplicated and is drained via two separate renal pelves and ureters.
name: Renal duplication

desc: A duplication of the renal pelvis.
name: Duplication of renal pelvis

desc: The presence of a partially duplicated kidney.
name: Partially duplicated kidney

desc: An abnormal increase in the size of the kidney.
name: Enlarged kidney

desc: A fluid filled sac in the kidney.
name: Renal cyst

desc: Multicystic dysplasia of the kidney is characterized by multiple cysts of varying size in the kidney and the absence of a normal pelvicaliceal system. The condition is associated with ureteral or ureteropelvic atresia, and the affected kidney is nonfunctional.
name: Multicystic kidney dysplasia

desc: The presence of multiple cysts at the border between the renal cortex and medulla.
name: Renal corticomedullary cysts

desc: The presence of multiple cysts in both kidneys.
name: Polycystic kidney dysplasia

desc: Cysts of the cortex of the kidney.
name: Renal cortical cysts

desc: Cysts of microscopic size confined to the cortex of the kidney.
name: Renal cortical microcysts

desc: The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
name: Multiple renal cysts

desc: The presence of many cysts in the medulla of the kidney.
name: Multiple small medullary renal cysts

desc: An isolated cyst of the kidney.
name: Solitary renal cyst

desc: A renal cyst characterized by epithelium lined space (squamous/columnar) with septations.
name: Complex renal cyst

desc: Tubular lumnal dilatation/prominence lined by simple layer of cuboidal-to-flat tublar epihelial cells.
name: Renal tubular cyst

desc: Cystic, urine-containing intrarenal cavities lined with transitional cell epithelium that communicate through a narrow channel with the collecting system.
name: Renal diverticulum

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
name: Renal dysplasia

desc: A unilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
name: Unilateral renal dysplasia

desc: A bilateral form of developmental dysplasia of the kidney.
name: Bilateral renal dysplasia

desc: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium salts in renal parenchyma.
layperson: Too much calcium deposited in kidneys
name: Nephrocalcinosis
synonyms: Too much calcium deposited in kidneys

desc: The presence of microscopic crystalline calcium precipitates in the form of oxalate and/or phosphate in the renal parenchyma.
name: Microscopic nephrocalcinosis

desc: The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal medulla (innermost part of the kidney).
name: Medullary nephrocalcinosis

desc: The deposition of calcium salts in the parenchyma of the renal cortex (the outer portion of the kidney between the renal capsule and the renal medulla).
name: Cortical nephrocalcinosis

desc: The presence of calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Nephrolithiasis

desc: The presence of uric acid-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Uric acid nephrolithiasis

layperson: Uric acid urolithiasis independent of gout
name: Uric acid urolithiasis independent of gout

desc: The presence of xanthine-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Xanthine nephrolithiasis

desc: The presence of calcium-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Calcium nephrolithiasis

desc: The presence of calcium- and oxalate-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis

desc: The presence of calcium- and phosphate-containing calculi (stones) in the kidneys.
name: Calcium phosphate nephrolithiasis

desc: Presence of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) containing calculi (kidney stones).
name: Struvite nephrolithiasis

desc: Abnormal fat accumulation in the kidneys.
name: Renal steatosis

desc: A form of amyloidosis that affects the kidney. On hematoxylin and eosin stain, amyloid is identified as extracellular amorphous material that is lightly eosinophilic. These deposits often stain weakly for periodic acid Schiff (PAS), demonstrate a blue-to-gray hue on the trichrome stain and are typically negative on the Jones methenamine silver (JMS) stain. These tinctorial properties contrast with the histologic appearance of collagen, a major component of basement membranes, mesangial matrix and areas of sclerosis, which demonstrates strong positivity for PAS and JMS (See Figure 1 of PMID:25852856).
name: Renal amyloidosis

desc: Deposition of amyloid in the interstitial tissue of the kidney. Amyloid is is made up of 10 nm (on average) fibrils that are most commonly composed of monoclonal light chains (AL), transthyretin (TTR), amd LECT2, or occur in the setting of long standing systemic inflammation.
name: Renal interstitial amyloid deposits

desc: Amyloid deposits located in the glomeruli in a focal segmental, diffuse segmental or diffuse global fashion. This abnormality can be accompanied by mesangial involvement and in later stages also involvement of the peripheral capillaries.
name: Renal glomerular amyloid deposition

desc: An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal orientation of the kidney.
name: Renal malrotation

desc: An abnormality of the normal developmental rotation of the kidney leading to an abnormal axial orientation of the kidney.
name: Axial malrotation of the kidney

desc: An increase in amplitude of waves returned in ultrasonography of the kidney, which is generally displayed as increased brightness of the signal.
name: Hyperechogenic kidneys
synonyms: Increased echogenicity of the renal parenchyma

desc: An abnormality of the renal collecting system.
name: Abnormal renal collecting system morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the renal collecting system

desc: A duplication of the collecting system of the kidney, defined as a kidney with two (instead of, normally, one) pyelocaliceal systems. The pyelocaliceal system is comprised of the renal pelvis and calices. The duplicated renal collecting system can be associated with a single ureter or with double ureters. In the latter case, the two ureters empty separately into the bladder or fuse to form a single ureteral orifice.
name: Duplicated collecting system
synonyms: Double urinary collecting systems on intravenous pyelography

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the kidney.
name: Renal hypoplasia/aplasia

desc: Hypoplasia of the kidney.
name: Renal hypoplasia

desc: One sided hypoplasia of the kidney.
name: Unilateral renal hypoplasia

desc: Two sided hypoplasia of the kidney.
name: Bilateral renal hypoplasia

desc: Agenesis, that is, failure of the kidney to develop during embryogenesis and development.
name: Renal agenesis

desc: A unilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.
name: Unilateral renal agenesis

desc: A bilateral form of agenesis of the kidney.
name: Bilateral renal agenesis

desc: Any structural abnormality of the renal artery.
name: Abnormal renal artery morphology

desc: The presence of stenosis of the renal artery.
name: Renal artery stenosis

desc: An atherosclerotic lesion located in the renal artery.
name: Renal artery atherosclerosis

desc: The renal arteries carry blood from the aorta to the kidney; normally one renal artery is present on each side of the body. Renal artery duplication refers to the presence of two rather than one renal artery on a given side of the body.
name: Renal artery duplication

desc: Nephrosclerosis refers to thickening or scarring ("sclerosis") resulting from damage to the renal arterioles, also referred to as arteriosclerosis of the kidney arteries.
name: Nephrosclerosis

desc: An abnormality of the renal pelvis.
name: Abnormal renal pelvis morphology

desc: Mild pyelectasis is defined as a hypoechoic spherical or elliptical space within the renal pelvis that measures at least 5mm and not more than 10 mm. The measurement is taken on a transverse section through the fetal renal pelvis using the maximum anterior-to-posterior measurement.
name: Fetal pyelectasis

desc: A bilateral form of fetal pyelectasis.
name: Bilateral fetal pyelectasis

desc: The presence of dilatation of the renal pelvis.
name: Dilatation of the renal pelvis

desc: Severe distention of the kidney with dilation of the renal pelvis and calices.
name: Hydronephrosis

desc: An abnormality of the cortex of the kidney.
name: Abnormal renal cortex morphology

desc: Atrophy of the cortex of the kidney.
name: Renal cortical atrophy

desc: An abnormality of corticomedullary differentiation (CMD) on diagnostic imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging, computer tomography, or sonography. CMD is a difference in the visualization of cortex and medulla.
name: Abnormal renal corticomedullary differentiation

desc: A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
name: Absence of renal corticomedullary differentiation

desc: Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
name: Reduced renal corticomedullary differentiation
synonyms: Loss of definition of corticomedullary differentiation

desc: Patchy or diffuse ischemic destruction of all the elements of renal cortex resulting from significantly diminished renal arterial perfusion. Coagulative necrosis may be present, involving all tubular segments and glomeruli. Nuclei may be pale and pyknotic, or may no longer be apparent. Thrombi may be present in vessels at the edge of the infarct.
name: Renal cortical necrosis

desc: Any anomolous structure of the renal corpuscle, which is the initial component of the nephron that filters blood. The renal corpuscle consists of a knot of capillaries (glomerulus) that is surrounded by a double-walled capsule (Bowman capsule) that opens into a renal tubule.
name: Abnormal renal corpuscle morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of the glomerulus.
name: Abnormality of renal glomerulus morphology

desc: Accumulation of scar tissue within the glomerulus.
name: Glomerulosclerosis

desc: Segmental accumulation of scar tissue in individual (but not all) glomeruli.
name: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

desc: Complete and diffuse scarring of glomerulus.
name: Global glomerulosclerosis

desc: Inflammation of the renal glomeruli.
name: Glomerulonephritis

desc: A type of glomerulonephritis characterized by diffuse mesangial cell proliferation and the thickening of capillary walls due to subendothelial extension of the mesangium. The term membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is often employed to denote a general pattern of glomerular injury seen in a variety of disease processes that share a common pathogenetic mechanism, rather than to describe a single disease entity
name: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

desc: A type of extracapillary glomerulonephritis characterized by the formation of crescent-like cellular proliferation.
name: Crescentic glomerulonephritis

desc: A type of glomerulonephropathy characterized by thickening of the basement membrane and deposition of immune complexes in the subepithelial space.
name: Membranous nephropathy

desc: The presence of minimal changes visible by light microscopy but flattened and fused podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy in a person with nephrotic range proteinuria.
name: Minimal change glomerulonephritis

desc: Increased number and size of the juxtaglomerular cells.
name: Renal juxtaglomerular cell hypertrophy/hyperplasia

desc: An abnormality of the mesangium, i.e., of the central part of the renal glomerulus between capillaries.
name: Mesangial abnormality

desc: Diffuse sclerosis of the mesangium, as manifestated by diffuse mesangial matrix expansion.
name: Diffuse mesangial sclerosis

desc: Increased numbers of mesangial cells per glomerulus, defined as four or more nuclei in a peripheral mesangial segment.
name: Mesangial hypercellularity

desc: Dissolution or attenuation of mesangial matrix and degeneration of mesangial cells. In essence, mesangiolysis is an injurious process which affects the glomerular mesangium without causing obvious damage to the capillary basement membranes. The matrix swells, loosens, and eventually dissolves; the mesangial cells may show only edema and vacuolization, or may undergo severe degeneration and necrosis.
name: Mesangiolysis

desc: Increase in thickness of the basal lamina of the glomerulus of the kidney.
layperson: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane
name: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane

desc: Reduction in thickness of the basal lamina of the glomerulus of the kidney.
name: Thin glomerular basement membrane

desc: A structural anomaly of the capillary blood vessels in the renal glomerulus.
name: Abnormal glomerular capillary morphology

desc: Widening of the wall of capillary blood vessels in the glomerulus. This feature may be produced by deposits and other changes affecting either subepithelial and subendothelial regions or the glomerular basement membrane itself.
name: Thickening of glomerular capillary wall

desc: Hypercellularity due to increased number of cells within glomerular capillary lumina, causing narrowing of the lumina.
name: Endocapillary hypercellularity

desc: Hypercellularity (increased number of cells) in the renal glomerulus but external to the glomerular capillaries, i.e., in the Bowman space or more than one layer of parietal or visceral epithelial cells.
name: Extracapillary hypercellularity

desc: Presence of abnormal additional layers of the basement membrane of the glomerulus.
name: Diffuse glomerular basement membrane lamellation
synonyms: Diffuse lamellation of the glomerular basement membrane

desc: Abnormally large size of glomeruli.
name: Glomerulomegaly

desc: An abnormal accumulation of protein in the glomerulus.
name: Glomerular deposits

desc: The presence of immunoglobulin A deposits in the glomerulus.
name: IgA deposition in the glomerulus

desc: Electron dense deposits at the glomerular basement membrane,
name: Glomerular subendothelial electron-dense deposits

desc: The presence of complement 3 deposits in the glomerulus.
name: Glomerular C3 deposition

desc: Periglomerular fibrosis is defined as glomeruli with open capillaries, but lamellated, frequently wrinkled, Bowman capsular basement membrane and circumferential layers of interstitial-type collagen around, within, or between the usually thickened, frequently lamellated, Bowman capsule basement membrane.
name: Periglomerular fibrosis

desc: The presence of many cysts in the glomerulus of the kidney related to dilatation of the Bowman's capsule.
name: Multiple glomerular cysts

desc: Inflammatory or noninflammatory diseases affecting the glomeruli of the nephron.
name: Glomerulopathy

desc: A structural anomaly of the double-walled capsule (Bowman capsule) that opens into a renal tubule.
name: Abnormal morphology of Bowman capsule

desc: Any structural anomaly of the podocyte, which is a highly specialized cell of the Bowman capsule and which forms multiple interdigitating foot processes. Podocytes are interconnected by slit diaphragms and cover the exterior basement membrane surface of the glomerular capillary.
name: Abnormal podocyte morphology

desc: Increase in size of the podocytes of the renal glomerulus.
name: Podocyte hypertrophy

desc: An anomaly of podocyte morphology characterized by the loss of the interdigitating foot process pattern (generally called foot process effacement; FPE). The term FPE designates the loss of the usual interdigitating pattern of foot processes of neighboring podocytes, leading to relatively broad expanses of podocyte processes covering the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). It is widely viewed as a pathological derangement that is associated with leakage of macromolecules such as albumin through the glomerular filtration barrier.
name: Podocyte foot process effacement

desc: The presence of cuboidal to columnar epithelium (height greater than width) lining the Bowman capsule, in an absence of adjacent segmental sclerosis, crescents, or collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; scored as present or absent in at least one glomerulus.
name: Tubularization of Bowman capsule

desc: Any abnormality of the morphology of the major calices or minor calices of the kidney.
name: Abnormal renal calyx morphology

desc: An abnormal polygonal shape of the calices of the kidney (which normally have a rounded or cup-shaped appearance).
name: Polygonal renal calices

desc: Increased number of calices of the kidney.
name: Polycalycosis

desc: An abnormal enlargement of the renal calices, the system of ducts of the kidney that collect urine.
name: Dilatation of renal calices

desc: A structural anomaly of the nephron.
name: Abnormal nephron morphology

desc: An abnormality of the renal tubules.
name: Abnormal renal tubule morphology
synonyms: Morphologic abnormality of the renal tubules

desc: An abnormality that involves the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney.
name: Abnormal tubulointerstitial morphology

desc: A form of inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
name: Tubulointerstitial nephritis

desc: Acute inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
name: Acute tubulointerstitial nephritis

desc: Chronic inflammation of the kidney affecting the interstitium of the kidneys surrounding the tubules.
name: Chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis

desc: A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
name: Tubulointerstitial fibrosis

desc: Infiltration of microorganisms into renal tubulointerstitial tissues as observed by appropriate staining procedures, e.g., bacteria on a bacterial stain (Brown and Hopps) or fungi on PAS or silver stain.
name: Tubulointerstitial microganismal infiltration

desc: Tubulointerstitial infiltration of bacteria identified on routine and/or special (Brown-Hopps) stains.
name: Tubulointerstitial bacterial infiltration

desc: Tubulointerstitial infiltration of yeast or hyphal-microrganisms identified on routine and/or special (PAS, silver) stains.
name: Tubulointerstitial fungal infiltration

desc: Renal tubulointerstitial infiltration of mycobacteria identified on acid-fast or Fite stains. Can be associated with granulomatous inflammation.
name: Tubulointerstitial mycobacterial infiltration

desc: Infiltration of viruses into renal tubulointerstitial tissues as demonstrated on renal biopsy by viral inclusions which can be seen on routine stains or with immunohistochemistry.
name: Tubulointerstitial viral infiltration

desc: A developmental defect characterized by absence or poor development of proximal renal tubules.
name: Renotubular dysgenesis

desc: Coagulative necrosis of tubular epithelial cells, defined as cells with increased cytoplasmic eosinophilia and nucleus that has a condensed chromatin pattern with fuzzy nuclear contour or has barely visible nuclear basophilic staining. The extent of cortical tubular necrosis is scoredsemiquantitatively as none, mild (less than 25% tubules with necrosis), moderate (25-50 percent), and severe (over 50%).
name: Renal tubular epithelial necrosis

desc: Abnormal structure of the basement membrane of the renal tubulus.
name: Abnormal tubular basement membrane morphology

desc: DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney.
name: Tubular basement membrane disintegration
synonyms: Disintegration of the tubular basement membrane

desc: Increase in thickness of the basement membrane of the tubulus of the kidney.
layperson: Thickening of the tubular basement membrane
name: Thickening of the tubular basement membrane

desc: Naked basement membranes without tubular epithelium.
name: Renal tubular basement membrane denudation

desc: Infiltration of the renal tubular epithelium by lymphocytes.
name: Renal lymphocytic tubulitis

desc: Infiltration of the renal tubular epithelium by neutrophils.
name: Renal neutrophilic tubulitis

desc: Any structural anomaly of the renal tubular epithelial cells (RTEC), a layer of cells in the outer layer of the renal tubule. These cells play a role in the absorption of substances such as glucose and amino from the primary urine.
name: Abnormal renal tubular epithelial morphology

desc: The presence of renal tubules with thick redundant basement membranes, or a reduction of greater than 50% in tubular diameter compared to surrounding non-atrophic tubules.
name: Renal tubular atrophy

desc: A type of renal tubular atrophy characterized by a thyroid-like appearance, with small round tubules with markedly flattened, simplified epithelium and uniform intratubular casts.
name: Thyroidization-type tubular atrophy

desc: A type of renal tubular atrophy characterized by endocrine-like appearance of tubules, which are small and have narrow lumina, clear cells, and relatively thin basement membranes.
name: Endocrine-type tubular atrophy

desc: A type of renal tubular atrophy in which the tubules show thick tubular basement membranes lined by small cuboidal or flat cells. Generally accompanied by fibrosis.
name: Usual-type tubular atrophy

desc: Tubular cross section with a space between the basolateral aspect of tubular epithelium and its basement membrane; classified as global when at least 2/3 circumference of the tubular cross section are involved and segmental when less than 2/3 are involved.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell detachment

desc: Tubular cross section with intracytoplasmic vacuoles in at least one tubular epithelial cell. This feature is classified as isometric when vacuoles are round and similar in size and coarse when vacuoles were not round in shape or varied in size.
layperson: Renal tubular epithelial cell cytoplasmic vacuolization
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell cytoplasmic vacuolization

desc: At least one free floating cell in the tubular lumen without attachment to adjacent cells or basement membrane in a tubular cross section without detachment. These cells must not aggregate into a tubular shape and completely fill the lumen, if so, it should be classified as a cast.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell sloughing

desc: Tubular cross section with round/irregular cytoplasmic protrusion, shaped like the Greek capital letter Omega (or it may be more vertically elongated Omega), pinched off from apical membrane without apparent closure of the lumen, involving over 50 percent of the tubular cells in cross section. The feature can be further classified into proximal or distal tubule.
layperson: Blebbing of apical cytoplasm of renal tubular epithelial cells
name: Blebbing of apical cytoplasm of renal tubular epithelial cells

desc: Tubular epithelium with round strongly PAS-positive cytoplasmic droplet material in at least one tubular epithelial cell.
layperson: Renal tubular epithelial cell hyaline droplets
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell hyaline droplets

desc: Tubular epithelial cells with greater than 3 nuclei in a single epithelial cell, often overlapping with each other in a single plane of view.
layperson: Multinucleation of renal tubular epithelial cells
name: Multinucleation of renal tubular epithelial cells

desc: Tubular epithelium with nucleoli clearly visible at 100-fold magnification.
layperson: Prominent nucleoli of renal tubular epithelial cells
name: Prominent nucleoli of renal tubular epithelial cells

desc: Tubular cross section with flattened tubular cell cytoplasm (height unequivocally less than width), with complete loss of brush border involving greater than 50 percent of the tubular cells in cross section, resulting in an apparent increase in the size of the lumen, without the presence of casts.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell simplification

desc: Tubular epithelial cells in any mitotic phase, identified by distinctively visible chromosome in either prophase, metaphase, anaphase or telophase configuration.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell mitosis

desc: At least one tubular epithelial cell with average sized cytoplasmic area and a nuclear area 3 times greater than average sized nuclei.
layperson: High renal tubular epithelial cell N/C ratio
name: High renal tubular epithelial cell N/C ratio
synonyms: High N/C ratio of renal tubular epithelial cells

desc: Presence of increased amount of lipofuscin, a yellow, granular cytoplasmic pigment in the renal tubules.
name: Renal tubular epithelial lipofuscin
