desc: Tubular cross section lined entirely by tubular epithelium with convex apical cell membrane (i.e., cells are shaped like an upside down U, and lack a distinct smaller protrusion seen in blebbing as defined above) resulting in apparent complete closure of the lumen.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell swelling

desc: Tubular epithelial cells containing cytoplasmic hemosiderin, brown-golden granular pigment.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell hemosiderin

desc: At least one tubular cross section with all tubular epithelial nuclei having a chromatin pattern resembling normal mature lymphocytes.
layperson: Hyperchromasia of renal tubular epithelial cells
name: Hyperchromasia of renal tubular epithelial cells
synonyms: Condensed chromatin of renal tubular epithelial cells

desc: Increased apoptosis (programmed cell death) of tubular epithelial cells. The cells arre rounded with increased eosinophilia and contain fragmented, densely basophilic nuclear debris.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell apoptosis

desc: Urinary casts are formed in the distal convoluted tubule or the collecting duct by solidification of protein in the lumen of the kidney tubules. This term refers to casts located within the tubuli of the kidney. More precisely, casts are defined as a material that completely fills and expands the tubular lumen with simplification of surrounding tubular epithelium. Casts are classified as either nuclear debris/granular brown material, red blood cell, white blood cell, myeloma, or myoglobin cast.
name: Renal intratubular casts

desc: A type of acelluar intratubular casts that have a surface composed of granules, which can vary in size. On H&E (red brown), PAS (amaranth purple), trichrome (red with ragged contours), Hall (olive-emerald green).
name: Intratubular bilirubin casts

desc: Casts that contain red blood cells and are located within the tubuli of the kidney.
name: Intratubular erythrocyte cast

desc: Intratubular casts composed of vancomycin aggregates and uromodulin.
name: Intratubular vancomycin casts

desc: Casts that contain white blood cells and are located within the tubuli of the kidney.
name: Intratubular leukocyte casts

desc: The presence of casts containing immunoglobulin light chains within the lumina of the renal tubules.
name: Intratubular light-chain casts

desc: A type of acelluar intratubular casts that have a surface composed of granules, which can vary in size. The granules can be rather heterogeneous, ranging from fine (finely granular cast) up to coarse (coarsely granular cast), dark, clear, and pigmented. On H&E (red granular), PAS (purple), trichrome (red granular), Hall (yellow brown). Stain positively for Hemoglobin A.
name: Intratubular hemoglobin casts

desc: A type of acellular urinary cast located within the distal tubules of the kidney and that is composed only of Tamm-Horsfall glycoprotein. Correspondingly, these casts have a low refractive index. Hyaline casts may display a spectrum of morphologies, which includes fluffy, compact, convoluted or wrinkled casts. Hyaline casts have a smooth texture and usually have parallel sides with clear margins and blunted ends.
name: Intratubular hyaline casts

desc: Casts located within the tubuli of the kidney and that contain myoglobin. Myoglobin casts are composed of round granules that may line up in chains or aggregate in clusters. Their color ranges from pink to red-brown with hematoxylin and eosin stain, light brown to black with Jones methenamine silver stain, pink to bright magenta with periodic acid-Schiff stain, and bright red with trichrome stain. Immunoperoxidase staining with antibody to myoglobin is stronglypositive in the casts.Electron microscopy shows globular casts with an electron-dense core and a somewhat less-intense periphery. Substructure is absent. This feature may be accompanied by acute tubular injury with variable flattening of tubular epithelial cells, loss of brush borders, and intratubular sloughed epithelial cells.
name: Intratubular myoglobin cast

desc: Birefringent calcium- and oxalate-containing casts located within the tubuli of the kidney.
name: Intratubular calcium oxalate casts

desc: Purple and finely granular/laminated calcium- and phosphate-containing casts located within the tubuli of the kidney.
name: Intratubular calcium phosphate casts

desc: Intratubular crystals composed of 2,8-dihydroxyadenine are small needle-shaped brownish crystals that are highly birefringent under polarized light and black by Jones methenamine silver.
name: Intratubular dihydroxyadenuria crystals

desc: Abnormal structure or form of the lumen (opening) of kidney tubules.
name: Abnormal renal tubular lumen morphology

desc: Dilatation (expansion beyond the normal dimension) of the cavity (lumen) of tubules of the kidney. The tubular cross section displays an attenuated brush border (apical PAS positivity greater than 10 percent of the normal expected height, but unequivocally less than normal expected height), resulting in an apparent increase in the size of lumen.
name: Tubular luminal dilatation

desc: Dilated renal tubules (over twice the diameter of a normal proximal tubule) containing eosinophilic amorphous material. This feature is generally accompanied by scalloping of the cast profile. The epithelium lining the microcyst is generally flattened and does not reveal brush border.
name: Tubular microcystic change

desc: Viral cytopathic changes consist of smudgy basophilic intranuclear inclusions with enlarged nuclei of infected cells. Distal tubules are more commonly involved than proximal tubules. There is associated acute tubular injury, often with frank tubular necrosis and destruction, with acute interstitial nephritis, often with a pleomorphic infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, histiocytes, plasma cells, and variable numbers of neutrophils, with interstitial edema and hemorrhage. Tubular destruction may be associated with necrotizing interstitial granulomas. Severe granulomatous tubulointerstitial nephritis appears to be characteristic of adenoviral infection and is quite rare in other viral infections. Focal wedge-shaped necrosis may occur in renal parenchyma. Immunostaining for adenovirus shows strong nuclear and cytoplasmic staining in infected cells.
name: Renal tubular viral cytopathic changes

desc: Characteristic intranuclear glassy-appearing basophilic inclusions with surrounding halo (owl's eye-type inclusion) and marked increase in the size of the cell (cytomegaly), particularly in tubular epithelial cells and in endothelial cells. Often accompanied by cytopathic changes including patchy interstitial pleomorphic infiltrate with lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages.
name: Renal tubular cytomegalovirus inclusions

desc: Viral cytopathic changes consist of smudgy basophilic intranuclear inclusions with enlarged nuclei of infected cells. The inclusions stain positive for adenovirus (e.g., Figure 3 of PMID:29273157). Distal tubules are more commonly involved than proximal tubules. Occasionally glomerular visceral and parietal epithelial cells can be infected. There is associated acute tubular injury, often with frank tubular necrosis and destruction, with acute interstitial nephritis, often with a pleomorphic infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, histiocytes, plasma cells, and variable numbersof neutrophils, with interstitial edema and hemorrhage.
name: Renal tubular adenovirus inclusions

desc: Renal ltubular nuclear inclusions have a ground-glass appearance with irregular central clearing, or a coarse, vesicular appearance. Distal tubules are involved more often than proximal tubules. There may be only medullary involvement in early stages, and parietal epithelial cells may be involved in later stages of the infection. Infected epithelial cell nuclei stain with antibody to the large T antigen of the SV40 virus, which serves as a surrogate marker of human polyomavirus infection.
name: Renal tubular polyoma virus inclusions

desc: Renal tubular nuclear inclusions that stain positive for herpes simplex virus (HSV). HSV is typically associated with multinucleated giant cells with nuclear inclusions and may cause hemorrhagic interstitial nephritis.
layperson: Renal tubular herpes simplex virus inclusions
name: Renal tubular herpes simplex virus inclusions

desc: A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney.
name: Decreased numbers of nephrons

desc: Atrophy of the kidney.
name: Renal atrophy

desc: A unilateral form of atrophy of the kidney.
name: Unilateral renal atrophy

desc: A two-sided form of atrophy of the kidney.
name: Bilateral renal atrophy

desc: Reduced dimension of the solid part of the kidney (parenchyma, the renal cortex and medulla) as measured from the collecting system (renal calyces and pelvis) to the border of the kidney. This measurement can be performed by measuring the thickness of the parenchyma in computed tomography scans.
name: Decreased renal parenchymal thickness

desc: A collection of clotted blood surrounding the kidney.
name: Perirenal hematoma

desc: Renal fibrosis is the consequence of an excessive accumulation of extracellular matrix that occurs in virtually every type of chronic kidney disease.
name: Renal fibrosis

desc: An accumulation of fluid in one or more of the perinephric spaces, which consist of the subcapsular, perirenal, anterior and posterior pararenal spaces. This abnormality can be demonstrated by cross-sectional imaging, particularly computed tomography.
name: Perinephric fluid collection

desc: Any structural anomaly of the interstitium of the kidney. The renal interstitium is defined as the intertubular, extraglomerular, extravascular space of the kidney. It is bounded on all sides by tubular and vascular basement membranes and is filled with cells, extracellular matrix, and interstitial fluid.
name: Abnormal renal insterstitial morphology

desc: Accumulation of foam cells (FC) in the interstitium of the kidney. Renal FCs display phenotypic characteristics of macrophages and belong to the monocyte/macrophage lineage. Histologically, renal FCs are characterized by round cells with small nuclei and an abundant PAS-positive cytoplasm with lipid-containing vacuoles.
name: Renal interstitial foam cells

desc: Increased numbers of neutrophils in the interstitial tissues of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial neutrophil infiltration

desc: Increased numbers of eosinophils in the interstitial tissues of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial eosinophil infiltration

desc: Increased numbers of plasma cells in the interstitial tissues of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial plasma cell infiltration

desc: The presence of birefringent calcium- and oxalate deposits in interstitial cells of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial calcium oxalate

desc: A focal collection of 20 or more red blood cells within the interstitium, that is irregular in shape (i.e., collections do not conform to the shape of tubules or capillary networks), without surrounding endothelium or tubular epithelium, and is in an area of intact core.
name: Renal interstitial hemorrhage

desc: Edema is characterized but the acute swelling of the stroma, with expansion of the interstitial space without the a concurrent increase in interstitial cells or extracellular matrix. Histologically this change is appreciated as interstitial areas of lower optical density.
name: Renal interstitial edema

desc: Interstital aggregates of histiciocytes, occasionally multinucleated with associated lymphoplasmacytic and occcasionally eosinophilic inflammation. Organization can range from poorly-to-well defined and multinucleated giant cells may be present.
name: Renal interstitial granulomas

desc: An organized collection of histiocytes (specifically macrophages) localized in the interstitial tissue of the kidney. Through light microscopy, the activated histiocytes appear as epithelioid cells with round to oval nuclei, often with irregular contours and abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm with indistinct cell borders. They may also coalesce to form multinucleated giant cells. Granulomas may be associated with a peripheral cuff of lymphoplasmacytic and occcasionally eosinophilic inflammation. Organization can range from poorly-to-well defined. Granulomas can present as necrotizing or non-necrotizing. Microscopically, necrotizing granulomas distinctly have central necrosis with a palisaded lymphohistiocytic reaction and a cuff of chronic inflammation.
name: Renal interstitial necrotizing granulomas

desc: Interstital aggregates of histiciocytes, occasionally multinucleated with associated lymphoplasmacytic and occcasionally eosinophilic inflammation. Organization can range from poorly-to-well defined and multinucleated giant cells may be present with no necrosis.
name: Renal interstitial non-necrotizing granulomas

desc: Abnormal accumulation of a metabolite, protein, or protein-derived substance in the interstitial region of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial deposits

desc: Deposition of hemosiderin (a golden-brown, granular pigment derived from ferritin) in interstitial cells of the kidney.
name: Renal interstitial hemosiderin

desc: Accumulation of an immunoglobulin in the interstitial tissue of the kidney. The immunoglobulin may be a monoclonal Ig or the corresponding heavy-chain (HC) or light-chain (LC) subunit. By convention this definition excludes Ig-derived amyloidosis (amyloidosis can be distinguished by its affinity for Congo red staining).
name: Renal interstitial immunoglobulin deposits

desc: The presence of interstitial aggregates of purple finely granular/laminated calcium- and phosphate deposits.
name: Renal interstitial calcium phosphate deposits

desc: Presence of interstitial mononuclear leukocytes, i.e., white blood ceclls with a single round nucleus, including lymphocytes and monocytes but not including granulocytes (which have multilobed nuclei).
name: Renal interstitial mononuclear cell infiltration

desc: Inflammation of interstitial tissues of the kidney consisting of foamy macrophages admixed with plasma cells, lymphocytes and neutrophils and occasional giant cells.
name: Renal interstitial xanthogranulomatous inflammation

desc: Histopathological findings of inflammation of the renal interstitium potentially involving fibrotic as well as non-fibrotic areas, composed of lymphocytes, monocytes, plasma cells.
name: Renal interstitial inflammation

desc: Histopathological findings of inflammation of the renal interstitium involving fibrotic as well as non-fibrotic renal cortex, composed of lymphocytes, monocytes, plasma cells.
name: Renal cortical interstitial inflammation

desc: Histopathological findings of inflammation of the interstitium of the renal medulla, composed of lymphocytes, monocytes, plasma cells.
name: Renal medullary interstitial inflammation

desc: The accumulation of collagen and related extracellular matrix (ECM) molecules in the interstitium of the kidney. The interstitium is expanded by the presence of collagen that stain blue on trichrome. Tubules are not back to back, but rather separated by fibrosis and can be atrophic.
name: Renal interstitial fibrosis

desc: Cell death (necrosis) affecting one or more parts of the kidney.
name: Renal necrosis

desc: Premature death of cells in the renal papilla (the apex of a renal pyramid which projects into the cavity of a calyx of the kidney and through which collecting ducts discharge urine). Histologically, one observes pale tissue with typical appearance of coagulative necrosis, affecting the renal papillae. Necrosis can be identified by pyknotic nuclei and simplified, flattened epithelium of proximal tubules. The tubular and glomerular basement membranes are still visible without viable nuclei.
name: Renal papillary necrosis

desc: A perinephric abscess is a collection of suppurative material in the perinephric space (i.e., the connective and adipose tissues surrounding the kidney).
name: Perinephric abscess

desc: An encapsulated collection of pus and necrotic material within the renal parenchyma. The destruction of renal parenchyma is associated with suppurative/neutrophil-rich inflammation and necrosis.
name: Intrarenal abscess

desc: An abnormal site of the kidney.
name: Abnormal localization of kidney

desc: A connection of the right and left kidney by an isthmus of functioning renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue that crosses the midline.
name: Horseshoe kidney

desc: A developmental defect in which a kidney is located in an abnormal anatomic position.
name: Ectopic kidney

desc: A developmental defect in which a kidney is located in an abnormal anatomic position within the pelvis.
name: Pelvic kidney

desc: A developmental anomaly in which the kidneys are fused and localized on the same side of the midline. This anomaly is thought to result from disruption of the normal embryologic migration of the kidneys.
name: Crossed fused renal ectopia

desc: A significant descent of the kidney as the patient moves from the supine to the erect position.
name: Nephroptosis

desc: Abnormally persistent clusters of embryonal cells, representing microscopic malformations (dysplasias) of the developing kidney.
name: Nephrogenic rest

desc: A type of nephrogenic rest associated with multiple lesions in the periphery of the renal lobe.
name: Perilobar nephrogenic rest

desc: A type of nephrogenic rest usually representing single lesions within the renal lobe, renal sinus, or calyceal walls.
name: Intralobar nephrogenic rest

desc: Any structural abnormality of the medulla of the kidney.
name: Abnormal renal medulla morphology

desc: Presence of cysts at the corticomedullary junction of the kidney in combination with tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
name: Nephronophthisis

desc: A structural anomaly of the pyramid of the adult kidney, cone-shaped structures with a broad base adjacent to the renal cortex and the narrow apex that is termed papilla.
name: Abnormality of medullary pyramid morphology

desc: Undergrowth of the pyramid of the adult kidney, cone-shaped structures with a broad base adjacent to the renal cortex and the narrow apex that is termed papilla.
name: Renal medullary pyramid hypoplasia

desc: An abnormal functionality of the kidney.
name: Abnormal renal physiology

desc: A reduction in the level of performance of the kidneys in areas of function comprising the concentration of urine, removal of wastes, the maintenance of electrolyte balance, homeostasis of blood pressure, and calcium metabolism.
name: Renal insufficiency

desc: Sudden loss of renal function, as manifested by decreased urine production, and a rise in serum creatinine or blood urea nitrogen concentration (azotemia).
name: Acute kidney injury

desc: Acute renal failure with resolution of manifestations.
name: Reversible renal failure

desc: Functional anomaly of the kidney persisting for at least three months.
name: Chronic kidney disease

desc: A degree of kidney failure severe enough to require dialysis or kidney transplantation for survival characterized by a severe reduction in glomerular filtration rate (less than 15 ml/min/1.73 m2) and other manifestations including increased serum creatinine.
name: Stage 5 chronic kidney disease

desc: A type of chronic kidney disease with normal or increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR at least 90 mL/min/1.73 m2).
name: Stage 1 chronic kidney disease

desc: A type of chronic kidney disease with mildly reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 60-89 mL/min/1.73 m2).
name: Stage 2 chronic kidney disease

desc: A type of chronic kidney disease with moderately reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 30-59 mL/min/1.73 m2).
name: Stage 3 chronic kidney disease

desc: A type of chronic kidney disease with severely reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR 15-29 mL/min/1.73 m2).
name: Stage 4 chronic kidney disease

desc: Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of findings resulting from glomerular dysfunction with an increase in glomerular capillary wall permeability associated with pronounced proteinuria. Nephrotic syndrome refers to the constellation of clinical findings that result from severe renal loss of protein, with Proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
name: Nephrotic syndrome

desc: Nephrotic syndrome with onset within the first three months of life.
name: Congenital nephrotic syndrome

desc: A form of nephrotic syndrome that does not respond to treatment with steroid medication.
name: Steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome

desc: A form of nephrotic syndrome that does not respond to any immunosuppresive treatment.
name: Multidrug-resistant nephrotic syndrome

desc: A nonspecific term referring to disease or damage of the kidneys.
name: Nephropathy

desc: The presence of inflammation affecting the kidney.
name: Nephritis

desc: An inflammation of the kidney involving the parenchyma of kidney, the renal pelvis and the kidney calices.
name: Pyelonephritis

desc: Repeated episodes of pyelonephritis.
name: Recurrent pyelonephritis

desc: Inflammation of the connective and adipose tissues surrounding the kidney.
name: Perinephritis

desc: Abnormal function of the renal tubule. The basic functional unit of the kidney, the nephron, consists of a renal corpuscle attached to a renal tubule, with roughly 0.8 to 1.5 nephrons per adult kidney. The functions of the renal tubule include reabsorption of water, electrolytes, glucose, and amino acids and secretion of substances such as uric acid.
layperson: Abnormal function of filtrating structures in kidney
name: Renal tubular dysfunction
synonyms: Abnormal function of filtrating structures in kidney

desc: Dysfunction of the proximal tubule, which is the portion of the duct system of the nephron of the kidney which leads from Bowman's capsule to the loop of Henle.
name: Proximal tubulopathy

desc: A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption without bicarbonate loss.
name: Non-acidotic proximal tubulopathy

desc: A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption with bicarbonate loss and resulting acidosis.
name: Global proximal tubulopathy

desc: Acidosis owing to malfunction of the kidney tubules with accumulation of metabolic acids and hyperchloremia, potentially leading to complications including hypokalemia, hypercalcinuria, nephrolithiasis and nephrocalcinosis.
layperson: Accumulation of acid in body due to kidney problem
name: Renal tubular acidosis
synonyms: Accumulation of acid in body due to kidney problem

desc: A type of renal tubular acidosis characterized by a failure of the proximal tubular cells to reabsorb bicarbonate, leading to urinary bicarbonate wasting and subsequent acidemia.
name: Proximal renal tubular acidosis

desc: A type of renal tubular acidosis characterized by a failure of acid secretion by the alpha intercalated cells of the cortical collecting duct of the distal nephron. The urine cannot be acidified below a pH of 5.3, associated with acidemia and hypokalemia.
name: Distal renal tubular acidosis

desc: The presence of blood in the urine. Hematuria may be gross hematuria (visible to the naked eye) or microscopic hematuria (detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine).
name: Hematuria

desc: Microscopic hematuria detected by dipstick or microscopic examination of the urine.
layperson: Small amount of blood in urine
name: Microscopic hematuria
synonyms: Small amount of blood in urine

desc: Hematuria that is visible upon inspection of the urine.
name: Macroscopic hematuria

desc: The presence of dysmorphic urinary erythrocytes. This feature can be observed by phase-contrastmicroscopy, differential interference microscopy, and bright-field microscopy. The acanthocyte or G1 cell, which is a doughnut-shaped cell with one or more blebs, is reported to constitute a special form of dysmorphic erythro-cyte (D cell) specific for glomerular hematuria.
name: Dysmorphic hematuria

desc: An abnormally increased level of kidney isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
layperson: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of renal origin
name: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of renal origin

desc: An abnormally reduced level of kidney isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood.
layperson: Low alkaline phosphatase of renal origin
name: Low alkaline phosphatase of renal origin

desc: An altered ability of the kidneys to void urine and/or specific substances.
name: Abnormality of renal excretion

desc: A reduction in the ability of the kidneys to remove uric acid from the serum.
name: Impaired renal uric acid clearance

desc: An abnormal amount of urine production.
name: Abnormal urine output

desc: An increased rate of urine production.
name: Polyuria

desc: A decreased rate of urine production.
name: Decreased urine output

desc: Absence of urine, clinically classified as below 50ml/day.
name: Anuria

desc: Low output of urine, clinically classified as an output below 300-500ml/day.
name: Oliguria

desc: An abnormality of renal absorption.
name: Abnormality of renal resorption

desc: An inability of the tubules in the kidney to reabsorb small molecules, causing increased urinary loss of electrolytes (sodium, potassium, bicarbonate), minerals, glucose, amino acids, and water.
name: Renal Fanconi syndrome

desc: A defect in the ability to concentrate the urine.
name: Impaired renal concentrating ability
Increased renal tubular phosphate reabsorption
synonyms: Increased percent tubular reabsorption of phosphorus

desc: Any impairment of reabsorption of chloride by the kidney in order to not lose too much chloride in the urine.
name: Impaired reabsorption of chloride

desc: An abnormally increased or reduced amount of fluid filtered out of plasma through glomerular capillary walls into Bowman's capsules per unit of time.
name: Abnormal glomerular filtration rate

desc: An abnormal reduction in the volume of fluid filtered out of plasma through glomerular capillary walls into Bowman's capsules per unit of time.
name: Decreased glomerular filtration rate

desc: An abnormal rise in the volume of water filtered out of plasma through glomerular capillary walls into Bowman's capsules per unit of time.
name: Increased glomerular filtration rate

desc: Inability of the kidneys to produce either concentrated or dilute urine.
name: Isothenuria

desc: The kidney contributes towards acid-base homeostasis by excreting H+ ions and retaining bicarbonate. This process is known as acidification of the urine. The pH of urine ranges normally from 4.5 to 8. The inability to reduce the pH of the urine in a situation where it would be otherwise expected is known as an acidification defect.
name: Impaired urinary acidification

desc: The presence of hypertension related to stenosis of the renal artery.
name: Renovascular hypertension
synonyms: Hypertension due to renal artery hyperplasia

desc: An abnormality of the lower urinary tract.
layperson: Abnormality of the lower urinary tract
name: Abnormality of the lower urinary tract

desc: An abnormality of the urinary bladder.
name: Abnormality of the bladder

desc: Dysfunction of the urinary bladder.
name: Functional abnormality of the bladder

desc: A type of bladder dysfunction caused by neurologic damage. Neurogenic bladder can be flaccid or spastic. Common manifestatios of neurogenic bladder are overflow incontinence, frequency, urgency, urge incontinence, and retention.
layperson: Lack of bladder control due to nervous system injury
name: Neurogenic bladder
synonyms: Lack of bladder control due to nervous system injury

desc: Urge incontinence is the strong, sudden need to urinate.
name: Urinary urgency

desc: Inability to completely empty the urinary bladder during the process of urination.
name: Urinary retention

desc: Abnormally increased production of urine during the night leading to an unusually frequent need to urinate.
name: Nocturia

desc: Difficulty in beginning the process of urination.
name: Urinary hesitancy

desc: Loss of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination.
name: Urinary incontinence

desc: Involuntary urine leakage synchronous with exertion, or actions such as sneezing, or coughing.
name: Stress urinary incontinence

desc: Lack of the ability to control the urinary bladder leading to involuntary urination at an age where control of the bladder should already be possible.
name: Enuresis

desc: Enuresis occurring during sleeping hours.
name: Enuresis nocturna

desc: Enuresis occurring during waking hours of the day.
name: Enuresis diurna

desc: Abnormal function of a sphincter of the urinary bladder.
name: Urinary bladder sphincter dysfunction

desc: A urodynamic anomaly characterized by bladder outlet obstruction from detrusor muscle contraction with concomitant involuntary urethral sphincter activation.
name: Detrusor sphincter dyssynergia

desc: A compression or resistance upon the bladder outflow channel at any location from the bladder neck to urethral meatus, which usually causes lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).
name: Bladder outlet obstruction

desc: Increased frequency of urination.
name: Pollakisuria

desc: Painful or difficult urination.
name: Dysuria

desc: Any structural anomaly of the bladder.
name: Abnormality of bladder morphology

desc: Diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
name: Bladder diverticulum

desc: Presence of a single diverticulum (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
name: Solitary bladder diverticulum

desc: Presence of a many diverticula (sac or pouch) in the wall of the urinary bladder.
name: Multiple bladder diverticula

desc: Eversion of the posterior bladder wall through the congenitally absent lower anterior abdominal wall and anterior bladder wall.
name: Bladder exstrophy

desc: The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to another organ or the skin. The fistula can involve the bowel, the vagina, or rarely, the skin.
name: Bladder fistula

desc: Abnormal enlargement of the urinary bladder.
name: Hypertrophy of the urinary bladder

desc: Buildups of minerals that form in the urinary bladder.
name: Bladder stones

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the bladder

desc: Underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
name: Hypoplasia of the bladder

desc: Aplasia (absence) of the urinary bladder.
name: Aplasia of the bladder

desc: Abnormality of the urachus.
name: Abnormality of the urachus

desc: Persistence of the urachal canal resulting in a canal between the bladder and the umbilicus.
name: Patent urachus

desc: A cyst located along the allantois canal.
name: Urachal cyst

desc: An abdominal wall defected related to a developmental anomaly of the allantois, which is an embryonic structure that develops as a diverticulum off the yolk sac at about 16 days post fertilization. During further development, the allantois becomes incorporated into the body of the embryo, connecting the ventral aspect of the urogenital sinus (which will develop into the upper pole of the urinary bladder) to the external portion of the umbilicus. Upon further development, the lumen of the allantois becomes obliterated and forms a thick fibrous cord called the urachus, which connects the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus. In adults, the urachus is known as the median umbilical ligament. Failure of the allantoic cavity to obliterate can result of one of four conditions: 1) congenital patent urachus (a completely open connection between bladder and umbilicus); 2) vesicourachal diverticulum (a diverticulum off the bladder but not communicating with the umbilicus); umbilical cyst and sinus (not communicating with the bladder); and 4) alternating urachal sinus. An abdominal wall defect can be associated with a urachal cyst.
name: Vesicoallantoic abdominal wall defect

desc: A swelling formed at the base of umbilicus associated with a patent urachus which results from an allantoic remnant. The urachus is a fibrous remnant of the allantois which communicates from the apex of the urinary bladder to the umbilicus. Failed obliteration of the urachus can lead to various abnormalities: urachal cyst, urachal diverticulum, sinus or patent urachus - the most common type. Allantoic cysts in infants with patent urachus can be formed due to the drainage of urine into the umbilical cord, or in uncommon situations, after leakage of hypo-osmotic urine into the Wharton's jelly.
name: Allantoic cyst

desc: Persistence of the urachal canal with drainage of urine from the bladder through the persistent allantois canal to the umbilicus.
name: Urachus fistula

desc: The presence of a dilated urinary bladder.
name: Dilatation of the bladder

desc: Dilatation of the bladder postnatally.
name: Megacystis

desc: Fetal megacystis is an abnormally enlarged bladder identified at any gestational age.
name: Fetal megacystis

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of two bladders.
name: Bladder duplication

desc: An abnormal growth that projects from the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder.
name: Bladder polyp

desc: Transmural inflammation of the bladder predominantly with eosinophils, associated with fibrosis with or without muscle necrosis.
name: Eosinophilic bladder infiltration

desc: Muscular projections that protrude into the lumen of the bladder, criss-crossing the walls of the bladder on its inner surface.
name: Bladder trabeculation

desc: Inflammation of the urinary bladder.
name: Urinary bladder inflammation

layperson: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology
name: Abnormality of the urinary system physiology

desc: Repeated infections of the urinary tract.
name: Recurrent urinary tract infections

desc: Repeated infections of the urinary bladder.
name: Recurrent cystitis

desc: An abnormality of the composition of urine or the levels of its components.
name: Abnormality of urine homeostasis

desc: Presence of myoglobin in the urine.
name: Myoglobinuria

desc: Recurring episodes of myoglobinuria, i.e., of the presence of myoglobin in the urine. This is usually a consequence of rhabdomyolysis, i.e., of the destruction of muscle tissue.
name: Recurrent myoglobinuria

desc: Presence of myoglobin in the urine following exercise.
name: Exercise-induced myoglobinuria

desc: High levels of ketone bodies in the urine.
name: Ketonuria

desc: An abnormally high level of uric acid in the urine.
name: Hyperuricosuria

desc: An abnormally low urinary specific gravity, i.e., reduced concentration of solutes in the urine.
name: Hyposthenuria

desc: An increased concentration of 5-aminolevulinic acid (CHEBI:17549) in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary delta-aminolevulinic acid

layperson: Low urinary cyclic AMP response to PTH administration
name: Low urinary cyclic AMP response to PTH administration

desc: An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the urine. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate.
name: Elevated urine pyrophosphate

desc: An increased concentration of prostaglandin in the urine.
name: Hyperprostaglandinuria

desc: An increase in the reabsorption of calcium by the renal tubulus that is not associated with increased parathormone levels.
layperson: Parathormone-independent increased renal tubular calcium reabsorption
name: Parathormone-independent increased renal tubular calcium reabsorption
synonyms: Parathormone-independent increased renal tubular Ca2+ reabsorption
Parathormone-independent increased renal tubular Ca reabsorption

desc: Excretion of glycosaminoglycan in the urine. Glycosaminoglycans are long unbranched polysaccharides consisting of a repeating disaccharide unit.
name: Urinary glycosaminoglycan excretion

desc: Excessive amounts of mucopolysaccharide in the urine.
name: Mucopolysacchariduria

desc: An increased concentration of heparan sulfates in the urine.
name: Heparan sulfate excretion in urine

desc: An increased concentration of dermatan sulfate in the urine.
name: Dermatan sulfate excretion in urine

desc: An increased concentration of keratan sulfate in the urine.
name: Keratan sulfate excretion in urine

desc: An increased concentration of chondroitin sulfate (CHEBI:37397) in the urine.
name: Chondroitin sulfate excretion in urine

desc: Lack of urothione (the urinary metabolite of molybdenum cofactor) in the urine.
name: Absent urinary urothione

desc: Increased concentration of trimethylamine in the urine.
name: Trimethylaminuria

desc: The presence of free hemoglobin in the urine.
name: Hemoglobinuria

desc: Abnormally increased excretion of porphyrins in the urine.
name: Porphyrinuria

desc: An increased concentration of xanthine in the urine.
name: Xanthinuria

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of glucose in the urine.
name: Abnormality of urine glucose concentration

desc: An increased concentration of glucose in the urine.
name: Glycosuria

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine.
name: Abnormality of urine bicarbonate concentration

desc: Abnormally increased concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine.
name: Bicarbonaturia

desc: Abnormally decreased concentration of hydrogencarbonate in the urine.
name: Decreased urine bicarbonate concentration

desc: An abnormal level of urinary catecholamine concentration.
name: Abnormality of urine catecholamine concentration

desc: An increased concentration of catecholamine in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary catecholamines

desc: An increased concentration of noradrenaline in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary norepinephrine

desc: An increased concentration of adrenaline in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary epinephrine

desc: An increased concentration of dopamine in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary dopamine

desc: An increased level of hypoxanthine in the urine.
name: Increased urinary hypoxanthine

desc: Increased concentration of SO3(2-), i.e., sulfite, in the urine.
name: Increased urinary sulfite

desc: Increased concentration of thiosulfate(2-) in the urine.
name: Increased urinary thiosulfate

desc: Increased excretion of glycopeptides in the urine. Glycopeptides are peptides with carbohydrate moieties covalently attached to the side chains of the amino acid residues.
name: Glycopeptiduria

desc: Excretion of peptides conjugated to sialic acid in the urine.
name: Increased urinary O-linked sialopeptides

desc: Excretion of excess amounts of aspartylglucosamine in the urine.
name: Aspartylglucosaminuria

desc: An abnormal distribution of N-acylglycines in the urine. There are numerous different N-acylglycines, and this term refers to pathological alterations in their level or distribution.
name: Abnormal urinary acylglycine profile

desc: Abnormal concentration of isobutyrylglycine in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine isobutyrylglycine concentration

desc: Elevated concentration of isobutyrylglycine in the urine.
name: Increased urine isobutyrylglycine concentration

desc: An abnormal color of the urine, that is, the color of the urine appears different from the usual straw-yellow color.
name: Abnormal urinary color

desc: An abnormal pink color of urine.
name: Pink urine

desc: An abnormal orange color of urine.
name: Orange urine

desc: An abnormal green color of urine.
name: Green urine

desc: An abnormal blue color of the urine.
name: Blue urine

desc: An abnormal red color of the urine.
name: Red urine

desc: An abnormal dark color of the urine.
name: Dark urine

desc: An abnormal red-brown color of the urine.
name: Red-brown urine

desc: An abnormal dark-yellow color of the urine.
name: Dark yellow urine

desc: An abnormal purple color of the urine.
name: Purple urine

desc: A deviation from the normal odor of the urine.
name: Abnormal urinary odor

desc: Increased concentration of porphobilinogen in the urine.
name: Increased urinary porphobilinogen

desc: A deviation from normal of the concentration of 2-oxoglutaric acid in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine alpha-ketoglutarate concentration
synonyms: Abnormality of urine alpha ketoglutarate concentration

desc: A greater than normal concentration of 2-oxoglutaric acid in the urine.
name: Increased urine alpha-ketoglutarate concentration

desc: A lower than normal concentration of 2-oxoglutaric acid in the urine.
name: Decreased urine alpha-ketoglutarate concentration

desc: A deviation from normal of the concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine citrate concentration

desc: A lower than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.
name: Hypocitraturia

desc: A greater than normal concentration of citrate(3-) in the urine.
name: Hypercitraturia

desc: The presence of bacteria in the urine.
name: Bacteriuria

desc: The presence of hemosiderin in the urine.
name: Hemosiderinuria

desc: An abnormality in the concentration of electrolytes in the urine.
name: Abnormal urinary electrolyte concentration

desc: A high concentration of one or more electrolytes in the urine in the presence of low serum concentrations of the electrolyte(s).
name: Renal salt wasting

desc: An abnormality of calcium concentration in the urine.
name: Abnormality of urine calcium concentration

desc: An abnormally decreased calcium concentration in the urine.
name: Hypocalciuria

desc: A reduction of the ratio of renal calcium clearance to creatinine clearance to below 0.01.
layperson: Reduced ration of kidney calcium clearance to creatinine clearance
name: Reduced ratio of renal calcium clearance to creatinine clearance
synonyms: Reduced ration of renal Ca2+ to creatinine clearance
Reduced ration of kidney calcium clearance to creatinine clearance
Reduced ration of renal Ca clearance to creatinine clearance

desc: High urine calcium in the presence of hypocalcemia.
name: Renal calcium wasting

desc: An abnormal concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine potassium concentration

desc: High urine potassium in the presence of hypokalemia.
name: Renal potassium wasting

desc: An increased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
name: Increased urinary potassium

desc: A decreased concentration of potassium(1+) in the urine.
name: Decreased urinary potassium

desc: An abnormal phosphate concentration in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine phosphate concentration

desc: High urine phosphate in the presence of hypophosphatemia.
name: Renal phosphate wasting
synonyms: Decreased tubular maximum for phosphate reabsorption per glomerular filtration rate

desc: An increased excretion of phosphates in the urine.
name: Hyperphosphaturia

desc: An increased concentration of phosphoethanolamine in the urine.
name: Phosphoethanolaminuria

desc: An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the urine.
name: Hypophosphaturia

desc: An abnormal concentration of chloride in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine chloride concentration

desc: An increased concentration of chloride in the urine.
name: Hyperchloriduria

desc: An decreased concentration of chloride in the urine.
name: Hypochloriduria

desc: High urine chloride in the presence of hypochloridemia.
name: Renal chloride wasting

desc: An abnormal concentration of sodium in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine sodium concentration

desc: An abnormally decreased sodium concentration in the urine.
name: Hyponatriuria

desc: An increased concentration of sodium(1+) in the urine.
name: Hypernatriuria

desc: An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the urine in the presence of hyponatremia.
name: Renal sodium wasting

desc: An abnormal concentration of magnesium the urine.
name: Abnormal urine magnesium concentration

desc: High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia.
name: Renal magnesium wasting

desc: An increased concentration of magnesium the urine.
name: Hypermagnesiuria

desc: An decreased concentration of magnesium the urine.
name: Hypomagnesiuria

desc: Abnormal concentration of urate in the urine.
layperson: Abnormality of urinary uric acid concentration
name: Abnormality of urinary uric acid concentration

desc: Decreased concentration of urate in the urine.
name: Decreased urinary urate

desc: Elevated concentration of urate in the urine.
name: Increased urinary urate

desc: Abnormal concentration of sulfate in the urine.
name: Abnormal urinary sulfate concentration

desc: Decreased concentration of sulfate in the urine.
name: Decreased urinary sulfate

desc: Elevated concentration of SO4(2-), i.e., sulfate, in the urine.
name: Increased urinary sulfate

desc: An anomalous finding in the examination of the urine for cells.
name: Abnormal urine cytology

desc: The presence of 10 or more white cells per cubic millimeter in a urine specimen, 3 or more white cells per high-power field of unspun urine, a positive result on Gram staining of an unspun urine specimen, or a urinary dipstick test that is positive for leukocyte esterase.
name: Pyuria

desc: Abnormally increased count of neutrophils in urine.
name: Increased urine neutrophil count

desc: Patients who routinely have greater than 20 leukocytes per microliter, but have abacterial urine, are said to have sterile pyuria.
name: Sterile pyuria

desc: The presence of renal casts (cylindrical, cigar-shaped structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
name: Cylindruria

desc: A type of urinary cast composed of cells incorporated in a protein matrix. The cells can be those found in the urinary sediment (erythrocytes, leuklocytes, renal tubular epithelial cells).
name: Cellular urinary casts

desc: Presence of leukocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
name: Leukocyte cylindruria

desc: Presence of erythrocyte casts (cylindrical structures produced by the kidney in certain disease states) in the urine.
name: Erythrocyte cylindruria

desc: A type of cellular urinary cast composed of renal tubular epithelial cells.
name: Renal tubular epithelial cell casts

desc: A type of urinary cast composed of a proteinaceous matrix without a substantial number of cells.
name: Acellular urinary casts

desc: A type of acellular urinary cast that are composed only of Tamm-Horsfall glycoprotein, a fact which explains their low refractive index. Hyaline casts may display a spectrum of morphologies, which includes fluffy, compact, convoluted or wrinkled casts. Hyaline casts have a smooth texture and usually have parallel sides with clear margins and blunted ends.
name: Hyaline casts

desc: A type of acelluar casts that have a surface composed of granules, which can vary in size. The granules can be rather heterogeneous, ranging from fine (finely granular cast) up to coarse (coarsely granular cast), dark, clear, and pigmented.
name: Granular casts

desc: A type of acellular urinary casts that display a melted wax (waxy) appearance, which gives them a high refractive index. They are frequently dark, with blunt extremities, indented and cracked edges and a large size, which is often several times that of other types of casts.
name: Waxy casts

desc: A type of acellular urinary casts that contain lipid droplets, oval fat bodies or cholesterol crystals, and are often associated with the free forms of these elements. Their identification may require the use of polarised light microscopy, under which fatty particles embedded into the cast matrix appear as Maltese crosses.
name: Fatty casts

desc: A type of acelluar casts with positive myoglobin staining A that have a surface composed of granules, which can vary in size. The granules can be rather heterogeneous, ranging from fine (finely granular cast) up to coarse (coarsely granular cast), dark, clear, and pigmented.
name: Myoglobin casts

desc: A type of urinary cast that contain bacteria. Bacterial casts can be difficult to identify and can be distinguished from other types of casts using phase contrast microscopy. Bacterial casts are diagnostic of acute pyelonephritis or intrinsic renal infection.
name: Bacterial cell casts

desc: An increased number of epithelial cells per high-power field in urinanalysis.
name: Increased urinary epithelial cell count

desc: An increased number of squamous epithelial cells per high-power field in urinanalysis.
layperson: Increased urinary squamous epithelial cell count
name: Increased urinary squamous epithelial cell count

desc: An increased number of renal tubular epithelial cells per high-power field in urinanalysis.
layperson: Increased urinary renal tubular epithelial cell count
name: Increased urinary renal tubular epithelial cell count

desc: An increased number of transitional epithelial cells per high-power field in urinanalysis.
layperson: Increased urinary transitional epithelial cell count
name: Increased urinary transitional epithelial cell count

desc: Distal tubular epithelial cells in which globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) has accumulated. they are the characteristic feature of Fabry disease. Urinary mulberry bodies are a component of mulberry cells that can be distinguished easily from fat particles by their inner lamellar appearance.
name: Urinary mulberry cells

desc: The presence in the urine of desquamated tubular epithelial cells or macrophages filled with lipid droplets.
name: Urinary oval fat bodies

desc: The presence of crystals in the urine.
name: Crystalluria

desc: Formation of crystals owing to an increased concentration of orotic acid in the urine.
name: Orotic acid crystalluria

desc: The presence of leuucine crystals in the urine.
name: Leucine crystalluria

desc: The presence of calcium phosphate crystals in the urine.
name: Calcium phosphate crystalluria

desc: The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.
name: Calcium oxalate crystalluria

desc: The presence of calcium carbonate crystals in the urine.
name: Calcium carbonate crystalluria

desc: Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals in the urine.
name: Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystalluria

desc: The presence of uric acid crystals in the urine.
name: Uric acid crystalluria

desc: Any deviation of the concentration of one or more proteins in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine protein level

desc: Increased levels of protein in the urine.
name: Proteinuria

desc: Excretion in urine of proteins of a size smaller than albumin (molecular weight 69 kD).
name: Low-molecular-weight proteinuria

desc: Severely increased amount of excretion of protein in the urine, defined as 3.5 grams per day or more in adults and 40 mg per meter-squared body surface area per hour in children.
name: Nephrotic range proteinuria

desc: Mildly increased levels of protein in the urine (150-500 mg per day in adults).
name: Mild proteinuria

desc: Moderately increased levels of protein in the urine (500-1000 mg per day in adults).
name: Moderate proteinuria

desc: Severely increased levels of protein in the urine (1000-3000 mg per day in adults).
name: Heavy proteinuria

desc: Increased concentration of albumin in the urine.
name: Albuminuria

desc: The presence of mildly increased concentrations of albumin in the urine (in adults, 30-150 mg per day).
name: Microalbuminuria

desc: An increased concentration of neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin in the urine (there is no generally accepted threshold, but some studies choose a threshold of above 150 nanogram per milliliter).
name: Increased urinary neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin

desc: An increased amount of uromodulin (also known as Tamm Horsfall protein) in the urine.
name: Elevated urinary uromodulin

desc: Increased level of beta 2-microglobulins in the urine.
name: Beta 2-microglobulinuria

desc: The presence of free monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains in the urine.
name: Bence Jones Proteinuria

desc: The presence of free monoclonal kappa immunoglobulin light chains in the urine.
name: Kappa Bence Jones proteinuria

desc: The presence of free monoclonal lambda immunoglobulin light chains in the urine.
name: Lambda Bence Jones proteinuria

desc: An increased concentration in the urine of alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (AGP), also known as orosomucoid (ORM). AGP is a 41-43-kDa glycoprotein with a pI of 2.8-3.8. AGP is an acute-phase protein that has many activities including, but not limited to, acting as an acute-phase reactant and disease marker, modulating immunity, binding and carrying drugs, maintaining the barrier function of capillary, and mediating the sphingolipid metabolism.
name: Increased urinary orosomucoid

desc: An abnormal concentration or amount of a mineral in the urine. Medically relevant minerals include calcium, phosphorus, potassium, sodium, chloride, magnesium, iron, zinc, iodine, chromium, copper, fluoride, molybdenum, manganese, and selenium.
name: Abnormal urinary mineral level

desc: An abnormally elevated amount of zinc in the urine, typically as assessed by a 24 hour urine collection.
name: Increased urinary zinc level

desc: An increased concentration of copper in the urine.
name: Increased urinary copper concentration

desc: Urine has an increased amount of frothy fine bubbles.
name: Foamy urine

desc: Presence of conjugated bilirubin in the urine.
name: Bilirubinuria

desc: Presence of nitrites in the urine.
name: Nitrituria

desc: The appearance of the urine having visible material in suspension, i.e., appearing cloudy.

name: Cloacal exstrophy

desc: Rectovestibular fistula with a normal anus is known as H-type fistula or double termination of the alimentary tract.

desc: An abnormality of head and neck.

name: Abnormality of the head

name: Abnormality of the face

name: Abnormality of the mouth

name: Abnormal oral physiology

desc: An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
name: Impaired mastication

desc: Recurrent or excessive bleeding from the mouth.
name: Oral cavity bleeding

desc: An intense sensation of burning, scalding, or tingling feeling of the tongue or other regions of the oral mucosa.
name: Burning mouth

desc: Reduced strength of the masseter muscle, whose primary function is to elevate the mandible and thereby raise the mandible towards the maxilla, closing the jaw.
name: Masseter muscular weakness

desc: Dryness of the mouth due to salivary gland dysfunction.
name: Xerostomia

desc: Excessive production of saliva.
name: Excessive salivation

desc: Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth.
name: Drooling

desc: Noticeably unpleasant odors exhaled in breathing.
name: Halitosis

desc: Fetor hepaticus is the characteristic breath of patients with severe parenchymal liver disease, which has been said to resemble the odor of a mixture of rotten eggs and garlic.
name: Fetor hepaticus

desc: Any structural anomaly of the mouth, which is also known as the oral cavity.
name: Abnormal oral morphology

desc: Abnormality of the oral cavity, i.e., the opening or hollow part of the mouth.
name: Abnormal oral cavity morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the tongue.
name: Abnormality of the tongue

desc: Any structural anomaly of the tongue.
name: Abnormal tongue morphology

desc: Increased length and width of the tongue.
name: Macroglossia

desc: A form of macrogloassia (increased size of the tongue) characterized by a broad based root of the tongue but a small tongue tip, giving the appearance of a triangle.
name: Triangular tongue

desc: Increased length and width of one half of the tounge.
layperson: Increased size of half of the tongue
name: Hemimacroglossia
synonyms: Increased size of half of the tongue
Hypertrophy of half of the tongue
Hyperplasia of half of the tongue

desc: Posterior displacement of the tongue into the pharynx, i.e., a tongue that is mislocalised posteriorly.
name: Glossoptosis

desc: Multiple indentations and/or elevations on the edge and/or surface of the tongue producing an irregular surface contour.
name: Lobulated tongue

desc: Inflammation of the tongue.
name: Glossitis

desc: Accentuation of the grooves on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
name: Furrowed tongue

desc: Increased depth of the median tongue furrow.
name: Exaggerated median tongue furrow

desc: Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the tongue.
name: Tongue telangiectasia

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the tongue.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the tongue

desc: Decreased length and width of the tongue.
name: Microglossia

desc: Absence of the tongue owing to a developmental abnormality.
name: Aglossia

desc: Short or anteriorly attached lingual frenulum, associated with limited mobility of the tongue.
name: Ankyloglossia

desc: Tongue with a median apical indentation or fork.
name: Bifid tongue

desc: Glossy appearance of the entire tongue surface.
name: Smooth tongue

desc: Tongue extending beyond the alveolar ridges or teeth at rest.
name: Protruding tongue

desc: Wasting of the tongue.
name: Tongue atrophy

desc: An anomaly of the tongue characterized by loss (atrophy) of filiform papillae of the tongue, leaving areas of erythema (redness), surrounded by a serpiginous, white, hyperkeratotic border. The name geographic tongue refers to an appearance that is said to be similar to a map.
name: Geographic tongue

desc: Inflammed tongue with hyperplastic (enlarged) fungiform papillae that is said to resemble a strawberry or raspberry.
name: Strawberry tongue

desc: Increased rigidity and reduced mobility of the tongue.
name: Stiff tongue

layperson: Abnormality of extrinsic muscle of tongue
name: Abnormality of extrinsic muscle of tongue

desc: An abnormality of a palatoglossus muscle.
name: Abnormality of palatoglossus muscle

desc: An abnormality of the styloglossus muscle.
name: Abnormality of styloglossus muscle

desc: An abnormality of a genioglossus muscle.
name: Abnormality of genioglossus muscle

desc: An abnormality of an intrinsic muscle of tongue.
layperson: Abnormality of intrinsic muscle of tongue
name: Abnormality of intrinsic muscle of tongue

desc: An abnormality of a hyoglossus muscle.
name: Abnormal hyoglossus muscle morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality of a lingual artery.
name: Abnormal lingual artery morphology

desc: An abnormality of a lingual tonsil.
name: Abnormality of lingual tonsil

desc: Any functional anomaly of the tongue.
name: Abnormal tongue physiology

desc: A distortion of the sense of taste, often characterized by the sensation of a metallic taste.
name: Parageusia

desc: A rare condition that is characterized by a complete loss of taste function of the tongue.
name: Ageusia

desc: Fasciculations or fibrillation affecting the tongue muscle.
name: Tongue fasciculations

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the tongue.
name: Tongue pain

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tongue.
name: Tongue edema

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the tongue.
name: Neoplasm of the tongue

desc: A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.
name: Hamartoma of tongue

desc: A carcinoma derived from a squamous epithelial cell of the tongue.
layperson: Squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue
name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue

desc: A low-grade variant of squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue with a warty (verrucous) appearance.
layperson: Verrucous cell carcinoma of the tongue
name: Verrucous cell carcinoma of the tongue

desc: Sarcomatoid (spindle cell) carcinomas of the tongue is a variant of squamous carcinoma of tongue that is monoclonal, having evolved from a conventional squamous carcinoma with dedifferentiation associated with sarcomatoid transformation.
name: Sarcomatoid carcinoma of the tongue
synonyms: Spindle cell carcinoma of the tongue

desc: A lipoma localized to the tongue. May present as a nontender, soft, spherical mass of the tongue.

desc: An abnormality of the lip.

name: Abnormality of upper lip

desc: Decreased width of the upper lip.
name: Short upper lip

name: Cleft upper lip

desc: A type of cleft lip presenting as a midline (median) gap in the upper lip.
name: Median cleft lip

desc: Cleft lip or palate affecting the midline region of the palate.
name: Median cleft lip and palate

desc: A cleft of the lip with overlying mucous membrane.
name: Submucous cleft lip

desc: A subtle unilateral cleft of the upper lip, which may appear as a small indentation.

name: Incomplete cleft of the upper lip
synonyms: Notched cleft of the upper lip
Partial cleft of the upper lip
Incomplete cleft of the upper lip

desc: Clefting of the upper lip affecting the lateral portions of the upper lip rather than the midline/median region.

synonyms: Paramedian cleft of the upper lip
Non-midline cleft of the upper lip

desc: A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on one side only.
name: Unilateral cleft lip

desc: A non-midline cleft of the upper lip on the left and right sides.
name: Bilateral cleft lip

desc: Cleft lip and cleft palate affecting both sides of the face.
layperson: Right and left cleft lip and palate
name: Bilateral cleft lip and palate
synonyms: Right and left cleft lip and palate
Bilateral cleft lip and cleft palate

desc: An abnormality of the philtrum.
name: Abnormality of the philtrum

desc: Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations above the mean, or alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
name: Broad philtrum

desc: Flat skin surface, with no ridge formation in the central region of the upper lip between the nasal base and upper vermilion border.
name: Smooth philtrum

desc: Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border.
name: Short philtrum

desc: Distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between nasal base and midline upper lip vermilion border.
name: Long philtrum

desc: Accentuated, prominent philtral ridges giving rise to an exaggerated groove in the midline between the nasal base and upper vermillion border.
name: Deep philtrum

desc: Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
name: Hypoplastic philtrum

desc: Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.
name: Tented philtrum

desc: Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove.
name: Philtrum with midline raphe

desc: Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges.
name: Malaligned philtral ridges

desc: Pit in the midline of the philtral groove.
name: Midline sinus of philtrum

desc: Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.
name: Narrow philtrum

desc: An abnormality of the vermilion border, the sharp demarcation between the lip (red colored) and the adjacent normal skin.
name: Abnormality of upper lip vermillion
synonyms: Deformity of the upper lip vermillion
Anomaly of the upper lip vermillion
Abnormality of the red part of the upper lip
Malformation of the upper lip vermillion

desc: Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
name: Thick upper lip vermilion
synonyms: Increased height of upper lip vermilion
Thick red part of the upper lip
Thick vermilion border of upper lip
Increased volume of upper lip vermilion

desc: Height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the midline more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently reduced height of the vermilion of the upper lip in the frontal view (subjective).
name: Thin upper lip vermilion
synonyms: Decreased height of upper lip vermilion
Decreased volume of upper lip vermilion
Thin red part of the upper lip
Thin vermilion border of upper lip

desc: More pronounced paramedian peaks and median notch of the Cupid's bow.
name: Exaggerated cupid's bow

desc: Lack of paramedian peaks and median notch of the upper lip vermilion.
name: Absent cupid's bow
synonyms: Failure of development of cupid's bow

desc: Inner aspect of the upper lip vermilion (normally apposing the teeth) visible in a frontal view, i.e., the presence of an everted upper lip.
name: Everted upper lip vermilion

desc: Triangular appearance of the oral aperture with the apex in the midpoint of the upper vermilion and the lower vermilion forming the base.
name: Tented upper lip vermilion

desc: Gentle upward curve of the upper lip vermilion such that the center is placed well superior to the commissures.
name: U-Shaped upper lip vermilion

desc: Increased width of the upper lip.
name: Long upper lip
synonyms: Increased vertical length of upper lip

desc: Depression located on the vermilion of the upper lip, usually paramedian.
name: Upper lip pit

desc: An abnormality of the lower lip.

desc:
A vascular malformation located in the lip that is characterized by
ectatic papillary dermal capillaries and postcapillary venules in the upper reticular dermis.
