Cleft soft palate can cause functional abnormalities of the Eustachian tube with resulting middle ear anomalies and hearing difficulties, as well as speech problems associated with hypernasal speech due to velopharyngeal insufficiency.
name: Cleft soft palate

desc: A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.
name: Submucous cleft soft palate

desc: Inability of velopharyngeal sphincter to sufficiently separate the nasal cavity from the oral cavity during speech.
name: Velopharyngeal insufficiency

desc: A developmental defect characterized by lack of a soft palate.
name: Absent soft palate

desc: An abnormality of one or more of the five muscles of the soft palate.
layperson: Abnormality of musculature of soft palate
name: Abnormality of musculature of soft palate

desc: An abnormality of the tensor veli palatini muscle
layperson: Abnormality of tensor veli palatini muscle
name: Abnormality of tensor veli palatini muscle

desc: An abnormality of a palatopharyngeus muscle.
name: Abnormality of palatopharyngeus muscle

desc: An abnormality of a levator veli palatini.
layperson: Abnormality of levator veli palatini muscle
name: Abnormality of levator veli palatini muscle

desc: Cleft palate is a developmental defect of the palate resulting from a failure of fusion of the palatine processes and manifesting as a separation of the roof of the mouth (soft and hard palate).
name: Cleft palate
synonyms: Cleft of hard and soft palate

desc: Cleft palate of the midline of the palate.
name: Median cleft palate

desc: Nonmidline cleft palate on the left and right sides.
name: Bilateral cleft palate

desc: A gap (cleft) affecting one of the alveolar ridges, which are the protuberances in the mouth that contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth. An alveolar cleft can affect all structures of the alveolar ridge, including the gingiva, other mucosa, periosteum, alveolar bone, and teeth.
name: Cleft of alveolar ridge of maxilla

desc: One sided alveolar cleft of the maxilla.
name: Unilateral alveolar cleft of maxilla

desc: Nonmidline alveolar cleft of the maxilla.
name: Bilateral alveolar cleft of maxilla

desc: Soft and hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the soft and hard palate that are covered by the lining (ie mucous membrane) of the roof of the mouth.
layperson: Submucous cleft of soft and hard palate
name: Submucous cleft of soft and hard palate

desc: Hard-palate submucous clefts are characterized by bony defects in the midline of the bony palate that are covered by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth. It may be possible to detect a submucous cleft hard palate upon palpation as a notch in the bony palate.
name: Submucous cleft hard palate

desc: Distance between the labial point of the incisive papilla to the midline junction of the hard and soft palate more than 2 SD below the mean (objective) or apparently decreased length of the hard palate (subjective).
name: Short hard palate

desc: A bony protrusion present on the midline of the hard palate.
name: Torus palatinus

desc: An abnormality of the lingual frenulum, that is of the small fold of mucous membrane that attaches the tongue to the floor of the mouth, or the presence of accessory frenula in the oral cavity.
name: Abnormal oral frenulum morphology

desc: Extra fold of tissue extending from the alveolar ridge to the inner surface of the upper or lower lip.
name: Accessory oral frenulum

desc: The presence of an abnormally short lingual frenulum.
name: Short lingual frenulum

desc: The presence of a cleft in the oral cavity, the two main types of which are cleft lip and cleft palate. In cleft lip, there is the congenital failure of the maxillary and median nasal processes to fuse, forming a groove or fissure in the lip. In cleft palate, there is a congenital failure of the palate to fuse properly, forming a grooved depression or fissure in the roof of the mouth. Clefts of the lip and palate can occur individually or together. It is preferable to code each defect separately.
name: Oral cleft

desc: Alveolar cleft is a tornado-shaped bone defect in the maxillary arch. Alveolar cleft occurs in response to divergence from normal development during frontonasal prominence growth, contact, and fusion. The most common alveolar portion of the cleft is located between the lateral incisor and the canine.
name: Cleft maxillary alveolus

desc: A gap in the lip or lips.
name: Cleft lip

desc: Any abnormality of the alveolar ridges (on the upper or lower jaws). The alveolar ridges contain the sockets (alveoli) of the teeth.
name: Abnormality of the alveolar ridges
synonyms: Abnormality of alveolar processes of jaw

name: Atrophy of alveolar ridges
synonyms: Atrophy of alveolar processes of jaw
Flattening of alveolar processes of jaw
Resorption of alveolar processes of jaw

desc: Underdevelopment of the alveolar process (also known as alveolar bone).
name: Alveolar process hypoplasia
synonyms: Decreased size of alveolar process of jaw
Underdevelopment of alveolar process of jaw
Deficiency of alveolar process of jaw

layperson: Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge
name: Midline notch of upper alveolar ridge
synonyms: Midline notch of maxillary alveolar process
Midline cleft of upper alveolar ridge
Midline cleft of maxillary alveolar process
Midline notch of upper gum ridge
Midline notch of maxillary alveolar ridge

desc: Increased width of the alveolar ridges.
name: Alveolar ridge overgrowth
synonyms: Hyperplasia of alveolar process of jaw

name: Thick anterior alveolar ridges
synonyms: Thick anterior alveolar process of jaw

name: Progressive alveolar ridge hypertropy
synonyms: Progressive hypertrophy of alveolar process of jaw

desc: Complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges.
name: Fibrous syngnathia

desc: Any abnormality of the salivary glands, the exocrine glands that produce saliva.
name: Abnormal salivary gland morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the parotid glands, which are the salivary glands that are located in the subcutaneous tissues of the face overlying the mandibular ramus and anterior and inferior to the external ear.
name: Abnormal parotid gland morphology
Absence of Stensen duct
synonyms: Failure of development of parotid duct
Failure of development of stensen duct

desc: Absence of the parotid gland.
name: Aplasia of the parotid gland

desc: Increased size of the parotid gland.
name: Enlargement of parotid gland

desc: Inflammation of the parotid gland.
name: Parotitis

desc: Any abnormality of the submandibular glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth, superior to the digastric muscles.
name: Abnormality of the submandibular glands

desc: Any abnormality of the sublingual glands, which are the salivary glands that are located beneath the floor of the mouth anterior to the submandibular glands.
name: Abnormality of the sublingual glands

desc: A ranula is a mucocele that occurs in the floor of the mouth and usually involve the major salivary glands. Specifically, the ranula originates in the body of the sublingual gland, in the ducts of the sublingual gland, in the Wharton's duct of the submandibular gland or infrequently from the minor salivary glands at this location.
name: Ranula

desc: Inflammation of a salivary gland.
name: Sialadenitis

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of a salivary gland.
name: Salivary gland neoplasm

desc: A benign epithelial neoplasm composed of layers of oncocytes (small round nucleus, micro-granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm with numerous tightly-packed mitochondria)
name: Salivary gland oncocytoma

desc: Distance between the oral commissures more than 2 SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
name: Wide mouth

desc: Distance between the commissures of the mouth more than 2 SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased width of the oral aperture (subjective).
name: Narrow mouth

desc: An abnormality of the outline, configuration, or contour of the mouth.
name: Abnormality of mouth shape

desc: A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth.
name: Open mouth

desc: A facial appearance characterized by a permanently or nearly permanently opened mouth, in which the upper lip is tented in a way that the opened mouth has the appearance of a triangle.
name: Triangular-shaped open mouth

desc: An abnormality of the appearance of the face caused by constant contraction of the lips leading to a puckered or pursed appearance.
name: Pursed lips

desc: An abnormality of facial morphology characterized by a small mouth opening and constant contraction of the lips as if the patient were whistling.
name: Whistling appearance

desc: The presence of a triangular form of the mouth.
name: Triangular mouth

desc: A morphological abnormality of the mouth in which the angle of the mouth is downturned. The oral commissures are positioned inferior to the midline labial fissure.
name: Downturned corners of mouth

desc: The presence of an asymmetric mouth.
name: Asymmetry of the mouth

desc: Oral commissures positioned superior to the midline labial fissure.
name: Upturned corners of mouth

desc: A horizontal cleft of the face, varying from slight widening of the mouth, to a cleft extending to the ear.
name: Transverse facial cleft

desc: A facial cleft extending from the zygomatic arch to the eye. This zygomaticomaxillary cleft is similar to that typically found in Treacher Collins syndrome. The overlying tissue shows a vertical sclerodermic furrow radiating from the labial commissure or the angle of the mandible across the cheek to a coloboma of the lower eyelid between the middle and lateral one-third. Microphthalmia is not observed. The skeletal cleft is between the maxilla and zygoma; it passes through the inferolateral orbital rim to enter the inferior orbital fissure. No alveolar cleft is present. The zygomatic arch is intact. The soft tissue furrow, which is more apparent on the right, radiates from the oral commissure toward the lateral two-thirds of the lower eyelid. The antimongoloid obliquity of the palpebral fissures is associated with laterally placed lower eyelid clefts and some ectropion. A left-sided anophthalmia is accompanied by adjacent soft tissue hypoplasia and is reflected in a short palpebral fissure, enophthalmos, and minor ptosis of the eyebrow. No abnormality is present in the alveolar arch except for some tilting of the occlusal plane secondary to hypoplasia of the left side of the maxilla. There is a vertical bony groove in the region of the zygomaticomaxillary suture that ends in the inferolateral portion of a small bony orbit. More laterally, the remainder of the zygomatic body and arch is normal in both shape and dimension. The lateral orbital floor is downslanting but intact, and it lacks direct communication with the temporal or infratemporal fossae. The hypoplasia of the left side of the maxilla and orbit is associated with a reduction in the transverse and anteroposterior dimensions of the anterior cranial fossa; mild asymmetry of the middle cranial fossa and calvarium is present. No significant asymmetry of size, shape, or position is present in the sphenoid.
name: Tessier number 6 facial cleft

desc: The temporozygomatic Number 7 cleft is found in both Treacher Collins syndrome and hemifacial microsomia. Soft tissue manifestations include macrostomia, malformations of the external and middle ear, temporalis muscle, variable involvement of the seventh cranial nerve (in hemifacial microsomia), and abnormalities of the preauricular hair in Treacher Collins syndrome. The skeletal cleft is through the pterygomaxillary junction, and vertical maxillary hypoplasia is present. In addition, abnormality of the mandibular ramus, coronoid, and condyle and absence of the zygomatic arch are typically present. A soft tissue furrow extends from the macrostomia laterally and superiorly across the cheek toward the preauricular hairline. The lower eyelids are intact. The anatomy of the external ear is normal, and there are no preauricular tags. Bony clefting is through the pterygomaxillary junction with hypoplasia of the alveolar process in the molar region, thereby producing a posterior open bite. The maxilla is hypoplastic, although the maxillary sinuses are symmetrically pneumatized. The hypoplastic zygomatic body arches upward, but then it takes a downward course and is severely malformed and displaced. The zygoma is continuous posteriorly with an apparently normal zygomatic process of the temporal bone. The mandibular condyle and coronoid process are hypoplastic and asymmetric. There is no antegonial notching of the mandible. Marked cranial base asymmetry, with tilting and asymmetric positioning of the temporomandibular articulations, is present. The anatomy of the sphenoid is abnormal, especially on the right where there is no recognizable medial or lateral pterygoid plate.
name: Tessier number 7 facial cleft

desc: The frontozygomatic or Number 8 cleft is found in both Treacher Collins syndrome and the Goldenhar variant of hemifacial microsomia. Skeletal defects are more prominent in Treacher Collins syndrome, whereas the soft tissue clefting is more typical in cases of ''Goldenhar syndrome''. Soft tissue clefting presents as a dermatocele, a true lateral eyelid coloboma with absence of the outer canthus, and anomalies of the globe itself, especially epibulbar cysts in patients with Goldenhar syndrome. The frontozygomatic bony cleft produces absence of the lateral orbital rim; this border now is formed by the hypoplastic greater wing of the sphenoid. The absence of bony support for the outer canthus produces lateral canthal dystopia and the characteristic antimongoloid slant of the palpebral fissures. Secondary to the bony deficiency in the lateral orbital wall and floor, there is soft tissue continuity between the orbit, temporal fossa, and infratemporal region. Preauricular hairline indicators delineate the Number 8 cleft as the first of the northbound clefts. Complete absence of the bony lateral orbital wall and rim constitute the skeletal element of the Number 8 cleft. The lateral border of the orbit is formed by the greater wing of the sphenoid from which small spicules of bone, which represent the rudimentary zygoma, may be found in Treacher Collins syndrome. The symmetry of the facial anomalies is reflected in the apparently normal symmetric anterior and middle cranial fossae.
name: Tessier number 8 facial cleft

desc: Abnormality of the oral mucosa.
name: Abnormal oral mucosa morphology

desc: Erosion of the mucous mebrane of the mouth with local excavation of the surface, resulting from the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.
name: Oral ulcer

desc: Any abnormality of the gingiva (also known as gums).
name: Abnormality of the gingiva

desc: The presence of fibrosis of the gingiva.
name: Gingival fibromatosis

desc: Hyperplasia of the gingiva (that is, a thickening of the soft tissue overlying the alveolar ridge. The degree of thickening ranges from involvement of the interdental papillae alone to gingival overgrowth covering the entire tooth crown.
name: Gingival overgrowth

desc: Hyperkeratosis of the gingiva.
name: Gingival hyperkeratosis

desc: Hemorrhage affecting the gingiva.
name: Gingival bleeding

desc: Inflammation of the gingiva.
name: Gingivitis

desc: A congenital defect with an abnormal joining of the gums of the upper and lower jaw.
name: Fusion of gums
synonyms: Upper and lower gums fused together

desc: Ectopic deposition of calcium salts found in the gingiva.
name: Gingival calcification

desc: A fissure in the gingiva (gums), i.e., the mucosal tissue that lies over the mandible and maxilla.
name: Gingival cleft

desc: The loss of gum tissue. The result is that gum tissue is recessed and its position on the tooth is lowered, exposing the roots of the teeth.
name: Gingival recession

desc: Presence of telangiectases in the oral cavity.
name: Oral cavity telangiectasia
synonyms: Spider veins of the oral cavity

desc: Telangiectasia (that is, the presence of small dilated superficial blood vessels) of the oral mucosa.
layperson: Spider veins of the oral mucosa
name: Telangiectasia of the oral mucosa
synonyms: Spider veins of the oral mucosa
Telangiectasia of the oral mucous membrane
Angioectasia of the oral mucous membrane

desc: Stomatitis is an inflammation of the mucous membranes of any of the structures in the mouth.
name: Stomatitis

desc: Recurrent episodes of ulceration of the oral mucosa, typically presenting as painful, sharply circumscribed fibrin-covered mucosal defects with a hyperemic border.
name: Recurrent aphthous stomatitis

desc: Fibrous band between the mucosal surfaces of the upper and lower alveolar ridges.
name: Oral synechia

desc: White lesions of the oral mucosa are generally caused by a condition that increases the thickness of the epithelium. This increases the distance to the vascular bed and thereby tends to change the usual reddish color of the oral mucosa to white. Common causes include hyperkeratosis (thickening of the keratin layer), acanthosis (thickening of the spinous cell layer), increased edema in the epithelium (leukoedema), and reduced vascularity of the underlying lamina propria. Additionally, fibrin caps or surface ulcerations and collapsed bullae can appear white.
layperson: White lesion of the oral mucosa
name: White lesion of the oral mucosa

desc: A thickened white patch on the oral mucosa that cannot be rubbed off.
name: Oral leukoplakia

desc: A corrugated white lesion of the oral mucosa that usually occurs on the lateral or ventral surfaces of the tongue and may have a shaggy or frayed appearance.
name: Oral hairy leukoplakia

desc: A sudden eruption (rash) of the surface of a mucous membrane of the mouth or pharynx.
name: Enanthema

desc: A velvety red but not ulcerated lesion of the oral mucosa. The texture may be roughened or normal, and the lesion is neither raised nor depressed.
name: Oral erythroplakia

desc: A palpable, solid lesion greater than 5mm in diameter. that is located in the mucosa of the mouth.
name: Oral mucosa nodule

desc: Loss of the superficial layer of the oral mucosa usually resulting in a shallow or crusted lesion.
name: Erosion of oral mucosa

desc: Mutliple lesions of the oral mucosa resembling those characteristic of the disease lichen planus. These are symmetric reticular lesions that resemble a white, lacelike network, as well as by papules, plaques, erythematous lesions, and erosions.
name: Oral lichenoid lesion

desc: Oral aphthous ulcers typically present as painful, sharply circumscribed fibrin-covered mucosal defects with a hyperemic border.
name: Aphthous ulcer

desc: An abnormality of the pigmentation of the mucosa of the mouth.
layperson: Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa
name: Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa
synonyms: Abnormal pigmentation of oral mucous membrane
Abnormal pigmentation of the oral mucosa/gingivae
Abnormal color of the oral mucosa

desc: Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the mucosa of the mouth.
name: Intra-oral hyperpigmentation

desc: A net-like pattern of increased pigmentation of the oral cavity.
name: Reticulate pigmentation of oral mucosa
synonyms: Reticulate pigmentation of oral mucous membrane

desc: Flat, distinct, discolored area of oral mucosal membrane less than 1 cm wide not associated with a change in the thickness or texture of the affected mucosal membrane. The lesions are small, solitary, well-circumscribed and often uniformly pigmented.
name: Oral melanotic macule

desc: Oral melanoacanthoma usually presents as an asymptomatic, ill-defined, rapidly enlarging, macular pigmentation. Although most lesions are heavily pigmented, the coloration may or may not be uniform. Any mucosal site may be affected, but buccal mucosal involvement is most common. Although typically solitary, rare patients may present with multifocal lesions.
name: Oral melanoacanthoma

desc: A small circumscribed whitish change in the color of the oral mucosa that is neither elevated nor depressed.
name: White oral mucosal macule

desc: Blisters arising in the mouth.
name: Oral mucosal blisters

desc: The occurrence of multiple or unique whitish or normal in color small papules or nodules in oral cavity, especially on labial and buccal mucosa, lower lip and tongue, and less often on the upper lip, gingiva and palate.
layperson: Focal epithelial hyperplasia of oral mucosa
name: Focal epithelial hyperplasia of oral mucosa
synonyms: Focal epithelial hyperplasia of the lining of mouth

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the oral cavity.
name: Neoplasm of the oral cavity

desc: A neoplasm that affects the hard palate, soft palate, or uvula.
name: Palate neoplasm

desc: Any abnormality of the mouth floor.
layperson: Abnormality of the floor of mouth
name: Abnormal mouth floor morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the floor of mouth

desc: An abnormality of a mylohyoid muscle.
name: Abnormality of mylohyoid muscle

desc: An abnormality of a mandibular ramus.
name: Abnormal mandibular ramus morphology
Short mandibular rami
synonyms: Short body and ramus of mandible

name: Short mandibular condyles
synonyms: Decreased length of condylar process of mandible
Bilateral hypoplasia of condylar process of mandible
Decreased height of condylar process of mandible
Bilateral hypoplasia of mandibular condylar neck
Bilateral hypoplasia of mandibular condylar head

name: Mandibular condyle aplasia
synonyms: Absence of the condylar neck of mandible
Underdevelopment of condylar neck of mandible
Underdevelopment of condylar process of mandible
Agenesis of condylar process of mandible
Absence of the condylar head of mandible
Failure of development of condylar neck of mandible
Agenesis of condylar neck of mandible
Underdevelopment of condylar head of mandible
Failure of development of condylar head of mandible
Absence of the condylar process of mandible
Agenesis of condylar head of mandible
Failure of development of the condylar process of mandible

name: Mandibular condyle hypoplasia
synonyms: Hypoplasia of subcondylar region of mandible
Hypoplasia of condylar neck of mandible
Decreased size of condylar process of mandible
Hypoplasia of condylar process of mandible
Hypoplasia of condylar head of mandible

desc: Pierre Robin malformation is a sequence of developmental malformations characterized by micrognathia (mandibular hypoplasia), glossoptosis and cleft palate.
name: Pierre-Robin sequence

desc: An abnormality of an inferior alveolar artery.
name: Abnormality of inferior alveolar artery

desc: An abnormality of a mandible condylar process.
name: Abnormal mandible condylar process morphology

desc: An abnormality of a mandible coronoid process.
name: Abnormal mandible coronoid process morphology

desc: A structural abnormality of a mandibular symphysis.
name: Abnormality of mandibular symphysis

desc: An anomaly of the forehead.
name: Abnormality of the forehead
synonyms: Abnormality of the frontal region of the face

desc: Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently increased distance between the two sides of the forehead.
name: Broad forehead

desc: Inclination of the anterior surface of the forehead from the vertical more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view.
name: Sloping forehead

desc: Width of the forehead or distance between the frontotemporales is more than two standard deviations below the mean (objective); or apparently narrow intertemporal region (subjective).
name: Narrow forehead

desc: An abnormally increased height of the forehead.
name: High forehead

desc: The presence of a forehead that is abnormally small.
name: Small forehead
synonyms: Decreased size of frontal region of face

desc: An anomaly in the placement or shape of the hairline (trichion) on the forehead, that is, the border between skin on the forehead that has head hair and that does not.
name: Abnormality of the frontal hairline
synonyms: Abnormality of hairline at front of head

desc: Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
name: Low anterior hairline

desc: Decreased number of head hairs per unit area on the anterior region of the scalp.
layperson: Sparse scalp hair at front of head
name: Sparse anterior scalp hair
synonyms: Sparse scalp hair at front of head
Thin scalp hair at front of head

desc: A pattern of hair growth in which there is hair extending from the temples to the lateral eyebrows.
layperson: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
name: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
synonyms: Unusual hairline with hair growth on temples extending to lateral eyebrow

desc: Distance between the hairline (trichion) and the glabella (the most prominent point on the frontal bone above the root of the nose), in the midline, more than two SD above the mean. Alternatively, an apparently increased distance between the hairline and the glabella.
name: High anterior hairline

desc: Frontal hairline with bilateral arcs to a low point in the midline of the forehead.
name: Widow's peak
synonyms: Pointed hairline at front of head

name: Large forehead
synonyms: Increased size of frontal region of face

desc: Bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline.
name: Frontal bossing

desc: An abnormality of the glabella.
layperson: Abnormality of the area between the eyebrows
name: Abnormality of the glabella
synonyms: Malformation of the area between the eyebrows
Deformity of the area between the eyebrows
Abnormality of the area between the eyebrows

desc: Forward protrusion of the glabella.
name: Prominent glabella

desc: Posterior positioning of the glabella, i.e., of the midline forehead between the supraorbital ridges.
name: Depressed glabella

desc: A forehead with abnormal flatness.
name: Flat forehead

desc: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone of the skull in infants and children and generally undergoes fusion by the age of six. A persistent frontal suture is referred to as a "metopic suture".
name: Abnormality of the metopic suture

desc: Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead.
name: Prominent metopic ridge

desc: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root.
layperson: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
name: Metopic suture patent to nasal root

desc: Linear vertical groove in the midline of the forehead, extending from hairline to glabella.
name: Metopic depression

desc: Premature fusion of the metopic suture.
name: Metopic synostosis

desc: Forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone.
name: Prominent forehead

desc: Vertical soft tissue creases in the midline of the forehead, often extending from the hairline to the brow, and seen with facial expression or when the face is at rest.
name: Vertical forehead creases

desc: Excessive amount of hair growth on forehead.
name: Frontal hirsutism

desc: An abnormality of a frontalis muscle belly.
name: Abnormality of frontalis muscle belly

desc: Reduced strength of the frontalis muscle (which is located on the forehead).
name: Frontalis muscle weakness

desc: An abnormality of the chin, i.e., of the inferior portion of the face lying inferior to the lower lip and including the central prominence of the lower jaw.
name: Abnormality of the chin

desc: Abnormal prominence of the chin related to increased length of the mandible.
name: Mandibular prognathia

desc: A marked tapering of the lower face to the chin.
name: Pointed chin

desc: Decreased vertical distance from the vermilion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
name: Short chin

desc: A persistent midline depression of the skin over the fat pad of the chin.
name: Dimple chin

desc: Incomplete fusion of the chin, resulting from a developmental defect and manifesting as a midline cleft or fissure of the chin.
name: Cleft of chin

desc: Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.
name: Broad chin

desc: Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.
name: Chin with horizontal crease

desc: H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.
name: Chin with H-shaped crease

desc: Increased vertical distance from the vermillion border of the lower lip to the inferior-most point of the chin.
name: Tall chin

desc: Vertical crease fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin with the face at rest.
name: Chin with vertical crease

desc: An abnormality of a mentalis muscle.
name: Abnormality of mentalis muscle

desc: An abnormality of a depressor labii inferioris.
name: Abnormality of depressor labii inferioris
synonyms: Abnormality of depressor labii inferioris muscle

desc: An anomaly of the midface, which is a region and not an anatomical term. It extends, superiorly, from the inferior orbital margin to, inferiorly, the level of nasal base. It is formed by the maxilla (upper jaw) and zygoma and cheeks and malar region. Traditionally, the nose and premaxilla are not included in the midface.
name: Abnormality of the midface

desc: An abnormality of the cheek- one of two bilateral soft tissue facial structures in the region of the face inferior to the eyes and between the nose and the ear. "Buccal" means relating to the cheek. The cheek is part of the midface
name: Abnormality of the cheek

desc: Increased prominence or roundness of soft tissues between zygomata and mandible.
name: Full cheeks
Abnormality of periauricular region
synonyms: Abnormality of the region around the ear

desc: A rudimentary tag of skin often containing ear tissue including a core of cartilage and located just anterior to the auricle (outer part of the ear).
name: Preauricular skin tag
synonyms: Skin tag in front of the ear
Skin tag on the posterior cheek

desc: A groove of the skin immediately in front of the ear.
name: Preauricular skin furrow
synonyms: Skin groove in front of the ear
Skin sulcus in front of the ear

desc: A rudimentary tag of ear tissue often containing a core of cartilage and located just in back of the auricle (outer part of the ear).
name: Postauricular skin tag

desc: Variably shaped, cartilage-containing tissue anterior to the external auditory meatus.
name: Pretragal ectopia
synonyms: Extra cartilage in front of the ear

desc: Preauricular sinus is an occasional finding and most frequently appears as a small pit close to the anterior margin of the ascending portion of the helix. The opening has also been reported along the postero superior margin of the helix, the tragus or the lobule. Preauricular sinus may lead to the formation of a subcutaneous cyst that is intimately related to the tragal cartilage and the anterior crus of the helix.
name: Preauricular cyst

desc: Benign congenital lesions of the periauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
name: Periauricular skin pits

desc: Benign congenital lesion of the postauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
name: Postauricular pit

desc: Small indentation anterior to the insertion of the ear.
layperson: Pit in front of the ear
name: Preauricular pit
synonyms: Pit in front of the ear

desc: Benign congenital lesion of the supraauricular soft tissue consisting of a blind-ending narrow tube or pit.
name: Supraauricular pit

desc: Lack or loss of the soft tissues between the zygomata and mandible.
name: Sunken cheeks

desc: An abnormality of a risorius muscle.
name: Abnormality of risorius muscle

desc: An abnormality of a zygomaticus major muscle.
name: Abnormality of zygomaticus major muscle

desc: An abnormality of a buccal mucosa.
name: Abnormality of buccal mucosa
synonyms: Abnormality of inside lining of cheek

desc: An anomalous amount or location of cell junction proteins such as plakoglobin or Cx43.
layperson: Abnormal distribution of cell junction proteins in buccal mucosal cells
name: Abnormal distribution of cell junction proteins in buccal mucosal cells

desc: An abnormality of a zygomaticus minor muscle.
name: Abnormality of zygomaticus minor muscle

desc: An abnormality of a buccal fat pad.
name: Abnormality of buccal fat pad

desc: An abnormality of a buccinator muscle.
name: Abnormality of buccinator muscle

desc: Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.
name: Midface retrusion

desc: An abnormality of the malar surface of the zygomatic bone and including the frontal process of maxilla.
name: Abnormality of malar bones

desc: Underdevelopment of the malar prominence of the jugal bone (zygomatic bone in mammals), appreciated in profile, frontal view, and/or by palpation.
name: Malar flattening

desc: Prominence of the malar process of the maxilla and infraorbital area appreciated in profile and from in front of the face.
name: Malar prominence

desc: Abnormally anterior positioning of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased convexity of the face, or increased nasolabial angle. The midface includes the maxilla, the cheeks, the zygomas, and the infraorbital and perialar regions of the face
name: Hyperplasia of midface

desc: An abnormal morphology (form) of the midface or its components, the cheeks, maxilla, zygomatic bone, malar region, and infraorbital rims.
layperson: Abnormality of the shape of the midface
name: Abnormality of the shape of the midface
synonyms: Abnormality of the shape of the midface

layperson: Abnormality of the region around the eyes
name: Abnormality of the orbital region
synonyms: Abnormality of the region around the eyes
Malformation of the orbital region of the face
Anomaly of the orbital region of the face
Deformity of the orbital region of the face

desc: Presence of a cyst in the region of the periorbital tissues. Orbital cysts can be derived from epithelial or glandular tissue within or surrounding the orbit (lacrimal glands, salivary glands, conjunctival, oral, nasal, or sinus epithelium).
name: Orbital cyst

desc: A cyst that is localized in the region of the orbit and exhibits an epithelial lining with a keratin-filled lumen. Hair follicles are one of the adnexal structures that are commonly found in walls of dermoid cysts.
name: Periorbital dermoid cyst

desc: A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the orbital region.
name: Hamartoma of the orbital region

desc: A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) which can originate from any tissue of the eye.
name: Hamartoma of the eye

desc: A hamartoma (a benign, focal malformation consisting of a disorganized mixture of cells and tissues) of the retina.
name: Retinal hamartoma

desc: A benign vascular tumor of the retina without any neoplastic characteristics.
name: Retinal capillary hemangioma

desc: A glial tumor of the retinal nerve fiber layer arising from a retinal astrocyte.
name: Retinal astrocytic hamartoma

layperson: Combined hamartoma of the retinal pigment epithelium and retina
name: Combined hamartoma of the retinal pigment epithelium and retina

desc: The presence of pigmented, oval and dome-shaped raised hamartomatous nevi of the iris..
name: Lisch nodules

desc: A hamartoma (disordered proliferation of mature tissues) of the conjunctiva.
name: Conjunctival hamartoma

desc: A hamartoma of lymph vessels that usually presents in childhood. It tends to increase in size with head-down posture and with the Valsalva manoeuvre. Superficial lesions are visible as transilluminable cystic spaces of the lid or conjunctiva that may also contain blood. Deep lesions may cause gradual proptosis or present acutely with orbital pain and reduced vision due to haemorrhage.
name: Lymphangioma of the orbit

desc: An anomaly of the adjacent structures (i.e., adnexa) of the eye, defined as the lacrimal apparatus, the extraocular muscles and the eyelids, eyelashes, eyebrows and the conjunctiva.
name: Abnormality of the ocular adnexa

desc: A structural anomaly of the adjacent structures (i.e., adnexa) of the eye, defined as the lacrimal apparatus, the extraocular muscles and the eyelids, eyelashes, eyebrows and the conjunctiva.
name: Abnormal ocular adnexa morphology

desc: An abnormality of the eyelids.
name: Abnormal eyelid morphology

desc: A fold of skin starting above the medial aspect of the upper eyelid and arching downward to cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
name: Epicanthus

desc: A fold of skin starting at or just below the medial aspect of the lower lid and arching upward to cover, extend in front of and lateral to the medial canthus.
name: Epicanthus inversus

desc: A type of epicanthus in which more extensive epicanthal folds with their origins in the eyebrow cover, pass in front of and lateral to the medial canthus (middle corner of the eye).
name: Epicanthus superciliaris

desc: A type of epicanthus in which a medial vertical fold is present between upper and lower lids.
name: Epicanthus palpebralis

desc: A type of epicanthus in which a primarily upper lid fold is present.
name: Epicanthus tarsalis

desc: Inflammation of the eyelids.
name: Blepharitis

desc: A type of blepharitis that affects the eyelid skin, base of the eyelashes, and the eyelash follicles.
name: Anterior blepharitis

desc: A type of blepharitis that affects the meibomian glands and meobomian gland orifices. This abnormality can be associated with a spectrum of appearances ranging from meibomian seborrhoea (foaming meibomian gland secretions) and meibomianitis (inflamed meibomian glands), to chalazia.
name: Posterior blepharitis

desc: Inflamation of the eyelid due to overactivity of the sebaceous gland.
name: Seborrhoeic blepharitis

desc: An abnormality of the eyelashes.
name: Abnormal eyelash morphology

desc: Mid upper eyelash length >10 mm or increased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
name: Long eyelashes

desc: Increased length of the upper eyelashes.
name: Long upper eyelashes

desc: Inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye.
name: Trichiasis

desc: White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes.
name: White eyelashes

desc: Abnormally curly or curved eyelashes.
name: Curly eyelashes

desc: Double rows of eyelashes.
name: Distichiasis

desc: Decreased length of the eyelashes (subjective).
name: Short eyelashes

desc: Eyelashes that draw the attention of the viewer due to increased density and/or length and/or curl without meeting the criteria of trichomegaly.
name: Prominent eyelashes

desc: This term refers to the loss of eyelashes that were previously present.
name: Loss of eyelashes
Sparse or absent eyelashes
synonyms: Partial to total absence of eyelashes

desc: Lack of eyelashes.
name: Absent eyelashes

desc: Lack of eyelashes on the lower lid.
layperson: Failure of development of lower eyelashes
name: Absent lower eyelashes
synonyms: Failure of development of lower eyelashes

layperson: Failure of development of upper eyelashes
name: Absent upper eyelashes
synonyms: Failure of development of upper eyelashes

desc: Decreased density/number of eyelashes.
name: Sparse eyelashes

desc: An eyelash that emerges from the underside (conjunctiva) of the upper or lower eyelid.
name: Ectopic cilia of eyelid

desc: Distance between the inner canthi more than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparently increased distance between the inner canthi.
name: Telecanthus

desc: An abnormal inversion (turning inward) of the eyelid (usually the lower) towards the globe. Entropion is usually acquired as a result of involutional or cicatricial processes but may occasionally be congenital.
name: Entropion

desc: An inward turning (inversion) of the margin of the upper eyelid.
name: Upper eyelid entropion

desc: An abnormal inversion of the eyelid towards the globe resulting from inferior retractor muscle dysfunction with tissue laxity and, possibly, overriding of the preseptal orbicularis muscle over the pretarsal orbicularis muscle.
name: Involutional entropion

desc: Abnormal inversion (turning inward) of the eyelid towards the globe associated with scarring that vertically shortens the posterior lamella of the eyelid.
name: Cicatricial entropion

desc: A type of entropion (abnormal inversion of the eyelid towards the globe) that is related to a mass effect of a lesion (e.g., a tumor) that pulls the eyelid margin away from the globe.
name: Mechanical entropion

desc: An outward turning (eversion) or rotation of the eyelid margin.
name: Ectropion

layperson: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids
name: Eversion of lateral third of lower eyelids

desc: An outward turning (eversion) or rotation of the eyelid margin (i.e., ectropion) caused by shortening or contraction of the anterior or middle lamellae related to scarring.
name: Cicatricial ectropion

desc: A type of ectropion associated with orbicularis muscle weakness caused by cranial nerve VII palsy.
name: Paralytic ectropion

desc: An anomaly of the space between the medial and lateral canthi of the two open eyelids.
name: Abnormality of the palpebral fissures
synonyms: Abnormality of the opening between the eyelids

desc: The presence of an abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure.
layperson: Abnormal shape of the opening between the eyelids
name: Abnormal shape of the palpebral fissure
synonyms: Abnormal shape of the opening between the eyelids
Abnormal morphology of the palpebral fissure

desc: A shape created by an acute downward arching of the upper eyelid and upward arching of the lower eyelid, toward the medial canthus, which gives the outline of the palpebral fissures the configuration of an almond. Thus, the maximum distance between the fissures is offset from, and medial to, the center point.
name: Almond-shaped palpebral fissure

layperson: Slanting of the opening between the eyelids
name: Slanting of the palpebral fissure
synonyms: Slanting of the opening between the eyelids

desc: The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations below the mean.
layperson: Downward slanting of the opening between the eyelids
name: Downslanted palpebral fissures
synonyms: Downward slanting of the opening between the eyelids

desc: The palpebral fissure inclination is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, the inclination of the palpebral fissure is greater than typical for age.
layperson: Upward slanting of the opening between the eyelids
name: Upslanted palpebral fissure
synonyms: Upward slanting of the opening between the eyelids

desc: An abnormal size of the palpebral fissures for example unusually long or short palpebral fissures.
layperson: Abnormal size of the opening between the eyelids
name: Abnormal size of the palpebral fissures
synonyms: Abnormal size of the opening between the eyelids

desc: A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures.
name: Blepharophimosis

desc: A fixed reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids with short palpebral fissures on one side only.
name: Unilateral narrow palpebral fissure
synonyms: Unequal size of opening between the eyelids

desc: Distance between medial and lateral canthi is more than two standard deviations above the mean for age (objective); or, apparently increased length of the palpebral fissures.
name: Long palpebral fissure

desc: Distance between the medial and lateral canthi is more than 2 SD below the mean for age (objective); or, apparently reduced length of the palpebral fissures.
name: Short palpebral fissure

desc: Reduction in the vertical distance between the upper and lower eyelids.
name: Narrow palpebral fissure

desc: Partial fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins by single or multiple bands of tissue.
name: Ankyloblepharon

desc: Nodular changes affecting the eyelids may have many different causes such as cystic lesions (chalaziae, hordeolae), lipogranulomas, melanomas, infectious diseases (Molluscum contagiosum) and many more.
name: Nodular changes affecting the eyelids

desc: The presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid.
layperson: Fatty deposits in skin around the eyes
name: Xanthelasma
synonyms: Fatty deposits in skin around the eyes

desc: A chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland. A chalazion or meibomian cyst appears as a painless tuberous swelling in the upper lid without loss of eyelashes.
name: Chalazion

desc: An acute purulent infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or the meibomian sebacious glands often caused by staphylococcus infections. Hordeola can either occur as Hordeola externa affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll or as Hordeola interna affecting the meibomian sebacious glands. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painful and can cause extreme local swelling.
name: Hordeolum

desc: Hordeola externa are acute purulent infections affecting the sebaceous glands of Zeis or the apocrine sweat glands of Moll, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia, hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.
name: Hordeolum externum

desc: Hordeola interna are acute purulent infections affecting the meibomian sebacious glands, often caused by staphylococcus infections. In contrast to chalazia (chronic epithelioid cell granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland caused by inflammation of a blocked meibomian gland), hordeola are extremely painfull and can cause extreme local swelling.
name: Hordeolum internum

desc: Loss of elasticity of the upper and lower eyelids causing the skin to sag and bulge.
name: Dermatochalasis

desc: Redundant eyelid skin pressing the eyelashes against the cornea and/or conjunctiva.
name: Epiblepharon

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the eyelid.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the eyelid

desc: A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower or upper eyelid.
name: Eyelid coloboma
synonyms: Full thickness defect of the eyelid

desc: A short discontinuity of the margin of the upper eyelid.
name: Upper eyelid coloboma
synonyms: Full thickness defect of the upper eyelid

desc: A short discontinuity of the margin of the lower eyelid.
name: Lower eyelid coloboma
synonyms: Full thickness defect of the lower eyelid

desc: Cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek, in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin, which is stretched over the orbital cavity.
name: Cryptophthalmos

desc: Absent eyelids.
name: Ablepharon

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the eyelid.
name: Hypoplasia of eyelid

desc: Underdevelopment of the lower eyelid.
name: Hypoplasia of the lower eyelids

desc: Euryblepharon is a congenital eyelid anomaly characterized by horizontal enlargement of the palpebral fissure. The eyelid is shortened vertically compared with the horizontal dimension, with associated lateral canthal malpositioning and lateral ectropion abnormally wide lid opening.
name: Euryblepharon

desc: A condition in which the eyelids do not close to cover the eye completely.
name: Lagopthalmos

desc: The inability to close the eyelids during sleep.
name: Nocturnal lagophthalmos
synonyms: Inability to close the eyelids at night

desc: A type of lagophthalmos that occurs in association with facial nerve palsy.
name: Paralytic lagophthalmos

desc: A type of lagophthalmos that occurs following trauma or surgery.
layperson: Inability to close the eyelids due to scarring
name: Cicatricial lagophthalmos
synonyms: Inability to close the eyelids due to scarring
Eyelids stay open due to scarring

desc: Eyelid partly covered by skin when eyes are open.
name: Hooded eyelid

desc: Lower eyelid partly covered by skin when eyes are open.
name: Hooded lower eyelid

desc: Upper eyelid partly covered by skin when eyes are open.
name: Hooded upper eyelid

desc: Heliotrope rash is a violaceous discoloration of the eyelids associated with periorbital edema.
name: Heliotrope rash of eyelid

desc: An increased thickness of the eyelid not related to acute inflammation.
name: Palpebral thickening

desc: Fatty tumors on the eyelids.
name: Lipomas of eyelids

desc: Redness of the skin of the eyelids, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
name: Erythema of the eyelids

desc: Edema in the region of the eyelids.
name: Palpebral edema

desc: Blepharochalasis is characterized by recurrent, non-painful, nonerythematous episodes of eyelid edema. It has been divided into hypertrophic and atrophic forms. In the hypertrophic form recurrent edema results in orbital fat herniation through a weakened orbital septum. Most patients who have blepharochalasis present in an atrophic condition with atrophy of redundant eyelid skin and superior nasal fat pads.
name: Blepharochalasis

desc: Edema in the region of the Lower eyelid.
name: Lower eyelid edema

desc: Edema in the region of the upper eyelid.
name: Upper eyelid edema

desc: A partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball.
name: Symblepharon
synonyms: Eyelid adhesion to globe of eye

desc: The presence of more than the normal number of eyelids.
name: Accessory eyelid

desc: Abnormal shortness of the vertical dimensions of the eyelids.
name: Microblepharia

desc: With the eyes in primary position, the sclera is visible above the superior corneal limbus.
name: Eyelid retraction

desc: Inferior malposition of the lower eyelid margin without eyelid eversion.
name: Lower eyelid retraction

desc: An elevation of the eyelid above the normal level in the primary position.
name: Upper eyelid retraction

desc: A unilateral or bilateral eyelid retraction due to midbrain lesions.
name: Collier's sign

desc: An abnormality of a levator palpebrae superioris.
name: Abnormal levator palpebrae superioris morphology

desc: Atrophy of the levator palpebrae superioris, the extraocular muscle that elevates the superior eyelid.
name: Levator palpebrae superioris atrophy

desc: An abnormality of the conjunctiva.
name: Abnormal conjunctiva morphology

desc: Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
name: Conjunctivitis

desc: Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.
name: Keratoconjunctivitis

desc: Dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components (aqueous, mucin, or lipid), lid surface abnormalities, or epithelial abnormalities. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often results in a scratchy or sandy sensation (foreign body sensation) in the eyes, and may also be associated with itching, inability to produce tears, photosensitivity, redness, pain, and difficulty in moving the eyelids.
name: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

desc: A chronic irritative conjunctivitis, which commonly presents with general irritation and redness of the eyes, with a burning, dry, or foreign-body sensation of the eyes.
name: Chronic irritative conjunctivitis

desc: Allergic Conjunctivitis is an allergic inflammation of the conjunctiva.
name: Allergic conjunctivitis

desc: A benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera (limbal epibullar dermoid).
name: Limbal dermoid

desc: Keratinization of the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus (corneoscleral junction), resulting in a raised spot.
name: Bitot spots of the conjunctiva

desc: The presence of whitish deposits in the conjunctiva resembling salt. May be related to calcinosis.
name: Conjunctival whitish salt-like deposits

desc: Any abnormality of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the conjunctival vasculature
name: Abnormal morphology of the conjunctival vasculature
synonyms: Abnormal vasculature of the conjunctiva morphology
Abnormal morphology of the conjunctiva vasculature
Abnormality of the vasculature of the conjunctiva

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the conjunctival blood vessels.
name: Tortuosity of conjunctival vessels

desc: The presence of small (ca. 0.5-1.0 mm) dilated blood vessels near the surface of the mucous membranes of the conjunctiva.
layperson: Small dilated blood vessels near membrane covering front of eye and eyelids
name: Conjunctival telangiectasia
synonyms: Small dilated blood vessels near membrane covering front of eye and eyelids

desc: Presence of multiple dilatations (sac-like outpouchings) in the blood vessels of the conjunctiva.
name: Saccular conjunctival dilatations

desc: Presence of nodules in the conjunctiva of the eye.
name: Conjunctival nodule

desc: A form of amyloidosis that affects the conjunctiva.
name: Conjunctival amyloidosis

desc: Edema (swelling) of the bulbar conjunctiva.
name: Chemosis

desc: A lipoma (a benign tumor composed of adipose tissue) located in the conjunctiva.
name: Conjunctival lipoma

desc: Avascular cystic elevations of the superior conjunctiva not related to ocular surgery or trauma.
name: Spontaneous conjunctival filtering bleb

desc: Raised tissue masses located on the palpebral conjunctiva with a central vessel. Papillae are created by a focal infiltration of inflammatory cells.
name: Conjunctival papillae

desc: Conjunctival papillae with a diameter greater than 1 millimeter. They characteristically have flattened tops which sometimes demonstrate staining with fluorescein.
name: Giant conjunctival papillae

desc: Small, dome-shaped nodules without a prominent central vessel located on the conjunctiva. The lymphoid follicles are located in the subendothelial region of the conjunctiva. They consist of a germinal center that contains immature, proliferating lymphocytes, as well as a corona that contains mature lymphocytes and plasma cells.
name: Conjunctival follicles

desc: An abnormality of the conjuctiva and ocular surface caused by conjunctival inflammation and associated with scarring.
name: Conjunctival cicatrization

desc: A benign tumor composed of adipose tissue and dense connective tissue usually located near the temporal fornix.
name: Dermolipoma of the conjunctiva

desc: Dilatation of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva leading to a red appearance of the sclera.
name: Conjunctival hyperemia

desc: A ring of redness at the limbus of the eye, the border between the cornea and the sclera.
name: Circumlimbal hyperemia

desc: A pinguecula is a yellowish to brown protruding lesion in the conjunctiva that is easily seen on the nasal and temporal sides of the cornea.
name: Pinguecula

desc: Conjunctival icterus is a condition where there is yellowing of the whites of the eyes. This is most commonly seen in patients who have liver disease.
layperson: Yellowing of the whites of the eyes
name: Conjunctival icterus
synonyms: Yellowing of the whites of the eyes

desc: An abnormality of the palpebral conjunctiva.
name: Defect of palpebral conjunctiva

desc: A conjuctival lesion composed of adipose tissue and dense connective tissue. Such choristomas of dermal elements are normally found at the outer canthus, and have a gelatinous appearance. Classically, there is an indistinct posterior border (with the lesion frequently extending into the orbit) and a well-demarcated anterior border several millimetres posterior to the limbus.
name: Conjunctival dermolipoma

desc: An abnormality of the eyebrow.
name: Abnormal eyebrow morphology

desc: Increased density/number and/or increased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
name: Thick eyebrow

desc: Meeting of the medial eyebrows in the midline.
name: Synophrys

desc: White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyebrow.
name: White eyebrow

desc: Increased height of the central portion of the eyebrow, forming a crescent, semicircular, or inverted U shape.
name: Highly arched eyebrow

desc: Increased length of the hairs of the eyebrows.
name: Long eyebrows

desc: This may present as a partial or complete duplication of the eyebrows.
name: Double eyebrow

desc: An abnormal distribution of eyebrow hair growth in the medial direction.
name: Medial flaring of the eyebrow

desc: An eyebrow that extends straight across the brow, without curve.
name: Horizontal eyebrow

desc: Regional increase in the width (height) of the eyebrow.
name: Broad eyebrow

desc: Regional increase in the width (height) of the lateral eyebrow.
name: Broad lateral eyebrow

desc: The eyebrows extend towards - or even all the way down to - the margin of the upper eyelid.
layperson: Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid
name: Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid
synonyms: Extension of eyebrows towards upper eyelid

desc: An eyebrow that extends laterally beyond the orbital rim rather than turning gently downward at that location.
name: Laterally extended eyebrow

desc: Drooping of the upper eyebrow below the superior orbital rim.
name: Brow ptosis

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the eyebrow.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the eyebrow

desc: Absence of the eyebrow.
name: Absent eyebrow

desc: Decreased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
name: Thin eyebrow

desc: Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of eyebrow hairs.
name: Sparse and thin eyebrow

desc: Decreased density/number of eyebrow hairs.
name: Sparse eyebrow

desc: Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
layperson: Limited hair on end of eyebrow
name: Sparse lateral eyebrow
synonyms: Limited hair on end of eyebrow

desc: Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of medial eyebrow hairs.
name: Sparse medial eyebrow

desc: An abnormality of the nasolacrimal drainage system, which serves as a conduit for tear flow from the external eye to the nasal cavity.
name: Abnormal nasolacrimal system morphology

desc: Inflammation of the nasolacrimal sac.
name: Dacryocystitis

desc: An abnormality of the lacrimal punctum, an opening on the eyelid close to the medial canthus that drains tears from the conjunctival sac into the lacrimal duct in the same eyelid.
name: Abnormal lacrimal punctum morphology

desc: No identifiable superior and/or inferior lacrimal punctum.
name: Absent lacrimal punctum

desc: Congenital absence or closure of the opening of the lacrimal punctum.
name: Lacrimal punctal atresia

desc: Underdevelopment of the lacrimal puncta.
name: Hypoplasia of the lacrimal punctum

desc: Positioning of a lacrimal punctum other than at the medial margins of the eyelid.
name: Ectopic lacrimal punctum
synonyms: Abnormal position of the lacrimal punctum

desc: Punctal stenosis is a condition in which the external opening of the lacrimal canaliculus is narrowed or occluded.
name: Punctal stenosis

desc: A congenital developmental anomaly characterized by the presence of two (instead of the normal one) lacrimal punctum on one or both sides of the face.
name: Duplicated lacrimal punctum

desc: An abnormality of the lacrimal duct, a duct that drain tears from the conjunctiva, via the lacrimal puncta, into the lacrimal sac.
name: Abnormal lacrimal duct morphology

desc: A developmental disorder of the lacrimal drainage system that most often affects the lacrimal ostium and resulting in non-opening of the nasolacrimal duct. It usually results from a non-canalization of the nasolacrimal duct.
name: Lacrimal duct atresia

desc: Blockage of the lacrimal duct.
name: Nasolacrimal duct obstruction

desc: Narrowing of a tear duct (lacrimal duct).
name: Lacrimal duct stenosis

desc: A nasolacrimal duct obstruction presenting as a grey-blue cystic swelling just below the medial canthus. Believed to be a result of concomitant upper obstruction of the Rosenmuller valve and lower obstruction of the Hasner valve.
name: Dacryocystocele

desc: A very common condition in which the extreme end of the nasolacrimal duct underneath the inferior turbinate fails to complete its canalization in the newborn period.
name: Delayed canalization of nasolacrimal duct

desc: A congenital defect resulting in absence of the lacrimal duct.
name: Lacrimal duct aplasia

desc: Congenital malformation of the lacrimal duct associated with incomplete development of the bony nasolacrimal canal or craniofacial anomalies.
name: Malformed lacrimal duct

desc: Abnormality of the lacrimal gland, i.e., of the almond-shaped gland that secretes the aqueous layer of the tear film for each eye.
name: Abnormal lacrimal gland morphology

desc: Abnormally big lacrimal glands.
name: Enlarged lacrimal glands

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland.
name: Aplastic/hypoplastic lacrimal glands

desc: A congenital defect of development characterized by absence of the lacrimal gland.
name: Lacrimal gland aplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the lacrimal gland.
name: Lacrimal gland hypoplasia

desc: An abnormality of a lacrimal sac.
name: Abnormal lacrimal sac morphology

desc: Blockage of the nasolacrimal sac.
name: Nasolacrimal sac obstruction

desc: A mass of granulation tissue in response to chronic dacryocystitis as polypoid formations or they follow accidental injury, from probing and as a reaction to retained foreign bodies in the sac.
name: Nasolacrimal sac granuloma

desc: Benign tumor of the nasolacrimal sac.
name: Nasolacrimal sac papilloma

desc: The malignant epithelial neoplasm with papillary growths in the nasolacrimal sac.
name: Nasolacrimal sac epithelial papillary carcinoma

desc: A type of lymphoma that involves the nasolacrimal sac.
name: Nasolacrimal sac lymphoma

desc: An abnormality of an extraocular muscle.
name: Abnormality of the extraocular muscles

desc: Congenital non-progressive ophthalmoplegia with multiple extraocular muscle restrictions. Typically, there is ptosis and variable degrees of restriction of horizontal and vertical eye movements.
name: Congenital fibrosis of extraocular muscles
synonyms: Congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles

desc: Congenital abnormality of the extraocular muscles.
name: Congenital extraocular muscle anomaly

desc: Congenital absence of the extraocular muscles.
name: Absent extraocular muscles

desc: Atrophy of the superior rectus, the extraocular muscle whose primary function is to elevate the globe.
name: Superior rectus atrophy

desc: An abnormality of an inferior oblique extraocular muscle.
layperson: Abnormality of inferior oblique extraocular muscle
name: Abnormality of inferior oblique extraocular muscle
synonyms: Abnormality of the inferior oblique muscle

desc: An abnormality of an inferior rectus extraocular muscle.

name: Horizontal eyelid laxity

desc: Abnormally lax eyelid associated with tissue relaxation, predominantly in the vertical plane. It can be demonstrated by vertical lid pull. Loosening of vertical stabilising structures (e.g. lower lid retractors) or tarsal atrophy are often present.

desc: Abnormally lax lower eyelid associated with tissue relaxation.

Because of the imprecision in this definition it is preferable to describe these features precisely. This term is retained because it was often used in the past, but it should not be used for new annotations.

desc: A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the face.

desc: A type of facial cleft located near to but not directly on the midline of the face.

desc: As seen in a typical cleft lip, a cleft of the lip is found in the region of the cupid's bow. The nostril is cleft through the alar dome and extends above onto the nasal dorsum. It passes medial to a normal, but dys- topic, medial canthus. There is an alveolar cleft between the central and lateral incisors that extends above through the pyriform margin lateral to the anterior nasal spine; the nasal septum is not involved. The bony cleft extends through the nasal bone or between the junction of the nasal bone and frontal process of the maxilla. Above the cleft lip, the clefting of the alar dome is associated with deviation to the opposite side of the shortened and broadened columella and nasal tip. Extension of the soft tissue cleft onto the nasal dorsum can be manifest as a series of vertical soft tissue furrows and ridges. Vertical inner canthal dysto- pia and severe telecanthus mark the superior aspect of the Number 1 facial cleft. A cranial soft tissue extension characterized by a tongue-like projection of the frontal hairline delineates the number 13 cleft. Skeletal clefting of the maxilla may extend posteriorly to form a complete cleft of the hard and soft palate. The maxilla is hypoplastic in all three dimensions. There is a keel-shaped alveolus and anterior open bite. Normal septation is preserved between the nasal cavity and the hypoplastic maxillary antrum on the affected side. Distortion of the nasal skeleton produces gross flattening of the nasal dorsum. There is asymmetry of the pterygoid plates, of the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid, and of the floor of the anterior cranial fossa. The distortion of the cranial base may result in a mild plagiocephaly.
name: Tessier number 1 facial cleft

desc: As is typically seen in isolated cleft cases, a cleft of the lip is present. There is hypoplasia, but not true notching of the ala nasi with flattening of the lateral part of the nose. The nasal root is broadened, with lateral displacement of the inner canthus. The palpebral fissure and lacrimal drainage system are not disturbed. The alveolar cleft is through the lateral incisor area and extends to the pyriform aperture. There is normal septation between the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus. Notching at the junction between the nasal bone is present, as is a broad, flat frontal process of the maxilla. Transverse ethmoid enlargement produces orbital hypertelorism. Above the cleft of the lip and palate is a true broad cleft of the nostril that is medial to the intact, but laterally displaced, tail of the alar cartilage. A shallow soft tissue groove extends superiorly to the asymmetrically widened nasal root. The lacrimal system, palpebral fissures, and eyebrows remain intact. The alveolar cleft extends posteriorly as a complete unilateral cleft of the hard and soft palate. The nasal septum is intact but deviated to the opposite side. The nasal cavity remains separated from the normally pneumatized, although hypoplastic, maxilla on the cleft side. Above the nasomaxillary notching, the ethmoid sinus is less well developed, and there is no pneumatization of the frontal sinus on this side. Anterior rotation of the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid occurs on the cleft side in relation to the narrower orbit and smaller ethmoid sinus. There is mild asymmetry of the anterior cranial fossa, which is narrower on the cleft side. The cranium is brachycephalic with marked occipital flattening.
name: Tessier number 2 facial cleft

desc: There is a soft tissue cleft medial to the inner canthus with a cleft of the root of the eyebrow. The frontal process of the maxilla is flat and broadened, and the ethmoid labyrinth is increased in tranverse dimension, thereby producing orbital hypertelorism. The cribriform plate is of normal width. The frontal sinus is enlarged. Even though the frontal bone is flattened, bony clefts with encephalocele have not been observed. There is a lateral displacement of the inner canthus with a mild thinning, aplasia, or irregularity of the medial end of the eyebrow. There are no eyelid clefts. The soft tissue contour of the forehead is normal, with only a short downward prolongation of the paramedian frontal hairline to mark the superior extent of the soft tissue cleft. Flattening of the frontal process of the maxilla, an increase in the transverse dimension of the ethmoid sinus, and a laterally convex bowing of the medial orbital wall produce orbital hypertelorism. Superiorly there is a minor flattening of the frontal bone medially, and the nasofrontal angle is somewhat obtuse. The extensive pneumatization of the sinuses on the cleft side extends backward through the frontal and ethmoid sinuses and into the sphenoid sinus. The anatomy of the sphenoid, including the pterygoid processes, is otherwise normal. The anterior and middle cranial fossae floors are both broadened on the cleft side with minor widening of the cribriform plate.
name: Tessier number 12 facial cleft

desc: There is a paramedian frontal encephalocele and a soft tissue cleft that passes medial to an intact eyebrow. The frontal bone shows a paramedian bony cleft with an associated encephalocele. The olfactory groove, cribriform plate, and ethmoid sinus are all increased in transverse diameter, resulting in hypertelorism. The cleft extends medially to the undisturbed eyebrow to end in a short paramedian frontal widow's peak. The bony cleft begins in the region of the nasal bone and extends superiorly through the full height of the frontal bone. Posteriorly, the cleft extends through the cribriform plate and ethmoid sinus as far as the lesser wing and body of the sphenoid. The pterygoid processes are anatomically normal, but they are displaced laterally from the midline on the cleft side. There is orbital hypertelorism below and asymmetry of the floor of the anterior cranial fossa above.
name: Tessier number 13 facial cleft

desc: A facial cleft characterized by involvement of the orbit.
name: Orbital cleft

desc: As in the Number 1 and Number 2 clefts, this cleft extends through the lip in the region of the typical cleft lip; however, it does not extend through the base. The cleft continues superiorly to involve the inner canthus and lower eyelid medial to the inferior lacrimal punctum, thereby disrupting the nasolacrimal system. Microphthalmia may be present. The alveolar cleft is between the lateral incisor and the canine. Absent septation between the nasal cavity and maxillary antrum, together with the distortion of the frontal process of the maxilla and lacrimal fossa, produces direct communication between the orbit, maxillary sinus, and nose. There is hypoplasia of the soft tissue margins of the cleft in the vertical dimension. This produces extreme soft tissue deficiency between the alar base and the cleft of the medial aspect of the lower eyelid. The inferior lacrimal punctum is evident at the lateral margin of the lower eyelid cleft. The lacrimal drainage system ends as an opening directly onto the cheek without communication into the nasal cavity. The globe is normal in size, but it is displaced inferiorly and laterally. The nasal septum shows the characteristic distortion seen in typical cleft lip and palate. There is absence of septation between the nasal cavity on the cleft side and the maxilla. The maxilla is hypoplastic in three dimensions, with a marked reduction in pneumatization. Superior extension of the skeletal clefting into the medial portion of the orbital floor and into the inferior orbital rim in the region of the frontal process of the maxilla allows direct communication between the orbit above and the nasomaxillary region below. There is mild narrowing of the ethmoid sinus and of the body of the sphenoid on the cleft side. The pterygoid process appears anatomically normal, but less displaced from the midline compared with that of the noncleft side. Both the orbit and the floor of the anterior cranial fossa are inferiorly displaced.
name: Tessier number 3 facial cleft

desc: The cleft lip is midway between the philtral ridge and the commissure of the mouth. The cleft is lateral to the normally shaped and placed nasal ala and passes onto the cheek. The cleft extends through the lower eyelid lateral to the punctum. The lacrimal system and inner canthus are normal. Microphthalmia may be present. The alveolar cleft passes between the lateral incisor and canine, as in the Number 3 cleft. The cleft passes around the pyriform aperture and continues through the portion of the maxillary sinus medial to the infraorbital foramen. The cleft terminates at the medial end of the inferior orbital rim. There is severe vertical soft tissue deficiency in a Number 4 cleft, with the medial margins of the cleft lip extending directly into the medially placed cleft of the lower eyelid. Within the medial segment of the right-sided cleft lip, muscle elements are apparently absent. Muscle bunching is noted in the ipsilateral lateral lip segment, as is seen in a typical unilateral cleft lip. The anatomically normal nasal ala is superiorly displaced in association with a severe deficiency in the overall nasal length. Marked dystopia of the right globe results in its inferior displacement into the medially deficient orbital floor and inferior rim. Both globes are otherwise normal. The complete palatal cleft passes through the maxilla medial to the infraorbital foramen and extends to the medial portion of the inferior orbital rim without evidence of an intact maxillary sinus. Bony septation persists medially, thereby separating the nasal cavity from the orbit, maxillary sinus, and mouth, which are contiguous. Marked midfacial hypoplasia is present. The cleft is manifest as asymmetry of the body of the sphenoid; it is smaller on the right, with asymmetric placement of the pterygoid plates relative to the midline. The orbital floor cleft has no communication with the inferior orbital fissure. The cleft does not extend to the skull base, but there is marked facial asymmetry associated with plagiocephaly.
name: Tessier number 4 facial cleft

desc: The cleft of the lip is just medial to the oral commissure and extends across the cheek as a furrow. It ends as a cleft at the junction of the middle and lateral third of the lower eyelid. Microphthalmia is frequently present. The alveolar cleft is through the premolar region and extends superiorly through the orbit at the inferolateral part of the rim and floor. There is a vertical soft tissue deficiency between the lateral portion of the lip and the lower eyelid cleft. The left side of the nose shows vertical shortening, and the left alar base is displaced superiorly. Facial asymmetry secondary to the skeletal abnormality is reflected by a vertical orbital dystopia. However, bothglobes are normal, and there is no abnormality of the upper eyelids, eyebrow, forehead, or frontal hairline. The skeletal clefts vary, ranging from a narrow skeletal furrow that traverses the anterior maxillary wall as on the rightto a broad cleft of the maxilla lateral to the infraorbital foramen and maxillary sinus. This latter cleft enters the inferolateral orbital rim and floor without posterior communication with the inferior orbital fissure on the left side. Medial collapse of the lateral maxillary segments is present bilaterally, with reduction in the transverse dimensions of the maxillary arch. Manifestations of the skeletal disturbance in the sphenoid include a shortening and thickening of the lateral orbital walls in the region of the greater wing and mild asymmetric placement of the pterygoid plates relative to the midline. The right-sided pterygoid plates are smaller and closer to the midline. There is minimal asymmetry of the cranial base and calvarium.
name: Tessier number 5 facial cleft

desc: This is an upper lateral orbital cleft. The soft tissue deformity is in the lateral one-third of the upper eyelid, and the bony cleft is through the superolateral orbital angle. Microphthalmia is present. The superolateral bony deficiency of the orbits allows a lateral displacement of the globes. The lateral one-third of the upper eyelid and the outer canthus are distorted, thus preventing apposition to the globe. The upper eyelid does not have a true cleft. A soft tissue furrow radiates superiorly and posterisphenoid is symmetric and normal. Mild cranial base asymmetry is reflected in the pterygoid plates. The left pair is more laterally displaced from the midline. Skull vault plagiocephaly is evident with an apparent reduction in the anteroposterior dimension of the anterior cranial fossa.
name: Tessier number 9 facial cleft

desc: In a Number 10 Tessier cleft there is an upper central orbital cleft with a cleft of the middle one-third of the upper eyelid, which often results in total ablepharia. The eyebrow is disrupted, being virtually absent medially, whereas the lateral portion angles upward toward the frontal hairline. There may be ocular anomalies, including colobomata of the iris. The skeletal cleft is through the midportion of the supraorbital rim, the adjacent frontal bone, and the orbital roof lateral to the supraorbital nerve. A frontal encephalocele frequently occupies the frontal bony cleft. The palpebral fissure is grossly elongated with an amblyopic eye displaced inferiorly and laterally. There is also a divergent squint of the right eye. The eyebrow is deficient medially and becomes thinned out laterally , where it is contiguous with a broad downward and forward projection of the frontotemporal hairline (this may be seen in both the Number 9 and 10 clefts.) A broad frontal encephalocele bulges forward from the middle one-third of the right forehead, supraorbital ridge, and orbital roof. The bony cleft, through which the frontal encephalocele presents, involves the anterior half of the orbital roof, the supraorbital rim, and two-thirds of the vertical height of the frontal bone lateral to the supraorbital nerve. The bony orbit is inferiorly displaced and widened with the lateral orbital wall shortened and laterally deviated. Similar distortion of the anterior cranial fossa is evident, being broader and more flattened on the affected side. The calvarium above the level of the cleft and the cranial base below is symmetric.
name: Tessier number 10 facial cleft

desc: An upper medial orbital cleft produces a cleft of the medial one-third of the upper eyelid that extends through the eyebrow into the frontal hairline. The skeletal element of the cleft in the region of the frontal process of the maxilla may either pass lateral to the ethmoid, through the supraorbital rim, or it may pass through the ethmoidal labyrinth to produce orbital hypertelorism. This cleft usually accompanies the Number 3 cleft. The soft tissue features include a cleft of the medial portion of the upper eyelid, an irregularity in hair orientation at the medial end of the eyebrow, and a long tongue-like projection of the frontal hairline onto the forehead. There is a mild flattening of the frontal process of the maxilla and extensive pneumatization of both the ethmoidal and frontal sinuses, both of which are more prominent on the cleft side. No bony clefting of the supraorbital rim or frontal bone is evident. The cranial base and sphenoid architecture, including the pterygoid processes, are symmetric and normal.
name: Tessier number 11 facial cleft
