desc: A congenital malformation with a cleft (gap or opening) in the midline of the face.
name: Midline facial cleft

desc: A Number 0 Tessier cleft is a true median cleft lip with a broad columella and bifid nasal tip. The alveolar cleft is between the central incisors. The nasal septum may be thickened, duplicated, or absent. The nasal bridge is usually broad with associated orbital hypertelorism. The midline soft tissue anomaly may range from a mild broadening of the philtrum or there may be a true median cleft lip. The columella and nasal tip are typically bifid and broadened with a midline depression. The alae nasi are intact but laterally displaced. The nose appears shortened in the vertical dimension.
name: Tessier number 0 facial cleft

desc: This midline cranial cleft usually occurs with a midline facial cleft that completes a median craniofacial dysraphia. A broad nasal root and bifid nose are associated with orbital hypertelorism and a median frontal encephalocele. The frontal bone abnormality varies from a minor flattening to a large midline defect. There is an increased distance between the olfactory grooves. The crista galli is widened, duplicated, or in some cases absent. Marked inferior prolapse of the enlarged ethmoid bone occurs with orbital hypertelorism. The severe orbital hypertelorism is associated with a broad flattening of the glabella and extreme lateral displacement of the inner canthi. The periorbita, including the eyelids and eyebrows, are otherwise normal. A long midline projection of the frontal hairline marks the superior extent of the soft tissue features of this midline cranial cleft. The median frontal defect delineates the region through which the frontal encephalocele herniates. The lateral segments of the frontal bone sweep upward from the region of the intact glabella and are flattened laterally. No pneumatization of the frontal sinus is evident. The crista galli and the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid are bifid. Just as the ethmoid, including the cribriform plate, is widened and caudally displaced, the sphenoid sinus is broadened and extensively, but symmetrically pneumatized. The lateral rotation of the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid results in a relative shortening of the anteroposterior dimension of the middle cranial fossa. The floor of the anterior cranial fossa is upslanting from its medial aspect to its lateral aspect, with a harlequin appearance on the coronal scan.
name: Tessier number 14 facial cleft

desc: A lower midline facial cleft, also known as the median mandibular cleft. It is a rare anomaly, which may be limited to a defect in the soft tissue of the lower lip. However, in the more severe form, it may extend into the bony mandibular symphysis.
name: Tessier number 30 facial cleft

desc: A characteristic appearance resulting from defective ossification of craniofacial bones.
name: Craniofacial dysostosis

desc: A type of craniofacial dysostosis associated with abnormalities of the external ears, mirognathia, macrostomia, coloboma of the lower eyelid, and cleft palate. This is a bundled term that is left in the HPO now for convenience with legacy annotations but should not be used for new annotations.
name: Mandibulofacial dysostosis

desc: Excessive growth of the craniofacial bones.
layperson: Excessive bone growth of the skull and face
name: Craniofacial hyperostosis
synonyms: Excessive bone growth of the skull and face

desc: Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
layperson: Increase in size of the facial bones
name: Facial hyperostosis
synonyms: Increase in size of the facial bones

desc: Hyperostosis (bony overgrowth) of the mandible.
name: Mandibular hyperostosis

desc: Paralysis of the facial nerves on the basis of overgrowth of the cranial bones causing impingement upon the seventh cranial nerve.
layperson: Facial palsy secondary to cranial hyperostosis
name: Facial palsy secondary to cranial hyperostosis
synonyms: Facial palsy caused by excessive growth of facial bones
Facial palsy secondary to hypertrophy of cranial bones
Facial palsy caused by enlargement of cranial bones
Facial palsy caused by overgrowth of cranial bones

desc: A reduced degree of voluntary and involuntary facial movements involved in responded to others or expressing emotions.
name: Decreased facial expression

desc: A lack of facial expression often with staring eyes and a slightly open mouth.
name: Mask-like facies

desc: A reduced degree of motion of the muscles beneath the skin of the face, often associated with reduced facial crease formation.
name: Hypomimic face

desc: A facial appearance characteristic of myopathic conditions. The face appears expressionless with sunken cheeks, bilateral ptosis, and inability to elevate the corners of the mouth, due to muscle weakness.
name: Myopathic facies

desc: An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.
name: Disturbance of facial expression

desc: Sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms), involving the eyes and muscles of the face.
name: Facial tics

desc: Fixed sarcastic grimace and anxious expression. Caused by spasms of the masseter and other facial muscles.
name: Risus sardonicus

desc: An increased amount of subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.
name: Increased facial adipose tissue
synonyms: Increased volume of facial adipose tissue
Increased amount of facial adipose tissue

desc: Loss of normal subcutaneous fat tissue in the face.
name: Loss of facial adipose tissue
synonyms: Decreased amount of facial adipose tissue
Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from face
Decreased volume of facial adipose tissue
Loss of facial subcutaneous adipose tissue

name: Progressive loss of facial adipose tissue
synonyms: Progressive loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from face
Loss of subcutaneous adipose tissue from face, progressive
Progressive loss of facial subcutaneous adipose tissue

desc: An anomaly of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Abnormality of facial musculature

desc: Reduced muscle tone of a muscle that is innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Facial hypotonia

desc: Facial myokymia is a fine fibrillary activity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Facial myokymia

desc: Spasticity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve.
name: Spasticity of facial muscles

desc: Underdevelopment of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Hypoplasia of facial musculature

desc: Hypertrophy of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Facial muscle hypertrophy

desc: Reduced strength of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve (the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Weakness of facial musculature

desc: Complete loss of ability to move facial muscles innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve).
name: Facial paralysis

desc: Facial nerve palsy is a dysfunction of cranial nerve VII (the facial nerve) that results in inability to control facial muscles on the affected side with weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure. This can either be present in unilateral or bilateral form.
name: Facial palsy
synonyms: Facial muscle weakness of muscles innervated by CN VII

desc: Facial diplegia refers to bilateral facial palsy (bilateral facial palsy is much rarer than unilateral facial palsy).
name: Facial diplegia

desc: Facial diplegia (that is, bilateral facial palsy) with congenital onset.
name: Congenital facial diplegia

desc: One-sided weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure.
layperson: Paralysis of one side of the face
name: Unilateral facial palsy
synonyms: Paralysis of one side of the face
Weakness of one side of the face

desc: Two-sided or bilateral weakness of the muscles of facial expression and eye closure.
layperson: Weakness of both sides of the face
name: Bilateral facial palsy
synonyms: Weakness of both sides of the face
Paralysis of both sides of the face

desc: Reduced strength of the orbicularis oculi, the circumorbital muscle in the face that closes the eyelid.
name: Weakness of orbicularis oculi muscle

desc: Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in jaw.
name: Jaw hyporeflexia

desc: Any abnormality of the masticatory muscle.
name: Abnormality of masticatory muscle

desc: An abnormality of a masseter muscle.
name: Abnormality of masseter muscle

desc: An abnormality of a medial pterygoid muscle.
name: Abnormality of medial pterygoid muscle

desc: An abnormality of a temporalis muscle.
name: Abnormality of temporalis muscle

desc: An abnormality of a lateral pterygoid muscle.
name: Abnormality of lateral pterygoid muscle

desc: An abnormality of the muscles of the structure of the nose.
name: Abnormality of nasal musculature
synonyms: Abnormality of musculature of the nose

desc: An abnormality of any of the muscles of facial expression, which are innervated by the seventh (VII) cranial nerve and control facial expression.
layperson: Abnormality of muscle of facial expression
name: Abnormality of muscle of facial expression
synonyms: Abnormality of muscle of facial expression
Abnormality of musculature of facial expression

desc: An abnormality of the levator labii superioris alaeque nasi muscle.
layperson: Abnormality of levator labii superioris alaeque nasi muscle
name: Abnormality of levator labii superioris alaeque nasi muscle

desc: An abnormality of an orbicularis oris muscle.
name: Abnormality of orbicularis oris muscle

desc: An abnormality of a depressor anguli oris muscle.
layperson: Abnormality of depressor anguli oris muscle
name: Abnormality of depressor anguli oris muscle

desc: An abnormality of a levator anguli oris.
name: Abnormality of levator anguli oris

desc: An abnormality of a levator labii superioris.
name: Abnormality of levator labii superioris

desc: An abnormality of the platysma muscle.
name: Abnormality of platysma

desc: Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the face.
name: Facial hemangioma

desc: Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells with small endothelial spaces, occurring in the face.
name: Facial capillary hemangioma

desc: Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, occurring in the midline region of the face.
name: Facial midline hemangioma

desc: Hemangioma is a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells. This term refers to facial hemangiomas that have a plaque-like morphology.
name: Plaque-like facial hemangioma

desc: The presence of a sebaceous adenoma with origin in the sebum secreting cells of the skin.
name: Adenoma sebaceum

desc: Symmetrical vermiform facial atrophy that affects mainly the forehead, the chin, the ear lobes and helices. Atrophodermia vermiculata is characterized by erythema and follicular plugs on the cheeks, developing into painless reticular impressions.
name: Atrophodermia vermiculata

desc: Any abnormality of the submandibular region, the region between the mandible and the hyoid bone contains the submandibular and sublingual glands, suprahyoid muscles, submandibular ganglion, and lingual artery.
name: Abnormality of the submandibular region

desc: An anomaly of the pharynx, i.e., of the tubular structure extending from the base of the skull superiorly to the esophageal inlet inferiorly.
name: Abnormality of the pharynx

desc: Underdevelopment of the pharynx.
name: Hypoplasia of the pharynx

desc: Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx.
name: Pharyngeal edema

desc: Inflammation (due to infection or irritation) of the pharynx.
name: Pharyngitis

desc: An abnormality of any of the muscles of the pharynx.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of musculature of pharynx
name: Abnormal morphology of musculature of pharynx
synonyms: Abnormality of muscles of the pharynx

desc: An abnormality of a hypopharynx.
name: Abnormality of hypopharynx

desc: An abnormality of the skull, the bony framework of the head which is comprised of eight cranial and fourteen facial bones.
name: Abnormal skull morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the size of the skull.
name: Abnormality of skull size

desc: An abnormally increased head circumference in a growing child. Head circumference is measured with a nonelastic tape and comprises the distance from above the eyebrows and ears and around the back of the head. The measured HC is then plotted on an appropriate growth chart.
name: Increased head circumference

desc: Occipitofrontal (head) circumference greater than 97th centile compared to appropriate, age matched, sex-matched normal standards. Alternatively, a apparently increased size of the cranium.
name: Macrocephaly

desc: The progressive development of an abnormally large skull.
name: Progressive macrocephaly

desc: A relatively mild degree of macrocephaly in which the head circumference is not above two standard deviations from the mean, but appears dysproportionately large when other factors such as body stature are taken into account.
name: Relative macrocephaly

desc: The presence of an abnormally large skull with onset at birth.
name: Macrocephaly at birth
synonyms: Head circumference large for gestational age

desc: The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly).
name: Postnatal macrocephaly

desc: An abnormally reduced head circumference in a growing child. Head circumference is measured with a nonelastic tape and comprises the distance from above the eyebrows and ears and around the back of the head. The measured HC is then plotted on an appropriate growth chart. Microcephaly is defined as a head circumference (HC) that is great than two standard deviations below the mean of age- and gender-matched population based samples. Severe microcephaly is defined with an HC that is three standard deviations below the mean.
name: Decreased head circumference

desc: Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender.
name: Microcephaly

desc: Head circumference which falls below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender because of insufficient head growth after birth.
name: Postnatal microcephaly
synonyms: Development of small head that was not present at birth

desc: Progressive microcephaly is diagnosed when the head circumference falls progressively behind age- and gender-dependent norms.
name: Progressive microcephaly

desc: Stagnation of head growth seen as flattening of the head circumference curve.
name: Cessation of head growth

desc: Head circumference below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender at birth.
name: Congenital microcephaly
synonyms: Small head circumference present at birth
Head circumference small for gestational age
Decreased head circumference present at birth

desc: Decreased occipito-frontal (head) circumference (OFC). For the microcephaly OFC must be between -3 SD and -2 SD compared to appropriate, age matched, normal standards (i.e. -3 SD <= OFC < -2 SD).
name: Mild microcephaly

desc: An abnormality of the mastoid process, which is the conical prominence projecting from the undersurface of the mastoid portion of the temporal bone.
name: Abnormality of the mastoid
synonyms: Abnormality of mastoid process of temporal bone

desc: An abnormally reduced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.
layperson: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process
name: Delayed pneumatization of the mastoid process

desc: An abnormally advanced degree of pneumatization (i.e., formation of air cells) in the mastoid process with respect to age-dependent norms.
layperson: Advanced pneumatization of the mastoid process
name: Advanced pneumatization of the mastoid process

desc: A developmental anomaly in which the mastoid process fails to form and is thus found to be congenitally absent.
name: Absent mastoid

desc: Abnormality of the sella turcica, a saddle-shaped depression in the sphenoid bone at the base of the human skull.
name: Abnormality of the sella turcica

desc: A deformity of the sella turcica whereby the sella extends further anterior than normal such that the anterior clinoid process appears to overhang it, giving the appearance of the letter J on imaging of the skull.
name: J-shaped sella turcica

desc: An abnormally flat sella turcica.
name: Flat sella turcica

desc: An abnormal enlargement of the sella turcica.
name: Large sella turcica

desc: An abnormally small sella turcica.
name: Small sella turcica

desc: Abnormality of the calvaria, which is the roof of the skull formed by the frontal bone, parietal bones, and occipital bone.
name: Abnormality of the calvaria

desc: Any abnormality of the fontanelles (the regions covered by a thick membrane that normally ossify in the first two years of life) or the cranial sutures (the fibrous joints in which the articulating bones or cartilages of the skull are connected by sutural ligaments ).
layperson: Abnormality of the fontanelles or cranial sutures
name: Abnormality of the fontanelles or cranial sutures

desc: An abnormality of the fontanelle.
name: Abnormality of fontanelles

desc: An abnormality of the anterior fontanelle, i.e., the cranial fontanelle that is located at the intersection of the coronal and sagittal sutures.
layperson: Abnormality of the forehead soft spot
name: Abnormality of the anterior fontanelle
synonyms: Abnormality of the forehead soft spot

desc: Abnormally decreased size of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.
name: Small anterior fontanelle

desc: Enlargement of the anterior fontanelle with respect to age-dependent norms.
name: Wide anterior fontanel

desc: A delay in closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.
layperson: Later than typical closing of soft spot of skull
name: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
synonyms: Late closure of the bregma sutures
Delayed closure of the soft spot on the skull
Late closure of soft spot on the skull
Late closure of large anterior fontanel
Delayed closure of the bregma sutures
Later than typical closing of soft spot of skull

desc: The anterior fontanelle generally ossifies by around the 18th month of life. A persistent open anterior fontanelle is diagnosed if closure is delayed beyond this age.
name: Persistent open anterior fontanelle

layperson: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles
name: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles

desc: Early closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.
name: Premature anterior fontanel closure

desc: In newborns, the two frontal bones, two parietal bones, and one occipital bone are joined by fibrous sutures, which form a small posterior fontanelle, and a larger, diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle. These regions allow for the skull to pass the birth canal and for later growth. The fontanelles gradually ossify, whereby the posterior fontanelle usually closes by eight weeks and the anterior fontanelle by the 9th to 16th month of age. Large fontanelles are diagnosed if the fontanelles are larger than age-dependent norms.
name: Large fontanelles

desc: An enlargement of the posterior fontanelle relative to age-dependent norms.
name: Large posterior fontanelle

desc: An abnormally increased width of the cranial fontanelles and sutures.
name: Widely patent fontanelles and sutures

desc: Normally, the posterior and lateral fontanelles are obliterated by about six months after birth, the anterior fontanelle closes by about the middle of the second year. This term refers to the situation in which the fontanelles close at an inappropriately early time point.
name: Premature closure of fontanelles
synonyms: Early closure of the bregma sutures
Premature closure of the bregma sutures
Premature closure of the cranial sutures
Early closure of the cranial sutures

desc: A fontanelle that is small for age.
name: Small fontanelle

desc: Bony defects situated along the cranial suture lines or at the junction of the bone plates of the skull.
name: Extra fontanelles

desc: Any anomaly of a cranial suture, that is one of the six membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.
name: Abnormality of cranial sutures

desc: Infants normally have two fontanels at birth, the diamond-shaped anterior fontanelle at the junction of the coronal and sagittal sutures, and the posterior fontanelle at the intersection of the occipital and parietal bones. The posterior fontanelle usually closes by the 8th week of life, and the anterior fontanel closes by the 18th month of life on average. This term applies if there is delay of closure of the fontanelles beyond the normal age.
name: Delayed cranial suture closure

desc: Craniosynostosis refers to the premature closure of the cranial sutures. Primary craniosynostosis refers to the closure of one or more sutures due to abnormalities in skull development, and secondary craniosynostosis results from failure of brain growth.
name: Craniosynostosis

desc: Premature closure of the coronal suture of skull.
name: Coronal craniosynostosis

desc: Synostosis affecting only one of the coronal sutures.
name: Unicoronal synostosis

desc: Synostosis affecting only the left coronal suture.
name: Left unicoronal synostosis

desc: Unicoronal synostosis affecting only the right coronal suture.
name: Right unicoronal synostosis

desc: Synostosis affecting the right and the left coronal suture.
name: Bicoronal synostosis

desc: A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the sagittal suture.
layperson: Early closure of midline skull joint
name: Sagittal craniosynostosis
synonyms: Early closure of midline skull joint

desc: A kind of craniosynostosis affecting the lambdoidal suture.
name: Lambdoidal craniosynostosis

desc: Premature synostosis of both lambdoid sutures.
name: Bilambdoid synostosis

desc: Premature synostosis of only one lambdoid suture.
name: Unilambdoid synostosis

desc: Premature synostosis of only the left lambdoid suture.
name: Left unilambdoid synostosis

desc: Premature synostosis of only the right lambdoid suture.
name: Right unilambdoid synostosis

desc: Craniosynostosis involving at least 2 cranial sutures, where the exact pattern of sutures fused has not been precisely specified.
name: Multiple suture craniosynostosis

desc: Craniosynostosis of all calvarial sutures.
name: Pansynostosis

desc: The presence of extra bones within a cranial suture. Wormian bones are irregular isolated bones which appear in addition to the usual centers of ossification of the cranium.
name: Wormian bones
synonyms: Islands of bone within cranial sutures

desc: An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration.
name: Sclerotic cranial sutures

desc: The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
name: Widely patent coronal suture

desc: The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
name: Widely patent sagittal suture

desc: An abnormally increased width of the cranial sutures for age-related norms (generally resulting from delayed closure).
name: Wide cranial sutures

desc: An overlap of the bony plates of the skull in an infant, with or without early closure.
name: Ridged cranial sutures

desc: A cranial suture that is in addition to canonical membrane-covered openings in the incompletely ossified skull of the fetus or newborn infant.
name: Accessory cranial suture

desc: An abnormal increase of density of the bones making up the calvaria.
name: Dense calvaria

desc: The presence of an abnormal shape of the calvaria (skullcap), that is, of that part of the skull that is made up of the superior portions of the frontal bone, occipital bone, and parietal bones and covers the cranial cavity that contains the brain.
layperson: Abnormality of the shape of cranium
name: Abnormality of calvarial morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the shape of cranium
Abnormality of the shape of calvarium
Abnormality of the shape of skull bones

desc: Wedge-shaped, or triangular head, with the apex of the triangle at the midline of the forehead and the base of the triangle at the occiput.
name: Trigonocephaly

desc: An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a decreased anterior-posterior diameter. That is, a cephalic index greater than 81%. Alternatively, an apparently shortened anteroposterior dimension (length) of the head compared to width.
name: Brachycephaly

desc: Abnormal vertical height of the skull and a shortening of its anterior-posterior length, frequently combined with malformations of the occipital region.
name: Brachyturricephaly

desc: An abnormality of head shape characterized by the presence of a short, wide head as well as a pointy or conical form of the top of the head owing to premature closure of the coronal and lambdoid sutures.
name: Acrobrachycephaly

desc: Tall head relative to width and length.
name: Turricephaly

desc: Oxycephaly (from Greek oxus, sharp, and kephalos, head) refers to a conical or pointed shape of the skull.
name: Oxycephaly

desc: Asymmetry of the bones of the skull.
name: Cranial asymmetry

desc: An abnormality of skull shape characterized by a increased anterior-posterior diameter, i.e., an increased antero-posterior dimension of the skull. Cephalic index less than 76%. Alternatively, an apparently increased antero-posterior length of the head compared to width. Often due to premature closure of the sagittal suture.
name: Dolichocephaly

desc: Scaphocephaly is a subtype of dolichocephaly where the anterior and posterior aspects of the cranial vault are pointed (boat-shaped). Scaphocephaly is caused by a precocious fusion of sagittal suture without other associated synostosis.
name: Scaphocephaly

desc: Asymmetric head shape, which is usually a combination of unilateral occipital flattening with ipsilateral frontal prominence, leading to rhomboid cranial shape.
name: Plagiocephaly

desc: Asymmetry of the anterior part of the skull.
name: Anterior plagiocephaly

desc: Asymmetry of the posterior part of the skull.
name: Posterior plagiocephaly

desc: A localized defect in the bone of the skull resulting from abnormal embryological development. The defect is covered by normal skin. In some cases, skull x-rays have shown underlying lytic bone lesions which have closed before the age of one year.
name: Calvarial skull defect

desc: Trilobar skull configuration when viewed from the front or behind.
name: Cloverleaf skull

desc: Increased width of the skull.
name: Broad skull

desc: A developmental malformation of the occipital bone and upper end of the cervical spine, in which the latter appears to have pushed the floor of the occipital bone upward such that there is an abnormal flattening of the skull base.
name: Platybasia
synonyms: Obtuse basal angle of skull base
Increased basal angle of skull base

desc: Any abnormality of the parietal bone of the skull.
name: Abnormal parietal bone morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the parietal bone of skull

desc: Parietal bossing is a marked prominence in the parietal region.
name: Parietal bossing
Symmetrical, oval parietal bone defects
synonyms: Symmetrical, oval defects in the parietal bone

desc: The presence of symmetrical and circular openings (foramina) in the parietal bone ranging in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters wide.
name: Parietal foramina
synonyms: Persistent foramina of the parietal bones

desc: A narrowing of the biparietal diameter (i.e., of the transverse distance between the protuberances of the two parietal bones of the skull).
name: Biparietal narrowing

desc: An abnormal shape of occiput.
name: Abnormal shape of the occiput
synonyms: Abnormal shape of the back of the head
Abnormal shape of the back of the skull

desc: Increased convexity of the occiput (posterior part of the skull).
name: Prominent occiput

desc: Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
name: Flat occiput

desc: An abnormal shape of the frontal part of the head.
name: Abnormal shape of the frontal region
synonyms: Abnormal morphology of the frontal region

desc: Underdevelopment of the frontal bone.
layperson: Decreased size of bone of forehead
name: Hypoplasia of the frontal bone
synonyms: Decreased size of bone of forehead

desc: Absence of the spongy bone structure (or tissue) of the internal part of the skull cap (i.e., of the calvarial diploe).
name: Obliteration of the calvarial diploe

desc: Partial or complete absence of the flat bones of the cranial vault. The condition is frequently, though not always, associated with anencephaly.
name: Acrania

desc: Extreme width of the skull in the occipital region, with anterior narrowing and prognathism.
name: Platystencephaly

desc: The presence of an abnormally thick calvaria.
name: Thickened calvaria

desc: Excessive growth of the bones of cranium, i.e., of the skull.
name: Cranial hyperostosis

desc: Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the frontal bone.
name: Hyperostosis frontalis interna
synonyms: Excessive growth of inner surface of the frontal bone
Overgrowth of the inside of the frontal bone
Hypertrophy of the internal surface of the frontal bone
Thick internal surface of the frontal bone
Overgrowth of the inner surface of the frontal bone
Thick inner surface of the frontal bone
Increased ossification of the internal surface of the frontal bone
Enlargement of the inner surface of the frontal bone
Hyperostosis of the internal surface of the frontal bone

desc: Excessive growth of the calvaria.
name: Calvarial hyperostosis

desc: Bony overgrowth of the internal (endosteal) surface of the calvaria and the base of skull.
layperson: Overgrowth of the inner surface of the skull bones
name: Hyperostosis cranialis interna
synonyms: Overgrowth of the inside of the skull
Hyperostosis of the internal surface of the cranial bone
Increased ossification of the internal surface of the cranial bones
Thick inner surface of the skull bones
Overgrowth of the inner surface of the skull bones
Thick internal surface of the cranial bones
Hypertrophy of the internal surface of the cranial bones
Excessive growth of inner surface of the skull bones
Hyperostosis of the internal surface of the cranial bones
Enlargement of the inner surface of the skull bones

desc: Abnormal reduction in ossification of the calvaria (roof of the skull consisting of the frontal bone, parietal bones, temporal bones, and occipital bone).
name: Decreased calvarial ossification

desc: Absent ossification of the calvaria (vault of the skull).
name: Absent ossification of calvaria

desc: The presence of an abnormally thin calvarium.
name: Thin calvarium

desc: An abnormality of the base of the skull, which forms the floor of the cranial cavity and separates the brain from other facial structures. The skull base is made up of five bones: the ethmoid, sphenoid, occipital, paired frontal, and paired parietal bones, and is subdivided into 3 regions: the anterior, middle, and posterior cranial fossae. The petro-occipital fissure subdivides the middle cranial fossa into 1 central component and 2 lateral components.
name: Abnormality of the skull base

layperson: Elevated imprint of the transverse sinuses
name: Elevated imprint of the transverse sinuses
synonyms: Elevated imprint of occipital bone over the transverse sinuses
Thinning and bulging of occipital bone over the transverse sinuses
Thinning and bulging of posterior skull bones over the transverse sinuses
Elevated imprint of posterior skull bones over the transverse sinuses

desc: An abnormality of the fossa cranii posterior (the posterior fossa), which is made up primarily of the occipital bone and which surrounds to the foramen magnum.
layperson: Abnormality of the posterior cranial fossa
name: Abnormality of the posterior cranial fossa

layperson: Thinning and bulging of the posterior fossa bones
name: Thinning and bulging of the posterior fossa bones
synonyms: Thinning and bulging of occipital bone of skull
Thinning and bulging of posterior fossa bones
Thinning and bulging of posterior skull bones

desc: A congenital brain malformation typically characterized by incomplete formation of the cerebellar vermis, dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. In layman's terms, Dandy Walker malformation is a cyst in the cerebellum (typically symmetrical) that is involved with the fourth ventricle. This may interfere with the ability to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, resulting in hydrocephalus. Dandy Walker cysts are formed during early embryonic development, while the brain forms. The cyst in the cerebellum typically has several blood vessels running through it connecting to the brain, thereby prohibiting surgical removal.
name: Dandy-Walker malformation

desc: Abnormal elevation of the floor of the posterior fossa including occipital condyles and foramen magnum.
name: Basilar impression

desc: A discrete posterior fossa cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) collection that does not communicate directly with the fourth ventricle.
name: Posterior fossa cyst

layperson: Posterior fossa cyst at the fourth ventricle
name: Posterior fossa cyst at the fourth ventricle

desc: An abnormality of the clivus, which is the inclined bony region of the posterior cranial fossa located between the sella turcica and the foramen magnum.
name: Abnormality of the clivus

desc: An abnormal vertical orientation of the clivus (which normally forms a kind of slope from the sella turcica down to the region of the foramen magnum).
name: Vertical clivus

desc: Projection of the tip of the dens more than 5 mm above a line joining the hard palate to the posterior lip of the foramen magnum (Chamberlain's line) or the tip of the dens is greater than 7 mm above McGregor's line (the back of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital squama).
name: Basilar invagination

desc: An abnormally small and flat configuration of the posterior cranial fossa.
name: Small flat posterior fossa
synonyms: Small and flat posterior fossa of skull
Small and flat posterior skull bones

desc: Increased bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.
name: Sclerosis of skull base

desc: Progressively increasing bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.
name: Progressive sclerosis of skull base
Thick skull base
synonyms: Increased thickness of bone of skull base

desc: A bony defect in the skull base.
name: Cleft in skull base

desc: Any abnormality of the foramen magnum.
name: Abnormality of the foramen magnum

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the foramen magnum.
name: Small foramen magnum

desc: An abnormal increase in the size of the foramen magnum.
name: Large foramen magnum

desc: An abnormality of the process of ossification of the skull.
name: Abnormality of skull ossification
synonyms: Abnormality of bone mineralization of cranium
Abnormality of bone calcification of skull
Abnormality of bone formation of calvarium
Abnormality of bone calcification of cranium
Abnormality of bone mineralization of skull
Abnormality of bone formation of cranium
Abnormality of bone calcification of calvarium
Abnormality of bone mineralization of calvarium

desc: An increase in the magnitude or amount of ossification of the skull.
name: Increased skull ossification

desc: Increased bone density affecting the bones of the spine (vertebral column).
name: Increased spinal bone density

desc: A reduction in the magnitude or amount of ossification of the skull.
name: Decreased skull ossification

layperson: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the skull
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the skull

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the maxilla.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the maxilla

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the mandible.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the mandible

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the mandible.
name: Micrognathia

desc: A form of developmental hypoplasia of the mandible in which the mandible is mislocalised posteriorly.
name: Microretrognathia

desc: Abnormally small dimension of the mandible (lower jaw) relative to the maxilla (upper jaw).
layperson: Hypoplasia of mandible relative to maxilla
name: Hypoplasia of mandible relative to maxilla
synonyms: Disorder of mandibular and maxillary dental arch relationship

desc: Absence of the mandible.
name: Mandibular aplasia
synonyms: Aplasia of the lower jaw bone
Failure of development of lower jaw

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of a cranial sinus or sinuses.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the sinuses

desc: Aplasia or hypoplasia of the paranasal sinuses.
name: Absent/hypoplastic paranasal sinuses

desc: Aplasia of the paranasal sinuses.
name: Absent paranasal sinuses

desc: Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus.
name: Absent ethmoidal sinuses
synonyms: Failure of development of ethmoid sinuses

desc: Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses.
name: Paranasal sinus hypoplasia

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of frontal sinus.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the frontal sinuses

desc: Aplasia of frontal sinus.
name: Absent frontal sinuses

desc: Underdevelopment of frontal sinus.
name: Hypoplastic frontal sinuses

desc: Abnormality of the temporal bone of the skull, which is situated at the sides and base of the skull roughly underlying the region of the face known as the temple.
name: Abnormal temporal bone morphology

desc: A developmental defect characterized by the lack of formation of the carotid canal, which normally is a circular aperture in the temporal bone of the skull through which the internal carotid artery and the carotid plexus of nerves traverse.
name: Agenesis of the carotid canal

desc: Underdevelopment of the carotid canal, which normally is a circular aperture in the temporal bone of the skull through which the internal carotid artery and the carotid plexus of nerves traverse.
name: Hypoplastic carotid canal

desc: A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.
name: Cephalocele

desc: A neural tube defect characterized by sac-like protrusions of the brain and the membranes that cover it through openings in the skull.
name: Encephalocele

desc: A type of encephalocele (that is, a a protrusion of part of the cranial contents including brain tissue through a congenital opening in the cranium, typically covered with skin or mucous membrane) in the occipital region of the skull. Occipital encephalocele presents as a midline swelling over the occipital bone. It is usually covered with normal full-thickness scalp.
layperson: Brain tissue sticks out through back of skull
name: Occipital encephalocele
synonyms: Brain tissue sticks out through back of skull

desc: An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda.
name: Parietal encephalocele

desc: Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.
name: Basal encephalocele

desc: A congenital defect in the occipital region of the skull, covered by skin of the scalp and containing meninges or remnants of glial or neural tissues.
name: Atretic occipital cephalocele

desc: An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton.
name: Abnormality of facial skeleton

desc: Abnormality of the paranasal (cranial) sinuses, which are air-filled spaces that are located within the bones of the skull and face and communicate with the nasal cavity. They comprise the maxillary sinuses, the frontal sinuses, the ethmoid sinuses, and the sphenoid sinuses.
layperson: Abnormality of the sinuses of the head
name: Abnormality of the paranasal sinuses
synonyms: Abnormality of the sinuses of the head

desc: Inflammation of the paranasal sinuses owing to a viral, bacterial, or fungal infection, allergy, or an autoimmune reaction.
name: Sinusitis

desc: An acute form of sinusitis.
name: Acute sinusitis

desc: A chronic form of sinusitis.
name: Chronic sinusitis

desc: An abnormality of the frontal sinus, one of the mucosa-lined, normally air-filled paranasal sinuses of the bones of the skull. The frontal sinus is located within the frontal bone.
name: Abnormality of frontal sinus

desc: A degree of pneumatization that is increased compared to age-related norms.
name: Advanced pneumatization of cranial sinuses

desc: An abnormality of the sphenoid sinus, one of the mucosa-lined, normally air-filled paranasal sinuses of the bones of the skull. The sphenoid sinus is located within the sphenoid bone.
name: Abnormality of the sphenoid sinus

desc: An abnormality of the maxillary sinus, one of the mucosa-lined, normally air-filled paranasal sinuses of the bones of the skull. The maxillary sinus is located within the skeleton of the midface, lateral to the nasal cavity.
layperson: Abnormality of the upper jaw sinus
name: Abnormality of the maxillary sinus
synonyms: Abnormality of the upper jaw sinus
Abnormality of the antrum of Highmore

desc: An abnormality of an ethmoid sinus.
name: Abnormality of ethmoid sinus

desc: An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively small in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures.
name: Hypoplasia of the premaxilla
synonyms: Decreased size of the primary palate bone
Hypoplasia of the primary palate bone
Underdevelopment of the primary palate bone

desc: Underdevelopment of the zygomatic bone. That is, a reduction in size of the zygomatic bone, including the zygomatic process of the temporal bone of the skull, which forms part of the zygomatic arch.
name: Hypoplasia of the zygomatic bone

desc: Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex.
name: Maxillozygomatic hypoplasia
synonyms: Decreased size of zygomaticomaxillary bone complex
Decreased projection of zygomaticomaxillary bone complex

desc: Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.
name: Craniofacial osteosclerosis

desc: An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).
name: Calvarial osteosclerosis

desc: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull).
layperson: Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull
name: Osteosclerosis of the base of the skull

desc: An abnormality of the zygomatic bone.
name: Abnormality of the zygomatic bone

desc: An abnormality of the zygomatic arch, also known as the cheek bone.
name: Abnormality of the zygomatic arch

desc: Large or prominent malar surface of the zygomatic bone of the skull, which is convex and forms the prominence of the 'cheek bones'.
name: Prominence of the zygomatic bone

desc: A structural anomaly of the jaw, the bony structure of the mouth that consists of the mandible and the maxilla.
name: Abnormal jaw morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the mandible, the bone of the lower jaw.
name: Abnormality of the mandible
synonyms: Malformation of the lower jaw bone
Deformity of the lower jaw bone
Abnormality of the lower jaw bone

desc: Limitation in the ability to open the mouth.
name: Trismus

desc: An abnormality in which the mandible is mislocalised posteriorly.
name: Retrognathia

desc: Recurrent partial dislocations of the mandible.
name: Recurrent mandibular subluxations

desc: Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
name: Obtuse angle of mandible

desc: Osteomyelitis of the lower jaw.
name: Mandibular osteomyelitis

desc: Lack of symmetry between the left and right mandible.
name: Asymmetry of the mandible
synonyms: Lower jaw shifted to one side

desc: Midline deficiency of the mandible and some or all overlying tissues.
name: Cleft mandible

desc: An anomaly of the temporomandibular joint.
name: Abnormality of the temporomandibular joint

desc: Bony fusion of the mandibular condyle to the base of the skull, resulting in limitation of jaw opening.
name: Temporomandibular joint ankylosis

desc: Noises from the temporomandibular joint during mandibular movement (e.g., chewing). Temporomandibular joint crepitus is often described as a clicking, popping, grating sound.
name: Temporomandibular joint crepitus

desc: Formation of one or more fibrous bands within the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) with resulting limitation of movement of the TMJ. Adhesions may be seen in degenerative processes that involve the TMJ.
name: Temporomandibular joint adhesion

desc: Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 standard deviations below the mean (objective); or an apparently decreased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
name: Narrow jaw

desc: Bigonial distance (lower facial width) more than 2 SD above the mean (objective); or an apparently increased width of the lower jaw (mandible) when viewed from the front (subjective).
name: Broad jaw

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the mandible.
name: Mandibular pain

desc: An abnormality of the Maxilla (upper jaw bone).
layperson: Abnormality of the upper jaw bone
name: Abnormality of the maxilla
synonyms: Deformity of the upper jaw bones
Malformation of the upper jaw bones
Abnormality of the upper jaw bone
Abnormality of the upper jaw bones

desc: Abnormally small dimension of the Maxilla. Usually creating a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or resulting in a deficient amount of projection of the base of the nose and lower midface region.
name: Hypoplasia of the maxilla

desc: Underdevelopment of the anterior nasal spine of maxilla.
layperson: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
name: Hypoplasia of the anterior nasal spine
synonyms: Decreased size of anterior nasal spine
Decreased length of anterior nasal spine
Decreased projection of anterior nasal spine

desc: Abnormally small dimension of the maxilla (upper jaw) relative to the mandible (lower jaw).
layperson: Hypoplasia of maxilla relative to mandible
name: Hypoplasia of maxilla relative to mandible
synonyms: Disorder of maxillary and mandibular dental arch relationship

layperson: Decreased breadth of upper jaw bones
name: Narrow maxilla
synonyms: Decreased width of upper jaw bones
Decreased breadth of upper jaw bones

desc: A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla.
name: Aplasia of the maxilla
synonyms: Aplasia of the upper jaw bones
Failure of development of upper jaw bones

desc: Asymmetry between the left and right sides of the maxilla.
name: Asymmetry of the maxilla
synonyms: Asymmetry of right and left side of the maxilla

desc: An abnormality of the premaxilla, the most anterior part of the maxilla that usually bears the central and lateral incisors and includes the anterior nasal spine and inferior aspect of the piriform rim. The premaxilla contains the bone and teeth of the primary palate.
name: Abnormality of the premaxilla
synonyms: Abnormality of the primary palate bone
Abnormality of the intermaxillary segment of the maxilla

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the premaxilla.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the premaxilla
synonyms: Aplasia/hypoplasia of the primary palate bone

desc: Absence of the premaxilla, which is the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla.
name: Aplasia of the premaxilla
synonyms: Aplasia of the primary palate bone
Absence of the primary palate bone
Failure of development of the primary palate bone

desc: Prominent positioning of the premaxilla in relation to the rest of the maxilla, the facial skeleton, or mandible. Not necessarily caused by an increase in size (hypertrophy of) the premaxilla.
name: Prominence of the premaxilla
synonyms: Anterior position of the primary palate bone
Prominence of the primary palate bone

desc: An abnormality of the premaxilla (the embryonic structure that forms the anterior part of the maxilla) causing it to appear relatively large in size compared to the other parts of the maxilla or other facial structures.
name: Hyperplasia of the premaxilla
synonyms: Increased size of the primary palate bone
Hyperplasia of the primary palate bone

desc: An arteriovenous malformation is a disruption of the normal vascular pattern in which arteries or arterioles connect directly to the venous collection system, bypassing any capillary bed. This term refers to an arteriovenous malformation located in the maxilla.
name: Arteriovenous malformation of the maxilla

desc: Abnormally increased dimension of the maxilla, especially relative to the mandible, resulting in a malocclusion or malalignment between the upper and lower teeth or in anterior positioning of the nasal base, increased convexity of the face, increased nasolabial angle, or increased width (transverse dimension of the maxilla.
name: Hyperplasia of the maxilla

desc: An abnormality of a frontal process of the maxilla bone.
layperson: Abnormality of frontal process of maxilla
name: Abnormality of frontal process of maxilla

desc: A tumor originating in the jaw (mandible or maxilla).
name: Jaw neoplasm

desc: Abnormal enlargement in the upper jaw (maxilla) or in the lower jaw (mandible).
name: Jaw swelling
Aplasia of facial bones
synonyms: Failure of development of facial bones
Failure of development of facial skeleton

desc: An abnormality of the vomer.
name: Abnormality of vomer

desc: An abnormality of the frontal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the bone of the forehead
name: Abnormality of the frontal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the bone of the forehead

desc: An abnormality of the lacrimal bone.
name: Abnormality of the lacrimal bone

desc: An abnormality of the palatine bone.
name: Abnormality of the palatine bone

desc: Failure to complete ossification (maturation and calcification) of the palatine bone.
name: Incomplete ossification of palatine bone

desc: Lack of formation of the palatine bone.
name: Absent palatine bone ossification

desc: An abnormality of the ethmoid bone
name: Abnormality of ethmoid bone

desc: Abnormality of the occipital bone of the skull.
name: Abnormality of the occipital bone

desc: Any anomaly of the scalp, the skin an subcutaneous tissue of the head on which head hair grows.
name: Abnormality of the scalp

desc: The presence of convoluted folds and furrows formed from thickened skin of the scalp, resembling cerebriform pattern. The scalp has convoluted and elevated folds, 1 to 2 cm in thickness. The convolutions generally cannot be flattened by traction.
layperson: Thickened folds on top of scalp
name: Cutis gyrata of scalp
synonyms: Furrows in thickened skin on top of scalp
Thickened folds on top of scalp

desc: An abnormality of the hair of head.
name: Abnormality of the scalp hair

desc: Decreased number of hairs per unit area of skin of the scalp.
name: Sparse scalp hair
synonyms: Reduction in the number of scalp follicles

name: Scarring alopecia of scalp
synonyms: Hair loss on scalp from scarring condition

desc: The hairline refers to the outline of hair of the head. An abnormality of the hairline can refer to an unusually low or high border between areas of the scalp with and without hair or to abnormal projections of scalp hair.
name: Abnormality of the hairline

desc: An tongue-like extension of hair towards the cheeks, in which hair growth extends in front of the ear to the lateral cheekbones.
layperson: Projection of scalp hair onto lateral cheek
name: Preauricular hair displacement
synonyms: Projection of scalp hair onto lateral cheek
Hair displacement, preauricular, towards lateral cheekbone

desc: An anomaly in the placement or shape of the hairline (trichion) on the back of the head (neck), that is, the border between skin on the back of the head that has head hair.
layperson: Abnormality of hairline at back of head
name: Abnormality of the posterior hairline
synonyms: Abnormality of hairline at back of head

desc: Hair on the neck extends more inferiorly than usual.
layperson: Low hairline at back of neck
name: Low posterior hairline
synonyms: Low hairline at back of neck

desc: Hair on the neck extends less inferiorly than usual.
layperson: High hairline at back of head
name: High posterior hairline
synonyms: High hairline at back of head

desc: Scalp hair whose growth is slower than normal.
name: Slow-growing scalp hair

desc: Pain or discomfort of the scalp elicited by palpation.
name: Scalp tenderness

desc: Head is bent in the posterior direction in a permanent fashion.
name: Fixed head retroflexion

desc: An abnormality of a blood vessel of the head, including branches of the arterial and venous systems of the head.
layperson: Abnormality of blood vessel of head
name: Abnormality of head blood vessel
synonyms: Abnormality of blood vessel of head

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal artery.
name: Retinal arterial tortuosity

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of retinal blood vessels (arteries, arterioles, veins, venules).
name: Central retinal vessel vascular tortuosity

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal arterioles.
name: Retinal arteriolar tortuosity

desc: Blockage of retinal arteriole, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to affected regions of the retina.
name: Retinal arteriolar occlusion

desc: Decreased retinal arteriolar diameters, which may decrease blood flow and slow oxygen delivery to regions of the retina.
name: Retinal arteriolar constriction

desc: Pallor of the perifoveal macula of the retina with appearance of a small circular reddish choroid shape as seen through the fovea centralis due to relative transparancy of the macula.
layperson: Cherry red spot of the macula
name: Cherry red spot of the macula

desc: Blockage of the retinal artery, generally associated with interruption of blood flow and oxygen delivery to the retina.
name: Retinal arterial occlusion

desc: Blockage of a branch of the retinal artery. This can cause loss of a section of visual field.
name: Branch retinal artery occlusion

desc: Blockage of the cilioretinal artery. The central retinal artery supplies the inner retina and the surface of the optic nerve. In some individuals, the cilioretinal artery, a branch of the ciliary circulation, may supply a portion of the retina including the macula. In cilioretinal artery occlusion, vision loss results from cell death in the inner retinal layers (mainly ganglion cells) despite relative sparing of the outer layers.
name: Cilioretinal artery occlusion

desc: A partial or complete obstruction of the ophthalmic artery (branch of the internal carotid artery) that may lead to severe ischemia of the affected globe and associated ocular tissues. It can present with a similar picture to central retinal artery occlusion; however, profound choroidal ischaemia also occurs.
name: Ophthalmic artery occlusion

desc: Blockage of the main artery in the retina. The typical presentation is one of profound monocular visual loss.
name: Central retinal artery occlusion

desc: Acquired focal dilatations of branches of the retinal artery, usually second-order retinal arterioles, that range in size from 100 to 200 micrometers in diameter. Macroaneurysms are generally located at the termporal retina and may be hemorrhagic or exudative.
name: Retinal arterial macroaneurysms

desc: An abnormality of a facial vein.
name: Abnormal facial vein morphology

desc: An abnormality of an internal carotid artery.
name: Abnormal internal carotid artery morphology

layperson: Decreased size of internal carotid artery
name: Internal carotid artery hypoplasia
synonyms: Decreased size of internal carotid artery

desc: Abnormality of the first branch of the internal carotid artery.
name: Abnormality of ophthalmic artery

desc: An abnormality of an anterior ethmoidal artery.
name: Abnormality of anterior ethmoidal artery

desc: An abnormality of a central retinal artery.
name: Abnormality of central retinal artery

desc: An abnormality of a dorsal nasal artery.
name: Abnormality of dorsal nasal artery

desc: An abnormality of a lacrimal artery.
name: Abnormal lacrimal artery morphology

desc: An abnormality of the neck.
name: Abnormality of the neck

desc: Pterygium colli is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders. It involves an ectopic fibrotic facial band superficial to the trapezius muscle. Excess hair-bearing skin is also present and extends down the cervical region well beyond the normal hairline.
name: Webbed neck

desc: An increased amount of subcutaneous fat tissue around the neck.
name: Increased adipose tissue around the neck

desc: Diminished length of the neck.
name: Short neck

desc: Increased inferior-superior length of the neck.
name: Long neck

desc: A thickening of the skin thickness in the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. A nuchal fold measurement is obtained in a transverse section of the fetal head at the level of the cavum septum pellucidum and thalami, angled posteriorly to include the cerebellum. The measurement is taken from the outer edge of the occiput bone to the outer skin limit directly in the midline. A measurement 6 mm or more is considered significant between 18 and 24 weeks and a measurement of 5 mm or more is considered significant at 16 to 18 weeks (PMID:16100637).
name: Thickened nuchal skin fold

desc: Increased side-to-side width of the neck.
name: Broad neck

desc: A cystic lymphatic lesion of the neck.
name: Cystic hygroma

desc: The presence during the prenatal period of a cystic mass with multiple septa with multiple, asymmetric, thin-walled cysts near the posterior aspect of the neck. Fetal cystic hygroma can be defined as nuchal translucency with or without septations measuring greater than 3.0 mm.
name: Fetal cystic hygroma

layperson: Restricted neck mobility due to contractures
name: Restricted neck movement due to contractures
synonyms: Restricted neck movement due to contractures
Restricted neck mobility due to contractures

desc: A sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side.
name: Stiff neck

desc: Resistance of the extensor muscles of the neck to being bent forwards (i.e., impaired neck flexion) as a result of muscle spasm of the extensor muscles of the neck. Nuchal rigidity is not a fixed rigidity. Nuchal rigidity has been used as a bedside test for meningism, although its sensitivity for this purpose has been debated.
name: Nuchal rigidity

desc: Excess skin around the neck, often lying in horizontal folds.
name: Redundant neck skin

desc: Underdevelopment of muscles of the neck.
name: Neck muscle hypoplasia

desc: Congenital developmental defect arising from the primitive branchial apparatus.
name: Branchial anomaly

desc: A congenital fistula in the neck resulting from incomplete closure of a branchial cleft.
name: Branchial fistula

desc: A branchial cyst is a remnant of embryonic development resulting from a failure of obliteration of a branchial cleft and consists of a subcutaneous cystic mass. Cysts are located anterior or posterior to the ear or in the submandibular region.
name: Branchial cyst

desc: A congenital branchial sinus is a remnant of the embryonic branchial arches and their intervening clefts and pouches that has failed to regress completely. Sinuses typically have their external orifice inferior to the ramus of the mandible. They may traverse the parotid gland, and run in close vicinity to the facial nerve in the external auditory canal.
name: Branchial sinus

desc: An abnormality of the neck musculature.
name: Abnormal morphology of the musculature of the neck
synonyms: Abnormality of the musculature of the neck

desc: Involuntary contractions of the neck musculature resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head.
name: Torticollis

desc: A form of torticollis in which the head is drawn back, either due to a permanent contractures of neck extensor muscles, or to a spasmodic contracture.
name: Retrocollis

desc: A congenital form of torticollis resulting from shortening of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and leading to a limited range of motion in both rotation and lateral bending.
name: Congenital muscular torticollis

desc: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the muscles of the neck.
name: Neck muscle hypertrophy

desc: An abnormality of a geniohyoid muscle.
name: Abnormality of geniohyoid muscle

desc: An abnormality of a blood vessel of the neck, including branches of the arterial and venous systems of the neck.
layperson: Abnormality of blood vessel of neck
name: Abnormality of neck blood vessel
synonyms: Abnormality of blood vessel of neck
Abnormality of the cervical blood vessels
Abnormality of the vasculature of the neck

desc: Any structural abnormality of a jugular vein.
name: Abnormal jugular vein morphology

desc: An abnormality of an external jugular vein of the neck.
name: Abnormality of external jugular vein

desc: An abnormality of an internal jugular vein.
name: Abnormality of internal jugular vein

desc: Any structural abnormality of a lateral crico-arytenoid muscle, which extends from the lateral cricoid cartilage to the muscular process of the arytenoid cartilage, and can adduct the vocal cords, which closes the rima glottidis and thereby protects the airway.
name: Abnormal lateral cricoarytenoid muscle morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the eye, including location, spacing, and intraocular abnormalities.
name: Abnormality of the eye

desc: A structural anomaly of the globe of the eye, or bulbus oculi.
name: Abnormal eye morphology

desc: An abnormality of the uvea, the vascular layer of the eyeball.
name: Abnormal uvea morphology

desc: An abnormality of the iris, which is the pigmented muscular tissue between the cornea and the lens, that is perforated by an opening called the pupil.
name: Abnormality iris morphology

desc: A coloboma of the iris.
name: Iris coloboma

desc: An abnormality of the pupil.
name: Abnormal pupil morphology

desc: An abnormal white reflection from the pupil rather than the usual black reflection.
name: Leukocoria

desc: Anisocoria, or unequal pupil size, may represent a benign physiologic variant or a manifestation of disease.
name: Anisocoria

desc: The presence of remnants of a fetal membrane that persist as strands of tissue crossing the pupil.
name: Persistent pupillary membrane

desc: A malposition of the pupil owing to a developmental defect of the iris.
name: Ectopia pupillae

desc: Multiple pupils.
name: Polycoria

desc: A deviation from the normal circular shape of the pupil
name: Abnormal pupil shape

desc: An abnormal pupil shape that is elliptical, i.e., egg-like.
name: Oval pupil

desc: A small pupil (typically diameter less than 2 mm) that dilates poorly or not at all in response to topically administered mydriatic drugs.
name: Microcoria

desc: Loss of iris tissue (atrophy)
name: Iris atrophy

desc: Inflammation of the iris.
name: Iritis

desc: New growth of vessels on the surface of the iris.
layperson: New blood vessel formation in iris
name: Iris neovascularization
synonyms: New blood vessel formation in iris

desc: Reduction in the amount of blood flow to the iris.
name: Iris hypoperfusion

desc: Formation of new blood vessels on the iris. The new vessels do not display the typical radially symmertic growth pattern of normal iris blood vessels, but rather appear disorganized. Rubeosis usually starts from the pupillary border with tiny tufts of dilated capillaries or red spots that can only be appreciated with high magnification.
name: Rubeosis iridis

desc: Abnormal pigmentation of the iris.
name: Abnormal iris pigmentation

desc: A markedly blue coloration of the iris.
name: Blue irides

desc: The presence of whitish spots in a ring-like arrangement at the periphery of the iris.
name: Brushfield spots

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation of the iris.
name: Iris hypopigmentation

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of the iris and retina.
name: Ocular albinism

desc: Shedding of the pigment granules that normally adhere to the back of the iris into the aqueous humor.
name: Iris pigment dispersion

desc: A lacy pattern or iris pigmentation that resembles the spokes of a bicycle wheel.
name: Stellate iris

desc: Transmission of light through the iris as visualized upon slit lamp examination or infrared iris transillumination videography. The light passes through defects in the pigmentation of the iris.
name: Iris transillumination defect

desc: Asymmetry between the two irides or asymmetry between different parts of one iris.
name: Asymmetry of iris pigmentation

desc: Heterochromia iridis is a difference in the color of the iris in the two eyes.
name: Heterochromia iridis

desc: The presence of distinct colors in the central (pupillary) zone of the iris than in the mid-peripheral (ciliary) zone.
name: Central heterochromia

desc: A zone of darker pigmentation around the central part of the iris with a roughly cloverleaf or flower shape.
name: Lester's sign

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the iris.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the iris

desc: Abnormality of the iris characterized by, typically bilateral, complete or partial iris hypoplasia. The phenotype ranges from mild defects of anterior iris stroma only to almost complete absence of the iris.
name: Aniridia

desc: Congenital underdevelopment of the iris.
name: Hypoplasia of the iris

desc: A congenital malformation of the anterior segment characterized by iridicorneal malformation, glaucoma, iris stroma hypoplasia, posterior embryotoxon, and corneal opacities.
name: Rieger anomaly

desc: Underdevelopment of the stroma of iris.
name: Hypoplastic iris stroma

desc: Underdevelopment of the dilatator pupillae.
layperson: Hypoplasia of the iris dilator muscle
name: Hypoplasia of the iris dilator muscle
synonyms: Hypoplasia of the pupil dilator muscle

desc: An iris cyst is composed of a single cell layer of epithelium and is filled with fluid.
name: Iris cyst

desc: Malignant tumor of melanocytes affecting the iris.
name: Iris melanoma

desc: A benign brown pigmented area over the iris representing proliferation of melanocyte cells in the stromal layer of the iris. An iris nevus can be flat or occasionally slightly elevated.
name: Iris nevus

desc: Presence of iris pigment epithelium on the anterior surface of the iris.
name: Uveal ectropion

desc: Tremulousness of the iris on movement of the eye, occurring in subluxation of the lens.
name: Iridodonesis

desc: Multiple cysts along the pupillary margin that appear as spherical or tear-drop-shaped pigmented lesions or wrinkled masses emerging from the pupillary border of the iris.
name: Iris flocculi

desc: Inflammation of one or all portions of the uveal tract.
name: Uveitis

desc: A form of uveitis that is not associated with the formation of granulomas.
name: Nongranulomatous uveitis

desc: Inflammation of the uveal tract in which inflammation affects the anterior chamber, vitreous, retina or choroid.
name: Panuveitis

desc: Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the anterior chamber.
name: Anterior uveitis

desc: A type of anterior uveitis, in which there is Inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body.
name: Iridocyclitis

desc: Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the retina or choroid.
name: Posterior uveitis

desc: Inflammation of the uveal tract in which the primary site of inflammation is the vitreous.
name: Intermediate uveitis

desc: Any structural abnormality of the choroid.
name: Abnormal choroid morphology

desc: An abnormality of the choroid and retina.
name: Abnormal chorioretinal morphology

desc: Absence of a region of the retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid.
layperson: Birth defect that causes a hole in the innermost layer at the back of the eye
name: Chorioretinal coloboma
synonyms: Birth defect that causes a hole in the innermost layer at the back of the eye

desc: Absence of a region of the retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid at the lower part of the fundus.
name: Inferior chorioretinal coloboma

desc: Abnormal development of the choroid and retina.
name: Chorioretinal dysplasia

desc: Punched out lesions in the pigmented layer of the retina.
name: Chorioretinal lacunae

desc: An inflammation of the choroid and retina.
name: Chorioretinitis

desc: An anomaly of the retina with serous detachment of the neurosensory retina secondary to one or more focal lesions of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), and associated with blurred vision, usually in one eye only and perceived typically by the patient as a dark spot in the centre of the visual field with associated micropsia and metamorphopsia. Normal vision often recurs spontaneously within a few months.
name: Central serous chorioretinopathy

desc: Atrophy of the choroid and retinal layers of the fundus.
name: Chorioretinal atrophy

desc: Chorioretinal atrophy along the retinal veins.
name: Paravenous chorioretinal atrophy

desc: Chorioretinal atrophy concentrated around the optic papilla (i.e., the optic nerve head).
name: Peripapillary chorioretinal atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the capillary lamina of choroid.
name: Choriocapillaris atrophy

desc: Fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound (i.e., a scar) located in the choroid and retina or the eye.
name: Chorioretinal scar

desc: A fluorescein angiographic finding of absence of the normal background fluorescence (a dark choroid).
name: Dark choroid

desc: A benign, flat or slightly elevated melanocytic lesions of the posterior uveawith clearly defined margins. Choroidal nevi tend they remain stable in size, and to display features such as overlying drusen as well as retinal pigment epithelial atrophy, hyperplasia or fibrous metaplasia.
name: Choroidal nevus

layperson: Abnormal morphology of the choroidal vasculature
name: Abnormal morphology of the choroidal vasculature

desc: The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the choroid. These are generally reddish or orange or can have increased pigmentation maiking them difficult to distinguish from choroidal melanomas.
name: Choroidal hemangioma

desc: Choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is the creation of new blood vessels in the choroid layer of the eye.
name: Choroidal neovascularization

desc: A type of choroidal neovascularization in which the nearest edge of the area of neovascularization is located 200 to 1500 micrometers from the center of the fovea.
name: Extrafoveal choroidal neovascularization

desc: A type of choroidal neovascularization in which the nearest edge of the area of neovascularization is located 1 to 199 micrometers from the center of the fovea.
name: Juxtafoveal choroidal neovascularization

desc: A type of choroidal neovascularization in which the area of neovascularization overlaps with the center of the fovea.
name: Subfoveal choroidal neovascularization

desc: The presence of aneurysmal polypoidal lesions in the choroidal vasculature. The aneurysmal dilatations, also known as polyps, may be found at subfoveal, juxtafoveal, extrafoveal, peripapillary or even peripheral regions. These polypoidal dilatations may be visible as reddish-orange subretinal nodules during ophthalmoscopic examination. The polypoidal lesions are best detected on indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) and might be associated with a branching vascular network (BVN) of neovascularization.
name: Polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy

desc: Increased tendency of choiroidal blood vessels to allow fluids to leak characterized by multifocal choroidal hyperfluorescence on indocyanine green angiography (ICGA).
name: Choroidal vascular hyperpermeability

desc: Enlargement of the large blood vessels in the choroid.
name: Dilatation of large choroidal vessels

desc: Multiple cream-yellow colored hypopigmented choroidal anomalies whose size is approximately one quarter to one half of that of the optic disc, and whose location tends to cluster around the optic nerve radiating towards the periphery. The pattern of the lesions is said to be similar to gunshot spatter from birdshot.
name: Birdshot choroidal lesions

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the uvea, the pigmented middle layer of the eye consisting of the iris and ciliary body together with the choroid.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the uvea

desc: Underdevelopment of the ciliary body.
name: Hypoplasia of the ciliary body

desc: A structural anomaly of the ciliary body.
name: Abnormal ciliary body morphology

desc: Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the ciliary body.
name: Ciliary body melanoma

desc: A developmental defect characterized by a cleft of some portion of the eye or ocular adnexa.
name: Coloboma

desc: A notch or cleft of the retina.
layperson: Hole in the back of the eye
name: Retinal coloboma
synonyms: Hole in the back of the eye

desc: A congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects. Macular coloboma is characterized by a sharply defined, rather large defect in the central area of the fundus that is oval or round, and coarsely pigmented.
name: Macular coloboma

desc: A notch or cleft of the lower part of the retina.
name: Inferior retinal coloboma

desc: A cleft of the optic nerve that extends inferiorly.
name: Optic nerve coloboma

desc: A coloboma of the ciliary body.
name: Ciliary body coloboma

desc: A sectoral indentation of the crystalline lens, usually due to zonular weakness or absence.
name: Lens coloboma

desc: An abnormality of the sclera.
name: Abnormal sclera morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the outer white part of eyeball

desc: An abnormal bluish coloration of the sclera.
layperson: Whites of eyes are a bluish-gray color
name: Blue sclerae
synonyms: Whites of eyes are a bluish-gray color
Blue outer white part of eyeball

name: Pigmentation of the sclera
synonyms: Pigmentation of the outer white part of the eyeball

desc: Prominence of blood vessels of the superficial episcleral tissues.
name: Superficial episcleral hyperemia

desc: Prominence of blood vessels of the deep episcleral tissues.
name: Deep episcleral hyperemia

desc: Breakage of the sclera.
name: Scleral rupture

desc: A congenital lesion of the sclera characterized by unilateral patchy but extensive slate-gray or bluish discoloration of the sclera . The conjunctiva are spared.
name: Ocular melanocytosis

desc: Increased dimension of the sclera in the anterior-posterior axis.
name: Scleral thickening

desc: A staphyloma is a localized defect in the eye wall with protrusion of uveal tissue due to alterations in scleral thickness and structure.
name: Scleral staphyloma

desc: A localized defect in the anterior eye wall with protrusion of uveal tissue due to alterations in scleral thickness and structure.
name: Anterior staphyloma

desc: A localized defect in the posterior eye wall with protrusion of uveal tissue due to alterations in scleral thickness and structure.
name: Posterior staphyloma

desc: Inflammation of the sclera.
name: Scleritis
synonyms: Inflammation of the outer white part of the eye

desc: Inflammation of the episclera, a thin layer of tissue covering the white part (sclera) of the eye.
layperson: Inflammation of the thin layer on top of the white part of eye
name: Episcleritis
synonyms: Inflammation of the thin layer on top of the white part of eye

desc: Atrophy of the eyeball with blindness and decreased intraocular pressure due to end-stage intraocular disease.
name: Phthisis bulbi

desc: An abnormality of the anterior segment of the eyeball (which comprises the structures in front of the vitreous humour: the cornea, iris, ciliary body, and lens).
name: Abnormal anterior eye segment morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the anterior segment of the eyeball
Abnormality of the anterior segment of the globe
Abnormality of the anterior segment of the eye

desc: Any abnormality of the cornea, which is the transparent tissue at the front of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber.
name: Abnormal cornea morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the size or morphology of the cornea.
name: Abnormality of corneal size

desc: A congenital abnormality of the cornea in which the cornea and the anterior segment of the eye are smaller than normal. The horizontal diameter of the cornea does not reach 10 mm even in adulthood.
layperson: Cornea of eye less than 10mm in diameter
name: Microcornea
synonyms: Cornea of eye less than 10mm in diameter

desc: An enlargement of the cornea with normal clarity and function. Megalocornea is diagnosed with a horizontal corneal diameter of 12 mm or more at birth or 13 mm or more after two years of age.
name: Megalocornea

desc: The presence of a size difference between the left and right cornea.
name: Corneal asymmetry

desc: An abnormality of the cornea that is characterized by opacity of one or parts of the cornea.
name: Corneal dystrophy

desc: The presence of fine, branching linear opacities in Bowman's layer in the central area that may spread to the periphery in the clinical course. The deep corneal stroma may be involved but the process does not reach Descemet's membrane. Recurrent corneal erosion may occur. Histologic examination reveals amyloid deposits in the collagen fibers of the cornea.
name: Lattice corneal dystrophy

desc: The presence of central, fine, whitish granular lesions in the stroma of the cornea. This type of corneal dystrophy is usually asymptomatic and begins in childhood and shows a slow progression. Later in the course, the corneal epithelium and Bowman's layer may be affected. Histologically, the cornea shows a uniform deposition of hyaline material.
name: Granular corneal dystrophy

desc: A reduction of corneal clarity.
name: Corneal opacity
synonyms: Scarring or clouding of the cornea of the eye

desc: A congenital anomaly in which a part or the whole of the cornea acquires the characteristics of sclera, resulting in clouding of the cornea.
layperson: Hardening of skin and connective tissue
name: Sclerocornea
synonyms: Hardening of skin and connective tissue

desc: Lack of transparency of the corneal epithelium.
name: Opacification of the corneal epithelium

desc: Reduced transparency of the stroma of cornea.
name: Opacification of the corneal stroma
