desc: Punctate opacification (reduced transparency) of the corneal stroma.
name: Punctate opacification of the cornea

desc: Reduced transparency of the peripheral region of the cornea.
name: Peripheral opacification of the cornea

desc: A hazy, grayish-white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus (the corneoscleral junction). Corneal arcus generally occurs bilaterally, and is related to lipid deposition in the cornea. Corneal arcus can occur in elderly persons as a part of the aging process but may be associated with hypercholesterolemia in people under the age of 50 years.
name: Corneal arcus

desc: Reduced transparency of the central portion of the corneal stroma.
name: Central opacification of the cornea

desc: An abnormality of the cornea characterized by the deposition of calcium in a band across the central cornea, leading to decreased vision, foreign body sensation, and ocular irritation.
name: Band keratopathy

desc: Grayish, polygonal pattern of opacities with intervening clear zones across the central cornea that resembles crocodile skin.
layperson: Posterior crocodile shagreen of the cornea
name: Posterior crocodile shagreen of the cornea

desc: Reduced transparency of the central posterior portion of the corneal stroma.
name: Central posterior corneal opacity

desc: Generalized reduced transparency of the stroma of the cornea.
name: Generalized opacification of the cornea

desc: Grey-green or brownish-pigmented ring in the deep epithelial layers at the outer border of the cornea.
name: Kayser-Fleischer ring

desc: An abnormally reduced response to stimulation of the cornea (by touch, foreign body, blowing air). The corneal reflex (also known as the blink reflex, normally results in an involuntary blinking of the eyelids.
name: Decreased corneal reflex

desc: An abnormality of the line of Schwalbe.
layperson: Abnormality of the line of Schwalbe
name: Abnormality of the line of Schwalbe

desc: A posterior embryotoxon is the presence of a prominent and anteriorly displaced line of Schwalbe.
name: Posterior embryotoxon

desc: An abnormal anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
name: Abnormality of corneal thickness

desc: A increased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
name: Increased corneal thickness

desc: A decreased anteroposterior thickness of the cornea.
name: Decreased corneal thickness

desc: A cone-shaped deformity of the cornea characterized by the presence of corneal distortion secondary to thinning of the apex.
name: Keratoconus

desc: Limbus-to-limbus corneal thinning, often greatest in the periphery, with globular protrusion of the cornea.
name: Keratoglobus

desc: Abnormality of the corneal endothelium, that is, the single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea.
name: Abnormal corneal endothelium morphology

desc: Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium.
name: Abnormal migration of corneal endothelium

desc: This corneal dystrophy affects the posterior limiting membrane of the cornea and is characterized by polymorphous plaques of calcium deposits in the deep stromal layers of the cornea, and occasionally by vesicular lesions of the endothelium and edema of the deep corneal stroma.
name: Polymorphous posterior corneal dystrophy

desc: Abnormality of Descemet's membrane, which is the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium.
name: Abnormal Descemet membrane morphology

desc: Corneal guttata are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. The presence of focal thickenings of Descemet's membrane histologically named guttae. Cornea guttata can be easily diagnosed in vivo and ex vivo by means of specular microscopy as it gives dark areas where no endothelial cells are visible.
name: Corneal guttata

desc: Presence of folds in the Descemet membrane, which is the basement membrane of the endothelial (inner) cell layer of the cornea. Descemet membrane folds are generally a manifestation of inflammation or edema of the cornea.
name: Descemet Membrane Folds

desc: A reduction in the thickness of Descemet's membrane.
name: Thinning of Descemet membrane

desc: A reduction in the number of corneal endothelial cells.
layperson: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells
name: Reduced number of corneal endothelial cells

desc: An inflammatory cellular deposit deposited on the corneal endothelium and visible as spots on the cornea.
name: Corneal keratic precipitates

desc: An abnormality of the stroma of cornea, also known as the substantia propria of cornea.
name: Abnormality of corneal stroma

desc: Abnormal prominence of the corneal nerve fibers.
name: Prominent corneal nerve fibers

desc: Abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling of the stroma of cornea.
name: Corneal stromal edema

desc: Abnormality of the corneal epithelium, that is of the epithelial tissue that covers the front of the cornea.
name: Abnormal corneal epithelium morphology

desc: Inflammation of the cornea.
name: Keratitis

desc: A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.
name: Punctate keratitis

desc: Disruption of the epithelial layer of the cornea with involvement of the underlying stroma.
name: Corneal ulceration

desc: The presence of one or more dendritic corneal epithelial ulcers characterized by a treelike branching linear pattern with feathery edges and terminal bulbs. Herpetiform corneal ulcers can be identified by fluorescein staining.
name: Herpetiform corneal ulceration

desc: An erosion or abrasion of the cornea's outermost layer of epithelial cells.
layperson: Damage to outer layer of the cornea of the eye
name: Corneal erosion
synonyms: Damage to outer layer of the cornea of the eye

desc: The presence of recurrent corneal epithelial erosions. Although most corneal epithelial defects heal quickly, some may show recurrent ulcerations.
layperson: Recurrent breakdown of clear protective layer of eye
name: Recurrent corneal erosions
synonyms: Recurrent breakdown of clear protective layer of eye

desc: Ingrowth of new blood vessels into the cornea.
layperson: New blood vessel formation in cornea
name: Corneal neovascularization
synonyms: New blood vessel formation in cornea

desc: Reduced ability of the cornea to respond to stimulation.
name: Decreased corneal sensation

desc: An anomaly of the margin of the cornea overlapped by the sclera.
name: Abnormality of the corneal limbus

desc: Swelling of the margin of the cornea overlapped by the sclera.
name: Limbal edema

desc: A rupture of the cornea through which a portion of the iris protrudes.
name: Corneal perforation

layperson: Abnormality of the curvature of the cornea
name: Abnormality of the curvature of the cornea

desc: A type of astigmatism associated with abnormal curvatures on the anterior and/or posterior surface of the cornea.
name: Astigmatism
synonyms: Abnormal curving of the cornea or lens of the eye

desc: A form of astigmatism in which one meridian is hyperopic while the one at a right angle to it has no refractive error.
name: Hyperopic astigmatism

desc: A type of refractive error related abnormal curvatures on the anterior or posterior surface of the cornea.
name: Corneal astigmatism

desc: Astigmatism in which the refractive power of the vertical meridian is the greatest.
name: Oblique astigmatism

desc: Refractive error in which the vertical meridian is relatively hypermetropic and the horizontal meridian is relatively myopic (or ocular astigmatism in which the refractive power of the horizontal meridian is the greatest).
name: With the rule astigmatism

desc: Astigmatism with more plus power on the horizontal meridian.
name: Against the rule astigmatism

desc: A type of astigmatism in which an unequal curvature of the cornea and some cases additionally of the lens causes one meridian of the eye to be hyperopic (farsighted) and a second meridian that is perpendicular to the first to be myopic (nearsighted).
name: Mixed astigmatism

desc: A type of astigmatism related to an irregular shape of the lens.
name: Lenticular astigmatism

desc: A type of astigmatism in which the principle meridians are not 90 degrees apart and which is associated with loss of vision.
name: Irregular astigmatism

desc: A condition where one or both of the two principal meridians focus in the front of the retina when the eye is at rest.
name: Myopic astigmatism

desc: Cornea plana is an abnormally flat shape of the cornea such that the normal protrusion of the cornea from the sclera is missing. The reduced corneal curvature can lead to hyperopia, and a hazy corneal limbus and arcus lipoides may develop at an early age.
name: Flat cornea

desc: An increase in the degree of curvature of the cornea compared to normal.
name: Increased corneal curvature

desc: Golden brown or gray deposits with a clockwise, whorl-like distribution in the inferior interpalpebal portion of the cornea.
name: Cornea verticillata

desc: An abnormality of the lens.
name: Abnormality of the lens

desc: A cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the crystalline lens of the eye or in its capsule.
layperson: Clouding of the lens of the eye
name: Cataract
synonyms: Clouding of the lens of the eye

desc: A cataract that occurs congenitally as the result of a developmental defect, in contrast to the majority of cataracts that occur in adulthood as the result of degenerative changes of the lens.
layperson: Clouding of the lens of the eye at birth
name: Developmental cataract
synonyms: Clouding of the lens of the eye at birth

desc: A cataract that affects the region of the lens directly beneath the capsule of the lens.
name: Subcapsular cataract

desc: A type of cataract affecting the posterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the Lens capsule.
name: Posterior subcapsular cataract
synonyms: Posterior subcapsular opacities of the lens

desc: A type of posterior subcapsular cataract characterized by an iridescent color.
name: Iridescent posterior subcapsular cataract

desc: A type of cataract affecting the anterior pole of lens immediately adjacent to ('beneath') the lens capsule.
name: Anterior subcapsular cataract

desc: A type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence.
name: Juvenile cataract

desc: Presenile cataract is a kind of cataract that occurs in early adulthood, that is, at an age that is younger than usual.
name: Presenile cataracts

desc: A kind of cataract that progresses with age.
name: Progressive cataract

desc: A type of Congenital cataract in which the opacities occupy the subcapsular cortex at the anterior or posterior pole of the lens.
name: Polar cataract

desc: A polar cataract that affects the posterior pole of the lens.
name: Posterior polar cataract

desc: A polar cataract that affects the anterior pole of the lens.
name: Anterior polar cataract

desc: A type of anterior polar cataract which projects as a conical opacity into the anterior chamber.
name: Anterior pyramidal cataract

desc: Zonular cataracts are defined to be cataracts that affect specific regions of the lens.
name: Zonular cataract

desc: A type of cataract with punctate opacities of the lens.
name: Punctate cataract

desc: Cerulean cataracts are a kind of congenital cataract having peripheral bluish and white opacifications in concentric layers with occasional central lesions arranged radially. Although the opacities may be observed during fetal development and childhood, usually visual acuity is only mildly reduced until adulthood, when lens extraction is generally necessary.
name: Cerulean cataract

desc: A kind of congenital cataract that is characterized by a hollow sphere of punctate opacities involving the fetal nucleus and that usually occurs bilaterally.
name: Pulverulent cataract

desc: A type of cataract characterized by punctate, dust-like opacities within the cortical region of the lens.
name: Cortical pulverulent cataract

desc: A type of nuclear cataract involving congenital dust-like (pulverulent) opacity of the embryonal and fetal nucleus.
name: Nuclear pulverulent cataract

desc: A congenital cataract in which opacity is limited to layers of the lens external to the nucleus (i.e., the perinuclear region), i.e., between the nuclear and cortical layers of the lens.
name: Lamellar cataract

desc: A Lamellar cataract with a pulverulent (punctate, "dust-like" opacities) appearance.
name: Lamellar pulverulent cataract

desc: Lamellar cataracts with associated linear lens opacities radially extending towards the periphery of the lens.
name: Lamellar cataract with riders

desc: A type of congenital cataract in which the opacity follows the anterior or posterior Y suture.
name: Sutural cataract

desc: A type of sutural cataract in which the opacity follows the posterior Y suture.
name: Posterior Y-sutural cataract

desc: A 'coral-like' pattern of opacity in the lens of the eye. That is, a cataract with an irregular, stellate form.
name: Coralliform cataract

desc: A type of cataract characterised by club-shaped and dot opacities distributed radially in the deep cortex. These lens opacities surround the nucleus in an appearance that is though to resemble a crown.
name: Coronary cataract

desc: A nuclear cataract is an opacity or clouding that develops in the lens nucleus. That is, a nuclear cataract is one that is located in the center of the lens. The nucleus tends to darken changing from clear to yellow and sometimes brown.
name: Nuclear cataract

desc: Opacity of the entire lens nucleus.
name: Diffuse nuclear cataract

desc: A nuclear cataract with a triangular form.
name: Triangular nuclear cataract

desc: A kind of nuclear cataract characterized by fiberglasslike or needlelike crystals projecting in different directions, through or close to the axial region of the lens.
name: Aculeiform cataract

desc: A cataract which affects the layer of the lens surrounding the nucleus, i.e., the lens cortex. It is identified by its unique wedge or spoke appearance.
name: Cortical cataract

desc: A cataract that affects the anterior part of the cortex of the lens.
name: Anterior cortical cataract

desc: A cataract that affects the posterior part of the cortex of the lens.
name: Posterior cortical cataract

desc: A type of posterior cortical cataract characterized by dense lenticular opacities.
name: Dense posterior cortical cataract

desc: A form of cataract in which the lens substance has shrunk, leaving a collapsed, flattened capsule with little or no cortex or epithelium on the lens.
name: Membranous cataract

desc: A type of cataract (opacification of the lens) that forms during the course of aging.
layperson: Clouding of the lens of the eye with age
name: Age-related cataract
synonyms: Clouding of the lens of the eye with age

desc: A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the nucleus of the lens.
name: Age-related nuclear cataract

desc: A type of age-related cataract that primarily affects the cortex of the lens.
name: Age-related cortical cataract

desc: A type of age-related cataract consisting of granular opacities occurring mainly in the central posterior cortex just under the posterior capsule.
name: Age-related posterior subcapsular cataract

desc: A type of cataract that shows a spectacular display of multiple colours that glitters with the change of incident light like an illuminated Christmas tree.
name: Christmas tree cataract

desc: A cataract that affects the capsule of the lens.
name: Capsular cataract

desc: A cataract which is found in the back outer layer of the lens. This type often develops more rapidly.
name: Posterior capsular cataract

desc: Dislocation or malposition of the crystalline lens of the eye. A partial displacement (or dislocation) of the lens is described as a subluxation of the lens, while a complete displacement is termed luxation of the lens. A complete displacement occurs if the lens is completely outside the patellar fossa of the lens, either in the anterior chamber, in the vitreous, or directly on the retina. If the lens is partially displaced but still contained within the lens space, then it is termed subluxation.
name: Ectopia lentis

desc: Partial dislocation of the lens of the eye.
name: Lens subluxation

desc: Partial dislocation of the lens in a superior direction.
name: Superior lens subluxation

desc: Partial displacement of the lens in the inferior direction.
name: Inferior lens subluxation

desc: Complete dislocation of the lens of the eye.
name: Lens luxation

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the lens.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the lens

desc: Absence of the crystalline lens of the eye as a result of a developmental defect.
name: Congenital aphakia

desc: Abnormal smallness of the lens.
name: Microphakia

desc: Lens of the eye is smaller than normal and spherically shaped.
name: Microspherophakia

desc: An abnormal shape of the lens.
name: Abnormality of lens shape

desc: A conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
name: Lenticonus

desc: A conical projection of the anterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
name: Anterior lenticonus

desc: A conical projection of the posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.
name: Posterior lenticonus

desc: Exaggerated curvature of the lens of the eye, producing an anterior or posterior spherical bulging.
name: Lentiglobus

desc: Tremulousness (trembling) of the lens of the eye.
name: Phakodonesis

desc: The term pseudophakia refers to having an artificial lens implanted after the natural eye lens has been removed. During cataract surgery the natural cloudy lens is replaced by an pseudophakia intraocular lens (IOL).
name: Pseudophakia

desc: Abnormality of the anterior chamber, which is the space in the eye that is behind the cornea and in front of the iris.
name: Abnormal anterior chamber morphology

desc: Reduced depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is decreased.
name: Shallow anterior chamber

desc: Increased depth of the anterior chamber, i.e., the anteroposterior distance between the cornea and the iris is increased.
name: Deep anterior chamber

desc: Adhesions between the iris and the cornea.
layperson: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
name: Anterior synechiae of the anterior chamber

desc: Adhesions between the iris and the lens.
layperson: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber
name: Posterior synechiae of the anterior chamber

desc: Absence of the anterior chamber of the eye owing to a developmental defect.
layperson: Absent anterior chamber of the eye
name: Absent anterior chamber of the eye

desc: Developmental abnormality in which the lens and cornea are not separated.
name: Corneolenticular adhesion

desc: An anomaly of the trabecular meshwork, which is the porelike structure surrounding the entire circumference of the anterior chamber at the base of the cornea and near the ciliary body. The trabecular mesh work is responsible for draining the aqueous humor into the canal of Schlemm.
name: Abnormal trabecular meshwork morphology

desc: Accumulation of abnormal amounts of pigment within the trabecular meshwork.
layperson: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork
name: Pigment deposition in the trabecular meshwork

desc: A closed sac, having a distinct membrane and division compared to the nearby tissue located within the anterior chamber. The sac that may contain air, fluids, or semi-solid material.
name: Anterior chamber cyst

desc: Tiny deposits corresponding to cells floating in the anterior chamber of the eye. This appearance is typically associated with intraocular inflammation leading to breakdown of the blood-aqueous barrier and resulting in an increase in the number of cells and in the aqueous humor. Grading (SUN Working Group) is performed by estimating the number of cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells

desc: Anterior chamber cells with 6-15 cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 1+

desc: Anterior chamber cells with 1-5 cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 0.5+

desc: Anterior chamber cells with less than one cell in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 0

desc: Anterior chamber cells with 16-25 cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 2+

desc: Anterior chamber cells with 26-50 cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 3+

desc: Anterior chamber cells with more than 50 cells in a 1 mm by 1 mm slit beam field, employing adequate light intensity and magnification on a slit lamp.
name: Anterior chamber cells grade 4+

desc: Presence of pus (appears as a white fluid) producing a fluid level in the inferior part of the anterior chamber.
name: Hypopyon

desc: An abnormal appearance of the beam of light traveling through the anterior chamber of the eye in a slit lamp examination. The flare is produced by an increased concentration of proteins in the aqueous humor in the anterior chamber.
name: Anterior chamber flare

desc: Faint anterior chamber flare.
name: Anterior chamber flare grade 1+

desc: Moderate anterior chamber flare (iris and lens details clear).
name: Anterior chamber flare grade 2+

desc: Marked anterior chamber flare (iris and lens details hazy).
name: Anterior chamber flare grade 3+

desc: Intense anterior chamber flare (fibrin/plastic aqueous).
name: Anterior chamber flare grade 4+

desc: The presence of inflammatory cells in the aqueous humor of the anterior chamber of the eye.
name: Anterior chamber inflammatory cells

desc: The presence of erythrocyte in the aqueous humor of the anterior chamber of the eye.
name: Anterior chamber red blood cells

desc: Abnormal development (dysgenesis) of the anterior segment of the eye globe. These structures are mainly of mesenchymal origin.
name: Ocular anterior segment dysgenesis

desc: A form of anterior segment dysgenesis in which abnormal cleavage of the anterior chamber occurs. Peters anomaly is characterized by central, paracentral, or complete corneal opacity.
name: Peters anomaly

desc: Glaucoma which forms during the early years of a child's life is called developmental or congenital glaucoma.
name: Developmental glaucoma

desc: Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) associated with glaucoma.
name: Buphthalmos

desc: Axenfeld's anomaly is a bilateral disorder characterized by a prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line (posterior embryotoxon) and peripheral iris strands which span the anterior chamber angle to attach to Schwalbe's line.
name: Axenfeld anomaly

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior segment of the eye.
layperson: Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the anterior segment of the eye
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia affecting the anterior segment of the eye

desc: Deposition of fibrillar material that can be found on all anterior segment structures bathed by aqueous humor.
name: Pseudoexfoliation

desc: An anomaly of the suspensory ligament of lens, also known as the ciliary zonule. These ligaments represent a series of fibers connecting the ciliary body and lens of the eye, holding the lens in place.
layperson: Abnormal suspensory ligament of lens morphology
name: Abnormal suspensory ligament of lens morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the suspensory ligament of lens

desc: A condition characterized by a loss or deficiency of the stem cells in the limbus that are vital for re-population of the corneal epithelium and to the barrier function of the limbus.
name: Limbal stem cell deficiency
Abnormal posterior eye segment morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the posterior segment of the eyeball
Abnormality of the posterior segment of the eye
Abnormal morphology of the posterior segment of the globe
Abnormality of the posterior segment of the globe

desc: Any structural abnormality of the fundus of the eye.
name: Abnormal fundus morphology

desc: A structural abnormality of the retina.
name: Abnormal retinal morphology

desc: Any noninflammatory disease of the retina. This nonspecific term is retained here because of its wide use in the literature, but if possible new annotations should indicate the precise type of retinal abnormality.
name: Retinopathy

desc: An avascular or abnormally vascularized retina that occurs in premature infants and can lead to blindness.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity

desc: The retinal vessels stop and then a linear flat white line is present that usually runs the circumference of the vascular retina.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 1

desc: The accumulating neovascularization thickens and manifests as a linear bump. The neovascularization remains along the surface of the retina and does not extend off the retina into the cortical vitreous.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 2

desc: The neovascularization accumulates at the edge of the vascularized retina and extends into the vitreous (also called extra retinal fibrosis proliferation). In cases of Zone 2 and Zone 3, this may be sausage shaped. In more posterior Zone 1 disease, the stage 3 can appear as a direct extension of the normal retinal vessels but extending tangentially over the avascular retina.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 3

desc: Scar tissue that forms a continuous sheet coming up from the edge of the vascularized retina. This scar tissue can grow toward the vitreous base/posterior lens capsule resulting in traction, distortion, and even detachment.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 4

desc: A detachment that involves the peripheral retina that does not extend into the macula.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 4a

desc: A detachment that involves the peripheral retina that involves the macula itself. The detachment usually starts in the temporal periphery although can also involve the nasal retina as well.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 4b

desc: Funnel detachment from the retina with generally traction in all four quadrants.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 5

desc: An open funnel detachment of the retina with generally traction in all four quadrants.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 5a

desc: A closed funnel detachment of the retina with generally traction in all four quadrants.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity stage 5b

desc: Retinopathy which extends from the center of the optic disc to twice the distance from the center of the optic disc to the center of the macula.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity zone I

desc: Retinopathy which extends centrifugally from the edge of zone I to the nasal ora serrata.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity zone II

desc: Retinopathy which is a residual crescent of retina anterior to zone II.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity zone III

desc: Venous dilatation and arteriolar tortuosity of the posterior retinal vessels and may later increase in severity to include iris vascular engorgement, poor pupillary dilatation (rigid pupil), and vitreous haze. This definition has been further refined in the later clinical trials in which the diagnosis of plus disease could be made if sufficient vascular dilatation and tortuosity are present in at least 2 quadrants of the eye.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity plus

desc: As vascular abnormalities of the posterior pole that are insufficient for the diagnosis of plus disease but that demonstrate more arterial tortuosity and more venous dilatation than normal.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity pre-plus

desc: A retinopathy with a 50% likelihood of progressing to retinal detachment. Threshold disease is considered to be present when stage 3 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is present in either zone I or zone II, with at least 5 continuous or 8 total clock hours of disease, and the presence of plus disease.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity threshold

desc: High risk patients who were in Zone 1 (no Plus or stage 3) or Zone 2 with Plus or stage 3 but not both.
name: Retinopathy of prematurity prethreshold

desc: Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium.
name: Retinal detachment

desc: Failure of attachment of the retina during development.
name: Retinal nonattachment

desc: A type of retinal detachment arising due to a combination of contracting retinal membranes, abnormal vitreoretinal adhesions, and vitreous changes. It is usually seen in the context of diseases that induce a fibrovascular response, e.g. diabetes.
name: Tractional retinal detachment

desc: Tractional retinal detachment at the periphery of the retina.
name: Peripheral tractional retinal detachment
synonyms: Tractional retinal detachment at the periphery of the retina

desc: Separation of the inner layers of the retina (neural retina) from the pigment epithelium occuring near the outer limit (periphery) of the retina.
name: Peripheral retinal detachment

desc: A type of retinal detachment associated with a retinal tear, that is, with a break in the retina that allows fluid to pass from the vitreous space into the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

desc: A type of retinal detachment arising from damage to the outer blood-retinal barrier that allows fluid to access the subretinal space and separate the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Exudative retinal detachment

desc: A nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and/or retinal photoreceptor cells.
name: Retinal degeneration

desc: A nonspecific term denoting degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium and/or retinal photoreceptor cells of the macula lutea.
name: Macular degeneration

desc: Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the macula, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.
name: Macular atrophy

desc: Scar tissue in the macula.
name: Macular scar

desc: A subretinal scar with a disc-like shape in the region of the macula.
name: Disciform macular scar

desc: A form of macular degeneration characterized by the presence of multiple cysts in the macula.
name: Cystoid macular degeneration

desc: Deterioration of the tissue of the fovea, i.e.,the region of sharpest vision within the macula of the retina.
name: Foveal degeneration

desc: Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the fundus, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.
name: Retinal atrophy

desc: Atrophy (loss or wasting) of the retinal pigment epithelium observed on fundoscopy or fundus imaging.
name: Retinal pigment epithelial atrophy

desc: Wasting (atrophy) of the retinal pigment epithelium present in small, isolated areas.
layperson: Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium
name: Patchy atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium

desc: Sharply demarcated area of partial or complete depigmentation of the fundus reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss. The margins of the de-pigmented area are usually scalloped and the large choroidal vessels are visible through the atrophic retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Geographic atrophy

layperson: Wasting of the outer part of the retina
name: Peripheral retinal atrophy
synonyms: Wasting of the outer part of the retina

desc: Degenerative changes of the peripheral retina consisting of close-packed tiny cystic spaces at the outer plexiform/inner nuclear retinal level. The degeneration is very common in adult eyes and starts adjacent to the ora serrata and extends circumferentially and posteriorly.
name: Peripheral cystoid retinal degeneration

desc: A type of retinal reticular pigmentation that forms a polygonal, netlike arrangement of hyperpigmented lines forming geometric patterns in the fundus.
name: Reticular pigmentary degeneration

desc: The appearance of yellow/white crystalline-like (hence the name) spots in the retina and thickening of the peripheral part of the vitreous.
name: Snowflake vitreoretinal degeneration

desc: Retinitis pigmentosa inversa is form of retinal degeneration characterized by areas of retinal/chorioretinal degeneration with pigment migration in the macular area (in contrast to retinitis pigmentosa which, at early disease stages, predominantly affects the retinal periphery).
name: Retinitis pigmentosa inversa

desc: Retinal dystrophy is an abnormality of the retina associated with a hereditary process. Retinal dystrophies are defined by their predominantly monogenic inheritance and they are frequently associated with loss or dysfunction of photoreceptor cells as a primary or secondary event.
layperson: Breakdown of light-sensitive cells in back of eye
name: Retinal dystrophy
synonyms: Breakdown of light-sensitive cells in back of eye

desc: An inherited retinal disease subtype in which the rod photoreceptors appear to be more severely affected than the cone photoreceptors. Typical presentation is with nyctalopia (due to rod dysfunction) followed by loss of mid-peripheral field of vision, which gradually extends and leaves many patients with a small central island of vision due to the preservation of macular cones.
name: Rod-cone dystrophy

desc: A subtype of retinitis pigmentosa in which, instead of the pathology starting in the mid-periphery like typical retinitis pigmentosa, the disease starts in the near periphery closer to the vascular arcades and tends to spare the far periphery.
name: Pericentral retinitis pigmentosa

desc: A variant of retinitis pigmentosa in which there is a regional distribution of the retinal degeneration.
name: Sectoral retinitis pigmentosa

desc: Inherited progressive cone degeneration.
name: Cone dystrophy

desc: A nonprogressive (i.e., stationary) form of difficulties with night blindness with congenital onset.
name: Congenital stationary night blindness

layperson: Congenital stationary night blindness with normal fundus
name: Congenital stationary night blindness with normal fundus

layperson: Congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus
name: Congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus

desc: Macular dystrophy is a nonspecific term for premature retinal cell aging and cell death, generally confied to the macula in which no clear extrinsic cause is evident.
name: Macular dystrophy

desc: Occult macular dystrophy is a, typically hereditary, abnormality of the macula associated with progressive foveal cone dysfunction and no apparent fundoscopic, full-field electroretinogram (ERG), or fluorescein angiogram abnormalities.
name: Occult macular dystrophy

desc: A spectrum of fundoscopic appearances characterized by the development of a variety of patterns of deposits predominantly in the macular area. The deposits are typically bilateral, relatively symmetrical, yellow/white and associated with changes at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium. With time, retinal atrophy may occur. A number of pattern dystrophy subtypes have been described including butterfly-shaped dystrophy, reticular dystrophy (net-like pattern) and fundus pulverulentus (granular, mottled pigmentation).
name: Pattern dystrophy of the retina

desc: A type of of patterned retinal dystrophy that shows a reticular pattern of pigmentation.
name: Reticular retinal dystrophy

layperson: Retinal dystrophy with early macular involvement
name: Retinal dystrophy with early macular involvement

desc: Hemorrhage occurring within the retina.
name: Retinal hemorrhage

desc: Accumulation of blood located beneath the neurosensory retina in the space between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Subretinal hemorrhage

desc: Bleeding between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) arising from the choroidal or retinal circulation.
name: Submacular hemorrhage

desc: An accumulation of blood located between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane.
name: Subretinal pigment epithelium hemorrhage
Macular hemorrhage
synonyms: Bleeding occurring within the macula lutea of the retina.

desc: Bleeding occurring within the fovea.
name: Foveal hemorrhage

desc: A type of intraretinal hemorrhage that is located in the superficial retina between the inner limiting membrane and the retinal nerve fiber layer.
name: Sub-inner limiting membrane hemorrhage

desc: A subtype of fundus hemorrhage occurring within the neurosensory retina. Intraretinal haemorrhages may be 'dot' or' blot' shaped or flame shaped depending upon their depth within the retina.
name: Intraretinal hemorrhage

desc: A type of retinal hemorrhage that is located within the nerve fiber layer (NFL) of the retina and that exhibits a characteristic flame shape which results from constraints by the structure of the NFL (axons of the ganglion cells).
name: Flame-shaped retinal hemorrhage

desc: Accumulation of blood located in the retina's inner nuclear and outer plexiform layers, and having a dot-like or blot-like shape. THe shape results from intraretinal compression, restricting the hemorrhages within a specific location.
name: Dot-and-blot retinal hemorrhage

desc: Irregular lines in the deep retina that are typically configured in a radiating fashion and emanate from the optic disc. Angioid streaks are crack-like dehiscences in abnormally thickened and calcified Bruch's membrane, resulting in atrophy of the overlying retinal pigment epithelium. They may be associated with a number of endocrine, metabolic, and connective tissue abnormalities but are frequently idiopathic.
name: Angioid streaks of the fundus

desc: A structural abnormality of the macula lutea, which is an oval-shaped highly pigmented yellow spot near the center of the retina.
name: Abnormal macular morphology

desc: An abnormality of the fovea centralis, the central area of the macula that mediates central, high resolution vision and contains the largest concentration of cone cells in the retina.
name: Abnormal foveal morphology

desc: Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the fovea centralis.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the fovea

desc: Underdevelopment of the fovea centralis.
name: Hypoplasia of the fovea

desc: Congenital absence of the fovea.
name: Aplasia of the fovea

desc: Splitting of the retinal layers in the macula.
name: Foveoschisis

desc: An abnormal anatomic position of the fovea, the small, central pit composed of closely packed cones that is located in the macula of the retina.
name: Ectopic fovea

desc: Partial or complete loss of foveal tissue that was once present.
name: Foveal atrophy

desc: An anomaly of the pigmentation in the fovea centralis.
name: Abnormality of foveal pigmentation

desc: Increased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis.
name: Foveal hyperpigmentation

desc: Decreased amount of pigmentation in the fovea centralis.
name: Foveal hypopigmentation

desc: Loss of pigment in the fovea centralis.
name: Foveal depigmentation

desc: Lack of the foveal reflex, which normally occurs as a result of the reflection of light from the ophthalmoscope in the foveal pit upon examination. The foveal reflex is a bright pinpoint of light that is observed to move sideways or up and down in response to movement of the opthalmoscope.
name: Absent foveal reflex

desc: Abnormality of macular or foveal pigmentation.
name: Abnormality of macular pigmentation

desc: Mottled (spotted or blotched with different shades) pigmentary abnormality of the macula lutea.
name: Granular macular appearance

desc: Decreased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.
name: Macular hypopigmentation

desc: Progressive maculopathy characterized by concentric regions of hyper- and hypo-pigmentation.
name: Bull's eye maculopathy

desc: Increased amount of pigmentation in the macula lutea.
name: Macular hyperpigmentation

desc: A shiny appearance of the macula, which is often called a beaten bronze appearance.
name: Beaten bronze macular sheen

desc: Underdevelopment of the macula lutea.
name: Macular hypoplasia

desc: A macular hole is a small break in the macula, located in the center of the retina.
name: Macular hole

desc: Full-thickness macular hole (FTMH) is defined as a foveal lesion with interruption of all retinal layers from the internal limiting membrane to the retinal pigment epithelium. Full-thickness macular hole is primary if caused by vitreous traction or secondary if directly the result of pathologic characteristics other than vitreomacular traction. Full-thickness macular hole is subclassified by size of the hole as determined by OCT and the presence or absence of vitreomacular traction.
name: Full-thickness macular hole

desc: Any structural anomaly of the blood vessels of the macula.
layperson: Abnormality morphology of the macular vasculature
name: Abnormality morphology of the macular vasculature

desc: Small, red dots in the superficial retinal layers (it is difficult to distinguish between small hemorrhages and microaneurysms).
name: Macular microaneurysm/hemorrhage

desc: Yellow-white intraretinal deposits in the macula typically associated with damaged outer blood-retina barrier and exudation of serous fluid and lipids from the retinal microvasculature.
name: Macular exudate

desc: Abnormal increase in retinal thickness in the macular area observed on fundoscopy or fundus imaging.
name: Macular thickening

desc: Splitting of the retina in the macular region.
name: Macular schisis

desc: Thickening of the retina that takes place due to accumulation of fluid in the macula as a nonspecific response to blood-retinal barrier breakdown. Macular edema is a common pathological response to a wide variety of ocular insults, most commonly after intraocular (e.g. cataract) surgery or in association with retinal vascular (e.g. diabetic eye disease, retinal vein occlusion) or inflammatory (e.g. uveitis) disease.
name: Macular edema

desc: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is any type of macular edema that involves cyst formation.
name: Cystoid macular edema

desc: An epiretinal membrane is a thin sheet of fibrous tissue that can develop on the surface of the macular area of the retina and cause a disturbance in vision. An epiretinal membrane area can develop on the thin macular area of the retin. An epiretinal membrane is also sometimes called a macular pucker, premacular fibrosis, surface wrinkling retinopathy or cellophane maculopathy.
name: Epiretinal membrane

desc: Vitelliform maculopathy is a sharply demarcated lesion caused by the accumulation of material, often lipofuscin in the subretinal space underlying the macula.
name: Vitelliform-like macular lesions

desc: Pale often indistinct lesions of the macula.
name: Macular flecks

desc: Yellow/white, sharply delineated lesion, typically of inflammatory nature, involving the macula.
name: Placoid macular lesion

desc: Fluffy white patch on the macula, representing localized areas of dense white swelling of the retinal nerve fibre layer. They often have a zigzag internal structure, a feathered edge but an otherwise well-delineated form and an approximately 1 mm dimension; they project slightly into the vitreous and sometimes deflect retinal vessels.
name: Macular cotton wool spot

desc: Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye. This class refers to the presence of Drusen in the macula.
name: Macular drusen

desc: Crystalline deposits in the macula.
name: Macular crystals

desc: A lesion that is observed following light damage to the macula. Damage to the retinal by exposure to intense visible light, usually the sun. Intense light exposure such as staring at the sun causes fine structural anomalies in the outer segments of the photoreceptors and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells of the macula. Symptoms usually develop within 1 to 4 h after exposure and include decreased vision, metamorphopsia, micropsia, and central or paracentral scotomas. Fundus examination typically shows a small yellow spot with a surrounding gray zone in the foveolar or parafoveolar area. Spontaneous evolution leads to the improvement of visual acuity.
layperson: Small yellow foveal lesion with surrounding gray zone
name: Small yellow foveal lesion with surrounding gray zone
synonyms: Small yellow foveal lesion with surrounding grey zone

desc: Yellow, white or greyish lesions in the macula that are well-defined/distinct, individual and mostly uniform in size.
name: Macular dots

desc: Perifoveal vitreous separation with remaining vitreomacular attachment and unperturbed foveal morphologic features. It is an OCT finding that is almost always the result of normal vitreous aging, which may lead to pathologic conditions.
name: Vitreomacular adhesion

desc: Vitreomacular traction is characterized by anomalous posterior vitreous detachment accompanied by anatomic distortion of the fovea, which may include pseudocysts, macular schisis, cystoid macular edema, and subretinal fluid. Vitreomacular traction can be subclassified by the diameter of vitreous attachment to the macular surface as measured by OCT, with attachment of 1500 micrometers or less defined as focal and attachment of more than 1500 micrometers as broad.
name: Vitreomacular traction
Abnormality of retinal pigmentation
synonyms: Abnormality of the retinal pigment epithelium

desc: An abnormality of the retina characterized by pigment deposition. It is typically associated with migration and proliferation of macrophages or retinal pigment epithelial cells into the retina; melanin from these cells causes the pigmentary changes. Pigmentary retinopathy is a common final pathway of many retinal conditions and is often associated with visual loss.
name: Pigmentary retinopathy

desc: Pigment migration into the retina in a bone-spicule configuration (resembling the nucleated cells within the lacuna of bone).
layperson: Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina
name: Bone spicule pigmentation of the retina

desc: Clumped pigmentary changes of nummular appearance (i.e., thought to resemble the shape of a coin or multiple coins stuck together) at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Nummular pigmentation of the fundus

desc: Mottling (spots or blotches with different shades) of the retinal pigment epithelium, i.e., localized or generalized fundal pigment granularity associated with processes at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Retinal pigment epithelial mottling
synonyms: Focal hypopigmentation of the retinal pigment epithelium

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the retina.
name: Retinal dysplasia

desc: A structural abnormality of retinal vasculature.
name: Abnormal retinal vascular morphology

desc: A creamy appearance of the retinal blood vessels that occurs when the concentration of lipids in the blood are extremely increased, with pale pink to milky white retinal vessels and altered pale reflexes from choroidal vasculature.
name: Lipemia retinalis

desc: Dilatation of small blood vessels of the retina.
name: Retinal telangiectasia

desc: A benign tumor of the retina that appears as a grouping of blood-filled saccules within the inner retinal layers or on the surface of the optic disc. Retinal cavernous angioma are described as having a 'cluster of grapes' appearance.
name: Retinal cavernous angioma

layperson: Abnormal distribution of retinal arterioles and venules
name: Abnormal distribution of retinal arterioles and venules

layperson: Narrowing of blood vessels in back of eye
name: Attenuation of retinal blood vessels
synonyms: Narrowing of blood vessels in back of eye

desc: Blockage of the retinal vein.
name: Retinal vein occlusion

desc: Blockage of a branch of the retinal vein. It may present with sudden-onset of painless vision loss or visual field defect correlating to the area of perfusion of the obstructed vessels.
name: Branch retinal vein occlusion

desc: Central retinal vein occlusion is an occlusion of the main retinal vein posterior to the lamina cribrosa of the optic nerve and is typically caused by thrombosis.
name: Central retinal vein occlusion

desc: A variant of central retinal vein occlusions that involves the superior or inferior half of the retina.
name: Hemiretinal vein occlusion

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal blood vessels.
name: Retinal vascular tortuosity

desc: Inflammation of retinal blood vessels as manifested by perivascular sheathing or cuffing, vascular leakage and/or occlusion.
name: Retinal vasculitis

desc: In wound repair, neovascularization (NV) involves the sprouting of new vessels from pre-existent vessels to repair or replace damaged vessels. In the retina, NV is a response to ischemia. The NV adheres to the inner surface of the retina and outer surface of the vitreous. NV are deficient in tight junctions and hence leak plasma into surrounding tissue including the vitreous. Plasma causes the vitreous gel to degenerate, contract, and eventually collapse which pulls on the retina. Since retinal NV is adherent to both retina and vitreous, as the vitreous contracts the NV may be sheared resulting in vitreous hemorrhage or the NV may remain intact and pull the retina with the vitreous resulting in retinal elevation referred to as traction retinal detachment.
name: Retinal neovascularization

desc: A type of retinal neovascularization that affects the posterior pole of the retina.
name: Posterior retinal neovascularization
synonyms: Neovascularization of peripheral and posterior retina

desc: A type of retinal neovascularization that affects the periphery of the retina.
name: Peripheral retinal neovascularization

desc: A localized dilation of microvasculature formed due to disruption of the internal elastic lamina of a retinal capillary blood vessel. The lesions present as small circular, red dots having distinct margins and are no larger than a blood vessel width at the disk margin. This expansion disturbs the normal flow pattern, changing shear force and pressure along the vessel. Shear force plays a key role in promoting the differentiation and proliferation of endothelial cells.
name: Retinal microaneurysm

desc: Microscopic aneurysms of the retinal arterioles near the central part of the fundus, visible as small round dark red dots on the retinal surface (not arising from visible vessels) that are by definition less than the diameter of the major optic veins as they cross the optic disc.
name: Central fundal arteriolar microaneurysms

desc: A wrinkle of retinal tissue projecting outward from the surface of the retina and visible as a line on fundoscopy.
name: Retinal fold

desc: An area of the retina that is buckled so that a sector-shaped sheet of retina lies in front of the normal retina. This feature is of congenital onset.
name: Falciform retinal fold

desc: A developmental defect characterized by absence of the retina.
name: Aplasia of the retina

desc: A small hole through the whole thickness of the retina.
name: Retinal perforation

desc: A small break in the retina.
name: Retinal hole

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the retina.
name: Retinal neoplasm

desc: A tumor of the eye originating from cells of the retina.
name: Retinoblastoma

desc: A structural abnormality of the retinal nerve fiber layer
layperson: Abnormal retinal nerve fiber layer morphology
name: Abnormal retinal nerve fiber layer morphology
synonyms: Abnormal retinal nerve fibre layer morphology

desc: Swelling (edema) of the retinal nerve fibers.
name: Retinal nerve fiber edema

desc: Reduced anteroposterior thickness of the retina. This phenotype can be appreciated by retinal optical coherence tomography (OCT).
name: Retinal thinning

desc: Splitting of the neuroretinal layers of the retina.
name: Retinoschisis

desc: Fluid which has escaped from retinal blood vessels with a high concentration of lipid, protein, and cellular debris with a typically bright, reflective, white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina.
name: Retinal exudate

desc: Retinal exudate within the retinal tissue itself.
name: Intraretinal exudate

desc: A type of retinal exudate located in the subretinal space between the sensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Subretinal exudate

desc: A retinal exudate in the area surrounding the optic nerve head.
name: Peripapillary exudate

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in the retina.
name: Retinal calcification

desc: Drusen (singular, 'druse') are tiny yellow or white accumulations of extracellular material (lipofuscin) that build up in Bruch's membrane of the eye.
name: Drusen

desc: Optic disc drusen are acellular, calcified deposits within the optic nerve head. Optic disc drusen are congenital and developmental anomalies of the optic nerve head, representing hyaline-containing bodies that, over time, appear as elevated, lumpy irregularities on the anterior portion of the optic nerve.
name: Optic disc drusen

desc: Presence of multiple yellowish-white lesions of various size and configuration on the retina not related to vascular lesions.
name: Retinal flecks

desc: Crystalline deposits in the retina.
name: Retinal crystals

desc: Fluffy white patch on the retina, representing localized areas of dense white swelling of the retinal nerve fibre layer. They often have a zigzag internal structure, a feathered edge but an otherwise well-delineated form and an approximately 1 mm dimension; they project slightly into the vitreous and sometimes deflect retinal vessels.
name: Retinal cotton wool spot

desc: Yellow, white or greyish lesions in the retina that are well-defined/distinct, individual and mostly uniform in size.
name: Retinal dots

desc: Edema/fluid accumulating between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane.
name: Subretinal fluid

desc: Edema/fluid accumulating within the retinal layers.
name: Intraretinal fluid

desc: Deposits accumulating between the outer retina and the retinal pigment epithelium.
name: Subretinal deposits

desc: Deposits accumulating between the outer retina and the retinal pigment epithelium and that have a focal distribution.
name: Focal subretinal deposits

desc: Deposits accumulating between the outer retina and the retinal pigment epithelium and that are distributed with multiple foci.
name: Multifocal subretinal deposits

desc: Deposits accumulating between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane.
name: Sub-RPE deposits

desc: Deposits accumulating between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane and that are distributed in a single focus.
name: Focal sub-RPE deposits

desc: Deposits accumulating between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane and that are distributed in multiple foci.
name: Multifocal sub-RPE deposits

desc: Inflammation of the retina of the eye.
name: Retinitis

desc: A pebbly orange appearance of the fundus that is said to resemble the skin of an orange.
name: Retinal peau d'orange

desc: Abnormality of the optic nerve.
name: Abnormality of the optic nerve

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the optic nerve.
name: Optic nerve dysplasia

desc: Degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and their axons.
name: Leber optic atrophy

desc: An acute condition characterized by sudden visual loss (usually discovered in the morning), optic disc edema at onset, optic disc-related visual field defects. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy can be associated with flame hemorrhages on the swollen disc or nearby neuroretinal layer, and sometimes with nearby cotton-wool exudates.
name: Nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy

desc: Underdevelopment of the optic nerve.
name: Optic nerve hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the optic nerve and absence of the septum pellucidum.
name: Septo-optic dysplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the optic disc, that is of the optic nerve head, where ganglion cell axons exit the eye to form the optic nerve.
name: Optic disc hypoplasia

desc: Congenital absence of the optic nerve.
name: Optic nerve aplasia

desc: A morphological abnormality of the optic disc, i.e., of the portion of the optic nerve clinically visible on fundoscopic examination.
name: Abnormality of the optic disc

desc: Apparent optic disc swelling in the absence of increased intracranial pressure.
name: Pseudopapilledema

desc: A pale yellow discoloration of the optic disk (the area of the optic nerve head in the retina). The optic disc normally has a pinkish hue with a central yellowish depression.
name: Optic disc pallor

desc: A pale yellow discoloration of the temporal (lateral) portion of the optic disc.
name: Temporal optic disc pallor

desc: Having a characteristic appearance of a slate gray area of pigmentation within the disc margins that commonly appears along the inferotemporal or temporal neuroretinal rim areas.
name: Optic nerve gray crescent

desc: A pale yellow discoloration of the entire optic disc.
name: Diffuse optic disc pallor

desc: Thinning in the layers of the retina and retinal pigment epithelium around the optic nerve.
name: Peripapillary atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the optic nerve. Optic atrophy results from the death of the retinal ganglion cell axons that comprise the optic nerve and manifesting as a pale optic nerve on fundoscopy.
name: Optic atrophy

layperson: Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression
name: Optic atrophy from cranial nerve compression

desc: Papilledema refers to edema (swelling) of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure.
name: Papilledema

desc: An elevation in the ratio of the diameter of the cup of the optic disc to the total diameter of the disc. The optic disc has an orange-pink rim with a pale centre (the cup) that does not contain neuroretinal tissue. An increase in this ratio therefore may indicate a decrease in the quantity of healthy neuroretinal cells.
name: Increased cup-to-disc ratio

desc: An abnormal increase in the ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc.
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio

desc: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.6 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.6

desc: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.7 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.7

desc: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.8 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.8

desc: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.9 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.9

desc: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 1.0 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).
name: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 1.0

desc: A structural abnormality of the optic chiasm.The optic chiasm, located below the hypothalamus, is a partial crossing of the optic nerves.
name: Abnormality of optic chiasm morphology

desc: An abnormality of the optic nerve in which the optic nerve is large and funneled and displays a conical excavation of the optic disc. The optic disc appears dysplastic.
name: Morning glory anomaly

desc: Abnormal decussation of the visual pathways, typically identified using visual evoked potentials (VEP) (asymmetrical distribution of the VEP over the posterior scalp).
name: Optic nerve misrouting

desc: An arteriovenous malformation is a disruption of the normal vascular pattern in which arteries or arterioles connect directly to the venous collection system, bypassing any capillary bed. This term refers to an arteriovenous malformation located in the optic nerve.
name: Optic nerve arteriovenous malformation

desc: A tram-track sign is composed of two enhancing areas of tumor separated from each other by the negative defect of the optic nerve. It is seen on contrast-enhanced CT scan and MRI images, in optic nerve sheath meningioma. The sign helps distinguish between optic nerve sheath meningioma and optic glioma. Optic glioma arises from glial cells within the optic nerve and there is no clear separation between the nerve and the tumor; hence the tram-track sign is not seen in optic gliomas. Calcification may be seen in optic nerve sheath meningiomas in 20-50% of cases and hence the tram-track sign may be seen on nonenhanced CT scan images as a linear calcification around the nerve, but this is less common.
name: Optic nerve tram-track sign

desc: Inflammation of the optic nerve.
name: Optic neuritis

desc: Optic neuritis that occurs in the section of the optic nerve located behind the eyeball.
name: Retrobulbar optic neuritis

desc: Golden, scintillating, particulate reflection noted on fundus examination (typically in the macula and sparing the fovea). The term tapetal is used to describe this 'metallic' sheen appearance as it is thought to be similar to the 'tapetal' reflex seen in the eyes of certain animals.
name: Tapetal-like fundal reflex

desc: Change in the color of the fundus from red in the dark-adapted state to golden immediately or shortly after the onset of the light. The color of the fundus reflex in the light adapted state has also been described as golden-yellow, gray-white, and yellow-white. This reflex can appear either homogeneous or in streaks in the fundus. The retinal vessels appear to be protruding in contrast to the radiant background. Dark adaptation leads to disappearance of the unusual fundus coloration [Digital Journal of Ophthalmology 2008; Volume 14, Number 14].
name: Mizuo phenomenon

desc: Any anomaly of the pigmentation of the fundus, the posterior part of the eye including the retina and optic nerve.
name: Abnormality of fundus pigmentation

desc: Reduced pigmentation of the fundus, typically generalised. Fundoscopy may reveal a low level pigment in both RPE and choroid with clear visibility of choroidal vessels (pale/albinoid) or low pigment level in the RPE with deep pigment in choroid so that visible choroidal vessels are separated by deeply pigmented zones (tesselated/tigroid).
name: Hypopigmentation of the fundus

desc: Areas of the retina lacking pigmentation. Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation less than 1 disc diameter in size and tending to be located in the midperiphery of the retina.
name: Achromatic retinal patches
synonyms: Punched out areas of chorioretinal hypopigmentation

desc: Increased pigmentation of the fundus
name: Hyperpigmentation of the fundus

desc: Sharply demarcated, congenital hyperpigmentation of the retinal pigment epithelium.
layperson: Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
name: Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium

desc: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital found in around 3-5% of the population and of no functional significance.
layperson: Solitary congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
name: Solitary congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
synonyms: Single isolated congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium

desc: Sharply demarcated hyperpigmentation which is congenital.
layperson: Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
name: Multiple bilateral congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium

layperson: Grouped congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
name: Grouped congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
synonyms: Bear track congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium

desc: Bleeding within the fundus of the eye.
name: Fundus hemorrhage

desc: An accumulation of blood between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) arising from the choroidal or retinal circulation.
name: Preretinal hemorrhage

desc: A localized detachment of the vitreous from the retina due to the accumulation of blood. When localized in the macular area, it results in sudden profound loss of vision. Subhyaloid premacular hemorrhage is typically characterized by a circumscribed, round or dumb-bell shaped, bright red mound of blood beneath the internal limiting membrane (ILM) or between the ILM and hyaloid face, in or near to the central macular area.
name: Subhyaloid hemorrhage

desc: Any structural anomaly of the vitreous body.
name: Abnormal vitreous humor morphology

desc: Separation of the vitreous humor from the retina.
name: Posterior vitreous detachment

desc: Ocular abnormality characterised by premature degeneration of the vitreous and the retina that may be associated with increased risk of retinal detachment.
name: Vitreoretinopathy

desc: A form of vitreoretinopathy characterized by thinning (erosion) of the retinal pigment epithelium that permits increased visualization of the choroidal vessels.
name: Erosive vitreoretinopathy

desc: A type of vitreoretinal degeneration with manifestations that are concentrated at the periphery of the retina.
name: Peripheral vitreoretinal degeneration

desc: Deposition of hyaline extracellular material (amyloid) into the vitreous humor, which can manifest as vitreous opacities and reduced visual acuity.
layperson: Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humor
name: Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humor
synonyms: Amyloid deposition in the vitreous humour

desc: Bleeding within the vitreous compartment of the eye.
name: Vitreous hemorrhage

desc: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth. This features results from a failure of regression of the hyaloid vessel, which supplies the primary vitreous during embryogenesis and normally regresses in the third trimester of pregnancy, leading to a particular form of posterior cataract.
layperson: Remnants of the hyaloid vascular system
name: Remnants of the hyaloid vascular system
synonyms: Persistent posterior fetal fibrovascular sheath of the lens

desc: Persistence of the hyaloid artery, which is the embryonic artery that runs from the optic disk to the posterior lens capsule may persist; the site of attachment may form an opacity. The hyaloid artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, and usually regresses completely before birth.
layperson: Vascular remnant arising from the disc
name: Vascular remnant arising from the disc

desc: This anomaly, also known as Mittendorf dot, is a benign, nonprogressive recognizable lesion that does not cause visual impairment. However, it can resemble a pathological congenital or acquired cataract lesion which may enlarge and cause visual impairment. The dot appears as a black speck that ranges in size from the dot made by a sharp pencil point to the size of a poppy seed. It is usually well defined, although occasionally there may be irregular, fine lines radiating outward from the dot.
name: Glial remnants posterior to lens

desc: Persistance of a posterior remnant of the hyaloid artery located at the optic disc.
layperson: Glial remnants anterior to the optic disc
name: Glial remnants anterior to the optic disc

desc: A type of persistance of the hyaloid vascular system associated with a retrolental mass that may lead to fetal cataract.
layperson: Hyaloid vascular remnant and retrolental mass
name: Hyaloid vascular remnant and retrolental mass

desc: Inflammation of the vitreous body, characterized by the presence of inflammatory cells and protein exudate in the vitreous cavity.
name: Vitritis

desc: Vitreous haze is the obscuration of fundus details by vitreous cells and protein exudation.
name: Vitreous haze

desc: Yellow-white inflammatory aggregates in the vitreous that are found in the midvitreous and inferior periphery.
name: Vitreous snowballs

desc: The presence of inflammatory cells such as lymphocytes and macrophages in the vitreous.
name: Vitreous inflammatory cells

desc: Vestigial vitreous gel occupying the immediate retrolental space and minimal to no discernable gel in the central vitreous cavity, giving the appearance of an empty vitreous cavity.
name: Optically empty vitreous

desc: The presence of small, white vitreous opacities consisting of calcium phosphate and complex, layered lipid deposits.
name: Asteroid hyalosis

desc: Vitreous humor of the eye displaying consisting of a vestigial gel in the retrolental space bounded by a convoluted membrane.
name: Membranous vitreous appearance

desc: Vitreous humor of the eye displaying beaded bundles of irregular diameters.
name: Beaded vitreous appearance

desc: Deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye's vitreous humour, which is normally transparent.
name: Vitreous floaters

desc: Fiber- or rope-like opacities located within the vitreous humor.
name: Vitreous strands

desc: Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) is a non-invasive retinal imaging modality used in clinical practice to provide a density map of lipofuscin, the predominant ocular fluorophore, in the retinal pigment epithelium. Autofluorescent patterns result from the complex interaction of fluorophores such a lipofuscin, which release an autofluorescent signal, and elements such as melanin and rhodopsin, which absorb the excitation beam and attenuate autofluorescence. Other structures such as retinal vessels and the crystalline lens may also influence autofluorescence through blocking and interference.
name: Abnormal fundus autofluorescence imaging

desc: Increased amount of autofluorescence in the retina as ascertained by fundus autofluorescence imaging.
name: Hyperautofluorescent retinal lesion

desc: Increased amount of autofluorescence in the macula as ascertained by fundus autofluorescence imaging.
name: Hyperautofluorescent macular lesion

desc: Decreased amount of autofluorescence in the retina as ascertained by fundus autofluorescence imaging.
name: Hypoautofluorescent retinal lesion

desc: Decreased amount of autofluorescence in the macula as ascertained by fundus autofluorescence imaging.
name: Hypoautofluorescent macular lesion

layperson: Perifoveal ring of hyperautofluorescence surrounded by normal autofluorescence
name: Perifoveal ring of hyperautofluorescence surrounded by normal autofluorescence

layperson: Perifoveal ring of hyperautofluorescence surrounded by abnormal autofluorescence
name: Perifoveal ring of hyperautofluorescence surrounded by abnormal autofluorescence

layperson: Abnormal retinal morphology on macular OCT
name: Abnormal retinal morphology on macular OCT

desc: Loss of the outer nuclear layer (photoreceptor layer) as assessed by ocular coherence tomography.
layperson: Photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT
name: Photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT

layperson: Photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT
name: Photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT

layperson: Retinal pigment epithelial loss on macular OCT
name: Retinal pigment epithelial loss on macular OCT

layperson: Abnormal foveal morphology on macular OCT
name: Abnormal foveal morphology on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT
name: Foveal photoreceptor layer loss on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT
name: Foveal photoreceptor outer segment loss on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal retinal pigment epithelial loss on macular OCT
name: Foveal retinal pigment epithelial loss on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal inner retinal layer loss on macular OCT
name: Foveal inner retinal layer loss on macular OCT

layperson: Abnormal foveal pit on macular OCT
name: Abnormal foveal pit on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT
name: Foveal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal intraretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT
name: Foveal intraretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT

layperson: Foveal subretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT
name: Foveal subretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT

layperson: Inner retinal layer loss on macular OCT
name: Inner retinal layer loss on macular OCT

layperson: Intraretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT
name: Intraretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT

layperson: Subretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT
name: Subretinal hyporeflective spaces on macular OCT

desc: An abnormality observed by retinal fluorescein angiography, which involves the intravenous injection of fluorescein dye followed by fluorescent imaging of the fundus immediately after injection and for up to ten minutes thereafter. It can be used to study various retinal abnormalities including especially anomalies of the choroidal and retinal circulation.
name: Abnormal fundus fluorescein angiography

desc: Leakage of fluorescein dye observed upon retinal fluorescein angiography. Areas of leakage can be appreciated as showing gradual enlargement with blurring of margins.
layperson: Leakage of dye on fundus fluorescein angiography
name: Leakage of dye on fundus fluorescein angiography
Abnormality of the vasculature of the eye

desc: A reddish appearance over the white part (sclera) of the eye ranging from a few enlarged blood vessels appearing as wiggly lines over the sclera to a bright red color completely covering to sclera.
name: Red eye

desc: Absence of the globe or eyeball.
name: Anophthalmia

desc: Absence of globe, optic nerve, chiasm and optic tracts. No evidence of ocular tissue on MRI scan or examination.
name: True anophthalmia

desc: A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one or both eyes.
name: Microphthalmia
synonyms: Decreased size of globe of eye

desc: A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of both eyes.
layperson: Abnormally small eyeball on both sides
name: Bilateral microphthalmos
synonyms: Abnormally small eyeball on both sides
Decreased size of globes of eyes

desc: A developmental anomaly characterized by abnormal smallness of one eye.
layperson: Abnormally small eyeball on one side
name: Unilateral microphthalmos
synonyms: Abnormally small eyeball on one side

desc: Rupture of the eyeball not due to trauma.
name: Spontaneous rupture of the globe

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the eye.
name: Neoplasm of the eye

desc: A malignant melanoma originating within the eye. The tumor originates from the melanocytes in the uvea (which comprises the iris, ciliary body, and choroid).
name: Uveal melanoma

desc: Malignant tumor of melanocytes of the choroid. The classic appearance of choroidal melanoma is a pigmented dome-shaped or collar button-shaped tumor with an associated exudative retinal detachment. Choroidal melanoma is usually pigmented, but can be variably pigmented and even amelanotic (non-pigmented).
name: Choroidal melanoma

desc: A schwannoma (benign, usually encapsulated slow growing tumor composed of Schwann cells) located in the orbit.
name: Orbital schwannoma

desc: An abnormality in the placement of the ocular globe (eyeball).
name: Abnormality of globe location

desc: Interpupillary distance more than 2 SD above the mean (alternatively, the appearance of an increased interpupillary distance or widely spaced eyes).
name: Hypertelorism

desc: An eye that is more deeply recessed into the plane of the face than is typical.
name: Deeply set eye

desc: An eye that is protruding anterior to the plane of the face to a greater extent than is typical.
name: Proptosis
synonyms: Anterior bulging of the globe of eye

desc: Interpupillary distance less than 2 SD below the mean (alternatively, the appearance of an decreased interpupillary distance or closely spaced eyes).
name: Hypotelorism

desc: Cyclopia is a congenital abnormality in which there is only one eye. That eye is centrally placed in the area normally occupied by the root of the nose.
name: Cyclopia

desc: The orbits do not lie on the same horizontal plane, that is, one eye is lower than the other.
name: Vertical orbital dystopia

desc: An abnormality in the size of the ocular globe (eyeball).
name: Abnormality of globe size

desc: Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) without glaucoma.
name: Abnormally large globe

desc: Abnormal largeness of the eye with an axial length > 2.5 standard deviations from population mean.
layperson: Increased front to back length of eyeball
name: Increased axial length of the globe
synonyms: Increased front to back length of eyeball

desc: A functional anomaly of the eye.
name: Abnormal eye physiology

desc: An abnormality in voluntary or involuntary eye movements or their control.
name: Abnormality of eye movement
synonyms: Abnormal motility of the globe of the eye
Abnormal movement of the globe of the eye

desc: Reduced ability to move the eye in the direction of the nose.
name: Impaired ocular adduction

desc: Any deviation from the normal motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object.
name: Abnormal conjugate eye movement

desc: A misalignment of the eyes so that the visual axes deviate from bifoveal fixation. The classification of strabismus may be based on a number of features including the relative position of the eyes, whether the deviation is latent or manifest, intermittent or constant, concomitant or otherwise and according to the age of onset and the relevance of any associated refractive error.
name: Strabismus

desc: A type of strabismus in which the fixating eye is always the same one, while the other eye is constantly deviated. Monocular strabismus is to be distinguished from alternating strabismus, in which either of the eyes 'squints' at different times.
name: Monocular strabismus

desc: A manifest or latent ocular deviation in which one or both eyes tends to deviate nasally.
name: Esodeviation

desc: A form of strabismus with one or both eyes turned inward ('crossed') to a relatively severe degree, usually defined as 10 diopters or more.
name: Esotropia

desc: Esotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.
name: Alternating esotropia

desc: A form of esotropia (convergent deviation of the eyes) associated with activation of the accommodative reflex.
name: Accommodative esotropia

desc: Esotropia in which normal binocular single vision is present for all distances when the hypermetropic refractive error is corrected. Esotropia is present for near and distance on accommodation without correction.
name: Fully accomodative esotropia

desc: A form of constant esotropia in which the angle of deviation is partially affected by accommodative effort. Typically there is esotropia at near and distance with hypermetropic correction and the angle of deviation increases without glasses.
name: Partially accomodative esotropia
synonyms: Constant esotropia with an accommodative component
Constant esotropia with an accommodative element

desc: An intermittent esotropia with binocular single vision present at distance fixation but esotropia on accommodation for near fixation.
