Usually associated with hypermetropia but patients can be emmetropic and rarely myopic. Associated with a high accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio.
name: Convergence excess esotropia

desc: Convergent squint which follows loss or impairment of vision.
name: Secondary esotropia

desc: A form of esotropia in which the angle of deviation is not affected by accommodative effort.
name: Non-accomodative esotropia

desc: An intermittent esotropia where there is binocular single vision on distance fixation and esotropia at near even when the accommodation is relieved.
name: Near esotropia

desc: A form of convergent strabismus (esotropia) in which the deviation is present under all conditions (ie at all distances and at all times).
name: Basic constant esotropia

desc: Constant esotropia occurring before 6 months of age. It is typically associated with a large angle of deviation, alternating fixation (therefore low risk of amblyopia) and poor potential for binocular single vision. Other features that might be present in individuals with infantile (constant) esotropia include latent nystagmus or manifest latent nystagmus, dissociated vertical divergence, cyclotropia, abnormal head posture, limited abduction.
name: Infantile constant esotropia

desc: An intermittent esotropia where binocular single vision is present on near fixation and an esotropia on distance fixation. Often associated with myopia and aging.
name: Distance esotropia

desc: Convergent strabismus in which normal binocular single vision is alternating with large angle esotropia in rhythmic cycle.
name: Cyclic esotropia

desc: Esotropia in a patient who has previously had exotropia or exophoria; may be constant or intermittent and usually follows surgical overcorrection.
name: Consecutive esotropia

desc: A form of strabismus with both eyes turned inward to a relatively mild degree, usually defined as less than 10 prism diopters.
name: Esophoria

desc: A manifest or latent ocular deviation in which one or both eyes tends to deviate temporally.
name: Exodeviation

desc: A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward.
name: Exotropia

desc: A form of divergent strabismus (exotropia) in which the eye turns outward at all distances and at all times.
name: Constant exotropia

desc: Constant exotropia occurring before 6 months of age.; often associated with a large angle of deviation and ocular/CNS abnormalities.
name: Infantile constant exotropia

desc: Constant exotropia for near and distance, presenting after 6 months of age.
name: Basic constant exotropia

desc: A type of divergent strabismus (exotropia) in which an eye tends to turn outwards (i.e., the eye squints) mainly when looking at distant objects. The eyes tend to remain straight when they look at near objects. Distance exotropia may be constant or intermittent.
name: Distance exotropia

desc: Exotropia (intermittent or constant) on distance fixation with binocular single vision on near fixation under all testing conditions. The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC:A) ratio is within normal limits.
name: True distance exotropia

desc: Exotropia (intermittent or constant) worse for distance fixation in which the near angle of deviation increases (or near exophoria becomes exotropia) with: (1) prolonged disruption of fusion and/or (2) elimination of accommodation.
name: Simulated distance exotropia

desc: An intermittent exotropia where there is binocular single vision on distance fixation and exotropia at near (intermittent or constant).
name: Near exotropia

desc: A type of exotropia (divergent strabismus) in which binocular single vision alternates with large angle exotropia in rhythmic cycle.
name: Cyclic exotropia

desc: A type of exotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.
name: Alternating exotropia

desc: Exotropia in an individual who has previously had esotropia or esophoria.
name: Consecutive exotropia

desc: A type of divergent strabismus (exotropia) that develops in a poorly seeing eye.
name: Sensory exotropia

desc: A form of strabismus with one or both eyes deviated outward to a milder degree than with exotropia.
name: Exophoria

desc: Strabismus in which the angle of deviation differs depending upon the direction of gaze or according to which eye is fixing, associated with: (i) defective movement of the eye, (ii) asymmetrical accommodative effort.
name: Incomitant strabismus

desc: A condition associated with a limitation of the horizontal ocular movement with retraction of the globe and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction
name: Duane anomaly
synonyms: Limited eye motility from Duane anomaly
Globe retraction and deviation on adduction
Limited eye movement from Duane anomaly

desc: A type of incomitant strabismus in which both elevator muscles (i.e., the inferior oblique and superior rectus muscles) of the same eye are weak leading to restricted elevation and hypotropia.
name: Double elevator palsy

desc: An ocular movement abnormality characterised by simultaneous weakness of the inferior rectus muscle and superior oblique muscle of the same eye.
name: Double depressor palsy

desc: A type of incomitant strabismus in which the angle of deviation varies as the patient's gaze shifts upwards and/or downwards.
name: Vertical incomitant strabismus

desc: An ocular motility defect where the affected eye(s) does not elevate in adduction but has full depression in adduction. It can be congenital or acquired from injury to or defect of the superior oblique tendon or trochlea and has a positive forced duction test result.
name: Brown anomaly

desc: Strabismus in which the angle of deviation of the squiting eye remains the same in relation to the other eye, in all directions of gaze, and whichever eye is fixing.
name: Concomitant strabismus

desc: A type of strabismus in which the visual axis of one eye is higher than that of the other.
name: Hyperdeviation

desc: Tendency for the visual axis of one eye to be higher than that of the other.
name: Hyperphoria

desc: A type of vertical phoria in which, in dissociation, the occluded eye deviates upwards.
name: Alternating hyperphoria

desc: A type of strabismus characterized by permanent upward deviation of the visual axis of one eye.
name: Hypertropia

desc: A type of vertical tropia in which, when one eye is fixing, the other eye is deviated upwards.
name: Alternating hypertropia

desc: A type of strabismus in which the visual axis of one eye is lower than that of the other.
name: Hypodeviation

desc: A form of manifest strabismus (heterotropia) in which one eye is deviated downwards when both eyes are open.
name: Hypotropia

desc: A type of vertical tropia in which, when one eye is fixing, the other eye is deviated downwards.
name: Alternating hypotropia

desc: A form of latent strabismus (heterophoria) in which, on dissociation, the occluded eye deviates downwards.
name: Hypophoria

desc: A type of vertical phoria in which, in dissociation, the occluded eye deviates downwards.
name: Alternating hypophoria

desc: Cyclodeviation is defined as the rotation of an eyeball along the anteroposterior axis and cyclotropia as a misalignment of cyclodeviation between the two eyes.
name: Cyclodeviation

desc: A form of manifest strabismus (heterotropia) in which the one eye is wheel rotated so that the upper end of its vertical axis is nasal (incyclotropia) or temporal (excyclotropia).
name: Cyclotropia

desc: A type of cyclotropia (torsion of one or both eye around the visual axis of the eyes) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated inward (medially) to each other.
name: Incyclotropia

desc: A type of cyclotropia (torsion of one or both eye around the visual axis of the eyes) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated outward (laterally) to each other.
name: Excyclotropia

desc: A form of latent strabismus (heterophoria) in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.
name: Cyclophoria

desc: A type of cyclophoria (latent strabismus in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated inward (medially) to each other.
name: Incyclophoria

desc: A type of cyclophoria (latent strabismus in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated outward (laterally) to each other.
name: Excyclophoria

desc: An ocular deviation caused by a palsy to one or more of the extraocular muscles or nerves supplying them.
name: Neurogenic strabismus

desc: Heterophorias are latent deviations that are controlled by fusion. In certain circumstances (specific visual tasks, fatigue, illness, etc.), fusion can no longer be maintained and decompensation occurs.
name: Heterophoria

desc: Manifest deviation of the visual axes not controlled by fusion.
name: Heterotropia

desc: A small angle heterotropia (usually of 10 diopters or less) in which a form of binocular single vision occurs.
name: Microtropia

desc: A type of microtropia with no manifest movement on cover test, the eccentric fixation point coinciding with the angle of ARC.
name: Microtropia with identity

desc: A type of microtropia in which the manifest movement is demonstrated on the cover-uncover test.
name: Microtropia without identity

desc: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a particular direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
name: Supranuclear gaze palsy

desc: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a vertical direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
name: Vertical supranuclear gaze palsy

desc: A limitation of the ability to direct one's gaze below the horizontal meridian.
name: Downgaze palsy

desc: A limitation of the ability to direct one's gaze above the horizontal meridian.
name: Upgaze palsy

desc: A supranuclear gaze palsy is an inability to look in a horizontal direction as a result of cerebral impairment. There is a loss of the voluntary aspect of eye movements, but, as the brainstem is still intact, all the reflex conjugate eye movements are normal.
name: Horizontal supranuclear gaze palsy

desc: Reduced ability to turn the eyes inward in order to focus on a nearby object.
name: Impaired convergence

desc: An abnormality of eye movement characterized by impairment of fast (saccadic) eye movements.
name: Abnormal saccadic eye movements

desc: An abnormally slow velocity of the saccadic eye movements.
name: Slow saccadic eye movements

desc: An abnormally slow velocity of horizontal saccadic eye movements.
name: Slowed horizontal saccades

desc: Saccadic undershoot, i.e., a saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
name: Hypometric saccades

desc: Saccadic undershoot of horizontal saccadic eye movements, i.e., a horizontal saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
name: Hypometric horizontal saccades

desc: Saccadic undershoot of upward saccadic eye movements, i.e., an upward saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.
name: Hypometric upward saccades

desc: The controller signal for saccadic eye movements has two components: the pulse that moves the eye rapidly from one point to the next, and the step that holds the eye in the new position. When both the pulse and the step are not the correct size, a dysmetric refixation eye movement results.
name: Dysmetric saccades

desc: Inaccurate saccades (rapid movement of the eye between fixation points) in the vertical direction.
name: Dysmetric vertical saccades

desc: Inaccurate saccades (rapid movement of the eye between fixation points) in the horizontal direction.
name: Dysmetric horizontal saccades

desc: A saccade that overshoots the target with the dynamic saccade.
name: Hypermetric saccades

desc: Overshoot of downward saccadic eye movements.
name: Hypermetric downward saccades

desc: Overshoot of horizontal (sideways) saccadic eye movements.
name: Hypermetric horizontal saccades

desc: An involuntary abnormality of fixation in which there is an abnormal saccade away from fixation followed by an immediate corrective saccade.
name: Saccadic oscillation

desc: Bursts of large-amplitude multidirectional saccades without intersaccadic interval
name: Opsoclonus

desc: Ocular flutter is an abnormal eye movement consisting of repetitive, irregular, involuntary bursts of horizontal saccades without an intersaccadic interval. It is generally superimposed on normal oculomotor behaviour and its occurrence may be favoured by various events, such as blinks, the triggering of normal saccades or optokinetic stimulation.
name: Ocular flutter

desc: A type of saccadic oscillations with brief periods of fixation between saccades (intersaccadic interval approximately 200 msec). Macrosaccadic oscillations (up to 40 degrees) straddle the intended fixation position and show a crescendo-decrescendo pattern.
name: Macrosaccadic oscillations

desc: An involuntary abnormality of fixation in which there is an abnormal saccade away from fixation followed by a delayed corrective saccade.
name: Saccadic intrusion

desc: Square wave jerks are saccadic eye movements which, when recorded with open eyes are considered to be a pathological sign, caused by fixation instability, and pointing to a central neurological lesion.
name: Square-wave jerks

desc: Horizontal 10-40 degree excursions from fixation and back again.
name: Macrosquare-wave jerks

desc: Ophthalmoplegia is a paralysis or weakness of one or more of the muscles that control eye movement.
layperson: Weakness of muscles controlling eye movement
name: Ophthalmoparesis
synonyms: Weakness of muscles controlling eye movement

desc: Paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles that are responsible for eye movements.
name: Ophthalmoplegia

desc: Paralysis of the external ocular muscles.
layperson: Paralysis or weakness of muscles within or surrounding outer part of eye
name: External ophthalmoplegia
synonyms: Progressive paralysis or weakness of muscles of eye motility
Progressive paralysis or weakness of muscles of eye movement
Paralysis or weakness of muscles within or surrounding outer part of eye

desc: Initial bilateral ptosis followed by limitation of eye movements in all directions and slowing of saccades.
name: Progressive external ophthalmoplegia

desc: Alternating and recurrent weakness of the external ocular muscles.
name: Recurrent external ophthalmoplegia

desc: Nonprogressive restriction of movement of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited.
name: Nonprogressive restrictive external ophthalmoplegia

desc: Fibrosis of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position. Residual eye movements are significantly limited.
name: Restrictive external ophthalmoplegia

desc: Fibrosis of only some of the external ocular muscles such that the eyes of affected individuals are partially or completely fixed in a strabismic position.
name: Restrictive partial external ophthalmoplegia

desc: A vertical gaze palsy with inability to direct the gaze of the eyes downwards.
name: Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia

desc: Paralysis of both the extrinsic and intrinsic ocular muscles.
name: Total ophthalmoplegia

desc: Paralysis of the iris and ciliary apparatus.
name: Internal ophthalmoplegia

desc: An abnormality of conjugate lateral gaze in which the affected eye shows impairment of adduction. The pathognomonic clinical sign of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is an impaired adduction while testing horizontal saccades on the side of the lesion in the ipsilateral medial longitudinal fascicule.
name: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

desc: Reduced ability to control the movement of the eye associated with damage to the third cranial nerve (the oculomotor nerve).
name: Oculomotor nerve palsy

desc: An ophthalmologic sign in young children resulting from upward-gaze paresis. In this condition, the eyes appear driven downward, the sclera may be seen between the upper eyelid and the iris, and part of the lower pupil may be covered by the lower eyelid.
name: Setting-sun eye phenomenon

desc: An abnormality of eye movement characterized by impaired smooth-pursuit eye movements.
name: Abnormality of ocular smooth pursuit

desc: An abnormality of tracking eye movements in which smooth pursuit is interrupted by an abnormally high number of saccadic movements.
name: Saccadic smooth pursuit

desc: An impairment of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion.
name: Impaired smooth pursuit

desc: An abnormality of ocular smooth pursuit characterized by an impairment of the ability to track horizontally moving objects.
name: Impaired horizontal smooth pursuit

desc: A complete lack of the ability to track objects with the ocular smooth pursuit system, a class of rather slow eye movements that minimizes retinal target motion.
name: Absent smooth pursuit

desc: Ocular motor apraxia is a deficiency in voluntary, horizontal, lateral, fast eye movements (saccades) with retention of slow pursuit movements. The inability to follow objects visually is often compensated by head movements. There may be decreased smooth pursuit, and cancellation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
name: Oculomotor apraxia
synonyms: Defective or absent horizontal voluntary eye movements

desc: An abnormality involving the movement of the eye outwards.
name: Abnormality of ocular abduction

layperson: Globe retraction and deviation on abduction
name: Globe retraction and deviation on abduction

desc: An impaired ability of the eye to move in the outward direction (towards the side of the head).
name: Impaired ocular abduction

desc: Anomalous movements of the eyes that occur without the subject wanting them to happen.
name: Abnormal involuntary eye movements

desc: Rhythmic, involuntary oscillations of one or both eyes related to abnormality in fixation, conjugate gaze, or vestibular mechanisms.
name: Nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
name: Gaze-evoked nystagmus

desc: Horizontal nystagmus made apparent by looking to the right or to the left.
name: Gaze-evoked horizontal nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements.
name: Horizontal nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements, in which the movement in one direction is faster than in the other.
name: Horizontal jerk nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus consisting of horizontal to-and-fro eye movements of equal velocity.
name: Horizontal pendular nystagmus

desc: Horizontal nystagmus dating from or present at birth.
name: Congenital horizontal nystagmus

desc: Head movements associated with nystagmus, that may represent an attempt to compensate for the involuntary eye movements and to improve vision.
name: Nystagmus-induced head nodding

desc: A form of nystagmus in which the eyeball makes rotary motions around the axis.
name: Rotary nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus dating from or present at birth.
name: Congenital nystagmus

desc: Nystagmus due to disturbance of the vestibular system; eye movements are rhythmic, with slow and fast components.
name: Vestibular nystagmus

desc: Vertical nystagmus may present with either up-beating or down-beating eye movements or both. When present in the straight-ahead position of gaze it is referred to as upbeat nystagmus or downbeat nystagmus.
name: Vertical nystagmus

desc: Downbeat nystagmus is a type of fixation nystagmus with the fast phase beating in a downward direction. It generally increases when looking to the side and down and when lying prone.
name: Downbeat nystagmus

desc: In primary position, the eyes drift slowly downward and then spontaneously beat upward. Upward gaze accentuates the nystagmus. The associated oscillopsias are often very irritating, but the symptoms are usually transient.
name: Upbeat nystagmus

desc: Rhythmic, involuntary sinusoidal oscillations of one or both eyes. The waveform of pendular nystagmus may occur in any direction.
name: Pendular nystagmus

desc: The combination of pendular nystagmus, head nodding, and torticollis.
name: Spasmus nutans

desc: Seesaw nystagmus is a type of pendular nystagmus where a half cycle consists of the elevation and intorsion of one eye, concurrently with the depression and extortion of the fellow eye. In the other half cycle, there is an inversion of the ocular movements.
name: Seesaw nystagmus

desc: A condition in which both eyes beat outward simultaneously.
name: Divergence nystagmus

desc: Sudden-onset episode of abnormal, involuntary eye movements.
name: Paroxysmal involuntary eye movements

desc: Unilateral ptosis with associated upper eyelid contraction and contraction of either the external or the internal pterygoid muscle. It is thought to occur because of congenital miswiring of a branch of the fifth cranial nerve into the branch of the third cranial nerve supplying the levator muscle. In Marcus Gunn jaw winking synkinesis, elevation and even retraction of the affected eyelid is triggered by chewing, suction, lateral mandible movement, smiling, sternocleidomastoid contraction, protruding tongue, Valsalva manoeuvre and even by breathing.
name: Marcus Gunn jaw winking synkinesis

desc: Any anomaly in the process of ocular fixation, which is the maintaining of the visual gaze on a single location.
name: Abnormal visual fixation

desc: A deficit in the ability to fixate eye movements in order to stabilize images on the retina
name: Visual fixation instability

desc: A uniocular condition in which there is fixation of an object by a point other than the fovea. This point adopts the principal visual direction. The degree of the eccentric fixation is defined by its distance from the fovea in degrees.
name: Eccentric visual fixation

desc: Fixation of an object in the area adjacent to the fovea.
name: Parafoveal fixation

desc: Fixation of an object in a peripheral area of the retina.
name: Peripheral fixation

desc: Eccentric fixation in which the angle of eccentricity equals the objective angle of deviation.
name: Absolute eccentric fixation

desc: An abnormality of gaze that can be observed following an acute supranuclear cerebral lesion (e.g., stroke) that is characterized by an acute inability to direct gaze contralateral to the side of the lesion and is accompanied by a tendency for tonic deviation of the eyes toward the side of the lesion.
name: Visual gaze preference

desc: A compensatory head posture occurs when the head is deviated out of the normal primary straight head position in order to compensate for an ocular problem.
name: Compensatory head posture

desc: A tendency to hold the chin elevated by about 20 to 30 degrees to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
name: Compensatory chin elevation

desc: A tendency to hold the chin depressed (lowered) to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
name: Compensatory chin depression

desc: A tendency to turn the face to the right to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
layperson: Compensatory face turn to the right
name: Compensatory face turn to the right

desc: A tendency to turn the face to the left to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
layperson: Compensatory face turn to the left
name: Compensatory face turn to the left

desc: A tendency to tilt the head towards the right shoulder to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
layperson: Compensatory head tilt to the right shoulder
name: Compensatory head tilt to the right shoulder

desc: A tendency to tilt the head towards the left shoulder to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.
layperson: Compensatory head tilt to the left shoulder
name: Compensatory head tilt to the left shoulder

desc: Any deviation from the normal ocular alignment.
name: Abnormal ocular alignment

desc: An incomitant tendency for an occluded eye to elevate and extort which resolves on uncovering.
name: Dissociated vertical deviation

desc: A change in horizontal ocular alignment, unrelated to accommodation, that is brought about solely by a change in the balance of visual input from the two eyes.
name: Dissociated horizontal deviation

desc: Glaucoma refers loss of retinal ganglion cells in a characteristic pattern of optic neuropathy usually associated with increased intraocular pressure.
name: Glaucoma

desc: A type of glaucoma defined by an open, normal appearing anterior chamber angle and raised intraocular pressure,
name: Open angle glaucoma

desc: A type of glaucomatous optic neuropathy in an eye that has evidence of angle closure (i.e. significant iridotrabecular contact).
name: Angle closure glaucoma

desc: A type of glaucomatous optic neuropathy occuring in the presence of a narrow anterior chamber angle.
name: Narrow angle glaucoma

desc: Abnormality of eyesight (visual perception).
name: Abnormality of vision

desc: Visual impairment (or vision impairment) is vision loss (of a person) to such a degree as to qualify as an additional support need through a significant limitation of visual capability resulting from either disease, trauma, or congenital or degenerative conditions that cannot be corrected by conventional means, such as refractive correction, medication, or surgery.
name: Visual impairment

desc: Loss of visual acuity (implying that vision was better at a certain timepoint in life). Otherwise the term reduced visual acuity should be used (or a subclass of that).
name: Visual loss

desc: A reduction of previously attained ability to see.
name: Progressive visual loss

layperson: Slow decrease in sharpness of vision
name: Slow decrease in visual acuity
synonyms: Slow decrease in sharpness of vision

layperson: Partial loss of field of vision
name: Visual field defect
synonyms: Partial loss of field of vision

desc: A regional and pathological increase of the light detection threshold in any region of the visual field surrounded by a field of normal or relatively well-preserved vision.
name: Scotoma

desc: A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) located between the central point of fixation and the blind spot with a roughly horizontal oval shape.
name: Centrocecal scotoma

desc: An area of depressed vision located at the point of fixation and that interferes with central vision.
name: Central scotoma
synonyms: Blind spot located at fixation point

desc: A scotoma (area of diminished vision within the visual field) that surrounds the central fixation point.
name: Pericentral scotoma

desc: A scintillating scotoma is a common visual aura that can preced a migraine, whereby a spot of flickering light near the center of the visual fields occurs. The spot prevents vision, and is thus termed scotoma. The scotoma can extend into one or more shimmering arcs of white or colored flashing lights.
name: Scintillating scotoma

layperson: Large central loss of field of vision
name: Large central visual field defect
synonyms: Large central loss of field of vision

desc: An absolute or relative decrease in retinal sensitivity extending from edge (periphery) of the visual field in a concentric pattern. The visual field is the area that is perceived simultaneously by a fixating eye.
name: Constriction of peripheral visual field

desc: Loss of peripheral vision with retention of central vision, resulting in a constricted circular tunnel-like field of vision.
name: Peripheral visual field loss

desc: A diminution of the peripheral visual field whereby at least 50 degrees of central field are preserved in all meridians.
layperson: Mild constriction of peripheral visual field
name: Mild constriction of peripheral visual field

desc: Peripheral visual field constriction with 20-49 degrees binocular visual field preserved.
layperson: Moderate constriction of peripheral visual field
name: Moderate constriction of peripheral visual field

desc: Peripheral visual field constriction with 10-19 degrees central field preserved.
layperson: Severe constriction of peripheral visual field
name: Severe constriction of peripheral visual field

desc: Peripheral visual field constriction with <10 degrees central field preserved.
layperson: Very severe constriction of peripheral visual field
name: Very severe constriction of peripheral visual field
synonyms: Very severe peripheral visual field loss

desc: Partial or complete loss of vision in one half of the visual field of one or both eyes.
name: Hemianopia

desc: Abnormal result of a test designed to test an individual's central and peripheral vision by determining the ability of the individual to perceive objects at differing locations of the visual field.
name: Abnormal visual field test

desc: Blindness is the condition of lacking visual perception defined as visual perception below 3/60 and/or a visual field of no greater than 10 degress in radius around central fixation.
name: Blindness

desc: Blindness with onset at birth.
name: Congenital blindness

desc: Reduced visual acuity that is uncorrectable by lenses in the absence of detectable anatomic defects in the eye or visual pathways.
name: Amblyopia

desc: Severe loss of visual acuity within hours or days. This is characteristic of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.
name: Sudden loss of visual acuity

desc: Severe reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/60 (20/200 in US notation; 0.1 in decimal notation) but at least 3/60 (20/400 in US notation; 0.05 in decimal notation).
name: Severely reduced visual acuity

desc: Moderate reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/18 (20/60 in US notation; 0.5 in decimal notation) but at least 6/60 (20/200 in US notation; 0.1 in decimal notation).
name: Moderately reduced visual acuity

layperson: Abnormal best corrected visual acuity test
name: Abnormal best corrected visual acuity test

layperson: Visual acuity light perception with projection
name: Visual acuity light perception with projection

layperson: Visual acuity light perception without projection
name: Visual acuity light perception without projection

desc: Mild reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/12 (20/40 in US notation; 0.5 in decimal notation) but at least 6/18 (20/63 in US notation; 0.32 in decimal notation).
name: Mildly reduced visual acuity

desc: A reduction in visual acuity with best corrected visual acuity between 1.40 (20/500) and 1.89 logMAR (up to roughly 20/1590).
name: Very low visual acuity

desc: Best corrected visual acuity worse than 1.90 logMAR (roughly 20/1590).
name: Ultra-low vision

desc: Ultra-low vision but with retained ability to identify a moving object (typically hand motion at distance of 30 cm).
layperson: Ultra-low vision with retained motion projection
name: Ultra-low vision with retained motion projection

desc: Ultra-low vision but with retained ability to perceive the difference between light and dark. Also when light is projected in each of the four quadrants of the visual field, the individual is able to correctly identify the origin of the light stimulus.
layperson: Ultra-low vision with retained light projection
name: Ultra-low vision with retained light projection

desc: Ultra-low vision but with retained ability to perceive the difference between light and dark.
layperson: Ultra-low vision with retained light perception
name: Ultra-low vision with retained light perception

desc: Ultra-low vision with complete lack of light and form perception.
layperson: Ultra-low vision with no light perception
name: Ultra-low vision with no light perception

desc: A form of loss of vision caused by damage to the visual cortex rather than a defect in the eye.
name: Cerebral visual impairment

desc: An anomaly in the ability to discriminate between or recognize colors.
name: Color vision defect

desc: A form of colorblindness in which only two of the three fundamental colors can be distinguished due to a lack of one of the retinal cone pigments.
name: Dyschromatopsia

desc: Difficulty with discriminating red and green hues.
name: Red-green dyschromatopsia

desc: A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with abnormal M photopigment, such that the absorption spectrum is shifted toward L wavelengths. Affected individuals have difficulties distinguishing between red and green.
name: Deuteranomaly

desc: Complete lack of the M photopigment, which is replaced with the L photopigment. Affected individuals tend to confuse red and green.
name: Deuteranopia

desc: Blue and green cones only; no functional red cones.
name: Protanopia

desc: A type of anomalous trichromacy associated with defective long-wavelength-sensitive (L) cones, causing the sensitivity spectrum to be shifted toward medium wavelengths. This leads to difficulties especially in distinguishing red and green.
name: Protanomaly

desc: Individuals affected by dichromacy possess only two types of cones, instead of three.
name: Dichromacy

desc: Individuals with anomalous trichromacy possess three types of cones, but one of the three types of cones has an abnormal spectral sensitivity compared to normal cones.
name: Anomalous trichromacy

desc: Difficulty distinguishing between yellow and blue, possible related to dysfunction of the S photopigment.
name: Tritanomaly

desc: Complete color blindness, a complete inability to distinguish colors. Affected persons cannot perceive colors, but only shades of gray.
name: Monochromacy

desc: A condition where the retina contains no functional cone cells, so that in addition to the absence of color discrimination, vision in lights of normal intensity is difficult.
name: Achromatopsia

desc: The condition of having both rods and cones, but only a single kind of cone. Affected individuals have good pattern vision in daylight, but cannot distinguish between colors.
name: Cone monochromacy

desc: A form of monochromacy in which vision is derived from the remaining preserved blue (S) cones and rod photoreceptors.
name: Blue cone monochromacy

desc: Excessive sensitivity to light with the sensation of discomfort or pain in the eyes due to exposure to bright light.
name: Photophobia
synonyms: Extreme sensitivity of the eyes to light

desc: Lack of sharpness of vision resulting in the inability to see fine detail.
name: Blurred vision

desc: Transient blurring of vision associated with the aura phase of migraine.
name: Transient unilateral blurring of vision

desc: Inability to see well at night or in poor light.
name: Nyctalopia

desc: Inability to see well at night or in poor light with onset in adulthood.
name: Adult-onset night blindness

desc: An abnormality of binocular vision, that is of the ability to synthesize the visual inputs from both eyes to a single image with perception of depth.
name: Abnormality of binocular vision

desc: Diplopia is a condition in which a single object is perceived as two images, it is also known as double vision.
name: Diplopia

desc: Inability to make fine depth discriminations from parallax provided by the two eyes' different positions on the head.
name: Abnormal stereopsis

desc: A visual defect characterized by the inability to see as clearly in bright light as in dim light. The word hemeralopia literally means day blindness.
name: Hemeralopia

desc: A visual anomaly in which images appear distorted. A grid of straight lines appears wavy and parts of the grid may appear blank.
name: Metamorphopsia

desc: Lack of visual responsiveness or decrease in visual capabilities suggesting a lack of visual responsiveness or decrease in visual capabilities in an infant or young child in which visual behavior fails to meet normal developmental milestones.
name: Poor visual behavior for age

desc: Difficulty in seeing moving objects.
name: Bradyopsia

layperson: Difficulty adjusting to changes in luminance
name: Difficulty adjusting to changes in luminance

layperson: Difficulty adjusting from light to dark
name: Difficulty adjusting from light to dark

layperson: Difficulty adjusting from dark to light
name: Difficulty adjusting from dark to light

desc: Perceived flashes of light.
name: Photopsia

desc: An abnormality in perception of contrast. Spatial contrast is a physical dimension referring to the light-dark transition of a border or an edge in an image that delineates the existence of a pattern or an object. Contrast sensitivity refers to a measure of how much contrast a person requires to see a target. Contrast-sensitivity measurements differ from acuity measurements; acuity is a measure of the spatial-resolving ability of the visual system under conditions of very high contrast, whereas contrast sensitivity is a measure of the threshold contrast for seeing a target.
name: Abnormal contrast sensitivity

desc: A mild reduction in the ability to perceive visual contrast characterized by 0.20-0.59 log unit contrast sensitivity loss.
name: Mildly reduced contrast sensitivity

desc: A moderate reduction in the ability to perceive visual contrast characterized by 0.60-0.99 log unit contrast sensitivity loss.
name: Moderately reduced contrast sensitivity

desc: A severe reduction in the ability to perceive visual contrast characterized by 1.00 log unit or more contrast sensitivity loss.
name: Severely reduced contrast sensitivity

desc: An abnormality in perception of contrast as measured by the Vistech wall chart sine wave grating test.
name: Abnormal Vistech contrast sensitivity test

desc: An abnormality in perception of contrast as measured by the Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity chart, which is a large wall-mounted chart, with letters of a fixed size (comprising spatial frequencies appropriate for estimating peak contrast sensitivity) that decrease in contrast.
layperson: Abnormal Pelli Robson contrast sensitivity chart test
name: Abnormal Pelli Robson contrast sensitivity chart test

desc: A transient visual disturbance that is typically caused by a circulatory, ocular or neurological underlying condition.
name: Amaurosis fugax

desc: The upper eyelid margin is positioned 3 mm or more lower than usual and covers the superior portion of the iris (objective); or, the upper lid margin obscures at least part of the pupil (subjective).
name: Ptosis

layperson: Congenital drooping of both upper eyelids
name: Congenital bilateral ptosis
synonyms: Congenital drooping of both upper eyelids

desc: An abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis, miosis, and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection.
name: Horner syndrome

desc: A type of Horner syndrome with congenital onset.
name: Congenital Horner syndrome

desc: A unilateral form of ptosis.
name: Unilateral ptosis

desc: A progressive form of ptosis.
name: Progressive ptosis

desc: An abnormality in the process of focusing of light by the eye in order to produce a sharp image on the retina.
name: Abnormality of refraction

desc: An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects in the distance clearly, while objects nearby appear blurry.
name: Hypermetropia

desc: A severe form of hypermetropia with over +5.00 diopters.
name: High hypermetropia

desc: A term to describe when farsightedness is masked when the accommodative muscles are used to increase the focusing power of the eye.
name: Latent hypermetropia

desc: A form of hypermetropia with not more than +2.00 diopters.
name: Mild hypermetropia

desc: A form of hypermetropia with more than +2.00 diopters but not more than +5.00 diopters.
name: Moderate hypermetropia

desc: An abnormality of refraction characterized by the ability to see objects nearby clearly, while objects in the distance appear blurry.
name: Myopia

desc: A severe form of myopia with greater than -6.00 diopters.
name: High myopia

desc: A mild form of myopia with up to -3.00 diopters.
name: Mild myopia

desc: A moderate form of myopia with refractive error of between -3.00 and -6.00 diopters.
name: Moderate myopia

desc: A form of myopia related to an axial length above the norm and too long for the refractive power of the whole optical system of the eye.
name: Axial myopia

desc: The difference between total and manifest myopia.
name: Latent myopia

desc: Inequality of refractive power of the two eyes.
name: Anisometropia

desc: Abnormality of tear production.
name: Lacrimation abnormality

desc: Abnormally decreased lacrimation, that is, reduced ability to produce tears.
name: Decreased lacrimation

desc: Absence of tear secretion.
name: Alacrima
synonyms: Absence of tears in the eyes

desc: Abnormally increased lacrimation, that is, excessive tearing (watering eye).
name: Epiphora

desc: Increased lacrimation owing to overproduction of tears.
name: Increased tear production

desc: A form of watery eye associated with overproduction of tears due to an increased parasympathetic drive to the secretory component of the lacrimal system (lacrimal gland); this could be due to pro-secretory drug use (e.g. pilocarpine) or autonomic disturbance.
name: Increased basal tear production

desc: A form of watery eye associated with overproduction of tears due to reflex tearing in response to a local irritant (e.g. trichiasis or foreign body), chronic ocular surface disease (e.g. blepharitis) or systemic disease (e.g. thyroid eye disease).
name: Reflex tearing

desc: A form of watery eye associated with abnormal lid tone and/or lid position. The former is due to lid laxity (common involutional change in the elderly) or a weak orbicularis muscle (e.g. due to VII cranial nerve palsy). The latter is typically associated with ectropion causing punctal eversion.
name: Lacrimal pump failure

desc: A form of watery eye associated with obstruction of the nasolacrimal system. This may arise at the level of the punctum, the canaliculi, the sac or the nasolacrimal duct.
name: Decreased tear drainage

desc: Gustatory lacrimation results from an aberrant innervation of fibres from the seventh cranial nerve to the pterygopalatine ganglion which are destined originally for the submandibular ganglion. This aberrant innervation leads to uncontrollable tearing while eating or in anticipation of a meal.
name: Gustatory lacrimation

desc: A functional abnormality of the pupil.
name: Abnormal pupillary function

desc: Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil.
name: Miosis

desc: Abnormal (non-physiological) constriction of the pupil of congenital onset.
name: Congenital miosis

desc: An abnormality of the reflex that controls the diameter of the pupil, in response to the intensity of light that falls on the retina of the eye.
name: Abnormal pupillary light reflex

desc: Reduced velocity and acceleration in the pupillary light response.
name: Slow pupillary light response

desc: Abnormal dilatation of the iris.
name: Mydriasis

desc: Congenital abnormal dilation of the pupil on both sides.
name: Bilateral congenital mydriasis

desc: An abnormality of the pupillary light reaction characterized by a marked slowing of the light reaction of usually just one pupil. The pupil tends to be relatively dilated, and there is reduced accommodation.
name: Tonic pupil

desc: Bleeding from vessels of the various tissues of the eye.
name: Hemorrhage of the eye

desc: Bleeding in the anterior chamber of the eye.
name: Hyphema

desc: Hemorrhage from the vessels of the choroid.
name: Choroid hemorrhage

desc: Bleeding beneath the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelid.
name: Subconjunctival hemorrhage

desc: An anomaly in the amount of force per unit area exerted by the intraocular fluid within the eye.
name: Abnormal intraocular pressure

desc: A difference in the amount of intraocular pressure in the right and left eye.
name: Asymmetry of intraocular pressure

desc: Intraocular pressure that is 2 standard deviations above the population mean.
name: Ocular hypertension

desc: An abnormal decrease of the pressure within the eye.
name: Low intraocular pressure

desc: An abnormality in which the eyes are held permanently wide open.
name: Staring gaze

desc: A functional anomaly of the muscles of the eye.
name: Abnormal extraocular muscle physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the inferior or superior oblique muscle.
name: Abnormal oblique muscle physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the superior oblique muscle, a fusiform muscle that originates in the upper, medial side of the orbit. The superior oblique muscle abducts, depresses and internally rotates the eye, and is the only extraocular muscle innervated by the fourth cranial nerve.
name: Abnormal superior oblique muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength of the superior oblique muscle.
name: Superior oblique muscle weakness

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the superior oblique muscle.
name: Superior oblique muscle restriction

desc: Reduced ocular movement of the superior oblique muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Superior oblique muscle underaction

desc: An ocular motility abnormality characterized by an overacting superior oblique muscle resulting to vertical incomitance of the eyes in lateral gaze. On examination, this is commonly seen as a downshoot of the adducting eye occuring when gaze is directed into the field of action of the inferior oblique muscle, producing a greater downward excursion of the adducted eye than of the abducted eye.
name: Superior oblique muscle overaction

desc: A functional anomaly of the inferior oblique muscle, an extraocular muscle that has its origin on the maxillary bone just posterior to the inferior medial orbital rim and lateral to the nasolacrimal canal and that is innervated by the inferior branch of the oculomotor nerve.
name: Abnormal inferior oblique muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength of the inferior oblique muscle.
name: Inferior oblique muscle weakness

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the inferior oblique muscle.
name: Inferior oblique muscle restriction

desc: Reduced ocular movement by the inferior oblique muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Inferior oblique muscle underaction

desc: A common ocular motility disorder characterized by vertical incomitance of the eyes in lateral gaze. In primary inferior oblique muscle overaction, an upshoot of the adducting eye occurs when gaze is directed into the field of action of the inferior oblique muscle, producing a greater upward excursion of the adducted eye than of the abducted eye.
name: Inferior oblique muscle overaction

desc: A functional anomaly of a vertical or horizontal rectus muscle.
name: Abnormal rectus muscle physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the medial rectus muscle or lateral rectus muscle.
name: Abnormal horizontal rectus muscle physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the medial rectus muscle, an extraocular muscle that is innervated by the inferior division of the oculomotor nerve and whose sole action is the adduction of the eyeball.
name: Abnormal medial rectus muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength of the medial rectus muscle.
name: Medial rectus muscle weakness

desc: Reduced movement of the medial rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Medial rectus muscle underaction

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the medial rectus muscle.
name: Medial rectus muscle restriction

desc: Excessive action of the medial rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.
name: Medial rectus muscle overaction

desc: A functional anomaly of the lateral rectus muscle.
name: Abnormal lateral rectus muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength (ability to move) of the lateral rectus muscle.
name: Lateral rectus muscle weakness

desc: Reduced movement of the lateral rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Lateral rectus muscle underaction

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the lateral rectus muscle.
name: Lateral rectus muscle restriction

desc: Excessive action of the lateral rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.
name: Lateral rectus muscle overaction

desc: A functional anomaly of the superior or inferior rectus muscle.
name: Abnormal vertical rectus muscle physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the inferior rectus muscle, which is innervated by the inferior division of oculomotor nerve and functions in the depression, adduction, and lateral rotation (extortion) of the eye.
name: Abnormal inferior rectus muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength of the inferior rectus muscle.
name: Inferior rectus muscle weakness

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the inferior rectus muscle.
name: Inferior rectus muscle restriction

desc: Reduced movement by the inferior rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Inferior rectus muscle underaction

desc: Excessive action of the inferior rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.
name: Inferior rectus muscle overaction

desc: A functional anomaly of the superior rectus muscle, an extraocular muscle that is innervated by the superior division of the oculomotor nerve, and whose primary function is the elevation of the globe.
name: Abnormal superior rectus muscle physiology

desc: Decreased strength of the superior rectus muscle.
name: Superior rectus muscle weakness

desc: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the superior rectus muscle.
name: Superior rectus muscle restriction

desc: Reduced movement of the superior rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.
name: Superior rectus muscle underaction

desc: Excessive action of the superior rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.
name: Superior rectus muscle overaction

desc: Any abnormality of the electrical responses of various cell types in the retina as measured by electroretinography.
name: Abnormal electroretinogram

desc: Lack of any response to stimulation upon electroretinography.
name: Undetectable electroretinogram

desc: No detectable response to the light-adapted 3.0 ERG (single-flash cone response). This type of ERG measures responses of the cone system; a-waves arise from cone photoreceptors and cone off-bipolar cells; the b-wave comes from On- and Off-cone bipolar cells.
name: Undetectable light-adapted electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of light-adapted single flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal amplitude of light-adapted single flash electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal timing of light-adapted single flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal timing of light-adapted single flash electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of light-adapted flicker electroretinogram
name: Abnormal amplitude of light-adapted flicker electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal timing of light-adapted flicker electroretinogram
name: Abnormal timing of light-adapted flicker electroretinogram

desc: An abnormality of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram.
name: Abnormal light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram

desc: Descreased amplitude of eletrical response upon electroretinography.
layperson: Decreased light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram amplitude
name: Decreased light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram amplitude
synonyms: Decreased amplitudes on flash visual electroretinogram

desc: Absence of the combined rod-and-cone response on electroretinogram.
name: Undetectable light- and dark-adapted electroretinogram
synonyms: Absent cone and rod functions by electroretinogram
Absent rod-and cone-mediated responses on ERG

layperson: Abnormal timing of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal timing of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram

desc: A dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram in which the b-wave that is of markedly lower amplitude than the associated a-wave (source: Holder GE., Inherited Chorioretinal Dystrophies: A Textbook and Atlas; 2014; p.17; ISBN 978-3-540-69466-3).
name: Electronegative electroretinogram
synonyms: Reduced amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram b-wave

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the a-wave.
layperson: Reduced amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram a-wave
name: Reduced amplitude of dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram a-wave

layperson: Supernormal dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram b-wave
name: Supernormal dark-adapted bright flash electroretinogram b-wave

layperson: Abnormal timing of dark-adapted dim flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal timing of dark-adapted dim flash electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of dark-adapted dim flash electroretinogram
name: Abnormal amplitude of dark-adapted dim flash electroretinogram

desc: An anomalous response to a pattern electroretinogram (PERG), a particular kind of ERG obtained in response to contrast modulation of patterned visual stimuli at constant mean luminance-typically contrast-reversing gratings or checkerboards-whose characteristics are fundamentally different from those of the traditional ERG in response to diffuse flashes of light.
name: Abnormal pattern electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal P50/N95 ratio of pattern electroretinogram
name: Abnormal P50/N95 ratio of pattern electroretinogram

desc: Absent response to a pattern electroretinogram (PERG).
name: Undetectable pattern electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal central response of multifocal electroretinogram
name: Abnormal central response of multifocal electroretinogram

layperson: Abnormal paracentral response of multifocal electroretinogram
name: Abnormal paracentral response of multifocal electroretinogram

desc: An anomaly of visually evoked potentials (VEP), which are electrical potentials, initiated by brief visual stimuli, which are recorded from the scalp overlying the visual cortex.
name: Abnormality of visual evoked potentials

desc: Anomaly of the visual evoked potentials elicited by a flash stimulus, generally a flash of light subtending an angle of at least 20 degrees of the visual field and presented in a dimly lit room.
name: Abnormal flash visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormal timing of flash visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal timing of flash visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of flash visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal amplitude of flash visual evoked potentials

layperson: Asymmetrical distribution of flash visual evoked potentials
name: Asymmetrical distribution of flash visual evoked potentials
synonyms: Crossed asymmetry of flash visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormality of pattern visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormality of pattern visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormality of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormality of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal amplitude of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials
synonyms: Abnormal amplitude of pattern onset/offset VEP

layperson: Abnormal timing of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal timing of pattern onset/offset visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormality of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormality of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormal amplitude of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal amplitude of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormal timing of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
name: Abnormal timing of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials

layperson: Asymmetrical distribution of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
name: Asymmetrical distribution of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials
synonyms: Crossed asymmetry of pattern reversal visual evoked potentials

desc: The clinical electro-oculogram (EOG) is an electrophysiological test of function of the outer retina and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) in which changes in electrical potential across the RPE are recorded during successive periods of dark and light adaptation.
name: Abnormal electrooculogram

desc: An abnormal reduction in the Arden ratio, which is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record.
name: Decreased Arden ratio of electrooculogram

desc: An abnormal increase in the Arden ratio, which is the ratio between the light peak and the dark trough of the smoothed (physiologic) EOG record.
name: Increased Arden ratio of electrooculogram

desc: Retinal phenotype characterised by cone photoreceptor dysfunction and preserved rod system. The abnormality is typically stationary or very slowly progressive and findings may include reduced central vision, colour vision abnormalities, nystagmus and photophobia.
name: Congenital stationary cone dysfunction

desc: An anomaly in the process of visual accommodation, which is the process of adjustment of the eye to enable sharp vision of objects at different distances. Accommodation is mediated by contraction of the ciliary muscles, which alter the convexity of the lens and, consequently, its refractive power.
name: Abnormal visual accommodation

desc: A decreased ability of the eye to adjust and thereby enable sharp vision of objects at different distances.
name: Reduced visual accommodation

desc: Eye strain, i.e., a feeling of fatigue or discomfort of the eyes related to 'overuse' of the eyes in activities such as reading or working at the computer and often accompanied by lacrimation or headache.
name: Asthenopia

desc: Inflammation of the eye, parts of the eye or the periorbital region.
name: Inflammatory abnormality of the eye

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye.
name: Ocular pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye that is worse in certain directions of gaze and during prolonged gaze holding.
name: Eye movement-induced pain

desc: An abnormality of the ear.
name: Abnormality of the ear

desc: Any structural anomaly of the ear.
name: Abnormal ear morphology

desc: An abnormality of the external ear.
name: Abnormality of the outer ear

desc: Abnormal location of the ear.
name: Abnormal location of ears

desc: A type of abnormal location of the ears in which the position of the ears is characterized by posterior rotation (the superior part of the ears is rotated towards the back of the head, and the inferior part of the ears towards the front).
layperson: Ears rotated toward back of head
name: Posteriorly rotated ears
synonyms: Ears rotated toward back of head

desc: Ears that are low-set (HP:0000369) and posteriorly rotated (HP:0000358).
name: Low-set, posteriorly rotated ears

desc: Upper insertion of the ear to the scalp below an imaginary horizontal line drawn between the inner canthi of the eye and extending posteriorly to the ear.
name: Low-set ears

desc: An asymmetriy, i.e., difference in size, shape or position between the left and right ear.
name: Asymmetry of the ears

layperson: Asymmetry of the size of ears
name: Asymmetry of the size of ears
synonyms: Asymmetry of the size of ears

layperson: Asymmetry of the shape of the ears
name: Asymmetry of the shape of the ears
synonyms: Asymmetry of the shape of the ears

layperson: Asymmetry of the position of the ears
name: Asymmetry of the position of the ears

desc: A congenital malformation characterized by the union or approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw.
name: Synotia

desc: An abnormality of the External acoustic tube (also known as the auditory canal).
name: Abnormality of the auditory canal

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the external auditory canal.
layperson: Narrowing of passageway from outer ear to middle ear
name: Stenosis of the external auditory canal
synonyms: Narrowing of passageway from outer ear to middle ear

desc: A type of stenosis of the external auditory meatus in which the opening of the external auditory meatus appears as a vertical slit.
layperson: Slit-like opening of the exterior auditory meatus
name: Slit-like opening of the exterior auditory meatus

layperson: Cutaneous stenosis of the external auditory canal
name: Cutaneous stenosis of the external auditory canal

layperson: Osseous stenosis of the external auditory canal
name: Osseous stenosis of the external auditory canal

desc: Absence or failure to form of the external auditory canal.
name: Atresia of the external auditory canal
synonyms: Atresia of the external auditory canals

layperson: Cutaneous atresia of the external auditory canal
name: Cutaneous atresia of the external auditory canal

layperson: Osseous atresia of the external auditory canal
name: Osseous atresia of the external auditory canal

desc: A benign bony growth projecting outward from a bone surface within the external auditory canal.
layperson: Exostosis of the external auditory canal
name: Exostosis of the external auditory canal

desc: Any anomaly of the cerumen (ear wax), the yellowish waxy substance secreted in the ear canal.
name: Cerumen abnormality

desc: Blockage of the external auditory canal by a buildup of earwax.
name: Impacted cerumen

desc: An increased quantity of earwax.
name: Excessive cerumen

desc: An anomolous earwax color. Earwax (cerumen) is usually light to dark brown or orange in color.
name: Abnormal cerumen color

desc: Inflammation or infection of the external auditory canal (EAC), the auricle, or both.
name: Otitis externa

desc: An abnormality of the pinna, which is also referred to as the auricle or external ear.
name: Abnormality of the pinna

desc: An abnormality of the lobule of pinna.
name: Abnormality of earlobe

desc: Pits in the earlobes at the location where ears are typically pierced for earrings.
name: Congenital earlobe sinuses

desc: Increased volume of the earlobe, that is, abnormally prominent ear lobules.
name: Large earlobe

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the ear lobes.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the earlobes

desc: Reduced volume of the earlobe.
name: Small earlobe

desc: Absence of fleshy non-cartilaginous tissue inferior to the tragus and incisura.
name: Absent earlobe

desc: Attachment of the lobe to the side of the face at the lowest point of the lobe without curving upward.
name: Attached earlobe

desc: Sharply demarcated, typically linear and approximately horizontal, indentations in the outer surface of the ear lobe.
name: Anterior creases of earlobe

desc: An abnormal orientation of the earlobes such that they point out- and upward. That is, the lateral surface of ear lobe faces superiorly.
name: Uplifted earlobe

desc: Positioning of the anterior surface of the ear lobe in a more coronal plane than the remainder of the ear.
name: Forward facing earlobe

desc: Discontinuity in the convexity of the inferior margin of the lobe.
name: Cleft earlobe

desc: A transverse linear fissure (crease) in the lobule of the ear.
name: Linear earlobe crease

desc: Diagonal earlobe creases run from the lower pole of the external meatus, diagonally backwards to the edge of the lobe at approximately 45 degrees.
name: Diagonal earlobe crease

desc: Laterally protruding ear that lacks antihelical folding (including absence of inferior and superior crura).
name: Cupped ear

desc: Anterior and inferior folding of the upper portion of the ear that obliterates triangular fossa and scapha.
name: Lop ear

desc: Median longitudinal ear length greater than two standard deviations above the mean and median ear width greater than two standard deviations above the mean (objective); or, apparent increase in length and width of the pinna (subjective).
name: Macrotia

desc: Angle formed by the plane of the ear and the mastoid bone greater than the 97th centile for age (objective); or, outer edge of the helix more than 2 cm from the mastoid at the point of maximum distance (objective).
name: Protruding ear

desc: Ossification affecting the external ear cartilage.
name: Calcification of the auricular cartilage

desc: Underdevelopment of the external ear.
name: Microtia

desc: Median longitudinal length of the ear more than two standard deviations below the mean in the presence of some, but not all, parts of the normal ear.
name: Microtia, second degree

desc: Presence of all the normal ear components and the median longitudinal length more than two standard deviations below the mean.
name: Microtia, first degree

desc: Presence of some auricular structures, but none of these structures conform to recognized ear components.
name: Microtia, third degree

desc: An abnormality of the antihelix.
name: Abnormality of the antihelix

desc: The presence of an abnormally prominent antihelix.
name: Prominent antihelix

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the antihelix.
name: Hypoplasia of the antihelix

desc: Antihelix protrusion directed more anteriorly than laterally, forming a shelf overlying the posterior concha.
name: Antihelical shelf

desc: No discernible ridge between concha and triangular fossa and helix.
name: Absent antihelix

desc: Supernumerary ridge or crus of the ear arising from the antihelix.
name: Additional crus of antihelix

desc: The presence of a supernumerary, i.e. third, crus of the helix in the helix, arising at or above the normal bifurcation of the antihelix.
name: Stahl ear

desc: Antihelical ridge that forms an acute angle between the antitragus and its bifurcation (stem) instead of a gently curving arc.
name: Angulated antihelix

desc: An abnormality of the inferior crus of the antihelix is the lower cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa.
layperson: Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix
name: Abnormality of inferior crus of antihelix
synonyms: Abnormality of anterior crus of antihelix

desc: Increased width of the inferred cross-section of the inferior crus.
name: Broad inferior crus of antihelix

desc: Increased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem.
name: Prominent inferior crus of antihelix

desc: Decreased protrusion of the inferior crus relative to the prominence of the antihelix stem.
name: Underdeveloped inferior crus of antihelix

desc: An abnormality of the stem of the antihelix, which is the part below the bifurcation of the antihelix into the inferior and superior crura.
name: Abnormality of stem of antihelix

desc: Increased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of the helix.
name: Prominent stem of antihelix

desc: Posterior curving of the antihelix from its origin at the antitragus, traveling initially almost perpendicular to the descending helix and obscuring some of the concha.
name: Serpiginous stem of antihelix

desc: Decreased protrusion of the antihelical ridge, proximal to its bifurcation, relative to the prominence of a normal helix.
name: Underdeveloped stem of antihelix

desc: An abnormality of the superior crus of the antihelix is the upper cartilaginous ridge arising at the bifurcation of the antihelix that ends beneath the fold of the ascending helix, and separates the concha from the triangular fossa.
layperson: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
name: Abnormality of superior crus of antihelix
synonyms: Abnormality of posterior crus of antihelix

desc: Decreased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.
name: Underdeveloped superior crus of antihelix

desc: Increased protrusion of the superior crus relative to the prominence of a normal antihelix stem.
name: Prominent superior crus of antihelix

desc: Increased thickness of the external ear.
name: Thickened ears

desc: An abnormality of the antitragus, which is a small tubercle opposite to the tragus of the ear. The antitragus and the tragus are separated by the intertragic notch.
name: Abnormality of the antitragus

desc: Increased anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
name: Prominent antitragus

desc: Positioning of the antitragus at an angle perpendicular to the plane of the ear (oriented away from the plane of the ear).
name: Everted antitragus

desc: Absence of the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
name: Absent antitragus

desc: Double rather than single peak of the antitragus.
name: Bifid antitragus

desc: Reduction in the anterosuperior prominence of the area between the bottom of the incisura and the inner margin of the antihelix.
name: Underdeveloped antitragus

desc: Distortion of the course of the normal folds of the ear and the appearance of supernumerary crura and folds.
name: Crumpled ear

desc: An abnormality of the tragus.
name: Abnormality of the tragus

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the tragus.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the tragus

desc: Lack of convexity or prominence of the contour of the ridge between the bottom of the incisura and the confluence of the ascending helix and crus helix.
name: Absent tragus

desc: Decreased posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
name: Underdeveloped tragus

desc: Increased height of the tragal ridge with a shallow indentation at the apex, giving the appearance of a double peak.
name: Bifid tragus

desc: A complete or partial duplication of the tragus; expected to lie anterior to the normal tragus.
name: Duplicated tragus

desc: Increase posterolateral protrusion of the tragus.
name: Prominent tragus

desc: An abnormality of the helix. The helix is the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe.
name: Abnormality of the helix

desc: Increased thickness of the helix of the ear.
name: Thickened helices

desc: Permanent indentation on the posteromedial aspect of the helix that may be sharply or indistinctly delineated.
layperson: Indentation in back of outer ear
name: Posterior helix pit
synonyms: Indentation in back of outer ear
Pits in posterior aspect of ear helices

layperson: Long hairs growing from helix of ear
name: Long hairs growing from helix of pinna
synonyms: Long hairs growing from helix of ear

desc: A condition in which the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal. That is, excessive curling of the helix edge, whereby the free edge is parallel to the plane of the ear.
name: Overfolded helix

desc: A condition in which the superior portion of the helix is folded over to a greater degree than normal.
name: Overfolding of the superior helices

desc: Underdevelopment of the helix that either affects the entire helix, or is localized.
name: Underfolded helix

desc: A condition in which the superior portion of the helix is folded over to a lesser degree than normal.
name: Underfolded superior helices

desc: Underdevelopment of the helix, i.e., of the outer rim of the pinna.
name: Hypoplastic helices

desc: An abnormality of the crus of the helix, which is the horizontal piece of cartilage located outside the ear canal that divides the upper and lower parts of the ear.
layperson: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
name: Abnormality of the crus of the helix
synonyms: Abnormality of the crus of the ear

desc: An abnormal horizontal axis orientation of the crus of the helix. That is, the main axis of the crus of the helix is perpendicular to the medial longitudinal axis of the ear, instead of sloping inferoposteriorly.
name: Horizontal crus of helix
synonyms: Horizontal orientation of the ear crus
Horizontal orientation of the crus of helix

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the crus of the helix. That is, flatter and/or shorter crus helix than average.
name: Underdeveloped crus of the helix
synonyms: Hypoplasia of the crus of the ear

desc: The presence of an abnormally prominent of the crus of the helix. That is, development of the crus helix to the same degree as an average antihelix stem or helix.
name: Prominent crus of helix
synonyms: Abnormal prominence of the crus of the ear

desc: Continuum between the tragus and ascending helix, without any evidence of a posterior extension (crus) towards the concha.
name: Absent crus of helix

desc: Extension of the ridge of the crus helix across the ear and connection of the crus to the antihelix.
layperson: Crus of helix connected to antihelix
name: Crus of helix connected to antihelix

desc: Curving course of the crus of the helix, approaching or joining the antitragus.
name: Serpiginous crus of helix

desc: The anterior origin of the crus encompasses the superior margin of the tragus, the crus overrides the upper portion of the conchal cavum and ends at the antihelix.
layperson: Tragal bridge of crus of helix
name: Tragal bridge of crus of helix

desc: Widening, rather than tapering, of the crus at its posterior border near the antihelix.
layperson: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix
name: Expanded terminal portion of crus of helix

desc: A notched form of the helix of the ear. That is, a defect in the continuity of the helix, which may occur at any point along its length.
name: Cleft helix

layperson: Cleft at the superior portion of the pinna
name: Cleft at the superior portion of the pinna
synonyms: Cleft at the superior portion of the ear

desc: Small defect of the helical fold that lies at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
name: Darwin notch of helix

desc: Abnormally prominent ear helix.
name: Prominent ear helix

desc: Decreased thickness of the helix of the ear.
name: Thin ear helix

desc: Small expansion of the helical fold at the junction of the superior and descending portions of the helix.
name: Darwin tubercle of helix

desc: Linear, circumferential indentation in the convexity of the outer surface of the helix.
name: Crimped helix

desc: Interruption between the ascending helix and the crus helix, allowing the ascending helix to be attached directly to the mastoid.
name: Discontinuous ascending root of helix

desc: Flattening instead of curving or rounded superior helix, allowing the superior helix to run more horizontally than usual.
name: Squared superior portion of helix

desc: An abnormal shape of the incisura, defined as the narrowed downward continuation of the conchal space bounded anteriorly by the borders of the tragus, posteriorly by the antitragus, and along its lower lateral margins and inferior boundary by the connection between the first two. The upper boundary is a somewhat arbitrary line crossing from the apices of the antitragus and the tragus.
name: Abnormal incisura morphology

desc: The length of the incisura from the upper to lower border is greater than that observed in the average population.
name: Increased incisura length

desc: The length of the incisura from the upper to lower border is less than that observed in the average population.
name: Decreased incisura length

desc: Width of the incisura from the anterior to posterior border less than that observed in the average population.
name: Narrow incisura width

desc: Breadth of the incisura from the anterior to posterior border greater than that observed in the average population.
name: Increased incisura width

desc: Invagination of the superior part of the auricle under a fold of temporal skin.
name: Cryptotia

desc: A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and superior crus.
name: Type I cryptotia

desc: A type of cryptotia associated with reduction in size of the antihelix and inferior crus that are affected.
name: Type II cryptotia

desc: The pinna has fewer folds and grooves than usual.
name: Simple ear

desc: Small protrusion within the pinna.
name: Auricular tag

desc: Cleft between the helix and the lobe.
name: Question mark ear

desc: Small cartilaginous prominence on the posterior concha.
name: Quelprud nodule

desc: Small indentation in the lower part of the ascending helix, concha, or in the crus helix.
name: Auricular pit

desc: Sharp pointed superior portion of the ear, with variable overfolding of the helix.
name: Satyr ear

desc: A congenital auricular deformity, which is mainly characterized by a bulging appearance of the anterosuperior portion of the auricle, a convexly protruded cavum conchae, and a slit-like narrowing of the orifice of the external auditory meatus.
name: Mozart ear

desc: Inflammation of the cartilage of the external ear.
name: Chondritis of pinna

desc: Median longitudinal ear length greater than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
name: Long ear

desc: Median longitudinal ear length less than two SD above the mean determined by the maximal distance from the superior aspect to the inferior aspect of the external ear.
name: Short ear

desc: A malformation of the auricle of the ear.
name: External ear malformation

layperson: Deformed external ear on one side
name: Unilateral external ear deformity
synonyms: Deformed external ear on one side

desc: The presence of aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of all or part of the external ear.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the external ear

desc: Complete absence of any auricular structures.
name: Anotia

desc: Absence of a localized portion of the ear that cannot be described by a more precise term (e.g., absent ear lobe).
layperson: Focal absence of the external ear
name: Focal absence of the external ear

desc: The presence of telangiectasia of the ear.
name: Telangiectasia of the ear

desc: An abnormality of the tympanic membrane
name: Abnormality of the tympanic membrane

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the outer ear.
name: Neoplasm of the outer ear

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ceruminal gland.
name: Neoplasm of the ceruminal gland

desc: The presence of an extra auricle on one or both sides of the head.
name: Polyotia

desc: Folds or ridges within the concha that are distinct from the crus helix.
name: Extra concha fold

desc: An abnormality of a cartilage of external ear.
layperson: Abnormality of cartilage of external ear
name: Abnormality of cartilage of external ear

desc: An abnormality of the inner ear.
name: Abnormality of the inner ear
