desc: An abnormality of the function of the inner ear.
layperson: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
name: Functional abnormality of the inner ear
synonyms: Functional abnormality of the inner ear

desc: A type of hearing impairment in one or both ears related to an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve.
name: Sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A progressive form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Progressive sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A type of hearing loss resulting from a combination of conductive hearing impairment and sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Mixed hearing impairment

desc: A form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the higher frequencies.
name: High-frequency sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: The presence of a moderate form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Moderate sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A type of hearing impairment caused by an abnormal functionality of the cochlear nerve with congenital onset.
name: Congenital sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A form of sensorineural hearing impairment that affects primarily the lower frequencies.
name: Low-frequency sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: The presence of a mild form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Mild neurosensory hearing impairment

desc: The presence of sensorineural deafness with late onset.
name: Adult onset sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A bilateral form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Bilateral sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A severe form of sensorineural hearing impairment.
name: Severe sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: Sensorineural hearing impairment with childhood onset.
name: Childhood onset sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A form of sensorineural deafness with either congenital onset or infantile onset, i.e., before the acquisition of speech.
name: Prelingual sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with onset after the acquisition of speech.
name: Postlingual sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: A form of sensorineural hearing impairment with infantile onset.
name: Infantile sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: Complete loss of hearing related to a sensorineural defect.
name: Profound sensorineural hearing impairment

desc: An abnormality of the functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
name: Vestibular dysfunction

desc: Reduced functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
name: Vestibular hypofunction

desc: Complete lack of functioning of the vestibular apparatus.
name: Absent vestibular function

desc: An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary.
name: Vertigo

desc: Paroxysmal episodes of vertigo.
name: Paroxysmal vertigo

desc: An abnormality of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR). The VOR attempts to keep the image stable on the retina. Ideally passive or active head movements in one direction are compensated for by eye movements of equal magnitude.
name: Abnormal vestibulo-ocular reflex

desc: Vestibular areflexia can be measured as the absence of the caloric nystagmus response in electronystagmography.
name: Vestibular areflexia

desc: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is responsible for the stabilization of the retinal image during movement. The visual vestibular ocular reflex (VVOR) or visual enhanced VOR, maintains ocular stability during head motion by generating compensatory eye movement opposite to head movement, and is a major component of visual vestibular interaction. This feature is an impairment of this reflex, manifested as the combined impairment of the three compensatory eye movement reflexes, namely the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), smooth pursuit (SP) and optokinetic reflex (OKR).
name: Impaired visually enhanced vestibulo-ocular reflex

desc: The doll's eye reflex (also known as oculocephalic reflex) is a test of brain function that is performed in comatose patients by elevating the head roughly 30 degrees and rapidly rotating the head from side to side with the eyes kept open. A normal response is for the eyes to move in the opposite direction. If the eyes do not move in the opposite direction this may indicate severe brain damage.
name: Abnormal doll's eye reflex

desc: A structural anomaly of the internal part of the ear.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear
name: Morphological abnormality of the inner ear

desc: An abnormality of the cochlea.
name: Abnormal cochlea morphology

desc: Deterioration or loss of the tissues of the cochlea.
name: Cochlear degeneration

desc: The presence of a malformed cochlea.
name: Cochlear malformation

desc: Incomplete formation of the cochlear partition. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani separated by the cochlear partition, except in the apical turn where the two scalae are in continuity via the helicotrema.
name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea

desc: IWith incomplete partition II, the cochlea consists of 1.5 turns; the apical and middle cochlea turns are undifferentiated and form a cystic apex. The vestibule is normal while the vestibular aqueduct is always enlarged. Developmental arrest occurs at the seventh week of gestation.
layperson: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type II
name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type II

desc: Incomplete partition I is also known as cystic cochleovestibular malformation, where the cochlea has no bony modiolus, resulting in an empty cystic cochlea. This is accompanied by a dilated cystic vestibule with developmental arrest at the fifth week of gestation.
layperson: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I
name: Incomplete partition of the cochlea type I

desc: Increased size of the cochlear duct, i.e., of a duct that communicates between the perilymphatic space and the subarachnoid space, and transmits a vein from the cochlea to join the internal jugular.
name: Enlarged cochlear aqueduct

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cochlea

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the cochlea.
name: Hypoplasia of the cochlea

desc: Absence of the cochlea, a spiral shaped cavity in the inner ear, owing to a developmental defect.
name: Cochlear aplasia

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the inner ear.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the inner ear

desc: Absence of the inner ear due to a developmental defect.
name: Aplasia of the inner ear

desc: A morphological abnormality of the vestibule, the central part of the osseous labyrinth that is situated medial to the tympanic cavity, behind the cochlea, and in front of the semicircular canals.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear
name: Morphological abnormality of the vestibule of the inner ear

desc: Complete absence of the vestibule of the inner ear.
name: Aplasia of the vestibule

desc: Underdevelopment of the vestibule of the inner ear.
layperson: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear
name: Hypoplasia of the vestibule of the inner ear

desc: Dilatation of the vestibule of the inner ear.
layperson: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear
name: Dilated vestibule of the inner ear

desc: An abnormality of the morphology of the semicircular canal.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal
name: Morphological abnormality of the semicircular canal

desc: Absence of the semicircular canal.
name: Aplasia of the semicircular canal

desc: Underdevelopment of the semicircular canal.
name: Hypoplasia of the semicircular canal

desc: Increased size of the semicircular canal.
name: Enlarged semicircular canal

layperson: Morphological abnormality of the lateral semicircular canal
name: Morphological abnormality of the lateral semicircular canal
synonyms: Morphological abnormality of the horizontal semicircular canal

layperson: Morphological abnormality of the posterior semicircular canal
name: Morphological abnormality of the posterior semicircular canal

layperson: Morphological abnormality of the anterior semicircular canal
name: Morphological abnormality of the anterior semicircular canal

desc: Increased size of the vestibular aqueduct.
name: Enlarged vestibular aqueduct

desc: Any structural anomaly of the saccule of the vestibule. The saccule is the otolith organ that senses motions in the sagittal plane (i.e., up-down movement).
name: Abnormal vestibular saccule morphology

desc: Deterioration or loss of the tissues of the saccule of the vestibule.
name: Vestibular saccular degeneration

desc: An abnormality of the Internal acoustic meatus, i.e., of the canal in the petrous part of the temporal bone through which the cranial nerve VII and cranial nerve VIII traverse.
layperson: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
name: Abnormality of the internal auditory canal
synonyms: Abnormality of the internal acoustic meatus

desc: The presence of a dilated inner part of external acoustic meatus.
name: Dilatated internal auditory canal

desc: Aplasia of the internal auditory canal.
name: Absent internal auditory canal

desc: Reduction in diameter of the internal auditory canal.
name: Narrow internal auditory canal

layperson: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear
name: Morphological abnormality of the nerves of the inner ear

desc: Absence of the vestibular nerve
name: Aplasia of the vestibular nerve.
synonyms: Aplasia of the eighth cranial nerve

desc: Underdevelopment of the vestibular nerve.
name: Hypoplasia of the vestibular nerve
synonyms: Hypoplasia of the eighth cranial nerve

desc: Any structural anomaly of an inner ear epithelium.
name: Abnormal inner ear epithelium morphology

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the inner ear.
name: Neoplasm of the inner ear

desc: A vestibular Schwannoma (also known as acoustic neuroma, acoustic neurinoma, or acoustic neurilemoma) is a benign, usually slow-growing tumor that develops from the VIIIth cranial nerve supplying the inner ear.
name: Vestibular Schwannoma

desc: A bilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
name: Bilateral vestibular Schwannoma

desc: A unilateral vestibular Schwannoma (acoustic neurinoma).
name: Unilateral vestibular Schwannoma

desc: A low-grade papillary epithelial neoplasm (adenocarcinoma) with a slow growth pattern. The endolymphatic duct emerges from the posterior wall of the saccule (of the inner ear) and ends in a blind pouch, the endolymphatic sac. Endolymphatic sac tumors (ELSTs) are known under different names in the literature (Heffner tumor, aggressive papillary middle ear tumor, and low-grade adenocarcinoma of endolymphatic sac origin).
name: Endolymphatic sac tumor
synonyms: Low-grade adenocarcinoma of endolymphatic sac origin

desc: An abnormality of the middle ear.
name: Abnormality of the middle ear

desc: Inflammation or infection of the middle ear.
name: Otitis media

desc: Acute otitis media is a short and generally painful infection of the middle ear.
name: Acute otitis media

desc: Chronic otitis media refers to fluid, swelling, or infection of the middle ear that does not heal and may cause permanent damage to the ear.
layperson: Chronic infections of the middle ear
name: Chronic otitis media
synonyms: Chronic infections of the middle ear

desc: Increased susceptibility to otitis media, as manifested by recurrent episodes of otitis media.
name: Recurrent otitis media

desc: Otitis media characterized by thick or sticky fluid behind the tympanic membrane.
name: Otitis media with effusion

desc: An abnormality of the morphology or structure of the middle ear.
name: Morphological abnormality of the middle ear
synonyms: Morphological abnormality of the middle ear

desc: An abnormality of the middle-ear ossicles (three small bones called malleus, incus, and stapes) that are contained within the middle ear and serve to transmit sounds from the air to the fluid-filled labyrinth (cochlea).
layperson: Abnormality of the middle ear ossicles
name: Abnormality of the middle ear ossicles

desc: Bony fusion of malleus, incus, and stapes.
name: Fusion of middle ear ossicles

desc: An abnormality of the stapes, a stirrup-shaped ossicle in the middle ear.
name: Abnormality of the stapes

desc: In otosclerosis, a callus of bone accumulates on the stapes creating a partial fixation. This limits the movement of the stapes bone, which results in hearing loss.
name: Otosclerosis

desc: Stapes ankylosis refers to congenital or acquired fixation of the stapes (the stirrup-shaped small bone or ossicle in the middle ear), which is associated with conductive hearing resulting from impairment of the sound-conduction mechanism (the external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and/or middle-ear ossicles).
name: Stapes ankylosis

desc: A form of stapes ankylosis with congenital onset.
name: Congenital stapes ankylosis

desc: Aplasia of the stapes.
name: Absent stapes

desc: Absence of the middle ear ossicles, malleus, incus, and stapes.
name: Aplasia of the middle ear ossicles

desc: An abnormality of the incus, an ossicle in the middle ear.
name: Abnormality of the incus

desc: An abnormality of the malleus, an ossicle in the middle ear.
name: Abnormality of the malleus

desc: Aplasia of the malleus.
name: Absent malleus

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of all or part of the middle ear.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the middle ear

desc: Cholesteatoma is a benign but potentially destructive growth consisting of keratinizing epithelium located in the middle ear and/or mastoid process. In cholesteatoma, a skin cyst grows into the middle ear and mastoid. The cyst is not cancerous but can erode tissue and cause destruction of the ear.
name: Cholesteatoma

desc: Persistence of the stapedial artery, which normally regresses during embryonic life.
name: Persistent stapedial artery

desc: A stiffening of the tympanic membrane due to calcification, typically presents as white plaque-like lesions, involving discrete regions of the tympanic membrane and/or middle ear.
name: Tympanosclerosis

desc: An abnormality of the function of the middle ear.
layperson: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
name: Functional abnormality of the middle ear
synonyms: Functional abnormality of the middle ear

desc: An abnormality of vibrational conductance of sound to the inner ear leading to impairment of sensory perception of sound.
name: Conductive hearing impairment

desc: A bilateral type of conductive hearing impairment.
name: Bilateral conductive hearing impairment

desc: A type of conductive deafness with congenital onset.
name: Congenital conductive hearing impairment

desc: A mild form of conductive hearing impairment.
name: Mild conductive hearing impairment

desc: A progressive type of conductive deafness.
name: Progressive conductive hearing impairment

desc: The presence of a moderate form of conductive hearing impairment.
name: Moderate conductive hearing impairment

desc: A severe form of conductive hearing impairment.
name: Severe conductive hearing impairment

layperson: Abnormality of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle
name: Abnormality of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle

layperson: Absence of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle
name: Absence of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle

layperson: Impairment of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle
name: Impairment of the reflex of the tensor tympani muscle

desc: An abnormality in the reflexive contraction of the middle-ear muscles in response to sound stimulation.
name: Abnormality of the acoustic reflex

desc: Absence of the acoustic reflex, an involuntary contraction of the stapedius muscle that occurs in response to high-intensity sound stimuli.
name: Absence of acoustic reflex
synonyms: Absence of acoustic middle ear muscle reflexes

layperson: Impairment of the the acoustic reflex
name: Impairment of the the acoustic reflex

desc: Middle ear is filled with glue-like fluid instead of air.
name: Glue ear

desc: Increased susceptibility to middle ear infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of middle ear infections
layperson: Recurrent infections of the middle ear
name: Recurrent infections of the middle ear

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the middle ear.
name: Neoplasm of the middle ear

desc: The presence of aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the ear.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the ear

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the ear.
name: Neoplasm of the ear

desc: Any functional anomaly of the ear.
name: Abnormal ear physiology

desc: An abnormality of the sensory perception of sound.
name: Hearing abnormality

desc: Tinnitus is an auditory perception that can be described as the experience of sound, in the ear or in the head, in the absence of external acoustic stimulation.
name: Tinnitus

desc: Pulsatile tinnitus is generally classified a kind of objective tinnitus, meaning that it is not only audible to the patient but also to the examiner on auscultation of the auditory canal and/or of surrounding structures with use of an auscultation tube or stethoscope. Usually, pulsatile tinnitus is heard as a lower pitched thumping or booming, a rougher blowing sound which is coincidental with respiration, or as a clicking, higher pitched rhythmic sensation. Pulsatile tinnitus may be associated with vascular abnormalities such as arterioevenous shunts or glomus tumors or the jugular vein, arterial bruits related to a high-riding carotid artery (close to the auditory areas) or carotid stenosis, or venous abnormalities such as a dehiscent jugular bulb or to hypertension. Finally, in some patients, mechanical abnormalities such a spatulous eustachian tubes, palatomyoclonus (small spasms of muscles in the soft palate area), or idiopathic stapedial muscle spasm may represent the underlying cause of pulsatile tinnitus.
name: Pulsatile tinnitus

desc: A decreased magnitude of the sensory perception of sound.
name: Hearing impairment

desc: A progressive form of hearing impairment.
name: Progressive hearing impairment

desc: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the higher frequencies of sound (3,000 to 6,000 Hz).
name: High-frequency hearing impairment

desc: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the low frequencies of sound (125 Hz to 1000 Hz).
name: Low-frequency hearing loss

desc: A unilateral absence of sensory perception of sound.
name: Unilateral deafness

desc: Partial or complete loss of hearing following ingestion of aminoglycoside antibiotics.
name: Aminoglycoside-induced hearing loss

desc: The presence of a mild form of hearing impairment.
name: Mild hearing impairment

desc: The presence of a moderate form of hearing impairment.
name: Moderate hearing impairment

desc: A severe form of hearing impairment.
name: Severe hearing impairment

desc: A profound (essentially complete) form of hearing impairment.
name: Profound hearing impairment

desc: Hearing loss that occurs acutely and resolves completely.
name: Transient hearing impairment

desc: A type of hearing impairment affecting primarily the middle frequencies of sound (1000 Hz to 3000 Hz).
name: Mid-frequency hearing loss

desc: A type of hearing impairment prominently characterized by a difficulty in understanding speech, rather than an inability to hear speech. Poor speech discrimination is a very common symptom of high frequency hearing loss.
name: Abnormal speech discrimination

desc: Pain in the ear can be a consequence of otologic disease (primary or otogenic otalgia), or can arise from pathologic processes and structures other than the ear (secondary or referred otalgia).
name: Ear pain

desc: An abnormality of the nervous system.
name: Abnormality of the nervous system

desc: A functional anomaly of the nervous system.
name: Abnormal nervous system physiology

desc: An abnormality of mental functioning including various affective, behavioural, cognitive and perceptual abnormalities.
name: Behavioral abnormality

desc: A condition characterized by changes of personality and thought patterns often accompanied by hallucinations and delusional beliefs.
name: Psychosis

desc: A tendency or compulsion to examine objects by mouth.
name: Hyperorality

desc: A state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control, nonproductive or disorganized behavior, and subjective distress.
name: Restlessness

desc: A state of exceeding restlessness and excessive motor activity associated with mental distress or a feeling of inner tension.
name: Agitation

desc: A state of motor restlessness, usually in the lower extremities, that is often but not always accompanied by a subjective sense of inner restlessness, an urge to move, and anxiety or dysphoria.
name: Akathisia

desc: Recurrent obsessions or compulsions that are severe enough to be time consuming (i.e., they take more than 1 hour a day) or cause marked distress or significant impairment (DSM-IV).
name: Obsessive-compulsive behavior

desc: The presence of one or more obsessive-compulsive personality traits. Obsessions refer to persistent intrusive thoughts, and compulsions to intrusive behaviors, which the affected person experiences as involuntary, senseless, or repugnant.
name: Obsessive-compulsive trait

desc: Excessive or pathological tendency to save and collect possessions.
name: Collectionism

desc: Persistent deficits in social interaction and communication and interaction as well as a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest as well as repetitive patterns of behavior.
name: Autistic behavior

desc: Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behavior. Autism begins in childhood. It is marked by the presence of markedly abnormal or impaired development in social interaction and communication and a markedly restricted repertoire of activity and interest. Manifestations of the disorder vary greatly depending on the developmental level and chronological age of the individual (DSM-IV).
name: Autism

desc: Behavior characterized by an abnormal limitation to few interests and activities.
name: Restrictive behavior

desc: Difficulty in social interactions related to an impairment of characteristics such as eye contact, smiling, appropriate facial expressions, and body postures and characterized by difficulty in forming peer relationships and forming friendships.
name: Impaired social interactions

layperson: Impaired ability to form peer relationships
name: Impaired ability to form peer relationships

desc: Reduced ability to use nonverbal behavior for communication, such as eye-to-eye gaze, facial expression, body posture, and gestures.
name: Impaired use of nonverbal behaviors

desc: Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye.
name: Poor eye contact

desc: A deficit in emotional awareness characterized by difficulties in recognizing and expressing feelings and emotions manifested as a limited ability to respond to facial clues or other signs of emotions in others often accompanied by detached connections to others.
name: Alexithymia

layperson: Inflexible adherence to routines or rituals
name: Inflexible adherence to routines or rituals

desc: Reduced attention span characterized by distractibility and impulsivity but not necessarily satisfying the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
name: Short attention span

desc: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) manifests at age 2-3 years or by first grade at the latest. The main symptoms are distractibility, impulsivity, hyperactivity, and often trouble organizing tasks and projects, difficulty going to sleep, and social problems from being aggressive, loud, or impatient.
name: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

desc: Perceptions in a conscious and awake state in the absence of external stimuli which have qualities of real perception, in that they are vivid, substantial, and located in external objective space.
name: Hallucinations

desc: The feeling of frustration can be defined as an emotional reaction that occurs if a desired goal is not achieved. Frustration intolerance is defined as an age-inappropriate response to frustration characterized by crying or temper tantrums (in children) or aggressive or other undesirable behaviors.
name: Low frustration tolerance

desc: A belief that is pathological and is held despite evidence to the contrary.
name: Delusions

desc: A persecutory delusion of supposed hostility of others.
name: Paranoia

desc: An abnormal shift in patterns of thinking, acting, or feeling.
name: Personality changes

desc: Individuals with Pseudobulbar signs often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.
name: Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms

desc: An abnormality of sleep including such phenomena as 1) insomnia/hypersomnia, 2) non-restorative sleep, 3) sleep schedule disorder, 4) excessive daytime somnolence, 5) sleep apnea, and 6) restlessness.
name: Sleep disturbance

desc: A state of abnormally strong desire for sleep during the daytime.
layperson: More than typical sleepiness during day
name: Excessive daytime somnolence
synonyms: More than typical sleepiness during day

desc: Abnormality of REM sleep. Phases of REM sleep are characterized by desynchronized EEG patterns, increases in heart rate and blood pressure, sympathetic activation, and a profound loss of muscle tonus except for the eye and middle-ear muscles. There are then phases of rapid eye movements.
name: Abnormal rapid eye movement sleep

desc: Bruxism is characterized by the grinding of the teeth including the clenching of the jaw and typically occur during sleep.
name: Bruxism

desc: Any abnormal alteration of an individual's circadian rhythm that affects the timing of sleeping and being awake.
name: Sleep-wake cycle disturbance

desc: A reversal of sleeping habits with a tendency to sleep during the day and to be awake at night.
name: Sleep-wake inversion

desc: A tendency towards rising very early in the morning and going to bed early in the evening.
name: Early chronotype

desc: A tendency towards rising very late in the morning and going to bed late at night.
name: Late chronotype

desc: An intermittent cessation of airflow at the mouth and nose during sleep. Apneas of at least 10 seconds are considered important, but persons with sleep apnea may have apneas of 20 seconds to up to 2 or 3 minutes. Patients may have up to 15 events per hour of sleep.
name: Sleep apnea

desc: A condition characterized by obstruction of the airway and by pauses in breathing during sleep occurring many times during the night. Obstructive sleep apnea is related to a relaxation of muscle tone (which normally occurs during sleep) leading to partial collapse of the soft tissues in the airway with resultant obstruction of the air flow.
name: Obstructive sleep apnea

desc: Sleep apnea resulting from a transient abolition of the central drive to the ventilatory muscles.
name: Central sleep apnea

desc: A feeling of uneasiness and restlessness in the legs after going to bed (sometimes causing insomnia).
name: Restless legs

desc: An inability to move the body at sleep onset or upon awakening from sleep lasting seconds to a few minutes.
name: Sleep paralysis

desc: An undesirable physical event or experience that occur during entry into sleep, during sleep, or during arousal from sleep.
name: Parasomnia

desc: A parasomnia that occurs in non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. This refers to a disorder of arousal that occurs during slow-wave sleep (ie, NREM stage 3 sleep).
name: Non-rapid eye movement parasomnia

desc: Ambulation or other complex motor behaviors after getting out of bed in a sleep-like state. During sleepwalking episodes, the sonambulating individual appears confused or dazed, the eyes are usually open, and he or she might mumble or give inappropriate answers to questions, or occasionally appear agitated.
name: Somnambulism

desc: A nocturnal episode characterized by disorientation, grogginess, and, at times, substantial agitation upon awakening from slow-wave sleep or following forced awakenings. These characteristics might present as agitation, crying or moaning, disorientation, and particularly slow mentation on arousal from sleep (i.e., sleep inertia). The duration of episodes is typically 5 to 15 min but they might last up to several hours.
name: Confusional arousal

desc: Episodes of intense fear, screaming and flailing although affected individuals are still asleep.
name: Sleep terror

desc: Deep, noisy breathing during sleep accompanied by hoarse or harsh sounds caused by the vibration of respiratory structures (especially the soft palate) resulting in sound due to obstructed air movement during breathing while sleeping.
name: Snoring

desc: Particularly loud snoring, snoring at high volume.
name: Loud snoring

desc: An abnormal phenomenon characterized by a classic tetrad of excessive daytime sleepiness with irresistible sleep attacks, cataplexy (sudden bilateral loss of muscle tone), hypnagogic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.
name: Narcolepsy

desc: Difficulty initiating sleep, that is, increased sleep onset latency.
name: Sleep onset Insomnia

desc: Abnormal difficulty in staying asleep. Affected individuals tend to wake up at night and have difficulty returning to sleep.
name: Maintenance insomnia

desc: A type of insomnia characterized by waking up (too) early in the morning.
name: Terminal insomnia

desc: The tendency to repeat vocalizations made by another person.
name: Echolalia

desc: An enduring pattern of uncooperative, defiant, and hostile behavior toward authority figures that does not involve major antisocial violations, is not accounted for by the child's developmental stage, and results in significant functional impairment. A certain level of oppositional behavior is common in children and adolescents.
name: Oppositional defiant disorder

desc: An abnormality of actions or reactions of a person taking place during interactions with others.
name: Abnormal social behavior

desc: A failure to meet one or more age-related milestones of social behavior.
name: Delayed social development

desc: A reduced ability to participate in the back and forth flow of social interaction, which is normally characterized by an influence of the behavior of one person on the behavior of another person who is in conversation with the first.
name: Impaired social reciprocity

desc: A form of hypersociability that presents as mostly inappropriate people-orientation and friendliness towards others on an inadequate level which might go as far as being dangerous considering for example young children following strangers without restriction.
name: Overfriendliness

desc: Decreased tolerance to sound.
name: Sound sensitivity

desc: An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds.
name: Phonophobia

desc: Over-sensitivity to certain frequency ranges of sound.
name: Hyperacusis

desc: An adverse response (dislike) to sound no matter what volume the sound is, characterized by a strong negative reaction to soft sounds that can sometimes be further triggered by seeing the source of the offending sound.
name: Misophonia

desc: A temper tantrum is an emotional outburst usually triggered by a sense of frustration and manifested as whining and crying, screaming, kicking, hitting, and breath holding. Temper tantrums are normal in toddlers and young children and usually happen between the ages of one to three years. Temper tantrums may be considered abnormal if they occur at an unusually high frequency, are of unusual severity, or occur at an old age than usual.
name: Abnormal temper tantrums

desc: Temper tantrums that occur more frequently than usual.
name: Frequent temper tantrums

desc: Temper tantrums whose severity is more severe than usual. For instance, a temper tantrum might be considered to be severe if a child loses control so completely that the child cannot control the tantrum on its own, continuing until it becomes exhausted or a parent intervenes.
name: Severe temper tantrums

desc: Neglecting one's own needs and well-being.
name: Self-neglect

desc: Perseveration can be defined as the contextually inappropriate and unintentional repetition of a response or behavioral unit. In other words, the observed repetitiveness does not meet the demands of the situation, is not the product of deliberation, and may even unfold despite counterintention. Perseveration can therefore be differentiated from goal-directed and intentional forms of repetition, such as linguistic redundancies designed to enhance communicative or poetic impact.
name: Perseveration

desc: Repetitive use of words, phrases, intonation, or sounds of speech, often of the speech of others.
name: Persistent repetition of words

desc: Repeated and inappropriate mechanical repetition of actions.
name: Persistent repetition of actions

desc: A recurrent pattern of behavior that is characeterized by the failure to resist an impulse, drive, or temptation to perform an act that is harmful to the person or to others. The repetitive engagement in these behaviors ultimately interferes with functioning in other domains.
name: Addictive behavior

desc: An addictive behavior defined as drinking excessive amounts of alcohol over a long period of time, having difficulty reducing the amount of alcohol consumed, strongly desiring alcohol and experiencing withdrawal symptoms when not drinking alcohol.
name: Alcoholism

desc: A maladaptive personality trait characterized by moderate or greater impairment in personality (self /interpersonal) functioning.
name: Impairment in personality functioning

desc: Unstable emotional experiences and frequent mood changes; emotions that are easily aroused, intense, and/or out of proportion to events and circumstances.
name: Emotional lability

desc: Frequent feelings of being down, miserable, and/or hopeless; difficulty recovering from such moods; pessimism about the future; pervasive shame; feeling of inferior self-worth; thoughts of suicide and suicidal behavior.
name: Depressivity

desc: Pathological persistent sexual disinhibiting behavior, directed at oneself or to others.
name: Hypersexuality

desc: Uncontrolled episodes of crying, without apparent motivating stimuli.
name: Inappropriate crying

desc: Behavior that is not in line with social norms.
name: Socially inappropriate behavior

desc: A lack of restraint manifested in several ways, including disregard for social conventions, impulsivity, and poor risk assessment.
name: Disinhibition

desc: Engagement in dangerous, risky, and potentially self-damaging activities, unnecessarily and without regard to consequences; lack of concern for one's limitations and denial of the reality of personal danger.
name: Risk taking

desc: Acting on the spur of the moment in response to immediate stimuli; acting on a momentary basis without a plan or consideration of outcomes; difficulty establishing or following plans; a sense of urgency and self-harming behavior under emotional distress.
name: Impulsivity

desc: An abnormality of mental functioning affecting the personality and behavioural tendencies of an individual and characterized by a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking and behavior. The definition of a personal disorder implies that the abnormality is not the result of damage or insult to the brain or from another psychiatric disorder.
name: Personality disorder

desc: A personality disorder characterized by impulsive behavior and unpredictable and capricious mood. Affected individuals show a liability to outbursts of emotion and an incapacity to control the behavioural explosions.
name: Borderline personality disorder

desc: A personality disorder characterized by shallow and labile affectivity, self-dramatization, theatricality, exaggerated expression of emotions, suggestibility, egocentricity, self-indulgence, lack of consideration for others, easily hurt feelings, and continuous seeking for appreciation, excitement and attention.
name: Histrionic personality disorder

desc: Inability to experience pleasure activities usually found enjoyable.
name: Anhedonia

desc: A stable tendency to experience negative emotions, i.e., a disposition to experience aversive emotional states.
name: Negative affectivity

desc: Fears of rejection by and/or separation from significant others, associated with fears of excessive dependency and complete loss of autonomy.
name: Separation insecurity

desc: Negative opinion about oneself characterized by low self-confidence and exaggeratedly critical feelings about oneself.
name: Low self esteem

desc: Persistent or frequent angry feelings; anger or irritability in response to minor slights and insults.
name: Hostility

desc: An abnormality of fear/anxiety-related behavior, which may relate to either abnormally reduced fear/anxiety-related response or increased fear/anxiety-related response.
name: Abnormal fear/anxiety-related behavior

desc: Intense feelings of nervousness, tenseness, or panic, often in reaction to interpersonal stresses; worry about the negative effects of past unpleasant experiences and future negative possibilities; feeling fearful, apprehensive, or threatened by uncertainty; fears of falling apart or losing control.
name: Anxiety

desc: Recurrent attacks of severe anxiety, whose occurence is not restricted to any particular situation or set of circumstances and is therefore unpredictable.
name: Episodic paroxysmal anxiety

desc: A type of anxiety disorder characterized by avoidance of public places, especially where crowds gather.
name: Agoraphobia

desc: An abnormal fear of being in a closed or narrow space with no escape.
name: Claustrophobia

desc: A sudden episode of intense fear in a situation in which there is no danger or apparent cause. The panic attack is accompanied by symptoms such as palpitations, sweating and chills or hot flushes. There may be a sensation of dyspnea (being out of breath), chest pain, or abdominal distress. Some individuals with panic attacks may experience depersonalization, a fear of going crazy, or a fear of dying.
name: Panic attack

desc: Being unable to focus one's attention or mental effort on a particular object or activity.
name: Diminished ability to concentrate

desc: Pharyngeal spasms provoked by an attempt to drink.
name: Hydrophobia

desc: Habitual insertion of foreign bodies into bodily orifices.
name: Polyembolokoilamania

desc: Onychotillomania is characterized by the compulsive or irresistible urge in patients to pick at, pull off, or harmfully bite or chew their nails.
name: Onychotillomania

desc: Involuntary, tic-like movements consisted of crossing both arms across the chest and tensing the body or clasping the hands and squeezing the arms to the sides. The movements last a few seconds and may occur in series or flurries, generally accompanied by facial grimacing and occasional grunting.
name: Self hugging

desc: Unintentional reexperiencing a traumatic event comprising symptoms are usually sensory impressions and emotional responses from the trauma that appear to lack a time perspective and a context.
name: Intrusion symptom

desc: After suffering psychological trauma, people can repeatedly experience sensory-perceptual impressions of the event, which intrude involuntarily into consciousness. These intrusive memories typically take the form of visual images (e.g., pictures in the mind's eye), but can also include sounds, smells, tastes and bodily sensations, and come with a range of negative emotions associated with the hotspots in the trauma memory.
layperson: Recurrent, involuntary and intrusive distressing memories
name: Recurrent, involuntary and intrusive distressing memories

desc: Recurrent distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the traumatic event or events.
name: Recurrent trauma-related distressing dreams

desc: Marked physiological reactions to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s).
name: Physiological reactivity to cues

desc: Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event or events.
name: Intense psychological distress to cues

desc: A disruption and/or discontinuity in the normal integration of consciousness, memory, identity, emotion, perception, body representation, motor control, and behavior. Clinical presentations of dissociation may include a wide variety of symptoms, including experiences of depersonalization, derealisation, emotional numbing, flashbacks of traumatic events, absorption, amnesia, voice hearing, interruptions in awareness, and identity alteration.
name: Dissociative reaction

desc: Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s). Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) that arouse distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s).
layperson: Avoidance of stimuli associated with traumatic event
name: Avoidance of stimuli associated with traumatic event

desc: Abnormal consumption of fluids with excessive or insufficient consumption of fluid or any other abnormal pattern of fluid consumption.
name: Abnormal drinking behavior

desc: Excessive thirst manifested by excessive fluid intake.
name: Polydipsia

desc: Reduced fluid intake (drinking) in a clinical situation where the plasma molarity or sodium concentration normally would induce greater fluid intake.
name: Hypodipsia

desc: Abnormal eating habit with excessive or insufficient consumption of food or any other abnormal pattern of food consumption.
name: Abnormal eating behavior

desc: A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat.
name: Polyphagia

desc: An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.
name: Pica

desc: The practice of eating earth or soil-like substrates such as clay or chalk.
name: Geophagia

desc: Reluctance or refusal of a child to be breastfed or eat, manifested as gagging, vomiting, turning head away from food, or avoidance of sensation in or around the mouth (i.e. toothbrushing or face-washing).
name: Oral aversion

desc: An excessive desire to eat salt (sodium chloride) or salty foods.
name: Salt craving

desc: Excessive desire to eat sweet foods.
name: Sweet craving

desc: Incidents in which a piece of food or other objects get stuck in the upper airway and provoke coughing, gagging, inability to talk, and difficulty breathing.
name: Choking episodes

desc: A form of anomalous eating behavior characterized by binge eating is followed by self-induced vomiting or other compensatory behavior intended to prevent weight gain (purging, fasting or exercising or a combination of these).
name: Bulimia

desc: A mental disorder characterized by a disintegration of thought processes and of emotional responsiveness. It most commonly manifests as auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3-0.7%.
name: Schizophrenia

desc: A state of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, arousal, and or energy levels.
name: Mania

desc: An abnormality of emotional behaviour.
name: Abnormal emotion/affect behavior

desc: An exaggeration of emotional affects such as laughing crying, or yawning beyond what the person feels.
name: Mood swings

desc: A reduction in goal-directed behavior, that is, motivation, the determinant of behavior and adaptation that allows individuals to get started, be energized to perform a sustained and directed action.
name: Diminished motivation

desc: Poverty of behavior and speech output, lack of initiative, loss of emotional responses, psychomotor slowing, and prolonged speech latency.
name: Abulia

desc: Akinetic mutism is essentially characterized by a total absence of spontaneous behavior and speech occurring in the presence of preserved visual tracking.
name: Akinetic mutism

desc: Reduction of goal-directed behaviors linked to the impairment in frontal executive functions (planning of an action for example).
name: Inertia

layperson: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
name: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
synonyms: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behaviour

desc: Aggressive behavior can denote verbal aggression, physical aggression against objects, physical aggression against people, and may also include aggression towards oneself.
name: Aggressive behavior

desc: Aggression towards oneself.
name: Self-injurious behavior

layperson: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements
name: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements
synonyms: Self-mutilation of tongue and lips due to involuntary movements

desc: Repetitive and compulsive picking of skin which results in tissue damage.
name: Skin-picking

desc: A phenomenon in which persons repetitively pull out their own hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss.
name: Hair-pulling

desc: Habitual striking of one's own head against a surface such as a mattress or wall of a crib.
name: Head-banging

desc: Habitual biting of one's own body.
name: Self-biting

desc: Habitual biting of one's own fingernails.
name: Nail-biting

desc: Lack of emotional reactivity and empathy for situations or persons, sometime also for family members.
name: Emotional blunting

desc: A conspicuously unhappy disposition characterized by negative assumptions, self-defeating talk, fear of failure, and negative ruminations about past events.
name: Unhappy demeanor

desc: Frequent thinking about or preoccupation with killing onself.
name: Suicidal ideation

desc: A sense of intense joy or happiness that is beyond what would be expected under the given circumstances.
name: Euphoria

desc: A conspicuously happy disposition with frequent smiling and laughing that may be context-inappropriate or unrelated to context.
name: Happy demeanor

desc: An unusually happy aspect over time which can also may be observed during inappropriate situations that should be causing for example distress, fear or anger.
name: Conspicuously happy disposition

desc: Opposing or not responding to instructions or external stimuli.
name: Negativism

desc: A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
name: Seizure

desc: Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.
layperson: Repeated seizures without recovery between them
name: Status epilepticus
synonyms: Repeated seizures without recovery between them

desc: There is inconclusive evidence to precisely define the duration of the seizure; however, based on current evidence an operational threshold of 10 minutes is appropriate as beyond this a seizure is likely to be more prolonged. The individual may or may not be aware or in coma.
layperson: Status epilepticus without prominent motor symptoms
name: Status epilepticus without prominent motor symptoms

desc: A type of status epilepticus without prominent motor symptoms and in the presence of coma.
name: Non-convulsive status epilepticus with coma

desc: A type of status epilepticus without prominent motor symptoms in the absence of coma.
name: Non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma

desc: Autonomic status epilepticus is a type of non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma with prominent autonomic features regardless of whether it is electrographically generalized or focal.
name: Autonomic status epilepticus

desc: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma is a type of status epilepticus without prominent motor signs, which is electrographically focal. It is a prolonged focal non-motor seizure.
layperson: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma
name: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma

desc: Aphasic status epilepticus is a type of focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma characterized by a cognitive (rather than motor) language deficit.
name: Aphasic status epilepticus

desc: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus with impairment of consciousness is a type of focal non-convulsive status epilepticus in which awareness is impaired.
layperson: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus with impairment of consciousness
name: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus with impairment of consciousness
synonyms: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus with impairment of awareness

desc: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without impairment of consciousness is a type of focal non-convulsive status epilepticus in which awareness remains intact.
layperson: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without impairment of consciousness
name: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without impairment of consciousness
synonyms: Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus with retained awareness
Focal non-convulsive status epilepticus without impairment of awareness

desc: Generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma is a type of status epilepticus without prominent motor signs, which is electrographically generalized. It is a prolonged absence seizure.
layperson: Generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma
name: Generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma
synonyms: Generalised non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma

desc: Atypical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged atypical absence seizure.
name: Atypical absence status epilepticus

desc: Typical absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged typical absence seizure.
name: Typical absence status epilepticus

desc: Myoclonic absence status epilepticus is a type of generalized non-convulsive status epilepticus without coma that is semiologically a prolonged myoclonic absence seizure. Myoclonic absence status epilepticus consists of proximal, predominantly upper extremity myoclonic jerks corresponding with 3 Hz spike-wave discharges in the EEG.
name: Myoclonic absence status epilepticus

desc: A seizure lasting 30 minutes without fully regaining consciousness, provoked by fever (temperature greater than 38.0 degrees Celcius) at the time of seizure-onset, without a prior history of afebrile seizure and with no evidence of an acute central nervous system infection or insult.
name: Febrile status epilepticus

desc: Status epilepticus with prominent motor signs during the prolonged seizure.
layperson: Status epilepticus with prominent motor symptoms
name: Status epilepticus with prominent motor symptoms

desc:
A type of status epilepticus characterized by a prolonged bilateral tonic-clonic seizure, or repeated bilateral tonic-clonic seizures without recovery between.
comment: 
source: 
seeAlso: Tonic-clonic status epilepticus
name: Convulsive status epilepticus

desc: A type of bilateral convulsive seizure of generalized onset that is sufficiently prolonged (or repeated without recovery) to reach the threshold for status epilepticus.
name: Generalized convulsive status epilepticus

desc: A type of bilateral convulsive seizure of focal onset (which could be with awareness or impaired awareness, either motor or non- motor) that is sufficiently prolonged (or repeated without recovery) to reach the threshold for status epilepticus.
layperson: Focal-onset seizure evolving into bilateral convulsive status epilepticus
name: Focal-onset seizure evolving into bilateral convulsive status epilepticus
synonyms: Focal-onset seizure evolving into generalized convulsive status epilepticus
Focal onset seizure evolving into bilateral convulsive status epilepticus
Partial onset seizure evolving into convulsive status epilepticus
Partial-onset seizure evolving into convulsive status epilepticus

desc: Status epilepticus with focal motor signs originating within networks limited to one hemisphere. Involves musculature in any form. The motor event could consist of an increase (positive) or decrease (negative) in muscle contraction to produce a movement.
name: Focal motor status epilepticus

desc: Epilepsia partialis continua (also called Kojevnikov's or Kozhevnikov's epilepsia) is a type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by repeated stereotyped simple motor manifestations such as jerks, typically of a limb or the face, recurring every few seconds or minutes for extended periods (days or years).
name: Epilepsia partialis continua

desc: A type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by continuous neck or body rotation and conjugate gaze deviation in a direction contralateral to the responsible epileptic focus. This includes some forms of tonic status epilepticus.
name: Adversive status epilepticus

desc: A type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by repeated motor, typically clonic events repeatedly affecting the same segments of the body with spread of clonic movements through contiguous body parts unilaterally, and repeating over a sufficiently prolonged period to reach a diagnosis of status epilepticus.
name: Repeated focal motor seizures

desc: A type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by prolonged ictal paresis or inhibitory motor seizures.
name: Status epilepticus with ictal paresis

desc: A type of focal motor status epilepticus characterized by repetitive and rapid saccades, in association with epileptic discharges.
name: Oculoclonic status epilepticus

desc: Status epilepticus characterized by continuous hyperkinetic proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements such as pedaling pelvic thrusting, thrashing, or rocking movements.
name: Hyperkinetic status epilepticus

desc: A type of motor status epilepticus with repeating bilateral sudden brief (less than 100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography.
name: Myoclonic status epilepticus

desc: A type of myoclonic status epilepticus in the absence of coma.
name: Myoclonic status epilepticus without coma

desc: A type of myoclonic status epilepticus in the presence of coma.
name: Myoclonic status epilepticus with coma

desc: Tonic status epilepticus is a type of status epilepticus characterized by focal or bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, which may be electrographically generalized or focal.
name: Tonic status epilepticus

desc: Refractory status epilepticus is defined as status epilepticus continuing despite two appropriately selected and dosed antiepileptic drugs, including a benzodiazepine.
name: Refractory status epilepticus

desc: Super-refractory status epilepticus is defined as refractory status epilepticus continuing for 24 h or more following initiation of anesthetic medications, including cases in which seizure control is attained after induction of anesthetic drugs but recurs on weaning the patient off the anesthetic agent.
name: Super-refractory status epilepticus

desc: A generalized-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating at some point within, and rapidly engaging, bilaterally distributed networks. The networks may include cortical and subcortical structures but not necessarily the entire cortex.
name: Generalized-onset seizure

desc: A generalized non-motor (absence) seizure is a type of a type of dialeptic seizure that is of electrographically generalized onset. It is a generalized seizure characterised by an interruption of activities, a blank stare, and usually the person will be unresponsive when spoken to. Any ictal motor phenomena are minor in comparison to these non-motor features.
name: Generalized non-motor (absence) seizure

desc: An atypical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by interruption of ongoing activities and reduced responsiveness. In comparison to a typical absence seizure, changes in tone may be more pronounced, onset and/or cessation may be less abrupt, and the duration of the ictus and post-ictal recovery may be longer. Although not always available, an EEG often demonstrates slow (<3 Hz), irregular, generalized spike-wave activity.
name: Atypical absence seizure

desc: A typical absence seizure is a type of generalised non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by its sudden onset, interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare, possibly a brief upward deviation of the eyes. Usually the patient will be unresponsive when spoken to. Duration is a few seconds to half a minute with very rapid recovery. Although not always available, an EEG would usually show 3 Hz generalized epileptiform discharges during the event.
name: Typical absence seizure

desc: Typical absence seizures starting before the age of 4 years.
name: Early onset absence seizures

desc: An absence with eyelid myoclonia seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by forced upward jerking of the eyelids during an absence seizure.
name: Absence seizure with eyelid myoclonia

desc: Myoclonic absence seizure is a type of generalized non-motor (absence) seizure characterised by an interruption of ongoing activities, a blank stare and rhythmic three-per-second myoclonic movements, causing ratcheting abduction of the upper limbs leading to progressive arm elevation, and associated with 3 Hz generalized spike-wave discharges on the electroencephalogram. Duration is typically 10-60 s. Whilst impairment of consciousness may not be obvious the ILAE classified this seizure as a generalized non-motor seizure in 2017.
name: Myoclonic absence seizure

desc: A generalized motor seizure is a type of generalized-onset seizure with predominantly motor (involving musculature) signs. The motor event could consist of an increase (positive) or decrease (negative) in muscle contraction to produce a movement.
name: Generalized-onset motor seizure

desc: A generalized myoclonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral, sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.
name: Generalized myoclonic seizure

desc: Generalised myoclonic seizure provoked by flashing or flickering light.
name: Photosensitive myoclonic seizure

desc: An eyelid myoclonia seizure is a type of generalized myoclonic seizure which may or may not be associated with loss of awareness.
name: Eyelid myoclonia seizure

desc: A generalized tonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, often with neck stiffening without a subsequent clonic phase. The tonic activity can be a sustained abnormal posture, either in extension or flexion, sometimes accompanied by tremor of the extremities.
name: Generalized tonic seizure

desc: Generalized clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by sustained bilateral jerking, either symmetric or asymmetric, that is regularly repetitive and involves the same muscle groups.
name: Generalized clonic seizure

desc: A generalized myoclonic-atonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterized by a myoclonic jerk followed by an atonic motor component.
name: Generalized myoclonic-atonic seizure

desc: A bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset is a type of bilateral tonic-clonic seizure characterised by generalized onset; these seizures rapidly engage networks in both hemispheres at the start of the seizure.
layperson: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset
name: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalized onset
synonyms: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure without partial onset
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures without focal onset
Generalised tonic-clonic seizures without focal onset
Generalized tonic-clonic seizure without focal onset
Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with generalised onset
Generalized tonic-clonic seizure without partial onset
Generalised tonic-clonic seizure without focal onset

desc: Generalized-onset tonic-clonic seizures that are provoked by flashing or flickering light.
name: Photosensitive tonic-clonic seizure

desc: A generalized myoclonic-tonic-clonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by a single or multiple jerks of limbs bilaterally, followed by tonic and clonic phases. The initial jerks can be considered to be either a brief period of clonus or myoclonus.
name: Generalized myoclonic-tonic-clonic seizure

desc: Generalised myoclonic-tonic-clonic seizure provoked by flashing or flickering light.
name: Photosensitive myoclonic-tonic-clonic seizure

desc: A type of epileptic spasm of generalized onset.
name: Generalized-onset epileptic spasm

desc: Generalized atonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1-2 s, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.
name: Generalized atonic seizure

desc: A focal-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating within networks limited to one hemisphere. They may be discretely localized or more widely distributed, and may originate in subcortical structures.
layperson: Seizure affecting one half of brain
name: Focal-onset seizure
synonyms: Seizure affecting one half of brain

desc: A type of focal-onset seizure in which awareness is preserved. Awareness during a seizure is defined as the patient being fully aware of themself and their environment throughout the seizure, even if immobile.
name: Focal aware seizure
synonyms: Focal seizures without impairment of consciousness or awareness
Focal seizure without impairment of consciousness or awareness
Partial seizure without impairment of awareness
Focal seizure without impairment of awareness

desc: A type of focal motor seizure in which awareness is retained throughout the seizure.
name: Focal motor aware seizure

desc: A type of focal atonic seizure during which awareness is fully retained throughout.
name: Focal aware atonic seizure

desc: A type of focal clonic seizure during which awareness is fully retained throughout.
name: Focal aware clonic seizure

desc: A focal hemiclonic seizure in which awareness is retained throughout.

layperson: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with crying
name: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with crying

desc: Focal emotional seizure with anxiety, fear or panic as an expressed or observed emotion at the outset of the seizure, in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with fear/anxiety/panic
name: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with fear/anxiety/panic

desc: A focal emotional seizure with agitation in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with agitation
name: Focal impaired awareness emotional seizure with agitation

desc: A focal autonomic seizure characterised by impaired awareness at some point within the seizure.
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure
synonyms: Partial autonomic seizure with altered responsiveness
Localized autonomic seizure with altered responsiveness
Focal autonomic seizure with altered responsiveness

desc: A Focal autonomic seizure with piloerection (bristling of hairs due to the involuntary contraction of small muscles at the base of hair follicles) characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with piloerection
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with piloerection

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with urge to urinate / defecate characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with urge to urinate/defecate
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with urge to urinate/defecate

desc: An autonomic seizure with hypoventilation / hyperventilation / altered respiration characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with hypoventilation/hyperventilation/altered respiration
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with hypoventilation/hyperventilation/altered respiration

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with pallor / flushing characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with pallor/flushing
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with pallor/flushing

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation / nausea / vomiting / other gastrointestinal phenomena characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with pupillary dilation / constriction characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with pupillary dilation/constriction
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with pupillary dilation/constriction

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with erection characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with erection
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with erection

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with lacrimation characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with lacrimation
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with lacrimation

desc: A focal autonomic seizure with palpitations / tachycardia / bradycardia / asystole characterized by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with palpitations/tachycardia/bradycardia/asystole
name: Focal impaired awareness autonomic seizure with palpitations/tachycardia/bradycardia/asystole

desc: A focal cognitive seizure in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with anomia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with anomia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with anomia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with receptive dysphasia / aphasia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with receptive dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with receptive dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with left-right confusion characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with left-right confusion
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with left-right confusion

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with neglect characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with neglect
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with neglect

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with memory impairment characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with memory impairment
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with memory impairment

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with dyscalculia / acalculia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dyscalculia/acalculia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dyscalculia/acalculia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with dysgraphia / agraphia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dysgraphia/agraphia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dysgraphia/agraphia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with conduction dysphasia / aphasia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with conduction dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with conduction dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with dyslexia / alexia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dyslexia/alexia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with dyslexia/alexia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with illusion characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with illusion
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with illusion

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with auditory agnosia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with auditory agnosia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with auditory agnosia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with dissociation at the onset of the seizure impairment of awareness at at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness seizure with dissociation at onset
name: Focal impaired awareness seizure with dissociation at onset

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with deja vu / jamais vu characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with deja vu/jamais vu
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with deja vu/jamais vu

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with hallucination characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with hallucination
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with hallucination

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with expressive dysphasia / aphasia characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with expressive dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with expressive dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure with forced thinking characterized by impairment of awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with forced thinking
name: Focal impaired awareness cognitive seizure with forced thinking

desc: A focal sensory seizure in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure

desc: A focal sensory seizure with olfaction in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with olfactory features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with olfactory features

desc: A focal sensory seizure with vestibular features in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with vestibular features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with vestibular features

desc: A focal sensory seizure with visual features in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with visual features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with visual features

desc: A focal sensory seizure with hot-cold sensations in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with hot-cold sensations
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with hot-cold sensations

desc: A focal sensory seizure with cephalic sensation in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with cephalic sensation
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with cephalic sensation

desc: A focal sensory seizure with auditory features in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with auditory features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with auditory features

desc: A focal sensory seizure with somatosensory features in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with somatosensory features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with somatosensory features

desc: A focal sensory seizure with gustatory features in which awareness is partially or fully impaired at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with gustatory features
name: Focal impaired awareness sensory seizure with gustatory features

desc: A focal behavior arrest seizure characterised by impaired awareness at some point during the seizure.
layperson: Focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizure
name: Focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizure
synonyms: Focal impaired awareness behaviour arrest seizure

desc: A bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset is a focal-onset seizure which progresses into a bilateral tonic-clonic phase.
layperson: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset
name: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure with focal onset
synonyms: Generalised tonic-clonic seizures with focal onset
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures with focal onset

desc: A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by a motor sign as its initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal motor seizure

desc: A focal clonic seizure is a type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking, that is regularly repetitive.
name: Focal clonic seizure

desc: A type of focal clonic seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking rapidly involves one side of the body at seizure onset.
name: Focal hemiclonic seizure

desc: Focal seizure characterized at onset by clonic movements affecting half of the face.
name: Focal hemifacial clonic seizure

desc: A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction(s) of muscles(s) or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.
name: Focal myoclonic seizure

desc: Focal seizure with eyelid myoclonia, not eyelid myoclonias in the context of absence seizures.
name: Eyelid myoclonias

desc: A type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained increase in muscle contraction, lasting a few seconds to minutes.
name: Focal tonic seizure

desc: A focal seizure characterized at onset by predominantly proximal limb or axial muscles producing irregular sequential ballistic movements, such as pedaling, pelvic thrusting, thrashing, rocking movements.
name: Focal hyperkinetic seizure

desc: A type of focal motor seizure characterised by sustained, forced conjugate ocular, cephalic, and/or truncal rotation or lateral deviation from the midline as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal motor seizure with version

desc: A focal seizure characterized at onset by sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic activity, typically lasting more than 500 ms but less than 2 seconds. It may involve the head, trunk, jaw or limb musculature.
name: Focal atonic seizure

desc: A type of focal motor seizure (it commences in one hemisphere) involving bilateral muscle groups rapidly at seizure onset.
name: Focal bilateral motor seizure

desc: A focal motor seizure in which the initial semiological manifestation is the sustained contraction of both agonist and antagonist muscles producing athetoid or twisting movements, which produces abnormal postures.
name: Focal motor seizure with dystonia

desc: A type of focal motor seizure characterized by difficulty with articulation of speech, due to impaired coordination of muscles involved in speech sound production as the initial semiological manifestation. Receptive and expressive language functions are intact, however speech is poorly articulated and is less intelligible.
name: Focal motor seizure with dysarthria/anarthria

desc: A focal motor seizure characterized by weakness or complete paralysis of a muscle or group of muscles as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal motor seizure with paresis/paralysis

desc: A type of epileptic spasm of focal onset.
name: Focal-onset epileptic spasm

desc: A type of focal motor seizure characterized by a sudden interruption in normal tonic muscle activity lasting 500 ms or less, without evidence of preceding myoclonus as the initial semiological manifestation. The interruption in muscle tone is briefer than seen in a focal atonic seizure.
layperson: Focal motor seizure with negative myoclonus
name: Focal motor seizure with negative myoclonus

desc: A focal seizure characterized at onset by coordinated motor activity. This often resembles a voluntary movement and may consist of an inappropriate continuation of preictal motor activity.
name: Focal automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by orofacial automatisms at onset.
name: Focal orofacial automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by manual automatisms at onset.
name: Focal manual automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by coordinated bilateral or unilateral movements of the feet or legs at onset. The movement is more reminiscent of normal movements in amplitude, and is less frenetic or rapid in comparison to the movements seen in focal hyperkinetic seizures involving the legs.
name: Focal pedal automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by inappropriate continuation of pre-seizure movement or behavior at onset.
name: Focal perseverative automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by the production of single or repetitive meaningless vocal sounds such as shrieks or grunts at onset.
