name: Focal vocal automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by the production of single or repetitive words, phrases, or brief sentences at onset.
name: Focal verbal automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by involuntary sexual behavior at onset.
name: Focal sexual automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by involuntary head nodding at onset.
name: Focal head nodding automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal automatism seizure characterized by involuntary undressing at onset.
name: Focal undressing automatism seizure

desc: A type of focal-onset seizure characterized by non-motor signs or symptoms (or behaviour arrest) as its initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal non-motor seizure

desc: An autonomic seizure is a type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by alteration of autonomic nervous system function as the initial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by symptoms or signs pertaining to the gastrointestinal system as the initial semiological feature.
layperson: Focal autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena
name: Focal autonomic seizure with epigastric sensation/nausea/vomiting/other gastrointestinal phenomena

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by changes of the skin as the initial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure with pallor/flushing

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by pupillary dilatation or contraction as the initial semiological feature.
layperson: Focal autonomic seizure with pupillary dilation/constriction
name: Focal autonomic seizure with pupillary dilation/constriction

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterised by penile erection as the intial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure with erection

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by an urge to unripe or defecate as the initial semiological feature.
layperson: Focal autonomic seizure with urge to urinate/defecate
name: Focal autonomic seizure with urge to urinate/defecate

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by changes in respiratory rate as the initial semiological feature.
layperson: Focal autonomic seizure with hypoventilation/hyperventilation/altered respiration
name: Focal autonomic seizure with hypoventilation/hyperventilation/altered respiration

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by piloerection (bristling of hairs due to the involuntary contraction of small muscles at the base of hair follicles) as the initial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure with piloerection

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by lacrimation as the initial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure with lacrimation

desc: A type of focal autonomic seizure characterized by changes in heart rate as the initial semiological feature.
name: Focal autonomic seizure with palpitations/tachycardia/bradycardia/asystole

desc: A focal sensory seizure is a type seizure beginning with a subjective sensation.
name: Focal sensory seizure

desc: A seizure characterized by elementary auditory phenomena including buzzing, ringing, drumming or single tones as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with auditory features
name: Focal sensory seizure with auditory features

desc: A seizure characterized by taste phenomena including acidic, bitter, salty, sweet, or metallic tastes as its first clinical manifestation.
name: Focal sensory seizure with gustatory features

desc: Seizures characterized by olfactory phenomena as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with olfactory features
name: Focal sensory seizure with olfactory features

desc: Auras with affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual phenomena including illusory or composite hallucinatory events.
name: Psychic auras

desc: A seizure characterized by sensory phenomena including tingling, numbness, electric-shock like sensation, pain, sense of movement, or desire to move as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with somatosensory features
name: Focal sensory seizure with somatosensory features

desc: A sensation consistent with involvement of the autonomic nervous system, including cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor and thermoregulatory functions.
name: Vegetative auras

desc: A seizure characterized by elementary visual hallucinations such as flashing or flickering lights/colours, or other shapes, simple patterns, scotomata, or amaurosis as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with visual features
name: Focal sensory seizure with visual features

desc: Affective, mnemonic or composite perceptual auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
name: Experiential auras

desc: Affective auras with subjective qualities similar to those experienced in life but are recognized by the subject as occurring outside of actual context.
name: Affective auras

desc: Auras which reflect ictal dysmnesia such as: feelings as familiarity (deja-vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais-vu).
name: Mnemonic auras

desc: A subjective feeling that an experience which is occurring for the first time has been experienced before.
name: Deja vu

desc: A subjective feeling that an experience which has occurred before is being experienced for the first time.
name: Jamais vu

desc: Auras with creation of composite perceptions without corresponding external stimuli involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory and/or gustatory phenomena.
name: Hallucinatory auras

desc: Auras with an alteration of actual percepts involving the visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory or gustatory systems.
name: Illusory auras

desc: A seizure characterized by symptoms of dizziness, spinning, vertigo or sense of rotation as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with vestibular features
name: Focal sensory seizure with vestibular features

desc: A seizure characterized by sensations of feeling hot or cold as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with hot-cold sensations
name: Focal sensory seizure with hot-cold sensations

desc: A seizure characterized by a sensation in the head such as light-headedness or headache as its first clinical manifestation.
layperson: Focal sensory seizure with cephalic sensation
name: Focal sensory seizure with cephalic sensation

desc: A type of focal non-motor seizure characterized by an arrest or pause of activities, freezing, or immobilization as the predominant semiological feature throughout the seizure.
name: Focal behavior arrest seizure

desc: Seizures presenting with an emotion or the appearance of having an emotion as an early prominent feature, such as fear, spontaneous joy or euphoria, laughing (gelastic), or crying, (dacrystic). These emotional seizures may occur with or without objective clinical signs of a seizure evident to the observer.
name: Focal emotional seizure

desc: Focal emotional seizure with crying (dacrystic) is characterized by the presence of stereotyped crying, this may be accompanied by lacrimation, sad facial expression and sobbing. The subjective emotion of sadness may or may not be present.
name: Focal emotional seizure with crying

desc: Focal emotional seizure with laughing (gelastic) is characterized by bursts of laughter or giggling, usually without appropriate related emotion of happiness, and described as 'mirthless'.
name: Focal emotional seizure with laughing

desc: Focal emotional seizure with agitation is characterized by the presence of psychomotor agitation as an expressed or observed emotion, at the outset of the seizure. Because of the unpleasant nature of these seizures, patients may also have anticipatory anxiety about having seizures.
name: Focal emotional seizure with agitation

desc: Focal emotional seizure with pleasure is characterized by the presence of a positive emotional experience with pleasure, bliss, joy, enhanced personal well-being, heightened self-awareness or ecstasy.
name: Focal emotional seizure with pleasure

desc: Focal emotional seizure with anger is characterized by the presence of anger, as an expressed or observed emotion, at the outset of the seizure. It may be accompanied by aggressive behaviour.
name: Focal emotional seizure with anger

desc: Focal emotional seizure with paranoia is characterized by the presence of paranoia as an expressed or observed emotion at the outset of the seizure.
name: Focal emotional seizure with paranoia

desc: Focal emotional seizure with anxiety is characterized by the presence of anxiety, fear or panic as an expressed or observed emotion, at the outset of the seizure. Because of the unpleasant nature of these seizures, patients may also have anticipatory anxiety about having seizures.
name: Focal emotional seizure with fear/anxiety/panic

desc: A focal cognitive seizure involves an alteration in a cognitive function (which can be a deficit or a positive phenomenon such as forced thought), which occurs at seizure onset. To be classified as a focal cognitive seizure, the change in cognitive function should be specific and out of proportion to other relatively unimpaired aspects of cognition, because all cognition is impaired in a focal impaired awareness seizure.
name: Focal cognitive seizure

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by auditory agnosia as the initial semiological manifestation. For example a person may hear a ringing sound, but may not connect this with the concept that the sound is from a telephone ringing.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with auditory agnosia
name: Focal cognitive seizure with auditory agnosia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by transient memory impairment as the initial semiological manifestation whilst other cognitive functions and awareness are preserved at seizure onset. The memory impairment may be an inability to recall events occurring prior to the seizure (retrograde amnesia), or failure to encode new memories for events occurring during the seizure (anterograde amnesia).
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with memory impairment
name: Focal cognitive seizure with memory impairment

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by an experience of being disconnected from, though aware of, self or environment as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with dissociation

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by dyscalculia / acalculia as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with dyscalculia/acalculia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by forced thinking as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with forced thinking
name: Focal cognitive seizure with forced thinking

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by neglect as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with neglect

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by dyslexia / alexia as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with dyslexia/alexia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by an alteration of actual perception involving visual, auditory, somatosensory, olfactory, and/or gustatory phenomena as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with illusion

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by receptive dysphasia / aphasia as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with receptive dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal cognitive seizure with receptive dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by memory phenomena such as feelings of familiarity (deja vu) and unfamiliarity (jamais vu) as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with deja vu/jamais vu
name: Focal cognitive seizure with deja vu/jamais vu

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by conduction dysphasia / aphasia as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with conduction dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal cognitive seizure with conduction dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by dysgraphia / agraphia as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with dysgraphia/agraphia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by left-right confusion as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with left-right confusion
name: Focal cognitive seizure with left-right confusion

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by anomia as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with anomia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by expressive dysphasia / aphasia as the initial semiological manifestation.
layperson: Focal cognitive seizure with expressive dysphasia/aphasia
name: Focal cognitive seizure with expressive dysphasia/aphasia

desc: A focal cognitive seizure characterized by hallucination as the initial semiological manifestation.
name: Focal cognitive seizure with hallucination

desc: A migrating focal seizure is a seizure that involves different body parts, usually without overlap, in a consecutive manner so that the offset of a seizure in one part coincides with its onset in another, even shifting multiple times between the sides of the body. They can be associated with autonomic manifestations.
name: Migrating focal seizure

desc: A seizure that occurs in the context of a brain insult (systemic, toxic, or metabolic) and may not recur when the underlying cause has been removed or the acute phase has elapsed.
name: Symptomatic seizures

desc: A dialeptic seizure is a type of seizure characterised predominantly by reduced responsiveness or awareness and with subsequent at least partial amnesia of the event.
name: Dialeptic seizure

desc: Seizures precipitated by exogenous stimuli.
name: Reflex seizure

desc: A seizure precipitated by aspects of anticipating food, eating itself, or the post-prandial period.
name: Eating-induced seizure

desc: A seizure precipitated by pouring cupfuls of very hot water (40 to 50 degrees Celsius) in rapid succession over the head. Bathing in this manner is the most common trigger.
name: Hot water-induced seizure

desc: A seizure precipitated by complex, cognition-guided tasks often involving visuomotor coordination and decision-making.
name: Praxis-induced seizure

desc: A seizure precipitated by movement or a change in posture.
name: Proprioceptive-induced seizure

desc: A seizure precipitated by reading.
name: Reading-induced seizure

desc: A somatosensory reflex seizure is a seizure precipitated by somatic stimulation of a specific part of the body in the absence of startle or surprise.
name: Somatosensory-induced seizure

desc: Startle-induced seizures are triggered by multiple and non-specific stimuli (auditory, somatosensory, and rarely visual) and are characterized by their sudden unexpected nature. Sudden noise rather than pure sound is the most effective acoustic stimulus.
name: Startle-induced seizure

desc:
Seizures induced by thinking and decision-making.
comment:
name: Thinking-induced seizure

desc: Seizures evoked by visual stimuli. This includes clinical seizures induced by strobe lighting, television and other screens, flickering environmental lighting and self-induction by causing a strobe effect.
name: Visually-induced seizure

desc: Seizure precipitated by listening to music or other complex sounds.
name: Music-induced seizure

desc: A motor seizure is a type of seizure that is characterized at onset by involvement of the skeletal musculature. The motor event could consist of an increase (positive) or decrease (negative) in muscle contraction to produce a movement.
name: Motor seizure

desc: A bilateral tonic-clonic seizure is a seizure defined by a tonic (bilateral increased tone, lasting seconds to minutes) and then a clonic (bilateral sustained rhythmic jerking) phase.
name: Bilateral tonic-clonic seizure
synonyms: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure (without specification of onset)
Generalized tonic-clonic seizure (without specification of onset)

desc: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures on awakening are a form of Generalized tonic-clonic seizures that occur upon awaking.
name: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures on awakening

desc: Atonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by a sudden loss or diminution of muscle tone without apparent preceding myoclonic or tonic event lasting about 1 to 2 seconds, involving head, trunk, jaw, or limb musculature.
name: Atonic seizure

desc: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: Grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. Epileptic spasms frequently occur in clusters. Infantile spasms are the best known form, but spasms can occur at all ages
name: Epileptic spasm

desc: Infantile spasms represent a subset of "epileptic spasms". Infantile Spasms are epileptic spasms starting in the first year of life (infancy).
name: Infantile spasms

desc: A clonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking, that is regularly repetitive.
name: Clonic seizure

desc: A tonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterised by unilateral or bilateral limb stiffening or elevation, often with neck stiffening.
name: Tonic seizure

desc: A myoclonic seizure is a type of motor seizure characterised by sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.
name: Myoclonic seizure

desc: Seizures that start from several different areas of the brain (i.e., with multiple ictal onset locations).
name: Multifocal seizures

desc: Seizures that occur while the affected individual is sleeping.
name: Nocturnal seizures

desc: A seizure occurring within the neonatal period (28 days beyond the full term date).
name: Neonatal seizure

desc: Neonatal seizure is a seizure type that occurs in neonatal period and is characterized by an electrographic event with sudden, repetitive, evolving stereotyped waveforms with a beginning and an end. This event can be associated or not with a clinical manifestation.
name: Neonatal seizure with electrographic correlate

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical seizure is an electrographic event occurring in neonatal period and coupled with a clinical manifestation.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical non-motor autonomic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure with predominant features of autonomic alterations, involving cardiovascular, pupillary, gastrointestinal, sudomotor, vasomotor, and thermoregulatory functions. May present as apnea.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical autonomic seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical non-motor seizure with behavior arrest is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure characterized by an arrest of activities, freezing, immobilization, with or without apnea and/or other autonomic manifestations.
layperson: Neonatal electro-clinical seizure with behavior arrest
name: Neonatal electro-clinical seizure with behavior arrest
synonyms: Neonatal electro-clinical seizure with behaviour arrest
Neonatal electroclinical seizure with behavioural arrest

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure with predominant motor features.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical clonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is a regularly repeating jerking involving the same muscle groups; it can be symmetric or asymmetric.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical clonic seizure

desc: Neonatal focal clonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical clonic seizure where the predominant motor feature is unilateral regularly repeating jerking involving the same muscle groups.
name: Neonatal focal clonic seizure

desc: Neonatal bilateral clonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical clonic seizure where the clonic jerking is bilateral.
name: Neonatal bilateral clonic seizure

desc: Neonatal focal clonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical clonic seizure where the predominant motor feature is a regularly repeating jerking involving the same muscle groups, which occurs at multiple sites.
name: Neonatal multifocal clonic seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical myoclonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is sudden, brief (<100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal).
name: Neonatal electro-clinical myoclonic seizure

desc: Neonatal multifocal myoclonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is sudden, brief (<100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal) wich occurs at multiple sites.
name: Neonatal multifocal myoclonic seizure

desc: Neonatal focal myoclonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is sudden, brief (<100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal) which occurs focally.
name: Neonatal focal myoclonic seizure

desc: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric myoclonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is sudden, brief (<100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal) wich occurs at both sides of the body asymmetrically.
name: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric myoclonic seizure

desc: Neonatal bilateral symmetric myoclonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is sudden, brief (<100 msec) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal) wich occurs at both sides of the body symmetrically.
name: Neonatal bilateral symmetric myoclonic seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical tonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure where the predominant motor feature is a sustained increase in muscle tone, usually focal, that can be unilateral or bilateral, and lasting a few seconds to minutes.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical tonic seizure

desc: Neonatal focal tonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical tonic seizure with a focal sustained increase in muscle tone, lasting a few seconds to minutes.
name: Neonatal focal tonic seizure

desc: Neonatal bilateral symmetric tonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical tonic seizure where the sustained increase in muscle tone, lasting a few seconds to minutes, occurs at both sides of the body symmetrically.
name: Neonatal bilateral symmetric tonic seizure

desc: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric tonic seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical tonic seizure where the sustained increase in muscle tone, lasting a few seconds to minutes, occurs at both sides of the body but asymmetrically.
name: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric tonic seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the predominant feature cannot be detected because of seizures presenting with a variety of clinical and electrographic signs, often changing lateralization within or between seizures.
name: Neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure

desc: Focal neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the predominant feature cannot be detected because of seizures presenting with a variety of clinical and electrographic focal signs, often changing lateralization within or between seizures.
name: Focal neonatal sequential seizure

desc: Multifocal neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the predominant feature cannot be detected because of seizures presenting with a variety of clinical and electrographic multifocal signs.
name: Multifocal neonatal sequential seizure

desc: Asymmetric neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the predominant feature cannot be detected because of seizures presenting asymmetrically with a variety of clinical and electrographic signs, often changing lateralization within or between seizures.
name: Bilateral asymmetric neonatal sequential seizure

desc: Symmetric neonatal electro-clinical sequential motor seizure is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the predominant feature cannot be detected because of seizures presenting symmetrically but with a variety of clinical and electrographic signs.
name: Bilateral symmetric neonatal sequential seizure

desc: Neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure with automatism is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the electrographic event is correlated with a coordinated motor activity, typically oral, usually with impaired awarness, and in association with other features.
layperson: Neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure with automatism
name: Neonatal electro-clinical motor seizure with automatism
synonyms: Neonatal electroclinical motor seizure with automatism

desc: Neonatal seizure with bilateral asymmetric automatism is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the electrographic event is correlated with coordinated motor activity, typically oral, usually with impaired awareness, occurring at both sides of the body asymmetrically.
layperson: Neonatal seizure with bilateral asymmetric automatism
name: Neonatal seizure with bilateral asymmetric automatism

desc: Neonatal seizure with bilateral asymmetric automatisms is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the electrographic event is correlated with a coordinated motor activity, typically oral, usually with impaired awarness, occurring at one side of the body.
name: Neonatal seizure with unilateral automatism

desc: Neonatal seizure with bilateral asymmetric automatism is a type of neonatal electro-clinical seizure where the electrographic event is correlated with a coordinated motor activity, typically oral, usually with impaired awarness, occurring at both sides of the body symmetrically.
layperson: Neonatal seizure with bilateral symmetric automatism
name: Neonatal seizure with bilateral symmetric automatism

desc: A sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that is usually more sustained than a myoclonic movement but not as sustained as a tonic seizure. Limited forms may occur: grimacing, head nodding, or subtle eye movements. May occur in clusters.
name: Neonatal epileptic spasm

desc: Neonatal unilateral epileptic spasm is a sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that occurs at one side of the body.
name: Neonatal unilateral epileptic spasm

desc: Neonatal bilateral symmetric epileptic spasm is a sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that occurs symmetrically at both sides of the body.
name: Neonatal bilateral symmetric epileptic spasm

desc: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric epileptic spasm is a sudden flexion, extension, or mixed extension-flexion of predominantly proximal and truncal muscles that occurs asymmetrically at both sides of the body.
name: Neonatal bilateral asymmetric epileptic spasm

desc: Neonatal electrographic only seizure is an electrographic event with sudden, repetitive, evolving stereotyped waveforms with a beginning and an end, which is not associated with a clinical manifestation.
name: Neonatal electrographic only seizure

desc: Seizure associated with a presumed or proven infection (excluding infection of the central nervous system) or inflammatory state without an alternative precipitant such as metabolic derangement, and regardless of the presence or absence of a fever.
name: Infection-related seizure

desc: Afebrile (less than 38.0 degrees Celcius), brief, and generalized seizures accompanying gastroenteritis without an alternative cause.
name: Gastroenteritis-related afebrile seizure

desc: Any form of seizure occurring at the time of a fever (temperature at or above 38.0 degrees Celcius) without infection of the central nervous system, and without an alternative cause such as severe metabolic derangement, occurring at any age.
name: Seizure precipitated by febrile infection

desc: A febrile seizure is any type of seizure (most often a generalized tonic-clonic seizure) occurring with fever (at least 38 degrees Celsius) but in the absence of central nervous system infection, severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years.
name: Febrile seizure (within the age range of 3 months to 6 years)

desc: A short generalized seizure, of a duration of <15 min, not recurring within 24 h, occurring during a febrile episode not caused by an acute disease of the nervous system intracranial infection or severe metabolic disturbance.
name: Simple febrile seizure

desc: A febrile seizure that has any of the following features: focal semiology (or associated with post-ictal neurologic abnormalities beyond drowsiness, such as a Todd's paresis), prolonged seizure beyond 15 minutes, or recurring (occurring more than once) in a 24 hour period.
name: Complex febrile seizure

desc: Any type of seizure (most often a generalized tonic-clonic seizure) occurring with fever (at least 38.0 degrees Celsius) but in the absence of central nervous system infection, severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in people beyond the typical arrange of 3 months-6 years with no prior history of afebrile seizure.
layperson: Febrile seizure outside the age of 3 months to 6 years
name: Febrile seizure outside the age of 3 months to 6 years

desc: A seizure during pregnancy.
name: Maternal seizure

desc: Bulbar weakness (or bulbar palsy) refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII, which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain-stem. Bulbar weakness is often associated with difficulty in chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.
name: Bulbar palsy

desc: Encephalopathy is a term that means brain disease, damage, or malfunction. In general, encephalopathy is manifested by an altered mental state.
name: Encephalopathy

desc: Central nervous system dysfunction in association with liver failure and characterized clinically (depending on degree of severity) by lethargy, confusion, nystagmus, decorticate posturing, spasticity, and bilateral Babinski reflexes.
name: Hepatic encephalopathy

desc: Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage.
name: Hypoglycemic encephalopathy

desc: A type of encephalopathy (brain disease, damage, or malfunction accompanied by an altered mental state) that is characterized by evidence of necrosis of brain tissue.
name: Necrotizing encephalopathy

desc: Encephalopathy with onset in the infantile period.
name: Infantile encephalopathy

desc: Recurrent episodes of brain dysfunction that may be triggered by factors such as metabolic disturbances or infections.
name: Recurrent encephalopathy

desc: A condition in which epileptiform abnormalities are believed to contribute to the progressive disturbance in cerebral function. Epileptic encephalaopathy is characterized by (1) electrographic EEG paroxysmal activity that is often aggressive, (2) seizures that are usually multiform and intractable, (3) cognitive, behavioral and neurological deficits that may be relentless, and (4) sometimes early death.
name: Epileptic encephalopathy

desc: An abnormality of the function of the electrical signals with which nerve cells communicate with each other or with muscles as measured by electrophysiological investigations.
name: Abnormal nervous system electrophysiology

desc: An abnormality of the function of the electrical signals with which peripheral nerve cells communicate with each other or with muscles.
layperson: Abnormality of peripheral nervous system electrophysiology
name: Abnormality of peripheral nervous system electrophysiology

desc: An abnormality of the conduction of electrical impulses by peripheral (motor or sensory) nerves. This finding is elicited by a nerve conduction study (NCS).
name: Abnormality of peripheral nerve conduction
synonyms: Sensory and motor nerve conduction abnormalities

desc: An anomaly in the magnitude of the action potential along a peripheral nerve, that is, of the rapid rise and fall of the electrical membrane potential of the nerve.
name: Abnormal peripheral action potential amplitude

desc: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies.
layperson: Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials
name: Decreased amplitude of sensory action potentials

desc: A reduction in the amplitude of sensory nerve action potential in distal nerve segments. This feature is measured by nerve conduction studies.
layperson: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential
name: Decreased distal sensory nerve action potential

desc: A reduction in the speed at which electrical signals propagate along the axon of a neuron.
name: Decreased nerve conduction velocity

desc: A type of decreased nerve conduction velocity that affects the motor neuron.
name: Decreased motor nerve conduction velocity

desc: Reduced speed of conduction of the action potential along a sensory nerve.
name: Decreased sensory nerve conduction velocity

desc: Blockade of impulses at a focal site along the course of a motor axon.
name: Motor conduction block

desc: An abnormality of the auditory evoked potentials, which are used to trace the signal generated by a sound, from the cochlear nerve, through the lateral lemniscus, to the medial geniculate nucleus, and to the cortex.
name: Abnormal auditory evoked potentials

desc: Lack of measurable response to stimulation of auditory evoked potentials.
name: Absent brainstem auditory responses

desc: An abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP), i.e., of the electrical signals of sensation going from the body to the brain in response to a defined stimulus. Recording electrodes are placed over the scalp, spine, and peripheral nerves proximal to the stimulation site. Clinical studies generally use electrical stimulation of peripheral nerves to elicit potentials. SSEP testing determines whether peripheral sensory nerves are able to transmit sensory information like pain, temperature, and touch to the brain. Abnormal SSEPs can result from dysfunction at the level of the peripheral nerve, plexus, spinal root, spinal cord, brain stem, thalamocortical projections, or primary somatosensory cortex.
name: Abnormality of somatosensory evoked potentials

desc: An abnormal enlargement (i.e. increase in measured voltage) of somatosensory evoked potentials.
name: Giant somatosensory evoked potentials

desc: Increase in amplitude of a long-loop response upon somatosensory evoked potential testing, representing an electrically evoked myoclonic response.
name: Enhancement of the C-reflex

layperson: Abnormality of peripheral somatosensory evoked potentials
name: Abnormality of peripheral somatosensory evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormality of central somatosensory evoked potentials
name: Abnormality of central somatosensory evoked potentials

layperson: Abnormality of central nervous system electrophysiology
name: Abnormality of central nervous system electrophysiology

desc: Jerk-locked averaging (JLA) is used to record the timing and distribution of brain activity preceding brisk involuntary movements such as those observed in patients with myoclonus. JLA is capable of revealing a premyoclonus spike in the absence of paroxysmal activity in the routine EEG.
name: Jerk-locked premyoclonus spikes

desc: Abnormality observed by electroencephalogram (EEG), which is used to record of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp.
name: EEG abnormality

desc: EEG abnormalities (epileptiform discharges) evoked by flashing lights or black and white striped patterns.
name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response

desc: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital regions during photic stimulation.
layperson: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade I
name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade I

desc: Occurence of epileptiform discharges in occipital and central regions during photic stimulation.
layperson: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade II
name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade II

desc: Occurrence of epileptiform discharges in occipital, central, temporal and parietal regions during photic stimulation.
layperson: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade III
name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade III

desc: Occurrence of generalized epileptiform discharges during photic stimulation.
layperson: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade IV
name: EEG with photoparoxysmal response grade IV

desc: An EEG with constitutional variants contains waves that are rare or unusual but not generally pathologic.
name: EEG with constitutional variants

layperson: EEG with persistent abnormal rhythmic activity
name: EEG with persistent abnormal rhythmic activity

desc: EEG background activity at 4-5/second.
name: EEG with 4-5/second background activity

desc: EEG dominated by diffuse alpha-waves (8-13Hz).
name: Alpha-EEG

desc: EEG dominated by diffuse beta-waves (>13 Hz).
name: Beta-EEG

desc: EEG dominated by diffuse beta waves (>13 Hz) with occipitally localized alpha waves (8-13 Hz).
name: Partial beta-EEG

desc: EEG with an amplitude less than 30 microvolts without observable occipital alpha rhythm (8-13 Hz).
name: Low voltage EEG

desc: EEG with abnormal amplitude.
name: EEG with changes in voltage

desc: An abnormal generalized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
layperson: EEG with generalized low amplitude activity
name: EEG with generalized low amplitude activity
synonyms: EEG with generalised low amplitude activity

desc: An abnormal localized reduction in amplitude of the cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
layperson: EEG with localized low amplitude activity
name: EEG with localized low amplitude activity
synonyms: EEG with localised low amplitude activity

desc: EEG frequency is abnormally increased.
name: EEG with diffuse acceleration

desc: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies.
name: EEG with abnormally slow frequencies

desc: Focal (localized) slow activity reflects focal dysfunction, not diffuse dysfunction (i.e., encephalopathy).
name: EEG with focal slow activity

desc: Slowing in occipital areas of the scalp EEG.
name: EEG with occipital slowing

desc: Multifocal slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with multifocal slow activity

desc: Diffuse slowing of cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with generalized slow activity

desc: EEG showing diffuse slowing without interruption.
name: EEG with continuous slow activity

desc: Non-continuous diffuse slowing of electroencephalographic patterns.
name: EEG with intermittent slow activity

desc: Slowing at frequencies between 7.5 and 8.5 Hz.
layperson: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 1
synonyms: EEG with generalised slow activity grade 1

desc: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 4-7 Hz.
layperson: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 2
synonyms: EEG with generalised slow activity grade 2

desc: Generalized slowing of EEG activity at frequencies between 0.5-3 Hz.
layperson: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 3
synonyms: EEG with generalised slow activity grade 3

desc: EEG without electrical activity.
layperson: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
name: EEG with generalized slow activity grade 4
synonyms: EEG with generalised slow activity grade 4

desc: Interictal refers to a period of time between epileptic seizures. Electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns are important in the differential diagnosis of epilepsy, and the EEG is almost always abnormal during a seizure. Some persons with seizures may show EEG abnormalities between seizures, while others do not. In some cases, multiple interictal EEGs must be recorded before an abnormality is observed. In most cases the electrographic pattern of seizure onset is completely different from the activity recorded during interictal discharge.
name: Interictal EEG abnormality

desc: Lack of observable abnormal electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns in an individual with a history of seizures. About half of individuals with epilepsy show interictal epileptiform discharges upon the first investigation. The yield can be increased by repeated studies, sleep studies, or by ambulatory EEG recordings over 24 hours. Normal interictal EEG is a sign that can be useful in the differential diagnosis.
name: Normal interictal EEG

desc: Epileptiform activity refers to distinctive EEG waves or complexes distinguished from background activity found in in a proportion of human subjects with epilepsy, but which can also be found in subjects without seizures. Interictal epileptiform activity refers to such activity that occurs in the absence of a clinical or subclinical seizure.
name: Interictal epileptiform activity

desc: Epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with hyperventilation-induced epileptiform discharges

desc: Focal epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
layperson: EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges
name: EEG with hyperventilation-induced focal epileptiform discharges

desc: Generalized epileptiform discharges induced by hyperventilation (overbreathing) in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
layperson: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
name: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalized epileptiform discharges
synonyms: EEG with hyperventilation-induced generalised epileptiform discharges

desc: EEG discharges recorded in particular areas of a localized (focal) abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with focal epileptiform discharges

desc: An abnormality in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG) and being identified at multiple locations (foci).
name: Multifocal epileptiform discharges

desc: Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in both hemispheres.
name: Bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges

desc: Epileptiform discharges identified at multiple locations temporarily in both hemispheres and temporarily in one hemisphere.
layperson: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges
name: Uni- and bilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges

desc: Epileptiform discharges being identified at multiple locations in one hemisphere.
name: Unilateral multifocal epileptiform discharges

desc: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to contralateral hemisphere but without secondary generalization.
layperson: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere
name: Focal epileptiform discharges with limited propagation to contralateral hemisphere

desc: Periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs)are periodic, lateralized, and epileptiform. PLEDs show a relatively constant interval between discharges (0.5 to 3 seconds).
layperson: EEG with periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges
name: EEG with periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges

desc: Focal epileptiform discharges with spreading to the hemisphere on the same side of the brain.
layperson: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere
name: Focal EEG discharges with propagation to ipsilateral hemisphere

desc: Focal EEG discharges that secondarily spread to both hemispheres and can then be recorded over the entire scalp.
layperson: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
name: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalization
synonyms: Focal EEG discharges with secondary generalisation

desc: Focal epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.
name: Polymorphic focal epileptiform discharges

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
name: EEG with focal spikes

desc: Focal spikes occurring for several seconds.
layperson: EEG with series of focal spikes
name: EEG with series of focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the central region.
name: EEG with central focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the frontal region.
name: EEG with frontal focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the occipital region.
name: EEG with occipital focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the parietal region.
name: EEG with parietal focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec in the temporal region.
name: EEG with temporal focal spikes

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with focal sharp slow waves
name: EEG with focal sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with sharp slow waves in the occipital region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with occipital sharp slow waves
name: EEG with occipital sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with sharp slow waves in the parietal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with parietal sharp slow waves
name: EEG with parietal sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with sharp slow waves in the temporal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves
name: EEG with temporal sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with sharp slow waves in the frontal region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves
name: EEG with frontal sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with sharp slow waves in the central region. Sharp slow waves are focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with central sharp slow waves
name: EEG with central sharp slow waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with focal sharp waves

desc: EEG with sharp waves in the occipital region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with occipital sharp waves

desc: EEG with sharp waves in the central region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with central sharp waves

desc: EEG with sharp waves in the frontal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with frontal sharp waves

desc: EEG with sharp waves in the parietal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with parietal sharp waves

desc: EEG with sharp waves in the temporal region, i.e., sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec.
name: EEG with temporal sharp waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
name: EEG with focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the central region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with central focal spike waves
name: EEG with central focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the frontal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with frontal focal spike waves
name: EEG with frontal focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the occipital region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with occipital focal spike waves
name: EEG with occipital focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the parietal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with parietal focal spike waves
name: EEG with parietal focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the temporal region, i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with temporal focal spike waves
name: EEG with temporal focal spike waves

desc: EEG with focal sharp transient waves in the centrotemporal region of the brain (also known as the central sulcus), i.e., focal sharp waves of a duration less than 80 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with centrotemporal focal spike waves
name: EEG with centrotemporal focal spike waves

desc: Hypsarrhythmia occurring in one hemisphere.
name: Hemihypsarrhythmia

desc: EEG discharges recorded on the entire scalp typically seen in persons with epilepsy.
name: EEG with generalized epileptiform discharges

desc: Hypsarrhythmia is abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes. There is continuous (during wakefulness), high-amplitude (>200 Hz), generalized polymorphic slowing with no organized background and multifocal spikes demonstrated by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: Hypsarrhythmia

desc: Complexes of spikes (<70 ms) and sharp waves (70-200 ms), which are sharp transient waves that have a strong association with epilepsy, in cerebral electrical activity recorded along the scalp by electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with spike-wave complexes

desc: EEG shows spikes (<80 ms) and waves, which are recorded over the entire scalp and do not have a specific frequency.
layperson: EEG with irregular generalized spike and wave complexes
name: EEG with irregular generalized spike and wave complexes
synonyms: EEG with irregular generalised spike and wave complexes

desc: The presence of complexes of repetitive spikes and waves in EEG.
name: EEG with polyspike wave complexes
synonyms: EEG: spike and multispike waves, 3-4 hz

desc: The presence of complexes of slow spikes and slow waves (<2.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with spike-wave complexes (<2.5 Hz)

desc: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (2.5-3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with spike-wave complexes (2.5-3.5 Hz)

desc: The presence of complexes of spikes and waves (>3.5 Hz) in electroencephalography (EEG).
name: EEG with spike-wave complexes (>3.5 Hz)

desc: The burst suppression pattern in electroencephalography refers to a characteristic periodic pattern of low voltage (<10 microvolts) suppressed background and a relatively shorter pattern of higher amplitude slow, sharp, and spiking complexes.
name: EEG with burst suppression

desc: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration between 80 and 200 msec followed by a slow wave.
layperson: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
name: EEG with generalized sharp slow waves
synonyms: EEG with generalised sharp slow waves

desc: Generalized epileptiform discharges of different shapes and frequencies.
layperson: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
name: EEG with generalized polymorphic epileptiform discharges
synonyms: EEG with generalised polymorphic epileptiform discharges

desc: Periodically recurring abnormalities in the EEG.
name: EEG with periodic abnormalities

desc: Periodically occurring generalized periodic complexes.
name: EEG with periodic complexes

desc: EEG with generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
name: EEG with generalized spikes

desc: EEG with repetitive generalized sharp transient waves of a duration less than 80 msec.
name: EEG with generalized polyspikes

desc: Diffuse, bilateral and recently also unilateral or focal localization spike-wave occurring in slow sleep or non-rapid eye movement sleep.
layperson: Continuous spike and waves during slow sleep
name: Continuous spike and waves during slow sleep

desc: Lack of normal alpha rhythm in the EEG. Alpha rhythm has been defined as a rhythm at 8-13 Hz occurring during wakefulness over the posterior regions of the head, generally with higher voltage over the occipital areas. Amplitude is variable but is mostly below 50 microvolt in adults. It is best seen with eyes closed and under conditions of physical relaxation and relative mental inactivity. It is blocked or attenuated by attention, especially visual and mental effort. One should here note the difference between the terms alpha rhythm and alpha activity: Alpha activity refers to activity in the range of 8-13 Hz and alpha rhythm is the activity of 8-13 Hz with specific characteristics as defined above.
name: Absent posterior alpha rhythm

desc: Increased frequency of theta wave activity in the electroencephalogram. Theta waves have a frequency of 3.5-7.5 Hertz, and are present in very small amounts in healthy waking adult EEGs. Theta activity is normal in small very amounts in the healthy waking adult EEG in a symmetrical distribution.
layperson: Increased theta frequency activity in EEG
name: Increased theta frequency activity in EEG

desc: An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs). MEPs are measured following single-pulse or repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation and can be used for the assessment of the excitability of the motor cortex and the integrity of conduction along the central and peripheral motor pathways.
name: Abnormal motor evoked potentials

desc: An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs) in the arm.
name: Abnormal upper-limb motor evoked potentials
synonyms: Abnormal motor evoked potentials in the upper limb

desc: An anomaly identified by motor evoked potentials (MEPs) in the leg.
name: Abnormal lower-limb motor evoked potentials
synonyms: Abnormal motor evoked potentials in the lower limb

desc: Difficulty in swallowing.
name: Dysphagia

desc: Bilateral impairment of the function of the cranial nerves 9-12, which control musculature involved in eating, swallowing, and speech. Pseudobulbar paralysis is characterized clinically by dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia with bifacial paralysis, and may be accompanied by Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms such as enforced crying and laughing.
name: Pseudobulbar paralysis

desc: An abnormality of swallowing characterized by reduced tongue coordination to form bolus after chewing. Food material spreads over the oral cavity instead of being concentrated into a bolus that is easily swallowed.
name: Impaired oral bolus formation

desc: Delay or absence of the swallow response, reflexes triggered by the contact the food bolus makes with the anterior faucial pillars.
name: Impaired oropharyngeal swallow response

desc: Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.
name: Pseudobulbar signs

desc: Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.
name: Headache

desc: Migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by episodic attacks of headache and associated symptoms.
name: Migraine

desc: A type of migraine in which there is an aura characterized by focal neurological phenomena that usually proceed, but may accompany or occur in the absence of, the headache. The symptoms of an aura may include fully reversible visual, sensory, and speech symptoms but not motor weakness. Visual symptoms may include flickering lights, spots and lines and/or loss of vision and/or unilateral sensory symptoms such as paresthesias or numbness. At least one of the symptoms of an aura develops gradually over 5 or more minutes and/or different symptoms occur in succession.
name: Migraine with aura

desc: Repeated headache attacks lasting 4-72 h fulfilling at least two of the following criteria: 1) unilateral location, 2) pulsating quality, 3) moderate or severe pain intensity, and 4) aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity such as climbing stairs. Headache attacks are commonly accompanied by nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia.
name: Migraine without aura

desc: Repeated episodes of headache with rapid onset, reaching a peak within minutes and of short duration (less than one hour) with pain that is throbbing, pulsating, or bursting in quality.
name: Recurrent paroxysmal headache

desc: A type of headache characterized by repeated attacks of unilateral pain lasting 15 to 180 minutes and associated with local autonomic signs.
name: Cluster headache

desc: A type of headache that last hours with continuous pain of mild or moderate intensity, bilateral location, a pressing/tightening (non-pulsating) quality and that is not aggravated by routine physical activity such as walking or climbing stairs.
name: Tension-type headache

desc: A distinct type of headache characterized by piercing, throbbing, or electric-shock-like chronic pain in the upper neck, back of the head, and behind the ears, usually on one side.
name: Occipital neuralgia

desc: A headache disorder that occurs exclusively at night, waking the affected individual from sleep.
name: Hypnic headache

desc: Severe head pain with sudden onset, reaching its maximum intensity in less than one minute and lasting from one hour to ten days.
name: Thunderclap headache

desc: Increased susceptibility to fatigue.
name: Easy fatigability

desc: Hyperexcitability of the neuromuscular system related to abnormally low level of calcium in the blood, resulting in carpopedal or generalized spasms.
name: Hypocalcemic tetany

desc: An anomaly of the control or production of movement in the central nervous system.
name: Abnormal central motor function

desc: Continuous involuntary sustained muscle contraction. When an affected muscle is passively stretched, the degree of resistance remains constant regardless of the rate at which the muscle is stretched. This feature helps to distinguish rigidity from muscle spasticity.
name: Rigidity

desc: A type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb (i.e., it gives way in little, repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched).
name: Cogwheel rigidity

desc: Muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement).
name: Extrapyramidal muscular rigidity

desc: A progressive degree of muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement).
name: Progressive extrapyramidal muscular rigidity

desc: A type of rigidity in which the arms are in flexion and adduction and the legs are extended. This signifies a lesion in the cerebral white matter, internal capsules, or thalamus.
name: Decorticate rigidity

desc: A type of rigidity that is manifested by an exaggerated extensor posture of all extremities.
name: Decerebrate rigidity

desc: A neurological condition related to lesions of the basal ganglia leading to typical abnormalities including akinesia (inability to initiate changes in activity and perform volitional movements rapidly and easily), muscular rigidity (continuous contraction of muscles with constant resistance to passive movement), chorea (widespread arrhythmic movements of a forcible, rapid, jerky, and restless nature), athetosis (inability to sustain the muscles of the fingers, toes, or other group of muscles in a fixed position), and akathisia (inability to remain motionless).
name: Abnormality of extrapyramidal motor function

desc: Characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting form degeneration of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, characterized clinically by shaking, rigidity, slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait.
name: Parkinsonism

desc: Parkinsonism is a clinical syndrome that is a feature of a number of different diseases, including Parkinson disease itself, other neurodegenerative diseases such as progressive supranuclear palsy, and as a side-effect of some neuroleptic medications. Some but not all individuals with Parkinsonism show responsiveness to dopaminergic medication defined as a substantial reduction of amelioration of the component signs of Parkinsonism (including mainly tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability) upon administration of dopaminergic medication.
layperson: Parkinsonism with favorable response to dopaminergic medication
name: Parkinsonism with favorable response to dopaminergic medication
synonyms: Parkinsonism with favourable response to dopaminergic medication

desc: Bradykinesia literally means slow movement, and is used clinically to denote a slowness in the execution of movement (in contrast to hypokinesia, which is used to refer to slowness in the initiation of movement).
name: Bradykinesia

desc: An exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus, or a quick movement near the face.
name: Exaggerated startle response

desc: A type of cerebral palsy characterized by slow, involuntary muscle movement and mixed muscle tone.
name: Athetoid cerebral palsy

desc: A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements.
name: Apraxia

desc: Gait apraxia affecting the ability to make walking movements with the legs.
name: Gait apraxia

desc: A type of apraxia that is characterized by difficulty or inability to execute speech movements because of problems with coordination and motor problems, leading to incorrect articulation. An increase of errors with increasing word and phrase length may occur.
name: Speech apraxia

desc: Difficulty in performing the correct execution of limbs movements in absence of motor impairment.
name: Limb apraxia

desc: Inability to perform purposeful (learned) movements with the hand upon command, even though the command is understood and there is a willingness to perform the movement. Hand apraxia includes the inability to grasp, pick up, and hold large and small objects.
name: Hand apraxia

desc: A functional anomaly of the upper motor neuron. The upper motor neurons are neurons of the primary motor cortex which project to the brainstem and spinal chord via the corticonuclear, corticobulbar and corticospinal (pyramidal) tracts. They are involved in control of voluntary movements. Dysfunction leads to weakness, impairment of fine motor movements, spasticity, hyperreflexia and abnormal pyramidal signs.
name: Upper motor neuron dysfunction

desc: A condition in which there is increased muscle tone so that arms or legs, for example, are stiff and difficult to move.
name: Hypertonia

desc: A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.
layperson: Involuntary muscle stiffness, contraction, or spasm
name: Spasticity
synonyms: Involuntary muscle stiffness, contraction, or spasm

desc: Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.
name: Spastic diplegia

desc: Spastic weakness affecting all four limbs.
name: Spastic tetraparesis

desc: Spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone and hyperexcitable tendon reflexes) in the muscles of the lower limbs, hips, and pelvis
name: Lower limb spasticity

desc: Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles.
name: Spastic paraplegia

desc: Spasticity is manifested by increased stretch reflex which is intensified with movement velocity. This results in excessive and inappropriate muscle activation which can contribute to muscle hypertonia. Spastic gait is characterized by manifestations such as muscle hypertonia, stiff knee, and circumduction of the leg.
name: Spastic gait

desc: Spastic hemiparesis is characterized by a dominance of the tonus in the upper limb flexor muscles: the arm is held in an adducted posture and is bent and rotated inwards, the forearm is pronated and the hand and the fingers are flexed. The leg is slightly bent at the hip, the knee cannot be extended fully at the end of the stance phase and the foot is inverted and in a plantar flexed position. Gait is slow, with a wide base and asymmetrical with a shortened weight-bearing phase on the paretic side. During the swing phase, the paretic leg performs a lateral movement (circumduction) which is characteristic of this gait disorder, also termed Wernicke-Mann gait. Spastic gait problems typically worsen on attempts to walk faster.
name: Spastic hemiparetic gait

desc: A type of spastic gait in which the legs are usually slightly bent at the hip and in an adducted position. The knees are extended or slightly bent and the feet are in a plantar flexion position. This posture requires circumduction of the legs during walking. The gait may appear stiff (spastic gait disorder) or stiff as well as insecure (spastic ataxic gait disorder). In spastic paraparetic gait, each leg appears to be dragged forward. If the muscle tone in the adductors is marked, the resulting gait disorder is referred to as scissor gait.
name: Spastic paraparetic gait

desc: A type of spastic paraparetic gait in which the muscle tone in the adductors is marked. It is characterized by hypertonia and flexion in the legs, hips and pelvis accompanied by extreme adduction leading to the knees and thighs hitting, or sometimes even crossing, in a scissors-like movement. The opposing muscles (abductors) become comparatively weak from lack of use.
name: Scissor gait

desc: Spasticity that increases in degree with time.
name: Progressive spasticity

desc: A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality.
name: Spastic dysarthria

desc: Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs.
name: Spastic tetraplegia

desc: Unilateral paresis (weakness) with spasticity of the affected muscles and increased tendon reflexes.
name: Spastic hemiparesis

desc: Clasp-knife phenomonen refers to increased muscle tone while bending or stretching a limb, whereby there is a sudden relaxation (decrease in resistance) as the muscle continues to be streched. This phenomenon has been likened to opening a clasp knife.
name: Clasp-knife sign

layperson: Increased muscle tone of arm or leg
name: Limb hypertonia
synonyms: Increased muscle tone of arm or leg

desc: Increased passive stiffness or tightness of the neck musculature.
name: Neck hypertonia

desc: Functional neurological abnormalities related to dysfunction of the pyramidal tract.
name: Abnormal pyramidal sign

desc: Upturning of the big toe (and sometimes fanning of the other toes) in response to stimulation of the sole of the foot. If the Babinski sign is present it can indicate damage to the corticospinal tract.
name: Babinski sign

desc: A diagnostic reflex elicited by stimulation of the skin over the surface of the lateral malleolus of the foot. The Chaddock refelx is present if there is extension of one or more or all of the toes with or without fanning of them when the external inframalleolar skin is stimulated. The Chaddock sign, similar to the Babinski sign, is taken to be an indication of disease of the spinocortical (pyramidal) tract.
name: Chaddock reflex

desc: Dorsiflexion of the big toe, sometimes accompanied by fanning of the other toes, elicited by stroking along the medial side of the tibia (the normal response would be no movement of the big toe).
name: Oppenheim reflex

desc: Dorsal extension of the big toe, sometimes accompanied by fanning of the other toes, elicited by compressing the calf muscles (a normal response is no movement of the big toe).
name: Gordon reflex

desc: A Hoffman test is performed by flicking the fingernail of the long finger, from dorsal to volar, on each hand while the hand was supported by the examiner's hand. The test was done with the neck in the neutral position and then with the neck maximally forward flexed. Any flexion of the ipsilateral thumb and/or index finger was interpreted as a positive test.
name: Hoffmann sign

desc: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts is related to a lesion in the corticospinal, corticobulbar or brainstem descending (subcorticospinal) neurons.
layperson: Weakness due to upper motor neuron dysfunction
name: Weakness due to upper motor neuron dysfunction
synonyms: Paralysis due to lesions of the principle motor tracts

desc: Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.
layperson: Paralysis or weakness of one side of body
name: Hemiplegia/hemiparesis
synonyms: Paralysis or weakness of one side of body

desc: Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to an incomplete loss of strength.
layperson: Weakness of one side of body
name: Hemiparesis
synonyms: Weakness of one side of body

desc: Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
layperson: Paralysis on one side of body
name: Hemiplegia
synonyms: Paralysis on one side of body

desc: Transient episodes of weakness of the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.
name: Episodic hemiplegia

desc: Weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities. Paraplegia refers to a severe or complete loss of strength, whereas paraparesis refers to a relatively mild loss of strength.
name: Paraplegia/paraparesis

desc: Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs.
name: Paraparesis

desc: Severe or complete weakness of both lower extremities with sparing of the upper extremities.
name: Paraplegia

desc: Loss of strength in all four limbs. Tetraplegia refers to a complete loss of strength, whereas Tetraparesis refers to an incomplete loss of strength.
name: Tetraplegia/tetraparesis

desc: Weakness of all four limbs.
name: Tetraparesis

desc: Paralysis of all four limbs, and trunk of the body below the level of an associated injury to the spinal cord. The etiology of quadriplegia is similar to that of paraplegia except that the lesion is in the cervical spinal cord rather than in the thoracic or lumbar segments of the spinal cord.
name: Tetraplegia

desc: Intermittent episodes of paralysis of all four limbs.
name: Episodic quadriplegia

desc: A sudden and transient episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone, often triggered by emotions.
name: Cataplexy

desc: Paralysis of voluntary muscles means loss of contraction due to interruption of one or more motor pathways from the brain to the muscle fibers. Although the word paralysis is often used interchangeably to mean either complete or partial loss of muscle strength, it is preferable to use paralysis or plegia for complete or severe loss of muscle strength, and paresis for partial or slight loss. Motor paralysis results from deficits of the upper motor neurons (corticospinal, corticobulbar, or subcorticospinal). Motor paralysis is often accompanied by an impairment in the facility of movement.
name: Paralysis

desc: A loss of the ability to move the vocal folds.
name: Vocal cord paralysis

desc: Decreased strength of the vocal folds.
name: Vocal cord paresis
synonyms: Hoarse voice due to vocal cord paresis
Vocal cord paresis in severe cases

desc: Decreased strength of the vocal fold on one side.
name: Unilateral vocal cord paresis

desc: Decreased strength of the vocal fold on both sides.
name: Bilateral vocal cord paresis

desc: A loss of the ability to move the vocal fold on one side.
name: Unilateral vocal cord paralysis
synonyms: Unilateral paralysis of the vocal cord

desc: A loss of the ability to move the vocal fold on both sides.
name: Bilateral vocal cord paralysis

desc: Inability to move the muscles of respiration.
name: Respiratory paralysis

desc: Episodes of muscle weakness.
name: Periodic paralysis

desc: Episodes of muscle weakness associated with elevated levels of potassium in the blood.
name: Periodic hyperkalemic paralysis

desc: Episodes of muscle weakness associated with reduced levels of potassium in the blood.
name: Periodic hypokalemic paresis

desc: The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm.
name: Diaphragmatic paralysis

desc: Reduced muscle tone secondary to an abnormality of the central nervous system.
name: Central hypotonia

desc: Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- oder overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).
name: Ataxia

desc: A type of ataxia characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.
name: Dysmetria

desc: A type of dysmetria involving the limbs.
name: Limb dysmetria

desc: A lack of coordination of leg movement manifested by undershoot or overshoot of the intended position of the leg.
name: Lower limb dysmetria

desc: A lack of coordination of arm movement manifested by undershoot or overshoot of the intended position of the arm.
name: Upper limb dysmetria

desc: A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal walking. Gait ataxia is characteirzed by a wide-based staggering gait with a tendency to fall.
layperson: Inability to coordinate movements when walking
name: Gait ataxia
synonyms: Inability to coordinate movements when walking

desc: A type of gait ataxia displaying progression of clinical severity.
name: Progressive gait ataxia

desc: A severe form of gait ataxia such that an affected person cannot walk at all.
name: Abasia

desc: A kind of ataxia that affects movements of the extremities.
name: Limb ataxia

desc: A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to perform rapidly alternating movements, such as pronating and supinating his or her hand on the dorsum of the other hand as rapidly as possible.
layperson: Difficulty performing quick and alternating movements
name: Dysdiadochokinesis
synonyms: Difficulty performing quick and alternating movements

desc: Truncal ataxia is a sign of ataxia characterized by instability of the trunk. It usually occurs during sitting.
layperson: Instability or lack of coordination of central trunk muscles
name: Truncal ataxia
synonyms: Instability or lack of coordination of central trunk muscles

desc: Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days.
name: Episodic ataxia

desc: The presence of cerebellar signs and symptoms such as lack of balance associated with quadrupedal gait (locomotion on all four extremities with a 'bear-like' gait with the legs held straight).
layperson: Cerebellar ataxia associated with quadrupedal gait
name: Cerebellar ataxia associated with quadrupedal gait

desc: A type of ataxia characterized by the impairment of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed. With dyssynergia, a voluntary movement appears broken down into its component parts.
name: Dyssynergia

desc: A type of dyssynergia affecting eye movements and characterized by the inability to smoothly follow a visual target across the visual field.
name: Ocular dyssynergia

desc: A type of dyssynergy characterized by the lack of the ability to smoothly perform the elements of a voluntary movement in the appropriate order and speed.
name: Asynergia

desc: Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech.
name: Slurred speech

desc: An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of small muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Fine motor skills are required to mediate movements of the wrists, hands, fingers, feet, and toes.
name: Poor fine motor coordination

desc: An abnormality of the ability (skills) to perform a precise movement of large muscles with the intent to perform a specific act. Gross motor skills are required to mediate movements of the arms, legs, and other large body parts.
name: Poor gross motor coordination

desc: Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects.
