name: Clumsiness

desc: The inability to maintain postures or positions (such as keeping eyes closed, protruding the tongue, maintaining conjugate gaze steadily in a fixed direction, or making a prolonged 'ah' sound) without repeated prompts.
name: Motor impersistence

desc: A subset of motor impersistence, defined as the inability to perform more than two of the simple voluntary acts simultaneously, such as closing the eyes and protruding the tongue.
name: Simultanapraxia

desc: Any anomaly of the conduction of motor nerve impulses in the central nervous system.
name: Abnormality of central motor conduction

desc: Cerebral palsy describes a group of permanent disorders of the development of movement and posture, causing activity limitation, that are attributed to nonprogressive disturbances that occurred in the developing fetal or infant brain. The motor disorders of cerebral palsy are often accompanied by disturbances of sensation, perception, cognition, communication, and behaviour, by epilepsy, and by secondary musculoskeletal problems.
name: Cerebral palsy

desc: Cognitive, psychiatric or memory anomaly.
name: Abnormality of higher mental function

desc: Subnormal intellectual functioning which originates during the developmental period. Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, has been defined as an IQ score below 70.
name: Intellectual disability

desc: Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69.
name: Intellectual disability, mild

desc: Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20.
name: Intellectual disability, profound

desc: Moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 35-49.
name: Intellectual disability, moderate

desc: The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time.
name: Intellectual disability, progressive

desc: Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-85.
name: Intellectual disability, borderline

desc: Severe mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 20-34.
name: Intellectual disability, severe

desc: Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed.
name: Dysarthria

desc: Complete lack of development of speech and language abilities.
name: Absent speech

desc: An impairment in the ability to produce voice sounds.
name: Dysphonia

desc: A form of focal dystonia that affects the vocal cords, associated with involuntary contractions of the vocal cords causing interruptions of speech and affecting the voice quality and often leading to patterned, repeated breaks in speech.
name: Laryngeal dystonia

desc: An acquired language impairment of some or all of the abilities to produce or comprehend speech and to read or write.
name: Aphasia

desc: Impairment of expressive language and relative preservation of receptive language abilities. That is, the patient understands language (speech, writing) but cannot express it.
name: Motor aphasia

desc: A defect in the motor ability that enables speech.
name: Anarthria

desc: Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. Nonword repetition (NWR) is a measure of short-term phonological memory.
name: Deficit in nonword repetition

desc: An acquired type of sensory aphasia where damage to the brain leads to the loss of the ability to read.
name: Alexia

desc: A writing disability in the absence of motor or sensory deficits of the upper extremities, resulting in an impairment in the ability to write regardless of the ability to read and not due to intellectual impairment.
name: Dysgraphia

desc: Disruptions in the production of speech sounds, with involuntary repetitions of words or parts of words, prolongations of speech sounds, or complete blockage of speech production for several seconds.
name: Stuttering

desc: An inability to name people and objects that are correctly perceived. The individual is able to describe the object in question, but cannot provide the name.
name: Anomia

desc: Repetition of one's own words or phrases.
name: Palilalia

desc: Extreme rapidity of speech.
name: Tachylalia

desc: Language impairment is a deficit in comprehension or production of language that includes reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure or impairments in written or spoken communication. Language abilities are substantially and quantifiably below age expectations.
name: Language impairment

desc: Reduced ability of lexical discrimination, which refers to the process of distinguishing a stimulus word from other phonologically similar words. Lexical discrimination can be defined as the process of correctly identifying words in the mental lexicon to match the phonological input of a stimulus.
name: Spoken Word Recognition Deficit

desc: A state of disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
name: Lethargy

desc: Repeated episodes of sudden-onset and transient lethargy.
name: Paroxysmal lethargy

desc: Complete absence of wakefulness and content of conscience, which manifests itself as a lack of response to any kind of external stimuli.
name: Coma

layperson: Coma caused by low blood sugar
name: Hypoglycemic coma
synonyms: Coma caused by low blood sugar
Loss of consciousness due to hypoglycemia

desc: Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action.
name: Confusion

desc: A state of sudden and severe confusion.
name: Delirium

desc: Excessive daytime sleepiness.
name: Drowsiness

desc: Attacks of disabling daytime drowsiness and low alertness.
name: Paroxysmal drowsiness

desc: Absence of wakefulness and conscience, but (in contrast to coma) with involuntary opening of the eyes and movements (such as teeth grinding, yawning, or thrashing of the extremities).
name: Vegetative state

desc: A reduction in the ability to maintain sustained attention characterized by reduced alertness.
name: Decreased vigilance

desc: Inability to recognize objects not because of sensory deficit but because of the inability to combine components of sensory impressions into a complete pattern. Thus, agnosia is a neurological condition which results in an inability to know, to name, to identify, and to extract meaning from visual, auditory, or tactile impressions.
name: Agnosia

desc: An inability or difficulty differentiating among the fingers of either hand as well as the hands of others.
name: Finger agnosia

desc: Inability to recognize the form of objects by touch without visual input. That is, an impairment in the recognition of objects based only on the texture, size, weight and three-dimensional form of the object in the absence of any major somatosensory deficit.
name: Astereognosia

desc: Inability to recognize faces of familiar persons.
name: Prosopagnosia

desc: Difficulty in recognizing objects by visual input in absence of sensorial visual impairment.
name: Visual agnosia

desc: Difficulty reaching to visually guided goals in peripheral vision, with the deficit leaves voluntary eye movements largely unaffected.
name: Optic ataxia

desc: Abnormally small sized handwriting defined formally as an impairment of a fine motor skill manifesting mainly as a progressive or stable reduction in amplitude during a writing task.
name: Micrographia

desc: Abnormality in the process of thought including the ability to process information.
name: Cognitive impairment

desc: Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults.
name: Mental deterioration

desc: A loss of global cognitive ability of sufficient amount to interfere with normal social or occupational function. Dementia represents a loss of previously present cognitive abilities, generally in adults, and can affect memory, thinking, language, judgment, and behavior.
name: Dementia

desc: A dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and lack of insight. The hallmark feature of frontotemporal dementia is the presentation with focal syndromes such as progressive language dysfunction, or aphasia, or behavioral changes characteristic of frontal lobe disorders.
name: Frontotemporal dementia

desc: A progressive loss of the ability to remember the meaning of words, faces and objects.
name: Semantic dementia

desc: A particular type of dementia characterized by a pattern of mental defects consisting prominently of forgetfulness, slowness of thought processes, and personality or mood change.
name: Subcortical dementia

desc: Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities.
name: Motor deterioration

desc: Progressive loss of previously present language abilities.
name: Progressive language deterioration

desc: Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities.
name: Psychomotor deterioration

desc: An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness.
name: Memory impairment

desc: A paroxysmal, transient loss of memory function with preservation of immediate recall and remote memory but with a severe impairment of memory for recent events and ability to retain new information.
name: Transient global amnesia

desc: Abnormal slowness of thought processes.
name: Bradyphrenia

desc: An abnormality of sensation related to CNS function. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function may indicate a lesion of a parietal cortex, the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex, or the spinal cord.
name: Abnormal central sensory function

desc: A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart.
name: Impaired two-point discrimination

desc: A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.
name: Impaired touch localization

desc: Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).
name: Agraphesthesia

desc: An abnormal functionality of the hypothalamus.
name: Abnormal hypothalamus physiology

desc: A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in thyrotropin-releasing hormone activity.
name: Hypothalamic hypothyroidism

desc: Decreased secretion of luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone by the hypothalamus.
name: Hypothalamic luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone deficiency

desc: An anomaly in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse. This is a four step process, comprising (i) synthesis and storage of neurotransmitters; (ii) neurotransmitter release; (iii) activation of postsynaptic receptors by the neurotransmitter; and (iv) inactivation of the neurotransmitter. Thus, this term is defined as an anomaly of neurotransmitter metabolic process.
name: Abnormal synaptic transmission

desc: An anomaly in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse in the peripheral nervous system.
layperson: Abnormal peripheral nervous system synaptic transmission
name: Abnormal peripheral nervous system synaptic transmission

desc: Any abnormality of the neuromuscular junction, which is the synapse between the motor end plate of a motor neuron and the skeletal muscle fibers.
layperson: Abnormal synaptic transmission at the neuromuscular junction
name: Abnormal synaptic transmission at the neuromuscular junction

layperson: Generalized hypotonia due to defect at the neuromuscular junction
name: Generalized hypotonia due to defect at the neuromuscular junction
synonyms: Generalised hypotonia due to defect at the neuromuscular junction

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amplitude of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
name: Decreased miniature endplate potentials

desc: An abnormal prolongation of the miniature endplate potentials, i.e. the postsynaptic response to transmitter released from an individual vesicle at the neuromuscular junction.
name: Prolonged miniature endplate currents

desc: A type of weakness that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness
synonyms: Generalized muscle weakness due to defect at the neuromuscular junction
Proximal muscle weakness due to defect at the neuromuscular junction

desc: A type of weakness of the bulbar muscles (muscles of the mouth and throat responsible for speech and swallowing) that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of bulbar muscles

desc: A type of weakness of the muscles involved in chewing that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of chewing muscles

desc: A type of weakness of the muscles involved in speech that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of speech muscles

desc: A type of weakness of the muscles involved in swallowing that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of swallowing muscles

desc: A type of weakness of the muscles involved in breathing (respiration) that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of respiratory muscles

desc: A type of weakness of skeletal muscle that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of skeletal muscles

desc: A type of weakness of a skeletal muscle of distal part of a limb that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
layperson: Fatigable weakness of distal limb muscles
name: Fatigable weakness of distal limb muscles

desc: A type of weakness of a skeletal muscle in the neck that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
name: Fatigable weakness of neck muscles

desc: A type of weakness of a skeletal muscle of proximal part of a limb that occurs after a muscle group is used and lessens if the muscle group has some rest. That is, there is diminution of strength with repetitive muscle actions.
layperson: Fatiguable weakness of proximal limb muscles
name: Fatiguable weakness of proximal limb muscles

desc: Specific drugs interfere selectively with the different cellular mechanisms involved in neuromuscular transmission (synthesis, storage, release, action and inactivation of transmitter). The response of a patient to a specific drug can therefore be useful information for the differential diagnosis.
layperson: Response to drugs acting on neuromuscular transmission
name: Response to drugs acting on neuromuscular transmission

desc: Improvement of muscle strength in response to administration of an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor.
layperson: Favorable response of weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors
name: Favorable response of weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors
synonyms: Favourable response of weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors

desc: Lack of improvement of muscle strength in response to administration of an acetylcholine esterase inhibitor.
layperson: Unfavorable response of muscle weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors
name: Unfavorable response of muscle weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors
synonyms: Unfavourable response of muscle weakness to acetylcholine esterase inhibitors

desc: A deviation from the norm of the intracranial pressure.
name: Abnormality of intracranial pressure

desc: An increase of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Increased intracranial pressure

desc: A reduction of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Decreased intracranial pressure

desc: A functional abnormality of the pineal gland.
name: Abnormality of pineal physiology

desc: An anomaly in the amount or timing of melatonin secretion by the pineal gland. Note that melatonin is also synthesized by multiple tissues outside of the pineal gland.
name: Abnormal pineal melatonin secretion

desc: A deviation from normal of the neurological development of a child, which may include any or all of the aspects of the development of personal, social, gross or fine motor, and cognitive abilities.
name: Neurodevelopmental abnormality

desc: Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence.
name: Specific learning disability

desc: A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic.
name: Dyscalculia

desc: A learning disorder characterized primarily by difficulties in learning to read and spell. Dyslectic children also exhibit a tendency to read words from right to left and to confuse letters such as b and d whose orientation is important for their identification. Children with dyslexia appear to be impaired in phonemic skills (the ability to associate visual symbols with the sounds they represent).
name: Dyslexia

desc: Reduced ability affecting mainly visuospatial cognition which may be tested using pattern construction (for example by Differential Ability Scales, which test a person's strengths and weaknesses across a range of intellectual abilities).
name: Impaired visuospatial constructive cognition

desc: Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.
name: Developmental regression

desc: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills.
name: Developmental stagnation

desc: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy.
layperson: Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
name: Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures

desc: A degree of language development that is significantly below the norm for a child of a specified age.
name: Delayed speech and language development

desc: A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
name: Expressive language delay

desc: A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
name: Severe expressive language delay

desc: A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
name: Moderate expressive language delay

desc: A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.
name: Mild expressive language delay

desc: A delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
name: Receptive language delay

desc: A mild delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
name: Mild receptive language delay

desc: A moderate delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
name: Moderate receptive language delay

desc: A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to understand the speech of others.
name: Severe receptive language delay

desc: A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age.
name: Global developmental delay

desc: A mild delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
name: Mild global developmental delay

desc: A moderate delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
name: Moderate global developmental delay

desc: A severe delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
name: Severe global developmental delay

desc: A profound delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child.
name: Profound global developmental delay

desc: A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills.
name: Motor delay

desc: A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling.
name: Delayed gross motor development

desc: A failure to achieve the ability to stand up at an appropriate developmental stage. Most children begin to walk alone at 11 to 15 months of age. On average, children can stand while holding on at the age of 9 to 10 months, can pull up to stand and walk with one hand being held at 12 months, and can stand alone and walk well at 18 months.
name: Delayed ability to stand

desc: A failure to achieve the ability to sit at an appropriate developmental stage. Most children sit with support at 6 months of age and sit steadily without support at 9 months of age.
name: Delayed ability to sit

desc: A failure to achieve the ability to walk at an appropriate developmental stage. Most children learn to walk in a series of stages, and learn to walk short distances independently between 12 and 15 months.
name: Delayed ability to walk

desc: Delayed ahcievement of the ability to roll front to back and back to front.
name: Delayed ability to roll over

desc: A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the fingers and hands.
name: Delayed fine motor development

desc: The Premie-Neuro and the Dubowitz Neurological Examination score head lag in the same manner. Scoring for both is as follows: 0 = head drops and stays back, 1 = tries to lift head but drops it back, 2 = able to lift head slightly, 3 = lifts head in line with body, and 4 = head in front of body. This term applies if head lag persists beyond an expected age at a level of 0 or 1. Persistent head lag beyond age 4 mo has been linked to poor outcomes.
name: Persistent head lag

desc: A functional abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem.
name: Abnormal cranial nerve physiology

desc: Paralysis of the fourth cranial (trochlear) nerve manifested as weakness of the superior oblique muscle which causes vertical diplopia that is maximal when the affected eye is adducted and directed inferiorly.
name: Fourth cranial nerve palsy

desc: Decreased or absent sensation in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve, which provides tactile, proprioceptive, and nociceptive sensation in the area of the face and mouth.
name: Trigeminal anesthesia

desc: A neuropathic disorder characterized by episodes of intense pain in the face, originating from the trigeminal nerve. One, two, or all three branches of the nerve may be affected.
name: Trigeminal neuralgia

desc: A functional abnormality affecting the lower cranial nerves, which include the paired 9th (glossopharyngeal), 10th (vagal), 11th (accessory) and 12th (hypoglossal) cranial nerves.
name: Lower cranial nerve dysfunction

desc: An electric shock-like sensation that occurs on flexion of the neck. This sensation radiates down the spine, often into the legs, arms, and sometimes to the trunk.
name: Lhermitte's sign

desc: An abnormality of movement with a neurological basis characterized by changes in coordination and speed of voluntary movements.
name: Abnormality of movement

desc: Primitive reflexes traditionally held to be a sign of disorders that affect the frontal lobes.
name: Frontal release signs

desc: Hyperactivity is a state of constantly being unusually or abnormally active, including in situations in which it is not appropriate.
name: Hyperactivity

desc: The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease.
name: Gait disturbance

desc: An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia.
name: Broad-based gait

layperson: Unstable walking, worse in the dark
name: Gait instability, worse in the dark
synonyms: Unstable walking, worse in the dark

desc: Reduced ability to walk (ambulate).
name: Difficulty walking

desc: A type of gait (walking) characterized by by dragging one's feet along or without lifting the feet fully from the ground.
name: Shuffling gait

desc: Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, for instance in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture in that joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients usually have difficulties standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase (in the German language literature this is referred to as Duchenne sign). Similar gait patterns can be caused by orthopedic conditions when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck.
name: Waddling gait

desc: Incapability to ambulate.
name: Inability to walk

layperson: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
name: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
synonyms: Loss of ability to walk in first decade

layperson: Loss of ability to walk in early childhood
name: Loss of ability to walk in early childhood

desc: An abnormal gait pattern that arises from weakness of the pretibial and peroneal muscles due to a lower motor neuron lesion. Affected patients have footdrop and are unable to dorsiflex and evert the foot. The leg is lifted high on walking so that the toes clear the ground, and there may be a slapping noise when the foot strikes the ground again.
name: Steppage gait

desc: An abnormal gait pattern characterized by the failure of the heel to contact the floor at the onset of stance during gait.
name: Tip-toe gait

desc: Reduced ability to walk in a straight line while placing the feet heel to toe.
name: Impaired tandem gait

desc: Freezing of gait is defined as a brief, episodic absence or marked reduction of forward progression of the feet despite the intention to walk.
name: Freezing of gait

desc: Reduced ability to walk (ambulate) in a backwards direction.
name: Difficulty walking backward

desc: Lumbar spinal stenoses may induce symptoms following an individually typical latency on standing or when walking due to swelling of the cauda equina, which leads to compression. This is referred to as neurogenic claudication. The symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis can be explained by an increase in lumbar lordosis and spinal canal stenosis in an upright position compared to the sitting position or if spondylolisthesis is present by a shift of the vertebrae while standing and walking. Following an individually characteristic distance, walking becomes associated with deep muscular pain and with neurological deficits, such as sensory deficits and paresis in the lower limbs, which resolve within minutes when the affected person sits or lies down. Activities performed in a flexed posture, such as cycling often cause less problems than walking. For the same reason, walking uphill may be tolerated better than walking downhill. Clinical neurological examination at rest may be entirely normal but there is usually pain on hyperextension of the lumbar spine.
name: Neurogenic claudication

desc: Cautious gait refers to an excessive degree of age-related changes in walking and fear of falling. The walking difficulties seem out of proportion when considering the patient's actual sensory or motor deficits. The gait appears slow, with a wider base than normal, reduced arm swing bilaterally and a slightly stooped posture. This type of gait change often occurs after the first time a patient has fallen.
name: Cautious gait

desc: Dystonic gait disorders frequently appear bizarre, particularly because activity increases dystonic tonus and posture. The abnormal posture of the foot in dystonic gait typically involves inversion, plantar flexion and tonic extension of the big toe. In many patients complex types of walking, such as walking backwards and running are paradoxically less impaired than walking forward and may seem completely unaffected. Sensory tricks, for instance, if the affected individual rests a hand on his or her neck, may improve or even normalize dystonic gait in some patients.
name: Dystonic gait

desc: An abnormality of gait that can be observed in individuals with dystonic posture in which the individual walks with an extended trunk and flexed arms, while strutting on the toes without the heels touching the floor.
name: Cock-walk gait

desc: An abnormal gait characterized by toe walking, stiff legs, and skipping. The gait pattern has some resemblance to cock-walk gait, but affected individuals are able to improve their dystonic gait by walking backward.
name: Hobby horse gait

desc: To avoid pain weight is put on the affected leg for as short a time as possible, resulting in a limp. The patients appear to be walking as if there were a thorn in the sole of the foot. To reduce the load on the affected leg the patients lift and lower their foot in a fixed ankle position.
name: Antalgic gait

desc: An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.
name: Dystonia

desc: Sustained involuntary muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body.
name: Torsion dystonia

desc: A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes.
name: Paroxysmal dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the limbs.
name: Limb dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the legs.
name: Leg dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the arms.
name: Arm dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia that affects the midline muscles, i.e., the chest, abdominal, and back muscles.
name: Axial dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia that is localized to a specific part of the body.
name: Focal dystonia

desc: A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument.
name: Writer's cramp

desc: A form of focal dystonia affecting the face and especially the jaw that is induced by the act of speaking. It is an involuntary contraction of the masticatory muscles, resulting in dysarthria or dysphagia.
name: Craniofacial dystonia

desc: A kind of focal dystonia characterized by forceful contractions of the face, jaw, and/or tongue causing difficulty in opening and closing the mouth and often affecting chewing and speech.
name: Oromandibular dystonia

layperson: Orofacial action-specific dystonia induced by speech
name: Orofacial action-specific dystonia induced by speech

desc: Involuntary protrusions, movements, spams and contortions of the tongue.
name: Lingual dystonia

desc: A type of dystonia that affects all or most of the body.
name: Generalized dystonia

desc: An acute dystonic reaction with blepharospasm, periorbital twitches, and protracted fixed staring episodes. There may be a maximal upward deviation of the eyes in the sustained fashion. Oculogyric crisis can be triggered by a number of factors including neuroleptic medications.
name: Oculogyric crisis

desc: Hemidystonia refers to dystonia which involves the ipsilateral face, arm, and leg.
name: Hemidystonia

desc: Involuntary movements of one hand that accompany and mirror intentional movements of the opposite hand.
name: Bimanual synkinesia

desc: A tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling; imbalance. The retropulsion test is widely regarded as the gold standard to evaluate postural instability, Use of the retropulsion test includes a rapid balance perturbation in the backward direction, and the number of balance correcting steps (or total absence thereof) is used to rate the degree of postural instability. Healthy subjects correct such perturbations with either one or two large steps, or without taking any steps, hinging rapidly at the hips while swinging the arms forward as a counterweight. In patients with balance impairment, balance correcting steps are often too small, forcing patients to take more than two steps. Taking three or more steps is generally considered to be abnormal, and taking more than five steps is regarded as being clearly abnormal. Markedly affected patients continue to step backward without ever regaining their balance and must be caught by the examiner (this would be called true retropulsion). Even more severely affected patients fail to correct entirely, and fall backward like a pushed toy soldier, without taking any corrective steps.
name: Postural instability

desc: Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily.
name: Akinesia

desc: Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency.
name: Hypokinesia

desc: Myokymia consists of involuntary, fine, continuous, undulating contractions that spread across the affected striated muscle.
name: Myokymia

desc: Involuntary, fine, continuous, undulating contractions of the eyelid.
name: Eyelid myokymia

desc: The presence of spontaneous bursts of rapidly firing potentials that recur at regular intervals of 2-10 per second and are unaffected by voluntary effort. This is an electromyographic (EMG) finding.
name: EMG: myokymic discharges

desc: A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction.
name: Head titubation

desc: Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.
name: Hyperkinetic movements

desc: Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs.
name: Abnormal posturing

desc: Involuntary contractions of muscle leading to involuntary movements of extremities, neck, trunk, or face.
name: Involuntary movements

desc: A stereotypy is a repetitive, simple movement that can be voluntarily suppressed. Stereotypies are typically simple back-and-forth movements such as waving of flapping the hands or arms, and they do not involve complex sequences or movement fragments. Movement is often but not always rhythmic and may involve fingers, wrists, or more proximal portions of the upper extremity. The lower extremity is not typically involved. Stereotypies are more commonly bilateral than unilateral.
name: Stereotypy

desc: Repetitive pressing, poking, and/or rubbing in the eyes.
name: Eye poking

desc: Habitual clasping and squeezing of the hands.
name: Stereotypical hand wringing

desc: Habitual repetitive movement of the body.
name: Stereotypical body rocking

desc: Punding is a stereotypical motor behavior characterized by an intense fascination with repetitive, excessive and non-goal oriented handling, and examining of objects.
name: Punding

desc: A type of stereotypic behavior in which the affected individual repeatedly waves the hands up and down.
name: Recurrent hand flapping

desc: Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements.
name: Myoclonus

desc: Intermittent clonic or tonic contraction of muscles supplied by facial nerve. Muscles are relaxed in between contractions.
layperson: Spasms on one side of the face
name: Hemifacial spasm
synonyms: Spasms on one side of the face

desc: Palatal myoclonus is characterized by myoclonic (rhythmic involuntary jerky) movements of the soft palate.
name: Palatal myoclonus

desc: Spinal myoclonus is generally due to a tumor, infection, injury, or degenerative process of the spinal cord, and is characterized by involuntary rhythmic muscle contractions, usually at a rate of more than one per second. Myoclonus occurs synchronously in several muscles and can be increased in severity and frequency by fatigue or stress, but is usually unaffected by sensory stimuli. Spinal myoclonus ceases during sleep or anesthesia.
name: Spinal myoclonus

desc: Myoclonus that occurs during the initial phases of sleep.
name: Sleep myoclonus

desc: Involuntary and irregular twitches of the chin.
name: Chin myoclonus

desc: Marked, involuntary jerking of the eyelids.
name: Eyelid myoclonus

desc: A type of myoclonus in which the myoclonias shift from body region to another in a random and asynchronous fashion. Erratic myoclonus can affect the face or limbs, are brief, single or repetitive, very frequent and nearly continuous.
name: Erratic myoclonus

desc: Irregular, small-amplitude myoclonic movements of the hands and/or fingers on keeping outstretched posture (jerky postural tremor). Polyminimyoclonus is stimulus-sensitive and accentuated during voluntary movements. A cortical origin can be demonstrated by back-averaging techniques, and somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEPs) are sometimes giant.
name: Polyminimyoclonus

desc: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis.
name: Tremor

desc: A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse.
name: Resting tremor

desc: A type of resting tremor characterized by simultaneous rubbing movements of thumb and index fingers against each other.
name: Pill-rolling tremor

desc: A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement.
name: Action tremor

desc: A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.
name: Postural tremor

desc: A type of tremors that is triggered by holding an arm in a fixed position.
name: Upper limb postural tremor

desc: A wavering, unsteady voice that reflects involuntary and approximately sinusoidal oscillation of motor unit firings of laryngeal muscles. Vocal tremor results in low frequency modulations of voice frequency or amplitude and intermittent voice instability.
name: Vocal tremor

desc: An isometric tremor occurs with muscle contraction against a rigid stationary object (e.g., when making a fist).
name: Isometric tremor

desc: Tremor that occurs during any voluntary movement. It may include visually or non-visually guided movements. Tremor during target directed movement is called intention tremor.
name: Kinetic tremor

desc: A type of kinetic tremor that occurs during target directed movement is called intention tremor. That is, an oscillatory cerebellar ataxia that tends to be absent when the limbs are inactive and during the first part of voluntary movement but worsening as the movement continues and greater precision is required (e.g., in touching a target such as the patient's nose or a physician's finger).
name: Intention tremor

desc: Nodding movement of the head or body.
name: Titubation

desc: Tremor of the trunk in an anterior-posterior plane at 3-4 Hz.
name: Truncal titubation

desc: Tremor classified by the affected body part.
name: Tremor by anatomical site

desc: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement.
name: Head tremor

desc: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the hand.
name: Hand tremor

desc: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the tongue.
name: Tongue tremor

desc: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the lip.
name: Lip tremor

desc: Rubral tremor is characterized by a slow coarse tremor at rest that is exacerbated by postural adjustments and by guided voluntary movements.
name: Rubral tremor

desc: Chorea (Greek for 'dance') refers to widespread arrhythmic involuntary movements of a forcible, jerky and restless fashion. It is a random-appearing sequence of one or more discrete involuntary movements or movement fragments. Movements appear random because of variability in timing, duration or location. Each movement may have a distinct start and end. However, movements may be strung together and thus may appear to flow randomly from one muscle group to another. Chorea can involve the trunk, neck, face, tongue, and extremities.
name: Chorea

desc: Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).
name: Choreoathetosis

desc: Episodes of choreoathetosis that can occur following triggers such as quick voluntary movements.
name: Paroxysmal choreoathetosis

desc: A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch.
name: Clonus
synonyms: Involuntary rhythmic muscular contractions and relaxations

desc: Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Ankle clonus is tested by rapidly flexing the foot upward.
name: Ankle clonus

desc: Clonus is an involuntary tendon reflex that causes repeated flexion and extension of the foot. Knee clonus can be tested by rapidly pushing the patella towards the toes.
name: Knee clonus

desc: Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.
name: Elbow clonus

desc: A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.
layperson: Involuntary writhing movements in fingers, hands, toes, and feet
name: Athetosis
synonyms: Involuntary writhing movements in fingers, hands, toes, and feet

desc: Fasciculations are observed as small, local, involuntary muscle contractions (twitching) visible under the skin. Fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron). This leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units.
name: Fasciculations

desc: Fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle and the musculature of the face.
name: Facial-lingual fasciculations

desc: Fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle and the musculature of the chin.
name: Labiomental fasciculations

desc: Fasciculations affecting the musculature of the arms and legs.
name: Limb fasciculations

desc: Episodic bouts of involuntary movements with dystonic, choreic, ballistic movements, or a combination thereof. There is no loss of consciousness during the attacks.
name: Paroxysmal dyskinesia

desc: A contraction of ipsilateral facial muscles subsequent to percussion over the facial nerve.
name: Chvostek sign

desc: Alien limb phenomenon refers to involuntary motor activity of a limb in conjunction with the feeling of estrangement from that limb.
name: Alien limb phenomenon

desc: Repeated, individually recognizable, intermittent movements or movement fragments that are almost always briefly suppresable and are usually associated with awareness of an urge to perform the movement.
name: Tics

desc: Movement-based tics affecting discrete muscle groups.
name: Motor tics

desc: Involuntary sounds produced by moving air through the nose, mouth, or throat. The vocal cords are not involved in all tics that produce sound.
name: Phonic tics

desc: Hemiballismus is a rare movement disorder that is caused primarily by damage to various areas in the basal ganglia. Hemiballismus is usually characterized by involuntary flinging motions of the extremities. The movements are often violent and have wide amplitudes of motion. They are continuous and random and can involve proximal and/or distal muscles on one side of the body, while some cases even include the facial muscles. The more a patient is active, the more the movements increase. With relaxation comes a decrease in movements.
name: Hemiballismus

desc: Fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers with little or no movement of the muscle as a whole. If a motor neuron or its axon is destroyed, the muscle fibers it innervates undergo denervation atrophy. This leads to hypersensitivity of individual muscle fibers to acetyl choline so that they may contract spontaneously. Isolated activity of individual muscle fibers is generally so fine it cannot be seen through the intact skin, although it can be recorded as a short-duration spike in the EMG.
name: Muscle fibrillation

desc: A clinical sign indicating a lapse of posture and is usually manifest by a bilateral flapping tremor at the wrist, metacarpophalangeal, and hip joints.
name: Asterixis

desc: A postural abnormality characterized by the inability to stand without external support despite having sufficient muscle strength.
name: Astasia

desc: A habitual positioning of the body with the head and upper back bent forward.
name: Stooped posture

desc: Any anomaly of a reflex, i.e., of an automatic response mediated by the nervous system (a reflex does not need the intervention of conscious thought to occur).
name: Abnormal reflex

desc: Diminution of tendon reflexes, which is an invariable sign of peripheral nerve disease.
name: Reduced tendon reflexes
synonyms: Hypoactive to absent deep tendon reflexes
Absent or decreased deep tendon reflexes
Weak or absent deep tendon reflexes
Decreased to absent deep tendon reflexes
Diminished or absent deep tendon reflexes

desc: Reduction of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
name: Hyporeflexia

desc: Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.
name: Hyporeflexia of lower limbs

desc: Decreased intensity of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
name: Decreased Achilles reflex

desc: Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).
name: Decreased patellar reflex

desc: Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the upper limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.
name: Hyporeflexia of upper limbs

desc: Absence of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.
name: Areflexia

desc: Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.
name: Areflexia of lower limbs

desc: Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella.
name: Absent patellar reflexes

desc: Absence of the Achilles reflex (also known as the ankle jerk reflex), which can normally be elicited by tapping the tendon is tapped while the foot is dorsiflexed.
name: Absent Achilles reflex

desc: Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the upper limbs.
name: Areflexia of upper limbs

desc: Areflexia that is limited to one side of the body.
name: Hemiareflexia

desc: Hyperreflexia is the presence of hyperactive stretch reflexes of the muscles.
name: Hyperreflexia

desc: Tendon reflexes that are noticeably more active than usual (conventionally denoted 3+ on clinical examination). Brisk reflexes may or may not indicate a neurological lesion. They are distinguished from hyperreflexia by the fact that hyerreflexia is characterized by hyperactive repeating (clonic) reflexes, which are considered to be always abnormal.
name: Brisk reflexes
Lower limb hyperreflexia
synonyms: Increased deep tendon reflexes in the lower limbs

desc: The primitive reflexes are a group of behavioural motor responses which are found in normal early development, are subsequently inhibited, but may be released from inhibition by cerebral, usually frontal, damage. They are thus part of a broader group of reflexes which reflect release phenomena, such as exaggerated stretch reflexes and extensor plantars. They do however involve more complex motor responses than such simple stretch reflexes, and are often a normal feature in the neonate or infant.
name: Primitive reflex

desc: A type of primitive reflex characterized by an involuntary contraction of the mentalis muscle of the chin caused by stimulation of the thenar eminence of the palm.
name: Palmomental reflex

desc: A type of primitive reflex that can be elicated when the hand of the examiner is gently inserted into the palm of the patient's hand. The palmar surface is stroked or simply touched. The flexor surfaces of the fingers may be stimulated also by the examiner's fingers. The stimulus should be in a distal direction. With a positive response, the patient grasps the examiner's hand with variable strength and continues to grasp as the examiner's hand is moved. Ability to release the grip voluntarily depends on the activity of the reflex; some patients can do so readily, while others can even be lifted off the bed, since the grasp has such power [NCBI Books:NBK395].
name: Grasp reflex

desc: A type of primitive reflex that is elicited by repetitive tapping on the forehead. Normal subjects usually blink in response to the first several taps, but if blinking persists, the response is abnormal and considered to be a sign of frontal release. Persistent blinking is also known as Myerson's sign.
name: Glabellar reflex

desc: A type of primitive reflex that is elicited by tapping the upper lip lightly. The contraction of the muscles causes the mouth to resemble a snout.
name: Snout reflex

desc: A type of primitive reflex that is elicited by lightly touching or tapping on the lips with an object such as a tongue blade, reflex hammer, or the examiner's finger. At times the reflex is obtained merely by approaching the lips with an object. A positive suck reflex consists of sucking movements by the lips when they are stroked or touched.
name: Suck reflex

desc: Persistence beyond the normal age (roughly the first half of the first year of life) of the asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR), which is an easily elicited primitive reflex in the immediate newborn period. The ATNR refers to the phenomenon whereby when the face of an infant is turned to one side, the ipsilateral arm and leg extend and the contralateral arm and leg flex. This posture has been compared to a typical posture of fencers.
name: Persistent asymmetrical tonic neck reflex
synonyms: Tonic neck reflex asymmetrical and persistent

desc: An anomaly of a reflex that is elicited as a motor response to scraping of the skin. They are generally graded as present or absent. They differ from tendon reflexes in that the sensory signal must ascend the spinal cord to reach the brain and then descend the spinal cord to reach the motor neurons.
name: Abnormal superficial reflex

desc: Lack of contraction of abdominal muscles in the quadrant of the abdomen that is stimulated by scraping the skin tangential to or toward the umbilicus.
name: Absent abdominal reflex

desc: Lack of response to scratching of the skin of the medial thigh, which in males normally elicits a brisk, short elevation of the ipsilateral testis, a phenomenon that is referred to as the cremaster reflex.
name: Absent cremaster reflex

desc: A movement disorder which consists of effects including diminished voluntary movements and the presence of involuntary movements.
name: Dyskinesia

desc: An anomaly of metabolism or structure of the brain identified by imaging.
name: Brain imaging abnormality

desc: A functional brain anomaly detectable by positron emission tomography (PET). PET scanning is a method for functional brain imaging, and its measurements reflect the amount of brain activity in the various regions of the brain.
name: Abnormal brain positron emission tomography

desc: An anomaly detectable in [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography (PET) brain scans. Glucose uptake measured with FDG-PET is a marker of neuronal metabolic activity.
layperson: Abnormal brain FDG positron emission tomography
name: Abnormal brain FDG positron emission tomography

desc: Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the prefrontal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
name: Prefrontal hypometabolism in FDG PET

desc: Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the thalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
name: Thalamic hypometabolism in FDG PET

desc: Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the hypothalamus as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
name: Hypothalamic hypometabolism in FDG PET

desc: Reduced uptake of [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) in the parietal cortex as measured by positron emission tomography (PET) brain scan.
name: Parietal hypometabolism in FDG PET

desc: An anomaly of metabolism in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Abnormal metabolic brain imaging by MRS
name: Abnormal metabolic brain imaging by MRS

desc: A deviation from normal in the ratio of choline to creatine in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Abnormal brain choline/creatine ratio by MRS
name: Abnormal brain choline/creatine ratio by MRS

desc: A deviation from normal of the level of lactate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Abnormal brain lactate level by MRS
name: Abnormal brain lactate level by MRS
synonyms: Abnormal lactate level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: An increase in the level of lactate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Elevated brain lactate level by MRS
name: Elevated brain lactate level by MRS

desc: A decrease in the level of lactate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain lactate level by MRS
name: Reduced brain lactate level by MRS
synonyms: Reduced brain lactate level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: A deviation from normal in the level of choline-containing compounds in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Abnormal brain choline level by MRS
name: Abnormal brain choline level by MRS
synonyms: Abnormal brain choline level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: An increase in the level of choline-containing compounds in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Elevated brain choline level by MRS
name: Elevated brain choline level by MRS

desc: An decrease in the level of choline-containing compounds in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain choline level by MRS
name: Reduced brain choline level by MRS
synonyms: Reduced brain choline level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

layperson: Abnormal brain creatine level by MRS
name: Abnormal brain creatine level by MRS
synonyms: Abnormal brain creatine level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: An increase in the level of creatine in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Elevated brain creatine level by MRS
name: Elevated brain creatine level by MRS
synonyms: Elevated brain creatine level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: A decrease in the level of creatine in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain creatine level by MRS
name: Reduced brain creatine level by MRS
synonyms: Reduced brain creatine level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: A deviation from normal in the level of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Abnormal brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
name: Abnormal brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
synonyms: Abnormal brain N-acetyl aspartate level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: A decrease in the level of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
name: Reduced brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
synonyms: Reduced brain N-acetyl aspartate level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: An increase in the level of N-acetyl aspartate in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Elevated brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
name: Elevated brain N-acetyl aspartate level by MRS
synonyms: Elevated brain N-acetyl aspartate level by magnetic resonance spectroscopy

desc: An elevated level of myoinositol in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: High myoinositol in brain by MRS
name: High myoinositol in brain by MRS
synonyms: High myo-inositol in brain by MRS

desc: An decrease in the level of glutamine in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain glutamine level by MRS
name: Reduced brain glutamine level by MRS

desc: An decrease in the level of glutamate (Glu) in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain glutamate level by MRS
name: Reduced brain glutamate level by MRS

desc: An decreased level of gamma-aminobutyric acid in the brain identified by magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS).
layperson: Reduced brain gamma-aminobutyric acid level by MRS
name: Reduced brain gamma-aminobutyric acid level by MRS

desc: A structural anomaly of the nervous system.
name: Abnormal nervous system morphology

desc: A structural abnormality of the peripheral nervous system, which is composed of the nerves that lead to or branch off from the central nervous system. This includes the cranial nerves (olfactory and optic nerves are technically part of the central nervous system).
name: Abnormal peripheral nervous system morphology

desc: Progressive deterioration of peripheral axons.
name: Peripheral axonal degeneration

desc: A pattern of simultaneous degeneration and regeneration of axons (see comment).
name: Axonal degeneration/regeneration

desc: Atrophic changes of axons of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Peripheral axonal atrophy

desc: A reduction in the number of axons in the peripheral nervous system.
name: Axonal loss

desc: The presence of axonal regeneration following a previous axonal lesion.
name: Axonal regeneration

desc: Groups of small caliber axons in peripheral nerve biospies indicative of axonal regeneration.
name: Clusters of axonal regeneration

desc: An abnormality characterized by disruption of the normal functioning of peripheral axons.
name: Peripheral axonal neuropathy

desc: An axonal neuropathy of peripheral sensory nerves.
name: Sensory axonal neuropathy

desc: Progressive impairment of function of motor axons with muscle weakness, atrophy, and cramps. The deficits are length-dependent, meaning that muscles innervated by the longest nerves are affected first, so that for instance the arms are affected at a later age than the onset of deficits involving the lower leg.
name: Motor axonal neuropathy

desc: An abnormality characterized by chronic impairment of the normal functioning of the axons.
name: Chronic axonal neuropathy

desc: Structural abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem.
name: Abnormal cranial nerve morphology

desc: Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve, the eighth cranial nerve, which is involved in transmitting sound and equilibrium information from the inner ear to the brain.
name: Abnormality of the vestibulocochlear nerve
synonyms: Abnormality of the VIIIth cranial nerve
Abnormality of the eighth cranial nerve

desc: Any structural abormality of the fifth cranial nerve.
name: Abnormal fifth cranial nerve morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the fifth cranial nerve

desc: A structural abnormality of an infra-orbital nerve. The infraorbital nerve arises from the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve and normally traverses the orbital floor in the infraorbital canal.
name: Abnormality of infra-orbital nerve

desc: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve.
layperson: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve
name: Abnormality of the eleventh cranial nerve

desc: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve sometimes also referred to as the facial nerve.
layperson: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve
name: Abnormality of the seventh cranial nerve

desc: An abnormality of the abducens nerve.
layperson: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve
name: Abnormality of the sixth cranial nerve

desc: Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward.
name: Abducens palsy

desc: Any structural anomaly of the glossopharyngeal nerve, the ninth paired cranial nerve (CN IX).
name: Abnormal glossopharyngeal nerve morphology

desc: An abnormality of an inferior alveolar nerve.
name: Abnormality of inferior alveolar nerve

desc: Any structural anomaly of the lower motor neuron.
name: Abnormal lower motor neuron morphology

desc: An abnormality of the myelination of motor and sensory peripheral nerves. These are axons for motor nerves and dendrites for sensory nerves in the strict anatomic sense.
name: Abnormal peripheral myelination

desc: A loss of myelinated nerve fibers in the peripheral nervous system (in general, this finding can be observed on nerve biopsy).
layperson: Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
name: Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
synonyms: Decreased number of peripheral myelinated nerve fibres
Decreased number of large and small myelinated fibers

desc: A reduced number of large myelinated nerve fibers.
layperson: Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
name: Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
synonyms: Loss of larger myelinated nerve fibers
Decreased number of large peripheral myelinated nerve fibres

layperson: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
name: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibers
synonyms: Decreased number of small peripheral myelinated nerve fibres

desc: Repeated episodes of segmental demyelination and remyelination lead to the accumulation of supernumerary Schwann cells around axons, which is referred to as onion bulb formation. This finding affects peripheral nerves.
name: Onion bulb formation

desc: A type of onion bulb formation prominently affecting the area of the basal lamina.
name: Basal lamina onion bulb formation
synonyms: Basal lamina 'onion bulb' formations on nerve biopsy

desc: Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths. Dysmyelination is distinguished from demyleination where there is destruction or damage of previously normal myelination.
name: Peripheral dysmyelination

desc: Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the peripheral nervous system.
name: Peripheral hypomyelination

desc: A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Peripheral demyelination

desc: A segmental pattern of demyelination and regeneration (remyelination) affecting peripheral nerves.
name: Segmental peripheral demyelination/remyelination

desc: A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Diffuse peripheral demyelination

desc: A loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers from segments of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Segmental peripheral demyelination

desc: A symmetric loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Symmetric peripheral demyelination

desc: A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Symmetrical progressive peripheral demyelination

desc: Loss of myelin from peripheral nerves in a pattern that differs between right and left.
name: Asymmetric peripheral demyelination

desc: Delayed myelination in the peripheral nervous system.
name: Delayed peripheral myelination

desc: Congenital absence of the myelin sheath on a nerve.
name: Peripheral amyelination

desc: Increased amount of peripheral myelination.
name: Peripheral hypermyelination

desc: The presence of excessive redundant myelin in the peripheral nerve sheath.
name: Myelin outfoldings
synonyms: Excessive focal folding of myelin sheaths

desc: Presence of irregular redundant loops of focally folded myelin in a peripheral nerve.
name: Irregular myelin loops

desc: Elevated thickness of the myelin sheath of peripheral nerves, in a regular and concentric fashion.
name: Increased peripheral myelin thickness

desc: The presence of multiple sausage-shaped swellings of the myelin sheath (The Latin tomaculum means sausage).
name: Myelin tomacula

desc: A reduction in the size of nerve terminals.
name: Decreased size of nerve terminals

desc: Any anomaly of the anterior horn cell.
name: Abnormal anterior horn cell morphology
synonyms: Anomaly of the anterior horn cells
Abnormality of the anterior horn cell
Abnormality of the anterior horn cells

name: Degeneration of anterior horn cells
synonyms: Degeneration of alpha-motor neurons in anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
Spinal cord anterior horn cell degeneration
Degeneration of spinal cord anterior horn cells
Progressive loss of anterior horn cells
Loss of spinal cord anterior horn cells

desc: Peripheral neuropathy is a general term for any disorder of the peripheral nervous system. The main clinical features used to classify peripheral neuropathy are distribution, type (mainly demyelinating versus mainly axonal), duration, and course.
name: Peripheral neuropathy

desc: Peripheral neuropathy affecting the sensory nerves.
layperson: Damage to nerves that sense feeling
name: Sensory neuropathy
synonyms: Damage to nerves that sense feeling

desc: Abnormal sensations such as tingling, pricking, or numbness of the skin with no apparent physical cause.
name: Paresthesia

desc: Abnormal sensations with no apparent physical cause that are painful or unpleasant.
name: Dysesthesia

desc: A type of paresthesia (tingling, pins-and-needles, burning or numbness or stiffness) that occurs in the hands and feet and particularly in the fingers and toes.
name: Acroparesthesia

layperson: Distal sensory impairment of all modalities
name: Distal sensory impairment of all modalities
synonyms: Distal sensory loss to all modalities

layperson: Distal sensory loss of all modalities
name: Distal sensory loss of all modalities

desc: Peripheral sensory neuropathy affecting primarily distal sensation.
name: Distal peripheral sensory neuropathy

desc: A generalized disorder of peripheral nerves.
name: Polyneuropathy

desc: An abnormality of the primary sensation that is mediated by peripheral nerves (pain, temperature, touch, vibration, joint position). The word hypoesthesia (or hypesthesia) refers to a reduction in cutaneous sensation to a specific type of testing.
name: Sensory impairment

desc: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to bony prominences such as the malleoli at the ankles or the metacarpal-phalangeal joints. There is a slow decay of vibration from the tuning fork. The degree of vibratory sense loss can be crudely estimated by counting the number of seconds that the examiner can perceive the vibration longer than the patient.
name: Impaired vibratory sensation

desc: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the legs.
layperson: Decreased vibratory sense in lower limbs
name: Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
synonyms: Decreased vibratory sense in the lower extremities
Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
Distal vibratory impairment of the lower limbs
Decreased vibratory sense in the lower limbs
Decreased vibratory sense in lower limbs
Diminished vibratory sensation in the legs
Distal sensory loss, especially vibratory sense

desc: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles.
name: Impaired vibration sensation at ankles

desc: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the distal portions of the limbs.
name: Impaired distal vibration sensation

desc: A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration.
name: Abolished vibration sense

desc: An abnormal reduction in sensation in the distal portions of the extremities.
name: Distal sensory impairment
synonyms: Distal sensory impairment in lower limbs
Distal sensory impairment of the lower extremities
Distal sensory loss, upper and lower limbs

desc: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints.
name: Impaired distal proprioception

desc: A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
name: Impaired distal tactile sensation

desc: A reduced ability to discriminate between different temperatures.
name: Impaired temperature sensation

desc: A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation). This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
name: Impaired tactile sensation

desc: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position.
name: Impaired proprioception

desc: The patient stands with the feet placed together and balance and is asked to close his or her eyes. A loss of balance upon eye closure is a positive Romberg sign and is interpreted as indicating a deficit in proprioception.
name: Positive Romberg sign

desc: Incoordination of movement caused by a deficit in the sensory nervous system. Sensory ataxia can be distinguished from cerebellar ataxia by asking the patient to close his or her eyes. Persons with cerebellar ataxia show only a minimal worsening of symptoms, whereas persons with sensory ataxia show a marked worsening of symptoms.
name: Sensory ataxia

desc: Pain is an unpleasant sensation that can range from mild, localized discomfort to agony, whereby the physical part of pain results from nerve stimulation and is often accompanied by an emotional component. This term groups abnormalities in pain sensation presumed to result from abnormalities related to the specific nerve fibers that carry the pain impulses to the brain.
name: Abnormality of pain sensation

desc: An increased tendency to fractures following trauma, with fractures occurring without pain.
name: Painless fractures due to injury

desc: Reduced ability to perceive painful stimuli.
name: Impaired pain sensation

desc: Inability to perceive painful stimuli.
name: Pain insensitivity

desc: Spontaneous pain is a kind of neuropathic pain which occurs without an identifiable trigger.
name: Spontaneous pain sensation

desc: Trophic changes is a term used to describe abnormalities in the area of pain that include primarily wasting away of the skin, tissues, or muscle, thinning of the bones, and changes in how the hair or nails grow, including thickening or thinning of hair or brittle nails.
name: Trophic changes related to pain

desc: Trophic changes occurring in a limb.
name: Trophic limb changes

desc: Abnormally increased sensitivity to pain.
name: Hyperalgesia

desc: A pattern of sensory loss with selective loss of touch sensation and proprioception without loss of pain and temperature, or vice-versa.
name: Dissociated sensory loss

layperson: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs
name: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs

desc: Demyelinating neuropathy is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocities with reduced amplitudes of sensory/motor nerve conduction and prolonged distal latencies.
name: Demyelinating peripheral neuropathy

desc: Acute progressive areflexic weakness and mild sensory changes resulting from myelin breakdown and axonal degeneration.
name: Acute demyelinating polyneuropathy

desc: Demyelination of peripheral motor nerves.
name: Demyelinating motor neuropathy

desc: Demyelination of peripheral sensory nerves.
name: Demyelinating sensory neuropathy

layperson: Nerve damage causing decreased feeling and movement
name: Sensorimotor neuropathy
synonyms: Nerve damage causing decreased feeling and movement

desc: A focal lesion of a single peripheral nerve. Damage to a sensory nerve is accompanied by sensory impairment of all modalities in the affected anatomic distribution.
name: Mononeuropathy

desc: Malfunction of a peripheral nerve resulting from mechanical compression of the nerve roots from internal or external causes and leading to a conduction block or axonal loss.
name: Entrapment neuropathy

desc: Injury to the median nerve caused by its entrapment at the wrist as it traverses through the carpal tunnel. Clinically, constrictive median neuropathy is characterized by pain, paresthesia, and weakness in the median nerve distribution of the hand.
name: Constrictive median neuropathy

desc: An entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel (in the elbow) characterized by numbness in the ring and little fingers and weakness of the intrinsic muscles in the hand.
layperson: Entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at elbow
name: Entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at elbow

desc: An entrapment neuropathy of the suprascapular nerve, presenting with shoulder weakness confined to the supraspinatus muscle (this muscle initiates shoulder abduction) or to the infraspinatus (this muscle externally rotates the arm), as well as with pain in the posterior part of the shoulder and upper periscapular region.
name: Entrapment neuropathy of suprascapular nerve

desc: A type of peripheral neuropathy that happens when there is damage to two or more different nerve areas characterized by peripheral neuropathy of both the motor and sensory nerves of at least two different nerve trunks. Different nerves are affected either simultaneously or sequentially.
name: Multiple mononeuropathy

desc: A nerve fascicle or fasciculus is a small bundle of axons, enclosed by the perineurium. A minifascule refers to a group of thinly myelinated and unmyelinated axons surrounded by a delicate perineurium, and with a smaller diameter than a normal nerve fascicle.
name: Minifascicle formation

desc: Inflammation of a nerve.
name: Neuritis

desc: Simulataneous inflammation of multiple nerves.
name: Polyneuritis

desc: Increase in size of a peripheral nerve. This finding can be appreciated by palpation along the axis of the nerve.
name: Enlarged peripheral nerve

desc: Wasting of the sural nerve, a sensory nerve in the calf region of the leg.
name: Sural nerve atrophy

desc: The presence of amyloid deposition in the nerves of the peripheral nervous system.
name: Amyloidosis of peripheral nerves

desc: Any structural anomaly of a great auricular nerve.
name: Abnormal great auricular nerve morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly of a lingual nerve.
name: Abnormal lingual nerve morphology

desc: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve.
layperson: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve
name: Abnormality of the twelfth cranial nerve

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) of the peripheral nervous system.
layperson: Tumor of the peripheral nervous system
name: Neoplasm of the peripheral nervous system
synonyms: Tumor of the peripheral nervous system

desc: The presence of multiple cutaneous neurofibromas.
name: Neurofibromas

desc: Neurofibromas present in a smaller number than usually seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.
name: Occasional neurofibromas

desc: A neurofibroma in which Schwann cells proliferate inside the nerve sheath, producing an irregularly thickened, distorted, tortuous structure.
name: Plexiform neurofibroma

desc: Neurofibromas originating in the spine.
name: Spinal neurofibromas

desc: Multiple neurofibromas of the spinal nerve roots with a symmetric distribution.
name: Symmetric spinal nerve root neurofibromas
synonyms: Spinal nerve root neurofibromas, symmetric, multiple

desc: The presence of Neurofibromas in the subcutis.
name: Subcutaneous neurofibromas

desc: A tumor made up of nerve cells and nerve fibers.
name: Neuroma

desc: Multiple painful, dome-shaped, translucent pink to skin-colored papules on oral mucosa. Histologically, the lesions may demonstrate dermal proliferation of well-demarcated nerve bundles associated with abundant mucin and surrounded by a distinct perineural sheath.
name: Multiple mucosal neuromas

desc: A tumor that arises from an element of the autonomic nervous system.
