layperson: Neuroplasm of the autonomic nervous system
name: Neuroplasm of the autonomic nervous system

desc: A benign neoplasm that usually arises from the sympathetic trunk in the mediastinum, representing a tumor of the sympathetic nerve fibers arising from neural crest cells.
name: Ganglioneuroma

desc: A gangioleneuroma originating from sympathetic ganglion cells in the abdomen.
name: Presacral ganglioneuroma

desc: A benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells.
name: Schwannoma

desc: The presence of a peripheral schwannoma.
name: Peripheral Schwannoma

desc: A tumor that originates from a neuroendocrine cell.
name: Neuroendocrine neoplasm

desc: Pheochromocytomas (also known as chromaffin tumors) produce, store, and secrete catecholamines. Pheochromocytomas usually originate from the adrenal medulla but may also develop from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia. A common symptom of pheochromocytoma is hypertension owing to release of catecholamines.
name: Pheochromocytoma

desc: Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia.
name: Extraadrenal pheochromocytoma

desc: Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla.
name: Adrenal pheochromocytoma

desc: A carotid body tumor (also called paraganglionoma or chemodectoma) is a tumor found in the upper neck at the branching of the carotid artery. They arise from the chemoreceptor organ (paraganglion) located in the adventitia of the carotid artery bifurcation.
name: Paraganglioma

desc: A tumor that develops in the retrostyloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, arising from an island of paraganglion tissue derived from the neural crest that is located on the vagus nerve.
name: Vagal paraganglioma

desc: A paraganglioma (a neuroendocrine neoplasm) originating in a carotid artery.
name: Carotid paraganglioma

desc: A usually benign neoplasm originating in the chemoreceptor tissue of the carotid body, glomus jugulare, glomus tympanicum, aortic bodies, or the female genital tract.
name: Chemodectoma

desc: A rare paranglioma of the lung, tumors that arise from extra-adrenal chromaffin cells.
name: Pulmonary paraglioma

desc: A neuroendocrine tumor originating in a hormone-producing cell (islet cell) of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic endocrine tumor

desc: The presence of an adenoma of the pancreas with origin in a pancreatic B cell.
name: Pancreatic islet cell adenoma

desc: The presence of multiple pancreatic islet cell adenomas.
name: Multiple pancreatic beta-cell adenomas

desc: A type of tumor of the pancreatic beta cells that secretes excess insulin and can result in hypoglycemia.
name: Insulinoma

desc: An endocrine tumor of the pancreas that secretes excessive amounts of glucagon.
name: Glucagonoma

desc: A tumor formed from the endocrine (argentaffin) cells of the mucosal lining of a variety of organs including the stomach and intestine. These cells are from neuroectodermal origin.
name: Carcinoid tumor

desc: A malignant neuroendocrine tumor of the lung. According to histopathologic criteria (WHO 2004), carcinoids are divided into four groups i.e. typical and atypical carcinoids, large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma and small cell lung carcinoma.
name: Pulmonary carcinoid tumor

desc: A structural abnormality of the central nervous system.
name: Morphological central nervous system abnormality
synonyms: Abnormality of the central nervous system
Morphological abnormality of the central nervous system

desc: Any structural abnormality of the pyramidal tract, whose chief element, the corticospinal tract, is the only direct connection between the brain and the spinal cord. In addition to the corticospinal tract, the pyramidal system includes the corticobulbar, corticomesencephalic, and corticopontine tracts.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the pyramidal tract
name: Morphological abnormality of the pyramidal tract

desc: Abnormality of the corticospinal tract, which is the chief element of the pyramidal system (the principle motor tract) and is the only direct connection between the cerebrum and the spinal cord.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the corticospinal tract
name: Morphological abnormality of the corticospinal tract

desc: Deterioration of the tissues of the lateral corticospinal tracts.
layperson: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
name: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts

desc: An abnormality of the spinal cord (myelon).
name: Abnormality of the spinal cord

desc: External mechanical compression of the spinal cord.
name: Spinal cord compression

desc: Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness.
name: Cervical cord compression

desc: Myelocystocele is characterized by a large, ependyma-lined, cystic dilation of the caudal end of the central canal of the spinal cord; it projects dorsally through a lamina defect, with overlying varying amounts of lipomatous subcutaneous tissue. Myelocystoceles are associated with a tethered cord and meningocele, which communicates with the spinal subarachnoid space, but not with the central canal cyst.
name: Myelocystocele

desc: An abnormality of the spinocerebellar tracts, a set of axonal fibers originating in the spinal cord and terminating in the ipsilateral cerebellum. The spinocerebellar tract convey information to the cerebellum about limb and joint position (proprioception). They comprise the ventral spinocerebellar tract, the anterior spinocerebellar tract, and the posterior spinocerebellar tract.
name: Abnormality of the spinocerebellar tracts

layperson: Spinocerebellar tract disease in lower limbs
name: Spinocerebellar tract disease in lower limbs
Atrophy/Degeneration involving the spinal cord
synonyms: Atrophic and degenerative changes in the spinal cord

desc: Atrophy of the cervical segment of the spinal cord.
name: Cervical spinal cord atrophy

layperson: Spinal cord posterior columns myelin loss
name: Spinal cord posterior columns myelin loss

desc: A heterogeneous group of congenital spinal anomalies that result from defective closure of the neural tube early in fetal life.
name: Spinal dysraphism
synonyms: Incomplete closure of the vertebral arch

desc: Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.
name: Spina bifida

desc: Protrusion of the meninges through a defect of the vertebral column.
name: Meningocele

desc: A herniation of meninges through a congenital bone defect in the skull in the occipital region.
name: Occipital meningocele

desc: Protrusion of the meninges and portions of the spinal cord through a defect of the vertebral column.
name: Myelomeningocele

desc: A type of spinal dysraphism presenting as a subcutaneous fatty mass, that is, a spinal defect associated with lipomatous tissue, and covered by skin. The most usual location for lipomyelomeningocele is at the gluteal cleft.
name: Lipomyelomeningocele

desc: The severe form of a neural tube defect where the open neural tube appears as a flattened, plate-like mass of nervous tissue with no overlying membrane.
name: Myeloschisis

desc: A form of closed neural tube defect in which the spinal tissue lies within the spinal cord having a junction between the spinal cord and the lipoma. Intact skin covers the defect. Neurologic findings first appear during the second year of life.
name: Lipomeningocele

desc: A herniation of meninges through a congenital bone defect in the skull at the junction of the frontal and ethmoidal bones.
name: Frontoethmoidal meningocele

desc: A herniation of meninges through a congenital bone defect in the skull in the parietal region.
name: Parietal meningocele

desc: Protrusion of the arachnoid and dura through spinal foramina.
name: Lateral spinal meningocele

desc: The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of a vertebral body with intact overlying skin.
name: Spina bifida occulta

desc: The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of the vertebra L5 with intact overlying skin.
name: Spina bifida occulta at L5

desc: The closed form of spina bifida with incomplete closure of S1 with intact overlying skin.
name: Spina bifida occulta at S1

desc: A neoplasm affecting the spinal cord.
name: Spinal cord tumor

desc: A hemangioblastoma of the spinal cord.
name: Spinal hemangioblastoma

desc: Any abnormality of the spinal meninges, the system of membranes (dura mater, the arachnoid mater, and the pia mater) which envelops the spinal cord.
name: Abnormal spinal meningeal morphology

desc: An abnormality of the spinal dura mater, which is the outermost of the three layers of the meninges surrounding the spinal cord.
name: Abnormal spinal dura mater morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the spinal dura mater

desc: Presence of arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal extradurally in the epidural space.
name: Spinalarachnoid cyst
synonyms: Epidural arachnoid cysts of the spinal canal

desc: An outpouching of the spinal meninges.
name: Spinal meningeal diverticulum

desc: This sign is created by a nonenhancing thrombus in the dural sinus surrounded by triangular enhancing dura as seen on cross-section. The sign, seen on contrast-enhanced CT scan images, suggests dural sinovenous thrombosis. It is best seen on wider window settings. It is a reliable sign of sinus thrombosis but is seen only in 25-30% of these cases.
name: Empty delta sign

desc: This sign represents thickening and enhancement of the dura mater in continuity with a mass, which on MR images, gives the appearance of a tail arising from the mass. The dural tail is thought to represent reactive change; however, it may also be due to tumor invasion. Three criteria need to be met for a positive dural tail sign: the tail should be seen on two successive images through the tumor, it should taper away from the tumor, and it must enhance more than the tumor.
name: Dural tail sign

desc: A widening or ballooning of the dural sac surrounding the spinal cord usually at the lumbosacral level.
name: Dural ectasia

desc: An abnormality of the dorsal columns, i.e., of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. The dorsal column consists of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus and itself is part of the dorsal funiculus.
layperson: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord
name: Abnormality of the dorsal column of the spinal cord

layperson: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord
name: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord

desc: Inflammation of the spinal cord.
name: Myelitis

desc: Fissure within the spinal cord of the neck.
name: Cervicomedullary schisis

desc: Any structural anomaly of the conus terminalis, which is the distal bulbous part of the spinal cord at the location where the spinal cord tapers and ends (usually between the L1 and L2 lumbar vertebrae).
name: Abnormal conus terminalis morphology

desc: During normal embryological development, the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of L1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column. The filum terminale is a slender, threadlike structure that remains after the normal regression of the distal embryonic spinal cord and attaches the spinal cord to the coccyx. A tethered cord results if there is a thickened rope-like filum terminale which anchors the cord at the level of L2 or below, potentially causing neurologic signs owing to abnormal tension on the spinal cord.
name: Tethered cord

desc: A region of high intensity (brightness) observed upon magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of the spinal cord.
layperson: Hyperintensity of MRI T2 signal of the spinal cord
name: Hyperintensity of MRI T2 signal of the spinal cord

desc: Dilated, glial-lined cavity in spinal cord. This cavity does not communicate with the central canal, and usually is between the dorsal columns unilaterally or bilaterally along the side of the cord.
name: Syringomyelia

desc: Duplication of the spinal cord.
name: Diplomyelia

desc: Coexistence of two hemicords, at variable levels, causing splaying of the posterior vertebral elements. Results in neurological deficits in lower limb or perineum.
name: Diastomatomyelia

desc: Triplication of the spinal cord - extremely rare.
name: Triplomyelia

desc: Dilation of central canal from incomplete fusion of the posterior columns or persistence of the primitive large canal of the embryo.
name: Hydromyelia

desc: Congenital absence of the spinal cord.
name: Amyelia

desc: An abnormality resulting from an anomaly of neuronal migration, i.e., of the process by which neurons travel from their origin to their final position in the brain.
name: Abnormality of neuronal migration

desc: Heterotopia or neuronal heterotopia are macroscopic clusters of misplaced neurons (gray matter), most often situated along the ventricular walls or within the subcortical white matter.
name: Gray matter heterotopia

desc: A form of gray matter heterotopia were the mislocalized gray matter is typically located periventricularly, also sometimes called subependymal heterotopia. Periventricular means beside the ventricles. This is by far the most common location for heterotopia. Subependymal heterotopia present in a wide array of variations. There can be a small single node or a large number of nodes, can exist on either or both sides of the brain at any point along the higher ventricle margins, can be small or large, single or multiple, and can form a small node or a large wavy or curved mass.
name: Periventricular heterotopia

desc: Nodules of heterotopia along the ventricular walls. There can be a single nodule or a large number of nodules, they can exist on either or both sides of the brain at any point along the higher ventricle margins, they can be small or large, single or multiple.
name: Periventricular nodular heterotopia

desc: A large mass of heterotopia in a laminar configuration along the ventricular walls. Usually bilateral.
name: Periventricular laminar heterotopia

desc: Heterotopia that forms a continuous wavy line along the ventricular wall.
name: Periventricular ribbonlike heterotopia

desc: A form of heterotopia were the mislocalized gray matter is located deep within the white matter.
name: Subcortical heterotopia

desc: Solid nodular heterotopia situated in the region of the peritrigonal optic pathway posterior to the deep gray nuclei.
layperson: Nodular subcortical heterotopia in peritrigonal regions
name: Nodular subcortical heterotopia in peritrigonal regions

desc: Subcortical heterotopia consisting of a bilateral and symmetric single continuous, undulating ribbon-like layer of gray matter located in the frontal, parietal and occipital lobes. It has no visible connection to the overlying cortex.
name: Diffuse ribbon-like subcortical heterotopia

desc: Subcortical heterotopia extending along the mesial aspect of the lateral ventricles, with direct connection to mesial polymicrogyria-like cortex at the anterior and posterior limits of the heterotopia.
name: Mesial parasagittal subcortical heterotopia

desc: Large subcortical heterotopia of variable morphology wiht streaks and swirls. These always connect to the overlying cortex in at least one, but usually in multiple, locations. Spaces with the signal intensity of CSF are usually seen within the heterotopia.
name: Curvilinear subcortical heterotopia

desc: Linear heterotopia spanning from the cerebral mantle from the pia to the ependyma.
name: Transmantle columnar heterotopia

desc: A form of subcortical heterotopia with mislocalized gray matter within the white matter.It is defined as longitudinal bands of gray matter located deep to the cerebral cortex and separated from it by a thin layer of normal appearing white matter. It is part of the lissencephaly spectrum.
name: Subcortical band heterotopia

desc: Longitudinal bands of gray matter located deep to the cerebral cortex and separated from it by a thin layer of normal appearing white matter visible along the occipital cortex.
name: Posterior predominant subcortical band heterotopia

desc: Longitudinal bands of gray matter located deep to the cerebral cortex and separated from it by a thin layer of normal appearing white matter visible in the frontal and temporal lobes.
name: Anterior predominant subcortical band heterotopia

desc: Longitudinal bands of gray matter located deep to the cerebral cortex and separated from it by a thin layer of normal appearing white matter visible along the whole brain.
name: Diffuse subcortical band heterotopia

desc: An abnormality of the gyri (i.e., the ridges) of the cerebral cortex of the brain.
name: Abnormal cortical gyration

desc: A spectrum of malformations of cortical development caused by insufficient neuronal migration that subsumes the terms agyria, pachygyria and subcortical band heterotopia. See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.
layperson: Fewer or absent grooves in brain
name: Lissencephaly
synonyms: Fewer or absent grooves in brain

desc: Pachygyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormally wide gyri with sulci 1,5-3 cm apart and abnormally thick cortex measuring more than 5 mm (radiological definition). See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.
layperson: Fewer and broader ridges in brain
name: Pachygyria
synonyms: Fewer and broader ridges in brain

desc: Pachygyria with a very thick cerebral cortex measuring 10-20 mm. Note that cortical thickness cannot be measured reliably on scans done between 3 and 24 months of age.
name: Thick pachygyria
synonyms: Pachygyria with cortical thickness above 10 mm

desc: Pachygyria with cortical thickness above 10 mm with and a posterior predominant severety gradient. The severety gradient is determined based on the gyral width, with gyri typically wider than 5mm over the more severely affected regions. Posterior predominant gradient indicates pachygyria more severe other the occipital lobes but also includes a rare perisylvian-predominant pachygyria and a temporal predominant pachygyria.
name: Posterior predominant thick cortex pachygyria
synonyms: Pachygyria with cortical thickness over 10 mm posterior predominant

desc: Pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm and a perisylvian predominant severity gradient. The severity gradient is determined based on the gyral width, with gyri typically wider than 5mm over the more severely affected regions. Perisylvian predominant gradient indicates pachygyria more severe other the occipital lobes but also includes a rare perisylvian-predominant pachygyria and a temporal predominant pachygyria.
name: Perisylvian predominant thick cortex pachygyria
synonyms: Pachygyria with cortical thickness > 10 mm perisylvian predominant

desc: Pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm and an anterior predominant severity gradient. The severety gradient is determined based on the gyral width, with gyri typically wider than 5mm over the more severely affected regions. Anterior predominant gradient indicates pachygyria more severe over the frontal and temporal lobes.
name: Anterior predominant thick cortex pachygyria
synonyms: Pachygyria with cortical thickness > 10 mm anterior predominant

desc: Pachygyria with a mildly thickend cerebral cortex measuring 5-10 mm. Note that cortical thickness cannot be measured reliably on scans done between 3 and 24 months of age.
name: Pachygyria with 5-10 mm cortical thickness

desc: Pachygyria with cortical thickness between 5 and 10 mm with and a posterior predominant severety gradient. The severety gradient is determined based on the gyral width, with gyri typically over 5mm over the more severely affected regions. Posterior predominant gradient indicates pachygyria more severe other the occipital lobes but also includes a rare perisylvian-predominant pachygyria and a temporal predominant pachygyria.
layperson: Anterior predominant pachygyria with 5-10 mm cortical thickness
name: Anterior predominant pachygyria with 5-10 mm cortical thickness

desc: A form of lissencephaly in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development. At neuropathological examination, a 4-layered cortex consists of an upper molecular layer, a second thin cellular layer containing pyramidal neurons usually observed in layer V, a third pale poorly cellular layer and a fourth thick deep layer made up of neurons which had failed to migrate. Radiologocally would manifest as agyria or pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm.
name: 4-layered lissencephaly

desc: A congenital absence of the convolutions of the cerebral cortex and a poorly formed sylvian fissure that affects a particular part of the cortex.
name: Focal lissencephaly

desc: A form of lissencephaly characterized by an uneven cortical surface with a so called 'cobblestone' appearace. There are no distinguishable cortical layers.
name: Type II lissencephaly

desc: A congenital abnormality of the cerebral hemisphere characterized by lack of gyrations (convolutions) of the cerebral cortex. Agyria is defined as cortical regions lacking gyration with sulci great than 3 cm apart and cerebral cortex thicker than 5 mm.
name: Agyria

desc: A type of lissencephaly whereby upon neuropathological examination the cortical plate is severely disorganized with a festooned-like pattern and with neither lamination nor clear demarcation between white and grey matter.
name: Unlayered lissencephaly

desc: Pachygyria-agyria spectrum whereby at neuropathological examination the cortical plate consists of a two-three layered organization made up of a molecular layer, a relatively thin wavy layer with a higher cellular density and a third layer with lower cellularity.
name: 2-3-layered lissencephaly

desc: Severe microcephaly and lissencephaly with granular surfaces with immature cortical plate, reduced in thickness, with focal polymicrogyria and immature small neurons with rare processes, intermingled with a considerable number of glial elements.
name: Microlissencephaly

desc: Polymicrogyria is a congenital malformation of the cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal cortical layering (lamination) and an excessive number of small gyri (folds).
name: Polymicrogyria

desc: A type of polymicrogyria with a gradient of severity (anterior more severe than posterior) extending from frontal poles posteriorly to precentral gyrus and inferiorly to frontal operculum.
name: Frontal polymicrogyria

desc: Excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of one side of the brain.
name: Unilateral polymicrogyria

desc: An excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of the brain in the frontoparietal region.
name: Frontoparietal polymicrogyria

desc: Polymicrogyria (an excessive number of small gyri or convolutions) that is maximal in perisylvian regions (the regions that surround the Sylvian fissures), which may be symmetric or asymmetric and may extend beyond perisylvian regions. The Sylvian fissures often extend posteriorly and superiorly.
name: Perisylvian polymicrogyria

desc: A type of perisylvian polymicrogyria that largely affects one side of the brain.
name: Unilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria

desc: A type of perisylvian polymicrogyria that affects both sides of the brain.
name: Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria

desc: Symmetric generalized polymicrogyria with no obvious gradient or region of maximal severity; may have abnormal high signal in white matter.
name: Bilateral generalized polymicrogyria

desc: Polymicrogyria in parasagittal and mesial aspects of parieto-occipital cortex.
name: Parasagittal parieto-occipital polymicrogyria

desc: Polymicrogyria affecting one or multiple small areas of the cerebral cortex.
name: Focal polymicrogyria

desc: Increased size of cerebral gyri, often associated with a moderate reduction in the number of sulci of the cerebrum.
name: Macrogyria

desc: An abnormality of the cerebral cortex with fewer gyri but with normal cortical thickness. This pattern is usually often associated with congenital microcephaly.
name: Simplified gyral pattern

desc: An abnormal gyral pattern characterized by abnormalities of sulcal depth or orientation.
name: Dysgyria

desc: An abnormal gyral pattern characterized by abnormalities of sulcal depth or orientation but with a normal thickness of the cortex.
name: Dysgyria with normal cortical thickness

desc: An abnormal gyral pattern characterized by abnormalities of sulcal depth or orientation and a thickened cortex intermediate between pachygyria and polymicrogyria.
name: Dysgyria with thickened cortex

desc: A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads.
layperson: Late-onset form of familial Alzheimer disease
name: Alzheimer disease
synonyms: Late-onset form of familial Alzheimer disease

desc: An abnormality of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormality of the cerebrospinal fluid

desc: Hydrocephalus is an active distension of the ventricular system of the brain resulting from inadequate passage of CSF from its point of production within the cerebral ventricles to its point of absorption into the systemic circulation.
layperson: Too much cerebrospinal fluid in the brain
name: Hydrocephalus
synonyms: Too much cerebrospinal fluid in the brain

desc: A form of hydrocephalus in which there is no visible obstruction to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.
name: Communicating hydrocephalus

desc: A form of hydrocephalus characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure upon lumbar puncture.
name: Normal pressure hydrocephalus

desc: A form of hydrocephalus in which the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the cerebral ventricular system or in the outlets of the CSF to the arachnoid space is obstructed.
name: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus

desc: An increased white blood cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: CSF pleocytosis

desc: An increased polymorphonuclear cell count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: CSF polymorphonuclear pleocytosis

desc: An increased lymphocyte count in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: CSF lymphocytic pleiocytosis

desc: Chronic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) lymphocytosis is defined as the finding, in at least two serial CSF examinations, of more than 5 cells per cubic millimeter.
name: Chronic CSF lymphocytosis

desc: An increased amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the subarachnoid space.
name: Extra-axial cerebrospinal fluid accumulation

desc: Any deviation from the normal range of concentration of a metabolite in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal CSF metabolite level

desc: Decreased concentration of homovanillic acid (HVA) in the cerebrospinal fluid. HVA is a metabolite of dopamine.
name: Decreased CSF homovanillic acid

desc: Increased concentration of interferon alpha in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Increased CSF interferon alpha

desc: A reduced concentration of 5-methyltetrahydrofolate(2-) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). 5-methyltetrahydrofolate is the active folate metabolite.
name: Decreased CSF 5-methyltetrahydrofolate concentration

desc: Abnormal concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormal CSF dopamine level

desc: Increased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Elevated CSF dopamine level

desc: Decreased concentration of dopamine in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Reduced CSF dopamine level

desc: CSF 5-HIAA (5-hydroxyindolacetic acid) level is below the lower limit of normal.
name: Decreased CSF 5-hydroxyindolacetic acid

desc: Abnormal concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal CSF lactate level

desc: Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Increased CSF lactate

desc: Decreased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Reduced CSF lactate

desc: A deviation from normal concentration of glucose content in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal CSF glucose level

desc: Abnormally low glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Low glucose levels in cerebral spinal fluid
name: Hypoglycorrhachia
synonyms: Low glucose levels in cerebral spinal fluid

desc: Abnormally high glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Hyperglycorrhachia

desc: Abnormal concentration of neopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormal CSF neopterin level

desc: Increased concentration of neopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Elevated CSF neopterin level

desc: Decreased concentration of neopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Decreased CSF neopterin level

desc: Abnormal concentration of biopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormal CSF biopterin level

desc: Increased concentration of biopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Elevated CSF biopterin level

desc: Decreased concentration of biopterin in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Decreased CSF biopterin level

desc: A decrease in the level of erythritol in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Decreased level of erythritol in CSF
name: Decreased level of erythritol in CSF
synonyms: Decreased level of erythritol in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: An increase in the level of D-threitol in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Increased level of D-threitol in CSF
name: Increased level of D-threitol in CSF
synonyms: Increased level of D-threitol in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: Abnormal concentration of urate in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormal CSF urate concentration

desc: Increased concentration of urate in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Increased CSF urate concentration

desc: Any deviation from the normal range of a protein concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal CSF protein level

desc: Increased concentration of protein in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Increased CSF protein

desc: CSF total protein level is below the lower limit of normal.
name: Decreased CSF protein

desc: Abnormal concentration of amyloid in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Abnormal CSF amyloid level

desc: Reduced concentration of amyloid in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Decreased CSF amyloid level

desc: Increased concentration of amyloid in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Elevated CSF amyloid level

desc: Increased concentration of glial fibrillary acidic protein in cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Elevated CSF glial fibrillary acidic protein level
name: Elevated CSF glial fibrillary acidic protein level

desc: Increased concentration of chitinase-3-like protein 1 in cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Elevated CSF chitinase-3-like protein 1 level

desc: Increased concentration of chitotriosidase 1 in cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Elevated CSF chitotriosidase 1 level

desc: Definition: Neurofilament light chain (NfL) is a neuronal cytoplasmic protein highly expressed in large calibre myelinated axons. Its levels increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and blood proportionally to the degree of axonal damage in a variety of neurological disorders, including inflammatory, neurodegenerative, traumatic and cerebrovascular diseases.
name: Elevated CSF neurofilamant light chain

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of albumin in the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal CSF albumin concentration
synonyms: Abnormal albumin levels in cerebrospinal fluid

name: Decreased CSF albumin concentration
synonyms: CSF albumin level is below the lower limit of normal.

name: Increased CSF albumin concentration
synonyms: High albumin levels in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: A deviation from the normal range of the ratio of the albumin concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to the concentration in serum (which may be defined as 3.2-9.0). This is an index of blood-brain barrier (BBB) integrity, adjusted for the serum albumin concentration, and an increased ratio is taken as a sign of a loss of integrity of the BBB with leakage of albumin into the CSF.
name: Abnormal CSF/serum albumin ratio

desc: An increase above normal limits of the ratio of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) albumin concentration to serum albumin concentration.
name: Increased CSF/serum albumin ratio

desc: A reduction below normal limits of the ratio of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) albumin concentration to serum albumin concentration.
name: Decreased CSF/serum albumin ratio

desc: Drainage of cerebrospinal fluid through the nose. This can occur when there is a fistula between the dura and the skull base and discharge of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the nose.
name: Cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhoea

desc: An abnormal form or size of neutrophils in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Abnormality of neutrophil morphology in CSF
name: Abnormality of neutrophil morphology in CSF
synonyms: Abnormality of neutrophil morphology in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: An abnormality of the nucleus of neutrophils, which presents as either a type I nuclear cleft, where the nuclear cleft may show a transition into a round/oval shape. The second type nuclear cleft, which runs perpendicular to the nuclear surface, and this type of cleft might be related to nuclear lobe formation.
name: Neutrophil nuclear clefts

desc: Hyposegmented (hypolobulated) or bilobed neutrophil nuclei in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
name: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
synonyms: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: An excessive division of the lobes of the nucleus of a neutrophil in the cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
name: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in CSF
synonyms: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in cerebrospinal fluid

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of tissue in the central nervous system.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the central nervous system

desc: Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size.
name: Global brain atrophy

desc: Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the pons.
name: Hypoplasia of the ventral pons

desc: Underdevelopment of the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar hypoplasia

desc: Hypoplasia of the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.
name: Olivopontocerebellar hypoplasia

desc: Lack of development of the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar agenesis

desc: Underdevelopment of the brainstem.
name: Hypoplasia of the brainstem

desc: A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue.
name: Hydranencephaly

desc: Underdevelopment of the cerebrum.
name: Cerebral hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the frontal lobe of the cerebrum.
name: Hypoplasia of the frontal lobes

desc: Underdevelopment of the operculum.
name: Open operculum

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the corpus callosum
synonyms: Complete or partial absence of the corpus callosum
Hypoplasia or absence of the corpus callosum

desc: Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.
name: Agenesis of corpus callosum

desc: A partial failure of the development of the corpus callosum.
layperson: Partial agenesis of the corpus callosum
name: Partial agenesis of the corpus callosum
synonyms: Partial or complete agenesis of corpus callosum
Partial to complete agenesis of corpus callosum
Partial or complete agenesis of the corpus callosum

desc: Underdevelopment of the corpus callosum.
layperson: Underdevelopment of part of brain called corpus callosum
name: Hypoplasia of the corpus callosum
synonyms: Underdevelopment of part of brain called corpus callosum

desc: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebrum, also known as the telencephalon, the largest and most highly developed part of the human brain.
name: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the cerebrum

desc: Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the cerebrum.
name: Cerebral atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum.
layperson: Decrease in size of the outer layer of the brain due to loss of brain cells
name: Cerebral cortical atrophy
synonyms: Decrease in size of the outer layer of the brain due to loss of brain cells

desc: Atrophy of the frontal cortex.
name: Frontal cortical atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the temporal cortex.
name: Temporal cortical atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the parietal cortex.
name: Parietal cortical atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the occipital cortex.
name: Occipital cortical atrophy

desc: Atrophy of one side of the brain, characterized by findings including thinning of the cerebral cortex, reduced volume of the cerebral white matter with abnormal myelination, and enlargement of the ispilateral fourth ventricle.
name: Cerebral cortical hemiatrophy

desc: Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum.
name: Diffuse cerebral atrophy

desc: Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the frontotemporal cerebrum.
name: Frontotemporal cerebral atrophy

desc: Generalized atrophy or hypoplasia of the cerebrum.
name: Generalized cerebral atrophy/hypoplasia

desc: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the corpus callosum.
name: Corpus callosum atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the cerebral subcortical white and gray matter, termed subcortical atrophy, reflects loss of nerve cells in the basal ganglia or fibers in the deep white matter.
name: Subcortical cerebral atrophy

desc: Neurodegeneration involving the globus pallidus,a part of the basal ganglia that is involved in the regulation of voluntary movement.
name: Pallidal degeneration

desc: Underdevelopment of the pons.
name: Hypoplasia of the pons

desc: Failure to develop of the pineal gland, defined clinically as the absence of the pineal gland with no indication of the pineal gland even having been present.
name: Agenesis of pineal gland

desc: Underdevelopment of the olfactory bulb.
name: Hypoplasia of the olfactory bulb

layperson: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system
name: Atrophy/Degeneration affecting the central nervous system

desc: Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue.
name: Neurodegeneration

desc: Electron-dense granules within double membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles.
name: Granulovacuolar degeneration
Neuronal loss in central nervous system

desc: Wasting involving the motor neuron.
name: Motor neuron atrophy

desc: Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes. This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
name: Increased cerebral lipofuscin

desc: Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the neuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
name: Increased neuronal autofluorescent lipopigment

desc: Lipofuscin, a generic term applied to autofluorescent lipopigment, is a mixture of protein and lipid that accumulates in most aging cells, particularly those involved in high lipid turnover (e.g., the adrenal medulla) or phagocytosis of other cell types (e g., the retinal pigment epithelium or RPE; macrophage). This term pertains if there is an increase in the extraneuronal accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.
name: Increased extraneuronal autofluorescent lipopigment

desc: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of brain tissue that was once present.
name: Brain atrophy

desc: Senile plaques are extracellular deposits of amyloid in the gray matter of the brain.
name: Senile plaques

desc: Deposition of large, diffuse cotton wool amyloid plaques (CWPs) lacking a dense core and associated neuritic changes.
name: Cotton wool plaques

desc: An abnormality of the Meninges, including any abnormality of the Dura mater, the Arachnoid mater, and the Pia mater.
name: Abnormal meningeal morphology

desc: An abnormality of the Dura mater.
name: Abnormal dura mater morphology

desc: An abnormality of the Falx cerebri.
name: Abnormality of the falx cerebri

desc: The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri.
name: Calcification of falx cerebri

desc: A developmental defect characterized by aplasia of the Falx cerebri.
name: Aplasia of the falx cerebri

desc: Contrast material enhancement of the pia mater or enhancement that extends into the subarachnoid spaces of the sulci and cisterns is leptomeningeal enhancement. Leptomeningeal enhancement is usually associated with meningitis, which may be bacterial, viral, or fungal. The primary mechanism of this enhancement is breakdown of the blood-brain barrier without angiogenesis.
name: Leptomeningeal enhancement

desc: A spontaneous cerebrospinal fluid leak (SCSFL) is a spontaneous and unexplained leak of the cerebrospinal fluid from the dura surrounding either the brain (cranial leak) or spine (spinal leak).
name: Spontaneous cerebrospinal fluid leak

desc: Calcium deposition affecting the Meninges.
name: Meningeal calcification

desc: An abnormality of the Arachnoid mater.
name: Abnormal arachnoid mater morphology

desc: An extra-parenchymal and intra-arachnoidal collection of fluid with a composition similar to that of cerebrospinal fluid.
layperson: Fluid-filled sac located in membrane surrounding brain or spinal cord
name: Arachnoid cyst
synonyms: Fluid-filled sac located in membrane surrounding brain or spinal cord

desc: An arachnoid cyst located at the margin of the cerebellum and pons.
name: Cerebellopontine angle arachnoid cyst

desc: An arachnoid cyst located within the ventricular system.
name: Intraventricular arachnoid cyst

desc: An arachnoid cyst that progressively enlarges from an abnormality in the membrane of Liliequist or in the interpeduncular cistern, and typically, expands from the prepontine space, displacing the floor of the third ventricle upwards, the pituitary stalk and optic chiasm upwards and forwards, and the mammillary bodies upwards and backwards.
name: Suprasellar arachnoid cyst

desc: An abnormality of the pia mater.
name: Abnormal pia mater

desc: An abnormality of myelination of nerves in the central nervous system.
name: Abnormal CNS myelination

desc: Delayed myelination in the central nervous system.
name: Delayed CNS myelination
synonyms: Delay in central nervous system myelination

desc: Leukodystrophy refers to deterioration of white matter of the brain resulting from degeneration of myelin sheaths in the CNS. Their basic defect is directly related to the synthesis and maintenance of myelin membranes.
name: Leukodystrophy
synonyms: Degeneration of white matter of brain

desc: Reduced amount of myelin in the central nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis.
name: CNS hypomyelination

desc: Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the white matter of the central nervous system.
name: Cerebral hypomyelination

desc: Defective structure and function of myelin sheaths of the white matter of the brain.
name: Cerebral dysmyelination

desc: A loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
name: CNS demyelination

desc: Patchy loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
layperson: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter
name: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter

desc: A diffuse loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
layperson: Diffuse demyelination of the cerebral white matter
name: Diffuse demyelination of the cerebral white matter

desc: A severe loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
layperson: Severe demyelination of the white matter
name: Severe demyelination of the white matter

desc: Increased amount of myelin in the central nervous system.
name: CNS hypermyelination

desc: A type of infection of the central nervous system that can be regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection.
name: Unusual CNS infection

desc: Inflammation of the meninges.
name: Meningitis

desc: Meningitis that persists for more than 4 weeks, and lymphocytes are present in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
name: Chronic lymphocytic meningitis

desc: An infection of the meninges caused by a fungus. Generally, only individuals with deficiencies of the immune system contract fungal meningitis.
name: Fungal meningitis

desc: A type of fungal meningitis caused by an encapsulated yeast that belongs to the genus Cryptococcus. Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii are responsible for the majority of cases of human cryptococcosis.
name: Cryptococcal meningitis

desc: A type of fungal meningitis caused by dissemination of coccidioides to basilar meninges.
name: Coccidioidal meningitis

desc: An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis.
name: Recurrent meningitis

desc: An increased susceptibility to bacterial meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of bacterial meningitis.
name: Recurrent bacterial meningitis

desc: Infection of the brain parenchyma with herpes simplex virus, resulting in inflammation of the brain parenchyma with neurologic dysfunction.
name: Herpes encephalitis

desc: A collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain.
name: Brain abscess

desc: A structural abnormality of the brain, which has as its parts the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain.
name: Abnormality of brain morphology

desc: Damage to cerebral nuclei caused in infants by highly increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin. The basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei could be shown to have a yellow staining historically in infants who died of kernicterus, that is, kernicterus is strictly speaking a pathological diagnosis. The presence of kernicterus may be inferred in infants with characteristic acute or chronic bilirubin-induced neurological dysfunction.
name: Kernicterus

desc: Holoprosencephaly is a structural anomaly of the brain in which the developing forebrain fails to divide into two separate hemispheres and ventricles.
name: Holoprosencephaly

desc: A type of holoprosencephaly in which the left and right frontal and parietal lobes are fused and the interhemispheric fissure is only present posteriorly.
name: Semilobar holoprosencephaly

desc: A type of holoprosencephaly in which most of the right and left cerebral hemispheres and lateral ventricles are separated but the most rostral aspect of the telencephalon, the frontal lobes, are fused, especially ventrally.
name: Lobar holoprosencephaly

desc: A type of holoprosencephaly characterized by the presence of a single ventricle and no separation of the cerebral hemisphere. The single midline ventricle is often greatly enlarged.
name: Alobar holoprosencephaly

desc: Ethmocephaly is the rarest form of holoprosencephaly, which occurs due to an incomplete cleavage of the forebrain. Clinically, the disease presents with a proboscis, hypotelorism, microphthalmos and malformed ears.
name: Ethmocephaly

desc: Abnormality of the cerebral ventricles.
name: Abnormality of the cerebral ventricles

desc: An increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain.
name: Ventriculomegaly

desc: An abnormal dilatation of the fourth cerebral ventricle.
name: Dilated fourth ventricle

desc: Increase in size of the cisterna magna, one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata.
name: Enlarged cisterna magna

desc: An increase in size of the third ventricle.
name: Dilated third ventricle

desc: A kind of ventriculomegaly occurring in the fetal period and usually diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound. Cerebral ventriculomegaly is defined by atrial measurements 10 mm or more. Mild ventriculomegaly (MVM) is defined as measurements between 10 and 15 mm. Measurements are obtained from an axial plane at the level of the thalamic nuclei just below the standard image to measure the BPD (PMID:16100637).
name: Mild fetal ventriculomegaly

desc: An increase in size of the subarachnoid space associated with the lateral cerebral sulcus (Sylvian fissure).
name: Enlarged sylvian cistern

desc: Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum.
name: Aqueductal stenosis

desc: Cerebral cysts, usually located in the wall of the caudate nucleus or in the caudothalamic groove. They are found in up to 5.2% of all neonates, using transfontanellar ultrasound in the first days of life.
name: Subependymal cysts

desc: An abnormality of the choroid plexus, which is the area in the cerebral ventricles in which cerebrospinal fluid is produced by modified ependymal cells.
name: Abnormality of the choroid plexus

desc: A cyst occurring within the choroid plexus within a cerebral ventricle.
name: Choroid plexus cyst

desc: The presence of calcium deposition in the choroid plexus.
name: Choroid plexus calcification

desc: Overgrowth of the choroid plexus.
name: Villous hypertrophy of choroid plexus
synonyms: Diffuse villous hypertrophy of choroid plexus

desc: Intraventricular papillary neoplasm derived from choroid plexus epithelium. Plexus tumors are most common in the lateral and fourth ventricles; while 80% of lateral ventricle tumors present in children, fourth ventricle tumors are evenly distributed in all age groups. Clinically, choroid plexus tumors tend to cause hydrocephalus and increased intracranial pressure. Histologically, choroid plexus papillomas correspond to WHO grade I, choroid plexus carcinomas to WHO grade III.
name: Choroid plexus carcinoma

desc: Choroid plexus papilloma is a histologically benign neoplasm located in the ventricular system of the choroid plexus.
name: Choroid plexus papilloma

desc: Small nodular masses which originate in the subependymal region of the lateral ventricles and protrude into the ventricular cavity. They may represent subependymal hamartomas of tuberous sclerosis or nodular heterotopia of grey matter.
name: Subependymal nodules

desc: An abnormality of the fourth ventricle.
name: Abnormality of the fourth ventricle

desc: An abnormality of the third ventricle.
name: Abnormality of the third ventricle

desc: A developmental defect characterized by the absence of the Third ventricle.
layperson: Absence of the third cerebral ventricle
name: Absence of the third cerebral ventricle

desc: An epithelial lined cyst filled with gelatinous material. The gelatinous material commonly contains mucin, old blood, cholesterol, and ions. Most colloid cysts identified are currently asymptomatic and identified incidentally on imaging. When a colloid cyst does cause issues, it most commonly causes obstructive hydrocephalus.
name: Third ventricle colloid cyst

desc: A morphological anomaly of the lateral ventricle.
name: Abnormality of lateral ventricle

desc: Colpocephaly is an anatomic finding in the brain manifested by occipital horns that are disproportionately enlarged in comparison with other parts of the lateral ventricles.
name: Colpocephaly

desc: An anomaly of the brainstem.
name: Abnormality of brainstem morphology

desc: A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord.
name: Brainstem dysplasia

desc: An abnormality of the pons.
name: Abnormality of the pons

desc: An anomaly of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
layperson: Abnormality of the superior cerebellar peduncle
name: Abnormality of the superior cerebellar peduncle

desc: Increased width of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
name: Thickened superior cerebellar peduncle

desc: Increased length of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
name: Elongated superior cerebellar peduncle

desc: Abnormal splayed configuration (spreading out) of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
name: Splayed superior cerebellar peduncle

desc: Atrophy of the superior cerebellar peduncle.
name: Atrophic superior cerebellar peduncle

desc: An abnormal curved or vaulted (capped) structure covering the middle third of the dorsal pontine tegmentum and projecting into the fourth ventricle.
name: Pontine tegmental cap

desc: An abnormality of the medulla oblongata, the lower half of the brainstem.
name: Abnormality of the medulla oblongata

desc: Degeneration of the olivary bodies, prominent oval structures in the medulla oblongata.
name: Olivary degeneration

desc: An anomaly of the white matter of brainstem.
layperson: Abnormality of the brainstem white matter
name: Abnormality of the brainstem white matter

desc: An anomaly of the cerebellar peduncles. The superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles emerge from the cerebellum. The superior cerebellar penduncles connect the cerebellum to the midbrain, the middle cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the pons, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle connects the medulla spinalis and medulla oblongata with the cerebellum.
name: Abnormality of the cerebellar peduncle

desc: A deviation from normal signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem.
name: Abnormal brainstem MRI signal intensity

desc: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the brainstem.
name: Focal T2 hyperintense brainstem lesion

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the brainstem.
name: Focal T2 hypointense brainstem lesion

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brainstem. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire brainstem.
name: T2 hypointense brainstem

desc: Abnormal increase in size of the brainstem.
name: Enlarged brainstem

desc: A kinked appearance of the brainstem, i.e., an exaggerated flexure.
name: Kinked brainstem

desc: An abnormality of the midbrain, which has as its parts the tectum, cerebral peduncle, midbrain tegmentum and cerebral aqueduct.
name: Abnormality of midbrain morphology

desc: An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth.
name: Molar tooth sign on MRI

desc: Agenesis of the midbrain.
name: Absent mesencephalon

desc: Focal proliferation of glial cells in the substantia nigra.
name: Substantia nigra gliosis

desc: An anomalous build up of iron (Fe) in the substantia nigra.
name: Iron accumulation in substantia nigra

desc: An abnormality of the hindbrain, also known as the rhombencephalon.
name: Abnormality of hindbrain morphology

desc: An abnormality of the metencephalon. The metencephalon is the part of the hindbrain that consists of the pons and the cerebellum.
name: Abnormality of the metencephalon

desc: Any structural abnormality of the cerebellum.
name: Abnormal cerebellum morphology

desc: Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar atrophy

desc: Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum.
name: Pontocerebellar atrophy

desc: Atrophy affecting the cerebellum and the spinocerebellar tracts of the spinal cord.
name: Spinocerebellar atrophy

desc: Atrophy (wasting) of the cerebellar cortex.
name: Cerebellar cortical atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the granular cell layer.
name: Cerebellar granular layer atrophy

desc: Atrophy of the cerebellum affecting primarily the Purkinje cell layer.
name: Cerebellar Purkinje layer atrophy

desc: Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebellum.
name: Diffuse cerebellar atrophy

desc: Arnold-Chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum, sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of CSF outflow.
name: Arnold-Chiari malformation

desc: Arnold-Chiari type I malformation refers to a relatively mild degree of herniation of the posteroinferior region of the cerebellum (the cerebellar tonsils) into the cervical canal with little or no displacement of the fourth ventricle.
name: Arnold-Chiari type I malformation

desc: An anomaly of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Abnormality of the cerebellar vermis

desc: Defective development of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Dysgenesis of the cerebellar vermis

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis

desc: Underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Inferior vermis hypoplasia

desc: Congenital absence of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Agenesis of cerebellar vermis

desc: Congenital absence of a part of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Partial absence of cerebellar vermis

layperson: Aplasia of the inferior half of the cerebellar vermis
name: Aplasia of the inferior half of the cerebellar vermis
synonyms: Absent inferior half of the cerebellar vermis

desc: Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar vermis atrophy

layperson: Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellar vermis
name: Loss of Purkinje cells in the cerebellar vermis

layperson: Disorganization of the anterior cerebellar vermis
name: Disorganization of the anterior cerebellar vermis
synonyms: Disorganisation of the anterior cerebellar vermis

desc: A structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the vermis of cerebellum.
name: Dysmorphic inferior cerebellar vermis

desc: Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.
name: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy

desc: A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar hemangioblastoma

desc: The presence of dysplasia (abnormal growth or development) of the cerebellum. Cerebellar dysplasia is a neuroimaging finding that describes abnormalities of both the cerebellar cortex and white matter and is associated with variable neurodevelopmental outcome.
name: Cerebellar dysplasia

desc: Abnormal morphological development of the superior part of the cerebellum.
name: Superior cerebellar dysplasia

layperson: Dense calcifications in the cerebellar dentate nucleus
name: Dense calcifications in the cerebellar dentate nucleus

desc: An abnormally increased size of the cerebellum compared to other brain structures.
name: Enlarged cerebellum

desc: Focal proliferation of glial cells in the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar gliosis

desc: Swelling from fluid accumulation (serous fluid infiltration into the interstitial space) in the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar edema

desc: Any structural anomaly of the cortex of the cerebellum.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the cerebellar cortex
name: Abnormal morphology of the cerebellar cortex

desc: Reduced size of the cerebellar cortex.
name: Small cerebellar cortex

desc: Rhombencephalosynapsis is a rare brain malformation defined by midline fusion of the cerebellar hemispheres with partial or complete loss of the intervening vermis.
name: Rhombencephalosynapsis

desc: An abnormality of the dentate nucleus.
name: Abnormality of the dentate nucleus

desc: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of dentate nucleus.
name: Atrophy of the dentate nucleus

desc: It is a rare, slowly growing tumor of the cerebellum, a gangliocytoma sometimes considered to be a hamartoma, characterized by diffuse hypertrophy of the granular layer of the cerebellum.
name: Dysplastic gangliocytoma of the cerebellum

desc: A morphological abnormality of the metencephalon.
name: Poorly formed metencephalon

desc: An anomaly of the pituitary gland.
name: Abnormality of the pituitary gland

desc: An abnormality of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
name: Abnormality of the anterior pituitary

desc: A condition in which the pituitary gland is partially resistant to thyroid hormone, so that it continues to secrete thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) until the blood level of thyroid hormone rises higher than normal.
name: Pituitary resistance to thyroid hormone

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in the pituitary gland.
name: Pituitary calcification

desc: Hypersecretion of one or more pituitary hormones. This can occur in conditions in which deficiency in the target organ leads to decreased hormonal feedback, or as a primary condition most usually in connection with a pituitary adenoma.
name: Hyperpituitarism

desc: Overproduction of gonadotropins (FSH, LH) by the anterior pituitary gland.
name: Increased circulating gonadotropin level

desc: An elevated concentration of follicle-stimulating hormone in the blood.
layperson: Elevated circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
name: Elevated circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
synonyms: Increased circulating follicle stimulating hormone level

desc: An elevated concentration of luteinizing hormone in the blood.
name: Elevated circulating luteinizing hormone level

desc: Acromegaly is a condition resulting from overproduction of growth hormone by the pituitary gland in persons with closed epiphyses, and consists chiefly in the enlargement of the distal parts of the body. The circumference of the skull increases, the nose becomes broad, the tongue becomes enlarged, the facial features become coarsened, the mandible grows excessively, and the teeth become separated. The fingers and toes grow chiefly in thickness.
name: Growth hormone excess

desc: The presence of abnormally increased levels of prolactin in the blood. Prolactin is a peptide hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland that plays a role in breast development and lactation during pregnancy.
name: Increased circulating prolactin concentration

desc: Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex.
name: Adrenocorticotropic hormone excess

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland, also known as the adenohypophysis.
name: Anterior pituitary dysgenesis

desc: Absence of the anterior pituitary gland resulting from a developmental defect.
name: Anterior pituitary agenesis

desc: Underdevelopment of the anterior pituitary gland.
name: Anterior pituitary hypoplasia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
name: Neoplasm of the anterior pituitary

desc: A benign epithelial tumor derived from intrinsic cells of the adenohypophysis.
name: Pituitary adenoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma originating in prolactin secreting cells. This kind of adenoma is characterized by overproduction of prolactin, and may cause loss of menstrual periods and breast milk production in women.
name: Pituitary prolactin cell adenoma

desc: A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of less than 10 mm diameter.
name: Microprolactinoma

desc: A pituitary prolactin cell adenoma of more than 10 mm diameter.
name: Macroprolactinoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).
name: Pituitary corticotropic cell adenoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins.
name: Pituitary gonadotropic cell adenoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces growth hormone.
name: Pituitary growth hormone cell adenoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.
name: Pituitary null cell adenoma

desc: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).
name: Pituitary thyrotropic cell adenoma

desc: A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS.
name: Pituitary carcinoma

desc: A spindled-to-epithelioid, oncocytic, nonendocrine neoplasm of the anterior hypophysis that manifests in adults and follows a benign clinical course. Pituitary spindle cell oncocytomas are firm, fibrous, and adherent to surrounding structures and are highly vascular.
name: Pituitary spindle cell oncocytoma

desc: Abnormal anatomic location of the anterior pituitary gland.
name: Ectopic anterior pituitary gland

desc: A condition of reduced function of the anterior pituitary gland characterized by decreased secretion of one or more of the pituitary hormones growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, prolactin, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone.
name: Anterior hypopituitarism

desc: Insufficient production of growth hormone, which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland. Growth hormone is a major participant in control of growth and metabolism.
name: Growth hormone deficiency

desc: A type of reduced stature with normal proportions related to dysfunction of the pituitary gland related to either an isolated defect in the secretion of growth hormone or to panhypopituitarism, i.e., a deficit of all the anterior pituitary hormones.
name: Pituitary dwarfism

desc: A pituitary functional deficit affecting all the anterior pituitary hormones (growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, adrenocorticotropic hormone, and prolactin).
name: Panhypopituitarism

desc: A reduced ability to secrete gonadotropins, which are protein hormones secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary gland, including the hormones follitropin (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
name: Gonadotropin deficiency

desc: A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in thyroid-stimulating hormone secretion.
layperson: Low thyroid gland function due to abnormal pituitary gland
name: Pituitary hypothyroidism
synonyms: Low thyroid gland function due to abnormal pituitary gland

desc: A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol.
name: Adrenocorticotropic hormone deficiency

desc: A reduced level of prolactin in the blood circulation. Prolactin is a protein hormone that is secreted by lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary and that stimulates mammary gland development and milk production.
name: Reduced circulating prolactin concentration

desc: An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.
name: Abnormality of the posterior pituitary

desc: A form of diabetes insipidus related to a failure of vasopressin (AVP) release from the hypothalamus.
name: Central diabetes insipidus

desc: The presence of a neoplasm (tumour) in the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.
name: Neoplasm of the posterior pituitary

desc: A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.
name: Pituicytoma

desc: Abnormal development of the neurohypophysis during embryonic growth and development.
name: Posterior pituitary dysgenesis

desc: An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.
name: Ectopic posterior pituitary

desc: Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect.
name: Posterior pituitary agenesis

desc: Underdevelopment of the neurohypophysis.
name: Posterior pituitary hypoplasia

desc: A deviation from the normal size of the pituitary gland.
name: Abnormal size of pituitary gland

desc: An abnormally increased size of the pituitary gland.
name: Enlarged pituitary gland

desc: An abnormally decreased size of the pituitary gland.
name: Small pituitary gland

desc: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of the pituitary gland.
name: Atrophic pituitary gland

desc: Any deviation from the normal amount of the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the function of the thyroid gland.
name: Abnormal thyroid-stimulating hormone level

desc: Overproduction of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) by the anterior pituitary gland.
name: Increased thyroid-stimulating hormone level

desc: Reduced amount of the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which is produced by the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the function of the thyroid gland.
name: Decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone level

desc: A benign tumor (adenoma) of the pituitary gland
name: Prolactinoma

desc: An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in brain tissue.
name: Iron accumulation in brain

desc: An abnormal build up of iron (Fe) in the globus pallidus.
name: Iron accumulation in globus pallidus

desc: An anomalous build up of copper (Cu) in the brain.
name: Copper accumulation in brain

desc: A structural abnormality of the pineal gland.
name: Abnormality of pineal morphology

desc: Accumulation of calcium salts in the pineal gland.
name: Pineal gland calcification

desc: A glial uniloculated or multiloculated fluid-filled sac that either reside within or completely replace the pineal gland.
name: Pineal cyst

desc: An abnormal increase or decrease in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
name: Abnormal pineal volume

desc: An abnormal reduction in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
name: Decreased pineal volume

desc: An abnormal elevation in the quantity of three-dimensional space taken up by the pineal gland.
name: Increased pineal volume

desc: An abnormality of the forebrain, which has as its parts the telencephalon, diencephalon, lateral ventricles and third ventricle.
name: Abnormality of forebrain morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality of the telencephalon, which is also known as the cerebrum.
name: Abnormal cerebral morphology

desc: Diffuse enlargement of the entire cerebral hemispheres leading to macrocephaly (with or without overlying cortical dysplasia).
name: Megalencephaly

desc: Enlargement of all or parts of one cerebral hemisphere.
name: Hemimegalencephaly

desc: A cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, filled with cerebrospinal fluid, that communicates directly with the ventricular system.
name: Porencephalic cyst

desc: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain.
name: Cerebral edema

desc: This term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells.
name: Leukoencephalopathy

layperson: Abnormality of the periventricular white matter
name: Abnormality of the periventricular white matter

desc: Multiple pointlike areas of high T2 signal observed upon magnetic resonance imaging of the periventricular cerebral white matter.
name: Punctate periventricular T2 hyperintense foci

desc: Leukoencephalopathy that gets more severe with time.
name: Progressive leukoencephalopathy

desc: The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures.
layperson: Abnormal deposits of calcium in the brain
name: Cerebral calcification
synonyms: Abnormal deposits of calcium in the brain

desc: The presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia.
name: Basal ganglia calcification

desc: Deposition of calcium salts on both sides of the brain.
name: Bilateral intracranial calcifications

desc: Generalized deposition of calcium salts within the brain.
name: Diffuse cerebral calcification

desc: The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures that is present already at the time of birth.
name: Congenital intracerebral calcification

desc: The presence of calcium deposition in the cerebral white matter surrounding the cerebral ventricles.
name: Intracerebral periventricular calcifications

desc: An abnormality of the cerebral cortex.
name: Abnormality of the cerebral cortex

desc: Reduced size of the cerebral cortex.
name: Small cerebral cortex

desc: Reduced size of the superior frontal portion of the cerebral cortex.
name: Small superior frontal cortex

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cerebral cortex.
name: Cortical dysplasia

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cortex of frontal lobe and the cortex of parietal lobe.
name: Frontoparietal cortical dysplasia

desc: A type of malformation of cortical development that primarily affects areas of neocortex. It can be identified on conventional magnetic resonance imaging as focal cortical thickening, abnormal gyration, and blurring between gray and white matter, often associated with clusters of heterotopic neurons.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia

desc: A type of focal cortical dysplasia that is characterized by abnormal cortical layering.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type I

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type I that is characterized by abnormal radial cortical lamination.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type Ia

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type I that is characterized by abnormal tangential cortical lamination.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type Ib

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type I that is characterized by abnormal radial and tangential cortical lamination.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type Ic

desc: A type of focal cortical dysplasia that is characterized by disrupted cortical lamination and specific cytological abnormalities.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type II

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type II that is characterized by dysmorphic neurons, which present with a significantly enlarged cell body and nucleus, malorientation, abnormally distributed intracellular Nissl substance and cytoplasmic accumulation of neurofilament proteins.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIa

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type II that is characterized by dysmorphic neurons (significantly enlarged with accumulation of neurofilament proteins) and balloon cells.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIb

desc: A type of focal cortical dysplasia that is characterized by cortical lamination abnormalities associated with a principal lesion, usually adjacent to or affecting the same cortical area/lobe.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type III

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type III that is characterized by alterations in architectural organisation (cortical dyslamination) or cytoarchitectural composition (hypertrophic neurons outside Layer 5) in patients with hippocampal sclerosis (HS, syn. Ammon's horn sclerosis).
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIIa

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type III that is characterized by altered architectural (cortical dyslamination, hypoplasia without six-layered structure) and/or cytoarchitectural composition (hypertrophic neurons) of the neocortex, which occur adjacent to glial or glioneuronal tumor.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIIb

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type III that is characterized by alterations in architectural (cortical dyslamination, hypoplasia) or cytoarchitectural composition of the neocortex (hypertrophic neurons), which occur adjacent to vascular malformations (cavernomas, arteriovenous malformations, leptomeningeal vascular malformations, telangiectasias, meningioangiomatosis).
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIIc

desc: A subtype of focal cortical dysplasia type III that is characterized by altered architectural (cortical dyslamination, hypoplasia without six-layered structure) or cytoarchitectural composition (hypertrophic neurons) of the neocortex, which occur adjacent to other lesions acquired during early life (not included into FCD Type IIIa-c). These lesions comprise a large spectrum including traumatic brain injury, glial scarring after prenatal or perinatal ischemic injury or bleeding, and inflammatory or infectious diseases, i.e. Rasmussen encephalitis, limbic encephalitis, bacterial or viral infections.
name: Focal cortical dysplasia type IIId

desc: A malformation of cortical development characterized by mild abnormalities of the cortex: excessive heterotopic neurons in Layer 1 or microscopic neuronal clusters or excess of single neurons of normal morphology in deep white matter.
name: Mild malformation of cortical development

layperson: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex
name: Neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex

desc: Cortical tubers in the brain are hamartomatous lesions typically located at the gray-white matter interface, commonly in the frontal and parietal lobes. Cortical tubers are composed of abnormal glial and neural cells, and the size, number, and location vary among patients.
name: Cortical tubers

desc: An abnormality of the septum pellucidum, which is a thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the lateral ventricles of the brain.
name: Abnormality of the septum pellucidum

desc: Absence of the septum pellucidum.
name: Absent septum pellucidum

desc: If the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid-filled space or cavum is present. The cavum septum pellucidum is present at birth but usually obliterates by the age of 3 to 6 months. It is up to 1cm in width and the walls are parallel.
