It is an enclosed space and is not part of the ventricular system or connected with the subarachnoid space.
name: Cavum septum pellucidum

desc: Only part of the septum pellucidum (a thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the lateral ventricles of the brain) is present. This feature can be appreciated on magnetic resonance tomography or computed tomography of the brain.
layperson: Partial absence of the septum pellucidum
name: Partial absence of the septum pellucidum

desc: The presence of a cleft in the cerebral cortex unilaterally or bilaterally, usually located in the frontal area.
name: Schizencephaly

desc: An abnormality of the cerebral subcortex.
name: Abnormality of the cerebral subcortex

desc: Abnormality of the basal ganglia.
name: Abnormality of the basal ganglia

desc: An abnormality of the globus pallidus.
name: Abnormal globus pallidus morphology

desc: The presence, on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, of markedly low signal intensity if the globus pallidus that surrounds a central region of high signal intensity in the anteromedial globus pallidus, producing an eye-of-the-tiger appearance.
layperson: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus
name: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus

desc: Pathological deposition of calcium salts in the globus pallidus.
name: Globus pallidus calcification
Basal ganglia cysts
synonyms: Cystic lesions in the basal ganglia

desc: Focal proliferation of glial cells in the basal ganglia.
name: Basal ganglia gliosis

desc: The formation of small cavities in the tissue of the basal ganglia.
name: Cavitation of the basal ganglia

layperson: Symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia
name: Symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia

desc: Increased size of the basal ganglia.
name: Large basal ganglia

desc: Abnormality of the striatum, which is the largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, comprising the caudate, putamen and ventral striatum, including the nucleus accumbens.
name: Abnormal corpus striatum morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality of the caudate nucleus.
name: Abnormal caudate nucleus morphology

desc: An elevated concentration of lactate in the caudate nucleus. This finding can be elicited by magnetic resonance spectroscopy imaging.
name: Increased caudate lactate level

desc: Abnormally bright T2 signal from the striatum on brain magnetic resonance imaging.
name: Striatal T2 hyperintensity

desc: Any structural anomaly of the putamen, a brain nucleus which together with the caudate nucleus and fundus striati makes up the striatum.
name: Abnormal putamen morphology

desc: Death of cells in the basal ganglia.
name: Basal ganglia necrosis

desc: Decreased size of the basal ganglia.
name: Small basal ganglia

desc: A deviation from normal signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia.
layperson: Abnormal basal ganglia MRI signal intensity
name: Abnormal basal ganglia MRI signal intensity

desc: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the basal ganglia.
layperson: Focal T2 hyperintense basal ganglia lesion
name: Focal T2 hyperintense basal ganglia lesion
synonyms: Hyperintense lesions in the basal ganglia on MRI

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the basal ganglia.
layperson: Focal T2 hypointense basal ganglia lesion
name: Focal T2 hypointense basal ganglia lesion

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the basal ganglia. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting all of the basal ganglia.
name: T2 hypointense basal ganglia

desc: Diffusely widened perivascular spaces in the basal ganglia, affecting especially the corpus striatum. Status cribrosum is usually symmetrical, with the perivascular spaces showing CSF signal and without diffusion restriction. The word cribriform means sievelike, with multiple perforations.
name: Status cribrosum

desc: Swelling within the basal ganglia due to the accumulation of fluid.
name: Basal ganglia edema

desc: Structural abnormality of the basal ganglia related to defective development.
name: Dysgenesis of the basal ganglia

desc: A reduction in the number of nerve cells in the basal ganglia.
name: Neuronal loss in basal ganglia

desc: An abnormality of the cerebral white matter.
layperson: Abnormality of the cerebral white matter
name: Abnormality of the cerebral white matter
synonyms: Cortical white matter abnormalities seen on MRI

desc: Abnormality of the corpus callosum.
name: Abnormal corpus callosum morphology

desc: Dysplasia and dysgenesis of the corpus callosum are nonspecific descriptions that imply defective development of the corpus callosum. The term dysplasia is applied when the morphology of the corpus callosum is altered as a congenital trait. For instance, the corpus callosum may be hump-shaped, kinked, or a striped corpus callosum that lacks an anatomically distinct genu and splenium.
name: Dysplastic corpus callosum

desc: Increased vertical dimension of the corpus callosum. This feature can be visualized by sagittal sections on magnetic resonance tomography imaging of the brain.
name: Thick corpus callosum

desc: Centrally located corpus callosum hyperintensities said to resemble snowballs upon magnetic resonance imaging (with T2 or Sagittal fluid attenuated inversion recovery [FLAIR] sequences). The central location in the callosum makes them pathognomonic for Susac syndrome.
name: Snowball lesion of corpus callosum

layperson: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region
name: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region

desc: An abnormal area of increased brightness (hyperintensity) that is limited to one particular area.
layperson: Focal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Focal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

layperson: Focal hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Focal hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

desc: An abnormal area of increased brightness (hyperintensity) that occurs in several distinct areas.
layperson: Multifocal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Multifocal hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

layperson: Multifocal hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Multifocal hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

desc: A darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter.
layperson: Hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

desc: Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the deep cerebral white matter.
name: Deep white matter hypodensities

desc: Multiple areas of darker than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter that surrounds the cerebral ventricles.
name: Periventricular white matter hypodensities

layperson: Confluent hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Confluent hypointensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

desc: Areas of brighter than expected MRI signal in the white matter of the brain whereby individual patches run together.
layperson: Confluent hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Confluent hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

layperson: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter
name: Diffuse swelling of cerebral white matter

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the cerebral white matter.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the cerebral white matter

desc: Underdevelopment of the cerebral white matter.
name: Cerebral white matter hypoplasia

desc: Congenital defect with failure of the development of the cerebral white matter.
name: Cerebral white matter agenesis
synonyms: Agenesis of the cerebral white matter

desc: An anomaly of the internal capsule, which is an area of white matter in the brain that separates the caudate nucleus and the thalamus from the putamen and the globus pallidus.
name: Abnormality of the internal capsule

desc: The presence of atrophy (wasting) of the cerebral white matter.
name: Cerebral white matter atrophy

desc: An anomaly of the anterior commissure, a bundle of nerve fibers that connect the two cerebral hemispheres across the midline. The anterior commissure plays a role in pain sensation and contains decussating fibers from the olfactory tracts.
name: Abnormality of the anterior commissure

desc: Absence of the anterior commissure.
name: Agenesis of the anterior commissure

desc: Underdevelopment of the anterior commissure.
name: Hypoplastic anterior commissure

desc: The stria terminalis is a slender, compact fiber bundle that connects the amygdala (amygdaloid body) with the hypothalamus and other basal forebrain regions. The bed nucleus of the stria terminalis is a limbic forebrain structure that receives heavy projections from, among other areas, the basolateral amygdala, and projects in turn to hypothalamic and brainstem target areas that mediate many of the autonomic and behavioral responses to aversive or threatening stimuli. This term refers to an anomaly of the bed nucleus.
layperson: Abnormality of the bed nucleus of stria terminalis
name: Abnormality of the bed nucleus of stria terminalis

desc: A diminished volume of the central part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.
layperson: Reduced volume of central subdivision of bed nucleus of stria terminalis
name: Reduced volume of central subdivision of bed nucleus of stria terminalis

desc: A brighter than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter.
layperson: Hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI
name: Hyperintensity of cerebral white matter on MRI

desc: Areas of brighter than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter that surrounds the cerebral ventricles.
name: Periventricular white matter hyperdensities

desc: Areas of brighter than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from the cerebral white matter that surrounds the fourth cerebral ventricle (which is located beneath the tentorium of the cerebellum).
name: Subtentorial periventricular white matter hyperdensity

desc: Areas of brighter than expected signal on magnetic resonance imaging emanating from locations distant from the ventricular system.
name: Deep cerebral white matter hyperdensities

desc: A diffusion abnormality observed in diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain. Molecular diffusion refers to the notion that any type of molecule in a fluid (eg, water) is randomly displaced as the molecule is agitated by thermal energy. Restricted diffusion of water appears bright on diffusion-weighted images.
layperson: Abnormal diffusion weighted cerebral MRI morphology
name: Abnormal diffusion weighted cerebral MRI morphology
synonyms: Diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DWI) abnormality
MRI diffusion abnormality of the cerebrum

desc: Encephalomalacia is the softening or loss of brain tissue after cerebral infarction, cerebral ischemia, infection, craniocerebral trauma, or other injury.
name: Encephalomalacia

desc: Cerebral inflammation involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.
name: Cerebral granulomatosis

desc: Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of stainable substances within cells of the brain.
name: Cerebral inclusion bodies

desc: Pathological protein aggregates formed by hyperphosphorylation of a microtubule-associated protein known as tau, causing it to aggregate in an insoluble form.
name: Neurofibrillary tangles
synonyms: Neurofibrillary tangles composed of disordered microtubules in neurons

desc: Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates that show positive staining with antibodies against ubiquitin within cells of the brain.
name: Ubiquitin-positive cerebral inclusion bodies

desc: Intracellular aggregates of actin and actin-associated proteins within nerve cells.
name: Hirano bodies

desc: Presence of abundant argyrophilic grains and coiled bodies on microscopic examination of brain tissue.
name: Argyrophilic inclusion bodies

desc: An intraneuronal inclusion body composed of acid mucopolysaccharides.
name: Lafora bodies

desc: Cerebral eosinophilic, discrete, intracytoplasmatic inclusions of unknown significance.
name: Cerebral hyaline bodies

desc: Thick, elongated, worm-like or corkscrew eosinophilic bundle that are found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders.
name: Rosenthal fibers

desc: Any structural anomaly of the limbic system, a set of midline structures surrounding the brainstem of the mammalian brain, originally described anatomically, e.g., hippocampal formation, amygdala, hypothalamus, cingulate cortex. Although the original designation was anatomical, the limbic system has come to be associated with the system in the brain subserving emotional functions. As such, it is very poorly defined and doesn't correspond closely to the anatomical meaning any longer. [BirnLex].
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the limbic system
name: Abnormal morphology of the limbic system

desc: Any structural anomaly of the hippocampus,
name: Abnormal morphology of the hippocampus

desc: Structural abnormality of the hippocampus related to defective development.
name: Dysgenesis of the hippocampus

desc: Underdevelopment of the hippocampus.
name: Hypoplastic hippocampus

desc: Increase in size of the hippocampus.
name: Enlarged hippocampus

desc: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of hippocampus tissue that was once present.
name: Hippocampal atrophy

desc: A decrease in the volume (size) of the amygdyla.
name: Reduced amygdala volume

desc: An abnormality of the Diencephalon, which together with the cerebrum (telencephalon) makes up the forebrain.
name: Abnormality of the diencephalon

desc: An abnormality of the thalamus.
name: Abnormality of thalamus morphology

desc: A developmental defect characterized by fusion of the left and right halves of the thalamus.
layperson: Fusion of the left and right thalami
name: Fusion of the left and right thalami

desc: Deviation from the normal range of size of the thalamus.
name: Abnormal thalamic size

desc: An increase in the quantity of space occupied by the thalamus.
name: Enlarged thalamic volume

desc: A reduction in the quantity of space occupied by the thalamus.
name: Decreased thalamic volume

desc: A deviation from normal signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus.
name: Abnormal thalamic MRI signal intensity

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a diffuse hypointensity affecting the entire thalamus.
name: T2 hypointense thalamus

desc: A darker than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a localized hypointensity affecting a particular region of the thalamus.
name: Focal T2 hypointense thalamic lesion

desc: A lighter than expected T2 signal on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thalamus. This term refers to a localized hyperintensity affecting a particular region of the thalamus.
name: Focal T2 hyperintense thalamic lesion

desc: Swelling within the thalamus due to the accumulation of fluid.
name: Thalamic edema

desc: Calcium deposition in the thalamus.
name: Thalamic calcification

desc: Bleeding in the thalamus.
name: Thalamic hemorrhage

desc: Structural abnormality of the thalamus related to defective development.
name: Dysgenesis of the thalamus

desc: An arteriovenous malformation is a disruption of the normal vascular pattern in which arteries or arterioles connect directly to the venous collection system, bypassing any capillary bed. This term refers to an arteriovenous malformation located in the thalamus.
name: Thalamic arteriovenous malformation

desc: Any structural anomaly of the hypothalamus.
name: Abnormal hypothalamus morphology

desc: The presence of a hamartoma of the hypothalamus.
name: Hypothalamic hamartoma
Hypothalamic atrophy
synonyms: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of hypothalamus tissue that was once present.

desc: Structural abnormality of the hypothalamus related to defective development.
name: Dysgenesis of the hypothalamus

desc: An arteriovenous malformation is a disruption of the normal vascular pattern in which arteries or arterioles connect directly to the venous collection system, bypassing any capillary bed. This term refers to an arteriovenous malformation located in the hypothalamus.
name: Hypothalamic arteriovenous malformation

desc: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the olfactory tract, which causes anosmia, a complete loss of the sense of smell.
name: Aplasia of the olfactory tract

desc: A structural anomaly of the olfactory lobe, the structure within the brain that receives neural input from the nasal cavity and thereby processes the sense of smell.
name: Abnormality of olfactory lobe morphology

desc: An abnormal morphology of the olfactory bulb (bulbus olfactorius), which is involved in olfaction, i.e. the sense of smell.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the olfactory bulb
name: Abnormal morphology of the olfactory bulb

desc: Lack of formation (congenital absence) of the olfactory bulb.
name: Aplasia of the olfactory bulb

layperson: Abnormality of the cerebral blood vessels
name: Abnormality of the cerebral vasculature
synonyms: Abnormality of the cerebral blood vessels

desc: Sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain.
name: Stroke

desc: A stroke related to a small infarct (2-20 mm in diameter) in the deep cerebral white matter, basal ganglia, or pons, that is presumed to result from the occlusion of a single small perforating artery supplying the subcortical areas of the brain.
name: Lacunar stroke

desc: Lacunes are infarcts less than 15 mm in diameter in the cortical white matter or in the corona radiata, internal capsule, centrum semiovale, thalamus, basal ganglia, or pons.
name: Pontine ischemic lacunes

desc: No consensus exists on what a stroke-like episode is, but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit, occurring with or without the context of seizures, which last longer than 24 hours.
name: Stroke-like episode

desc: Hemorrhage occurring within the skull.
name: Intracranial hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the brain.
name: Cerebral hemorrhage

desc: Recurrent bleeding into the parenchyma of the brain.
name: Recurrent cerebral hemorrhage

desc: Cerebral hemorrhage that occurs before birth.
name: Antenatal intracerebral hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage occurring between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.
name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar hemorrhage

desc: Bleeding into the ventricles of the brain.
name: Intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Intraventricular hemorrhage that occurs in a premature infant.
name: Preterm intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Intraventricular hemorrhage that occurs in a preterm infant and that is restricted to subependymal region/germline matrix which is seen in the caudothalamic groove.
name: Grade I preterm intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Intraventricular hemorrhage that occurs in a preterm infant and that has extension into normal-sized ventricles and typically fills less than 50% of the volume of the ventricle.
name: Grade II preterm intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Intraventricular hemorrhage that occurs in a preterm infant and that has extension into dilated ventricles.
name: Grade III preterm intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Intraventricular hemorrhage that occurs in a preterm infant and that shows parenchymal extension.
name: Grade IV preterm intraventricular hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.
name: Subdural hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage occurring between the dura mater and the skull.
name: Epidural hemorrhage

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the brain.
name: Cerebral arteriovenous malformation

desc: Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.
name: Cerebral vasculitis

desc: Any structural anomaly of a cerebral artery. The cerebral arteries comprise three main pairs of arteries and their branches, which supply the cerebrum of the brain. These are the anterior cerebral artery, the middle cerebral artery, and the posterior cerebral artery.
name: Abnormal cerebral artery morphology

desc: Deposition of calcium salts within small blood vessels of the brain.
layperson: Calcification of the small brain vessels
name: Calcification of the small brain vessels

layperson: Disruption of blood oxygen supply to brain
name: Cerebral ischemia
synonyms: Disruption of blood oxygen supply to brain

desc: Arteriosclerosis (increased thickness, increased stiffness, loss of elasticity) of the small arteries of the brain.
name: Arteriosclerosis of small cerebral arteries
synonyms: Hardened artery wall in small cerebral arteries

desc: Excessive bending, twisting, and winding of a cerebral artery.
name: Tortuous cerebral arteries

desc: The presence of a localized dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
name: Dilatation of the cerebral artery

desc: A small, sac-like aneurysm (outpouching) of a cerebral blood vessel.
name: Cerebral berry aneurysm

desc: A localized circumferential (i.e., bulges on all sides) dilatation or ballooning of a cerebral artery.
name: Fusiform cerebral aneurysm

desc: Atherosclerosis (HP:0002621) of a cerebral artery.
name: Cerebral artery atherosclerosis

desc: A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis.
name: Moyamoya phenomenon

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of a cerebral artery.
name: Cerebral artery stenosis

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the middle cerebral artery.
name: Middle cerebral artery stenosis

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the anterior cerebral artery.
name: Anterior cerebral artery stenosis

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of the posterior cerebral artery.
name: Posterior cerebral artery stenosis

desc: An anomaly of the circle of Willis, also known as the cerebral arterial circle.
name: Abnormal circle of Willis morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the cerebral arterial circle

desc: Any structural anomaly of the posterior circulating artery (PCOM).
name: Abnormal posterior circulating artery morphology

desc: Underdeveloped posterior communicating artery.
name: Hypoplastic posterior communicating artery

desc: A widening (ballooning) localized in the wall of the posterior communicating artery.
name: Posterior communicating artery aneurysm

desc: A funnel-shaped symmetrical enlargement of the origin of the posterior communicating artery at its junction with the internal carotid artery.
name: Posterior communicating artery infundibulum

desc: An anomaly of cerebral veins.
name: Abnormality of cerebral veins

desc: A congenital malformation of veins which drain normal brain characterized by a caput medusae or an umbrellalike convergence of multiple venules on a single, or occasionally multiple, enlarged parenchymal or medullary vein, like the trunk of a tree or the shank of an umbrella. This dilated terminal vein penetrates the cortex to drain either (a) superficially to cortical veins or sinuses, (b) deeply to subependymal veins of the lateral ventricle and then into the galenic system, (c) to the fourth ventricle and then to the pontomesencephalic vein, or (d) to the precentral cerebellar vein and into the galenic system.
name: Cerebral venous angioma

desc: A venous angioma of the frontal lobe of the brain.
name: Frontal venous angioma

desc: Gross dilatation of the vein of Galen, being fed by large anomalous vessel or vessels arising from the carotid or basilar circulation.
name: Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformation

desc: Increased dimensions of the Virchow-Robin spaces (also known as perivascular spaces), which surround the walls of vessels as they course from the subarachnoid space through the brain parenchyma. Perivascular spaces are commonly microscopic, and not visible on conventional neuroimaging. This term refers to an increase of size of these spaces such that they are visible on neuroimaging (usually magnetic resonance imaging). The dilatations are regular cavities that always contain a patent artery.
name: Perivascular spaces

desc: Abnormality in the space in the meninges beneath the arachnoid membrane and above the pia mater that contains the cerebrospinal fluid.
name: Abnormal subarachnoid space morphology

desc: An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater.
name: Widened subarachnoid space

desc: An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebellum.
name: Widened cerebellar subarachnoid space

desc: An increase in size of the anatomic space between the arachnoid membrane and pia mater in the region surrounding the cerebrum.
name: Widened cerebral subarachnoid space

desc: Cystic collection (sac-like, fluid containing pocket of membranous tissue) located in the interhemispheric fissure, with or without communication with the ventricular system.
name: Interhemispheric cyst

desc: A fluid-filled sac (cyst) located within the central nervous system.
name: Central nervous system cyst
synonyms: Cyst of the central nervous system

desc: A cystic lesion originating within the brain.
name: Intracranial cystic lesion

desc: A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from ectodermal cells that normally form skin cells being left behind in the nervous system during development.
name: Intracranial epidermoid cyst

desc: A congenital inclusion cysts that arises from the inclusion of ectodermally committed cells at the time of neural tube closure (3rd-5th week of embryogenesis). The capsule of dermoid cysts consists of simple epithelium supported by collagen. In thicker parts, the lining is supplemented with dermis containing hair follicles, sebaceous glands, and apocrine glands.
name: Intracranial dermoid cyst

desc: A fluid-filled sacs that develop on or near the pituitary gland.
name: Pituitary gland cyst

desc: A cerebrospinal fluid-filled nerve root cyst most often localized in the sacral spine.
name: Tarlov cyst

desc: The neurenteric cyst is a rare lesion composed of heterotopic endodermal tissue. During the third week of human embryogenesis, the neurenteric canal unites the yolk sac and the amniotic cavity as it traverses the primitive notochordal plate. Persistence of the normally transient neurenteric canal prevents appropriate separation of endoderm and notochord. This results in a variable degree of communication between neural and enteric epithelium.
name: Neurenteric cyst

desc: A neurenteric cyst located in the spine.
name: Spinal neurenteric cyst

desc: A neurenteric cyst located within the skull.
name: Intracranial neurenteric cyst

desc: A neoplasm of the central nervous system.
layperson: Tumors of the central nervous system
name: Neoplasm of the central nervous system
synonyms: Tumors of the central nervous system
Neoplasia of the central nervous system

desc: A central nervous system neoplasm with neuronal and, less consistently, glial differentiation.
layperson: Neuronal/glioneuronal neoplasm of the central nervous system
name: Neuronal/glioneuronal neoplasm of the central nervous system

desc: A tumor of the central nervous system that has components of both neurocytic and glial areas, whereby usually the glial component of the tumour predominates. Rossette-forming glioneuronal tumors (RGNT) have biphasic cytoarchitecture with two elements; neurocytic rosettes resembling Homer-Wright rosettes, and astrocytic component resembling a pilocytic astrocytoma. RGNTs are low-grade tumors that lack histopathological signs of malignancy.
name: Rosette-forming glioneuronal tumor
synonyms: Rosette-forming glioneuronal tumor of the fourth ventricle

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from or metastasizes to the brain.
name: Brain neoplasm

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that occurs within the intracranial cavity above the tentorium cerebelli.
name: Supratentorial neoplasm

desc: A neoplasm of the pineal gland.
name: Pinealoma

desc: A type of pineal parenchymal cell neoplasm that is a mature well-differentiated tumour (WHO grade I).
name: Pineocytoma

desc: Pineoblastoma is a rare primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET) arising in the pineal gland. Pineoblastomas are classified as a WHO grade IV tumour and comprise one-fourth to one-half of pineal parenchymal tumours. Pineoblastoma is a highly cellular tumor originating in the pineal gland and containing small, poorly differentiated cells.
name: Pineoblastoma

layperson: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system
name: Benign neoplasm of the central nervous system

desc: The presence of a meningioma, i.e., a benign tumor originating from the dura mater or arachnoid mater.
name: Meningioma
synonyms: Noncancerous growth of membranes covering brain

desc: A benign tumour of meningothelial cells of the meninges that usually occurs in middle age. It is typically unilateral and there is an association with neurofibromatosis type 2.
name: Optic nerve sheath meningioma

desc: The presence of a hamartoma of the cerebrum.
name: Cerebral hamartoma

desc: A hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular neoplasm that arises almost exclusively in the central nervous system. Hemangioblastomas consist of a tightly packed cluster of small blood vessels forming a mass of up to 1 or 2 cm in diameter.
name: Hemangioblastoma

desc: The presence of mulitple lipomas located in the central nervous system.
name: Multiple central nervous system lipomas
synonyms: Lipomas of the central nervous system

desc: A tumor that originates in the pineal gland, has moderate cellularity and tends to form rosette patterns.
layperson: Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system
name: Malignant neoplasm of the central nervous system

desc: A rapidly growing embryonic tumor arising in the posterior part of the cerebellar vermis and neuroepithelial roof of the fourth ventricle in children. More rarely, medulloblastoma arises in the cerebellum in adults.
name: Medulloblastoma

desc: A family of tumours arising in the embryonal remnants of the sympathetic nervous system, which includes neuroblastoma, ganglioneuroblastoma, and ganglioneuroma.
name: Neuroblastic tumor

desc: Neuroblastoma is a solid tumor that originate in neural crest cells of the sympathetic nervous system. Most neuroblastomas originate in the abdomen, and most abdominal neuroblastomas originate in the adrenal gland. Neuroblastomas can also originate in the thorax, usually in the posterior mediastinum.
name: Neuroblastoma

desc: A malignant olfactory neuroblastoma arising from the olfactory epithelium of the superior nasal cavity and cribriform plate.
name: Olfactory esthesioneuroblastoma

desc: The presence of a glioma, which is a neoplasm of the central nervous system originating from a glial cell (astrocytes or oligodendrocytes).
name: Glioma

desc: The presence of an ependymoma of the central nervous system.
name: Ependymoma

desc: Astrocytoma is a neoplasm of the central nervous system derived from astrocytes. Astrocytes are a type of glial cell, and thus astrocytoma is a subtype of glioma.
name: Astrocytoma

desc: A demarcated, largely intraventricular tumor in the region of the foramen of Monro composed of spindle to large plump or ganglion-like cells with eosinophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm and somewhat pleomorphic nuclei with occasional prominent nucleoli. These tumors are almost always associated with tuberous sclerosis.
name: Subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma

desc: A glioma originating in the optic nerve or optic chiasm.
name: Optic nerve glioma

desc: A glioma affecting the cerebellum.
name: Cerebellar glioma

desc: A glioma affecting the brainstem.
name: Brainstem glioma

desc: A tumor arising from glia in the central nervous system with macroscopic regions of necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopically, glioblastoma multiforme is characterized by regions of pseudopalisading necrosis, pleomorphic nuclei and cells, and microvascular proliferation.
name: Glioblastoma multiforme

desc: An abnormality of the glia cell.
name: Abnormality of the glial cells

desc: Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.
name: Gliosis

desc: A type of gliosis that occurs in the vicinity of injured neurons.
name: Myelin-dependent gliosis

desc: Focal proliferation of glial cells in the hypothalamus.
name: Hypothalamic gliosis

desc: Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system.
name: Astrocytosis

desc: One of the three types of glia cells that, with the nerve cells, compose the central nervous system and are characterized by sheetlike processes that wrap around individual axons to form the myelin sheath of nerve fibers.
name: Abnormality of the oligodendroglia

desc: An abnormality of astrocytes.
name: Abnormality of the astrocytes

desc: An abnormality of the microglial cells. They are also known as brain-resident macrophages or hortega cells.
name: Abnormality of the microglia

desc: Any structural anomaly of the hollow epithelial tube found on the dorsal side of the vertebrate embryo that develops into the central nervous system (i.e. brain and spinal cord).
name: Abnormal neural tube morphology

desc: A neural tube defect arises when the neural tube, the embryonic precursor of the brain and spinal cord, fails to close during neurulation. The cranial region (anencephaly) or the low spine (open spina bifida; myelomeningocele) are most commonly affected although, in the severe NTD craniorachischisis, almost the entire neural tube remains open, from midbrain to low spine.
name: Neural tube defect

desc: A malformation of the neural tube with a large amount of protruding brain tissue and absence of calvarium.
name: Exencephaly

desc: A neural tube defect in which both the brain and spinal cord remain open to varying degrees.
name: Craniorachischisis

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nervous system.
name: Neoplasm of the nervous system

desc: Any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons.
name: Abnormal myelination

desc: Delayed myelination.
name: Delayed myelination

desc: A structural anomaly of a neuron.
name: Abnormal neuron morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly that affects the motor neuron.
name: Abnormal motor neuron morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly that affects the upper motor neuron.
layperson: Abnormal shape of upper motor neuron
name: Abnormal upper motor neuron morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of upper motor neuron

layperson: Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons
name: Paucity of anterior horn motor neurons

desc: Abnormality of the structure and branching of the dendrites of a neuron.
name: Abnormal neuron branching

desc: Any abnormality of the part of the nervous system that consists of the nerves and ganglia outside of the brain and spinal cord.
layperson: Abnormality of the peripheral nervous system
name: Abnormality of the peripheral nervous system
synonyms: Abnormality of the peripheral nervous system

desc: An abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
layperson: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
name: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system

desc: A structural abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
name: Abnormal autonomic nervous system morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of nerves of the enteric nervous system.
layperson: Abnormality of enteric nervous system morphology
name: Abnormality of enteric nervous system morphology

desc: An abnormality of the enteric nervous system, which comprises two types of ganglia, the myenteric (Auerbach's) and submucosal (Meissner's) plexuses. The enteric nervous system functions to control gut movement, fluid exchange between the gut and its lumen, and local blood flow.
name: Abnormality of enteric ganglion morphology

desc: An abnormality resulting from a lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) that results in bowel obstruction with enlargement of the colon.
name: Aganglionic megacolon

desc: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment does not extend beyond the upper sigmoid.
name: Short-segment aganglionic megacolon

desc: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment extends proximal to the sigmoid.
name: Long-segment aganglionic megacolon

desc: A type of aganglionic megacolon in which the aganglionic segment comprises the entire colon.
name: Total colonic aganglionosis

desc: A congenital defect characterized by the lack of ganglion cells in the entire intestine, i.e., the aganglionic segment comprises the entire large and small bowel.
name: Total intestinal aganglionosis

desc: A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the small intestine.
name: Aganglionosis of the small intestine

desc: A lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) affecting the duodenum.
name: Duodenal aganglionosis

desc: Sparse and small myenteric ganglia
name: Hypoganglionosis

desc: Hyperplastic submucosal and myenteric plexus containing an increased number of ganglion cells, glial cells and nerve fibers.
name: Ganglioneuromatosis

desc: Deterioration of enteric neurons with impairment of enteric neuronal structure. Typical neuropathological findings include qualitative (e.g., neuronal swelling, intranuclear inclusions, axonal degeneration) and quantitative (e.g., reduction in the number of neurons) abnormalities of the enteric neurons.
name: Enteric neuronal degeneration

desc: Aggregates of stainable substances (proteins) in the nuclei of enteric neurons.
name: Enteric intraneuronal nuclear inclusion bodies

desc: A functional abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.
name: Abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology

desc: A form of hypotension characterized by a sudden fall in blood pressure that occurs when a person assumes a standing position.
layperson: Decrease in blood pressure upon standing up
name: Orthostatic hypotension
synonyms: Decrease in blood pressure upon standing up

layperson: Orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction
name: Orthostatic hypotension due to autonomic dysfunction

desc: Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
name: Autonomic bladder dysfunction

desc: An increase in heart rate with standing of 30 beats per minute or more.
name: Orthostatic tachycardia

desc: An abnormal regulation of the sweat glands by the sympathetic nervous system associated with abnormal perspiration.
name: Abnormal sudomotor regulation

desc: Any functional abnormality of the part of the nervous system that consists of the nerves and ganglia outside of the brain and spinal cord.
name: Abnormal peripheral nervous system physiology

desc: An abnormal result of a physical examination of the the hand that tests for palsy of the ulnar nerve. This nerve innervates the adductor pollicis and interossei muscles and thereby enables adduction of the thumb and extension of the interphalangeal joint. An abnormal result consists in reduced functionality and muscular weakness in the pinch grip between the thumb and index finger of the affected hand as the patient attempts to pinch a piece of paper that the examiner tries to pull away. The flexor pollicis longus muscle tries to compensate for the weakness by flexing the tip of the thumb at the interphalangeal joint.
name: Froment sign

desc: Any abnormality of the part of the peripheral nervous system associated with sensation and skeletal muscle voluntary control of body movements.
layperson: Abnormality of the somatic nervous system
name: Abnormality of the somatic nervous system

desc: Any abnormality of the somatic nerve plexus.
name: Abnormality of somatic nerve plexus

desc: Any abnormality of the brachial nerve plexus.
layperson: Abnormality of the brachial nerve plexus
name: Abnormality of the brachial nerve plexus

desc: Any abnormality of the lumbosacral nerve plexus.
layperson: Abnormality of the lumbosacral nerve plexus
name: Abnormality of the lumbosacral nerve plexus

desc: Abnormality of the plexus of the ventral rami of the first four cervical spinal nerves which are located from C1 to C4 cervical segment in the neck.
name: Abnormality of cervical plexus

desc: An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the autonomic nervous system.
name: Abnormality of ganglion

desc: An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the peripheral autonomic nervous system.
layperson: Abnormality of ganglion of peripheral nervous system
name: Abnormality of ganglion of peripheral nervous system

desc: An abnormality of nerve cell cluster or a group of nerve cell bodies located in the autonomic nervous system of the cranium.
name: Abnormality of cranial ganglion

desc: An abnormality of a ciliary ganglion.
name: Abnormality of ciliary ganglion

desc: An abnormality of the breast.
name: Abnormality of the breast

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the breast.
name: Abnormal breast morphology

desc: Abnormal development of large mammary glands in males resulting in breast enlargement.
name: Gynecomastia

desc: An abnormality of the nipple.
name: Abnormal nipple morphology

desc: Presence of more than two nipples.
name: Supernumerary nipple

desc: Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location.
name: Low-set nipples

desc: The presence of nipples that instead of pointing outward are retracted inwards.
name: Inverted nipples

desc: Underdevelopment of the nipple.
name: Hypoplastic nipples

desc: Congenital failure to develop, and absence of, the nipple.
name: Absent nipple
Dry nipple
synonyms: Abnormally dry skin in the area of the nipple of the breast.

desc: A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple.
name: Wide intermamillary distance

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the breasts.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the breasts

desc: Underdevelopment of the breast.
name: Breast hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the breast on one side only.
name: Unilateral breast hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the breast on both sides.
name: Bilateral breast hypoplasia

desc: Failure to develop and congenital absence of the breast.
name: Breast aplasia

desc: The presence of asymmetrical breasts.
name: Asymmetry of the breasts

desc: The presence of hypertrophy of the breast.
name: Breast hypertrophy

desc: An abnormal appearance or structure of the ring of pigmented skin that surrounds the nipple.
name: Abnormal areolar morphology

desc: The areola (ring of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple) is filled out so as to produce a rounded shape.
name: Areolar fullness

desc: Underdevelopment of the areola, the circular area of pigmented skin surrounding the nipple.
name: Hypoplastic areola

desc: A breast lump is any discrete mass in a breast noticed by the patient, significant other, or physician.
name: Breast mass

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the breast.
name: Neoplasm of the breast

desc: The presence of a carcinoma of the breast.
name: Breast carcinoma

desc: Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal.
name: Multifocal breast carcinoma

desc: A benign biphasic tumor of the breast with epithelial and stromal components.
name: Fibroadenoma of the breast

desc: Presence of abnormal cells inside a milk duct, that is, non-invasive breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma in situ is considered to be a precursor lesion to invasive breast cancer.
name: Ductal carcinoma in situ

desc: Any anomaly of the function of the breast.
name: Abnormal breast physiology

desc: Failure of secretion of milk following childbirth associated with an inability to breastfeed an infant.
name: Agalactia

desc: Spontaneous flow of milk from the breast, unassociated with childbirth or nursing.
name: Galactorrhea

desc: An abnormality of the endocrine system.
name: Abnormality of the endocrine system

desc: Abnormality of the thymus, an organ located in the upper anterior portion of the chest cavity just behind the sternum and whose main function is to provide an environment for T lymphocyte maturation.
name: Abnormality of the thymus

desc: A reduction in the level of thymic horomone.
name: Thymic hormone decreased

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the thymus.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the thymus

desc: Underdevelopment of the thymus.
name: Hypoplasia of the thymus

desc: Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination.
name: Aplasia of the thymus

desc: Enlargement of the thymus.
name: Thymus hyperplasia

desc: The presence of ectopic thymus tissue. Normally, cells of the ventral bud of the third pharyngeal pouch detach and migrate in the eighth gestational week caudally and medially towards the location of the mature thyroid. They migrate further retrosternally into the superior mediastinum. There are two main ways ectopic thymus tissue can develop. Either cells detach along the descensus path and proliferate, thereby forming accessory thymus tissue, or the entire gland fails to descend.
name: Ectopic thymus tissue

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thymus.
name: Neoplasm of the thymus

desc: A tumor originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus.
name: Thymoma

desc: A group of abnormalities characterized by hyperglycemia and glucose intolerance.
name: Diabetes mellitus

desc: A type of diabetes mellitus related not to lack of insulin but rather to lack of response to insulin on the part of the target tissues of insulin such as muscle, fat, and liver cells. This type of diabetes is typically associated with increases both in blood glucose concentrations as will as in fasting and postprandial serum insulin levels.
name: Insulin-resistant diabetes mellitus

desc: A type of diabetic metabolic abnormality with an accumulation of ketone bodies.
name: Diabetic ketoacidosis

desc: The term Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) was initially used for patients diagnosed with fasting hyperglycemia that could be treated without insulin for more than two years, where the initial diagnosis was made at a young age (under 25 years). Thus, MODY combines characteristics of type 1 diabetes (young age at diagnosis) and type 2 diabetes (less insulin dependence than type 1 diabetes). The term MODY is now most often used to refer to a group of monogenic diseases with these characteristics. Here, the term is used to describe hyperglycemia diagnosed at a young age with no or minor insulin dependency, no evidence of insulin resistence, and lack of evidence of autoimmune destruction of the beta cells.
name: Maturity-onset diabetes of the young
synonyms: Maturity onset diabetes of the young

desc: A type of diabetes mellitus initially characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia and subsequently by glucose interolerance and hyperglycemia.
name: Type II diabetes mellitus

desc: Ketosis-resistant diabetes is a synonym for type II diabetes. This term thus refers to a form of type II diabetes in which patients are dependent on insulin.
name: Insulin-dependent but ketosis-resistant diabetes

desc: Maternal diabetes can either be a gestational, mostly type 2 diabetes, or a type 1 diabetes. Essential is the resulting maternal hyperglycemia as a non-specific teratogen, imposing the same risk of congenital malformations to pregnant women with both type 1 and type2 diabetes.
name: Maternal diabetes

desc: A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin. Type I diabetes mellitus is manifested by the sudden onset of severe hyperglycemia with rapid progression to diabetic ketoacidosis unless treated with insulin.
name: Type I diabetes mellitus

desc: An abnormality of the thyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of the thyroid gland

desc: An abnormal functionality of the thyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of thyroid physiology

desc: Deficiency of thyroid hormone.
name: Hypothyroidism

desc: A type of hypothyroidism that results from a defect in the thyroid gland.
name: Primary hypothyroidism

desc: A type of hypothyroidism with congenital onset.
name: Congenital hypothyroidism

desc: Condition associated with a raised serum concentration of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) but a normal serum free thyroxine (FT4).
name: Compensated hypothyroidism

desc: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.
name: Central hypothyroidism

desc: An abnormality of thyroid physiology characterized by excessive secretion of the thyroid hormones thyroxine (i.e., T4) and/or 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine zwitterion (i.e., triiodothyronine or T3).
name: Hyperthyroidism

desc: An autoimmune disease where the thyroid is overactive, producing an excessive amount of thyroid hormones (a serious metabolic imbalance known as hyperthyroidism and thyrotoxicosis). This is caused by autoantibodies to the TSH-receptor (TSHR-Ab) that activate that TSH-receptor (TSHR), thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, and thyroid growth (causing a diffusely enlarged goiter). The resulting state of hyperthyroidism can cause a dramatic constellation of neuropsychological and physical signs and symptoms, which can severely compromise the patients.
name: Graves disease

layperson: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule
name: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule

desc: Reduced sensitivity of end organs to thyroid hormone characterized by elevated serum levels of free thyroid hormone with nonsuppressed thyroid stimulating hormone.
name: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid hormone
synonyms: Elevated serum levels of free thyroid hormone with nonsuppressed TSH

desc: An abnormality of thyroid physiology (HP:0002926) characterized by increased levels of thyroxine without evidence of clinical thyroid disease.
name: Euthyroid hyperthyroxinemia

layperson: Thyroid defect in oxidation and organification of iodide
name: Thyroid defect in oxidation and organification of iodide

desc: Reduced sensitivity of thyroid follicle cells to stimulation by biologically active thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).
layperson: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone
name: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone

desc: Gain-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.
name: Activating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect

desc: Loss-of-function thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) defect.
name: Inactivating thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor defect

desc: An abnormal result of the perchlorate discharge test. In this test, first radioactive iodine is administered, sufficinet time is allowed to pass so that the radioactive iodine is captured by the thyroid,and then, perchlorate is administered orally. The perchlorate displaces non-organified iodide from the thyroid. The perchlorate discharge test is considered positive (abnormal) if there is an abnormally rapid loss of radioactive iodine from the thyroid.
name: Positive perchlorate discharge test

desc: Any deviation from normal in the amount of uptake on the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) test, which utilizes a radioisotope of iodine to measure how much iodine the thyroid gland absorbs from the blood. The radioactive marker is measured 4-6 hours and in some cases also 24 hours after administration of the radioactive marker.
layperson: Abnormal radioactive iodine uptake test result
name: Abnormal radioactive iodine uptake test result

desc: A decreased amount of uptake on the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) test, which utilizes a radioisotope of iodine to measure how much iodine the thyroid gland absorbs from the blood. The radioactive marker is measured 4-6 hours and in some cases also 24 hours after administration of the radioactive marker.
name: Reduced radioactive iodine uptake

desc: An elevated amount of uptake on the radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) test, which utilizes a radioisotope of iodine to measure how much iodine the thyroid gland absorbs from the blood. The radioactive marker is measured 4-6 hours and in some cases also 24 hours after administration of the radioactive marker.
name: Increased radioactive iodine uptake

desc: Any deviation from the normal range of the hormones produced by the thyroid gland.
name: Abnormal thyroid hormone level

desc: A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that deviates from normal.
name: Abnormal T3/T4 ratio

desc: A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is higher than normal.
name: Increased T3/T4 ratio

desc: A ratio of serum triiodothyronine (T3) to thyroxine (T4) in the blood that is lower than normal.
name: Decreased T3/T4 ratio

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of thyroxine in the blood. Thyroxine (also known as T4) is the main hormone secreted by the thyroid gland into the blood. It can be converted into the active form triiodothyronine (also known as T3).
name: Abnormal circulating thyroxine level

desc: An elevation above the normal concentration of thyroxine in the blood. Thyroxine (also known as T4) is the main hormone secreted by the thyroid gland into the blood. It can be converted into the active form triiodothyronine (also known as T3).
name: Increased circulating thyroxine level

desc: A reduction below the normal concentration of thyroxine in the blood. Thyroxine (also known as T4) is the main hormone secreted by the thyroid gland into the blood. It can be converted into the active form triiodothyronine (also known as T3).
name: Decreased circulating thyroxine level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of free triiodothyronine (T3) in the blood circulation. A proportion of T3 is bound to plasma proteins in the blood, including mainly thyroxine binding globulin, transthyretin, and albumin. T3 that is not bound to a protein is referred to as free T3.
name: Abnormal circulating free T3 concentration

desc: An elevated concentration of free 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood circulation.
name: Increased circulating free T3

desc: A reduced concentration of free 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased circulating free T3

desc: A structural abnormality of the thyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of thyroid morphology

desc: An enlargement of the thyroid gland.
name: Goiter

desc: Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to one or more nodules in the thyroid gland.
name: Nodular goiter

desc: Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to multiple nodules in the thyroid gland.
name: Multinodular goiter

desc: Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland.
name: Uninodular goiter

desc: An enlargement of the thyroid gland with congenital onset.
name: Congenital goiter

desc: A goiter that is not associated with functional thyroid abnormalities.
name: Euthyroid goiter

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid hypoplasia

desc: The congenital absence of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid agenesis

desc: Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development.
name: Thyroid hemiagenesis

desc: Mislocalised thyroid gland.
name: Ectopic thyroid

desc: An aberrant thyroid gland or Ectopic thyroid located at the base of the tongue, just posterior to the foramen cecum as a result of a failure of the thyroid to descend.
name: Lingual thyroid

desc: Accessory ectopic thyroid tissue arising from remnants of the thyroglossal duct anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct tract.
name: Accessory ectopic thyroid tissue

desc: The presence of lymphangiectasis of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid lymphangiectasia

desc: Hyperplasia of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid hyperplasia

desc: An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.
name: Thyroid C cell hyperplasia

desc: An abnormality of the thyroid gland owing to the presence of a fibrous cyst resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct.
name: Thyroglossal cyst

desc: A nodular lesion that develops in the thyroid gland. The term "thyroid nodule" refers to any abnormal growth that forms a lump in the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid nodule

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the thyroid gland.
name: Neoplasm of the thyroid gland

desc: The presence of a adenoma of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid adenoma

desc: A kind of thyroid adenoma characterized by the presence of oxyphil cells.
name: Hurthle cell thyroid adenoma

desc: The presence of a carcinoma of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroid carcinoma

desc: The presence of a medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland.
name: Medullary thyroid carcinoma

desc: The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
name: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

desc: The presence of an follicular adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
name: Follicular thyroid carcinoma

desc: Inflammation of the thyroid gland.
name: Thyroiditis

desc: A chronic, autoimmune type of thyroiditis associated with hypothyroidism.
name: Hashimoto thyroiditis

desc: An abnormality of the parathyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of the parathyroid gland

desc: A structural abnormality of the parathyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of the parathyroid morphology

desc: Hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland.
name: Parathyroid hyperplasia

desc: Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland.
name: Parathyroid dysgenesis

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the parathyroid gland.
name: Parathyroid hypoplasia

desc: Aplasia of the parathyroid gland.
name: Parathyroid agenesis

desc: An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland.
name: Ectopic parathyroid

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the parathyroid gland.
name: Neoplasm of the parathyroid gland

desc: A benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can cause hyperparathyroidism.
name: Parathyroid adenoma

desc: A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism.
name: Parathyroid carcinoma

desc: A functional abnormality of the parathyroid gland.
name: Abnormality of the parathyroid physiology

desc: A condition caused by a deficiency of parathyroid hormone characterized by hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
name: Hypoparathyroidism

desc: Deficiency of parathyroid hormone with congenital onset.
name: Congenital hypoparathyroidism

desc: A type of hypoparathyroidism with circulating antiparathyroid or anti-calcium sensing receptor antibodies indicative of autoimmunity.
name: Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism

desc: Excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.
name: Hyperparathyroidism

desc: Secondary hyperparathyroidism refers to the production of higher than normal levels of parathyroid hormone in the presence of hypocalcemia.
name: Secondary hyperparathyroidism

desc: A type of hyperparathyroidism caused by a primary abnormality of the parathyroid glands (e.g., adenoma, carcinoma, hyperplasia). Primary hyperparathyroidism is associated with hyercalcemia.
name: Primary hyperparathyroidism

desc: A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism.
name: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism

desc: A condition characterized by resistance to the action of parathyroid hormone, in which there is hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and (appropriately) high levels of parathyroid hormone.
name: Pseudohypoparathyroidism

desc: Abnormality of the adrenal glands, i.e., of the endocrine glands located at the top of the kindneys.
name: Abnormality of the adrenal glands

desc: Any structural anomaly of the adrenal glands.
name: Abnormality of adrenal morphology

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal glands.
name: Adrenal hypoplasia

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the adrenal medulla.
name: Adrenal medullary hypoplasia

desc: A type of adrenal hypoplasia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital adrenal hypoplasia

desc: The presence of large polyhedral cells with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm and enlarged nuclei in the adrenal cortex.
name: Adrenocortical cytomegaly

desc: Abnormal development of the adrenal gland.
name: Adrenal gland dysgenesis

desc: Absent development of the adrenal gland.
name: Adrenal gland agenesis

desc: Enlargement of the adrenal gland.
name: Adrenal hyperplasia

desc: A type of adrenal hyperplasia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

desc: Calcification within the adrenal glands.
name: Adrenal calcification

desc: Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.
name: Ectopic adrenal gland

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adrenal gland.
name: Neoplasm of the adrenal gland

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the adrenal cortex.
name: Neoplasm of the adrenal cortex

desc: A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone.
name: Adrenocortical carcinoma

desc: Adrenocortical adenomas are benign tumors of the adrenal cortex.
name: Adrenocortical adenoma

desc: An hormonally inactive adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that does not secrete excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.
name: Non-secretory adrenocortical adenoma

desc: An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.
name: Secretory adrenocortical adenoma

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the adrenal medulla.
name: Neoplasm of the adrenal medulla

desc: A functional abnormality of the adrenal glands.
name: Abnormality of adrenal physiology

desc: Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands.
name: Adrenal insufficiency

desc: Insufficient production of steroid hormones (primarily cortisol) by the adrenal glands as a result of a primary defect in the glands themselves.
name: Primary adrenal insufficiency

desc: Abnormally reduced levels of aldosterone.
name: Decreased circulating aldosterone level

desc: Abnormally reduced concentration of cortisol in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating cortisol level

desc: A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.
name: Central adrenal insufficiency

desc: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the ACTH receptor.
name: Adrenocorticotropin receptor defect

desc: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production.
name: Adrenocorticotropin deficient adrenal insufficiency

desc: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in corticotropin-releasing hormone production.
name: Corticotropin-releasing hormone deficient adrenal insufficiency

desc: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor.
name: Corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor defect

desc: Overproduction of the mineralocorticoid aldosterone by the adrenal cortex.
name: Hyperaldosteronism

desc: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.
name: Primary hyperaldosteronism

desc: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone.
name: Dexamethasone-suppressible primary hyperaldosteronism

desc: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids.
name: Glucocortocoid-insensitive primary hyperaldosteronism

desc: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by abnormally increased renin levels.
name: Secondary hyperaldosteronism

desc: Overproduction of the hormone of cortisol by the adrenal cortex, resulting in a characteristic combination of clinical symptoms termed Cushing syndrome, with truncal obesity, a round, full face, striae atrophicae and acne, muscle weakness, and other features.
name: Increased circulating cortisol level

desc: Hypercortisolemia associated with a primary defect of the adrenal gland leading to overproduction of cortisol.
name: Primary hypercortisolism

desc: Hypercortisolemia associated with a overproduction of ACTH (often from a tumor), leading secondarily to overproduction of cortisol.
name: Secondary hypercortisolism

desc: Increased concentration of 11-deoxycortisol in the circulation. 11-deoxycorticosterone, which is also known as simply deoxycorticosterone and 21-hydroxyprogesterone, is a steroid hormore that is produces in the adrenals and is a precursor to aldosterone.
name: Elevated serum 11-deoxycortisol

desc: A state of renal tubular unresponsiveness or resistance to the action of aldosterone.
name: Pseudohypoaldosteronism

desc: An abnormality of the renin-angiotensin system.
name: Abnormality of renin-angiotensin system

desc: An abnormally increased activity of the renin-angiotensin system, causing hypertension by a combination of volume excess and vasoconstrictor mechanisms.
name: Hyperactive renin-angiotensin system

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of renin in the blood, a central hormone in the control of blood pressure and various other physiological functions.
name: Abnormal circulating renin

desc: An increased level of renin in the blood.
name: Increased circulating renin level

desc: An decreased level of renin in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating renin level

desc: Abnormality of the pituitary gland (also known as hypophysis), which is an endocrine gland that protrudes from the bottom of the hypothalamus at the base of the brain. The pituitary gland secretes the hormones ACTH, TSH, PRL, GH, endorphins, FSH, LH, oxytocin, and antidiuretic hormone. The secretion of hormones from the anterior pituitary is under the strict control of hypothalamic hormones, and the posterior pituitary is essentially an extension of the hypothalamus, so that hypothalamus and pituitary gland may be regarded as a functional unit.
name: Abnormality of the hypothalamus-pituitary axis

desc: A state of excessive water intake and hypotonic (dilute) polyuria. Diabetes insipidus may be due to failure of vasopressin (AVP) release (central or neurogenic diabetes insipidus) or to a failure of the kidney to respond to AVP (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus).
name: Diabetes insipidus

desc: A form of diabetes insipidus caused by failure of the kidneys to respond to vasopressin (AVP).
name: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

desc: An abnormal concentration of a hormone in the blood.
name: Abnormal circulating hormone level

desc: A increased concentration of serotonin in the blood.
name: Increased serum serotonin

desc: An abnormal concentration of leptin in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating leptin level

desc: A decreased concentration of leptin in the blood.
name: Decreased serum leptin

desc: An increased concentration of leptin in the blood.
name: Increased serum leptin

desc: An abnormal concentration of corticotropin in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating adrenocorticotropin level
synonyms: Abnormality of circulating adrenocorticotropic hormone level

desc: An abnormal reduction in the concentration of corticotropin, also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating ACTH level

desc: An abnormal increased in the concentration of corticotropin, also known as adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), in the blood.
name: Increased circulating ACTH level

desc: An abnormal catecholamine concentration in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating catecholamine level

desc: An abnormal increase in catecholamine concentration in the blood.
name: Elevated circulating catecholamine level

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of a glucocorticoid in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating glucocorticoid level

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of cortisol in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating cortisol level

layperson: Paradoxical increased cortisol secretion on dexamethasone suppression test
name: Paradoxical increased cortisol secretion on dexamethasone suppression test

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of corticosterone in the blood.
name: Abnormal circulating corticosterone level

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of 18-Hydroxycorticosterone level in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal circulating 18-hydroxycorticosterone level

desc: A subnormal concentration of 18-Hydroxycorticosterone level in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased circulating 18-hydroxycortisone level

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration of 18-Hydroxycorticosterone level in the blood circulation.
name: Increased circulating 18-hydroxycortisone level

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of deoxycorticosterone in the blood. Deoxycorticosterone comprises 11-deoxycorticosterone and 21-deoxycorticosterone.
name: Abnormal circulating deoxycorticosterone level

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration of corticosterone in the blood.
name: Increased circulating corticosterone level

desc: An abnormally reduced concentration of corticosterone in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating corticosterone level

desc: A deviation from normal concentration of the hormone estrogen in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal circulating estrogen level

desc: A deviation from normal concentrations of estradiol in the circulation.
name: Abnormal serum estradiol

desc: A reduction below normal concentration of estradiol in the circulation.
name: Decreased serum estradiol

desc: An elevation above normal limits of the concentration of estradiol in the circulation.
name: Increased serum estradiol

desc: A deviation from normal concentration of estriol in the circulation.
name: Abnormal serum estriol

desc: An elevation above normal limits of estriol concentration in the circulation.
name: Increased serum estriol

desc: A reduction below normal limits of estriol in the circulation.
name: Decreased serum estriol

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of circulating estrone.
name: Abnormal serum estrone

desc: An elevation above normal limits of the concentration of estrone in the circulation.
name: Increased serum estrone

desc: A reduction below normal limits of the concentration of estrone in the circulation.
name: Decreased serum estrone

desc: An anomaly of the circulating level of a gonadotropin, that is, of a protein hormone secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary of vertebrates. The primary gonadotropins are luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
name: Abnormal circulating gonadotropin level

desc: A reduction of the circulating level of a gonadotropin, that is, of a protein hormone secreted by gonadotrope cells of the anterior pituitary of vertebrates. The primary gonadotropins are luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
name: Decreased circulating gonadotropin level

desc: A reduction of the circulating level of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
layperson: Decreased circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
name: Decreased circulating follicle stimulating hormone level

desc: A reduction in the circulating level of luteinizing hormone (LH).
name: Decreased circulating luteinizing hormone level

desc: An anomaly of the circulating level of luteinizing hormone (LH).
name: Abnormal circulating luteinizing hormone level

desc: An anomaly of the circulating level of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
name: Abnormal circulating follicle-stimulating hormone level

desc: An anomaly in the blood concentration of an androgen, that is, of a steroid hormone that controls development and maintenance of masculine characteristics. The androgens include testosterone and Dehydroepiandrosterone.
name: Abnormal circulating androgen level

desc: An anomalous concentration of testosterone in the blood.
name: Abnormal serum testosterone level

desc: An elevated circulating testosterone level in the blood.
name: Increased serum testosterone level

desc: An elevation of the blood concentration of an androgen, that is, of a steroid hormone that controls development and maintenance of masculine characteristics. The androgens include testosterone and Dehydroepiandrosterone.
name: Increased circulating androgen level

desc: Increased level of circulating 4-androstenedione.
name: Increased serum androstenedione

desc: A reduction in the blood concentration of an androgen, that is, of a steroid hormone that controls development and maintenance of masculine characteristics. The androgens include testosterone and Dehydroepiandrosterone.
name: Decreased circulating androgen level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of dehydroepiandrosterone in the circulation.
name: Abnormal serum dehydroepiandrosterone level

desc: An anomalous level of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF1) in the blood circulation.
layperson: Abnormal serum insulin-like growth factor 1 level
name: Abnormal serum insulin-like growth factor 1 level

desc: An elevated level of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF1) in the blood circulation.
name: Increased serum insulin-like growth factor 1

desc: A reduced level of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF1) in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased serum insulin-like growth factor 1

desc: A deviation from the normal circulating concentration of adiponectin, a 30-kDa complement C1-related protein that is the most abundant secreted protein expressed in adipose tissue, and that plays a crucial role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism.
name: Abnormal adiponectin level

desc: A reduced circulating concentration of adiponectin, a 30-kDa complement C1-related protein that is the most abundant secreted protein expressed in adipose tissue.
name: Decreased adiponectin level

desc: An elevated circulating concentration of adiponectin, a 30-kDa complement C1-related protein that is the most abundant secreted protein expressed in adipose tissue.
name: Increased adiponectin level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of glucagon in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal glucagon level

desc: An elevated concentration of glucagon in the blood circulation.
name: Increased glucagon level

desc: A reduced concentration of glucagon in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased glucagon level

desc: Increased blood concentration of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).
layperson: Elevated vascular endothelial growth factor level
name: Elevated vascular endothelial growth factor level

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of inhibins, which are heterodimeric protein hormones secreted by granulosa cells of the ovary in females and Sertoli cells of the testis in males. Inhibins suppress the secretion of pituitary follicle-stimulating hormone.
name: Abnormal circulating inhibin level

desc: A reduced concentration of inhibin B in the blood.
name: Decreased inhibin B level

desc: Any deviation from the normal range of the antimullerian hormone, a peptide produced by the granulosa cells of follicles. Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), also known as Mullerian inhibiting substance, is produced by the granulosa cells of small antral follicles of the ovary. AMH has an inhibiting role in the ovary, contributing to follicular arrest. AMH levels in women are low until the age of 8, rise rapidly until puberty and decline steadily from the age of 25 until menopause, when AMH production ceases.
name: Abnormal antimullerian hormone level

desc: An elevation above the normal range of the antimullerian hormone in the circulation.
name: Increased antimullerian hormone level

desc: A reduction below the normal range of the antimullerian hormone in the circulation.
name: Decreased antimullerian hormone level

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of pregnenolone in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating pregnenolone level

desc: An reduced concentration of progesterone in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating progesterone

desc: An increased level of 17-hydroxyprogesterone in the blood. 17-hydroxyprogesterone is an intermediate steroid in the adrenal biosynthetic pathway from cholesterol to cortisol and is the substrate for steroid 21-hydroxylase.
name: Elevated circulating 17-hydroxyprogesterone

desc: An elevated concentration of progesterone in the blood.
name: Increased circulating progesterone

desc: A reduced concentration of dehydroepiandrosterone-sulfate in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating dehydroepiandrosterone-sulfate level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of osteocalcin in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal circulating osteocalcin level

desc: An elevated level of osteocalcin in the blood.
name: Increased circulating osteocalcin level

desc: A reduced level of osteocalcin in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating osteocalcin level

desc: Any deviation from the normal level of growth hormone (GH) in the blood circulation. GH or somatotropin is a peptide hormone that stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and cell regeneration. Its secretion from the pituitary is regulated by the neurosecretory nuclei of the hypothalamus, which can release Growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH or somatocrinin) and Growth hormone-inhibiting hormone (GHIH or somatostatin) into the hypophyseal portal venous blood surrounding the pituitary. GH is secreted in a pulsatile manner, which is one of the reasons why an isolated measurement of its blood concentration is not meaningful.
name: Abnormal growth hormone level

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of circulating alpha polypeptide of glycoprotein hormones (NCBI Gene 1081).
layperson: Abnormal pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
name: Abnormal pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level

desc: An increased concentration of circulating alpha polypeptide of glycoprotein hormones (NCBI Gene 1081). This alpha subunit is common to luteinizing hormone (LH) , follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) , thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which are glycoprotein hormones composed of an identical alpha subunit together with a beta subunit that confers biological specificity. The alpha subunit is used as a marker for tumors that produce these hormones.
