layperson: Increased pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
name: Increased pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
synonyms: Increased pituitary glycoprotein alpha subunit level
Increased pituitary glycoprotein polypeptide alpha subunit level

desc: An reduced concentration of circulating alpha polypeptide of glycoprotein hormones (NCBI Gene 1081).
layperson: Decreased pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
name: Decreased pituitary glycoprotein hormone alpha subunit level
synonyms: Decreased pituitary glycoprotein alpha subunit level
Decreased pituitary glycoprotein polypeptide alpha subunit level

desc: An abnormal concentration of insulin in the body.
name: Abnormal insulin level

desc: An abnormal concentration of insulin in the blood.
name: Abnormal circulating insulin level

desc: An increased concentration of insulin in the blood.
name: Hyperinsulinemia

desc: An increased concentration of insulin combined with a decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
name: Hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia

desc: An increased concentration of insulin in the blood in the fasting state, i.e., not as the response to food intake.
layperson: High blood insulin levels while fasting
name: Fasting hyperinsulinemia
synonyms: High blood insulin levels while fasting

desc: A decreased concentration of insulin in the blood.
name: Hypoinsulinemia

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration in the blood circulation of a hormone that is involved in the regulation of phosphate and calcium.
name: Abnormal calcium-phosphate regulating hormone level
synonyms: Abnormal Ca2+ PO4 regulating hormone level

desc: An abnormal increased concentration of parathyroid hormone.
name: Elevated circulating parathyroid hormone level

desc: An abnormally decreased concentration of parathyroid hormone.
name: Decreased circulating parathyroid hormone level

desc: An elevated concentration of procalcitonin in the blood circulation.
name: Increased circulating procalcitonin level

desc: A deviation from the normal circulating concentration of the normal gonadotropin-releasing hormone level secreted from the pituitary gland.
name: Abnormality of gonadotropin-releasing hormone level

desc: Secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone that does not occur in a pulsatile fashion.
name: Lack of gonadotropin-releasing hormone pulsatility

desc: An abnormal concentration of gastrin in the blood.
name: Abnormal circulating gastrin level

desc: An elevated amount of gastrin in the blood.
name: Hypergastrinemia

desc: Passing the age when puberty normally occurs with no physical or hormonal signs of the onset of puberty.
name: Delayed puberty

desc: Occurence of adrenarche at a later than normal age. Adrenarche normally occurs between six and eight years of age with increased adrenal androgen secretion; its exact biologic role is not well understood. It is accompanied by changes in pilosebaceous units, a transient growth spurt and the appearance of axillary and pubic hair in some children, but no sexual development.
name: Delayed adrenarche

desc: Later than normal development of the breasts.
name: Delayed thelarche

desc: Adrenogenital syndrome is also known as congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which results from disorders of steroid hormone production in the adrenal glands leading to a deficiency of cortisol. The pituitary gland reacts by increased secretion of corticotropin, which in turn causes the adrenal glands to overproduce certain intermediary hormones which have testosterone-like effects.
name: Adrenogenital syndrome

desc: No secondary sexual characteristics are present at puberty.
name: Absence of secondary sex characteristics
synonyms: No secondary sexual characteristics at puberty

desc: Insufficient amount of androgenic activity.
name: Androgen insufficiency

desc: An early onset of puberty, in this case early does not refer to precocious.
name: Early onset of sexual maturation

desc: The onset of secondary sexual characteristics before a normal age. Although it is difficult to define normal age ranges because of the marked variation with which puberty begins in normal children, precocious puberty can be defined as the onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls or 9 years in boys.
name: Precocious puberty

desc: The onset of puberty before the age of 9 years in boys.
layperson: Early onset of puberty in males
name: Precocious puberty in males
synonyms: Early onset of puberty in males

desc: Premature development of the breasts.
name: Premature thelarche

desc: The onset of puberty before the age of 8 years in girls.
name: Precocious puberty in females

desc: The onset of growth of pubic hair at an earlier age than normal.
name: Premature pubarche

desc: Onset of adrenarche at an earlier age than usual.
name: Premature adrenarche

desc: An abnormal concentration of a hormone in the urine.
name: Abnormal urine hormone level

desc: An elevated concentration of a gonadotropin hormone (stimulating hormone or luteinizing hormone) in the urine, consistent with the diagnosis of primary hypogonadism.
name: High urinary gonadotropin level

desc: Abnormally increased concentration of cortisol in the urine.
name: Increased urinary cortisol level

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration of 11-deoxycortisol in the urine.
name: Increased urinary 11-deoxycortisol level

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration or amount of 11-deoxycorticosterone in the urine.
name: Increased urinary 11-deoxycorticosterone level

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration or amount of 11-deoxytetrahydrocorticosterone the urine.
name: Increased urinary 11-deoxytetrahydrocorticosterone level

desc: A function abnormality of the endocrine pancreas.
name: Abnormality of endocrine pancreas physiology

desc: An abnormality of the islet of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells. These are the alpha cells, which produce glucagon, the beta cells, which produce insulin and amylin, the delta cells, which produce somatostatin, the PP cells, which produce pancreatic polypeptide, and the epsilon cells, which produce ghrelin.
layperson: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells
name: Abnormality of the pancreatic islet cells

desc: Hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans, i.e., of the regions of the pancreas that contain its endocrine cells.
name: Pancreatic islet-cell hyperplasia

desc: Hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans that affects only certain regions of the pancreas and not others.
name: Focal pancreatic islet hyperplasia

desc: Hyperplasia of the islets of Langerhans with a generalized distribution.
name: Diffuse pancreatic islet hyperplasia

desc: Reduced number of beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans.
name: Reduced pancreatic beta cells

desc: An anomaly of the pineal gland,a small endocrine gland in the brain that produces melatonin.
name: Abnormality of the pineal gland

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of an organ ofthe endocrine system.
name: Abnormal endocrine morphology

desc: Any anomaly of the function of the endocrine system.
name: Abnormal endocrine physiology

desc: An anomalous response to a test that is designed to probe the function of the endocrine system.
layperson: Abnormal response to endocrine stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to endocrine stimulation test

desc: An anomolous response to stimulation by adminstration of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH stimulation normally stimulates the adrenal glands to release cortisol and adrenaline.
layperson: Abnormal response to ACTH stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to ACTH stimulation test
synonyms: Abnormal response to corticotropin stimulation test
Abnormal response to adrenocorticotropic-hormone stimulation test

desc: An anomalous response to the insulin tolerance test (ITT), in which insulin is administered intravenously and blood glucose and potentially other compounds are measured at intervals. Insulin administration is intended to induce extreme hypoglycemia (bloodgluoce below 40 mg/dl), which in turn induces release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and growth hormone (GH). ACTH induces the adrenal gland to release cortisol, which together with GH opposes the action of insulin on the blood glucose level.
layperson: Abnormal response to insulin tolerance test
name: Abnormal response to insulin tolerance test

desc: Failure of cortisol levels to respond adequately (by increasing) to the insulin tolerance test (ITT).
layperson: Impaired cortisol response to insulin stimulation test
name: Impaired cortisol response to insulin stimulation test

desc: Failure of growth hormone levels to respond adequately (by increasing) to the insulin tolerance test (ITT).
layperson: Impaired growth-hormone response to insulin stimulation test
name: Impaired growth-hormone response to insulin stimulation test

desc: An anomalous response to the corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) stimulation test. Normally,CRH is released by the hypothalamus to induce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) release by the anterior pituitary. In the stimulation test, CRH is administered intravenously and ACTH and cortisol are measured at intervals.
layperson: Abnormal response to corticotropin releasing hormone stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to corticotropin releasing hormone stimulation test
synonyms: Abnormal response to CRH stimulation test

desc: Failure of cortisol levels to respond adequately (by increasing) to the corticotropin releasing hormone stimulation test.
layperson: Impaired cortisol response to corticotropin releasing hormone stimulation test
name: Impaired cortisol response to corticotropin releasing hormone stimulation test

desc: An abnormal response to the gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation test. This test typically involves intravenous administration of GnRH followed by repeated blood sampling at various time points to measure the levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
layperson: Abnormal response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test
synonyms: Abnormal response to GnRH stimulation test

desc: Failure of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) stimulation test to induce an appropriate increased in luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels.
layperson: Reduced response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test
name: Reduced response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test
synonyms: Reduce response to GnRH stimulation test

desc: An abnormally high amount of luteinizing hormone (LH) is released upon gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test.
layperson: Increased LH response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test
name: Increased LH response to gonadotropin-releasing hormone stimulation test

desc: An anomalous response to the glucagon stimulation test, which like the insulin tolerance test (ITT) stimulates the release of both adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and growth hormone (GH).
layperson: Abnormal response to glucagon stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to glucagon stimulation test

desc: Failure of cortisol levels to respond adequately (by increasing) to the glucagon stimulation test.
layperson: Impaired cortisol response to glucagon stimulation test
name: Impaired cortisol response to glucagon stimulation test

desc: Failure of growth hormone levels to respond adequately (by increasing) to the glucagon stimulation test.
layperson: Impaired growth-hormone response to glucagon stimulation test
name: Impaired growth-hormone response to glucagon stimulation test

desc: An abnormally high increase in insulin levels following a glucagon stimulation test.
layperson: Excessive insulin response to glucagon test
name: Excessive insulin response to glucagon test

desc: An anomalous response to intravenous stimulation by human chorionic gonadotrophin. Stimulation with hCG stimulates testicular Leydig cells to secrete androgens via the Leydig hormone receptors.
layperson: Abnormal response to human chorionic gonadotrophin stimulation test
name: Abnormal response to human chorionic gonadotrophin stimulation test
synonyms: Abnormal response to hCG stimulation test

desc: A state of increased circulating antidiuretic hormone despite hyponatremia and hypo-osmolality with normal or increased plasma volume.
name: Inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
synonyms: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the endocrine system.
name: Neoplasm of the endocrine system

desc: An endocrine tumor arising from an APUD cell.
name: APUdoma
synonyms: Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation tumours

desc: A malignant cutaneous tumor of the elderly that is characterized by an aggressive course with regional nodal involvement, distant metastases and a high rate of recurrence. Most patients present with rapidly growing, painless, firm, non-tender, dome-shaped red, occasionally ulcerated skin nodules, which have a red or bluish color, measuring up to several centimeters, on predominantly sun-exposed areas of the body. The overlying skin is smooth and shiny, sometimes exhibiting ulcerative, acneiform or telangiectatic features.
name: Merkel cell skin cancer
synonyms: Primary undifferentiated carcinoma of the skin
Merkel cell cancer of the skin
Primary small cell carcinoma of the skin

desc: Abnormal calcification in the cardiovascular system.
name: Cardiovascular calcification

desc: Abnormal calcification of the vasculature.
name: Vascular calcification

desc: Pathological deposition of calcium salts in one or more arteries.
name: Arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in a coronary artery.
name: Coronary artery calcification

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts, affecting arteries distributed throughout the body.
name: Generalized arterial calcification

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the aorta.
name: Calcification of the aorta

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the thoracic aorta.
name: Thoracic aorta calcification

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the arch of aorta.
name: Aortic arch calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in abdominal aorta.
name: Abdominal aortic calcification

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of arteries.
name: Medial arterial calcification

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of large (conduit) arteries.
name: Medial calcification of large arteries

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of medium-sized (muscular or distributive) arteries.
name: Medial calcification of medium-sized arteries

desc: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the tunica media of small arteries.
name: Medial calcification of small arteries

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall.
name: Peripheral arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall of the leg.
name: Lower extremity peripheral arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall of the femoral artery.
name: Femoral arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall of the iliac artery.
name: Iliac arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall of the tibial artery.
name: Tibial arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in an artery that is located within the skull (intracranial).
name: Intracranial arterial calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the internal carotid artery.
name: Internal carotid artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the vertebral artery.
name: Vertebral artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in a cerebral artery.
name: Cerebral artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the middle cerebral artery.
name: Middle cerebral artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the basilar artery.
name: Basilar artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in a carotid artery.
name: Carotid artery calcification

desc: An accumulation of calcium and phosphate in arteries with mineral deposits in the intimal or medial layer of the vessel wall in the external carotid artery.
name: External carotid artery calcification

desc: Abnormal calcification of a cardiac valve.
name: Cardiac valve calcification

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in the aortic valve.
name: Aortic valve calcification

desc: Abnormal calcification of the mitral valve.
name: Mitral valve calcification

desc: Mitral annular calcification (MAC) results from progressive calcium deposition along and beneath the mitral valve annulus.
name: Mitral annular calcification

layperson: Early progressive calcific cardiac valvular disease
name: Early progressive calcific cardiac valvular disease

desc: Calcium deposition in the myocardium.
name: Myocardial calcification

desc: Calcified deposits in soft tissue structures outside a joint.
name: Periarticular calcification

desc: Deposition of calcium in the skin.
name: Calcinosis cutis

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs.
name: Anterior rib punctate calcifications

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in muscle tissue.
name: Calcification of muscles

desc: Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax.
name: Costal cartilage calcification

desc: An abnormality of the form, structure, or size of the skeletal system.
name: Abnormality of skeletal morphology

desc: An abnormal structure or form of the joints, i.e., one or more of the articulations where two bones join.
name: Abnormal joint morphology

desc: Pterygia are 'winglike' triangular membranes occurring in the neck, eyes, knees, elbows, ankles or digits.
name: Pterygium

desc: Presence of a cutaneous membrane (flap) in the armpit.
name: Axillary pterygium

desc: A pterygium (or pterygia) occurring in the popliteal region (the back of the knee).
name: Popliteal pterygium

desc: A pterygium (or pterygia) in the intercrural (groin) region.
name: Intercrural pterygium

desc: Pterygia affecting the neck.
name: Neck pterygia

desc: Pterygium affecting the elbow. This is a cutaneous web that can lead to severe flexion contracture of the elbow joint. Antecubital pterygium can be unilateral, bilateral, symmetric, or asysmmetric.
name: Antecubital pterygium

desc: Inflammation of a joint.
name: Arthritis

desc: Inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures with widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, as well as atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures.
name: Rheumatoid arthritis

desc: Recurrent attacks of acute inflammatory arthritis of a joint or set of joints caused by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood which crystallize and are deposited in joints, tendons, and surrounding tissues.
name: Gout

desc: Gout affecting the Metatarsophalangeal joint of big toe.
name: Podagra

desc: Degeneration (wear and tear) of articular cartilage, i.e., of the joint surface. Joint degeneration may be accompanied by osteophytes (bone overgrowth), narrowing of the joint space, regions of sclerosis at the joint surface, or joint deformity.
name: Osteoarthritis

layperson: Osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand
name: Osteoarthritis of the small joints of the hand

layperson: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint
name: Osteoarthritis of the first carpometacarpal joint

layperson: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint
name: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint

desc: Inflammation of the sacroiliac joint, generally accompanied by lower back pain.
name: Sacroiliac arthritis

desc: Degeneration (wear and tear) of the articular cartilage of the neck joints.
name: Cervical osteoarthritis

desc: An inflammatory arthritis characterized by purulent synovial fluid with neutrophil accumulation, but with negative cultures.
name: Sterile arthritis

desc: A type of arthritis that affects up to four joints in the first six months of disease.
name: Oligoarthritis

desc: Displacement or malalignment of joints.
name: Joint dislocation

desc: Dislocation of many joints.
name: Multiple joint dislocation

desc: Displacement or malalignment of one or more joints in the upper extremity (arm).
name: Upper extremity joint dislocation

desc: Dislocation of the distal humerus out of the elbow joint, where the radius, ulna, and humerus meet.
name: Elbow dislocation

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint.
name: Dislocated radial head

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterolateral direction.
name: Anterolateral radial head dislocation

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an proximal direction.
name: Proximal radial head dislocation

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an anterior direction.
name: Anterior radial head dislocation

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an posterior direction.
name: Posterior radial head dislocation

desc: A dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint in an ulnar direction.
name: Ulnar radial head dislocation

desc: A displacement or misalignment of the humerus with respect to the other bones of the should joint. Note that a subluxation is a partial dislocation.
name: Shoulder dislocation

desc: Shoulder dislocation occurring repeated times.
name: Recurrent shoulder dislocation

desc: An injury of the wrist with displacement of any of the eight carpal bones.
name: Dislocated wrist

desc: Displacement or malalignment of one or more joints in the lower extremity (leg).
name: Lower extremity joint dislocation

desc: Displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint.
name: Hip dislocation

desc: The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar dislocation occurs if the patella fully dislocates out of the groove.
name: Patellar dislocation

desc: Patellar dislocation occurring repeated times.
name: Recurrent patellar dislocation

desc: Joint dislocation of the femoral head.
name: Dislocation of the femoral head

desc: Dislocation of a given joint repeated times.
name: Recurrent joint dislocation

desc: Increase in size of one or more joints.
name: Enlarged joints

desc: Bony swelling of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically.
name: Heberden's node

desc: Bony swelling of the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) associated with the formation of osteophytes (calcific spurs) of the articular (joint) cartilage that are visible radiographically.
name: Bouchard's node

desc: Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
name: Joint hemorrhage

desc: An abnormality of the hip joint.
name: Abnormality of the hip joint

desc: An abnormality of the acetabulum, i.e., the Acetabular part of hip bone, which together with the head of the femur forms the hip joint.
name: Abnormality of the acetabulum

desc: Intrapelvic bulging of the medial acetabular wall.
name: Protrusio acetabuli

desc: Flattening of the superior part of the acetabulum, which is a cup-shaped cavity at the base of the hipbone into which the ball-shaped head of the femur fits. The acetabular roof thereby appears horizontal rather than arched, as it normally does.
name: Flat acetabular roof

desc: Underdeveloped acetabulae.
name: Hypoplastic acetabulae

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the acetabular part of hip bone.
name: Acetabular dysplasia

desc: The presence of osteophytes (bone spurs), i.e., of bony projections originating from the acetabulum.
name: Acetabular spurs

desc: An exaggeration of the normal arched form of the acetabular roof such that it takes on a steep appearance.
name: Steep acetabular roof

desc: A partial dislocation of the hip joint, whereby the head of the femur is partially displaced from the socket.
name: Hip subluxation

desc: Femoroacetabular impingement (FAI) results from one or more bony abnormalities that lead to abnormal contact between the acetabulum and the femoral head or neck. The femoral abnormality is proposed to cause compression and shear stresses in the region between the labrum and cartilage, anterosuperiorly. These stresses cause a separation between the labrum and cartilage as the labrum is pushed outwards and the cartilage is pushed centrally. This eventually leads to articular degeneration and eventually global hip osteoarthritis.
name: Femoroacetabular impingement

desc: Interphalangeal joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in the interphalangeal joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff interphalangeal joints
Abnormality of upper limb joint
synonyms: Abnormality of the joints of the upper limbs

desc: Abnormality of the wrist, the structure connecting the hand and the forearm.
name: Abnormality of the wrist

desc: An abnormality affecting the carpal bones of the wrist (scaphoid, lunate, triquetral, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate).
name: Abnormality of the carpal bones

desc: Osteolysis affecting carpal bones.
name: Carpal osteolysis

desc: The presence of more than the normal number of carpal bones.
name: Accessory carpal bones

desc: Underdevelopment of the scaphoid.
name: Small scaphoid

desc: Formation of bone tissue of scaphoid is less than expected for age.
name: Delayed ossification of the scaphoid

desc: Osseous fusion of the lunate and triquetrum.
name: Lunate-triquetral fusion

desc: Morbus Kienboeck is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os lunatum.
name: Morbus Kienboeck

desc: An anomaly of trapezium.
name: Abnormality of the trapezium

desc: Underdevelopment of the trapezium.
name: Small trapezium

desc: Formation of bone tissue of trapezium is less than expected for age.
name: Delayed ossification of the trapezium

desc: Underdevelopment of the trapezoid.
name: Small trapezoid bone

layperson: Abnormal ossification of the trapezoid bone
name: Abnormal ossification of the trapezoid bone

desc: Formation of bone tissue of trapezoid is less than expected for age.
layperson: Delayed ossification of the trapezoid bone
name: Delayed ossification of the trapezoid bone
synonyms: Delayed maturation of the trapezoid bone

desc: Carpal bones with irregular or fragmented margins.
name: Irregular carpal bones

desc: Increased size of carpal bones.
name: Large carpal bones

desc: Malalignement of carpal bone angles either with respect to each other, to the corresponding metacarpals or with respect to the wrist (radius and ulna).
name: Malaligned carpal bone

desc: Ossification of carpal bones occurs later than age-adjusted norms.
name: Delayed ossification of carpal bones
Severe carpal ossification delay
synonyms: Severe delay in maturation of wrist bone

desc: Ossification of carpal bones at an abnormally early age.
name: Advanced ossification of carpal bones

desc: A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones.
name: Multiple carpal ossification centers

layperson: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth
name: Two carpal ossification centers present at birth
synonyms: Two carpal ossification centres present at birth

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the carpal bones.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the carpal bones

desc: Underdevelopment of one or more carpal bones.
name: Carpal bone hypoplasia

desc: Congenital absence of a carpal bone.
name: Carpal bone aplasia

desc: Congenital absence of the scaphoid..
name: Absent scaphoid

desc: Synostosis (bony fusion) involving one or more bones of the carpus (scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate, pisiform).
name: Carpal synostosis

layperson: Partial fusion of proximal row of carpal bones
name: Partial fusion of proximal row of carpal bones
synonyms: Partial fusion of innermost row of wrist bones

desc: Fusion involving carpal and metacarpal bones.
layperson: Fused wrist bones and long bones of hand
name: Carpometacarpal synostosis
synonyms: Fused wrist bones and long bones of hand

desc: Fusion of the second metacarpal-trapezoid.
name: Synostosis of second metacarpal-trapezoid

desc: A chronic loss of wrist joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the wrist.
name: Wrist flexion contracture

desc: A chronic loss of wrist joint motion on the right and left sides.
name: Bilateral wrist flexion contracture

desc: A chronic loss of wrist joint motion on one side only.
name: Unilateral wrist flexion contracture

desc: An anomaly related to partial closure, or failure of development of the ulnar side of the distal radial growth plate, which results in an arrest of epiphyseal growth of the medial and volar portions of the distal radius. This leads to shortening of the radius and relative overgrowth of the ulna.
name: Madelung deformity

desc: An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the wrist.
name: Limited wrist movement

desc: A benign soft tissue tumor of the wrist usually found in the dorsal aspect of the wrist and communicate with the joint via a pedicle. This pedicle usually originates not only at the scapholunate ligament, but also may arise from a number of other sites over the dorsal aspect of the wrist capsule.
name: Wrist ganglion

desc: Contractures of one ore more joints of the hands meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
name: Joint contracture of the hand

desc: An abnormality of the hand resulting from contracture of the palmar fascia with a fixed flexion deformity of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.
name: Dupuytren contracture

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in a finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
name: Flexion contracture of finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in an interphalangeal joint of a finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
name: Interphalangeal joint contracture of finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio interphalangealis pollicis.
layperson: Contractures of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb
name: Contractures of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in one or more distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the fingers

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the outermost hinge joint of the 3rd finger
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger
synonyms: Contracture of the outermost hinge joint of the 3rd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
name: Camptodactyly of finger
synonyms: Flexion contractures of proximal interphalangeal joints
Contractures of the proximal interphalangeal joints of the fingers

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the second to fifth fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
name: Camptodactyly of 2nd-5th fingers

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th fingers due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of proximal interphalangeal joints of 2nd-5th fingers
name: Contracture of proximal interphalangeal joints of 2nd-5th fingers

desc: Multiple bent (flexed) finger joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Congenital finger flexion contractures

desc: Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) flexion deformity of the little finger. That is, the PIP joint of a little finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. That is, the PIP joint of a fourth finger is bent (flexed) and cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 5th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
name: Joint contracture of the 5th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 5th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 5th finger
name: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 5th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 4th finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
name: Joint contracture of the 4th finger
synonyms: Joint contractures of the fourth finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 4th finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 4th finger
name: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 4th finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 3rd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
name: Joint contracture of the 3rd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 3rd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 3rd finger
name: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 3rd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly of the 2nd finger is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
name: Flexion contracture of the 2nd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 2nd finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 2nd finger
name: Contracture of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the 2nd finger

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The term camptodactyly is used if the distal and/or proximal interphalangeal joints are affected.
name: Flexion contracture of thumb

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is formed by the first metacarpal and the trapezial bone and is also called Articulatio carpometacarpalis pollicis, carpometacarpal articulation of thumb, carpometacarpal joint of thumb or first carpometacarpal articulation. Seldom referred to as thumb saddle joint.
layperson: Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb
name: Contractures of the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. This joint is also called Articulatio metacarpophalangealis pollicis.
layperson: Contractures of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb
name: Contractures of the metacarpophalangeal joint of the thumb

desc: Limitation of wrist and finger extension on asking patient to form a prayer sign. This is a result of progressive wrist and finger flexion contractures.
name: Bethlem sign

desc: An anomaly of the joint that connects the upper and the lower arm.
name: Abnormality of the elbow

desc: Abnormal positioning in which the elbows are turned out.
name: Cubitus valgus

desc: Limited ability to straighten the arm at the elbow joint.
name: Limited elbow extension

desc: A chronic loss of elbow joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the elbow.
name: Elbow flexion contracture
synonyms: Fixed flexion at the elbow joint

desc: A limitation of the ability to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces anteriorly (supination) and to place the forearm in a position such that the palm faces posteriorly (pronation).
name: Limited pronation/supination of forearm

desc: An abnormal increase in the carrying angle, which is the angle he long axis of the extended forearm as it lies lateral to the long axis of the arm.
name: Increased carrying angle

desc: An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the radius and the humerus.
layperson: Fusion of upper and lower arm bones
name: Humeroradial synostosis
synonyms: Fusion of upper and lower arm bones

desc: An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the ulna and the humerus.
name: Humeroulnar synostosis

layperson: Abnormality of the joint spaces of the elbow
name: Abnormality of the joint spaces of the elbow
synonyms: Abnormality of the joint spaces of the elbow

layperson: Narrow joint spaces of the elbow
name: Narrow joint spaces of the elbow
synonyms: Narrow joint spaces of the elbow

layperson: Irregular articular surfaces of the elbow joints
name: Irregular articular surfaces of the elbow joints

layperson: Abnormality of end part of the elbow bone
name: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the elbow
synonyms: Abnormality of end part of the elbow bone

desc: A delay in the process of formation and maturation of the epiphysis of one or more long bones that are part of the elbow.
layperson: Delayed maturation of the end part of the elbow bone
name: Delayed elbow epiphyseal ossification
synonyms: Delayed maturation of the end part of the elbow bone

layperson: Irregular end part of the elbow bone
name: Irregular epiphyses of the elbow
synonyms: Irregular end part of the elbow bone

desc: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the radius.
layperson: Abnormality of the proximal radial epiphysis
name: Abnormality of the proximal radial epiphysis

desc: Absence of the proximal radial epiphysis.
name: Absent proximal radial epiphyses

desc: Any abnormality of the distal epiphysis of the humerus.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the outermost long bone in upper arm
name: Abnormality of the distal humeral epiphysis
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the outermost long bone in upper arm

desc: Any abnormality of the proximal epiphysis of the ulna.
layperson: Abnormality of the proximal ulnar epiphysis
name: Abnormality of the proximal ulnar epiphysis

layperson: Abnormal wide portion of elbow bone
name: Abnormality of the elbow metaphyses
synonyms: Abnormal wide portion of elbow bone

layperson: Flared wide portion of elbow bone
name: Flared elbow metaphyses
synonyms: Flared wide portion of elbow bone

desc: Irregularity of the normally smooth surface of the metaphysis at the distal end of the humerus (at the elbow).
layperson: Irregular wide portion of elbow bone
name: Distal humeral metaphyseal irregularity
synonyms: Irregular wide portion of elbow bone

layperson: Sclerotic foci of metaphyses of the elbow
name: Sclerotic foci of metaphyses of the elbow
synonyms: Vertical linear mixed lucent and sclerotic pattern of metaphyses

desc: A deformity of the elbow in which there is a deviation of the forearm toward the midline of the body.
name: Cubitus varus

desc: Abnormal increased size of the elbow joint.
name: Large elbow

desc: An anomaly of the joint between the trochlear notch of ulna and the trochlea of humerus, which is part of the elbow joint.
name: Abnormality of the humeroulnar joint

desc: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the upper limbs.
layperson: Fusion involving bones of the upper limbs
name: Synostosis involving bones of the upper limbs
synonyms: Fusion involving bones of the upper limbs

desc: An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the radius and the ulna.
name: Radioulnar synostosis

desc: An abnormal osseous union (fusion) between the proximal portions of the radius and the ulna.
name: Proximal radio-ulnar synostosis

desc: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the hand.
layperson: Synostosis involving bones of the hand
name: Synostosis involving bones of the hand

desc: An abnormal union between bones or parts of bones of the fingers. The synonymous term "symphalangism of the hand" may be translated as fusions of bones of varying digree, that involve at least one phalangeal bone of the hand. If bony fusions are referred to as "Symphalangism" the fusion occurs in a proximo-distal axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a radio-ulnar axis are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly.
name: Finger symphalangism
synonyms: Synostosis involving bones of the fingers

desc: The term distal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the distal and middle phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the distal interphalangeal joint (DIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the distal interphalangeal finger creases.
name: Distal symphalangism of hands
synonyms: Symphalangism affecting the distal phalanges of the hand

desc: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger.
layperson: Fused end and middle bones of pinky finger
name: Distal/middle symphalangism of 5th finger
synonyms: Fused end and middle bones of pinkie finger
Fused end and middle bones of little finger
Fused end and middle bones of pinky finger
Symphalangism of the terminal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger
Fusion of the terminal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger
Symphalangism of the distal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger
Fifth finger distal interphalangeal joint symphalangism

desc: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger.
layperson: Fused outermost and middle bones of ring finger
name: Distal/middle symphalangism of 4th finger
synonyms: Fused outermost and middle bones of ring finger
Symphalangism of the distal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger

desc: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 3rd finger.
layperson: Fused outermost and middle bones of middle finger
name: Distal/middle symphalangism of 3rd finger
synonyms: Fused outermost and middle bones of middle finger
Symphalangism of the distal and middle phalanges of the 3rd finger

desc: Fusion of the terminal/distal and middle phalanges of the 2nd finger.
layperson: Fused outermost and middle index finger bones
name: Distal/middle symphalangism of 2nd finger
synonyms: Fused outermost and middle index finger bones
Symphalangism of the distal and middle phalanges of the 2nd finger

desc: Congenital fusion (ankylosis) of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.
name: Symphalangism of the thumb
synonyms: Symphalangism of the distal and proximal phalanges of the thumb

desc: Fusion of two or more bones of the 4th finger.
name: Symphalangism of the 4th finger

desc: Fusion of the middle phalanx of the 4th finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused middle bone of ring finger
name: Symphalangism of middle phalanx of 4th finger
synonyms: Fused middle bone of ring finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 4th finger.
layperson: Fused innermost and middle bone of fourth finger
name: Proximal/middle symphalangism of 4th finger
synonyms: Fused innermost and middle bone of fourth finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of ring finger
name: Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of ring finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger with the 4th metacarpal.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of ring finger with 4th long bone of hand
name: Symphalangism of the proximal phalanx of the 4th finger with the 4th metacarpal
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of ring finger with 4th long bone of hand

desc: Fusion of two or more bones of the 5th finger.
name: Symphalangism of the 5th finger

desc: Fusion of the middle phalanx of the 5th finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused middle bones of pinkie finger
name: Symphalangism of middle phalanx of 5th finger
synonyms: Fused middle bones of pinky finger
Fused middle bones of pinkie finger
Fused middle bones of little finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger.
layperson: Fused innermost and middle bones of pinkie finger
name: Proximal/middle symphalangism of 5th finger
synonyms: Symphalangism of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 5th finger
Fused innermost and middle bones of pinkie finger
Fused innermost and middle bones of little finger
Fused innermost and middle bones of pinky finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of pinky finger
name: Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of pinky finger
Fused innermost bone of little finger
Fused innermost bone of pinkie finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger with the 5th metacarpal.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of pinky finger with 5th long bone of hand
name: Symphalangism of the proximal phalanx of the 5th finger with the 5th metacarpal
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of little finger with 5th long bone of hand
Fused innermost bone of pinky finger with 5th long bone of hand
Fused innermost bone of pinkie finger with 5th long bone of hand

desc: Fusion of a metacarpal bone with the proximal phalanx of the finger distal to it across the corresponding metacarpophalangeal joint.
layperson: Fused long bone of hand with innermost finger bone
name: Metacarpophalangeal synostosis
synonyms: Fused long bone of hand with innermost finger bone

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger with the 3rd metacarpal.
layperson: Fused innermost bones of middle finger with middle long bone of hand
name: Symphalangism of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger with the 3rd metacarpal
synonyms: Fused innermost bones of middle finger with middle long bone of hand

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger with the 2nd metacarpal.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of index finger with 2nd long bone of hand
name: Symphalangism of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger with the 2nd metacarpal
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of index finger with 2nd long bone of hand

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal.
layperson: Fusion of the innermost bone of the thumb with the 1st long bone of hand
name: Synostosis of the proximal phalanx of the thumb with the 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Fusion of the innermost bone of the thumb with the 1st long bone of hand

desc: The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.
name: Proximal symphalangism of hands

desc: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 3rd finger.
layperson: Fused of innermost and middle bones of middle finger
name: Proximal/middle symphalangism of 3rd finger
synonyms: Fused of innermost and middle bones of middle finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal and middle phalanges of the 2nd finger.
layperson: Fused innermost and middle index finger bones
name: Proximal/middle symphalangism of the 2nd finger
synonyms: Fused innermost and middle index finger bones

desc: Fusion of two or more bones of the 3rd finger.
name: Symphalangism of the 3rd finger

desc: Fusion of the middle phalanx of the 3rd finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused middle bone of middle finger
name: Symphalangism of middle phalanx of 3rd finger
synonyms: Fused middle bone of middle finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of middle finger
name: Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanx of the 3rd finger
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of middle finger

desc: Fusion of the middle phalanx of the 2nd finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused middle bone of index finger
name: Symphalangism of middle phalanx of 2nd finger
synonyms: Fused middle bone of index finger

desc: Fusion of the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger with another bone.
layperson: Fused innermost bone of index finger
name: Symphalangism affecting the proximal phalanx of the 2nd finger
synonyms: Fused innermost bone of index finger

desc: Fusion involving two or more metacarpal bones (A synostosis of the first metacarpal and the proximal phalanx of the thumb can also be observed, note that the first metacarpal bone corresponds to a proximal phalanx).
name: Metacarpal synostosis

desc: Fusion of the 1st metacarpal with another bone. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2 to 5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.
layperson: Fusion involving 1st long bone of hand
name: Synostosis involving the 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Fusion involving 1st long bone of hand

name: Synostosis involving the 2nd metacarpal
synonyms: Fusion involving the 2nd long bone of hand

synonyms: Fusion of shoulder blade to long bone in upper arm

desc: A lump detected in the region that surrounds a joiny. In this context, mass is a general term for a lump or growth that may be caused by the abnormal growth of cells, a cyst, hormonal changes, or an immune reaction.
name: Periarticular soft-tissue mass

desc: A partial dislocation of a joint.
name: Joint subluxation

desc: Partial dislocation of the head of the radius.
name: Radial head subluxation

desc: Partial dislocation of the head of the radius in the posterior direction.
name: Posterior subluxation of radial head

desc: A partial dislocation of one or more intervertebral joints in the cervical vertebral column.
name: Cervical subluxation

desc: A partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joints.
name: C1-C2 subluxation

desc: A partial dislocation of the intervertebral joint between the second and third cervical vertebrae.
name: C2-C3 subluxation

desc: A partial dislocation of the shoulder joint.
name: Shoulder subluxation

desc: A partial dislocation of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the little finger.

name: Subluxation of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the little finger

Partially dislocated innermost hinge joint of pinkie finger
Partially dislocated innermost hinge joint of little finger

desc: A partial dislocation of some or all of the small joints of the hand.
layperson: Partial dislocation of small joints of hand
name: Subluxation of the small joints of the hand
synonyms: Partial dislocation of small joints of hand

desc: A partial dislocation affecting some or all of the metacarpophalangeal joints.
name: Subluxation of metacarpal phalangeal joints

desc: Abnormal growth ossification centers in children. Initially a degeneration/ necrosis followed by regeneration or recalcification.
name: Osteochondrosis

desc: A joint disorder caused by blood deprivation in the subchondral bone causing the subchondral bone to die in a process called avascular necrosis. The bone is then reabsorbed by the body, leaving the articular cartilage it supported prone to damage. The result is fragmentation (dissection) of both cartilage and bone, and the free movement of these osteochondral fragments within the joint space, causing pain and further damage.
name: Osteochondritis Dissecans

desc: The abnormal fusion of neighboring bones across a joint.
name: Synostosis of joints

desc: A developmental defect leading to the union of two adjacent vertebrae.
name: Vertebral fusion

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by a joining (fusion) of two or more cervical vertebral bodies with one another.
name: Fused cervical vertebrae

desc: Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C2 and C3, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development, leading to a short neck with a low hairline at the back of the head, and restricted mobility of the upper spine.
name: Cervical C2/C3 vertebral fusion

desc: Fusion of the C5 and C6 cervical vertebrae.
name: Cervical C5/C6 vertebrae fusion

desc: Fusion of cervical vertebrae at C3 and C4, caused by a failure in the normal segmentation or division of the cervical vertebrae during the early weeks of fetal development.
name: Cervical C3/C4 vertebral fusion

desc: Congenital synostosis between two or more adjacent vertebrae (partial or complete fusion of adjacent vertabral bodies).
name: Block vertebrae

desc: Bony fusion of the posterior part of the L5 vertebral body with the sacrum.
name: Posterior fusion of lumbosacral vertebrae

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by a joining (fusion) of two or more thoracic vertebral bodies with one another.
name: Fused thoracic vertebrae

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by a joining (fusion) of two or more lumbar vertebral bodies with one another.
name: Fused lumbar vertebrae

desc: A congenital anomaly, in which the transverse process of the last lumbar vertebra (L5) fuses to the sacrum on one side or both, or to ilium, or both.
layperson: Sacralization of the fifth lumbar vertebra

desc: The carpus consists of the scaphoid, lunate, triquetal, pisiform, captitate, hamate, trapezoid, and trapezium bones. The tarsus consists of the talus, calcaneus, navicular, cuboid, cuneiform, and navicular bones. This term applies if there is any fusion among the bones of the carpus or tarsus.
name: Synostosis of carpals/tarsals
synonyms: Fusion of carpal and tarsal bones
Coalescence of carpal and tarsal bones

name: Abnormality of lower limb joint
synonyms: Abnormality of the joints of the lower limbs

desc: An abnormality of the knee joint or surrounding structures.
name: Abnormality of the knee

desc: The legs angle inward, such that the knees are close together and the ankles far apart.
name: Genu valgum

desc: The appearance of abnormal valgus deformity in one knee in association with varus deformity in the other.
name: Wind-swept deformity of the knees

desc: A positional abnormality marked by outward bowing of the legs in which the knees stay wide apart when a person stands with the feet and ankles together.
name: Genu varum

desc: Abnormality of the patella (knee cap).
name: Abnormal patella morphology

desc: An alteration of the normally relatively smooth margins of the kneecap in radiographic images leading to an irregular contour.
name: Irregular patellae

desc: Formation of bone in the patella later than normal.
name: Delayed patellar ossification
synonyms: Delayed bone maturation of the knee cap

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the patella.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the patella

desc: Underdevelopment of the patella.
name: Patellar hypoplasia

desc: Absence of the patella.
name: Patellar aplasia

desc: A developmental defect that occurs if the two halves of the patella fail to fuse in early childhood.
name: Bipartite patella

desc: The kneecap normally is located within the groove termed trochlea on the distal femur and can slide up and down in it. Patellar subluxation refers to an unstable kneecap that does not slide centrally within its groove, i.e., a partial dislocation of the patella.
name: Patellar subluxation

desc: An anomaly of the patella characterized by two layers visible on lateral knee X-ray such that one layer is in front of the other in the sagittal orientation (See Figure 2A and 3B of PMID:12966518). This finding persists into adulthood.
name: Double-layered patella

desc: A limited ability of the knee joint extension and flexion.
name: Limited knee flexion/extension

layperson: Flattened end part of knee bone
name: Flattened knee epiphyses
synonyms: Flattened end part of knee bone

desc: A bent (flexed) knee joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Knee flexion contracture

desc: The ability of the knee joint to extend beyond its normal range of motion (the lower leg is moved beyond a straight position with respect to the thigh).
name: Hyperextensibility of the knee

desc: An abnormally increased extension of the knee joint, so that the knee can bend backwards.
name: Genu recurvatum

desc: The ability of the knee to move past its normal range of motion, (knee hyperextension is greater than 10 degrees).
name: Knee joint hypermobility

desc: An abnormal limitation of knee joint mobility.
name: Limitation of knee mobility

desc: Abnormally increased size of the knee joint.
name: Large knee

desc: A fluid-filled mass that is a distention of a preexisting bursa in the popliteal fossa, most commonly the gastrocnemio-semimembranosus bursa. This bursa is unique in that it communicates with the knee joint, unlike other periarticular bursae, via an opening in the joint capsule posterior to the medial femoral condyle.
name: Popliteal synovial cyst

desc: Abnormal structure of the meniscus of the knee, two crescent shape fibrocartilaginous pads that disperse the weight of the body and reduce friction of the knee joint during movement.
name: Abnormal meniscus morphology

desc: A tear in the cartilaginous pad (meniscus) of the knee.
name: Torn meniscus

desc: Outward turning of the heel, resulting in clubfoot with the person walking on the inner part of the foot.
name: Talipes valgus

desc: A bending or abnormal curvature of the distal portion of the tibia.
name: Distal tibial bowing

desc: A chronic loss of ankle joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the ankle.
name: Ankle flexion contracture

desc: An abnormal limitation of the mobility of the ankle joint.
name: Limitation of movement at ankles

desc: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in or around the ankle joint.
name: Ankle joint effusion

desc: Contractures of one ore more joints of the feet meaning chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.
layperson: Joint contractures involving the joints of the feet
name: Joint contractures involving the joints of the feet

desc: One or more bent (flexed) toe joints that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Flexion contracture of toe

desc: Camptodactyly is a painless flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint that is usually gradually progressive. This term refers to camptodactyly of one or more toes.
name: Camptodactyly of toe

desc: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe

desc: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe

desc: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe
name: Contracture of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe
synonyms: Contracture of the innermost hinge joint of the 4th toe

desc: The proximal interphalangeal joint of the fifth toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contractures of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th toe
name: Contractures of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the 5th toe

desc: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the first (big) toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Joint contracture of the big toe
name: Flexion contracture of the hallux
synonyms: Joint contracture of the big toe

desc: Chronic loss of joint motion in the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux due to structural changes in non-bony tissue. The tarsometatarsal joints of the feet are also called Lisfranc's joints.
layperson: Contracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux
name: Contracture of the tarsometatarsal joint of the hallux

desc: The interphalangeal joint of the big toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the interphalangeal joint of the hallux
name: Contracture of the interphalangeal joint of the hallux

desc: The joint between the first metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the first (big) toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contractures of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the hallux
name: Contractures of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the hallux

desc: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the second toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Flexion contracture of the 2nd toe

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 2nd toe
synonyms: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the second toe

desc: The joint between the second metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the 2nd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 2nd toe
name: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 2nd toe

desc: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the third toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Flexion contracture of 3rd toe

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 3rd toe

desc: The joint between the second metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the 3rd toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 3rd toe
name: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 3rd toe

desc: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fourth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.
name: Flexion contracture of the 4th toe

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe
name: Contracture of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th toe

desc: The joint between the second metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the 4th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 4th toe
name: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 4th toe

desc: One or more bent (flexed) joints of the fifth toe that cannot be straightened actively or passively.

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the outermost hinge joint of the 5th toe
name: Contractures of the distal interphalangeal joint of the 5th toe

desc: The joint between the second metatarsal and the proximal phalanx of the 5th toe cannot be straightened actively or passively.
layperson: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 5th toe
name: Contracture of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the 5th toe

desc: An anomaly of the sacroiliac joint, which connects the base of the spine (sacrum) to the ilium (a hip bone).
name: Abnormality of the sacroiliac joint

desc: Inflammation of the synovial membrane of the sacroiliac joint.
name: Sacroiliac joint synovitis

desc: A general term describing features characterized by abnormal development of bones and connective tissues.
name: Skeletal dysplasia

desc: Any morphological abnormality of cartilage.

desc: Abnormal morphology of collagen fibers in cartilage. In cartilage, collagen II, actually a collagen II:IX:XI heterofibril, is by far the most important type of collagen. A number of abnormalities may be appreciated by electron micrography or biochemical investigations, including sparse collagen fibers in the cartilage matrix.
name: Abnormal cartilage collagen

desc: Any abnormal structure of a chondrocyte, which is a polymorphic cell that forms cartilage.

desc: The presence of cartilage cells (chondrocytes) that are substantially increased in size and contain more than one nucleus and are located within the resting zone of the epiphyseal cartilage.

desc: Concentric rings around the chondrocytes.

desc: Inflammation of cartilage.

desc: Any anomaly in the composite material or the layered arrangement of the bony skeleton.

desc: An abnormality of compact bone (also known as cortical bone), which forms the dense surface of bones.

name: Thin bony cortex

desc: Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
name: Cortical sclerosis

desc: An abnormal irregularity of cortical bone.
name: Cortical irregularity

desc: An abnormal irregularity of the cortical surface of the diaphysis (shaft) of the humerus.
name: Cortical irregularity of humeral diaphysis

desc: An anomaly of the outer shell (cortex) of a hand bone.

desc: Any abnormality affecting the cortex of the humerus.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the cortex of the humerus
name: Abnormal morphology of the cortex of the humerus

desc: An anomaly of the outer shell (cortex) of a foot bone.
name: Abnormality of foot cortical bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the cortex of foot bones

desc: A reduction in the thickness of the outer shell (cortex) of foot bones.
name: Cortical thinning of foot bones

desc: A band of bone material of decreased density forming alongside the surface of the cortical bone with thickening of the periosteum. Callus formation in the affected area is common and gives the appearance of a false fracture.
name: Pseudo-fractures

desc: An Abnormality of cortical bone leading to an abnormal thickness of the cortex of affected bones.
name: Thickened cortex of bones

name: Thickened cortex of long bones
synonyms: Cortical thickening of the long bones

name: Massively thickened long bone cortices

layperson: Cortical thickening of long bone diaphyses

desc: Increased density of the compact bone of long bone.
name: Cortically dense long tubular bones

desc: Radial dysplasia, also known as radial longitudinal deficiency, includes radial clubhand and is a disfiguring, and potentially disabling, congenital limb anomaly. The entire upper limb may be involved, although the defect is most evident in the forearm and hand. Affected children suffer a variable degree of hypoplasia or absence of the preaxial skeleton and soft tissues, in particular the thumb, radius, and dorsoradial soft tissues. The hand is usually radially deviated and subluxated off the distal aspect of the ulna, the ulna may be shortened and have a bow-shaped deformity, and there is no true wrist (radiocarpal) joint in Bayne2 type-III and IV radial dysplasia.
name: Radial dysplasia

desc: Wrist is bent inward toward the thumb because of a congenital defect associated with shortening or absence of the radius.
name: Radial club hand

desc: The presence of asymmetric developmental dysplasia of the radius.
name: Asymmetric radial dysplasia

desc: Tumor-like growths that consist of replacement of the medullary bone with fibrous tissue, causing the expansion and weakening of the areas of bone involved. Especially when involving the skull or facial bones, the lesions can cause externally visible deformities. The skull is often, but not necessarily, affected, and any other bone or bones may be involved. Fibrous dysplasia can either effect isolated bones (Monostotic fibrous dysplasia) or also generalized all bones of the body (Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia).
name: Fibrous dysplasia of the bones

desc: Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in many bones throughout of the body. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is a cardinal feature of McCune-Albright syndrome.
name: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia

desc: Fibrous dysplasia of the bones were lesions are localized in only one bone.
name: Monostotic fibrous dysplasia

desc: Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.
name: Abnormal bone ossification

desc: An abnormality of the process of endochondral ossification, which is a type of replacement ossification in which bone tissue replaces cartilage.
name: Abnormal enchondral ossification

layperson: Irregular ossification of the radial metaphysis
name: Irregular ossification of the radial metaphysis

layperson: Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton
name: Calcific stippling of infantile cartilaginous skeleton

desc: An abnormality of the formation and mineralization of any bone of the bony pelvis.
name: Abnormal pelvis bone ossification
synonyms: Abnormal maturation of the pelvis bone
Abnormal ossification involving the bones of the pelvis

desc: Abnormal ossification (bone tissue formation) affecting the pubic bone, also known as the pubis.
layperson: Abnormal ossification of the pubic bone
name: Abnormal ossification of the pubic bone
synonyms: Abnormal maturation of the pubic bone

desc: Delayed maturation and calcification of the rami (branches) of the pubic bone.

name: Abnormal ossification involving the femoral head and neck

name: Multicentric ossification of proximal femoral epiphyses

desc: Delayed ossification of the femoral head.

desc: Any abnormal process of ossification of the metatarsal bones, which normally are each ossified from two centers: one for the body, and one for the head (metatarsal II,III,IV, and V) and one for the body and one for the base (metatarsal I). The ossification process begins in the center of the body about the ninth week, and extends toward either extremity. The center for the base of the first metatarsal appears about the third year, and the centers for the heads of the other bones between the fifth and eighth years. They join the bodies between the eighteenth and twentieth years.
name: Abnormal metatarsal ossification
synonyms: Abnormal maturation of long bone of foot

desc: The presence of a fifth metatarsal bone that has not undergone ossification at an age when ossification is usually visible.
name: Nonossified fifth metatarsal

desc: Any anomaly in the formation of the bony substance of the sternum.
name: Abnormal sternal ossification

desc: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms.
layperson: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
name: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
synonyms: Decreased number of sternal ossification centres

desc: Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum.
name: Absent sternal ossification

layperson: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends
name: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends

desc: Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass).

This term applies if there are additional vertebral ossification centers present during the development and maturation of the spine.
