desc: This term applies to all changes in bone mineral density which (depending on severity) can be seen on x-rays as a change in density and or structure of the bone. Changes may affect all bones of the organism, just certain bones or only parts of bones and include decreased mineralisation as may be seen in osteoporosis or increased mineralisation and or ossification as in osteopetrosis, exostoses or any kind of atopic calicfications of different origin and distribution. The overall amount of mineralization of the bone-organ can be measured as the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones, usually measured by densitometry of the lumbar spine or hip. The measurements are usually reported as g/cm3 or as a Z-score (the number of standard deviations above or below the mean for the patient's age and sex). Note that measurement with this method does not reflect local changes in other bones, and as such might not be correct with regard the hole bone-organ.
name: Abnormality of bone mineral density
synonyms: Abnormality of bone mineralisation and ossification

desc: A reduction of bone mineral density, that is, of the amount of matter per cubic centimeter of bones.
layperson: Low solidness and mass of the bones
name: Reduced bone mineral density
synonyms: Decreased bone mineral density Z score
Low solidness and mass of the bones

desc: Osteopenia is a term to define bone density that is not normal but also not as low as osteoporosis. By definition from the World Health Organization osteopenia is defined by bone densitometry as a T score -1 to -2.5.
name: Osteopenia

desc: Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone density and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue with a consequent increase in bone fragility. According to the WHO criteria, osteoporosis is defined as a BMD that lies 2.5 standard deviations or more below the average value for young healthy adults (a T-score below -2.5 SD).
name: Osteoporosis

desc: Moderate osteoporosis.
name: Moderate generalized osteoporosis

desc: Severe degree of osteoporosis.
name: Severe generalized osteoporosis

desc: Osteoporosis affecting predominantly the vertebrae.
name: Osteoporosis of vertebrae

desc: Rickets is divided into two major categories including calcipenic and phosphopenic. Hypophosphatemia is described as a common manifestation of both categories. Hypophosphatemic rickets is the most common type of rickets that is characterized by low levels of serum phosphate, resistance to ultraviolet radiation or vitamin D intake. There are several issues involved in hypophosphatemic rickets such as calcium, vitamin D, phosphorus deficiencies. Moreover, other disorder can be associated with its occurrence such as absorption defects due to pancreatic, intestinal, gastric, and renal disorders and hepatobiliary disease. Symptoms are usually seen in childhood and can be varied in severity. Severe forms may be linked to bowing of the legs, poor bone growth, and short stature as well as joint and bone pain. Hypophosphatemic rickets are associated with renal excretion of phosphate, hypophosphatemia, and mineral defects in bones. The familial type of the disease is the most common type of rickets.
name: Rickets

desc: Osteomalacia is a general term for bone weakness owing to a defect in mineralization of the protein framework known as osteoid. This defective mineralization is mainly caused by lack in vitamin D. Osteomalacia in children is known as rickets.
name: Osteomalacia

desc: A generalized decrease in bone mineral density.
name: Generalized bone demineralization

desc: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density with patches of bone showing an increased density side to side with patches that are affected by reduction of mineral density. This is sometimes referred to as a moth-eaten appearance on x-rays.
layperson: Patchy increased and decreased bone mineral density
name: Patchy variation in bone mineral density
synonyms: Patchy increased and decreased bone mineral density

desc: This term applies to all changes in bone mineral density of the tarsal bones, which (depending on severity) can be seen on x-rays as a change in density and or structure of the bone.
name: Abnormal tarsal bone mineral density
synonyms: Abnormality of bone mineral density involving tarsal bones

desc: Reduction in bone mineral density affecting any or all of the tarsal bones, seven bones of the foot comprising the calcaneus, talus, cuboid, navicular, and the cuneiform bones.
name: Osteoporotic tarsals

desc: An elevation in bone density in one or more tarsal bones of the foot. Sclerosis is normally detected on a radiograph as an area of increased opacity.
name: Tarsal sclerosis

desc: Patchy (irregular) changes in bone mineral density. These changes can either be patchy reduction or increase of mineral density as seen on x-rays. Depending on the pathomechanism and the underlying disease, these changes can either appear solely as reduction or increase or as a combination of both (patches of bone showing an increased density while others are affected by reduction of mineral density).
layperson: Patchy changes of bone mineral density
name: Patchy changes of bone mineral density

desc: Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.
name: Patchy osteosclerosis
synonyms: Patchy increase of bone mineral density

desc: Osteopoikilosis is a benign, asymptomatic sclerotic dysplasia of the bones. It affects both male and female and may be seen at any age. Radiographically sclerotic circular or ovoid lesions are usually symmetrically distributed in a periarticular location. Lesions can increase or decrease in size and number in serial radiographs or even disappear and do not have increased bone radiotracer uptake.
name: Osteopoikilosis

desc: Abnormally increased formation of dense trabecular bone tissue. Despite the increased density of bone tissue, osteopetrotic bones tend to be more fracture-prone than normal.
name: Osteopetrosis

desc: Formation of abnormal, extraskeletal bony tissue, i.e., the presence of bone in soft tissue where bone normally does not exist.
name: Ectopic ossification

desc: Formation of calcified tissue in the soft tissues surrounding the shoulder.
name: Soft-tissue ossification around the shoulders
synonyms: Calcification of the soft-tissue around the shoulders

desc: Formation of abnormal bony tissue within muscle tissue.
name: Ectopic ossification in muscle tissue

desc: Formation of abnormal bony tissue within tendon tissue.
name: Ectopic ossification in tendon tissue

desc: Formation of abnormal bony tissue within ligament tissue.
name: Ectopic ossification in ligament tissue

desc: An anomaly in the process of intramembranous ossification by which flat bones (cranial bones of the skull, i.e., the frontal, parietal, occipital, and temporal bones, and the clavicles) are formed.
name: Abnormal intramembranous ossification

desc: Any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of bone tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity.

desc: A fluid filled cavity that develops with a bone.
name: Bone cyst

desc: Disseminated multifocal hemangiomatous or lymphangiomatous lesions of the skeleton. The lesions are lytic, well-defined, round or oval lesions within the medullary cavity, and they have an intact cortex, and manifest variable peripheral sclerosis and may exhibit endosteal scalloping.
name: Cystic angiomatosis of bone
synonyms: Lytic cystic lesions in appendicular bones

desc: Radiographic features include a dilated, radiolucent lesion typically located eccentrically within the metaphyseal portion of the bone, with fluid levels visible on magnetic resonance imaging.
name: Aneurysmal bone cyst

desc: A benign fluid filled simple cyst of bone filled with serous fluid.
name: Unicameral bone cyst

desc: Presence of multiple cystic changes in multiple areas or multiple bones.
name: Multiple bony cystic lesions

desc: An anomalous structure of the periosteum, i.e., of the membrane that covers the outer surface of bones.
name: Abnormal periosteum morphology

name: Periostosis

name: Periosteal new bone of humeral diaphysis

desc: Inflammation of the periosteum

desc: The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle.
name: Congenital pseudoarthrosis of the clavicle

desc: Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect.

desc: Partial absence of a free limb (excluding girdle). It can refer to the proximal, middle or distal segment of the upper or lower limb. The deficiency may be transverse or longitudinal. Thus, meromelia is a lack of a part, but not all, of one or more limbs with the presence of a hand or foot.
name: Meromelia

desc: Undergrowth of the limbs that affects only one side.

desc: Unilateral atrophy (reduction in size) of an arm.

desc: Amelia of one or both legs.

desc: The distal parts of the limbs are missing leading to a stump formation.
name: Peromelia

name: Upper limb peromelia

desc: Peromelia affecting only the lower limbs. That is, the distal parts of the leg are missing leading to stump formation.
name: Lower limb peromelia

desc: Missing or malformed long bones of the extremities with the distal parts (such as hands and/or feet) connected to the variably shortened or even absent extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the hole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
name: Phocomelia

desc: Missing or malformed long bones of the upper limbs with the distal parts (the hands) connected to the variably shortened or even absent upper extremity, leading to a flipper-like appearance, as opposed to other forms of limb malformations were either the whole limb is missing (such as amelia), or the distal part of a limb is absent (peromelia).
name: Upper limb phocomelia

desc: Phocomelia affecting only the lower limbs.
name: Lower limb phocomelia

desc: Phocomelia involving all four extremities.
name: Tetraphocomelia

desc: Shortening of the extremities affecting primarily the distal parts of the limbs (hands and feet) in relation to the other segments of the limbs.
name: Acromelia

desc: Shortening of the arms predominantly affecting terminal parts of the arm in relation to the upper and middle limb segments.

desc: Shortening of the legs predominantly affecting terminal parts of the leg in relation to the upper and middle arm segments.

name: Aplasia involving bones of the extremities

desc: An abnormality of the axial skeleton, which comprises the skull, the vertebral column, the ribs and the sternum.
name: Abnormal axial skeleton morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the thorax (the region of the body formed by the sternum, the thoracic vertebrae and the ribs).
name: Abnormality of the thorax

desc: An anomaly of the sternum, also known as the breastbone.
name: Abnormality of the sternum

desc: A defect of the chest wall characterized by a depression of the sternum, giving the chest ("pectus") a caved-in ("excavatum") appearance.
name: Pectus excavatum

desc: Pectus excavatum (defect of the chest wall characterized by depression of the sternum) affecting primarily the inferior region of the sternum.
name: Pectus excavatum of inferior sternum

desc: A deformity of the chest caused by overgrowth of the ribs and characterized by protrusion of the sternum.
name: Pectus carinatum

desc: Pectus carinatum affecting primarily the superior part of the sternum.
name: Superior pectus carinatum

desc: Abnormal outward curving (protuberance) of the junction of ribs and costal cartilage.
name: Bulging of the costochondral junction

desc: A row of beadlike prominences at the junction of a rib and its cartilage (i.e., enlarged costochondral joints), resembling a rosary.
name: Rachitic rosary

desc: The sternal cleft is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from a fusion failure of the sternum.
name: Bifid sternum

desc: An abnormality of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
name: Abnormality of the xiphoid process

desc: A cleft of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
name: Bifid xiphoid process

desc: Increased prominence of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
name: Prominent xiphoid process

desc: Increased side-to-side width of the xiphoid process of the sternum.
name: Broad xiphoid process

desc: An abnormality of the sternum that presents at birth as a ventral sternal non-union defect, due to an abnormality of the fusion of the layers of the skin. It presents as a scar-like line that extends upward from the umbilicus (belly button).
name: Supraumbilical raphe

desc: A sternal pit is a small indentation or dimple in the skin overlying the sternum of the chest. In some cases, the skin defect can be linear, extending several inches over the sternum.
name: Sternal pit

desc: Any abnormality of the scapula, also known as the shoulder blade.
name: Abnormality of the scapula

desc: A congenital skeletal deformity characterized by the elevation of one scapula (thus, one scapula is located superior to the other).
name: Sprengel anomaly
synonyms: Congenital, upward displacement of the scapula

desc: The presence of multiple exostoses on the scapula. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage.
name: Scapular exostoses

desc: Abnormal protrusion of the scapula away from the surface of the back.
name: Scapular winging

layperson: Thickening of the lateral border of the shoulder blade
name: Thickening of the lateral border of the scapula
synonyms: Thickening of the lateral border of the shoulder blade

desc: An anomaly of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
name: Abnormality of the glenoid fossa

desc: Abnormally flat configuration of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
name: Flat glenoid fossa

desc: Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
name: Absent glenoid fossa

desc: Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus.
name: Glenoid fossa hypoplasia

desc: A morphological abnormality of the scapula in which there is a flat (horizontal) inferior edge of the scapula. The entire scapula is said to resemble a square, leading to the designation sqaring of the scapula (in Figure 1 of PMID:24706940 the scapulae have a roughly rectangular shape).
name: Horizontal inferior border of scapula

desc: Any abnormality of the clavicles (collar bones).
name: Abnormality of the clavicle

desc: Increased length of the clavicles.
name: Long clavicles

desc: An excessive upward convexity of the lateral clavicle.
name: Lateral clavicle hook

desc: Increased width (cross-sectional diameter) of the clavicles.
name: Broad clavicles

desc: An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved .
name: Straight clavicles

desc: Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles.
name: Thin clavicles

desc: An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the clavicles.
name: Undulate clavicles

desc: A morphological anomaly of the rib cage.
name: Abnormality of the rib cage

desc: An anomaly of the rib.
name: Abnormality of the ribs

desc: Ribs with a reduced diameter.
name: Thin ribs

desc: Increased width of ribs
name: Broad ribs

desc: Ribs that are increased in width and taper to the posterior ends.
name: Spatulate ribs

desc: Wide, concave rib end.
name: Cupped ribs

desc: Wide, concave anterior rib end.
name: Anterior rib cupping

desc: Wide, concave posterior rib end.
name: Posterior rib cupping

desc: A horizontal (flat) conformation of the ribs, the long curved bones that form the rib cage and normally progressively oblique (slanted) from ribs 1 through 9, then less slanted through rib 12.
name: Horizontal ribs

desc: A bifid rib refers to cleavage of the sternal end of a rib, usually unilateral. Bifid ribs are usually asymptomatic, and are often discovered incidentally by chest x-ray.
name: Bifid ribs

desc: Multiple circumscribed bony excrescences located in the ribs.
name: Rib exostoses

desc: Increased thickness (diameter) of ribs.
name: Thickened ribs

desc: Complete or partial merging of adjacent ribs.
name: Rib fusion

desc: Complete or partial merging of the posterior part of adjacent ribs.
name: Posterior rib fusion

desc: The presence of wide, concave anterior rib ends.
name: Flaring of rib cage

desc: Any anomaly of the costochondral junction. The costochondral junctions are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
name: Abnormality of the costochondral junction

desc: Abnormally increased size of the costochondral junctions, which are located between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
name: Enlargement of the costochondral junction

desc: Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth border between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
name: Irregular chondrocostal junctions

desc: Abnormal increase in density of the tissue at the costochondral junctions.
name: Costochondral joint sclerosis

desc: Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions.
name: Costochondral pain

desc: The presence of a row of multiple rounded expansions (beadlike prominences) at the junction of a rib and its cartilage.
name: Beaded ribs

desc: The presence of more than 12 rib pairs.
name: Supernumerary ribs

desc: More than one fracture of the ribs.
name: Multiple rib fractures

desc: An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger).
name: Coat hanger sign of ribs

desc: An abnormally wavy surface or edge of the ribs.
name: Undulate ribs

desc: Radiolucent focal defect of a rib shaft.
name: Rib gap

desc: Radiolucent focal defect of the posterior portion of a rib shaft. The 'gaps' may lead to flail chest.
name: Posterior rib gap

desc: Malformation of the rib cage.
name: Deformed rib cage

desc: Lack of symmetry between the left and right halves of the thorax.
name: Asymmetry of the thorax

desc: The rib cage has the shape of a wide mouthed bell. That is, the superior portion of the rib cage is constricted, followed by a convex region, and the inferior portion of the rib cage expands again to have a large diameter.
name: Bell-shaped thorax

layperson: Abnormal facility in opposing the shoulders
name: Abnormal facility in opposing the shoulders

desc: A broad chest.
name: Shield chest

desc: A rounded, bulging chest that resembles the shape of a barrel. That is, there is an increased anteroposterior diameter and usually some degree of kyphosis.
name: Barrel-shaped chest

desc: Increased inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
name: Long thorax

desc: An abnormality of the shoulder, which is defined as the structures surrounding the shoulder joint where the humerus attaches to the scapula.
name: Abnormality of the shoulder

desc: Chronic reduction in active and passive mobility of the shoulder joint due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
name: Shoulder flexion contracture

desc: A limitation of the range of movement of the shoulder joint.
name: Limited shoulder movement

desc: Shoulder joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in shoulders when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff shoulders

desc: Trapping and compression of the rotator cuff tendons during shoulder movements.
name: Shoulder impingement

desc: The term rotator cuff describes the tendons connecting the infraspinatus, supraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis muscles to the humeral head.Traumatic tears of the rotator cuff tend to occur at the tendon-bone junction of the supraspinatus and greater tuberosity of the humerus whereas degenerative tears tend to be seen posteriorly at the junction of the supraspinatus and infraspinatu A rotator cuff tear is when one or more of these tendons tears or detaches from the humerus.
name: Rotator cuff tear

desc: Low set, steeply sloping shoulders.
name: Down-sloping shoulders

desc: Lack of strength of the intercostal muscles, i.e., of the muscle groups running along the ribs that create and move the chest wall.
name: Intercostal muscle weakness

desc: Reduced width of the chest from side to side, associated with a reduced distance from the sternal notch to the tip of the shoulder.
name: Narrow chest

desc: Reduced inferior to superior extent of the thorax.
layperson: Shorter than typical length between neck and abdomen
name: Short thorax
synonyms: Shorter than typical length between neck and abdomen

desc: Failure to close of the chest and abdominal wall likely caused by the failure of the ventral wall to close during week 4 of development.
name: Thoracoabdominal wall defect

desc: Congenital protrusion of the abdominal or thoracic viscera, usually with a defect of the sternum and ribs as well as of the abdominal walls.
name: Thoracoabdominal eventration

desc: An abnormality of the thoracic vertebral column.
name: Abnormality of the thoracic spine

desc: Over curvature of the thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
name: Thoracic kyphosis

desc: Over curvature of the lower thoracic region, leading to a round back or if sever to a hump.
name: Lower thoracic kyphosis

desc: Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance.
name: Thoracolumbar kyphosis

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the chest.
name: Chest pain

desc: A type of chest pain that arises in the or under the left breast and often described as throbbing, stabbing, or burning, and lasting hours or longer. The pain may arise with or after effort, and may spread to the left arm or left side of the neck.
name: Precordial pain

desc: Any abnormality of the vertebral column.
name: Abnormality of the vertebral column

desc: Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the vertebra.
name: Spondylolisthesis
synonyms: Displacement of one backbone compared to another

desc: Complete bilateral fractures of the pars interarticularis resulting in the anterior slippage of the fifth lumbar vertebral body (L5) onto the sacrum (level S1).
name: Spondylolisthesis at L5-S1

desc: Spondylolysis is an osseous defect of the pars interarticularis, thought to be a developmental or acquired stress fracture secondary to chronic low-grade trauma.
name: Spondylolysis

desc: Reduced ability to move the vertebral column with a resulting limitation of neck and trunk flexion.
name: Spinal rigidity

desc: Abnormality of the dens of the axis, which is also known as the odontoid process.
name: Abnormality of the odontoid process

desc: Anterior mislocalization of the dens of the axis.
name: Anteriorly placed odontoid process

desc: Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.
name: Os odontoideum

desc: Os odontoideum is classified into two anatomic types (orthotopic and dystopic). Os odontoideum is defined as an ossicle that consists of smooth and separate caudal portions of the odontoid process.With dystopic os odontoideum, the ossicle is located near the basion or is fused with the clivus.
name: Orthotopic os odontoideum

desc: Os odontoideum is classified into two anatomic types (orthotopic and dystopic). Os odontoideum is defined as an ossicle that consists of smooth and separate caudal portions of the odontoid process. With orthotopic os odontoideum, the ossicle moves with the anterior arch of the atlas, while the dystopic type consists of an ossicle near the basion, or one that is fused with the clivus
name: Dystopic os odontoideum

desc: The presence of two distinct odontoid processes. The odontoid process, also known as the dens of the axis, is a protuberance of the C2 vertebral body around which the first vertebra rotates.
name: Duplicated odontoid process

desc: Any abnormality of the cervical vertebral column.
name: Abnormality of the cervical spine

layperson: Enlarged sagittal diameter of the cervical canal
name: Enlarged sagittal diameter of the cervical canal

desc: Any abnormality of the atlas and the axis.
name: C1-C2 vertebral abnormality

desc: The presence of arthrosis, i.e., of degenerative joint disease, affecting the cervical vertebral column.
name: Cervical spondylosis

layperson: Cervical vertebral bodies with decreased anteroposterior diameter
name: Cervical vertebral bodies with decreased anteroposterior diameter

desc: An abnormal lack of stability of the cervical spine.
name: Cervical spine instability

desc: Any morphological abnormality of the cervical vertebral column.
name: Abnormal cervical spine morphology

desc: A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates affecting the cervical spine.
name: Cervical platyspondyly

desc: The presence of an abnormal curvature of the cervical vertebral column.
name: Abnormal cervical curvature

desc: Exaggerated convexity of the cervical vertebral column, causing the cervical spine to bow outwards and take on a rounded appearance.
name: Cervical kyphosis

desc: Dysplasia of the cervical vertebral column.
name: Cervical vertebral dysplasia

desc: An anomaly of the atlantoaxial joint, i.e., of the joint between the first (atlas) and second (axis) cervical vertebrae.
name: Atlantoaxial abnormality

desc: Partial dislocation of the atlantoaxial joint.
name: Atlantoaxial dislocation

desc: Abnormally increased movement at the junction between the first cervical (atlas) and the second cervical (axis) vertebrae as a result of either a bony or ligamentous anomaly.
name: Atlantoaxial instability

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal.
name: Spinal canal stenosis

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal.
name: Lumbar spinal canal stenosis

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal related to a reduction in the interpedicular distance (i.e., the distance measured between the pedicles on frontal [coronal] imaging).
layperson: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance
name: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance
synonyms: Spinal stenosis due to short pedicles

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the cervical spinal canal.
name: Cervical spinal canal stenosis

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the back.
name: Back pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the lower back.
name: Low back pain

desc: Pain in the lower back and hip radiating in the distribution of the sciatic nerve.
name: Sciatica

desc: An abnormality of one or more of the vertebrae.
name: Abnormal vertebral morphology

desc: Abnormal morphology of vertebral body.
layperson: Abnormal form of the vertebral bodies
name: Abnormal form of the vertebral bodies

desc: A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance between the vertebral endplates.
name: Platyspondyly

desc: A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the thoracic spine.
name: Thoracic platyspondyly

desc: A flattened vertebral body shape with reduced distance beween the vertebral endplates affecting the lumbar spine.
name: Lumbar platyspondyly

desc: Abnormally increased variability of the size of the vertebral bodies.
name: Anisospondyly

desc: Absence of one half of the vertebral body.
name: Hemivertebrae

desc: Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the lumbar spine.
name: Lumbar hemivertebrae

desc: Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the thoracic spine.
name: Thoracic hemivertebrae

desc: Absence of one half of the vertebral body in the cervical spine.
name: Cervical hemivertebrae

desc: When viewed in lateral radiographs, vertebral bodies have a roughly rectangular configuration. This term applies if the vertebral body appears rounded or oval.
name: Ovoid vertebral bodies

desc: Bulbous appearance of the anterior vertebral bodies, such that the vertebral bodies have the greatest vertical height anteriorly as well as bulbous anterior superior-inferior contours.
name: Pear-shaped vertebrae

desc: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies.
name: Beaking of vertebral bodies

desc: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the lower thoracic vertebral bodies.
layperson: Anterior beaking of lower thoracic vertebrae
name: Anterior beaking of lower thoracic vertebrae

desc: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of thoracic vertebral bodies.
name: Anterior beaking of thoracic vertebrae

desc: Anterior tongue-like protrusions of the vertebral bodies of the lumbar spine.
name: Anterior beaking of lumbar vertebrae
synonyms: Anterior tongue-like protrusion of lumbar vertebral bodies

desc: A tongue-like protusion from the anterior aspect of lumbar vertebral bodies.
name: Tongue-like lumbar vertebral deformities

desc: Increased top to bottom height of vertebral bodies.
name: Increased vertebral height

desc: Exaggerated concavity of the anterior or posterior surface of the vertebral body, i.e., the upper and lower vertebral endplates are hollowed inward.
name: Biconcave vertebral bodies

desc: An excessive concavity of the anterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
name: Anterior scalloping of vertebral bodies

desc: An excessive concavity of the posterior surface of one or more vertebral bodies.
name: Posterior scalloping of vertebral bodies

desc: Presence of abnormal convexity of the upper and lower end plates of the vertebrae, i.e., an exaggerated bulging out of the upper and lower vertebral end plates.
name: Biconvex vertebral bodies

desc: Any abnormality of the vertebral end plates, which are the top and bottom portions of the vertebral bodies that interface with the vertebral discs.
name: Abnormality of the vertebral endplates

desc: An irregular surface of the vertebral end plates, which are normally relatively smooth.
name: Irregular vertebral endplates

layperson: Hump-shaped mound of bone in central and posterior portions of vertebral endplate
name: Hump-shaped mound of bone in central and posterior portions of vertebral endplate

desc: Sclerosis (increased density) affecting vertebral end plates.
name: Sclerotic vertebral endplates

desc: An abnormal shape of the vertebral bodies whereby the vertebral bodies are thick on one side and taper to a thin edge at the other.
name: Vertebral wedging

desc: An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T11 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
name: Anterior wedging of T11
synonyms: Anterior wedging of the 11th thoracic vertebra

desc: An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L1 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
name: Anterior wedging of L1

desc: An abnormality of the shape of vertebrae, such that they are wedge-shaped (narrow towards the back).
name: Posterior wedging of vertebral bodies

desc: An abnormality of the shape of the thoracic vertebra T12 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
name: Anterior wedging of T12
synonyms: Anterior wedging of the 12th thoracic vertebra

desc: An abnormality of the shape of the lumbar vertebra L2 such that it is wedge-shaped (narrow towards the front).
name: Anterior wedging of L2

desc: Schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
name: Vertebral clefting

desc: In the orthopedic and radiological literature, sagittally cleft vertebra is generally known as a butterfly vertebra.
name: Butterfly vertebrae

desc: Frontal schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
name: Coronal cleft vertebrae

desc: Anterior schisis (cleft or cleavage) of vertebral bodies.
name: Anterior clefting of vertebral bodies

desc: A morphological abnormality of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
name: Vertebral arch anomaly

desc: A discontinuity of the vertebral arch, i.e., of the posterior part of a vertebra.
name: Cleft vertebral arch

desc: Butterfly vertebrae have a cleft through the body of the vertebrae and a funnel shape at the ends.
name: Butterfly vertebral arch

desc: A reduction of the distance between vertebral pedicles, which are the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the vertebral body, at the junction of its posterior and lateral surfaces.
name: Narrow vertebral interpedicular distance

desc: Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column. Note that normally, the interpedicular distances get progressively wider as one proceeds down the spine.
name: Caudal interpedicular narrowing

desc: Narrowing (becoming gradually narrower) of the distance between lumbar vertebral pedicles that gets progressively more severe towards to caudal (lower) end of the vertebral column.
name: Lumbar interpedicular narrowing

desc: A reduction of the distance between the lower thoracic vertebral pedicles.
name: Lower thoracic interpediculate narrowness
synonyms: Narrowness of interpediculate distances in lower thoracic regions

desc: A reduction of the distance between thoracolumbar vertebral pedicles.
name: Thoracolumbar interpediculate narrowness

desc: An increase in the distance between vertebral pedicles, which are the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the vertebral body, at the junction of its posterior and lateral surfaces.
name: Widened interpedicular distance

desc: Abnormal morphology of a vertebral pedical.
name: Abnormal vertebral pedicle morphology

desc: Increased size of the vertebral pedicle.
name: Enlarged vertebral pedicles

desc: Underdeveloped vertebral pedicle.
name: Hypoplastic vertebral pedicle

desc: Underdeveloped pedicle of the fifth lumbar vertebra.
name: Hypoplastic L5 vertebral pedicle

layperson: Abnormality of the vertebral spinous processes
name: Abnormality of the vertebral spinous processes

layperson: Absent spinous processes of lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae
name: Absent spinous processes of lower thoracic and lumbar vertebrae

desc: An anomaly of the small joints located between and behind adjacent vertebrae.
name: Abnormality of spinal facet joint

desc: Osteoarthritis of facet joints in the spine. Degeneration of cartilage in the facet joints results in bone rubbing on bone and reactive new bone formation visible on X-ray.
name: Facet joint arthrosis

desc: An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation during development.
name: Vertebral segmentation defect

desc: An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of cervical vertebrae during development.
name: Cervical segmentation defect

desc: An abnormality related to a defect of vertebral separation of sacral vertebrae during development.
name: Abnormal sacral segmentation

desc: A hemisacral defect involving the sacral vertebrae S2 to S5. In hemisacrum, the first sacral vertebra is intact and there is agenesis involving only S2-S5.
name: Hemisacrum

desc: Presence of a bifid sacral bone.
name: Bifid sacrum

desc: Excessive growth of the bones of the vertebral bodies.
name: Vertebral hyperostosis

desc: A developmental growth retardation of the vertebral end plates that may lead to secondary destruction of the vertebral end plates and protrusion of the nucleus pulposus into the vertebral body (so called Schmorl's nodes as seen on x-rays).
name: Morbus Scheuermann

desc: A Schmorl's node is the herniation of nucleus pulposus through the cartilaginous and bony end plate into the body of the adjacent vertebra.
name: Schmorl's node

desc: A deviation from the normal number of vertebrae in the spinal column.
name: Abnormal number of vertebrae

desc: The presence of 11 instead of the normal 12 thoracic vertebrae.
name: 11 thoracic vertebrae

desc: An abnormal magnetic resonance tomography signal from a vertebral endplate according to a widely used classification published by Dr. Michael Modic.
name: Modic type vertebral endplate changes

desc: An abnormal magnetic resonance tomography signal from a vertebral endplate with a low signal on T1-weighted sequences and high signal on T2-weighted sequences. Modic type I changes are thought to represent bone marrow edema and inflammation.
layperson: Modic type I vertebral endplate changes
name: Modic type I vertebral endplate changes

desc: An abnormal magnetic resonance tomography signal from a vertebral endplate with a high signal on T1-weighted sequences and high- or isointense signal on T2 sequences. Modic type II signals are thought to indicate fatty replacement in the bone marrow.
layperson: Modic type II vertebral endplate changes
name: Modic type II vertebral endplate changes

desc: An abnormal magnetic resonance tomography signal from a vertebral endplate with a low signal on T1 and T2-weighted sequences. Modic type III signals are thought to correspond to subchondral sclerosis seen on plain radiographs.
layperson: Modic type III vertebral endplate changes
name: Modic type III vertebral endplate changes

desc: An anomaly of one or more epiphyses of one or more vertebrae.
layperson: Abnormal shape of the end part of the vertebra bone
name: Abnormality of vertebral epiphysis morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of the end part of the vertebra bone

desc: Increase in bone density of the vertebral body.
name: Sclerotic vertebral body

desc: An abnormality of the sacral bone.
name: Abnormal sacrum morphology

desc: A developmental defect of the sacrum characterized by partial or disordered development of the sacrum in which portions of the sacrum, which normally is formed by fusion of five sacral vertebrae S1-S5, fail to form or fail to form normally.
layperson: Absence of some of the sacral and coccygeal bones
name: Dysplastic sacrum
synonyms: Absence of some of the sacral and coccygeal bones

desc: The presence of a cyst, fistula, or abscess in the sacrococcygeal region (gluteal crease) characteristically accompanied by hair and skin folds.
name: Sacrococcygeal pilonidal abnormality

desc: A cutaneous indentation resulting from tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) of the intergluteal cleft.
name: Sacral dimple

desc: A sinus in the coccygeal region (the region of the intergluteal cleft). A pilonidal sinus often contains hair and skin debris.
name: Pilonidal sinus

desc: A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region.
name: Pilonidal abscess

desc: Abnormal bone tissue formation (ossification) affecting the sacrum.
name: Abnormal ossification of the sacrum

desc: Formation of the sacrum bone tissue occurs later than age-adjusted norms.
name: Delayed ossification of the sacrum

desc: Lack of ossification of the sacrum.
name: Unossified sacrum

desc: An abnormality of the intervertebral disk.
name: Abnormality of the intervertebral disk

desc: Decreased height of the intervertebral disk.
name: Intervertebral space narrowing

desc: A progressive form of decreased height of the intervertebral disk.
name: Progressive intervertebral space narrowing

desc: The presence of degenerative changes of intervertebral disk.
name: Intervertebral disc degeneration

desc: The presence of one or more herniated nucleus pulposus of intervertebral disk.
name: Herniation of intervertebral nuclei

desc: An increase in the vertical distance between adjacent vertebral bodies, observed as an increase in the intervertebral disc space.
name: Increased intervertebral space

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the vertebral column.
name: Spinal dysplasia

desc: An abnormality of the coccyx.
name: Abnormality of the coccyx

desc: The presence of a tail-like skin appendage located adjacent to the sacrum.
name: Caudal appendage

desc: The presence of an abnormal curvature of the vertebral column.
name: Abnormality of the curvature of the vertebral column

desc: The presence of an abnormal lateral curvature of the spine.
name: Scoliosis

desc: An abnormal curvature of the spine in both a coronal (lateral) and sagittal (back-to-front) plane.
name: Kyphoscoliosis

desc: A progressive form of scoliosis with congenital onset.
name: Progressive congenital scoliosis

desc: A scoliosis which is the results of a difference in leg length (which might be due to hemihypertrophy or hemihypotrophy of a leg) and the resulting tilting of the pelvis. If untreated this will lead to the development of scoliosis over time.
name: Compensatory scoliosis

desc: Exaggerated anterior convexity of the thoracic vertebral column.
name: Kyphosis

desc: Abnormally increased cuvature (anterior concavity) of the lumbar or cervical spine.
name: Hyperlordosis

desc: An abnormal accentuation of the inward curvature of the spine in the lumbar region.
layperson: Excessive inward curvature of lower spine
name: Lumbar hyperlordosis
synonyms: Excessive inward curvature of lower spine

desc: An abnormal forward-flexed posture e.g. forward flexion of the spine, which is noticeable when standing or walking but disappears when lying down. It is becoming an increasingly recognized feature of Parkinson's disease and dystonic disorders.
name: Camptocormia

desc: The absence of the normal curvature of the vertebral column.
name: Abnormally straight spine

desc: An abnormality of the lumbar vertebral column.
name: Abnormality of the lumbar spine

desc: Over curvature of the lumbar region.
name: Lumbar kyphosis

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs.
name: Disproportionate short-trunk short stature

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with congenital onset recognizable at birth.
name: Neonatal short-trunk short stature

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in childhood.
layperson: Disproportionate short-trunk short stature, identifiable in childhood
name: Childhood-onset short-trunk short stature
synonyms: Disproportionate short-trunk short stature, identifiable in childhood

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs that is lethal at birth.
name: Lethal short-trunk short stature

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short trunk but a average-sized limbs with onset in infancy.
name: Infancy onset short-trunk short stature

layperson: Supernumerary bones of the axial skeleton
name: Supernumerary bones of the axial skeleton

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skeleton.
name: Neoplasm of the skeletal system

desc: A malignant bone tumor that usually develops during adolescence and usually affects the long bones including the tibia, femur, and humerus. The typical symptoms of osteosarcoma comprise bone pain, fracture, limitation of motion, and tenderness or swelling at the site of the tumor.
name: Osteosarcoma

desc: A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells.
name: Chondrosarcoma

desc: A chordoma is a tumors that arises from embryonic remnants of the notochord along the length of the neuraxis. Chordomas generally occur in the sacrum, intracranially at the clivus, or along the spinal axis.
name: Chordoma

desc: A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue.
name: Osteoblastoma

desc: A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts.
name: Giant cell tumor of bone

desc: A solitary, benign, intramedullary cartilage tumor that is often found in the short tubular bones of the hands and feet, distal femur, and proximal humerus.
name: Enchondroma

desc: A cartilage capped bony outgrowth of a long bone. Osteochondroma arises on the external surface of bone containing a marrow cavity that is continuous with that of the underlying bone.
name: Osteochondroma

desc: A usually benign tumor composed of cells which arise from chondroblasts or their precursors and which tend to differentiate into cartilage cells.
name: Chondroblastoma

desc: Osteomas are bony growths found most commonly on the skull and mandible; however, they may occur in any bone of the body. Osteomas do not usually cause clinical problems and do not become malignant.
name: Osteoma

desc: A bening tumor of bone composed of a central zone named nidus which is an atypical bone completely enclosed within a well vascularized stroma and a peripheral sclerotic reaction zone.
name: Osteoid osteoma

desc: An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
layperson: Formation of new noncancerous bone on top of existing bone
name: Exostoses
synonyms: Formation of new noncancerous bone on top of existing bone

desc: Presence of more than one exostosis. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
name: Multiple exostoses

desc: Presence of more than one exostosis originating in one or noth humerus bones. An exostosis is a benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface. It is capped by cartilage, and arises from a bone that develops from cartilage.
name: Humeral exostoses

desc: Multiple exostoses originating in long bones.
name: Multiple long-bone exostoses
synonyms: Multiple exostoses of long tubular bones

desc: Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
name: Multiple digital exostoses

desc: A benign growth the projects outward from the bone surface of the pelvis. Exostoses are capped by cartilage, and arise from a bone that develops from cartilage.
name: Pelvic bone exostoses

desc: Abnormal formation of new bone on the surface of a bone of the hand.
name: Exostoses of hand bones

desc: An abnormality of the appendicular skeletal system, consisting of the of the limbs, shoulder and pelvic girdles.
name: Abnormal appendicular skeleton morphology

desc: An abnormality of the bony pelvic girdle, which is a ring of bones connecting the vertebral column to the femurs.
layperson: Abnormal shape of pelvic girdle bone
name: Abnormality of pelvic girdle bone morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of pelvic girdle bone

desc: An abnormality of the hip bone.
name: Abnormality of the hip bone

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the hip.
name: Hip dysplasia

desc: An abnormality of the ilium, the largest and uppermost bone of the pelvis.
name: Abnormality of the ilium

desc: Underdevelopment of the ilium.
name: Hypoplastic ilia
synonyms: Small wings of the pelvic girdle

desc: Underdevelopment of the ilium ala.
name: Hypoplastic iliac wing

desc: Underdevelopment of the body of ilium.
name: Hypoplastic iliac body

desc: Underdevelopment of the iliac bones.
name: Short iliac bones

desc: A shift from the normally round (convex) appearance of the iliac wing towards a square-like appearance.
name: Squared iliac bones

desc: Irregularity of the iliac crest, which is the superior border of the wing of the ilium.
name: Irregular iliac crest

desc: Irregularities of the iliac crest that produce the appearance of a lace border around it.
name: Iliac crest serration

desc: Horn-like malformations of the iliac crests with symmetrical bilateral central posterior iliac processes. A characteristic finding in the Nail-Patella syndrome. Iliac horns are visible on X-ray and may be palpable, but are asymptomatic.
name: Iliac horns

desc: An anomaly of the ilium ala. This is the large expanded portion of the ilum which bounds the greater pelvis laterally.
layperson: Abnormality of the wing of the ilium
name: Abnormality of the wing of the ilium

desc: Decreased width of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
name: Narrow iliac wings

desc: Widening of the ilium ala, that is of the wing of the ilium, combined with external rotation, leading to a flared appearance of the iliac wing.
name: Flared iliac wings

desc: Increased height of the wing (or ala) of the ilium (which is the large expanded portion which bounds the greater pelvis laterally).
name: High iliac wings

desc: Increased size of the ilium ala.
name: Large iliac wings

desc: The ilia is round and hypoplastic with a very flat acetabular roof and a very unusual medial projection of bone that is said to resemble the head of a snail. Figure 4 of PMID:3799723 illustrates this feature.
name: Snail-like ilia

desc: An anomaly of the the pubic bone, i.e., of the ventral and anterior of the three principal components (publis, ilium, ischium) of the hip bone.
name: Abnormality of the pubic bone

desc: Abnormally increased width of the pubic symphysis is the midline cartilaginous joint uniting the superior rami of the left and right pubic bones.
name: Wide pubic symphysis

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the pubic bone.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the pubic bone

desc: Underdevelopment of the pubis, which together with the ilium and the ischium, is one of the three bones that make up the hip bone.
name: Hypoplastic pubic bone

desc: Underdevelopment of the ischiopubic ramus, which is comprised of the inferior pubic ramus and the inferior ramus of the ischium.
name: Hypoplastic ischiopubic rami

desc: Decreased width of the foramen obturatorium. The foramen obturatorium (also known as the obturator foramen) is a hole located between the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis.
name: Narrow foramen obturatorium

desc: An anomaly of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
name: Abnormality of the ischium

desc: Underdevelopment of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
name: Hypoplastic ischia

desc: Increased width of the ischium, which forms the lower and back part of the hip bone.
name: Broad ischia

desc: Widening of the femoral head and neck.
name: Coxa magna

desc: Joint pain affecting the hip.
name: Arthralgia of the hip

desc: A decreased ability to move the femur at the hip joint associated with a decreased range of motion of the hip.
name: Limited hip movement

desc: Limitation of the extension of the hip, i.e., decreased ability to straighten the hip joint and thereby increase the angle between torso and thigh; moving the thigh or top of the pelvis backward.
name: Limited hip extension

desc: Reduced ability to move the femur outward to the side.
name: Decreased hip abduction

desc: Underdevelopment of the bony pelvis.

desc: An abnormality of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium.
name: Abnormal greater sciatic notch morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the greater sacrosciatic notch

desc: The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a reduction in the height of the notch.
name: Short greater sciatic notch

desc: A narrowing of the sacrosciatic notch, i.e., the deep indentation in the posterior border of the hip bone at the point of union of the ilium and ischium.
name: Narrow greater sciatic notch

desc: The sacroiliac joint in the bony pelvis connects the sacrum and the ilium of the pelvis, which are joined by strong ligaments. The notch is located directly superior to the joint. This term refers to a increase in the lateral dimension of the notch.
name: Widened greater sciatic notch

desc: An anomalous radiographic appearance of the developing pelvis, in which the greater ischiadic noth (incisura ischiadica major) is shallow and the pelvis takes on the appearance said to resemble a halberd (a weapon especially of the 15th and 16th centuries consisting typically of a battle-ax and pike mounted on a handle).
name: Halberd-shaped pelvis

desc: Reduced side to side width of the pelvis.
name: Narrow pelvis bone

desc: An abnormally squared appearance of the bony pelvis, a normally rounded or basin-shaped structure.
name: Square pelvis bone

desc: Pelvic asymmetry refers to asymmetric positioning of landmarks on the two sides of the pelvis and may have a structural or functional etiology.

desc: The presence of an abnormally large pelvis.

The radiographic appearance is that of a small corner of metaphysis separated from the metaphyseal edge by thin linear radiolucency. This feature can be observed in child abuse but fragmented appearance of the metaphysis or facture-like lesions can also be detected in the setting of certain skeletal dysplasias.

Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins.

Calcifications in the necrotic marrow lead to this lamellar or lattice-like appearance.

desc: A pseudoepiphysis is a secondary ossification center distinct from the normal epiphysis. The normal metacarpal epiphyses are located at the distal ends of the metacarpal bones. Accessory epiphyses (which are also known as pseudoepiphyses) can also occasionally be observed at the proximal ends of the metacarpals, usually involving the 2nd metacarpal bone.

desc: In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits). The epiphysis of the first metacarpal is localized at the proximal end (as seen in the proximal phalanges of the other digits), whereas the epiphyses of the other metacarpal bones are located at the distal end. This term applies if the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal is in any way abnormal, referring to age and gender depending norms, as seen on x-rays.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the 1st long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the 1st long bone of hand

desc: An epiphysis that curves around from its transverse orientation to a longitudinal one from proximal to distal along one side of the phalanx, thus resembling the letter 'C' and forming a bracket around the diaphysis. This results in a so called delta phalanx characterized by a triangular or trapezoidal shaped bone with a C-shaped epiphyseal plate.
layperson: Bracket shaped end part of 1st long bone of hand
name: Bracket epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Bracket shaped end part of 1st long bone of hand

layperson: Bracket shaped end part of long bone of hand
name: Bracket metacarpal epiphyses
synonyms: Bracket shaped end part of long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of a metatarsal bone epiphysis.
layperson: Abnormality of end part of long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of metatarsal epiphysis
synonyms: Abnormality of the epiphyses of the metatarsals
Abnormality of end part of long bone of foot

desc: A morphological abnormality of a digit, i.e., of a finger or toe.
name: Abnormal digit morphology

desc: Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers or toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "symphalangism".
name: Syndactyly

desc: Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
name: Toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to three.
name: 1-3 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes two and three.
name: 2-3 toe syndactyly
synonyms: Syndactyly of second and third toes

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes four and five.
name: 4-5 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes three and four.
name: 3-4 toe syndactyly

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between adjacent foot digits that involves at least half of the proximodistal length of one of the two involved digits; or, a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits of the foot that does not meet the prior objective criteria.
name: Cutaneous syndactyly of toes
2-3 toe cutaneous syndactyly
synonyms: Cutaneous syndactyly of second and third toes
Complete cutaneous syndactyly of second and third toes

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the toes 2, 3, and 4.
name: 2-4 toe cutaneous syndactyly
synonyms: Webbed second, third and fourth toes
Soft tissue syndactyly of toes 2, 3, and 4

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one and two.
name: 1-2 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to four.
name: 1-4 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to five (complete syndactyly of all toes of the foot).
name: 1-5 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to four.
name: 2-4 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes two to five.
name: 2-5 toe syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of toes three to five.
name: 3-5 toe syndactyly

desc: Webbing or fusion of the toes, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual bones of the toes. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a tibial-fibular axis. Fusions of bones of the toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
name: Osseous syndactyly of toes

desc: Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
name: Finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two and three.
name: 2-3 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three and four.
name: 3-4 finger syndactyly

desc: Webbing or fusion of the fingers, involving soft parts and including fusion of individual finger bones. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" Syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "Symphalangism".
name: Osseous finger syndactyly

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two fingers that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal joint of the adjacent fingers.
name: Cutaneous finger syndactyly

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints.
name: Cutaneous syndactyly between fingers 2 and 5

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between fingers 3 and 4.
name: 3-4 finger cutaneous syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two to five.
layperson: Webbed index, middle and pinky finger
name: 2-5 finger syndactyly
synonyms: Webbed index, middle and little finger
Webbed index, middle and pinkie finger
Webbed index, middle and pinky finger

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one and two.
name: 1-2 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers four and five.
name: 4-5 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to three.
name: 1-3 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to four.
name: 1-4 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers one to five (complete syndactyly of all fingers of the hand).
name: 1-5 finger syndactyly

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of the fingers two to four.
name: 2-4 finger syndactyly
synonyms: Syndactyly of second to fourth fingers

desc: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers three to five.
layperson: Webbed third, fourth and fifth toes
name: 3-5 finger syndactyly
synonyms: Webbed third, fourth and fifth toes

desc: A soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints, or a soft tissue continuity in the A/P axis between two digits that lies significantly distal to the flexion crease that overlies the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joint of the adjacent digits.
name: Cutaneous syndactyly

desc: An anomaly of a finger.
name: Abnormality of finger

desc: An abnormal structure of the first digit of the hand.
name: Abnormal thumb morphology

desc: Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.
name: Preaxial hand polydactyly

desc: In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger.
name: Adducted thumb

desc: A structural anomaly of one or more phalanges of the thumb.
name: Abnormality of thumb phalanx

desc: A thumb with three phalanges in a single, proximo-distal axis. Thus, this term applies if the thumb has an accessory phalanx, leading to a digit like appearance of the thumb.
name: Triphalangeal thumb

desc: A bilateral form of triphalangeal thumb.
name: Bilateral triphalangeal thumbs

desc: A form of triphalangeal thumb that cannot be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.
name: Nonopposable triphalangeal thumb

desc: A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.
name: Opposable triphalangeal thumb

desc: Any anomaly of the distal phalanx of thumb.
layperson: Abnormality of the outermost bone of the thumb
name: Abnormality of the distal phalanx of the thumb
synonyms: Abnormality of the outermost bone of the thumb

desc: With the hand relaxed and the thumb in the plane of the palm, the axis of the thumb forms an angle of at least 90 degrees with the long axis of the hand.
name: Hitchhiker thumb

layperson: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole
name: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole

layperson: Radial deviation of thumb terminal phalanx
name: Radial deviation of thumb terminal phalanx

desc: Complete or partial duplication of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side.
layperson: Duplication of the outermost bone of the thumb

desc: Complete or partial duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones, or two separate bones appearing side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

synonyms: Partial/complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb

desc: Complete duplication of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. On x-ray two separate bones appear side to side. In contrast to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5, the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

desc: Bullet-shaped phalanx refers to a short and wide phalanx that tapers distally. Bullet-shaped phalanges lack the normal diaphyseal constriction. This term is used if the proximal phalanx of the thumb is affected.

desc: Complete or partial duplication of the phalanges of the thumb. Depending on the severity, the appearance on x-ray can vary from a notched phalanx (the duplicated bone is almost completely fused with the phalanx), a partially fused appearance of the two bones (bifid), two separate bones appearing side to side, or completely duplicated phalanges (proximal and distal phalanx of the thumb and/or 1st metacarpal). In contrast to the phalanges of the digits 2-5 (proximal, middle and distal), the proximal phalanx of the thumb is embryologically equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits, whereas the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the other digits.

desc: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the thumb. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.
name: Complete duplication of thumb phalanx
synonyms: Complete duplication of the phalanges of the thumb

desc: An abnormally increased ability to bend (dorsiflex) one's fifth finger. To assess this feature, the examiner requests to proband to extend the elbows,to bend the wrist back so that it forms a ninety degree angle to the forearm, and to extend the fingers. Then, the proband is requested to bend the fifth finger back as far as is possible without discomfort. If the angle of the fifth finger exceeds 90 degrees, this is considered to be abnormal.

desc: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the middle phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accessory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a pseudoepiphysis (see corresponding terms) sometimes also referred to as hyperphalangism.

desc: In contrast to forms of polydactyly where the supernumerary digit (this can either be a rudimentary or a completely 'normal' digit) is either located postaxial (on the ulnar side of the hand, next to the little finger), preaxial (on the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb) or mesoaxial (somewhere central, between thumb and little finger), a supernumerary digit may also be placed ectopically, meaning anywhere else except post-,meso- or preaxial. In the literature this is sometimes referred to as Disorganisation-like Syndrome (OMIM223200).

desc: A complete duplication affecting one or more of the phalanges of the hand. As opposed to a partial duplication were there is still a variable degree of fusion between the duplicated bones, a complete duplication leads to two separate bones appearing side to side (radio-ulnar axis) as seen on x-rays. A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, is a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

A duplication leading to an accesory bone appearing in the proximo-distal axis on x-rays, this is actually a different entity called a Pseudoepiphyses (see according terms) sometimes also referred to as Hyperphalangism.

desc: The absence of a phalangeal segment of a finger.
name: Partial absence of finger

desc: Hyperphalangy is a digit morphology in which increased numbers of phalanges are arranged linearly within a digit. That is, there is an accessory phalanx that is arranged linearly with the other phalanges.
name: Finger hyperphalangy

desc: An accessory phalanx of the index (second) finger that is arranged linearly with the other phalanges. Hyperphalangy of the index finger results from an accessory ossification center at the metacarpophalangeal joint, resulting in radial deviation of the index finger. Note that this term refers only to this type of hyperphalangy.
name: Hyperphalangy of the 2nd finger

desc: An accessory phalanx of the third (middle) finger that is arranged linearly with the other phalanges. Hyperphalangy results from an accessory ossification center at the metacarpophalangeal joint.
name: Hyperphalangy of the 3rd finger

desc: A phalangeal malformation that is termed angel-shaped phalanx (ASP), because of its resemblance to the angels used for decoration of Christmas trees. The various components of an angel-shaped phalanx are: diaphyseal cuff (wings), surrounding a meta-diaphyseal core (body), which may appear empty or structured with a cone-shaped epiphysis (skirt) and pseudoepiphysis (head).
name: Angel-shaped phalanx

desc: The ability of the finger joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.

layperson: Absent dorsal skin creases over affected joints
name: Absent dorsal skin creases over affected joints

desc: Absence of one or more interphalangeal creases (i.e., of the transverse lines in the skin between the phalanges of the fingers).

desc: Absence of the proximal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.

desc: Presence of only one (instead of two, as normal) interphalangeal crease of the fifth finger.

name: Single interphalangeal crease of fifth finger

desc: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke.
layperson: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
name: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers

desc: Chilblains, also called perniosis, are an inflammatory skin condition related to an abnormal vascular response to the cold. We are unaware of a reliable estimate of incidence. It typically presents as tender, pruritic red or bluish lesions located symmetrically on the dorsal aspect of the fingers, toes, ears and nose. Less commonly, reports describe involvement of the thighs and buttocks. The lesions present hours after exposure to cold and usually resolve spontaneously in one to three weeks.
name: Chilblains

desc: Enlargement of the soft tissues of one or more fingers.

desc: Divergence of digits along the A/P axis (in the plane of the palm).

desc: Mallet finger refers to a condition in which the end joint of a finger bends but will not straighten by itself. In this situation, the joint can be pushed straight but will not hold that position on its own.

desc: Medial deviation of the second toe.

desc: Bending or curvature of a third toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).

desc: Bending or curvature of a fourth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).

synonyms: Wide space between the 4th and 5th toe

desc: An anomaly of the little toe.
name: Abnormality of the 5th toe

desc: Bending or curvature of a fifth toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
name: Clinodactyly of the 5th toe

desc: An ability of the toe joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
name: Hypermobility of toe joints

desc: Toes that appear disproportionately long compared to the foot.
name: Long toe

desc: Divergence of digits along the anteroposterior axis (in the plane of the sole).
name: Splayed toes

desc: Toes that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.
name: Slender toe

desc: The gradual reduction in girth of the toe from proximal to distal.
name: Tapered toe

desc: Development of a fibrotic constriction ring involving the base of one or more toes, conditioning eversion and absorption of distal structures, possibly progressing to spontaneous amputation.
name: Ainhum

desc: Toes appear swollen and plump owing to inflammation of the complete toe.
name: Toe dactylitis

desc: Bending or curvature of a toe in the tibial direction (i.e., towards the big toe).
name: Toe clinodactyly

desc: A type of Macrodactyly affecting one or several toes.
name: Macrodactyly of toe

desc: Significant increase in the length and girth of most or all of a digit compared to its contralateral digit (if unaffected) or compared to what would be expected for age/body build. The increased girth is accompanied by an increase in the dorso-ventral dimension AND the lateral dimension of the digit.
name: Macrodactyly

desc: Increased side-to-side width of one or more phalanges of the fingers or toes.
name: Broad phalanx

layperson: Wide tips of outermost digital bone
name: Wide tufts of distal phalanges
synonyms: Wide tips of outermost digital bone

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of supernumerary fingers or toes.
layperson: More than five fingers or toes on hands or feet
name: Polydactyly
synonyms: More than five fingers or toes on hands or feet

desc: A hand or foot with more than five digits that has a recognizable A/P axis of symmetry. The axis can lie within a normally formed or partially duplicated digit resembling a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe, or hallux. Alternatively, the axis can be in an interdigital space with a flanking pair of digits that resemble a middle finger, index finger, thumb, toe or hallux. The most lateral digits on each side of the hand typically resemble fifth fingers/toes.
name: Mirror image polydactyly

desc: A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the thumb or great toe.
name: Preaxial polydactyly

desc: A form of polydactyly in which the extra digit or digits are localized on the side of the fifth finger or fifth toe.
name: Postaxial polydactyly

desc: The presence of a supernumerary finger or toe (not a thumb or hallux) involving the third or fourth metacarpal/tarsal with associated osseous syndactyly.
name: Mesoaxial polydactyly

desc: One or more digit that appears disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot, whereby either the entire digit or a specific phalanx is shortened.
name: Short digit

desc: Digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot. The word brachydactyly is used here to describe a series distinct patterns of shortened digits (brachydactyly types A-E). This is the sense used here.
name: Brachydactyly

desc: This type of brachydactyly is characterized by short and broad terminal phalanges of the thumbs and big toes.
name: Type D brachydactyly

desc: In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals.
name: Type E brachydactyly

desc: Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot.
name: Brachytelomesophalangy
synonyms: Short middle and distal phalanges of digits ii through v
Progressive brachydactyly of middle and distal phalanges

layperson: Short index fingers and second toes
name: Type A2 brachydactyly
synonyms: Short index fingers and second toes

desc: A type of brachydactyly characterized by brachymesophalangy affecting mainly the 2nd and 5th digits.
name: Type A4 brachydactyly

desc: A type of brachydactyly characterized by absent middle phalanges of digits 2 to 5.
name: Type A5 brachydactyly

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of digits.
name: Oligodactyly

desc: An angulation of a digit at an interphalangeal joint in the plane of the palm (finger) or sole (toe).
name: Clinodactyly

desc: The absence of all phalanges of a digit and the associated metacarpal /metatarsal.
name: Absent ray

desc: Small hands and feet in proportion to the rest of the body.
name: Acromicria

layperson: Abnormal shape of bones of the lower limbs
name: Abnormal lower limb bone morphology
synonyms: Abnormal morphology of bones of the lower limbs
Abnormal shape of bones of the lower limbs

desc: Abnormalities of the metatarsal bones (i.e. of five tubular bones located between the tarsal bones of the hind- and mid-foot and the phalanges of the toes).
layperson: Abnormality of the long bone of foot
name: Abnormal metatarsal morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the long bone of foot

layperson: Duplication of long bones of foot
name: Duplication of metatarsal bones
synonyms: Duplication of long bones of foot

desc: A developmental defect consisting in the duplication of the first metatarsal bone.
name: Duplication of the 1st metatarsal

desc: A developmental defect consisting in the complete duplication of the first metatarsal bone.
layperson: Complete duplication of the 1st long bone of foot
name: Complete duplication of the 1st metatarsal
synonyms: Complete duplication of the 1st long bone of foot

desc: Increased side-to-side width of a metatarsal bone.
name: Broad metatarsal

desc: Increased side-to-side width of the first metatarsal bone.
name: Broad first metatarsal

desc: The metatarsals are deviated medially (tibially), that is, the bones in the front half of the foot bend or turn in toward the body.
layperson: Front half of foot turns inward
name: Metatarsus adductus
synonyms: Front half of foot turns inward

desc: Decrease in mass and density of the metatarsal bones.
name: Osteoporotic metatarsal

desc: Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
layperson: Flattened head of long bone of foot
name: Flattened metatarsal heads
synonyms: Flattened head of long bone of foot

desc: An anomaly of the fifth metatarsal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 5th long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of the fifth metatarsal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the 5th long bone of foot

layperson: Expanded metatarsals with widened medullary cavities
name: Expanded metatarsals with widened medullary cavities

desc: An anomaly of the first metatarsal bone.
