layperson: Abnormality of the 1st long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of the first metatarsal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the 1st long bone of foot

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the first metatarsal bone.
name: Aplasia/hypoplasia of the 1st metatarsal

desc: An abnormal morphology of the firstmetatarsal bone, which is short and wide and tapers distally, and lacks the normal diaphyseal constriction.
name: Bullet-shaped 1st metatarsal

desc: A deviation from the normal straight shape of a proximal phalanx of the 1st metatarsal bone.
name: Curved 1st metatarsal

layperson: Fusion involving the 1st long bone of foot
name: Synostosis involving the 1st metatarsal
synonyms: Fusion involving the 1st long bone of foot

desc: A condition in which the anterior part of the foot rotates outward away from the midline of the body and the heel remains straight.
name: Metatarsus valgus

desc: Y-shaped metatarsals are the result of a partial fusion of two metatarsal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metatarsals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
name: Y-shaped metatarsals

desc: An abnormality of the third metatarsal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 3rd long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of the third metatarsal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the 3rd long bone of foot

layperson: Abnormality of the 2nd long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of the second metatarsal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the 2nd long bone of foot

layperson: Abnormality of the 4th long bone of foot
name: Abnormality of the fourth metatarsal bone
synonyms: Abnormality of the 4th long bone of foot

desc: An abnormality of the tarsus are the cluster of seven bones in the foot between the tibia and fibula and the metatarsus, including the calcaneus (heel) bone and the talus (ankle) bone.
name: Abnormality of the tarsal bones

desc: This is a postural deformity in which the foot is positioned up against the tibia. The heel (calcaneus) is positioned downward (that is, the ankle is flexed upward), and the heel is turned outward (valgus).
name: Calcaneovalgus deformity
synonyms: Foot and ankle bend up toward shin of leg

desc: An abnormality of the calcaneus, also known as the heel bone, one of the or heel bone, one of the components of the tarsus of the foot which make up the heel.
name: Abnormality of the calcaneus

desc: A two-part calcaneus, a finding that probably results from delayed coalescence of two primary calcaneal centers of ossification.
name: Bipartite calcaneus
synonyms: Delayed coalescence of calcaneal ossification centers

desc: Abnormal plantar flexion of the calcaneus relative to the longitudinal axis of the tibia. This results in the angle between the long axis of the tibia and the long axis of the heel bone (calcaneus) being greater than 90 degrees.
name: Equinus calcaneus

desc: Protruding heel bone, or calcaneus.
name: Prominent calcaneus

desc: An abnormality of the talus.
name: Abnormality of the talus

desc: The presence of both a prominent heel and a convex contour of the sole.
name: Rocker bottom foot

layperson: Abnormality of the os naviculare pedis
name: Abnormality of the os naviculare pedis

desc: Morbus Koehler is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Os naviculare pedis.
name: Morbus Koehler

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the femur.
name: Abnormality of femur morphology

layperson: Abnormal neck or head of thigh bone
name: Abnormality of the femoral neck or head region
synonyms: Abnormal neck or head of thigh bone

desc: An abnormality of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
name: Abnormality of the femoral neck

desc: Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip in which the angle between the femoral shaft and the femoral neck is increased compared to age-adjusted values (about 150 degrees in newborns gradually reducing to 120-130 degrees in adults).
name: Coxa valga

desc: The presence of bilateral coxa valga.
name: Bilateral coxa valga

desc: Coxa vara includes all forms of decrease of the femoral neck shaft angle (the angle between the neck and the shaft of the femur) to less than 120 degrees.
name: Coxa vara

desc: An abnormally wide femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
name: Broad femoral neck

desc: An abnormally reduced diameter of the femoral neck (which is the process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft).
name: Narrow femoral neck

desc: An abnormality of the femoral head.
name: Abnormality of the femoral head

desc: A developmental anomaly with lateral displacement of the femoral head.
layperson: Lateral displacement of the femoral head
name: Lateral displacement of the femoral head

desc: Increased width of the femoral head.
name: Broad femoral head

desc: An abnormally flattened femoral head.
name: Flattened femoral head

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the femoral head.
name: Dysplasia of the femoral head

desc: A small V-shaped indentation on the internal aspect of the femoral head. This feature is well illustrated in Figure 5 of PMID:11694546.
layperson: Internal notch of the femoral head
name: Internal notch of the femoral head

desc: Underdevelopment of the lesser trochanter.
name: Hypoplasia of the lesser trochanter

desc: Flaring of distal femur.
name: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femurs
synonyms: Erlenmeyer flask deformity of distal femur

desc: An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the distal end. This feature affects the distal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
name: Club-shaped distal femur

desc: An abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged towards the proximal end. This feature affects the proximal femoral metaphysis and epiphysis.
name: Club-shaped proximal femur

layperson: Tapering of outermost end of thighbone
name: Distal tapering femur
synonyms: Tapering of outermost end of thighbone

layperson: Disproportionate prominence of the femoral medial condyle
name: Disproportionate prominence of the femoral medial condyle

desc: A bifid or bifurcated appearance of the femur as seen on x-rays, possible appearing as a more or less severe bowing of the upper leg. Might be associated with hip dysplasia on the affected side.
name: Bifid femur

desc: An increased degree of femoral version, which is defined as the angular difference between axis of femoral neck and transcondylar axis of the knee. Thus, femoral anteversion is an inward twisting of the femur that causes the knees and feet to turn inward.
name: Excessive femoral anteversion

desc: Femoral torsion, also known as femoral rotation or femoral version, refers to the twist between the proximal and distal parts of the femur on the transverse plane. Femoral anteversion averages between 30-40 degress at birth, and between 8-14 degrees in adults. This term applies if the amount of femoral torsion deviates from this range.
name: Abnormal femoral torsion

desc: Femoral torsion, also known as femoral rotation or femoral version, refers to the twist between the proximal and distal parts of the femur on the transverse plane. Femoral anteversion averages between 30-40 degress at birth, and between 8-14 degrees in adults. This term applies if the amount of femoral torsion exceeds this range.
name: Increased femoral torsion

desc: Femoral torsion, also known as femoral rotation or femoral version, refers to the twist between the proximal and distal parts of the femur on the transverse plane. Femoral anteversion averages between 30-40 degress at birth, and between 8-14 degrees in adults. This term applies if the amount of femoral torsion is below this range.
name: Decreased femoral torsion

desc: Reduced bone mineral density of the femur.
name: Low femoral bone density

desc: A bony projection (spur, osteophyte) originating from the femur, often in the medial femoral neck.
name: Femoral spur

desc: A break or crush injury of the thigh bone (femur).
name: Femur fracture

desc: An anomaly of the calf bone (fibula), one of the two bones of the calf.
name: Abnormality of fibula morphology

desc: Disproportionately long fibulae.
name: Long fibula

desc: Relatively increased growth of the fibula compared to that of the tibia.
name: Fibular overgrowth

desc: Overgrowth of the proximal part of the fibula.
layperson: Overgrowth of innermost part of calf bone
name: Proximal fibular overgrowth
synonyms: Overgrowth of innermost part of calf bone

desc: Duplication of the fibula. This may occur as a part of diplopodia (accessory tarsal or metatarsal bone). Diplopodia with double fibula is an extremely rare condition.
name: Fibular duplication

desc: Increased width of the cross sectional diameter of the fibula.
name: Increased fibular diameter

desc: Elongated curved (S-shaped) fibulae.
name: Serpentine fibula

desc: Reduced width of the cross sectional diameter of the fibula.
name: Decreased fibular diameter

desc: Abnormality of the tibia (shinbone).
name: Abnormality of tibia morphology

desc: Pseudarthrosis, or "false joint" of the tibia is the result of a developmental failure in the tibia progressing to spontaneous fracture and subsequent fibrous nonunion. The fracture is rarely present at birth but commonly develops during the first 18 months of life.
name: Tibial pseudarthrosis

desc: An abnormal increase in the length of the tibia.
name: Increased length of the tibia

desc: Morbus Osgood-Schlatter is a Juvenile aseptic necrosis affecting the Tuberositas tibiae.
name: Morbus Osgood-Schlatter

desc: A bony projection (spur, osteophyte) originating from the tibia.
name: Tibial spur

desc: A short, dysplastic tibia with a triangular shape. Instead of the normal shaft configuration of the tibia, the tibia forms a triangle with the longest side corresponding to the proximal-distal dimension, and the apex of the triangle directed laterally.
name: Triangular tibia

desc: Tibial torsion is inward twisting (medial rotation) (PATO:0002155) of the tibia.
name: Tibial torsion

layperson: Duplication involving bones of the feet
name: Duplication involving bones of the feet
synonyms: Duplication involving bones of the feet

name: Abnormal upper limb bone morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of bones of the upper limbs
Abnormal morphology of bones of the upper limbs

desc: An abnormality of the metacarpal bones.
layperson: Abnormality of the long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the metacarpal bones
synonyms: Abnormality of the long bone of hand

desc: Irregularly shaped metacarpal bones of varying degree.
layperson: Abnormal shape of long bones of hand
name: Abnormal metacarpal morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of long bones of hand

desc: Abnormally broad metacarpal bones.
name: Broad metacarpals

layperson: Broad shaft of long bone of hand
name: Widened metacarpal shaft
synonyms: Broad shaft of long bone of hand

desc: Y-shaped metacarpals are the result of a partial fusion of two metacarpal bones, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen in combination with polydactyly.
name: Y-shaped metacarpals

desc: A central Y-shaped metacarpal is the result of a partial fusion of two central metacarpals (i.e., metacarpals 2-4) of the hand, with the two arms of the Y pointing in the distal direction. Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.
layperson: Y-shaped central long bones of hand
name: Central Y-shaped metacarpal
synonyms: Y-shaped central long bones of hand

desc: Abnormal increase in width of the distal region of the metacarpal bones.
layperson: Wide outermost end of long bone
name: Distal widening of metacarpals
synonyms: Wide outermost end of long bone

desc: Metacarpal that becomes thinner toward the distal end.
name: Tapered metacarpals

desc: Some or all of the metacarpal bones (i.e., metacarpal II to V) have a pointed proximal appearance.
layperson: Pointed innermost long bone of hand
name: Proximal tapering of metacarpals
synonyms: Pointed innermost long bone of hand

desc: All of the metacarpal bones of the hand have a pointed proximal appearance.
layperson: Pointed proximal second through fifth metacarpals
name: Pointed proximal second through fifth metacarpals

desc: Irregular morphology of one or more metacarpal bones.
name: Irregular metacarpals

layperson: Cylindrical shaped long bones of hand
name: Tubular metacarpal bones
synonyms: Cylindrical shaped long bones of hand

layperson: Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities
name: Expanded metacarpals with widened medullary cavities

desc: Decreased width of the metacarpal bones (that is, reduced diameter).
name: Slender metacarpals

desc: An abnormally increased length of the metacarpal bones.
name: Long metacarpals

desc: Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metacarpal bones.
layperson: Flattened head of long bone of hand
name: Flattened metacarpal heads
synonyms: Flattened head of long bone of hand

desc: Shortening of the fourth and fifth metacarpals when the fist is clenched.
name: Archibald's sign

desc: The presence of more than the normal number of metacarpal bones.
name: Supernumerary metacarpal bones

desc: Duplication of the metacarpal I bones.
name: Double first metacarpals

desc: A structural anomaly of the first metacarpal.
layperson: Abnormality of the 1st long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the 1st long bone of hand

desc: The presence of short and wide 1st metacarpal which tapers distally ("bullet shaped").
name: Bullet-shaped 1st metacarpal

desc: A deviation from the normal straight shape of the first metacarpal.
name: Curved 1st metacarpal

desc: This term applies to a triangular shaped 1st metacarpal.
layperson: Triangular shaped 1st long bone of hand
name: Triangular shaped 1st metacarpal
synonyms: Triangular shaped 1st long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of the second metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 2nd long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the 2nd metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the 2nd long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the second metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the 2nd long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 2nd metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the 2nd long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of the third metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 3rd long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the 3rd metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the 3rd long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the third metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the 3rd long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 3rd metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the 3rd long bone of hand

desc: The normal epiphysis of the third metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.
name: Pseudoepiphysis of the 3rd metacarpal

desc: Any abnormality of the fourth metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 4th long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the 4th metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the 4th long bone of hand

desc: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the 4th long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 4th metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the 4th long bone of hand

desc: The normal epiphysis of the fourth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.
name: Pseudoepiphysis of the 4th metacarpal

desc: Any abnormality of the fifth metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the 5th long bone of hand
name: Abnormality of the 5th metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the 5th long bone of hand

desc: Presence of an angular or V -shaped indentation on the ulnar side of the fifth metacarpal bone (i.e., on the sides towards the fifth finger).
name: Fifth metacarpal with ulnar notch
synonyms: Fifth metacarpal notched on ulnar side

desc: Any abnormality of the epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal bone.
layperson: Abnormality of the end part of the long bone of pinkie finger
name: Abnormality of the epiphysis of the 5th metacarpal
synonyms: Abnormality of the end part of the long bone of pinkie finger
Abnormality of the end part of the long bone of little finger
Abnormality of the end part of the long bone of pinky finger

desc: The normal epiphysis of the fifth metacarpal is localised at the distal end of the metacarpal bone. This term aplies if an accesory epiphysis, located at the proximal end of the metacarpal bone, is present.
name: Pseudoepiphysis of the 5th metacarpal

desc: An anomaly of a metacarpophalangeal joint.
name: Abnormality of metacarpophalangeal joint

desc: A chronic loss of joint motion in metacarpophalangeal joints due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement.
name: Metacarpophalangeal joint contracture

desc: Increased mobility of one ore more metacarpophalangeal joint.
name: Metacarpophalangeal joint hyperextensibility

desc: An abnormality of the humerus (i.e., upper arm bone).
name: Abnormality of the humerus

layperson: Triangular long bone of upper arm
name: Triangular humerus
synonyms: Triangular long bone of upper arm

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the humerus.
name: Abnormal humerus morphology

layperson: Angulated long bone in upper arm
name: Angulated humerus
synonyms: Angulated long bone in upper arm

desc: Clefting affecting the humerus.
layperson: Notched long bone in upper arm
name: Bifid humerus
synonyms: Notched long bone in upper arm

layperson: Crumpled long bone in upper arm
name: Crumpled humerus
synonyms: Crumpled long bone in upper arm

layperson: Deformed long bone in upper arm
name: Deformed humerus
synonyms: Deformed long bone in upper arm

layperson: Deformed head of long bone in upper arm
name: Deformed humeral heads
synonyms: Deformed head of long bone in upper arm

desc: Destruction of an area of humerus bone due to a disease process, such as cancer.
name: Humeral lytic defects

layperson: False joint (long bone in upper arm)
name: Humeral pseudarthrosis
synonyms: False joint (long bone in upper arm)

desc: Reduction in diameter of the humerus.
layperson: Slender long bone of upper arm
name: Slender humerus
synonyms: Slender long bone of upper arm

layperson: Tapered long bone of upper arm
name: Tapered humerus
synonyms: Tapered long bone of upper arm

layperson: Wide long bone of upper arm
name: Wide humerus
synonyms: Wide long bone of upper arm

layperson: Abnormal head of long bone in upper arm
name: Abnormality of the humeral heads
synonyms: Abnormal head of long bone in upper arm

layperson: Flattended head of long bone in upper arm
name: Flattened humeral heads
synonyms: Flattended head of long bone in upper arm

desc: An abnormality of the radius.
name: Abnormality of the radius

desc: Increased width of the radius.
name: Broad radius

desc: Increased length of the radius.
name: Elongated radius

desc: An abnormality of the ulna bone of the forearm.
name: Abnormality of the ulna

desc: Increased length of the ulna.
name: Long ulna

desc: Reduction in diameter of the ulna.
name: Slender ulna

desc: Partial dislocation of the ulna in the dorsal direction.
name: Dorsal subluxation of ulna

desc: Increased width of the ulna.
name: Broad ulna

layperson: Cortical thickening of the forearm bones
name: Cortical thickening of the forearm bones

layperson: Lytic defects of the forearm bones
name: Lytic defects of the forearm bones

layperson: Increased bone density of forearm bones
name: Sclerotic forearm bones
synonyms: Increased bone density of forearm bones

layperson: Abnormal shape of of forearm bone
name: Abnormal forearm bone morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of of forearm bone

desc: Abnormally wide bone of the skeleton of forearm.
name: Broad forearm bones

desc: A condition in which middle parts of the hands and/or feet (digits and meta-carpals and -tarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe/fingers over absent 2nd or 3rd toes/fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands and/or feet.
name: Ectrodactyly

desc: A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands.
name: Split hand

desc: A condition in which middle parts of the foot (toes and metatarsals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic 3rd toe over absent 2nd or 3rd toes as far as oligo- or monodactyl feet.
name: Split foot

desc: Congenital duplication of all or part of a limb.
name: Limb duplication

desc: An abnormality of size or shape of the long bones.
name: Abnormality of long bone morphology

desc: One or more abnormally short long bone.
name: Short long bone

desc: Decreased length of the tubular bones of the hand, that is, the phalanges and metacarpals.
layperson: Short tubular bones of the hand
name: Short tubular bones of the hand
synonyms: Shortened short tubular bones of the hand

desc: An increased tendency to fractures of the long bones (Mainly, the femur, tibia, fibula,humerus, radius, and ulna).
name: Fractures of the long bones

desc: Reduced diameter of a long bone.
name: Slender long bone

desc: The presence of multiple protuberances (bulges, or knobs) at the ends of the long bones.
layperson: Protuberances at ends of long bones
name: Protuberances at ends of long bones
synonyms: Protuberances at ends of long bones

desc: Increased cross-section (diameter) of the long bones. Note that widening may primarily affect specific regions of long bones (e.g., diaphysis or metaphysis), but this should be coded separately.
name: Broad long bones

desc: A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or "false joint").
name: Pseudoarthrosis

desc: An anomaly of epiphysis, which is the expanded articular end of a long bone that developes from a secondary ossification center, and which during the period of growth is either entirely cartilaginous or is separated from the shaft by a cartilaginous disk.
layperson: Abnormal shape of end part of bone
name: Abnormality of epiphysis morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of end part of bone

layperson: Flattened, squared-off end part of tubular bones
name: Flattened, squared-off epiphyses of tubular bones
synonyms: Flattened, squared-off end part of tubular bones

desc: Abnormal flatness (decreased height) of epiphyses.
name: Flattened epiphysis

desc: An abnormal flattening of an epiphysis of femur.
layperson: Flattended end part of thigh bone
name: Flattened femoral epiphysis
synonyms: Flattended end part of thigh bone

layperson: Bracket shaped end part of long bone
name: Bracket epiphyses
synonyms: Bracket shaped end part of long bone

desc: Cone-shaped epiphyses (also known as coned epiphyses) are epiphyses that invaginate into cupped metaphyses. That is, the epiphysis has a cone-shaped distal extension resulting from increased growth of the central portion of the epiphysis relative to its periphery.
name: Cone-shaped epiphysis

layperson: Cone-shaped end part of long bone fused within their wide portion of wide bone
name: Cone-shaped epiphyses fused within their metaphyses
synonyms: Cone-shaped end part of long bone fused within their wide portion of wide bone

desc: Increased size of epiphyses.
name: Enlarged epiphyses

desc: A morphological abnormality of epiphyses whereby they are abnormally outwardly curving (protuberant).
name: Bulging epiphyses

desc: An alteration of the normally smooth contour of the epiphysis leading to an irregular appearance.
layperson: Irregular end part of long bone
name: Irregular epiphyses
synonyms: Irregular end part of long bone

layperson: Fragmented, irregular end part of bone
name: Fragmented, irregular epiphyses
synonyms: Fragmented, irregular end part of bone

desc: Sclerosis of the epiphyses, leading to an increased degree of radiopacity (white or ivory appearance) in X-rays.
layperson: Increased bone density in end part of bone
name: Ivory epiphyses
synonyms: Increased bone density in end part of bone

desc: Reduction in the size or volume of epiphyses.
name: Small epiphyses

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at each end of a long bone, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the hand, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in hand

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the foot, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in foot

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the tibia, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in tibia

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the fibula, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in fibula

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the radius, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in radius

desc: Stop of growth at the epiphyseal plate the hyaline cartilage plate in the metaphysis at one or more long bones in the ulna, at an earlier than normal age, resulting in growth arrest and shortening of the involved bone.
name: Premature epimetaphyseal fusion in ulna

desc: Fragmented appearance of the epiphyses.
name: Fragmented epiphyses

desc: Flaring (widening) of the epiphysis.
name: Splayed epiphyses

desc: An crumpled radiographic appearance of the long bones, as if the long bone had been crushed together producing irregularities. This feature is the result of multiple fractures and repeated rounds of ineffective healing, as can be seen for instance in severe forms of osteogenesis imperfecta.
name: Crumpled long bones

desc: Overconstriction, or narrowness of the diaphysis and metaphysis of long bones.
name: Overtubulated long bones

desc: A partial or complete breakage of the continuity of a bone.
name: Bone fracture

desc: A structural anomaly of a synovial bursa.
name: Abnormality of synovial bursa morphology

desc: Inflammation of a synovial bursa.
name: Bursitis

desc: A structural anomaly of the growth plates (epiphyseal plates), areas of cartilage located near the ends of long bones that are located between the metaphysis (widened part of the shaft of the bone) and the epiphysis (end of the bone) and in which growth occurs in the developing bone. After conclusion of bone growth, the growth plates ossify (harden into solid bone).
name: Abnormality of growth plate morphology

desc: Increased thickness (dimension along the axis of the bone) of the growth plate.
name: Thick growth plates

desc: Increased growth of callus, the bony and cartilaginous material that forms a connecting bridge across a bone fracture during fracture healing.
name: Hyperplastic callus formation

desc: A reduction in diameter and volume of the central cavity of bone where red or yellow bone marrow is located.
name: Narrowing of medullary canal

desc: An abnormality of the structure or form of the tendons, also often called sinews.
name: Abnormal tendon morphology

desc: A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.
layperson: Flexed joint that cannot be straightened
name: Flexion contracture
synonyms: Flexed joint that cannot be straightened

desc: One or more flexion contractures (a bent joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively) that are present at birth.
name: Congenital contracture

desc: Multiple congenital contractures in different body areas.
name: Arthrogryposis multiplex congenita

desc: An inherited primary limb malformation disorder characterized by congenital contractures of two or more different body areas and without primary neurologic and/or muscle disease that affects limb function.
name: Distal arthrogryposis

desc: A contrqacture (chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin) that prevent normal movement of one or more joints of the limbs.
name: Limb joint contracture

layperson: Contractures of the joints of the lower limbs
name: Contractures of the joints of the lower limbs
Contractures involving the joints of the feet

desc: A contracture of the Achilles tendon.
name: Achilles tendon contracture

layperson: Contractures of the joints of the upper limbs
name: Contractures of the joints of the upper limbs

layperson: Decreased cervical spine flexion due to contractures of posterior cervical muscles
name: Decreased cervical spine flexion due to contractures of posterior cervical muscles
synonyms: Inability to touch chin to chest

desc: Progressively worsening joint contractures.
name: Progressive flexion contractures

desc: A bent (flexed) finger or toe joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.
name: Flexion contracture of digit

desc: The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the fingers or toes cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.
layperson: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe
name: Camptodactyly
synonyms: Permanent flexion of the finger or toe

desc: An abnormality of the Achilles tendon.
name: Abnormality of the Achilles tendon

desc: An abnormal thickening of the Achilles tendon.
name: Thickened Achilles tendon

desc: Ectopic deposition of calcium salts in the Achilles tendon.
name: Achilles tendon calcification

desc: The presence of xanthomas (intra-and extra-cellular accumulations of cholesterol) extensor tendons (typically over knuckles, Achilles tendon, knee, and elbows).
name: Tendon xanthomatosis

desc: Inflammation of the flexor digitorum tendon, often associated with the Kanavel signs: (i) finger held in slight flexion, (ii) fusiform swelling, (iii) tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath, and (iv) pain with passive extension of the digit.
name: Digital flexor tenosynovitis

desc: Inflammation of a tendon.
name: Tendonitis

desc: Inflammation of the Achilles tendon.
name: Achilles tendonitis

desc: An abnormal increase in the thickness (diameter) of a tendon.
name: Tendon thickening

desc: Breakage (tear) of a tendon.
name: Tendon rupture

desc: Excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue.
name: Hyperostosis

desc: An abnormality of a hyoid bone.
name: Abnormality of hyoid bone

desc: An abnormality of the function of the skeletal system.
name: Abnormality of skeletal physiology

desc: The bones of the skeleton undergo a series of characteristic changes in size, shape, and calcification from fetal life until puberty. An abnormality of this process can include delayed or accelerated skeletal maturation, or deviation of some, but not all bones from the expected patterns of maturation.
name: Abnormality of skeletal maturation

desc: A decreased rate of skeletal maturation. Delayed skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
name: Delayed skeletal maturation

desc: A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is a delay in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.
name: Dysharmonic delayed bone age

desc: An abnormally increased rate of skeletal maturation. Accelerated skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.
name: Accelerated skeletal maturation

desc: A type of dysharmonic skeletal maturation in which there is an acceleration in skeletal maturation whose degree differs markedly in different bones.
name: Dysharmonic accelerated bone age

desc: Different levels of maturation of different bones.
name: Dysharmonic bone age

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to bone.
name: Bone pain

desc: An abnormally increased tendency to fractures of bones caused by an abnormal reduction in bone strength that is generally associated with an increased risk of fracture.
name: Increased susceptibility to fractures

desc: A pathologic fracture occurs when a bone breaks in an area that is weakened secondary to another disease process such as tumor, infection, and certain inherited bone disorders. A pathologic fracture can occur without a degree of trauma required to cause fracture in healthy bone.
name: Pathologic fracture

desc: The repeated occurrence of bone fractures (implying an abnormally increased tendency for fracture).
name: Recurrent fractures

desc: Curvature of the shafts of the long bones due to multiple fractures.
layperson: Bowing of limbs due to multiple fractures
name: Bowing of limbs due to multiple fractures
synonyms: Bowed limbs due to multiple fractures

desc: The presence of bone fractures in the prenatal period that are diagnosed at birth or before.
layperson: Numerous multiple fractures that are present at birth
name: Multiple prenatal fractures
synonyms: Numerous multiple fractures present at birth
Numerous multiple fractures that are present at birth

desc: Osteomyelitis is an inflammatory process accompanied by bone destruction and caused by an infecting microorganism.
name: Osteomyelitis

desc: An infection of bone of the foot.
name: Foot osteomyelitis

layperson: Osteomyelitis leading to amputation due to slow healing fractures
name: Osteomyelitis leading to amputation due to slow healing fractures

desc: Osteomyelitis caused by infection with the bacteria, salmonella.
name: Salmonella osteomyelitis

desc: Chronic pain in the limbs with no clear focal etiology.
name: Limb pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the arm.
name: Upper limb pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the elbow.
name: Elbow pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the wrist.
name: Wrist pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort localized to the hand.
name: Hand pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the finger.
name: Finger pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the leg.
name: Lower limb pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the foot.
name: Foot pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the knee.
name: Knee pain

desc: Wilson sign is defined as the elicitation of pain by internally rotating the patient's tibia during knee extension between 90 degrees and 30 degrees of flexion and then relieving that pain by externally rotating the tibia.
name: Wilson sign

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the ankle.
name: Ankle pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the toe.
name: Toe pain

desc: A disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply.
layperson: Death of bone due to decreased blood supply
name: Avascular necrosis
synonyms: Death of bone due to decreased blood supply

desc: Juvenile aseptic necrosis comprises a group of orthopedic diseases characterized by interruption of the blood supply of a bone, followed by localized bony necrosis most often of the epiphyses of bones of children or teenagers.
name: Juvenile aseptic necrosis

desc: An abnormality in the range and ease of motion of joints across their normal range.
name: Abnormality of joint mobility

desc: A reduction in the freedom of movement of one or more joints.
name: Limitation of joint mobility

desc: Joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in a joint or joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity. Joint stiffness typically subsides over time.
name: Joint stiffness

desc: A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.
name: Generalized morning stiffness

desc: A sensation of tightness in the elbow joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff elbow

desc: A sensation of tightness in the wrist joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff wrist

desc: A sensation of tightness in a finger joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff finger

desc: A sensation of tightness in the hip joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff hip

desc: A sensation of tightness in the knee joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff knee

desc: A sensation of tightness in the ankle joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff ankle

desc: A sensation of tightness in a toe joint when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity.
name: Stiff toe

layperson: Decreased range of movement range in hinge joints
name: Decreased movement range in interphalangeal joints
synonyms: Decreased range of movement range in hinge joints

desc: A reduction of joint mobility resulting from changes involving the articular surfaces.
name: Ankylosis

desc: The ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
name: Joint hypermobility

desc: The ability of the wrist joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
name: Hyperextensibility at wrists

desc: The ability of the interphalangeal joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
name: Hypermobility of interphalangeal joints

layperson: Increased mobility of outermost hinge joint
name: Hypermobility of distal interphalangeal joints
synonyms: Increased mobility of outermost hinge joint

desc: The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
name: Hyperextensible hand joints

desc: The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.
name: Hyperextensible thumb

desc: Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles.
layperson: Joints move beyond expected range of motion
name: Joint hyperflexibility
synonyms: Joints move beyond expected range of motion

desc: The ability of the elbow joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.
name: Hyperextensibility at elbow

desc: Lack of stability of a joint.
name: Joint laxity

desc: Joint hypermobility (ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion) affecting many or all joints of the body.
name: Generalized joint laxity

desc: Lack of stability of a distal joint (e.g., finger).
name: Distal joint laxity

desc: A delay in healing of a fracture past the expected duration.
name: Delayed fracture healing

desc: An abnormality of an odontoid tissue.
name: Abnormality of odontoid tissue
synonyms: Abnormality of hard tissues of teeth

desc: An abnormality of the fetus or the birth of the fetus, excluding structural abnormalities.
layperson: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
name: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
synonyms: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth

desc: An abnormality of the placenta (the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall) or of the umbilical cord (the cord that connects the fetus to the placenta).
layperson: Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord
name: Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord
synonyms: Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord

desc: An abnormality of the umbilical cord, which is the cord connecting the developing embryo or fetus to the placenta.
name: Abnormality of the umbilical cord

desc: Decreased length of the umbilical cord.
name: Short umbilical cord

desc: Single umbilical artery (SUA) is the absence of one of the two umbilical arteries surrounding the fetal bladder and in the fetal umbilical cord.
layperson: Only one artery in umbilical cord instead of two
name: Single umbilical artery
synonyms: Only one artery in umbilical cord instead of two

desc: A first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the umbilical vein.
layperson: Abnormality of umbilical vein blood flow
name: Abnormality of umbilical vein blood flow

desc: Four-vessel umbilical cord containing two arteries and two veins.
name: Four-vessel umbilical cord

desc: Increased length of the umbilical cord.
name: Long umbilical cord

desc: Insertion of the umbilical cord within 2 cm from the placental edge.
name: Marginal umbilical cord insertion

desc: Insertion of the umbilical cord into the chorio-amniotic membranes of the placenta.
name: Velamentous cord insertion

desc: Branching of the umbilical cord before its insertion into the placenta.
name: Furcate cord insertion

desc: Any cystic lesion associated with the umbilical cord.
name: Umbilical cord cyst

desc: An entwining of a segment of umbilical cord, usually without obstructing fetal circulation and commonly result from fetal slippage through a loop of the cord.
name: Umbilical cord knot

desc: Focal dilation of the umbilical vein.
name: Umbilical vein varix

desc: Bleeding from the vessels of the cord with extravasation of blood into the Wharton jelly surrounding the umbilical cord vessels.
name: Umbilical cord hematoma

desc: Separation of the umbilical cord occurs at an abnormally late timepoint.
name: Delayed umbilical cord separation

desc: An infection of the umbilicus and/or surrounding tissues occurring in the neonatal period.
name: Neonatal omphalitis

desc: An abnormality in any umbilical cord measurement performed after birth, such as the blood gas level.
name: Abnormal cord blood measurement

layperson: Abnormal blood gas level in cord blood
name: Abnormal blood gas level in cord blood

desc: Abnormal amount of carbon dioxide in umbilical cord blood
layperson: Abnormal carbon dioxide level in cord blood
name: Abnormal carbon dioxide level in cord blood
synonyms: Abnormal CO2 level in cord blood
Abnormal umbilical cord blood levels of carbon dioxide

desc: Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level in the cord blood.
layperson: High cord blood carbon dioxide level
name: Hypercapnia in cord blood
synonyms: High cord blood carbon dioxide level

desc: Abnormally decreased blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level in the cord blood.
layperson: Low cord blood carbon dioxide level
name: Hypocapnia in cord blood
synonyms: Low cord blood carbon dioxide level

desc: An abnormal level of blood oxygen in the cord blood.
layperson: Abnormal oxygen level in cord blood
name: Abnormal oxygen level in cord blood
synonyms: Abnormal oxygen amount in umbilical cord blood
Abnormal O2 level in cord blood

desc: An abnormally high level of blood oxygen in the cord blood.
name: Hyperoxemia in cord blood

desc: An abnormally low level of blood oxygen in the cord blood.
name: Hypoxemia in cord blood

desc: Annular constrictions around the digits, limbs, or trunk, occurring congenitally (sometimes causing intrauterine autoamputation) and also associated with a wide variety of disorders. Constrictive amniotic bands are the result of primary amniotic rupture, which can lead to entanglement of fetal tissue (especially limbs) in fibrous amniotic strands.
name: Amniotic constriction ring

desc: Amniotic constriction rings affecting the arms.
name: Amniotic constriction rings of arms

desc: A narrow segment of significantly reduced circumference of a digit.
name: Digital constriction ring

desc: Amniotic constriction rings affecting the legs.
name: Amniotic constriction rings of legs

desc: A sheet like projection that can result from uterine synechiae that has been encompassed by the expanding chorion and amnion.
name: Amniotic Sheet

desc: Hydatidiform mole (HM) is an aberrant human pregnancy with absence of, or abnormal embryonic development, hydropic degeneration of chorionic villi, and excessive proliferation of the trophoblast.
name: Hydatidiform mole

desc: An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange.
name: Abnormality of the placenta

desc: Separation of the placenta from the uterus wall before delivery.
name: Placental abruption

desc: A deviation from normal size of the placenta.
name: Abnormal placental size

desc: Reduced size of the placenta.
name: Small placenta

desc: Increased size of the placenta.
name: Large placenta

desc: An abnormality of the placenta in which there are numerous cystic spaces within the placenta as well as placental enlargement.
name: Hydropic placenta

desc: Abnormally elevated placental thickness.
name: Increased placental thickness

desc: A large maternal clot that separates the chorionic plate from the villous chorion.
name: Subchorionic thrombohematoma

desc: Cyst on the surface of the placenta consisting of amnion and chorion.
name: Subchorionic septal cyst

desc: Placental mesenchymal dysplasia is an abnormality of the stem villi of the placenta that may be mistaken for a hydatidiform mole, and in particular, partial mole, owing to the mixture of cysts and normal-appearing parenchyma. The stem (anchoring) villi form as outgrowths of the chorionic plate early in placentogenesis and give rise to the branching villous trees.
name: Placental mesenchymal dysplasia

desc: Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels.
name: Chorangioma

desc: An abnormality of fetal movement.
name: Prenatal movement abnormality

desc: An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements.
layperson: Less than 10 fetal movements in 12 hours
name: Decreased fetal movement
synonyms: Less than 10 fetal movements in 12 hours

desc: Decreased fetal activity associated with multiple joint contractures, facial anomalies and pulmonary hypoplasia. Ultrasound examination may reveal polyhydramnios, ankylosis, scalp edema, and decreased chest movements (reflecting pulmonary hypoplasia).
name: Fetal akinesia sequence

desc: An abnormal increase in quantity or strength of fetal movements.
name: Increased fetal movement

desc: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid, which is the fluid contained in the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.
name: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid

desc: The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy.
name: Polyhydramnios

desc: Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy.
name: Oligohydramnios

desc: Abnormally increased production of urine by the fetus resulting in polyhydramnios.
name: Fetal polyuria

desc: Amniotic fluid containing the earliest stools of a mammalian infant.
name: Meconium stained amniotic fluid

desc: The birth of a baby of less than 37 weeks of gestational age.
name: Premature birth

layperson: Premature birth following premature rupture of fetal membranes
name: Premature birth following premature rupture of fetal membranes
synonyms: Premature birth following premature rupture of foetal membranes

layperson: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility
name: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility

desc: An abnormality of the birth process.
name: Abnormal delivery

desc: A position of the fetus at delivery in which the fetus enters the birth canal with the buttocks or feet first.
layperson: Feet or buttocks of fetus positioned near opening of uterus
name: Breech presentation
synonyms: Feet or buttocks of fetus positioned near opening of uterus

desc: A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are extended.
name: Frank breech presentation

desc: A kind of breech presentation in which the hips are flexed and the knees are flexed.
name: Complete breech presentation

desc: A kind of breech presentation in which one or both hips are extended and one or both of the fetus' feet are pointing down and entering the birth canal.
name: Incomplete breech presentation

desc: Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) is a condition which occurs in pregnancy when the amniotic sac ruptures more than an hour before the onset of labor.
name: Premature rupture of membranes

desc: A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 20th week of pregnancy.
name: Spontaneous abortion

desc: Repeated episodes of abortion (Expulsion of the product of fertilization before completing the term of gestation) without deliberate interference.
name: Recurrent spontaneous abortion

desc: Delivery of a fetus through surgical incisions made through the abdominal wall (laparotomy) and the uterine wall (hysterotomy).
name: Caesarian section

desc: Delivery by Caesarian section representing the first time the mother has delivered by Caesarian section.
name: Primary Caesarian section

desc: Delivery by Caesarian section representing where the mother has already had a previous Cesarean delivery, and this is a repeat Cesarean birth.
name: Secondary Caesarian section

desc: Delivery of newborn by means of a ventouse, a vacuum device used to assist the delivery of a baby when the second stage of labour has not progressed adequately.
name: Ventouse delivery

desc: Shoulder dystocia occurs when the fetal anterior shoulder impacts against the maternal symphysis following delivery of the vertex.
name: Shoulder dystocia

desc: A complication of pregnancy and delivery in which the umbilical cord wraps around the fetal neck once or multiple times.
name: Nuchal cord

desc: Hemorrhage between the skull and periosteum of a newborn resulting from rupture of blood vessels that cross the periosteum.
name: Cephalohematoma

desc: Vaginal birth after Caesarian (VBAC) refers to the situation where the mother has had a previous Cesarean delivery but has now delivered vaginally.
name: Vaginal birth after Caesarian

desc: The Odon device is an instrument for assisted vaginal deliveries that is applied on the head of the baby and used to apply traction to assist the birth process.
name: Delivery by Odon device

desc: Vaginal delivery following induction of labor, a procedure used to stimulate uterine contractions during pregnancy before labor begins on its own.
name: Induced vaginal delivery

desc: Delivery by means of therapeutic termination of pregnancy. Therapeutic abortion may be done to end a pregnancy if the mother's life is in danger or if the baby has abnormalities involving the major organ systems and is not expected to survive after birth or by choice.
name: Therapeutic abortion

desc: The abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, including ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, and skin edema.
name: Hydrops fetalis

desc: A type of hydrops fetalis in which there is no identifiable circulating antibody to red blood cell antigens .
name: Nonimmune hydrops fetalis

desc: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity during the fetal period.
name: Fetal ascites

desc: Virilization (deepening of voice, facial hirsutism and scalp hair loss) with onset during pregnancy (usually towards the end of the first trimester) and regression several months post-partum.
name: Maternal virilization in pregnancy

desc: An abnormally elevated or decreased level of a maternal serum marker analytes used in screening for aneuploidy.
name: Abnormal maternal serum screening

desc: An abnormally high concentration of serum conjugated estriol as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: Low maternal serum estriol

desc: An abnormally low concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: Low maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein

desc: An abnormally high concentration of serum alpha-fetoprotein as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: High maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein

desc: An abnormally high concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: High maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin

desc: An abnormally low concentration of maternal serum human chorionic gonadotropin as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: Low maternal serum chorionic gonadotropin

desc: An abnormally low concentration of serum PAPP-A (pregnancy associated plasma protein A), as compared to normal values for gestational-age.
name: Low maternal serum PAPP-A

desc: A medical history of a fetus or child born to a mother with an autoimmune disease.
name: Maternal autoimmune disease

desc: The presence of circulating autoantibodies to anticardiolipin in the mother.
name: Maternal anticardiolipin antibody positive

desc: Excessive vomiting in early pregnancy, leading to the loss of 5% or more of body weight.
name: Hyperemesis gravidarum

desc: A deviation from equal (50%) inactivation of each parental X chromosome in maternal cells.
name: Skewed maternal X inactivation

desc: The occurence of an elevated body temperature of the mother during pregnancy.
name: Maternal fever in pregnancy

desc: The occurence of maternal fever during labor.
name: Intrapartum fever

desc: The occurence of fever in a mother during the first trimester of pregnancy.
name: Maternal first trimester fever

desc: Exposure of pregnant women to toxins from any source, such as environmental toxins or chemicals, that may potentially cause problems such as miscarriage, preterm delivery, low birth weight, and, in some cases, developmental delays in infants.
name: Pregnancy exposure

desc: A medical history of exposure of the mother of a child or fetus to a teratogenic substance during pregnancy.
name: Maternal teratogenic exposure

desc: A pregnancy in which the fertilized egg inserts in a location outside of the main cavity of the uterus (usually in the Fallopian tube).
name: Ectopic pregnancy

desc: An increased tendency towards thrombosis in the mother during a pregnancy.
name: Maternal thrombophilia

desc: Pregnancy-induced toxic reactions of the mother that can be as harmless as slight Maternal hypertension or as life threatening as Eclampsia.
name: Toxemia of pregnancy

desc: Increased blood pressure during a pregnancy.
name: Maternal hypertension

desc: An acute and life-threatening complication of pregnancy, which is characterized by the appearance of tonic-clonic seizures, usually in a patient who had developed pre-eclampsia. Eclampsia includes seizures and coma that happen during pregnancy but are not due to preexisting or organic brain disorders.
name: Eclampsia

desc: Pregnancy-induced hypertension in association with significant amounts of protein in the urine.
name: Preeclampsia

desc: A medical history of exposure during the fetal period to hyperphenylalaninemia because the mother had phenylketonuria with inadequate control during pregnancy.
layperson: High blood phenylalanine level in mother
name: Maternal hyperphenylalaninemia
synonyms: High blood phenylalanine level in mother

desc: The presence of an abnormally large hypoechoic space in the posterior fetal neck (usually detected on prenatal ultrasound examination).
name: Increased nuchal translucency

desc: An finding upon obstetric ultrasound examination performed at around 16 to 20 weeks of gestation that is abnormal but not clearly identifiable as a fetal anatomic malformation or growth restriction. Such findings are known as soft markers since they are associated with increased risk for fetal aneuploidy or other disorders.
name: Fetal ultrasound soft marker

desc: A finding of a focus of increased echogenicity upon prenatal ultrasound examination of the fetus. The foci may be present in one or both ventricles. Echogenic intracardiac focus (EICF) is defined as a focus of echogenicity comparable to bone, in the region of the papillary muscle in either or both ventricles of the fetal heart.
name: Echogenic intracardiac focus

desc: Echogenic bowel is defined as fetal bowel with homogenous areas of echogenicity that are equal to or greater than that of surrounding bone.
name: Echogenic fetal bowel

desc: By the 14th week of gestation it is nearly always possible to visualized the fluid-filled fetal stomach bubble on prenatal sonography. This term refers to the absence of a normal fetal stomach bubble on fetal ultrasonography performed at around 16 to 20 weeks' gestation.
layperson: Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
name: Absence of stomach bubble on fetal sonography
synonyms: Absence of stomach bubble on foetal sonography

desc: Fetal choroid plexus cysts (CPCs) are sonographically discrete, small cysts found in the choroid plexus within the lateral cerebral ventricles of the developing fetus at 14 to 24 weeks gestation. Imaging of the choroid plexus is performed in the transverse plane of the fetal head at the same level that the lateral cerebral ventricle is evaluated. The choroid plexus should be inspected bilaterally for the presence of cysts. The size of CPCs is not of clinical relevance (PMID:16100637).
name: Fetal choroid plexus cysts

desc: The cisterna magna is measured on a transaxial view of the fetal head angled 15 degrees caudal to the canthomeatal line. The anterior/posterior diameter is taken between the inferior/posterior surface of the vermis of the cerebellum to the inner surface of the cranium. An enlarged cisternal magna is defined by an anterior/posterior diameter of 10 mm or more (PMID:16100637).
name: Enlarged fetal cisterna magna

desc: A short femur length is defined as either a measurement below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or a measurement that is less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The femur should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (PMID:16100637).
name: Short fetal femur length

desc: A short humerus length is defined as a length below the 2.5th percentile for gestational age or as a measurement less than 0.9 of that predicted by the measured biparietal diameter. The humerus should be measured with the bone perpendicular to the ultrasound beam and with epiphyseal cartilages visible but not included in the measurement (PMID:16100637).
layperson: Short fetal long bone in upper arm length
name: Short fetal humerus length
synonyms: Short fetal long bone in upper arm length

desc: On prenatal ultrasound, the nasal bone is a thin echogenic line within the bridge of the fetal nose. The fetus is imaged facing the transducer with the fetal face strictly in the midline. The angle of insonation is 90 degrees, with the longitudinal axis of the nasal bone as the reference line. Calibres are placed at each end of the nasal bone. Absence of the nasal bone or measurements below 2.5th percentile are considered significant (PMID:16100637).
name: Hypoplasia of fetal nasal bone

desc: Fifth finger clinodactyly is defined by a hypoplastic or absent mid-phalanx of the fifth digit. Ultrasound identification of the fetal hand must first be undertaken and then appropriate magnification accomplished. The evaluation requires stretching of the 5 fingers. The diagnosis is established when the middle phalanx of the fifth finger is markedly smaller than normal or absent, which often causes the finger to be curved inward (PMID:16100637).
name: Fetal fifth finger clinodactyly

desc: An intrauterine state characterized by suboptimal values in the fetal heart rate, oxygenation of fetal blood, or other parameters indicative of compromise of the fetus. Signs of fetal distress include repetitive variable decelerations, fetal tachycardia or bradycardia, late decelerations, or low biophysical profile.
name: Fetal distress

desc: Loss of one twin occurring after midgestation (17 weeks gestation).
layperson: Intrauterine fetal demise of one twin after midgestation
name: Intrauterine fetal demise of one twin after midgestation
synonyms: Intrauterine foetal demise of one twin after midgestation

desc: As a result of sharing a single placenta, the blood supplies of monochorionic twin fetuses can become connected, so that they share blood circulation: although each fetus uses its own portion of the placenta, the connecting blood vessels within the placenta allow blood to pass from one twin to the other.Depending on the number, type and direction of the interconnecting blood vessels (anastomoses), blood can be transferred disproportionately from one twin (the donor) to the other (the recipient). This state of transfusion causes the donor twin to have decreased blood volume, retarding the donor's development and growth. The blood volume of the recipient twin is increased, which can strain the fetus's heart and eventually lead to heart failure.
name: Twin-to-twin transfusion

desc: A pregnancy that extends to 42 weeks of gestation or beyond.
name: Postterm pregnancy

desc: Fetal masculinization of female external genitalia.
name: Female fetal virilization

desc: It is estimated that about 40-70 percent of human embryos produced in vitro fertilization (IVF) and intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) are viable embryos, whereas others arrest at different early stages of development. The phenotype of preimplantation lethality is inferred if IVF and ICSI cycles fail because all of an individual's embryos are arrested at early stages of development.
name: Preimplantation lethality

desc: Deviation from the norm of height with respect to that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
name: Abnormality of body height

desc: A height above that which is expected according to age and gender norms.
name: Tall stature

desc: A tall and slim body build with increased arm span to height ratio (>1.05) and a reduced upper-to-lower segment ratio (<0.85), i.e., unusually long arms and legs. The extremities as well as the hands and feet are unusually slim.
name: Disproportionate tall stature

desc: Asthenic habitus refers to a slender build with long limbs, an angular profile, and prominent muscles or bones.
name: Slender build

desc: Excessive postnatal growth which may comprise increased weight, increased length, and/or increased head circumference.
name: Overgrowth

desc: A height below that which is expected according to age and gender norms. Although there is no universally accepted definition of short stature, many refer to "short stature" as height more than 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender (or below the 3rd percentile for age and gender dependent norms).
name: Short stature

desc: A kind of short stature in which different regions of the body are shortened to differing extents.
name: Disproportionate short stature

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by a short limbs but an average-sized trunk.
name: Disproportionate short-limb short stature

desc: A type of disproportionate short stature characterized by disproportionate shortening of the medial parts of the extremities (forearm or lower leg).
name: Mesomelic short stature

desc: A type of short-limbed dwarfism that is manifest beginning in the neonatal period.
name: Neonatal short-limb short stature
synonyms: Short limb dwarfism recognizable at birth

desc: A kind of short stature in which different regions of the body are shortened to a comparable extent.
name: Proportionate short stature

desc: A mild degree of short stature, more than -2 SD but not more than -3 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
name: Mild short stature

desc: A severe degree of short stature, more than -4 SD from the mean corrected for age and sex.
name: Severe short stature

desc: A moderate degree of short stature, more than -3 SD but not more than -4 SD from mean corrected for age and sex.
name: Moderately short stature

desc: A deviation from normal of the relation between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis.
layperson: Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio
name: Abnormal upper to lower segment ratio

desc: Decreased ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis. Consider the term Disproportionate tall stature (HP:0001519) if tall stature is also present.
layperson: Reduced upper to lower segment ratio
name: Reduced upper to lower segment ratio

desc: Elevated ratio between the upper and the lower segment of the body, where the lower segment is defined as the length between the top of pubic symphysis to floor, and the upper segment is defined as the top of head to top of pubic symphysis.
layperson: Increased upper to lower segment ratio
name: Increased upper to lower segment ratio

desc: A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.
name: Growth delay

desc: An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.
name: Intrauterine growth retardation

desc: Intrauterine growth retardation that is 4 or more standard deviations below average, corrected for sex and gestational age.
name: Severe intrauterine growth retardation

desc: Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 2 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 3 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.
name: Mild intrauterine growth retardation

desc: Intrauterine growth retardation that is at least 3 standard deviations (SD) below average, but not as low as 4 SD, corrected for sex and gestational age.
name: Moderate intrauterine growth retardation

desc: Slow or limited growth after birth.
name: Postnatal growth retardation

desc: A mild degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between two and three standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms.
name: Mild postnatal growth retardation
synonyms: Postnatal onset of mild growth retardation

desc: Severely slow or limited growth after birth, being four standard deviations or more below age- and sex-related norms.
name: Severe postnatal growth retardation

desc: A moderate degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between three and four standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms.
name: Moderate postnatal growth retardation

desc: The abrupt and transient increase in the annual growth rate normally observed in adolescent individuals does not occur.
name: Absent pubertal growth spurt

desc: An abnormal increase or decrease of weight or an abnormal distribution of mass in the body.
name: Abnormality of body weight

desc: Abnormally increased body weight.
name: Increased body weight

desc: Accumulation of substantial excess body fat.
name: Obesity

desc: Obesity located preferentially in the trunk of the body as opposed to the extremities.
name: Truncal obesity

desc: Truncal obesity with onset during childhood, defined as between 2 and 10 years of age.
name: Childhood-onset truncal obesity

desc: Excessive fat around the stomach and abdomen.
name: Abdominal obesity

desc: Obesity with a body mass index of 30 to 34.9 kg per square meter.
name: Class I obesity

desc: Obesity with a body mass index of 35 to 39.9 kg per square meter.
name: Class II obesity

desc: Obesity with a body mass index of 40 kg per square meter or higher.
name: Class III obesity

desc: The term large for gestational age applies to babies whose birth weight lies above the 90th percentile for that gestational age.
name: Large for gestational age

desc: Increased body weight with a body mass index of 25-29.9 kg per square meter.
name: Overweight

desc: Abnormally low body weight.
name: Decreased body weight

desc: Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.
name: Failure to thrive
Failure to thrive in infancy
synonyms: Failure to thrive in first year of life

desc: Insufficient weight gain or inappropriate weight loss for a child, that is attributed to an endogenous recurrent infections.
layperson: Weight faltering secondary to recurrent infections
name: Failure to thrive secondary to recurrent infections
synonyms: Weight faltering secondary to recurrent infections
Faltering weight secondary to recurrent infections

desc: Smaller than normal size according to sex and gestational age related norms, defined as a weight below the 10th percentile for the gestational age.
name: Small for gestational age

desc: Reduction inexisting body weight.
name: Weight loss

desc: Severe weight loss, wasting of muscle, loss of appetite, and general debility related to a chronic disease.
name: Cachexia

desc: A body habitus that is tall, slim and underweight, with long legs and long arms (i.e., arm span exceeds height by 5 cm or more).
name: Eunuchoid habitus

desc: Abnormally decreased weight-to-height squared ratio, calculated by dividing the individual's weight in kilograms by the square of the individual's height in meters and used as an indicator of underweight compared to averages.
name: Decreased body mass index

desc: A deviation from normal of the waist to hip ratio, defined as the waist measurement divided by hip measurement.
name: Abnormal waist to hip ratio

desc: Increased waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) is a measurement above the average for the dimensionless ratio of the circumference of the waist to that of the hips. WHR is calculated as waist measurement divided by hip measurement.
name: Increased waist to hip ratio

desc: Decreased waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) is a measurement below the average for the dimensionless ratio of the circumference of the waist to that of the hips. WHR is calculated as waist measurement divided by hip measurement.
name: Decreased waist to hip ratio

desc: Anomaly in the weight-to-height squared ratio, calculated by dividing the individual's weight in kilograms by the square of the individual's height in meters and used as an indicator of obesity and underweight compared to averages.
name: Abnormality of body mass index

desc: Abnormally increased weight-to-height squared ratio, calculated by dividing the individual's weight in kilograms by the square of the individual's height in meters and used as an indicator of overweight compared to averages.
name: Increased body mass index

desc: The percentage of fat as a part of total body weight above the norm, usually defined as 32% for females and 25% for males.
name: Increased body fat percentage

desc: An abnormality in which the internal thoraco-abdominal organs demonstrate abnormal arrangement across the left-right axis of the body.
name: Heterotaxy

desc: An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomen and its organs.
name: Abnormality of abdominal situs

desc: A left-right reversal (or "mirror reflection") of the anatomical location of the viscera of the abdomen.
name: Abdominal situs inversus

desc: An abnormality in which the abdominal organs are positioned in such a way with respect to each other and the left-right axis as to be not clearly lateralised and thus have neither the usual, or normal (situs solitus), nor the mirror-imaged (situs inversus) arrangements.
name: Abdominal situs ambiguus

desc: Isomerism in the context of the congenitally malformed heart is defined as a situation where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are, in morphologic terms, symmetrical mirror images of each other.
name: Isomerism

desc: An anomalous mirror-imaged arrangement of some bronchial structures. Right isomerism is defined as a subset of heterotaxy where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are symmetrical mirror images of each other, and have the morphology of the normal right-sided structures (vice versa for left isomerism).
name: Bronchial isomerism

desc: A type of heterotaxy where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are symmetrical mirror images of each other, and have the morphology of the normal left-sided structures.
name: Left Isomerism

desc: In left atrial isomerism there is a bilateral small finger-shaped morphologically left atrial appendage joining the atrial chamber along a narrow front without an internal terminal crest.
name: Left atrial isomerism

desc: A type of heterotaxy where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are symmetrical mirror images of each other, and have the morphology of the normal right-sided structures.
name: Right isomerism

desc: Right atrial isomerism is characterized by bilateral triangular, morphologically right atrial, appendages, both joining the atrial chamber along a broad front with internal terminal crest.
name: Right atrial isomerism

desc: A growth pattern that displays an abnormal difference between the left and the right side.
layperson: Uneven or disproportionate growth of one body part compared to another
name: Asymmetric growth
synonyms: Uneven or disproportionate growth of one body part compared to another

desc: Overgrowth of only one side of the body.
name: Hemihypertrophy

desc: Overgrowth of only one leg.
name: Hemihypertrophy of lower limb

desc: Overgrowth of only one arm.
name: Hemihypertrophy of upper limb

desc: A difference in length or diameter between the left and right leg.
layperson: Left and right leg differ in length or width
name: Lower limb asymmetry
synonyms: Left and right leg differ in length or width

desc: Difference in length or size between the right and left arm.
name: Upper limb asymmetry

desc: An abnormality of the integument, which consists of the skin and the superficial fascia.
name: Abnormality of the integument

desc: An abnormality of the skin.
name: Abnormality of the skin

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the skin.
name: Neoplasm of the skin

desc: The presence of subcutaneous lipoma.
name: Subcutaneous lipoma

desc: The presence of multiple subcutaneous lipoma that cause pain.
layperson: Painful noncancerous fat tissue tumor under the skin
name: Painful subcutaneous lipomas
synonyms: Painful noncancerous fat tissue tumor under the skin

desc: The presence of a basal cell carcinoma of the skin.
name: Basal cell carcinoma

desc: The presence of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
name: Squamous cell carcinoma

desc: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium.
layperson: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

desc: A squamous cell carcinoma that originates in the oropharnyx.
name: Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma

desc: The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin.
name: Cutaneous leiomyosarcoma

desc: The presence of multiple leiomyomas of the skin.
name: Multiple cutaneous leiomyomas

desc: Presence of a cutaneous lipoma on the forehead.
name: Frontal cutaneous lipoma

desc: The presence of leiomyoma of the skin.
name: Cutaneous leiomyoma

desc: Multiple, localized or widespread, asymptomatic or inflammatory dermal cysts involving the pilosebaceous units. Lesions can appear anywhere on the body, but steatocystoma multiplex is more commonly involved with those areas of the skin with a high density of developed pilosebaceous units (e.g., the axilla, groin, neck, and proximal extremities).
name: Steatocystoma multiplex

desc: The presence of a melanoma of the skin.
name: Cutaneous melanoma

desc: A type of melanoma that is flat and irregular in shape and color, with different shades of black and brown.
name: Superficial spreading melanoma

desc: A type of melanoma that starts as a raised area that is usually dark blackish-blue or bluish-red but may not have any color.
name: Nodular melanoma

desc: A subtype of melanoma in situ that typically develops on sun-damaged skin. The lesion is typically a large, irregularly pigmented macule that has developed from an ordinary lentigo (a small pigmented spot on the skin with a clearly-defined edge). Change to a malignant lentigo typically takes place over 20 years or more, and many patients accept the change as a consequence of aging.
name: Lentigo maligna melanoma

desc: A type of cutaneous melanoma localized to the palm, sole, or beneath the nail (subungual melanoma). Acral lentiginous melanoma starts as a slowly-enlarging flat patch of discoloured skin and usually displays a size above 6 mm and often several centimetres or more in diameter upon diagnosis and variable pigmentation with a mixutre of colors including brown, and blue-grey, black and red. The surface of the lesion is initially smooth but later in the course may become thicker and irregular, and may ulcerate or bleed.
name: Acral lentiginous melanoma

desc: A tumor of the skin or mucous membrane with finger-like projections.
name: Papilloma

desc: A benign epithelial neoplasm characterized by a papillary growth pattern and a proliferation of neoplastic squamous cells without morphologic evidence of malignancy [NCI thesaurus].
name: Squamous Papilloma

desc: A benign exophytic neoplasm that arises from the oropharynx. It is characterized by the presence of a connective tissue core covered by stratified squamous epithelium [NCI thesaurus].
name: Oropharyngeal squamous papilloma

desc: Warts, benign growths on the skin or mucous membranes that cause cosmetic problems as well as pain and discomfort. Warts most often occur on the hands, feet, and genital areas.
name: Verrucae

desc: Multiple skin warts located in multiple parts of the body, e.g., neck, trunks, and extremities.
name: Disseminated cutaneous warts

desc: Warts affecting the skin in the genital area (peniile shaft, scrotum, vagina, or labia majora).
