Warts can be small, beginning as a pinhead-size swelling that may become larger and take on a pdenuculated appearance. Warts can spread and coalesce into large masses in the genital or anal area. Their color is variable but tends to be skin colored or darker, and they may occasionally bleed. Warts may cause itching, redness, or discomfort. An outbreak of genital warts may also cause psychological distress.
name: Genital warts

desc: Slightly raised wart 2-5 mm in diameter often associated with viral infections, commonly persistent in immunodeficient individuals.
name: Verruca plana

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from the hair follicles, sebaceous glands, or sweat glands.
name: Skin appendage neoplasm

desc: An uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation originating in a hair follicle, which is an epidermal adnexal structures responsible for hair growth.
name: Hair follicle neoplasm

desc: A benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
name: Trichilemmoma

desc: Presence of a unitary trichilemmoma, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
name: Single trichilemmoma

desc: Presence of multiple trichilemmomata, a benign tumour originating from the outer root sheath of the hair follicle.
name: Multiple trichilemmomata

desc: A benign hair follicle tumor whose tumor cells form rudimentary hair follicles but not actual hair shafts. A trichoepithelioma is usually less than one centimeter, firm, round, and shihy with yellow, pink, brown, or bluish color. They may occur multiply, usually on the face, and may gradually increase in number with age.
name: Trichoepithelioma

desc: A carcinoma that arises in a sebaseous gland (an exocrine gland of the skin that secretes sebum, a waxy substance)
name: Sebaceous gland carcinoma

desc: Pilomatricoma is an asymptomatic slowly growing benign cutaneous tumor, differentiating towards the hair matrix of the hair follicle. It is covered by normal or hyperemic skin, and usually varies in size from 0.5 to 3 cm.
name: Pilomatrixoma

desc: A benign skin adnexal tumor of eccrine differentiation.
name: Cylindroma

desc: A benign, well circumscribed sweat gland neoplasm with eccrine or apocrine differentiation. It usually presents as a solitary, dome-shaped papule, nodule, or plaque on acral sites. It is characterized by a proliferation of uniform basaloid cells in the dermis and it is associated with the presence of focal ductal and cystic structures [NCIT:C27273].
name: Poroma

desc: A cystic lesions that forms a benign tumor of an apocrine sweat gland.
name: Apocrine hidrocystoma

desc: A cutaneous adnexal neoplasm with variable clinical presentation. It tends to be located in the head and neck and the presentation is papulonodular, scaly, asymptomatic, measuring up to 1-2cm, simulating a basal cell carcinoma.
name: Follicular infundibulum tumor
synonyms: Basal cell hamartoma with follicular differentiation

desc: A small benign fibrovascular tumor of the dermal part of the hair disk. Trichodiscoma is rather simple in appearance and consists of a dome-shaped fibrous tumor with a prominent vascular component that fills the papillary dermis under an atrophic epidermis. As in a normal hair disk, a hair follicle may be present at one edge of the papular lesion.
name: Trichodiscoma

desc: A scaly, crusty lesion caused by damage from the ultraviolet radiation of the sun, with typical location on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Actinic keratosis lesions are often elevated, rough, and wartlike, and may be red, or occasionally tan, pink, or flesh-toned in color.
name: Actinic keratosis

desc: A benign epithelial skin tumor manifesting as a slightly elevated circular plaque or nodule with a red, pink or brown color and a diameter up to 22 mm.
name: Acanthoma

desc: A myxoma originating in the skin.
name: Cutaneous myxoma

desc: Fibrofolliculoma is a clinically asymptomatic, 2-4 mm, skin-colored, dome-shaped smooth papule. It usually arises in the form of multiple lesions in adults in different areas such as the scalp, forehead, face, and neck. According to histology, the lesion is a fibrotic hamartoma characterized by infundibular epithelial proliferation and perifollicular fibrous proliferation.
name: Fibrofolliculoma

desc: Eccrine syringofibroadenoma (ESFA) is a benign adnexal tumor arising most often on the extremities of elderly individuals characterized by anastomosing cords of cuboidal epithelial cells surrounded by a fibrovascular stroma containing plasma cells and ductal structures. ESFA stains positively with epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA).
name: Eccrine syringofibroadenoma

desc: A raised growth on the skin of older individuals. The lesion usually is initially light tan and may darken to dark brown or nearly black. The consistent feature of seborrheic keratoses is their waxy, pasted-on or stuck-on look.
name: Seborrheic keratosis

desc: Keratoacanthoma (KA) is a common benign epithelial tumour that originates from the pilosebaceous glands. In most cases, it is characterized by rapid evolution, followed by spontaneous resolution over 4 to 6 months. KA usually presents as a solitary flesh-coloured nodule with a central keratin plug on the sun-exposed skin of elderly individuals.
name: Keratoacanthoma

desc: Lymphocytoma cutis, or Spiegler-Fendt sarcoid, is classed as one of the pseudolymphomas, referring to inflammatory disorders in which the accumulation of lymphocytes on the skin resemble, clinically and histopathologically, cutaneous lymphomas. Careful clinical evaluation, histopathological and immunohistochemical exams may be needed to make the correct diagnosis.
name: Lymphocytoma cutis

desc: Perifollicular fibroma is a rare cutaneous hamartoma that shows differentiation in the connective tissue sheath of hair follicles. It can occur as a solitary papule or as multiple lesions. Histologically, the lesion consists of a concentric arrangement of cellular fibrous tissue around a normal hair follicle.
name: Perifollicular fibroma

desc: A systemic disease which can present with cutaneous lesions with or without internal involvement. Tumors are caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV).
name: Kaposi's sarcoma

desc: Multifocal dense infiltrates of mast cells in cutaneous tissue.
name: Cutaneous mastocytosis

desc: Any morphological abnormality of the skin.
name: Abnormality of skin morphology

desc: Skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture.
name: Dry skin

desc: Abnormally pale skin.
name: Pallor

desc: A type of pallor that is secondary to the presence of anemia.
name: Anemic pallor

desc: An abnormality of the pigmentation of the skin.
name: Abnormality of skin pigmentation

desc: A darkening of the skin related to an increase in melanin production and deposition.
name: Hyperpigmentation of the skin

desc: A hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size.
name: Hypermelanotic macule

desc: Presence of an unusually high number of lentigines (singular: lentigo), which are flat, tan to brown oval spots.
name: Multiple lentigines

desc: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders.
layperson: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
name: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins

desc: Congenital deep dermal melanosis in the sacral area.
name: Mongolian blue spot

layperson: Increased groin pigmentation with raindrop depigmentation
name: Increased groin pigmentation with raindrop depigmentation

desc: Increased pigmentation of the skin with a netlike (reticular) pattern.
name: Reticular hyperpigmentation

layperson: Mixed hypo- and hyperpigmentation of the skin
name: Mixed hypo- and hyperpigmentation of the skin

layperson: Areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation that do not follow Blaschko lines
name: Areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation that do not follow Blaschko lines

layperson: Discrete 2 to 5-mm hyper- and hypopigmented macules
name: Discrete 2 to 5-mm hyper- and hypopigmented macules

layperson: Axillary and groin hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation
name: Axillary and groin hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation

desc: Symmetrical, blotchy, brownish facial pigmentation.
name: Melasma

desc: A oval and round, colored (usually medium-to dark brown, reddish brown, or flesh colored) lesion. Typically, a melanocytic nevus is less than 6 mm in diameter, but may be much smaller or larger.
name: Melanocytic nevus

desc: The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child.
name: Congenital giant melanocytic nevus

desc: A reduction of skin color related to a decrease in melanin production and deposition.
name: Hypopigmentation of the skin

layperson: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches
name: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches

layperson: Patchy loss of skin color on arms
name: Hypopigmented skin patches on arms
synonyms: Patchy loss of skin color on arms

desc: Absence of melanin pigment in various areas, which is found at birth and is permanent. The lesions are known as leucoderma and are often found on the face, trunk, or limbs.
name: Partial albinism
synonyms: Congenital partial albinism on face, trunk, or limbs

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of skin, hair and eye (iris and retina).
name: Albinism

desc: Piebaldism is characterized by stable and persistent, well-circumscribed depigmented patches present at birth affecting the skin of the face, trunk, and extremities in a symmetrical distribution.
name: Piebaldism

layperson: Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin
name: Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin
synonyms: Confetti hypopigmentation pattern of lower leg skin

desc: Hypomelanotic macules ("ash leaf spots") are white or lighter patches of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by a lack of melanin. White ash leaf-shaped macules are considered to be characteristic of tuberous sclerosis.
name: Hypomelanotic macule

desc: A hypopigmented spot in the shape of a leaf from the mountain ash tree.
name: Ash-leaf spot

desc: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring).
name: Absent skin pigmentation

desc: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the abdomen.
name: Absent pigmentation of the abdomen

desc: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the arms and legs.
name: Absent pigmentation of the limbs

desc: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the chest.
layperson: Lack of skin coloring on chest
name: Absent pigmentation of chest
synonyms: Lack of skin coloring on chest

desc: Lack of skin pigmentation (coloring) of the anterior chest.
layperson: Absent pigmentation of the ventral chest
name: Absent pigmentation of the ventral chest

desc: Patchy and irregular skin pigmentation.
name: Mottled pigmentation

layperson: Mottled pigmentation of the trunk and proximal extremities
name: Mottled pigmentation of the trunk and proximal extremities

desc: The presence of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
name: Freckling

desc: The presence in the axillary region (armpit) of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
name: Axillary freckling

desc: The presence in the inguinal region (groin) of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.
name: Inguinal freckling

desc: Increased pigmentation, either focal or generalized, of the skin surrounding the vermilion of the lips.
name: Perioral hyperpigmentation
synonyms: Darkening of skin around the mouth

desc: An abnormality of the melanosomes, i.e., of the cellular organelles in which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored within melanocytes (the cells that produce pigment in the dermis).
name: Abnormality of dermal melanosomes

desc: The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes.
name: Giant melanosomes in melanocytes

desc: Poikiloderma refers to a patch of skin with (1) reticulated hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, (2) wrinkling secondary to epidermal atrophy, and (3) telangiectasias.
name: Poikiloderma

desc: Laminar thickening of skin.
name: Thickened skin

desc: Thickening of the epidermal layer of the skin.
name: Epidermal thickening

desc: A dermatosis characterized by thickened, hyperpigmented plaques, typically on the intertriginous surfaces and neck.
name: Acanthosis nigricans

desc: Hyperkeratosis is thickening of the outer layer of the skin, the stratum corneum, which is composed of large, polyhedral, plate-like envelopes filled with keratin which are the dead cells that have migrated up from the stratum granulosum.
name: Hyperkeratosis

desc: Abnormal thickening of the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
name: Palmoplantar keratoderma

desc: A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in which only certain areas of the palms and soles are affected.
name: Patchy palmoplantar keratoderma

desc: Increased amount of keratin (visible as white scales) surrounding hair follicles.
name: Perifollicular hyperkeratosis

layperson: Linear arrays of macular hyperkeratoses in flexural areas
name: Linear arrays of macular hyperkeratoses in flexural areas

layperson: Streaks of hyperkeratosis along each finger onto the palm
name: Streaks of hyperkeratosis along each finger onto the palm

desc: A skin condition characterized by excessive development of keratin in hair follicles, resulting in rough, cone-shaped, elevated papules resulting from closure of hair follicles with a white plug of sebum.
name: Follicular hyperkeratosis

desc: Hyperkeratosis affecting the sole of the foot.
name: Plantar hyperkeratosis

desc: Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot.
layperson: Thickening of the outer layer of the skin of the palms and soles
name: Palmoplantar hyperkeratosis
synonyms: Thickening of the outer layer of the skin of the palms and soles
Hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles

desc: Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot in areas exposed to friction.
name: Focal friction-related palmoplantar hyperkeratosis

layperson: Palmoplantar keratosis with erythema and scale
name: Palmoplantar keratosis with erythema and scale

layperson: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles
name: Spinous keratoses of palms and soles

desc: Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans (HLP), also known as Flegel disease, is a keratinization abnormality characterized by small, asymptomatic erythematous papules that leave characteristic punctate bleeding when they become detached. The lesions generally occur symmetrically along the top of the foot and on the legs, appearing more rarely on the arms, forearms, palms, and soles, and even on the oral mucosa.
name: Hyperkeratosis lenticularis perstans

desc: A thickening of the stratum corneum in the region beneath the nails.
name: Subungual hyperkeratosis

desc: A thickening of the stratum corneum, the outer layer of the skin, in the region surrounding the nails.
name: Circumungual hyperkeratosis

desc: Hyperkeratosis affecting the palm of the hand.
name: Palmar hyperkeratosis

desc: Tiny bumps of thickened skin (hyperkeratosis) on the palms of the hands.
name: Punctate palmar hyperkeratosis

desc: A form of hyperkeratosis characterized by thickening of the cornified layer without retained nuclei.
name: Orthokeratotic hyperkeratosis

desc: The presence of verrucous, cobblestone-like papules and nodules in a region of skin that is said to have an appearance like that of cobblestones.
name: Cobblestone-like hyperkeratosis

desc: Abnormal keratinization of the epidermal stratum coreum (horny layer) with increased keratin formation, preservation of the nuclei in the superficial cells, and absence of the stratum granulosum.
name: Hyperparakeratosis

desc: A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point that is composed of localized hyperkeratosis (the latter may be demonstrated histopathologically).
name: Hyperkeratotic papule

desc: Abnormal formation of the keratinocytes of the epidermis characterized by persistence of nuclei, incomplete formation of keratin, and moistness and swelling of the keratinocytes.
name: Parakeratosis

desc: An abnormality of the skin characterized the presence of excessive amounts of dry surface scales on the skin resulting from an abnormality of keratinization.
name: Ichthyosis

desc: A type of ichthyosiform erythroderma with postnatal onset.
name: Postnatal-onset ichthyosiform erythroderma

desc: An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin with congenital onset.
name: Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma

desc: An ichthyosiform abnormality of the skin that presents at birth or shortly thereafter with generalized erythema, blistering, erosions, and peeling. In the subsequent months, erythema and blistering improves but patients go on to develop hyperkeratotic scaling that is especially prominent along the joint flexures, neck, hands and feet.
name: Congenital bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma

desc: The term collodion baby applies to newborns who appear to have an extra layer of skin (known as a collodion membrane) that has a collodion-like quality. It is a descriptive term, not a specific diagnosis or disorder (as such, it is a syndrome). Affected babies are born in a collodion membrane, a shiny waxy outer layer to the skin. This is shed 10-14 days after birth, revealing the main symptom of the disease, extensive scaling of the skin caused by hyperkeratosis. With increasing age, the scaling tends to be concentrated around joints in areas such as the groin, the armpits, the inside of the elbow and the neck. The scales often tile the skin and may resemble fish scales.
name: Congenital nonbullous ichthyosiform erythroderma

desc: Ichthyosis follicularis is characterized by widespread non inflammatory thorn-like follicular projections. Dyskeratotic papules are most pronounced over the extensor extremities and scalp and are symmetrically distributed.
name: Ichthyosis follicularis

desc: Hypergranulosis is an increased thickness of the stratum granulosum.
name: Hypergranulosis

desc: Formation of an anuclear keratin layer
name: Orthokeratosis

desc: Overgrowth of the stratum corneum characterized by flesh-coloured or slightly pigmented smooth or warty papules on the upper surface of hands and feet.
name: Acrokeratosis

desc: A clonal disorder of keratinization with one or multiple atrophic patches surrounded by a clinically and histologically distinctive hyperkeratotic ridgelike border called the cornoid lamella.
name: Porokeratosis

desc: Localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes.
name: Sclerodactyly

desc: Isolated patches of hardened skin (scleroderma).
name: Morphea

desc: A chronic autoimmune phenomenon characterized by fibrosis (or hardening) and vascular alterations of the skin.
name: Scleroderma

desc: Symmetrical thickening, tightening and induration of the skin of the fingers and the skin proximal to the metacarpophalangeal or metatarsophalangeal joints. These changes can involve the entire limb, face, neck and trunk.
name: Proximal scleroderma

desc: The presence of one or more bullae on the skin, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls.
name: Abnormal blistering of the skin

desc: The formation of bullae (blisters) with cleavage in the lamina lucida layer of the skin.
name: Junctional split
synonyms: Subepidermal blistering with cleavage in the lamina lucida

desc: Bullae (defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls) of the skin with an acral distribution (affecting peripheral regions such as hands and feet)
name: Acral blistering

desc: The presence of one or more bullae on the skin of the genital region, defined as fluid-filled blisters more than 5 mm in diameter with thin walls.
name: Genital blistering

desc: Any abnormal increase or reduction in skin elasticity.
name: Abnormal elasticity of skin

desc: Subjective impression of increased softness upon palpitation of the skin.
name: Soft skin

desc: A skin texture that is unusually soft (and may feel silky), and has a malleable consistency resembling that of dough.
name: Soft, doughy skin

desc: Wrinkled, redundant, inelastic and sagging skin.
name: Cutis laxa

desc: Loose and sagging skin often associated with loss of skin elasticity.
name: Redundant skin

desc: Loose and sagging skin of the fingers.
name: Redundant skin on fingers

desc: Loose, wrinkled skin of hands and feet.
layperson: Increased wrinkles of palms and soles
name: Palmoplantar cutis laxa
synonyms: Excessive wrinkled skin of palms and soles
Increased wrinkles of palms and soles
Wrinkled skin of hands and feet

desc: A condition in which the skin can be stretched beyond normal, and then returns to its initial position.
name: Hyperextensible skin

layperson: Excessive skin wrinkling on back of hands and fingers
name: Excessive skin wrinkling on dorsum of hands and fingers
synonyms: Excessive skin wrinkling on back of hands and fingers

desc: Area of skin requiring an increased amount of time to return to its original shape after being stretched.
layperson: Delayed recoil upon stretching of skin
name: Delayed recoil upon stretching of skin

desc: A confined region of lax skin that hangs below the level of the surrounding skin. Histopatholigically, there is a loss of elastic fibers in the dermis of the affected region.
name: Localized area of pendulous skin

desc: Thinned, erythematous, depressed bands of atrophic skin. Initially, striae appear as flattened and thinned, pinkish linear regions of the skin. Striae tend to enlarge in length and become reddish or purplish. Later, striae tend to appear as white, depressed bands that are parallel to the lines of skin tension. Striae distensae occur most often in areas that have been subject to distension such as the lower back, buttocks, thighs, breast, abdomen, and shoulders.
name: Striae distensae

desc: An abnormally increased ability of the skin to permit light to pass through (translucency) such that subcutaneous structures such as veins display an increased degree of visibility.
name: Dermal translucency

desc: An abnormality of the morphology of the epidermis.
name: Abnormality of epidermal morphology

desc: Diffuse hypertrophy or thickening of the stratum spinosum of the epidermis (prickle cell layer of the skin).
layperson: Thickening of upper layer of skin
name: Epidermal acanthosis
synonyms: Thickening of upper layer of skin

desc: A type of epidermal acanthosis characterized by a jagged (sawtooth) appearance of the rete ridges of the epidermis.
name: Sawtooth acanthosis

desc: Eosinophilic hyaline ovoid bodies which are often found in the subepidermal papillary regions or sometimes in the epidermis. Civatte bodies (CBs) are seen as rounded, homogenous, eosinophilic masses on routine H and E staining lying in the deeper parts of epidermis/epithelium and more frequently in dermis/connective tissue. They are known as CBs (in epithelium/epidermis), colloid bodies, or hyaline bodies (in connective tissue). They are 10-25 micrometers in diameter and situated mostly within or above the inflammatory cell infiltrate. In lichen planus, the number of necrotic keratinocytes may be so large that they are seen lying in clusters in the uppermost dermis. These bodies show a positive periodic acid Schiff reaction and are diastase resistant
name: Civatte bodies

desc: Rete pegs (or ridges) are the epithelial extensions that project into the underlying connective tissue in both skin and mucous membranes. Rete ridge flattening refers to the loss of these projections so that the skin epithelium acquires a relatively flat appearance.
name: Rete ridge flattening

desc: Refers to the loss of the outer layer of the epidermis in large, scale-like flakes.
name: Scaling skin

desc: Loss of the outer layer of the epidermis in large, scale-like flakes localized to the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot.
name: Palmoplantar scaling skin

desc: Loss of the outer layer of the epidermis in large, scale-like flakes localized to one or more fingertips.
name: Scaling skin on fingertip

desc: A skin lesions that resembles the lesions observed in psoriasis, viz., an erythematous plaque covered by fine silvery scales. Psoriasiform lesions can be observed in psoriasis as well as in other conditions including allergic contact dermatitis, seborrhoeic dermatitis, Atopic dermatitis, pityriasis rubra, and lichen simplex chronicus.
name: Psoriasiform lesion

desc: The loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes.
name: Acantholysis

desc: An abnormality of the skin that is not localized to any one particular region.
name: Generalized abnormality of skin

desc: Ectodermal dysplasia is a group of conditions in which there is abnormal development of the skin, hair, nails, teeth, or sweat glands.
name: Ectodermal dysplasia

desc: An increased sensitivity of the skin to light. Photosensitivity may result in a rash upon exposure to the sun (which is known as photodermatosis). Photosensitivity can be diagnosed by phototests in which light is shone on small areas of skin.
name: Cutaneous photosensitivity

desc: Photosensitivity of the skin occurring early in life.
layperson: Sun sensitivity occurring early in life
name: Early cutaneous photosensitivity
synonyms: Sun sensitivity occurring early in life

desc: A severe degree of photosensitivity of the skin.
name: Severe photosensitivity

desc: The cardinal symptom is severely pruritic skin lesions. Macular, papular, papulovesicular, urticarial, multiforme- and plaque-like variants are differentiated morphologically, hence the name polymorphous. Usually one morphology dominates in a single individual (monomorphous). The skin lesions develop a few hours to several days after sun exposure. Initially, patchy erythema develops, accompanied by pruritus. Distinct lesions then develop. The upper chest, upper arms, backs of the hands, thighs, and the sides of the face are the primary localizations. The skin lesions resolve spontaneously within several days of ceasing sun exposure and do not leave behind any traces.
name: Polymorphous light eruption

desc: In response to the spring sun distinct inflamed reddened skin develops on the ears, nose, cheeks, fingers, backs of the hands, and the lower arms, on which blisters with serous or hemorrhagic content develop. These dry out with the formation of a blackish scab. After shedding of the scab, depressed, varioliform, often hypopigmented scars remain. In addition, hyper- and hypopigmentation are present together, resulting in a polymorphous skin presentation.
name: Hydroa vacciniforme
synonyms: Acute vesiculation and crusting and scarring following sun exposure

desc: Urticaria in response to exposure to ultraviolet-A (UVA), ultraviolet-B (UVB), visible and rarely infrared light.
name: Solar urticaria

layperson: Abnormality of fatty tissue below the skin
name: Abnormality of subcutaneous fat tissue
synonyms: Abnormality of fatty tissue below the skin

desc: A reduced amount of fat tissue in the lowest layer of the integument. This feature can be appreciated by a reduced skinfold thickness.
layperson: Reduced fat tissue below the skin
name: Reduced subcutaneous adipose tissue
synonyms: Reduced fat tissue below the skin

layperson: Lack of facial fat below the skin
name: Lack of facial subcutaneous fat
synonyms: Lack of facial fat below the skin

desc: Reduced amount of adipose tissue in the region of the neck.
name: Decreased adipose tissue around neck
synonyms: Loss of adipose tissue around the neck

layperson: Yellow subcutaneous tissue covered by thin, scaly skin
name: Yellow subcutaneous tissue covered by thin, scaly skin

layperson: Abnormal fat tissue distribution below the skin
name: Abnormal subcutaneous fat tissue distribution
synonyms: Abnormal fat tissue distribution below the skin

desc: The presence of an abnormally increased amount of subcutaneous adipose tissue in the trunk of the body.
layperson: Increased fat below the skin in trunk
name: Increased subcutaneous truncal adipose tissue
synonyms: Increased fat below the skin in trunk

desc: An area of fat accumulation at the back of the neck in the form of a hump.
name: Dorsocervical fat pad

desc: Yellow pigmentation of the skin due to bilirubin, which in turn is the result of increased bilirubin concentration in the bloodstream.
name: Jaundice

desc: Jaundice that is sometimes present, sometimes not.
name: Intermittent jaundice

desc: Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.
layperson: Prolonged yellowing of skin in newborn
name: Prolonged neonatal jaundice
synonyms: Prolonged yellowing of skin in newborn

desc: Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucosa due to poor circulation or inadequate oxygenation of arterial or capillary blood.
name: Cyanosis

layperson: Persistent blue color of hands, feet, or parts of face
name: Acrocyanosis
synonyms: Persistent blue color of hands, feet, or parts of face

desc: Persistent blue color of the skin that surrounds the mouth.
name: Circumoral cyanosis

desc: Skin that splits easily with minimal injury.
name: Fragile skin

desc: A reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds.
name: Poor wound healing

desc: Development of gray hair at a younger than normal age.
name: Premature graying of hair

desc: A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
name: Progeroid facial appearance

desc: The presence of an increased degree of wrinkling (irregular folds and indentations) of the skin as compared with age-related norms.
name: Premature skin wrinkling

layperson: Wrinkled skin of hands and feet in newborn
name: Neonatal wrinkled skin of hands and feet
synonyms: Wrinkled skin of hands and feet in newborn

desc: Excessive wrinkling of the skin of the face.
name: Facial wrinkling

layperson: Desquamation of skin soon after birth
name: Desquamation of skin soon after birth

desc: A reticular discoloration of the skin with cyanotic (reddish-blue appearing) areas surrounding pale central areas due to dilation of capillary blood vessels and stagnation of blood within the vessels. Cutis marmorata, also called livedo reticularis, generally occurs on the legs, arms and trunk and is often more severe in cold weather.
name: Cutis marmorata

desc: Telangiectasias refer to small dilated blood vessels located near the surface of the skin or mucous membranes, measuring between 0.5 and 1 millimeter in diameter. Telangiectasia are located especially on the tongue, lips, palate, fingers, face, conjunctiva, trunk, nail beds, and fingertips.
name: Telangiectasia

desc: Telangiectases in the area of the nails.
name: Nail bed telangiectasia

desc: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) with a diffuse localization.
name: Diffuse telangiectasia

desc: Telangiectasia of the mucosa, the mucous membranes which are involved in absorption and secretion that line cavities that are exposed to the external environment and internal organs.
name: Mucosal telangiectasiae

desc: Telangiectasia affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
layperson: Small, enlarged blood vessels near skin
name: Gastrointestinal telangiectasia
synonyms: Small, enlarged blood vessels near skin

desc: Presence of small, permanently dilated blood vessels near the surface of the skin, visible as small focal red lesions.
name: Telangiectasia of the skin

desc: Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located in the fingerpads at the tips of the fingers.
layperson: Small dilated blood vessels in fingerpads
name: Fingerpad telangiectases
synonyms: Small dilated blood vessels in fingerpads

desc: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the face.
name: Facial telangiectasia

desc: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution.
layperson: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution
name: Facial telangiectasia in butterfly midface distribution

desc: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin of the cheeks.
name: Telangiectases of the cheeks

layperson: Telangiectases in sun-exposed and nonexposed skin
name: Telangiectases in sun-exposed and nonexposed skin

desc: A form of telangiectasis characterized by a central elevated red dot the size of a pinhead, representing an arteriole, with numerous small blood vessels that radiate out thereby resembling the legs of a spider. Characteristically, compression of the central arteriole causes the entire lesion to blanch, and the lesion quickly refills once the compression is released.
name: Spider hemangioma

desc: Telangiectasia (small dilated blood vessels) located near to the fingernails or toenails.
name: Periungual teleangiectasia

desc: The presence of telangiectases on the skin of palm of hand.
name: Palmar telangiectasia

desc: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located on the skin of sole of foot.
name: Plantar telangiectasia

desc: A vascular lesion defined histologically as one or more dilated blood vessels lying directly subepidermal and showing an epidermal proliferative reaction. Clinically, angiokeratoma presents as a small, raised, dark-red spot.
name: Angiokeratoma

desc: Raised, well-circumscribed areas of erythema and edema involving the dermis and epidermis. Urticaria is intensely pruritic, and blanches completely with pressure.
name: Urticaria

desc: A skin change elicited by briskly rubbing the skin lesion in urticaria pigmentosa (UP), whereby the area begins to itch and becomes raised and surrounded by erythema. Unlike other forms of dermatographism, Darier's sign refers to urtication that is limited to the UP involved areas and, as in this case, spares the skin unaffected by UP.
name: Darier's sign

desc: Urticaria characterized by spontaneously recurring hives for 6 weeks or longer.
name: Chronic idiopathic urticaria

desc: Urticaria caused by physical agents, such as heat, cold, light, friction.
name: Physical urticaria

desc: An exaggerated whealing tendency when the skin is stroked, that is, formation of red, itchy bumps and lines on the skin as a result of pressure on the skin (for instance, stroking the skin with a pen or tongue depressor).
name: Dermatographic urticaria

desc: Urticaria may be caused by cold temperatures.
name: Cold urticaria

desc: A form of physical urticaria, in which contact with water, regardless of its temperature and source, evokes pruritic follicular wheals on the skin.
name: Aquagenic urticaria

desc: Urticaria in response to dermal vibration, with coincident degranulation of mast cells and increased histamine levels in serum.
name: Vibratory urticaria

desc: This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to bruising (purpura, petechiae, or ecchymoses).
name: Subcutaneous hemorrhage

desc: An ecchymosis (bruise) refers to the skin discoloration caused by the escape of blood into the tissues from ruptured blood vessels. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to bruising. The corresponding phenotypic abnormality is generally elicited on medical history as a report of frequent ecchymoses or bruising without adequate trauma.
name: Bruising susceptibility

desc: Purpura (from Latin: purpura, meaning "purple") is the appearance of red or purple discolorations on the skin that do not blanch on applying pressure. They are caused by bleeding underneath the skin. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing purpura. Purpura are larger than petechiae.
layperson: Red or purple spots on the skin
name: Purpura
synonyms: Red or purple spots on the skin

desc: A type of purpura in which the lesions are raised (and can therefore be appreciated upon palpation).
name: Palpable purpura

desc: Purpura that is flat (non-palpable, not raised).
name: Macular purpura

desc: Petechiae are pinpoint-sized reddish/purple spots, resembling a rash, that appear just under the skin or a mucous membrane when capillaries have ruptured and some superficial bleeding into the skin has happened. This term refers to an abnormally increased susceptibility to developing petechiae.
name: Petechiae

desc: A purpuric lesion that is larger than 1 cm in diameter.
name: Ecchymosis

desc: Spontaneous development of hematomas (hematoma) or bruises without significant trauma.
name: Spontaneous hematomas

desc: A condition in which superficial veins (i.e., veins just under the skin) are more conspicuous or noticable than normal.
name: Prominent superficial veins

desc: Prominent thoracic and abdominal veins.
name: Prominent veins on trunk

desc: Increase in diameter of the veins located underneath the skin of the abdomen.
name: Dilated superficial abdominal veins
synonyms: Dilatation of the superficial abdominal veins

desc: Distended and engorged umbilical veins which are seen radiating from the umbilicus across the abdomen to join systemic veins.
name: Caput medusae

desc: Persistence of the embryonic dorsal or sciatic vein system that normally should have involuted around the tenth to twelfth week of intrauterine life.
name: Lateral venous anomaly

desc: Redness of the skin, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
name: Erythema
synonyms: Redness of skin or mucous membrane

desc: Redness of the skin of the face, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
name: Facial erythema

desc: Redness of the skin of the palm of the hand and the sole of the foot caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.
name: Palmoplantar erythema

desc: Erythematous, poikilodermatous macules distributed in a shawl pattern over the shoulders, arms and upper back.
name: Shawl sign

desc: Erythematous, poikilodermatous macules distributed in a V-shaped distribution over the anterior neck and chest.
name: V-sign

desc: An expanding erythematous (red) skin lesion, usually round or oval, by definition at least 5 cm in size (in largest diameter).
name: Erythema migrans

desc: Acral or periorificial lesions that evolve in recurrent crops, with an annular and migratory distribution.
name: Necrolytic migratory erythema

desc: Pale reddish slightly elevated papules and plaques of 0.5-3 cm in diameter and not accompanied by pruritus.
name: Non-pruritic urticaria

desc: Rapid swelling (edema) of the dermis, subcutaneous tissue, mucosa and submucosal tissues of the skin of the face, normally around the mouth, and the mucosa of the mouth and/or throat, as well as the tongue during a period of minutes to several hours. The swelling can also occur elsewhere, typically in the hands. Angioedema is similar to urticaria, but the swelling is subcutaneous rather than on the epidermis.
name: Angioedema

desc: Recurrent episodes of redness of the skin together with a sensation of warmth or burning of the affected areas of skin.
name: Flushing

desc: A lesion of the skin that is located in a specific region rather than being generalized.
name: Localized skin lesion

desc: Cafe-au-lait spots are hyperpigmented lesions that can vary in color from light brown to dark brown with smooth borders and having a size of 1.5 cm or more in adults and 0.5 cm or more in children.
name: Cafe-au-lait spot

desc: The presence of two to five cafe-au-lait macules.
name: Few cafe-au-lait spots

desc: The presence of six or more cafe-au-lait spots.
name: Multiple cafe-au-lait spots
synonyms: Multiple flat light-brown marks on skin

desc: Atypically scarred skin .
name: Atypical scarring of skin

desc: Scars that form a depression compared to the level of the surrounding skin because of damage to the collagen, fat or other tissues below the skin.
layperson: Sunken or indented skin due to damage
name: Atrophic scars
synonyms: Sunken or indented skin due to damage

desc: Thin (atrophic) and wide scars.
name: Cigarette-paper scars

desc: An atrophic scar (fibrous connective tissue resulting from incomplete healing of a wound) that has stretched (gotten wider), a manifestation of tissue fragility.
name: Widened atrophic scar

desc: The presence of multiple xanthomas (xanthomata) in the skin. Xanthomas are yellowish, firm, lipid-laden nodules in the skin.
layperson: Yellow bumps of fatty deposits on skin
name: Xanthomatosis
synonyms: Yellow bumps of fatty deposits on skin

desc: Eruptive xanthomas are yellow-orange-to-red-brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo. They appear in crops on the buttocks, extensor surfaces of the extremities, and flexural creases. Acutely, variable amounts of pruritus and pain occur.
name: Eruptive xanthomas

desc: The presence of multiple xanthomas (xanthomata) in the skin distributed in the creases of the palm of the hand. Xanthomas are yellowish, firm, lipid-laden nodules in the skin.
name: Xanthomas of the palmar creases

desc: A type of xanthoma characterized by a nodular form. Tuberous xanthomas are firm subcutaneous nodules,whereby the overlying skin can have red or red-yellow color changes.
name: Tuberous xanthoma

desc: A papillary or cauliflower-like growth characterized by the presence of foamy histiocytes within the elongated dermal papillae forms.
name: Verruciform xanthoma

desc: Bluish-grey, spongy nodules associated with scars over pressure points and easily traumatized areas like the elbows and knees.
name: Molluscoid pseudotumors

desc: Presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin (skin protein) and presenting as tiny pearly-white bumps just under the surface of the skin.
name: Milia

desc: A nevus is a type of hamartoma that is a circumscribed stable malformation of the skin.
name: Nevus

desc: A congenital vascular malformation consisting of superficial and deep dilated capillaries in the skin which produce a reddish to purplish discolouration of the skin.
name: Nevus flammeus

desc: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the forehead.
name: Nevus flammeus of the forehead

desc: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the neck. This is one of the most common birthmarks and present in approximately 25% of all newborns.
name: Nevus flammeus nuchae

desc: Naevus flammeus localised in the skin of the eyelid.
name: Naevus flammeus of the eyelid

desc: A large pigmented lesion measuring 5-15 mm in diameter with irregular, notched, and ill defined border and with color that may range from tan to dark brown to pink.
name: Atypical nevus

layperson: Atypical nevi in non-sun exposed areas
name: Atypical nevi in non-sun exposed areas

desc: A dermal melanocytic hamartoma that presents as bluish hyperpigmentation on the face along the first or second branches of the trigeminal nerve. Nevus of Ota may involve the sclera.
name: Nevus of Ota

desc: Epidermal naevi are due to an overgrowth of the epidermis and may be present at birth (50%) or develop during childhood.
name: Epidermal nevus

desc: A congenital, hairless plaque consisting of overgrown epidermis, sebaceous glands, hair follicles, apocrine glands and connective tissue. They are a variant of epidermal naevi. Sebaceous naevi most often appear on the scalp, but they may also arise on the face, neck or forehead. At birth, a sevaceous nevus typically appears as a solitary, smooth, yellow-orange hairless patch. Sebaceous naevi become more pronounced around adolescence, often appearing bumpy, warty or scaly.
name: Nevus sebaceous

desc: A type of nevus sebaceous with a linear form, raised borders and yellowish color.
name: Linear nevus sebaceous

desc: A type of epidermal nevus characterized by closely arranged, dilated follicular openings with keratinous plugs resembling classical comedones.
name: Nevus comedonicus

desc: A hamartomatous proliferation containing malformed hair follicles in various stages of development. Panfolliculomas are well-circumscribed lesions demonstrating all stages of follicular differentiation.
name: Congenital panfollicular nevus

desc: A tan, regularly bordered patch with darker macules within the lesion.
name: Nevus spilus

desc: A solitary yellow-orange slightly raised plaque typically on scalp or face. The plaque typically thickens and becomes more verrucous or pebbly during childhood.
name: Nevus sebaceus

desc: Connective tissue nevi are hamartomas in which one or several components of the dermis is altered.
name: Connective tissue nevi

desc: A plaque representing a connective-tissue nevus. Connective tissue naevi are uncommon skin lesions that occur when the deeper layers of the skin do not develop correctly or the components of these layers occur in the wrong proportion. Shagreen patches are oval-shaped and nevoid, skin-colored or occasionally pigmented, smooth or crinkled, The word shagreen refers to a type of roughened untanned leather.
name: Shagreen patch

desc: Reduction in thickness of the skin, generally associated with a loss of suppleness and elasticity of the skin.
name: Thin skin

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin in multiple or solitary non-inflammatory, well-demarcated, oval or circular ulcers with a diameter of about 1 to 2 cm. Aplasia cutis congenita most commonly occurs on the scalp, but may present in the face, trunk, or limbs.
layperson: Absence of part of skin at birth
name: Aplasia cutis congenita
synonyms: Absence of part of skin at birth

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp.
name: Aplasia cutis congenita of scalp

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp vertex, often just lateral to the midline.
layperson: Aplasia cutis congenita over the scalp vertex
name: Aplasia cutis congenita over the scalp vertex

layperson: Aplasia cutis congenita of midline scalp vertex
name: Aplasia cutis congenita of midline scalp vertex

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the scalp in the parietal area.
layperson: Aplasia cutis congenita over parietal area
name: Aplasia cutis congenita over parietal area
synonyms: Absent cutis congenita over parietal area

layperson: Aplasia cutis congenita over posterior parietal area
name: Aplasia cutis congenita over posterior parietal area

desc: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin on the trunk or the limbs.
layperson: Aplasia cutis congenita on trunk or limbs
name: Aplasia cutis congenita on trunk or limbs

desc: Partial or complete wasting (atrophy) of the skin.
name: Dermal atrophy

layperson: Missing skin on limbs since birth
name: Congenital absence of skin of limbs
synonyms: Missing skin on limbs since birth

desc: Cutaneous skin tags also known as acrochorda or fibroepithelial polyps are small benign tumours that may either form secondarily over time primarily in areas where the skin forms creases, such as the neck, armpit or groin or may also be present at birth, in which case they usually occur in the periauricular region.
name: Skin tags

desc: Skin dimples are cutaneous indentations that are the result of tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) causing an indentation.
name: Skin dimple

layperson: Skin dimple over apex of long bone angulation
name: Skin dimple over apex of long bone angulation

desc: A subtype of skin dimples occurring in the shoulder region.
name: Shoulder dimple

desc: A groove or crease on the shins (pretibial, i.e., over the shin bone). Pretibial creases may be obvious at birth and may range from 3 cm to over 15 cm in length and lenghten as the limb grows. They appear as an elongated dimple because of the attachment of skin to underlying tissue (e.g., to the tibia). The dimple or crease grows in proportion to the growth of the leg.
name: Pretibial dimple

desc: A cutaneous indentation resulting from tethering of the skin to underlying structures (bone) of the hand.
name: Hand dimple

desc: A flat, distinct, discolored area of skin less than 1 cm wide that does not involve any change in the thickness or texture of the skin.
name: Macule

desc: A white or lighter patch of skin that may appear anywhere on the body and are caused by decreased skin pigmentation.
name: Hypopigmented macule

desc: A macule (flat, distinct, discolored area of skin less than 1 cm wide that does not involve any change in the thickness or texture of the skin) with a red or reddish color often associated with inflammation or irritation.
name: Erythematous macule

desc: A capillary malformation is a flat, sharply defined vascular stain of the skin. It may cover a large surface area or it may be scattered and appear as little islands of color. In a capillary maformation, the predominant vessels are small, slow-flow vessels (i.e., arterioles and postcapillary venules).
name: Capillary malformation

desc: A congenital skin lesion characterized by irregular hypopigmented macules that coalesce to form plaques and occur particularly on the chest. It is generally present at birth or develops in the first days of life. It is more common in females. Diagnosis is confirmed by applying gentle friction to the lesion and the surrounding skin and checking that the erythema produced in the healthy skin does not appear in the hypopigmented lesion. This pale macule becomes more conspicuous when the lesion and its surroundings are rubbed. The margin of the naevus is ill-defined and consists of an archipelago of small anaemic spots.
name: Nevus anemicus

desc: A variant of port-wine stain characterized by a pale red or even pink tone, in contrast to the darker hue of the port-wine stain. By analogy with the term port-wine stain, this variant rose-wine stain, or nevus roseus. Nevus roseus, however, cannot be definitely diagnosed until adulthood as port-wine stains are sometimes pink in children. While the natural history of port-wine stains includes hypertrophy, darkening, and nodularity, nevus roseus remains unchanged for life.
name: Nevus roseus

desc: A congenital vascular malformation that presents as localized or generalized erythematous-telangiectatic lesions with a reticular pattern; the lesions are almost always present at birth or develop in the first days of life. Cutis marmorata telangiectatica congenita (CMTC) appears as marble-like pattern (mottling) on the surface of the skin. In contrast to cutis marmorata, the marbling is more severe and always visible.
name: Cutis marmorata telangiectatica congenita

desc: Angioma serpiginosum consists of punctate, tightly packed telangiectatic lesions. Characteristic histopathological features are dilated and tortuous capillaries involving the uppermost part of the dermis.
name: Angioma serpentinum

desc: A hollow mass located in the skin that is surrounded by an epithelium-lined wall and is well demarcated from the adjacent tissue. Cysts are often said to be sac-like and may contain serous liquid or semisolid material.
name: Cutaneous cyst

desc: Nontender, round and firm, but slightly compressible, intradermal or subcutaneous cyst measuring 0.5-5 cm in diameter. Trichilemmal cysts are acquired rather than congenital, and tend to appear on the scalp rather than the face, and to be intradermal rather than subcutaneous.
name: Trichilemmal cyst

desc:
A congenital subcutaneous cyst that arises from entrapment of skin along the lines of embryonic fusion. In contrast to epidermal cysts, dermoid cysts tend to contain various adnexal structures such as hair, sebaceous, eccrine or apocrine glands. Dermoid cysts are present at birth, and are indolent, firm, deep, subcutaneous nodules. They are often located on the head and neck, and rarely in the anogenital area. Dermoid cysts are
slowly progressive and can grow to a size of 1 to 4 cm.
name: Dermoid cyst

desc: A cutaneous cyst that is small (one or two millimeters in diameter) and painless, presenting as a follicular papule that usually is skin colored but may have a reddish or brownish tinge.
name: Eruptive vellus hair cyst

desc: Nontender, round and firm, but slightly compressible, intradermal or subcutaneous cyst measuring 0.5-5 cm in diameter. Epidermal cysts are intradermal or subcutaneous tumors, grow slowly and occur on the face, neck, back and scrotum. They usually appear at or around puberty, and as a rule an affected individual has one solitary or a few cysts.
name: Epidermoid cyst

desc: An epidermoid cyst in the armpit.
name: Axillary epidermoid cyst

desc: A clogged cutaneous sebaceous follicle, which is a cutaneous gland that secretes sebum (usually into a hair follicle).
name: Comedo

desc: A comedo in which the top of the pore is not stretched open and thus does not expose the clogged portion (which would appear black), hence the name whitehead.
name: Closed comedo

desc: A comedo in which the part of the pore at the surface of the skin is stretched and open, exposing the contents of the comedo, which appear black.
name: Open comedo

desc: A skin lesion with a snake- or serpent-like distribution.
name: Serpiginous cutaneous lesion

desc: A lesion of the skin with a ring-like distribution.
name: Annular cutaneous lesion

desc: A clearly-defined and roughly linear cleavage in the skin that usually extends to the dermis.
name: Skin fissure

desc: Mutliple skin lesions resembling those characteristic of the disease lichen planus. These lesions are violaceous (reddish-purple), shiny, isolated, flat-topped papules and plaques.
name: Lichenoid skin lesion

desc: The presence of linear erythematous palpable cords, often on the lateral trunk.
name: Rope sign

desc: Circumscribed area of flaccid skin due to the loss of elastic tissue in the dermis.
name: Anetoderma

desc: The presence of radial grooves in the skin surrounding the mouth (see Figure 4 of PMID:27833976).
name: Perioral radial furrowing

desc: Loss of sections of skin either spontaneously or after gentle handling.
name: Skin detachment

desc: A small, skin-lined tract that leads from the surface to deep within the tissues.
name: Skin pit

desc: The presence of multiple pits (small, pinpoint-large indentations on the surface of the skin) located on the skin of sole of foot.
name: Plantar pits

desc: Pinhole-sized concave depressions with hyperkeratosis in the skin of a finger or toe.
name: Digital pitting scar

desc: A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
name: Papule

desc: A wartlike (with multiple small elevated projections) papule.
name: Verrucous papule

desc: A papule (circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid, varying in size from a pinhead to less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point) that exhibits increased pigmentation (is darker) compared to the surrounding skin.
name: Hyperpigmented papule

desc: A papule with yellow color.
name: Yellow papule

desc: Violaceous papules overlying the dorsal and lateral aspects of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints.
name: Gottron's papules

desc: Flesh-colored or yellowish papules, 2 mm or larger, that are responses to internal mechanical pressure and weakness in the connective tissue in the dermis, appear commonly over the medial aspect of the heel, but in some cases on the wrists. They are thought to represent herniations of adipose tissue through the plantar fascia retinaculum.
name: Piezogenic pedal papules

desc: A papule with the same color as the surrounding skin.
name: Skin-colored papule

desc: A circumscribed, solid elevation of skin with no visible fluid that is reddish (erythematous) in color.
name: Erythematous papule

desc: A papule with white color.
name: White papule

desc: A plaque is a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter.
name: Skin plaque

desc: A plaque (a solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter) with a red or reddish color often associated with inflammation or irritation.
name: Erythematous plaque

desc: A well-circumscribed, intensely pruritic, raised wheal (edema of the superficial skin) typically 1 to 2 cm in diameter.
name: Urticarial plaque

desc: A solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter that is characterized by hardening (sclerosis) of the affected skin area (related to collagen thickening).
name: Cutaneous sclerotic plaque

desc: A solid, raised, plateau-like (flat-topped) lesion greater than 1 cm in diameter and that has a yellow color.
name: Yellow skin plaque

desc: Morphologically similar to a papule, but greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat.
name: Skin nodule
synonyms: Growth of abnormal tissue on or under the skin

desc: Slightly elevated lesions on or in the skin with a diameter of over 5 mm.
layperson: Growth of abnormal tissue under the skin
name: Subcutaneous nodule
synonyms: Growth of abnormal tissue under the skin

desc: Subcutaneous nodules that are located in the vicinity of joints.
name: Periarticular subcutaneous nodules

desc: Small, hard cyst-like nodules, freely moveable in the subcutis over the bony prominences of the legs and arms, which have an outer calcified layer with a translucent core on x-ray.
name: Subcutaneous spheroids

desc: The term osteoma refers to the anomalous presence of ossification (bone formation) in the interior of the dermis or epidermis. The dermal or subcutaneous bone formation presents as stony hard nodules. The osteomata appear as irregular, hardened small nodules that are well circumscribed and generally of the same color as the skin.
name: Osteoma cutis

desc: A type of skin nodule that has a small depression that resembles a navel (i.e., is umbilicated).
name: Umbilicated nodule

desc: A nodule of the skin that exhibits an increased amount of pigmentation.
name: Hyperpigmented nodule

desc: A type of skin nodule (a lesions that is greater than either 10mm in both width and depth, and most frequently centered in the dermis or subcutaneous fat) with a yellowish coloration (that reflects a high lipid content of the lesion).
name: Yellow nodule

desc: A skin nodule that is unusually hard (indurated).
name: Indurated nodule

desc: A circumscribed, fluid-containing, epidermal elevation generally considered less than 10mm in diameter at the widest point.
name: Skin vesicle

desc: Multiple vesicles distributed in multiple distinct groups consisting of multiple adjacent vesicles.
name: Herpetiform vesicles

desc: A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting incomplete loss of the epidermis, a lesion that is moist, circumscribed, and usually depressed.
name: Skin erosion

desc: A discontinuity of the skin exhibiting complete loss of the epidermis and often portions of the dermis and even subcutaneous fat.
name: Skin ulcer

desc: A type of ulcer that is caused when an area of skin is subject to pressure over a prolonged period of time, ranging in range in severity from patches of discolored skin to open wounds that expose the underlying bone or muscle. The most common sites are the sacrum, coccyx, heels and the hips.
name: Pressure ulcer

desc: A deep skin ulcer with a well defined border, which is usually violet or blue. The ulcer edge is often undermined (worn and damaged) and the surrounding skin is erythematous and indurated. The ulcer often starts as a small papule or collection of papules, which break down to form small ulcers with a so called cat's paw appearance. These coalesce and the central area then undergoes necrosis to form a single ulcer.
name: Pyoderma gangrenosum

desc: An open sore on the surface of the skin of a finger or toe.
name: Digital ulcer

desc: A type of digital ulcer that manifests as an open sore on the surface of the skin at the tip of a finger or toe.
name: Acral ulceration

desc: An abnormality of the skin that is restricted to a particular body region.
name: Regional abnormality of skin

desc: An abnormality of dermatoglyphs (fingerprints), which are present on fingers, palms, toes, and soles.
name: Abnormal dermatoglyphics

desc: An abnormality of the dermatoglyphs, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of palm of hand.
name: Abnormal palmar dermatoglyphics

desc: An abnormality of the creases of the skin of palm of hand.
name: Abnormality of the palmar creases

desc: The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease.
name: Single transverse palmar crease

desc: The distal and proximal transverse palmar creases are merged into a single transverse palmar crease on both hands.
name: Bilateral single transverse palmar creases

desc: The presence of multiple creases on the palm of the hand (more than the normal three major creases (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, and thenar crease).
name: Multiple palmar creases

desc: Excessively deep creases of the palm.
name: Deep palmar crease

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the palmar creases.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the palmar creases

desc: Poorly defined or shallow palmar creases.
name: Decreased palmar creases

desc: The absence of the major creases of the palm (distal transverse crease, proximal transverse crease, or thenar crease).
name: Absent palmar crease

desc: A crease that connects the proximal and distal transverse palmar creases.
name: Bridged palmar crease

desc: Extension of the proximal transverse crease (five finger crease) to the ulnar edge of the palm.
name: Sydney crease

desc: Cutis gyrata of palms and soles.
name: Palmoplantar cutis gyrata
synonyms: Cutis gyrata of palms and soles

desc: An abnormality of dermatoglyphs on the toes and soles, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of sole of foot.
name: Abnormal plantar dermatoglyphics

desc: A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips or toe tips.
name: Prominent digit pad

desc: A type of blistering that affects the skin of the tibial region.
name: Pretibial blistering

desc: Knuckle pads are benign fibrofatty subcutaneous pads located over the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints that can be mistaken for arthritis. Rarely they affect the dorsal aspect of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Clinically they are painless and often affect both hands in an asymmetrical pattern.
name: Knuckle pad
synonyms: Knuckle pads on dorsal aspect of finger joints

desc: An abnormality of the skin of the palm, that is, the skin of the front of the hand.
layperson: Abnormal skin morphology of the palm
name: Abnormal skin morphology of the palm

desc: An abnormally increased perspiration on palms and soles.
layperson: Excessive sweating of palms and soles
name: Palmoplantar hyperhidrosis
synonyms: Excessive sweating of palms and soles

desc: A type of blistering that affects the skin of the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet.
name: Palmoplantar blistering

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the palm of the hand.
name: Palmar edema

desc: Multiple verrucous lesions on the skin of the palm. These lesions are raised, have a thickened and rough surface, and may display prominent black dots (thrombosed capillaries). Palmar warts are caused by caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).
name: Palmar warts

desc: An abnormality of the region around the nails of the fingers or toes.
name: Abnormality of the periungual region

desc: The nail disease paronychia is an often-tender bacterial or fungal hand infection or foot infection where the nail and skin meet at the side or the base of a finger or toenail. The infection can start suddenly (acute paronychia) or gradually (chronic paronychia).
name: Paronychia

desc: Flesh-colored papule in or around the nail bed. Ungual fibromas may be periungual (arising under the proximal nail fold ) or subungual (originating under the nail plate).
name: Ungual fibroma

desc: A chronic, relapsing, pustular eruption that is localized to the palms and soles.
name: Palmoplantar pustulosis

desc: An abnormality of the plantar part of foot, that is of the soles of the feet.
layperson: Abnormality of the plantar skin of foot
name: Abnormality of the plantar skin of foot

desc: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot.
layperson: Deep wrinkles in soles of feet
name: Deep plantar creases
synonyms: Deep wrinkles in soles of feet

desc: Narrow, paramedian longitudinal depressions in the plantar skin of the forefoot.
name: Deep longitudinal plantar crease

desc: The presence of unusually deep creases (ridges/wrinkles) on the skin of sole of foot located between the first and second toe.
layperson: Plantar crease between first and second toes
name: Plantar crease between first and second toes

desc: The contour of the foot in lateral profile has a convex shape.
name: Convex contour of sole

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on sole of the foot.
name: Plantar edema

desc: Multiple verrucous lesions on the skin of the sole of the foot. These lesions are raised, have a thickened and rough surface, and may display prominent black dots (thrombosed capillaries). Palmar warts are caused by caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).
name: Plantar warts

desc: A diffuse, non-pitting edema and thickening of the skin usually on the anterior aspect of the lower legs spreading to the dorsum of the feet.
name: Pretibial myxedema

desc: Any structural anomaly of the elastic fibers of the skin. Elastic fibers are the essential extracellular matrix macromolecules comprising an elastin core surrounded by a mantle of fibrillin-rich microfibrils.
name: Abnormal cutaneous elastic fiber morphology

desc: An elevated number of elastic fibers, that is of bundles of proteins and glycoproteins in the extracellular matrix in the reticular dermis. Elastic fibers can stretch and recoil back to their original length. This feature can be appreciated on histology with hematoxylin and eosin or other staining methods.
layperson: Increased number of elastic fibers in the dermis
name: Increased number of elastic fibers in the dermis
synonyms: Increased number of elastic fibres in the dermis

desc: Formation of clumps or aggregates that make up small protuberances from elastic fibers within the dermis (especially the reticular dermis).
layperson: Clumping of elastic fibers in the dermis
name: Clumping of elastic fibers in the dermis
synonyms: Clumping of elastic fibres in the dermis

desc: An increase of the diameter of elastic fibers in the dermis.
layperson: Thickened elastic fibers in the dermis
name: Thickened elastic fibers in the dermis
synonyms: Thickened elastic fibres in the dermis

desc: Elastic fibers in the dermis exhibit an increased number of breaks associated with disorganization of the structure of the elastic fibers.
layperson: Fragmented elastic fibers in the dermis
name: Fragmented elastic fibers in the dermis
synonyms: Fragmented elastic fibres in the dermis

desc: An increased amount of desmosine measure in the skin. Desmosine is a cross-linking amino acid formed from lysyl residues in elastin.
name: Elevated dermal desmosine content

desc: An induration (hardening) of the skin
name: Stiff skin

desc: Brown or blue-gray discoloration of the skin tha can present on the axillary and inguinal areas, face, palms or soles. In addition, blue-black discoloration can be apparent on skin overlying cartilage in which the pigment is deposited, such as the ears. This is a characteristic manifestation of alkaptonuria, which is an autosomal recessively inherited deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase that results in accumulation of homogentisic acid in collagenous structures. The sclerae are also typically involved.
name: Ochronosis

desc: Fusiform collagen fibers with abnormally long spacing (exceeding 100 nm) between electron-dense bands.
name: Luse bodies

desc: An anomaly of collagen fibers of the skin that is said to resemble a cauliflower and can be appreciated by electron microscopy.
layperson: Cauliflower deformity of dermal collagen fibrils
name: Cauliflower deformity of dermal collagen fibrils

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the acellular zone that is between the dermis and the epidermis and which functions to bind the epidermis to the dermis and to serve as a selective barrier allowing the control of molecular and cellular exchanges between the two compartments.
name: Abnormal dermoepidermal junction morphology

desc: Presence of IgA antibodies in the dermoepidermal junction that are distributed in a linear pattern. This feature can be appreciated by immunofluorescence microscopy.
layperson: Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone
name: Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone

desc: Presence of IgG antibodies in the dermoepidermal junction that are distributed in a linear pattern. This feature can be appreciated by immunofluorescence microscopy.
layperson: Linear IgG deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone
name: Linear IgG deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone

desc: Presence of complement C3 in the dermoepidermal junction that are distributed in a linear pattern. This feature can be appreciated by immunofluorescence microscopy.
layperson: Linear C3 deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone
name: Linear C3 deposits along the epidermal basement membrane zone

desc: An abnormal structure or appearance of hemidesmosomes, multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
name: Abnormal dermoepidermal hemidesmosome morphology

desc: Underdeveloped hemidesmosomes at the dermoepidermal junction. Hemidesmosomes are the specialized junctional complexes, that contribute to the attachment of epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane in stratified and other complex epithelia, such as the skin.
name: Hypoplastic dermoepidermal hemidesmosomes

desc: A softening and breaking down of skin resulting from prolonged exposure to moisture. Macerated skin becomes soft and wrinkly and takes on a whitish hue.
name: Maceration

desc: An anomaly of the hair follicles of the skin that typically presents as small, rough, brown folliculocentric papules distributed over characteristic areas of the skin, particularly the outer-upper arms and thighs.
name: Keratosis pilaris

desc: A dermatosis characterized by generalized shiny, enamel-like, hyperpigmented scales in an irregular pattern. The scales may peel or desquamate, rather like old, sun-baked blistered paint, often with areas of underlying hypopigmentation. This has led to the terms peeling paint or flaky paint dermatosis (See the Figure in PMID:24285001).
name: Flaky paint dermatosis

desc: A cutaneous wound is a defined as a disruption of normal anatomic structure and function of the skin that occured owing to an injury of the skin. Wound healing is a dynamic, interactive processinvolving soluble mediators, blood cells, extracellularmatrix, and parenchymal cells. Wound healing has three phases: inflammation, tissue formation, and tissue remodeling, that overlap in time.
name: Cutaneous wound

desc: A cutaneous wound that is proceeding through an orderly and timely reparative process that results in sustained restoration of the anatomic and functional integrity of the skin.
name: Acute cutaneous wound

desc: A cutaneous wound that has failed to proceed through the orderly and timely process to produce an atomic and functional integrity, or proceeded through the repair process without establishing a sustained anatomic and functional result.
name: Chronic cutaneous wound

desc: Thickening and hardening of the epidermis seen with exaggeration of normal skin lines.
name: Lichenification

desc: Lichenification affecting primarily flexural areas of the skin.
name: Flexural lichenification

desc: Any abnormality of the physiological function of the skin.
name: Abnormality of skin physiology

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased disposition to experience pruritus.
name: Pruritus

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased sensation of itching over the skin of the abdomen.
name: Pruritis on abdomen

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased sensation of itching over the skin of the hand.
name: Pruritis on hand

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased sensation of itching over the palm(s) of the hand.
name: Palmar pruritus

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased sensation of itching over the skin of the foot.
name: Pruritus on foot

desc: Pruritus is an itch or a sensation that makes a person want to scratch. This term refers to an abnormally increased sensation of itching over the skin of the breast.
name: Pruritis on breast

desc: A sensation of itching in the vulvar region.
name: Pruritus vulvae

desc: The presence of inflammation of the skin. That is, an abnormality of the skin resulting from the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes.
name: Inflammatory abnormality of the skin
synonyms: Abnormal tendency to infections of the skin

desc: Eczema is a form of dermatitis. The term eczema is broadly applied to a range of persistent skin conditions and can be related to a number of underlying conditions. Manifestations of eczema can include dryness and recurring skin rashes with redness, skin edema, itching and dryness, crusting, flaking, blistering, cracking, oozing, or bleeding.
name: Eczema

desc: Atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema is an itchy, inflammatory skin condition with a predilection for the skin flexures. It is characterized by poorly defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and weeping in the acute stage and skin thickening (lichenification) in the chronic stage.
name: Atopic dermatitis

desc: A form of atopic dermatitis with onset in adulthood characterized by atopic red face, chronic lichenified eczema on the trunk, subacute or psoriasiform dermatitis.
name: Late onset atopic dermatitis

desc: Seborrheic dermatitis is a form of eczema which is closely related to dandruff. It causes dry or greasy peeling of the scalp, eyebrows, and face, and sometimes trunk.
name: Seborrheic dermatitis

desc: Seborrheic dermatitis that is not localized to any one particular region.
name: Generalized seborrheic dermatitis

desc: A type of eczema that occurs in the lips and perioral area.
name: Perioral eczema

desc: An inflammatory process in skin caused by an exogenous agent that directly or indirectly injure the skin. If the offending agent is identified and removed, the eruption will resolve. An unusual or patterned eruption may be a clue to the presence of a contact dermatitis. Patch testing may be helpful in the differential diagnosis.
name: Contact dermatitis

desc: A red eruption of the skin.
name: Skin rash

desc: Cutaneous lesion that develops as a dry, scaly, red patch that evolves to an indurated and hyperpigmented plaque with adherent scale. Scarring may result in central white patches (loss of pigmentation) and skin atrophy.
name: Discoid lupus rash

desc: An exanthema consisting of widespread pink-to-red macules (flat spots of 2-10 mm in diameter) or papules (red bumps) that blanch with pressure. The macules and papules may cluster and merge to form sheets over several days.
name: Morbilliform rash

desc: An erythematous (red), flat facial rash that affects the skin in the malar area (over the cheekbones) and extends over the bridge of the nose.
name: Malar rash

desc: A skin rash that is characterized by diffuse cutaneous erythema with areas of skin elevation. It may evolve to vesicles or papules as part of a more severe clinical entity. Different degrees of angioedema with involvement of subcutaneous tissue may also appear.
name: Maculopapular exanthema

desc: In a heliotrope rash, the color of the skin turns to violet, which is the color of the heliotrope flower.
name: Heliotrope rash

desc: A cutaneous eruption that consists of multiple (at least two) concentric erythematous rings.
name: Bull's eye rash

desc: An inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin. Erythroderma develops suddenly. A patchy erythema may generalize and spread to affect most of the skin. Scaling may appear in 2-6 days and be accompanied by hot, red, dry skin, malaise, and fever.
name: Erythroderma
synonyms: Red scaly skin caused by inflammatory skin disease

desc: Increased susceptibility to erysipelas, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas, which is a superficial infection of the skin, typically involving the lymphatic system.
name: Erysipelas

desc: A skin condition in which there is an increase in sebum secretion by the pilosebaceous apparatus associated with open comedones (blackheads), closed comedones (whiteheads), and pustular nodules (papules, pustules, and cysts).
name: Acne

desc: A type of acne in which open and closed comedones comprise the majority of the lesions, with substantially fewer papules and pustules.
name: Comedonal acne

desc: A chronic skin condition involving the inflammation of the apocrine sweat glands, forming pimple-like bumps known as abscesses.
name: Acne inversa

desc: Infections of the skin that happen multiple times.
name: Recurrent skin infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections of the skin, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infectious dermatitis.
name: Recurrent bacterial skin infections

desc: Any manifestation of a skin disease associated with the production of pus.
name: Pyoderma

desc: A furuncle (boil) is a skin infection involving an entire hair follicle and nearby skin tissue. Chronic furunculosis refers to recurrent episodes of furuncles, often caused by recurrent staphylococcus infection.
name: Chronic furunculosis

desc: An increased susceptibility to cutaneous abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent cutaneous abscesses.
name: Recurrent cutaneous abscess formation

desc: Increased susceptibility to cutaneous fungal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of cutaneous fungal infections.
name: Recurrent cutaneous fungal infections

desc: Recurrent or persistent superficial Candida infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and nails.
name: Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
synonyms: Chronic candidiasis of mucosa, skin and nails

desc: Persistent overgrowth of Candida albicans in the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Chronic intestinal candidiasis
