desc: Chronic accumulation and overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans on the mucous membranes of the mouth, generally manifested as associated with creamy white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks, occasionally spreading to the gums, tonsils, palate or oropharynx.
name: Chronic oral candidiasis

desc: Recurrent infection involving the vulva, vagina, and adjacent crural areas, whereby the causative agent belongs to the genus Candida.
name: Recurrent vulvovaginal candidiasis

desc: Increased susceptibility to viral skin infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral skin infections.
name: Recurrent viral skin infections

desc: A skin abnormality characterized by redness and irritation, with thick, red skin that displays flaky, silver-white patches (scales).
name: Psoriasiform dermatitis

desc: An erythematous eruption commonly associated with drug reactions or infection and characterized by inflammatory nodules that are usually tender, multiple, and bilateral.
name: Erythema nodosum

desc: Inflammation surrounding hair follicles.
name: Perifolliculitis

desc: Inflammatory cells within the wall and ostia of the hair follicle, creating a follicular-based pustule.
name: Folliculitis

desc: An infection of a hair follicle that extends subcutaneously, forming an abscess.
name: Furuncle

desc: A group of infected hair follicles, larger and deeper than a furuncle.
name: Carbuncle

desc: Numerous lymphocytes surrounding blood vessels in the superfical part of the dermis.
name: Superficial dermal perivascular inflammatory infiltrate

desc: Numerous lymphocytes surrounding blood vessels in the deep part of the dermis.
name: Deep dermal perivascular inflammatory infiltrate

desc: A predominantly neutrophilic infiltrate of the dermis and or epidermis (i.e., a large number of neutrophils inferred to have migrated into the skin).
name: Neutrophilic infiltration of the skin

desc: Collection of neutrophils in the epidermis.
name: Predominantly epidermal neutrophilic infiltrate

desc: Collection of neutrophils in the dermis.
name: Predominantly dermal neutrophilic infiltrate

desc: A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the skin.
name: Cutaneous abscess

desc: The presence of an abscess located around the anus.
name: Perianal abscess

desc: Presence of abnormally increased amounts of intraepidermal inflammatory cells with a predominance of eosinophils.
name: Eosinophilic dermal infiltration

desc: A small elevation of the skin containing cloudy or purulent material usually consisting of necrotic inflammatory cells.
name: Pustule

desc: The Harlequin phenomenon consists of a sudden change in skin colour, resulting in two different body colours, one on each half of the body.
name: Harlequin phenomenon

desc: With the pathergy test, a small, sterile needle is inserted into the skin of the forearm. The site of injectionis circuled and observed after one and two days. If a small red bump or pustule at the site of needle insertion occurs, the pathergy test is considered to have a positive (abnormal) result.
name: Positive pathergy test

desc: A reduced ability of the skin of the fingertips to wrinkle when exposed to stimuli such as soaking in water or application of EMLA cream (the fingertip remains smooth).
name: Impaired stimulus-induced skin wrinkling

desc: A type of infection of the skin that can be regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection.
name: Unusual skin infection

desc: Molluscum contagiosum is a cutaneous viral infection that is commonly observed in both healthy and immunocompromised children. The infection is caused by a member of the Poxviridae family, the molluscum contagiosum virus. Molluscum contagiosum presents as single or multiple small white or flesh-colored papules that typically have a central umbilication. The central umbilication may be difficult to observe in young children and, instead, may bear an appearance similar to an acneiform eruption. The lesions vary in size (from 1 mm to 1 cm in diameter) and are painless, although a subset of patients report pruritus in the area of infection. On average, 11-20 papules appear on the body during the course of infection and generally remains a self-limiting disease. However, in immunosuppressed patients, molluscum contagiosum can be a severe infection with hundreds of lesions developing on the body. Extensive eruption is indicative of an advanced immunodeficiency state.
name: Molluscum contagiosum

desc: The presense of molluscum contagiosum lesions across multiple areas of the body.
name: Disseminated molluscum contagiosum

desc: Infection that extends deeply into the dermins by dermatophytes, fungi that typically cause different types of superficial infection (tinea) or skin, hair, or nails.
name: Invasive dermatophyte infection

desc: A type of invasive dermatophyte infection of the deep dermis characterized by extensive dermal infiltration by fungal elements.
name: Deep dermatophytosis

desc: Majocchi's granuloma (MG) is an inflammatory and granulomatous, dermatophytic infection characterized by a granulomatous inflammation around the hair follicle. Histopathologically, MG demonstrates a nodular perifollicular granulomatous infiltrate of lymphoid cells, macrophages, epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and neutrophils. Unlike superficial dermatophytoses, fungal hyphae and spores can be detected not only on the surface of the epidermis but also within or around the hair follicles.
name: Majocchi's granuloma

desc: A type of invasive dermatophyte infection characterized by vascular involvement and dissemination to other organs.
name: Disseminated dermatophytosis

desc: Any structural anomaly in the areas surrounding the hair follicles.
name: Abnormal perifollicular morphology

desc: Presence of excess fibrous connective tissue surrounding hair follicules.
name: Perifollicular fibrosis

desc: Redness surrounding the hair follicles.
name: Perifollicular erythema

desc: An abnormality of the skin adnexa (skin appendages), which are specialized skin structures located within the dermis and focally within the subcutaneous fatty tissue, comprising three histologically distinct structures: (1) the pilosebaceous unit (hair follicle and sebaceous glands); (2) the eccrine sweat glands; and (3) the apocrine glands.
name: Abnormality of skin adnexa morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality of the sweat gland.
name: Abnormal sweat gland morphology

desc: The presence of fewer than normal sweat glands.
name: Decreased number of sweat glands

desc: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the sweat glands.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the sweat glands

desc: Underdevelopment of the sweat glands.
name: Hypoplastic sweat glands
Hypoplasia of the eccrine sweat glands

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the apocrine sweat glands in the region of the axilla.
name: Axillary apocrine gland hypoplasia

desc: Absence or developmental hypoplasia of the eccrine sweat glands.
layperson: Aplasia/Hypoplastia of the eccrine sweat glands
name: Aplasia/Hypoplastia of the eccrine sweat glands

layperson: Aplasia of the eccrine sweat glands
name: Aplasia of the eccrine sweat glands

desc: Absence of the sweat glands.
name: Aplasia of the sweat glands

desc: An abnormality of the hair.
name: Abnormal hair morphology

desc: Developmental dysplasia of the hair.
name: Trichodysplasia

desc: Uncombable hair.
name: Pili canaliculi

layperson: Hair shafts flattened at irregular intervals and twisted through 180 degrees about their axes
name: Hair shafts flattened at irregular intervals and twisted through 180 degrees about their axes

desc: Pili (from Latin pilus, hair) torti (from Latin tortus, twisted) refers to short and brittle hairs that appear flattened and twisted when viewed through a microscope.
name: Pili torti

desc: Trichorrhexis nodosa is the formation of nodes along the hair shaft through which breakage readily occurs. It is thus a focal defect in the hair fiber that is characterized by thickening or weak points (nodes) that cause the hair to break off easily. The result is defective, abnormally fragile hair.
name: Trichorrhexis nodosa

desc: The hair shaft has a beaded appearance due to the presence of elliptical nodes that have the diameter of normal hair and are medullated, regularly separated by internodes that are narrow, devoid of medulla and are the site of fracture.
name: Monilethrix

desc: A deviation from the normal proportion of terminal to vellus hairs.
name: Abnormal terminal:vellus ratio

desc: An increased proportion of terminal hairs compared to vellus hairs.
name: Elevated terminal:vellus ratio

desc: A terminal:vellus ratio under 4:1 is characteristic of androgenetic alopecia.
name: Reduced terminal:vellus ratio

desc: An abnormal appearance of hair under polarizing microscopy (using crossed polarizers), whereby hair shafts show striking alternating bright and dark bands, often referred to as tiger tail banding.
name: Tiger tail banding

desc: An abnormality of hair pigmentation (color).
name: Abnormality of hair pigmentation

layperson: Melanin pigment aggregation in hair shafts
name: Melanin pigment aggregation in hair shafts

layperson: Large clumps of pigment irregularly distributed along hair shaft
name: Large clumps of pigment irregularly distributed along hair shaft
synonyms: Large clumps of pigment irregularly distributed along hair shaft

desc: Reduced pigmentation of hair diffusely.
name: Generalized hypopigmentation of hair

desc: Hypopigmented hair that appears silver-gray.
name: Silver-gray hair

desc: A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.
name: Fair hair

desc: Hypopigmented hair that appears white.
name: White hair

desc: Reduced pigmentation of hair in patches.
name: Patchy hypopigmentation of hair

desc: A triangular depigmented region of white hairs located in the anterior midline of the scalp.
layperson: White part of hair above forehead
name: White forelock
synonyms: White part of hair above forehead

desc: Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes.
name: Poliosis

desc: Abnormality of the growth of secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty. In males, secondary sexual hair usually comprises body hair, including underarm, abdominal, chest, and pubic hair. In females, secondary sexual hair usually comprises a lesser degree of body hair, most prominently underarm and pubic hair.
name: Abnormality of secondary sexual hair

desc: Abnormality of the growth of the pubic hair. Pubic hair is part of the secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty.
name: Abnormality of the pubic hair

desc: Reduced number or density of pubic hair.
name: Sparse pubic hair

desc: Absence of pubic hair.
name: Absent pubic hair

desc: Abnormality of the growth of the axillary hair. Axillary hair is part of the secondary sexual hair, which normally ensues during puberty.
name: Abnormality of the axillary hair

desc: Reduced number or density of axillary hair.
name: Sparse axillary hair
synonyms: Sparse scalp, axillary, and pubic hair

desc: Absence of axillary hair.
name: Absent axillary hair

desc: An abnormality of the texture of the hair.
name: Abnormality of hair texture

desc: Hair shafts are rough in texture.
name: Coarse hair

desc: Hair that is fine or thin to the touch.
name: Fine hair

desc: The term woolly hair refers to an abnormal variant of hair that is fine, with tightly coiled curls, and often hypopigmented. Optical microscopy may reveal the presence of tight spirals and a clear diameter reduction as compared with normal hair. Electron microscopy may show flat, oval hair shafts with reduced transversal diameter.
name: Woolly hair

desc: The presence of woolly hair on the scalp. The term woolly hair refers to an abnormal variant of hair that is fine, with tightly coiled curls, and often hypopigmented. Optical microscopy may reveal the presence of tight spirals and a clear diameter reduction as compared with normal hair. Electron microscopy may show flat, oval hair shafts with reduced transversal diameter.
name: Woolly scalp hair

desc: Fragile, easily breakable hair, i.e., with reduced tensile strength.
name: Brittle hair

desc: Fragile, easily breakable scalp hair.
name: Brittle scalp hair

desc: Hair that lacks the lustre (shine or gleam) of normal hair.
name: Dry hair

desc: Hair that is disorderly, stands out from the scalp, and cannot be combed flat.
name: Uncombable hair

desc: An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.
name: Abnormal hair pattern

desc: An abnormality of the distribution of hair growth that is acquired during the course of life.
name: Acquired abnormal hair pattern

desc: Transient, non-scarring hair loss and preservation of the hair follicle located in in well-defined patches.
name: Patchy alopecia

desc: Loss of scalp hair at an earlier than normal age.
name: Early balding

desc: Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas.
name: Frontal balding

desc: The presence of tufts of 8-15 hairs that appear to emerge from a single follicular orifice.
name: Tufted hairs

desc: A congenital abnormality of the distribution of hair growth.
name: Congenital abnormal hair pattern

desc: Reduced or lacking hair growth in the temporal region (i.e., around the temples on the side of the skull).
layperson: Reduced hair growth in temporal region
name: Temporal hypotrichosis
synonyms: Reduced hair growth in temporal region

desc: Loss of hair in the occipital region of the scalp with congenital onset.
name: Congenital posterior occipital alopecia

desc: An abnormal hair whorl (that is, a patch of hair growing in the opposite direction of the rest of the hair).
name: Abnormal hair whorl

desc: Upward and/or sideward growth of anterior hair.
name: Frontal upsweep of hair

desc: More than two clockwise hair whorls.
name: Abnormal number of hair whorls

desc: Hair growth from a single point on the scalp in any location other than lateral to the midline and close to the vertex of the skull.
name: Abnormal position of hair whorl

desc: An abnormal amount of hair.
name: Abnormal hair quantity

desc: Hypertrichosis is increased hair growth that is abnormal in quantity or location.
name: Hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the facial region.
name: Facial hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the region of the forehead and temple.
name: Frontotemporal hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the sacral region.
name: Sacral hypertrichosis

desc: Anterior cervical hypertrichosis (ACH) or 'hairy throat' refers to the presence of a tuft of terminal hair on the anterior neck, just above the laryngeal prominence.
name: Anterior cervical hypertrichosis

desc: A confluent, generalized overgrowth of silvery blonde to gray lanugo hair at birth.
name: Congenital, generalized hypertrichosis

desc: Generalized excessive, abnormal hairiness.
name: Generalized hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the elbow region.
name: Elbow hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the lumbar region.
name: Lumbar hypertrichosis

desc: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the thoracic region.
name: Thoracic hypertrichosis

desc: Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair).
name: Hirsutism

desc: Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body.
name: Generalized hirsutism

desc: Abnormally increased hair growth with a localized distribution.
name: Localized hirsutism

desc: Abnormally increased hair growth in the lumbosacral region.
name: Lumbosacral hirsutism

desc: Excess facial hair.
name: Facial hirsutism

desc: A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.
name: Alopecia

desc: Progressive loss of hair.
name: Progressive alopecia

desc: Loss of all hair on the entire body.
name: Alopecia universalis

desc: Loss of all scalp hair.
name: Alopecia totalis

desc: Loss of all scalp hair with congenital onset.
name: Congenital alopecia totalis

desc: Absence of facial hair.
name: Absent facial hair

desc: Reduced density of hairs.
name: Sparse hair

desc: Sparseness of the body hair.
name: Sparse body hair

desc: Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth.
name: Progressive hypotrichosis

desc: Reduced or lacking hair growth in a generalized distribution.
name: Generalized hypotrichosis

desc: Reduced number or density of facial hair.
name: Sparse facial hair

desc: An abnormal loss of anagen (growth phase) hairs.
name: Anagen effluvium

desc: A type of hair loss characterized by an abnormal increase in dormant, telogen stage hair follicles.
name: Telogen effluvium

desc: Increased density of hairs, i.e., and elevated number of hairs per unit area.
name: Thick hair

desc: The most dramatic and severe form of hair loss characterized by an absence of hair follicles.
name: Atrichia

desc: Hair whose growth rate deviates from the norm.
layperson: Abnormality of pace of hair growth
name: Abnormality of hair growth rate
synonyms: Abnormality of speed of hair growth
Abnormality of pace of hair growth

desc: Hair whose growth is slower than normal.
name: Slow-growing hair

desc: Abnormality of the nail.
name: Abnormality of the nail

desc: An abnormality of the fingernails.
name: Abnormal fingernail morphology

desc: Underdevelopment of a fingernail.
name: Hypoplastic fingernail

desc: A nail of the fifth finger that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail of little finger.
name: Hypoplastic fifth fingernail

desc: A thumbnail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped thumb nail.
name: Hypoplastic thumbnail

desc: The presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, often with accumulation of soft, yellow keratin between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed, resulting in elevation of the nail plate.
name: Dystrophic fingernails

desc: Longitudinal, linear prominences in the fingernail plate.
name: Ridged fingernail

desc: Fingernail that appears thin when viewed on end.
name: Thin fingernail

desc: Detachment of the distal fingernails from the nail bed.
name: Onycholysis of distal fingernails

desc: An abnormality of the development of the fingernails.
name: Fingernail dysplasia

desc: Nail that appears thick when viewed on end.
name: Onychogryposis

desc: Thickened toenails.
name: Onychogryposis of toenails

desc: Thickened nails without deformity.
name: Onychauxis

desc: Thickened fingernails.
name: Onychogryposis of fingernail

desc: Detachment of the nail from the nail bed.
name: Onycholysis

desc: Complete shedding (separation) of the nail from the proximal matrix. Onychomadesis is the proximal separation of the nail plate from the nail matrix due to a temporary cessation of nail growth.
name: Onychomadesis

desc: Painless and spontaneous separation of a toenail from the nail bed.
name: Toenail onycholysis

desc: Nails that easily break.
name: Fragile nails

desc: Nail that appears thin when viewed on end.
name: Thin nail

desc: Toenail that appears thin when viewed on end.
name: Thin toenail

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the nail.
name: Nail dysplasia

desc: The natural longitudinal (posterodistal) convex arch is not present or is inverted.
name: Concave nail

desc: When viewed on end (with the digit tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the nail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
name: Hyperconvex nail

desc: When viewed on end (with the finger tip pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the fingernail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
name: Hyperconvex fingernails

desc: When viewed on end (with the tip of the toe pointing toward the examiner's eye) the curve of the toenail forms a tighter curve of convexity.
name: Hyperconvex toenail

desc: Small (typically about 1 mm or less in size) depressions on the dorsal nail surface.
name: Nail pits

desc: Longitudinal, linear prominences in the nail plate.
name: Ridged nail

desc: A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation and the two sections of the nail share the same lateral radius of curvature.
name: Split nail

desc: Deeply placed nails.
name: Deep-set nails

desc: Increased width of nail.
name: Broad nail

desc: A digit with two nails, with at least some soft tissue between them.
name: Bifid nail

desc: A nail plate that has a longitudinal separation with partially separated nails, each with a separate lateral radius of curvature.
name: Fused nails

desc: Decreased width of nail.
name: Narrow nail

desc: Abnormal flat nail.
name: Platonychia

desc: Excessive longitudinal ridging that gives the surface of the nail plate a rough appearance. It results from multiple foci of defective keratinization of the proximal nail matrix.
name: Trachyonychia

desc: An abnormality of the development of the toenails.
name: Toenail dysplasia

desc: Inward advance of skin over the nail plate.
name: Pterygium of nails

desc: Aplasia or developmental hypoplasia of the nail.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the nails

desc: A nail that is diminished in length and width, i.e., underdeveloped nail.
name: Small nail

desc: Underdevelopment of the toenail.
name: Hypoplastic toenails

desc: Underdeveloped nails of the fifth toes.
name: Hypoplastic fifth toenail

desc: Aplasia of the nail.
name: Anonychia

desc: Congenital absence of the toenail.
name: Absent toenail

desc: Absent nail of big toe.
name: Absent nail of hallux

desc: Absence of a fingernail.
name: Absent fingernail

desc: Absence of thumb nail.
name: Absent thumbnail

desc: Absence of nail of little finger.
name: Absent fifth fingernail

desc: Decreased length of nail.
name: Short nail

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the toenail.
name: Aplastic/hypoplastic toenail

desc: An anomaly of the toenail.
name: Abnormal toenail morphology

desc: Toenail changes apart from changes of the color of the toenail (nail dyschromia) that involve partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
name: Dystrophic toenail

layperson: Congenital curved nail of fourth toe
name: Congenital curved nail of fourth toe

desc: A lateral deviation of the nail plate of the great toe along the longitudinal axis due to the lateral rotation of the nail matrix. The nail plate grows out in ridges.
name: Malalignment of the great toenail

desc: Upturned concavity of toenails.
name: Upslanting toenail

desc: Recurrent loss, or shedding, of the nails of the fingers and toes.
layperson: Recurrent shedding of toenails and fingernails
name: Recurrent loss of toenails and fingernails
synonyms: Recurrent loss of toenails and fingernails
Recurrent shedding of toenails and fingernails

desc: Chronic infection of the nails by Candida species.
name: Chronic monilial nail infection

desc: Onychodystrophy (nail dystrophy) refers to nail changes apart from changes of the color (nail dyschromia) and involves partial or complete disruption of the various keratinous layers of the nail plate.
name: Nail dystrophy

desc: The presense of a depressed line ("canal") in the center of the nail.
name: Central nail canal

desc: A lesion located beneath a fingernail or toenail.
name: Abnormality of the subungual region

desc: The presence of fibromata beneath finger or toenails.
name: Subungual fibromas

desc: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails is a rare and distinctive anomaly seen in popliteal pterygia syndrome.
layperson: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails
name: Pyramidal skinfold extending from the base to the top of the nails

desc: Excessive growth of a nail laterally into the nail fold.
name: Ingrown nail

desc: Small areas of bleeding (hemorrhage) under the fingernail or toenail.
name: Nail bed hemorrhage

desc: Lack of the lunula at the base of a nail. The lunula is the crescent-shaped whitish area of the bed of a fingernail or toenail.
name: Absent lunula

desc: Nail whose growth pattern or speed deviates from normal.
name: Abnormal nail growth

desc: Nails whose growth is slower than normal.
name: Slow-growing nails

desc: Nails whose growth is quicker than normal.
name: Fast-growing nails

desc: The cuticle (properly known as the eponychium, or the medial nail fold or the proximal nail fold), is the thickened layer of skin surrounding fingernails and toenails. Its function is to protect the area between the nail and epidermis from exposure to bacteria. This term refers to the presence of and irregular edge or outline of the cuticle.
name: Ragged cuticle

desc: Severe nail curvature, causing the tip of the nail to point downwards with respect to the axis of the finger. Beaked nails are caused by resorption of the distal digit.
name: Beaked nails

desc: Nails that slope upward at the free edge.
name: Ski jump nail

desc: An anomaly of the color of the nail.
name: Abnormality of nail color

desc: White discoloration of the nails.
name: Leukonychia

desc: Yellowish discoloration of the nails.
name: Yellow nails

desc: Brown or black discoloration of the nails.
name: Melanonychia

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the nail.
name: Neoplasm of the nail

desc: Any structural anomaly of the sebaceous glands.
name: Abnormal sebaceous gland morphology

desc: A common, benign skin condition involving hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands characterized by single or multiple lesions that manifest as yellow, soft, small papules with umbilication. The lesions are located commonly on the central face (specifically, the nose, cheeks and forehead) but may also occur elswehere, including the chest, mouth, scrotum, foreskin, penile shaft, vulva, and areola.
name: Sebaceous hyperplasia

desc: Absence of the sebaceous gland, the holocrine gland that secretes sebum into the hair follicles, or in hairless areas into ducts.
name: Absent sebaceous glands

desc: Any functional anomaly of the skin adnexa (skin appendages), which are specialized skin structures located within the dermis and focally within the subcutaneous fatty tissue, comprising three histologically distinct structures: (1) the pilosebaceous unit (hair follicle and sebaceous glands); (2) the eccrine sweat glands; and (3) the apocrine glands.
name: Abnormality of skin adnexa physiology

desc: Inability to sweat.
name: Anhidrosis

layperson: Lack of sweating or excessive sweating
name: Hypohidrosis or hyperhidrosis
synonyms: Lack of sweating or excessive sweating

desc: Abnormally diminished capacity to sweat.
name: Hypohidrosis

layperson: Decreased sweating due to autonomic dysfunction
name: Decreased sweating due to autonomic dysfunction

desc: Abnormal excessive perspiration (sweating) despite the lack of appropriate stimuli like hot and humid weather.
name: Hyperhidrosis

desc: Intermittent episodes of abnormally increased perspiration.
name: Episodic hyperhidrosis

desc: Hyperhidrosis that occurs with gustatory stimulation (e.g., moisture on face from sweating that occurs after eating).
name: Gustatory sweating

desc: Sweating provoked by cold temperature rather than by heat.
name: Cold-induced sweating

desc: Hoarseness refers to a change in the pitch or quality of the voice, with the voice sounding weak, very breathy, scratchy, or husky.
name: Hoarse voice

desc: A type of speech characterized by the presence of an abnormally increased nasal airflow during speech.
name: Nasal speech

desc: An abnormal increase in the pitch (frequency) of the voice.
name: High pitched voice

desc: Reduced intensity (volume) of speech.
name: Weak voice

desc: Impairment in the physical production of speech sounds.
name: Speech articulation difficulties

desc: An abnormally low-pitched voice.
name: Abnormally low-pitched voice

desc: Any anomaly of the vocalizing of an infant's crying, i.e.,the typically loud voice production that is accompanied by tears and agitation.
name: Abnormal cry

desc: A type of crying in an abnormally high-pitched voice.
name: High-pitched cry

desc: A type of cry that is abnormal because it is consists of unusually shortened and detached vocalizations.
name: Staccato cry

desc: The presence of a characteristic high-pitched cry that sounds similar to the meowing of a kitten.
name: Cat cry

desc: An anomaly of the expressive patterns of speech that involve intonation, stress pattern, loudness variations, pausing, articulatory force, and rhythm.
name: Abnormal speech prosody

desc: A speech pattern characterized by abnormally reduced or lacking variability of the pitch of the voice.
name: Monotonic speech

desc: A speech pattern characterized by abnormally elevated variability of the pitch of the voice.
name: Increased pitch variability of speech

desc: Any functional anomaly of the vocal cord.
name: Vocal cord dysfunction

desc: Hyponasal speech is when there is an abnormally reduced nasal airflow during speech often in a setting of nasal obstruction or congestion.
name: Hyponasal speech

desc: Any abnormality of the cardiovascular system.
name: Abnormality of the cardiovascular system

desc: An abnormality of the vasculature.
name: Abnormality of the vasculature

desc: Dysplasia affecting the vasculature of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Gastrointestinal angiodysplasia

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Gastrointestinal arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the stomach.
name: Gastric arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the duodenum.
name: Duodenal arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the jejunum.
name: Jejunal arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the colon.
name: Colonic arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the rectum.
name: Rectal arteriovenous malformation

layperson: Abnormality of the lung blood vessels
name: Abnormality of the pulmonary vasculature
synonyms: Abnormality of the lung blood vessels

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary artery.
name: Abnormality of the pulmonary artery

desc: An abnormality of the structure of the pulmonary artery.
name: Abnormal pulmonary artery morphology

desc: An abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
name: Pulmonary artery stenosis

desc: Stenosis of a peripheral branch of the pulmonary artery.
name: Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis

desc: An abnormal widening of the diameter of the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary artery dilatation

desc: An aneurysm (severe localized balloon-like outward bulging) in the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary artery aneurysm

desc: A congenital anomaly with a narrowing or complete absence of the opening between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary artery atresia

desc: A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery.
name: Absent pulmonary artery

desc: An anomalous origin of the left pulmonary artery, such that it arises from the posterior aspect of the right pulmonary artery and passes between the trachea and esophagus to reach the left hilum.
name: Pulmonary artery sling

desc: Increase in mass of the tunica media of the arteries in the pulmonary circulation.
name: Pulmonary arterial medial hypertrophy
synonyms: Hypertrophy of the pulmonary artery wall

desc: Underdevelopment of the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary artery hypoplasia

desc: Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries in the pulmonary circulation.
name: Pulmonary aterial intimal fibrosis

desc: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from the ascending aorta with the contralateral pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle.
layperson: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
name: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta

desc: The right pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of right pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
name: Anomalous origin of right pulmonary artery from ascending aorta

desc: The left pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
name: Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta

desc: Accumulation of lipids and inflammatory cells along the inner walls of the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary arterial atherosclerosis

desc: An abnormality of the function of the pulmonary artery.
name: Abnormal pulmonary artery physiology

desc: Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins.
name: Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary veins.
name: Abnormality of the pulmonary veins

desc: An abnormality of the structure of the pulmonary veins.
name: Abnormal pulmonary vein morphology

desc: Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition.
name: Pulmonary venous occlusion

desc: A developmental defect characterized by abnormal connection of one or more pulmonary veins to the superior or inferior vena cava, the right atrium, or the coronary sinus, resulting in a left-to-right shunt of oxygenated blood.
name: Anomalous pulmonary venous return

desc: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return refers to a congenital malformation in which all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, but instead drain abnormally to the right atrium.
name: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return

desc: Type 1 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.
layperson: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
name: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
synonyms: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connexion
Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, supracardiac
Type 1 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

desc: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.
layperson: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
name: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
synonyms: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connexion
Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, intracardiac

desc: Type 3 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.
layperson: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
name: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
synonyms: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connexion
Type 3 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection

desc: Type 4 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.
layperson: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
name: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
synonyms: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connexion
Type 4 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, mixed

desc: A form of anomalous pulmonary venous return in which not all pulmonary veins drain abnormally. Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return frequently involves one or both of the veins from one lung.
name: Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return

desc: Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.
name: Scimitar anomaly

desc: An abnormality of the function of the pulmonary veins.
name: Abnormal pulmonary vein physiology

desc: An abnormality of the hepatic vasculature.
name: Abnormality of the hepatic vasculature

desc: Increased pressure in the portal vein.
name: Portal hypertension

desc: Increased pressure in the pre-hepatic portal vein.
name: Extrahepatic portal hypertension

desc: Any structural anomaly of the portal venous sytem, which comprises all of the veins draining the abdominal part of the digestive tract, including the lower esophagus but excluding the lower anal canal. The portal vein conveys blood from viscera and ramifies like an artery at the liver, ending at the sinusoids. Tributaries of the portal vein, which make up the portal venous system, are the splenic, superior mesenteric, left gastric, right gastric, paraumbilical, and cystic veins.
name: Abnormal portal venous system morphology

desc: Sclerosis of the intrahepatic portal veins of the liver and generally accompanied by non-cirrhotic portal hypertension, features of which may include splenomegaly and varices.
name: Intrahepatic portal vein sclerosis

desc: Anomaly where the intestinal and the splenic venous drainage bypass the liver and drain into systemic veins through other possible venous shunts.
name: Congenital absence of portal vein

desc: An abnormality of the hepatic veins, which normally drain de-oxygenated blood from the liver into the inferior vena cava, whereby the hepatic veins drain into the left atrium.
layperson: Anomalous hepatic venous drainage into the left atrium
name: Anomalous hepatic venous drainage into the left atrium

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of an atery, vein or the heart.
layperson: Wider than typical opening or gap
name: Dilatation
synonyms: Wider than typical opening or gap

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in an artery that originates from he abdominal aorta.
name: Dilatation of an abdominal artery

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery or superior mesenteric artery .
name: Dilatation of mesenteric artery

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the superior mesenteric artery .
name: Dilatation of superior mesenteric artery

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the inferior mesenteric artery .
name: Dilatation of Inferior mesenteric artery

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of the celiac artery.
name: Dilatation of celiac artery

desc: Aortic dilatation refers to a dimension that is greater than the 95th percentile for the normal person age, sex and body size. In contrast, an aneurysm is defined as a localized dilation of the aorta that is more than 150 percent of predicted (ratio of observed to expected diameter 1.5 or more). Aneurysm should be distinguished from ectasia, which represents a diffuse dilation of the aorta less than 50 percent of normal aorta diameter.
layperson: Bulge in wall of large artery that carries blood away from heart
name: Aortic aneurysm
synonyms: Bulge in wall of large artery that carries blood away from heart

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the abdominal aorta.
name: Abdominal aortic aneurysm

desc: A concentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the abdominal aorta that involves the full circumference of the vessel wall
name: Fusiform abdominal aortic aneurysm

desc: An eccentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the abdominal aorta that involves only a portion of the circumference of the vessel wall.
name: Saccular abdominal aortic aneurysm

desc: An abdominal aortic aneurysm that is not symmetric around its axis (not axisymmetric).
name: Asymmetric abdominal aortic aneurysm

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the thoracic aorta.
name: Thoracic aortic aneurysm

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic root.
layperson: Bulge in wall of root of large artery that carries blood away from heart
name: Aortic root aneurysm
synonyms: Bulge in wall of root of large artery that carries blood away from heart

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the descending thoracic aorta.
name: Descending thoracic aorta aneurysm
synonyms: Dilatation of the descending thoracic aorta

desc: A concentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the descending thoracic aorta that involves the full circumference of the vessel wall
name: Fusiform descending thoracic aortic aneurysm
synonyms: Dilatation of the fusiform descending thoracic aorta

desc: An eccentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the descending thoracic aorta that involves only a portion of the circumference of the vessel wall
name: Saccular descending thoracic aortic aneurysm
synonyms: Dilatation of the saccular descending thoracic aorta

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the tubular part of the ascending aorta.
layperson: Bulging of wall of large artery located above heart
name: Ascending tubular aorta aneurysm
synonyms: Aneurysm of the ascending tubular aorta
Bulging of wall of large artery located above heart

desc: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.
layperson: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva
name: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva

desc: An eccentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the ascending tubular aorta that involves only a portion of the circumference of the vessel wall.
name: Fusiform ascending tubular aorta aneurysm

desc: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch.
name: Aortic arch aneurysm

desc: A concentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch that involves the full circumference of the vessel wall.
name: Fusiform aortic arch aneurysm

desc: An eccentric abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic arch that involves only a portion of the circumference of the vessel wall.
name: Saccular aortic arch aneurysm

desc: A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole.
name: Dilatation of the ventricular cavity

desc: A fibrous cardiac diverticulum refers to an aneurysm and usually appears as an isolated congenital anomaly.
name: Fibrous cardiac diverticulum

desc: A saccular or fusiform dilation and elongation of the ductus arteriosus.
name: Dilatation of the ductus arteriosus
Pseudoaneurysm
synonyms: A contained rupture of an artery with a disruption in all 3 layers of the arterial wall.

desc: An anomaly of vein.
name: Abnormal venous morphology

layperson: Arteriovenous fistulas of celiac and mesenteric vessels
name: Arteriovenous fistulas of celiac and mesenteric vessels
synonyms: Arteriovenous fistulas of coeliac and mesenteric vessels

desc: Enlarged and tortuous veins.
name: Varicose veins

desc: Elongated and tortuous mesenteric veins, which comprise the inferior mesenteric vein and the superior mesenteric vein.
layperson: Venous varicosities of celiac and mesenteric vessels
name: Venous varicosities of celiac and mesenteric vessels
synonyms: Venous varicosities of coeliac and mesenteric vessels

desc: An abnormality of the structure of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.
name: Abnormal vena cava morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly of the principal vein draining blood from the upper portion of the body and delivering it to the right ventricle of the heart.
name: Abnormal superior vena cava morphology

desc: A rare congenital vascular anomaly that results when the left superior cardinal vein caudal to the innominate vein fails to regress.
name: Persistent left superior vena cava

desc: Absence of the right superior vena cava (RSVC). An absent RSVC is always associated with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). During normal fetal development, the left-sided anterior venous cardinal system regresses, leaving the coronary sinus (CS) and the ligament of Marshall. Failure of the closure of the left anterior cardinal vein results in PLSVC. In general, PLSVC is associated with the right superior vena cava (RSVC) and drains into the RA via a dilated CS. When developmental arrest occurs at an earlier stage, the CS is absent and the PLSVC drains into the left atrium.
name: Absent right superior vena cava

layperson: Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein
name: Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein

layperson: Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein
name: Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein

desc: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the left atrium instead of the right atrium via the coronary sinus, resulting in a right to left sided shunt.
layperson: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
name: Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium

desc: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the right atrium via the coronary sinus. This is the case in 80-92% of cases of PLSVC and results in no hemodynamic consequence.
layperson: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
name: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus

desc: The superior vena cava passes below the aortic arch.
name: Infra-aortic superior vena cava

desc: Blockage of blood flow through the superior vena cava (SVC). Because the venous drainage from the upper extremities, upper thorax and head is obstructed, SVC obstruction presents with symptoms related to engorgement of these areas. Both the degree of SVC compromise and the extent of collateral veins determine the varied clinical presentation, which can be as mild as slight facial and upper extremity edema or as dire as intracranial swelling, seizures, hemodynamic instability and tracheal obstruction.
layperson: Obstruction of the superior vena cava
name: Obstruction of the superior vena cava

desc: Any structural anomaly of the principal vein draining blood from the lower portion of the body.
name: Abnormal inferior vena cava morphology

desc: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation is the result of connection failure between the right subcardinal vein and the right vitelline vein. Consequently, venous blood from the caudal part of the body reaches the heart via the azygous vein and superior vena cava.
layperson: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
name: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation

desc: An abnormally large Eustachian valve (postnatally). The Eustachian valve is also known as the valve of the inferior vena cava, and is an embryologic remnant of the valve of the inferior vena cava.
name: Enlarged Eustachian valve

desc: A vascular malformation resulting from a developmental error of venous tissue composed of dysmorphic channels lined by flattened endothelium and exhibiting slow turnover. A venous malformation may present as a blue patch on the skin ranging to a soft blue mass. Venous malformations are easily compressible and usually swell in thewhen venous pressure increases (e.g., when held in a dependent position or when a child cries). They may be relatively localized or quite extensive within an anatomic region.
name: Venous malformation

desc: Narrowing of a vein due to intimal hyperplasia and fibrosis.
name: Venous stenosis

desc: An abnormality of an inferior thyroid vein.
name: Abnormal inferior thyroid vein morphology

desc: Inflammation of blood vessel.
name: Vasculitis

desc: A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta.
name: Large vessel vasculitis

desc: A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) that affects blood vessels that are smaller than arteries, i.e., arterioles, venules, and capilllaries.
name: Small vessel vasculitis

desc: Abnormal twisting of arteries or veins.
name: Vascular tortuosity

desc: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries.
name: Arterial tortuosity

desc: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of arteries affecting most or all arteries.
name: Generalized arterial tortuosity

desc: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries.
name: Carotid artery tortuosity

desc: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the temporal artery.
name: Temporal artery tortuosity

desc: An abnormality of the systemic arterial tree, which consists of the aorta and other systemic arteries.
name: Abnormal systemic arterial morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the systemic arterial tree

desc: An abnormality of the aorta.
name: Abnormal aortic morphology

desc: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the aorta.
name: Coarctation of aorta

desc: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a segment of the abdominal aorta.
name: Coarctation of abdominal aorta

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized to the region of the descending trunk of arch of aorta.
layperson: Coarctation of the descending aortic arch
name: Coarctation of the descending aortic arch

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized proximal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the preductal region of aortic arch.
name: Preductal coarctation of the aorta

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the juxtaductal region of aortic arch.
name: Juxtaductal coarctation of the aorta

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized distal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the postductal region of aortic arch.
name: Postductal coarctation of the aorta

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized to the region of the transverse aortic arch.
layperson: Coarctation in the transverse aortic arch
name: Coarctation in the transverse aortic arch

desc: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing or constriction of a long segment of the arch of the aorta.
layperson: Long segment coarctation of the aorta
name: Long segment coarctation of the aorta

desc: An overriding aorta is a congenital heart defect where the aorta is positioned directly over a ventricular septal defect, instead of over the left ventricle. The result is that the aorta receives some blood from the right ventricle, which reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood. It is one of the four conditions of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The aortic root can be displaced toward the front (anteriorly) or directly above the septal defect, but it is always abnormally located to the right of the root of the pulmonary artery. The degree of override is quite variable, with 5-95% of the valve being connected to the right ventricle.
name: Overriding aorta

desc: Aortic dissection refers to a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta causing a separation between the intima and the medial layers of the aorta.
layperson: Tear in inner wall of large artery that carries blood away from heart
name: Aortic dissection
synonyms: Tear in inner wall of large artery that carries blood away from heart

desc: A separation of the layers within the wall of the ascending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.
name: Ascending aortic dissection

desc: A separation of the layers within the wall of the descending aorta. Tears in the intimal layer result in the propagation of dissection (proximally or distally) secondary to blood entering the intima-media space.
name: Descending aortic dissection

desc: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta.
name: Aortic tortuosity

desc: Aorto-ventricular tunnel is a congenital, extracardiac channel which connects the ascending aorta above the sinutubular junction to the cavity of the left, or (less commonly) right ventricle.
name: Aorto-ventricular tunnel

desc: Aorto-left ventricular tunnel (ALVT) is a congenital extracardiac channel connecting the ascending aorta above the sino-tubular junction to either left ventricular cavity.
name: Aorto-left ventricular tunnel

desc: The presence of an extracardiac channel that connects the ascending aorta above the sinotubular junction to the cavity of the right ventricle.
name: Aorto-right ventricular tunnel

desc: An anomaly of the arch of aorta.
name: Abnormal aortic arch morphology

desc: Pseudocoarctation is a congenital anomaly of kinking, or buckling, of the aorta without a pressure gradient across the lesion. It is characterized by elongation and kinking of the aorta at the level of the ligamentum arteriosum.
name: Pseudocoarctation of the aorta

desc: A deviance from the norm of the origin or course of the right brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery or the proximal vertebral arteries.
layperson: Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
name: Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch

desc: A developmental defect of the aortic arch system in which the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches. This occurs if the normal process of regression and persistence of the bilateral embryonic aortic arches fails.
name: Vascular ring

desc: The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta.
name: Cervical aortic arch

desc: The left common carotid artery has a common origin with the innominate artery.
layperson: Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery
name: Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery

desc: A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).
name: Double aortic arch

desc: A type of double aortic arch in which the two branches are of equal size. In most cases of double aortic arch, the right aortic arch is larger and located higher than the left aortic arch.
name: Balanced double aortic arch

desc: Aorta descends on right instead of on the left.
name: Right aortic arch

desc: The aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus and not the left mainstem bronchus, but does not result in the creation of a vascular ring. The first branch is the left brachiocephalic artery which divides into the left carotid artery and left subclavian artery, the second branch is the right carotid artery, the third branch is the right subclavian artery.
layperson: Right aortic arch with mirror image branching
name: Right aortic arch with mirror image branching

desc: Aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus. The left carotid artery is the first branch, right carotid artery the second branch and right subclavian artery as the third branch.
layperson: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
name: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell

layperson: Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus
name: Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus

layperson: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery
name: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery
synonyms: Right aortic arch with anomalous left subclavian artery
Right aortic arch with aberrant left subclavian artery

desc: A deviance from the norm of the origin or course of the right brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery or the proximal vertebral arteries, whereby the aortic arch descends on the left as normal (as opposed to right aortic arch).
layperson: Abnormal branching pattern of left aortic arch
name: Abnormal branching pattern of left aortic arch

layperson: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery
name: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery

desc: The subclavian artery arises from ductus arteriosus. While the ductus arteriosus is patent its blood supply comes from the ductus, hence from the pulmonary artery. After it closes, the blood supply is retrogradely from the vertebral artery via the circle of Willis.
layperson: Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery
name: Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery

desc: A patent ductus arteriosus or ductal ligament completes the ring.
layperson: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
name: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell

desc: Aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus. The first branch is the right carotid artery, the second branch is the left carotid artery, the third branch is the subclavian artery, the fourth branch is the right subclavian artery arising from the posteromedial aspect of the distal aortic arch and continuing posterior to the esophagus to the right hand side of the body.
layperson: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
name: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery

desc: The ring may be completed by the ductal ligament.
layperson: Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus
name: Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus

desc: Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment.
name: Interrupted aortic arch

desc: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment at the level of the isthmus.
name: Interrupted aortic arch type A

desc: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the left carotid and subclavian arteries.
name: Interrupted aortic arch type B

desc: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the innominate and left carotid arteries.
name: Interrupted aortic arch type C

desc: Underdevelopment of the arch of aorta.
name: Hypoplastic aortic arch

desc: The presence of atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques in the aorta.
name: Aortic atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Regular circumferential periaortic fibrosis involving the whole aorta and leading to a coated aorta appearance on computed tomography scans
name: Coated aorta

desc: A focal defect in the elastic lamina of the aortic wall that leads to localized medial disruption and potential rupture.
name: Penetrating aortic ulcer

desc: Tearing of the aortic wall generally associated with profuse internal bleeding.
name: Aortic rupture

desc: Any structural anomaly of the portion of the aorta that arises from the base of the left ventricle and extends upward to the aortic arch and from which the coronary arteries arise.
name: Abnormal ascending aorta morphology

desc: Significant luminal narrowing of a long segment of or the entire ascending aorta.
name: Ascending aorta hypoplasia

desc: Small ectopic arteries or arterial branches that connect the aorta, aortic branches and/or subclavian artery regions directly to the lung parenchyma, usually seen in conjunction with pulmonary atresia, ventricular septal defect (VSD) and/or closed ductus arteriosus.
name: Aortopulmonary collateral arteries

desc: A structural abnormality of the part of the aorta that begins at the aortic arch and then descends through the chest and abdomen.
name: Abnormal descending aorta morphology

desc: Significant luminal narrowing of a long segment of the descending aorta.
name: Descending aorta hypoplasia

desc: Medial degeneration of the aorta is to be used as an overarching term for any aortic surgical specimens that demonstrate one or more of the specific histopathologies mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation, elastic fiber fragmentation and/or loss, elastic fiber thinning, elastic fiber disorganization, smooth muscle cell nuclei loss, laminar medial collapse, smooth muscle cell disorganization, medial fibrosis. Grading of medial degeneration is based on the average overall severity of specific histopathologies as described, considering the worst area(s) sampled from multiple slides and aorta sections.
name: Medial degeneration

desc: Loss and/or fragmentation of elastic fibers of the media of the aorta creating increasingly extended translamellar spaces, with absence of elastic fibers, and increased gaps in elastic fiber lamellae as identified on a stain for elastic fibers.
name: Aortic elastic fiber fragmentation

desc: A thinning out of elastic fibers of the media of the aorta that creates widening of intralamellar spaces, as identified on a stain for elastic fibers.
name: Aortic elastic fiber thinning

desc: Nonparallel arrangement/disarray of elastic fibers of the media of the aorta as identified on a stain for elastic fibers.
name: Aortic elastic fiber disorganization

desc: A region of the aortic media in which smooth muscle cell nuclei, involving multiple lamellae, are not clearly identifiable on an hematoxylin and eosin stain.
layperson: Aortic smooth muscle cell nuclei loss
name: Aortic smooth muscle cell nuclei loss

desc: Architecturally, a compaction of aortic medial elastic fibers that creates thinning of the lamellar unit secondary to a band-like smooth muscle cell loss identified using a stain for elastic fibers.
name: Aortic laminar medial collapse

desc: Nonparallel arrangement/disarray of smooth muscle cells of the aortic media creating focal/multifocal disarray or sometimes nodular aggregates of smooth muscle cells.
name: Aortic smooth muscle cell disorganization

desc: An increase in collagen fibers creating areas of substitutive fibrosis or a widening of intralamellar spaces in the media of the aorta. This can be seen in conjunction with a loss to varying degrees of parallel arrangement of the elastic lamellae (or lamellar units).
name: Aortic medial fibrosis

desc: A type of aortic medial fibrosis in which the increase in collagen does not significantly alter the arrangement of the lamellar units.
name: Intralamellar aortic medial fibrosis

desc: A type of aortic medial fibrosis in which the increase in collagen is more scar-like, altering the arrangement of the lamellar units.
name: Translamellar aortic medial fibrosis

desc: An increase of medial mucoid extracellular matrix creating translamellar and/or intralamellar expansions including extracellular pools as noted on an H&E stain and/or a stain to highlight extracellular matrix material (Movat's pentachrome, Alcian blue, etc.).
name: Mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation
synonyms: Cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

desc: A type of mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation in which the increase in mucoid extracellular matrix does not significantly alter the arrangement of the lamellar units.
name: Intralamellar mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation

desc: A type of mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation in which the increase in mucoid extracellular matrix alters the arrangement of the lamellar units to varying degrees.
name: Translamellar mucoid extracellular matrix accumulation

desc: Sclerosis (hardening) of the arteries with increased thickness of the wall of arteries as well as increased stiffness and a loss of elasticity.
name: Arteriosclerosis

desc: A condition characterized by patchy atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques which develop in the walls of medium-sized and large arteries and can lead to arterial stenosis with reduced or blocked blood flow.
name: Atherosclerosis

desc: Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries, which increases the risk of myocardial ischemia.
layperson: Plaque build-up in arteries supplying blood to heart
name: Coronary artery atherosclerosis
synonyms: Plaque build-up in arteries supplying blood to heart

desc: Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries before age of 45.
name: Premature coronary artery atherosclerosis

desc: Coronary disease that has not progressed to the point of causing significant occlusion (blockage) of the coronary arteries.
name: Nonocclusive coronary artery atherosclerosis

desc: The presence of foam cells, a type of macrophage that localizes to fatty deposits on blood vessel walls, where they ingest low-density lipoproteins and become laden with lipids, giving them a foamy appearance.
name: Foam cells

desc: The presence of foam cells that contain lamellar inclusion bodies.
layperson: Foam cells with lamellar inclusion bodies
name: Foam cells with lamellar inclusion bodies

layperson: Foam cells in visceral organs and CNS
name: Foam cells in visceral organs and CNS

desc: Atherosclerosis which occurs in a person with certain risk factors (e.g., SLE, diabetes, smoking, hypertension, hypercholesterolaemia, family history of early heart disease) at an earlier age than would occur in another person without those risk factors.
name: Accelerated atherosclerosis

desc: Yellow-colored streaks, patches, or spots on the intimal surface of arteries. Fatty streaks stain red with Sudan III or Sudan IV.
name: Fatty streak

desc: Thin-cap fibroatheroma is characterized by a relatively large necrotic core with an overlying thin fibrous cap measuring <65 Âµm typically containing numerous macrophages, and is considered to be the precursor lesion of plaque rupture which is the most common cause of coronary thrombosis.
name: Thin-cap fibroatheroma

desc: A lesion associated with atherosclerosis, a multifactorial and multipart progressive disease manifested by the focal development within the arterial wall of lesions, that ranges from teh development of a fatty streak, plaque progression, and plaque disruption. Atherosclerotic lesions demonstrate consistent morphological characteristics, which indicate that each type may stabilize temporarily or permanently and that progression to the next type may require an additional stimulus.
name: Atherosclerotic lesion

desc: In type IV atherosclerotic lesions a dense accumulation of extracellular lipid occupies an extensive but well-defined region of the intima. This type of extracellular lipid accumulation is known as the lipid core. A fibrous tissue increase is not a feature, and complications such as defects of the lesion surface and thrombosis are not present. The type IV lesion is also known as atheroma. Type IV is the first lesion considered advanced in this classification because of the severe intimal disorganization caused by the lipid core. The characteristic core appears to develop from an increase and the consequent confluence of the small isolated pools of extracellular lipid that characterize type III lesions. The increase in lipid is believed to result from continued insudation from the plasma. Type IV lesions, when they first appear in younger people, are found in the same locations as adaptive intimal thickenings of the eccentric type. Thus, atheroma is, at least initially, an eccentric lesion.
name: Type IV atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Type I lesions represent the very initial changes and are recognized as an increase in the number of intimal macrophages and the appearance of macrophages filled with lipid droplets (foam cells).
name: Type I atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Type II atherosclerotic lesions include the fatty streak lesion, the first grossly visible lesion, and are characterized by layers of macrophage foam cells and lipid droplets within intimal smooth muscle cells and minimal coarse-grained particles and heterogeneous droplets of extracellular lipid.
name: Type II atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Type III (intermediate) atherosclerotic lesions are the morphological and chemical bridge between type II and advanced lesions. Type III lesions appear in some adaptive intimal thickenings (progression-prone locations) in young adults and are characterized by pools of extracellular lipid in addition to all the components of type II lesions.
name: Type III atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Type V lesions are defined as lesions in which prominent new fibrous connective tissue has formed. When the new tissue is part of a lesion with a lipid core (type IV), this type of morphology may be referred to as fibroatheroma or type Va lesion. A type V lesion in which the lipid core and other parts of the lesion are calcified may be referred to as type Vb. A type V lesion in which a lipid core is absent and lipid in general is minimal may be referred to as type Vc. With these lesions, arteries are variously narrowed, generally more than with type IV. Importantly, as with type IV lesions, type V lesions may develop fissures, hematoma, and/or thrombus (type VI lesion), and for this reason too they are clinically relevant.
name: Type V atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Type VI atherosclerotic lesions generally have the underlying morphology of type IV or V lesions, surface disruptions, hematoma, and thrombosis may be (although less often) superimposed on any other type of lesion and even on intima without an apparent lesion. Complicating features may arise because of individual differences in risk factors and tissue reactions. These may include differences in composition of the blood, the relative quantities and distributions in the components of the underlying lesion or intima, as well as modifications of shear and tensile forces to which the lesion or intima is exposed. Clinical imaging of lesions may be expected to contribute greatly to the understanding of type VI lesions and the associated clinical syndromes.
name: Type VI atherosclerotic lesion

desc: Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.
name: Premature arteriosclerosis

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.
name: Arterial dissection

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the extracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall.
name: Extracranial internal carotid artery dissection

desc: An arterial lesion that is characterized by either intimal fibroplasia, with neointimal lesions of cells and matrix deposition, or medial fibroplasia, in which there is loss of smooth muscle cells and increased deposition of collagen and proteoglycans in the medial layer.
name: Arterial fibromuscular dysplasia

desc: Any structural abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches.
name: Abnormal carotid artery morphology

layperson: Anomalous branches of internal carotid artery
name: Anomalous branches of internal carotid artery

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the carotid artery wall.
name: Carotid artery dissection

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the internal carotid artery wall.
name: Internal carotid artery dissection

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the intracranial portion of the internal carotid artery wall.
name: Intracranial internal carotid artery dissection

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the external carotid artery wall.
name: External carotid artery dissection

desc: A separation (dissection) of the layers of the common carotid artery wall.
name: Common carotid artery dissection

desc: A dilatation (balooning or bulging out of the vessel wall) of a carotid artery.
name: Carotid artery dilatation

desc: An increase in the combined thickness of the intima and media of the carotid artery.
layperson: Increased carotid artery intimal medial thickness
name: Increased carotid artery intimal medial thickness

desc: Complete obstruction of a carotid artery.
name: Carotid artery occlusion

desc: An abnormal connection between a carotid artery and the cavernous sinus.
name: Carotid cavernous fistula

desc: Narrowing of the carotid arteries.
name: Carotid artery stenosis

desc: An abnormality of the common carotid arteries, which provide the arterial supply to the head and neck and give rise to the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery.
layperson: Abnormality of the common carotid artery
name: Abnormal common carotid artery morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the common carotid artery

desc: The left common carotid artery normally originates from the aortic arch. This term refers to an origin of this artery from the main pulmonary artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the left common carotid artery from the main pulmonary artery
name: Anomalous origin of the left common carotid artery from the main pulmonary artery

desc: The left common carotid artery normally originates from the aortic arch. This term refers to an origin of this artery from the brachiocephalic artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the left common carotid artery from the brachiocephalic artery
name: Anomalous origin of the left common carotid artery from the brachiocephalic artery
synonyms: Anomalous origin of the left common carotid artery from the brachiocephalic trunk

desc: The right common carotid artery normally originates from the brachiocephalic artery. This term refers to an origin of this artery directly from the aorta.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the right common carotid artery from the aorta
name: Anomalous origin of the right common carotid artery from the aorta

desc: An abnormality of an external carotid artery.
name: Abnormality of external carotid artery

desc: Any structural abnormality of the coronary arteries.
name: Abnormal coronary artery morphology

desc: Abnormal narrowing of the coronary artery.
name: Coronary artery stenosis

layperson: Intimal thickening in the coronary arteries
name: Intimal thickening in the coronary arteries

desc: Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.
name: Granulomatous coronary arteritis

desc: Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery.
name: Coronary artery dissection

desc: Isolated abnormalities of the coronary artery origins. This may be in associated with other structural heart malformations but not the patterns of complex structural heart malformations which result in abnormal course of the coronary arteries.
name: Abnormal coronary artery origin

desc: A coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta.
layperson: Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
name: Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery

desc: Left main coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the left cusp of the aortic valve.
layperson: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
name: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
synonyms: Anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery

desc: Right coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the right cusp of the aortic valve.
layperson: Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
name: Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery

desc: The left anterior descending artery (LAD) branches off from the pulmonary artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the left anterior descending artery from the pulmonary artery
name: Anomalous origin of the left anterior descending artery from the pulmonary artery

desc: The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise.
name: Single coronary artery origin

desc: Origin of the right coronary artery (RCA) from the left sinus of Valsalva or of the left main (LM) or left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery from the right sinus of Valsalva.
layperson: Anomalous coronary artery arising from the opposite sinus
name: Anomalous coronary artery arising from the opposite sinus

desc: Origin of the right coronary artery (RCA) from the left sinus of Valsalva or of the left main (LM) or left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery from the right sinus of Valsalva, with the additional feature that the artery passes between the two great arteries. This carries a risk of the artery being compressed by these two vessels,
name: Coronary artery sandwich anomaly
synonyms: Anomalous coronary artery with aortic origin and course between the great arteries

desc: The circumflex coronary artery originates from the right aortic sinus of Valsalva.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the circumflex artery from the right sinus of Valsalva
name: Anomalous origin of the circumflex artery from the right sinus of Valsalva

desc: An abnormal origin of the left circumflex artery (LCX) from the right coronary artery. Normally, the left anterior descending (LAD) and the LCX arise from a common stem, the left main coronary artery (LMCA).
layperson: Anomalous origin of the left circumflex artery from the right coronary artery
name: Anomalous origin of the left circumflex artery from the right coronary artery

desc: Anomalous coronary origin whereby the left anterior descending (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX) arise separately. Normally, these arteries arise from a common stem, the left main coronary artery (LMCA).
layperson: Separate origin of the left anterior descending and left circumflex artery
name: Separate origin of the left anterior descending and left circumflex artery

desc: Absence of the normal opening of a coronary ostium. There are normally two coronary ostia, which are site of origin of the main left or right main coronary artery and are located in the ascending aorta just above the aortic valve.
name: Coronary ostial atresia

desc: Absence of the normal opening of the coronary ostium from which the right main coronary artery originates.
name: Right coronary artery ostial atresia

desc: The left main coronary artery (LMCA) is absent and the left anterior descending (LAD) and left circumflex (LCX) arteries arise from separate but adjacent ostia in the left sinus of Valsava.
name: Absent left main coronary artery

desc: An abnormal path of a coronary artery.
name: Abnormal coronary artery course

desc: A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel.
name: Coronary artery fistula

desc: A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and the pulmonary artery.
name: Coronary-pulmonary artery fistula

desc: An abnormal communication between coronary artery and a cardiac chamber.
name: Coronary cameral fistula
