desc: An abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering the right ventricle.
layperson: Coronary cameral fistula to right ventricle
name: Coronary cameral fistula to right ventricle

desc: An abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering any segment of the systemic or pulmonary circulation.
name: Coronary arteriovenous fistula

desc: A congenital variant of a coronary artery in which a portion of an epicardial coronary artery (most frequently the middle segment of the left anterior descending artery) takes an intramuscular course.
name: Myocardial bridging

desc: Enlargement of the diameter (cross-section) of a coronary artery as defined by a focal dilation of a segment at least 1.5 times larger than the reference vessel.
name: Coronary artery aneurysm

desc: Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries.
name: Arterial intimal fibrosis

desc: Arterial inflammation.
name: Arteritis

desc: A disorder of large arteries, in particular the aorta, characterized by an accumulation of basophilic ground substance in the media with cyst-like lesions associated with degenerative changes of collagen, elastin and the vascular smooth muscle cells.
name: Cystic medial necrosis

desc: An anomaly of the celiac artery.
name: Abnormal celiac artery morphology

desc: Compression of the celiac artery.
name: Celiac artery compression

desc: An anomaly of the vertebral artery, the major artery of the neck that originates from the subclavian artery and merges to form the single midline basilar artery in a complex called the vertebrobasilar system.
name: Abnormal vertebral artery morphology

desc: Elongation, dilatation, and/or tortuosity of the vertebrobasilar segment. The definition of VBD includes: (i) diameter of basilar or vertebral artery over 4.5 mm; or (ii) deviation of any portion more than 10 mm from the shortest expected course; and (iii) length of basilar artery over 29.5 mm or length of intracranial vertebral artery over 23.5 mm.
name: Vertebrobasilar dolichoectasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the vertebral artery.
name: Vertebral artery hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the vertebral artery on one side.
name: Unilateral vertebral artery hypoplasia

desc: Underdevelopment of the vertebral artery on both sides.
name: Bilateral vertebral artery hypoplasia

desc: Any anomaly of a subclavian artery.
name: Abnormal subclavian artery morphology

desc: Usually, three large arteries arise from the arch of the aorta: the brachiocephalic trunk (divided into the right common carotid artery and the right subclavian artery), the left common carotid artery, and the left subclavian artery. However, when aberrant right subclavian artery variant is present, the brachiocephalic trunk is absent and four large arteries arise from the arch of the aorta: the right common carotid artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery, and the final one with the most distal left sided origin, the right subclavian artery, also called the arteria lusoria.
name: Arteria lusoria

desc: Abnormally increased caliber of the left subclavian artery.
name: Dilated left subclavian artery

desc: Origin of the left subclavian artery from an anomalous anatomical location.
layperson: Anomalous origin of left subclavian artery
name: Anomalous origin of left subclavian artery

desc: Abnormal origin of the right subclavian artery from the descending aorta. The right subclavian artery normally arises from the brachiocephalic trunk, which divides into the right common carotid artery and right subclavian artery.
layperson: Anomalous origin of the right subclavian artery from the descending aorta
name: Anomalous origin of the right subclavian artery from the descending aorta

desc: The loss of continuity between the left subclavian artery and the aorta, with persistent connection to the homolateral pulmonary artery through the patent (PDA) or nonpatent ductus arteriosus.
layperson: Isolation of the left subclavian artery
name: Isolation of the left subclavian artery

desc: Any structural anomaly of the radial artery.
name: Abnormal radial artery morphology

desc: Congenital absence of the radial artery.
name: Radial artery aplasia

desc: Narrowing or constriction of the inner surface (lumen) of an artery.
name: Arterial stenosis

desc: Narrowing of peripheral arteries with reduction of blood flow to the limbs. This feature may be quantified as an ankle-brachial index of less than 0.9, and may be manifested clinically as claudication.
name: Peripheral arterial stenosis

desc: Peripheral arterial stenosis with onset before the age of 50 years.
name: Premature occlusive vascular stenosis

desc: Any structural abnormality of a facial artery, one of the branches of the external carotid artery.
name: Abnormal facial artery morphology

desc: An abnormality of the angular artery, the terminal branch of the facial artery.
name: Abnormality of angular artery

desc: An abnormality of an artery of lower lip.
layperson: Abnormality of artery of lower lip
name: Abnormality of artery of lower lip
synonyms: Abnormality of the inferior labial artery

desc: An abnormality of a greater palatine artery.
name: Abnormal greater palatine artery morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of the tiny blood vessels that connect arterioles with venules and whose walls act as semipermeable membranes that mediate the diffusion of fluids and gases between the blood circulation and body tissues.
name: Abnormal capillary morphology

desc: A structural anomaly affecting a blood vessel involved in the circulation of the heart, i.e., the superior or inferior vena cava, the pulmonary arteries, the pulmonary veins, and the aorta.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the great vessels
name: Abnormal morphology of the great vessels

desc: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the aorta and pulmonary arteries.
layperson: Congenital malformation of the great arteries
name: Congenital malformation of the great arteries

desc: In utero, the ductus arteriosus (DA) serves to divert ventricular output away from the lungs and toward the placenta by connecting the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in the first 3 days of life is a physiologic shunt in healthy term and preterm newborn infants, and normally is substantially closed within about 24 hours after bith and completely closed after about three weeks. Failure of physiologcal closure is referred to a persistent or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Depending on the degree of left-to-right shunting, PDA can have clinical consequences.
name: Patent ductus arteriosus

desc: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus in postnatal life when birth was at 37 completed weeks of gestation or greater.
layperson: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
name: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term

desc: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus when birth was at less than 37 weeks completed gestation.
layperson: Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth
name: Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth

desc: The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus.
name: Bilateral ductus arteriosus

desc: A single arterial trunk arises from the cardiac mass. The pulmonary arteries, aorta and coronary arteries arise from this single trunk with no evidence of another outflow tract.
name: Truncus arteriosus

desc: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with a short pulmonary trunk arises from the truncus arteriosus, giving rise to both pulmonary arteries.
name: Type I truncus arteriosus

desc: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus.
name: Type II truncus arteriosus

desc: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta.
name: Type III truncus arteriosus

desc: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present.
name: Type IV truncus arteriosus

desc: A complex congenital heart defect in which the aorta arises from the morphologic right ventricle and the pulmonary artery arises from the morphologic left ventricle.
name: Transposition of the great arteries

desc: A type of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) in which aorta is in front of and primarily to the right of the pulmonary artery. This is the most common kind of TGA.
name: Dextrotransposition of the great arteries
synonyms: D-loop transposition of the great arteries

desc: A type of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) in which aorta is in front of and primarily to the left of the pulmonary artery.
name: Levotransposition of the great arteries

desc: A congenital malformation of the outflow tract of the heart. Conotruncal defects are thought to result from a disturbance of the outflow tract of the embryonic heart, and comprise truncus arteriosus, tetralogy of Fallot, interrupted aortic arch, transposition of the great arteries, and double outlet right ventricle.
name: Conotruncal defect

desc: A congenital cardiac malformation comprising pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The diagnosis of TOF is made if at least three of the four above mentioned features are present.
name: Tetralogy of Fallot

desc: Features of tetralogy of Fallot with either rudimentary ridges or the complete absence of pulmonic valve tissue.
layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
synonyms: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve syndrome

layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus

layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect

desc: The commonest form of tetralogy of Fallot characterized by pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, without pulmonary atresia, absent pulmonary valve, atrioventricular canal defect or absent subarterial conus.
layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis

desc: An extreme form of tetralogy of Fallot characterized by absence of flow from the right ventricle to the pulmonary arteries.
layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia

desc: A type of tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia in which all pulmonary blood flow is derived from major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCA).
layperson: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries
name: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries

desc: Double outlet right ventricle (DORV) is a type of ventriculoarterial connection in which both great vessels arise entirely or predominantly from the right ventricle.
name: Double outlet right ventricle

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with doubly committed VSD and pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: Double outlet right ventricle, doubly committed ventricular septal defect

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, and also has a pulmonary stenosis; abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with non-committed VSD and pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, but there is not accompanying pulmonary stenosis; the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: Double outlet right ventricle, noncommitted ventricular septal defect
DORV with non-committed VSD without pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with subaortic VSD and pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with subaortic VSD without pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with subpulmonary VSD and pulmonary stenosis

desc: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.
layperson: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
name: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
synonyms: DORV with subpulmonary VSD without pulmonary stenosis

desc: The essence of the lesion is the combination of discordant atrioventricular and ventriculo-arterial connections. Thus, the morphologically right atrium is connected to a morphologically left ventricle across the mitral valve, with the left ventricle then connected to the pulmonary trunk. The morphologically left atrium is connected to the morphologically right ventricle across the tricuspid valve, with the morphologically right ventricle connected to the aorta.
layperson: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries
name: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries

desc: A congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with a ventricular septal defect: a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The ventricular septal defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.
layperson: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
name: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect

desc: A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt.
name: Aortopulmonary window

desc: A structural anomaly of vasa vasorum, which are defined as small blood vessels that supply or drain the walls of larger arteries and veins, delivering nutrients and oxygen as well as removing systemic waste products.
name: Abnormal vasa vasorum morphology

desc: The presence of thick collagen bundles around blood vessels, often in an onion-skin type whorling pattern.
name: Perivascular fibrosis

desc: A type of myocardial fibrosis characterized by excessive diffuse collagen accumulation concentrated in perivascular spaces.
name: Perivascular cardiac fibrosis

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries.
name: Arteriovenous malformation

desc: An abnormal connection between an artery and vein.
name: Arteriovenous fistula

desc: A rare vascular anomaly with a direct communication between pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary bed.
name: Pulmonary arteriovenous fistulas

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the pelvis.
name: Pelvic arteriovenous malformation

desc: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the uterus.
name: Uterine arteriovenous malformation

desc: A structural anomaly of the vessel that contains or conveys lymph fluid.
name: Abnormal lymphatic vessel morphology

desc: Congenital underdevelopment of lymph vessels.
name: Hypoplasia of lymphatic vessels

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm arising from the lymphatic vessels.
name: Lymphatic vessel neoplasm

desc: Infiltration of smooth muscle-like cells in lymph vessels as well as the lung (pleura, alveolar septa, bronchi, pulmonary vessels and lymphatics as well as lymph nodes, especially in posterior mediastinum and retroperitoneum). Focal emphysema can develop because of airway narrowing, and the thoracic duct may be obliterated. Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis may lead to multiple small cysts with a hamartomatous proliferation of smooth muscle in their walls.
name: Pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis

desc: Any structural anomaly of the thoracic duct.
name: Abnormal thoracic duct morphology

desc: Dilation of the lymphatic vessels, the basic process that may result in the formation of a lymphangioma.
name: Lymphangiectasis

desc: Angiectasia of lymph vessels (i.e., dilatation of lymphatic vessels) in the intestines.
name: Intestinal lymphangiectasia

desc: An abnormal dilatation of lymph vessels in the pericardium.
name: Pericardial lymphangiectasia

desc: The presence of lymphangiectasis in the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic lymphangiectasis

desc: Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid.
name: Pulmonary lymphangiectasia

desc: Aplasia (absence) of the lymphatic vessels.
name: Aplasia of lymphatic vessels

desc: Abnormality of vascular function.
name: Abnormal vascular physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the tiny blood vessels that connect arterioles with venules and whose walls act as semipermeable membranes that mediate the diffusion of fluids and gases between the blood circulation and body tissues.
name: Abnormal capillary physiology

desc: Reduced resistance to rupture of capillary blood vessels. Capillary fragility may manifest as a bleeding diathesis with spontaneous ecchymoses (bruises).
name: Capillary fragility

desc: An acute phenomenon characterized by hypotension and anasarca due to the loss of plasma volume into peripheral tissues, with evidence of decreased plasma volume (hemoconcentration) and protein loss from the intravascular space (hypoalbuminemia) during acute episodes.
name: Capillary leak

desc: An anomaly of arterial function.
name: Abnormal arterial physiology

desc: Intermittent claudication is a symptom of peripheral arterial occlusive disease. After having walked over a distance which is individually characteristic, the patients experience pain or cramps in the calves, feet or thighs which typically subsides on standing still.
name: Intermittent claudication

desc: Sudden breakage of an artery leading to leakage of blood from the circulation.
name: Arterial rupture

desc: Blockage of blood flow through an artery.
name: Arterial occlusion

desc: Any anomaly of the function of a coronary artery.
name: Abnormal coronary artery physiology

desc: A brief and sudden narrowing of a coronary artery.
name: Coronary artery spasm

desc: Narrowing of an artery due to constriction of the blood vessels.
name: Vasospasm

desc: Pain in the jaw or ear induced by chewing or otherwise moving the jaw.
name: Jaw claudication

desc: The elastic properties of the aorta allow the aorta to store half of the cardiac ejected blood volume per beat, whereby aortic recoil during diastole pushes the remaining stored volume forward into the peripheral circulation, a phenomenon known as the Windkessel function. Aortic stiffness occurs as the elastic fibers within the arterial wall become disrupted due to mechanical stress (with age or due to other factors). Aortic stiffness refers to a reduction in the elasticity of the aorta, which is associated with an elevated pulse pressure, increased wave reflection, and often hypertension.
name: Aortic stiffness

desc: An anomaly of the rhythmic throbbing of an artery that reflects the widening of the artery as blood flows through it and is caused by successive contractions of the heart.
name: Abnormal pulse

desc: A diminution in the amplitude (strength) of the pulse such that the examiner has difficulty feeling the pulse.
name: Weak pulse

desc: The pulsation of an artery where the pulse is taken (e.g. the radial artery at the wrist) cannot be detected on physical examination.
name: Absent pulse

desc: The pulsation of the posterior tibial artery behind the internal malleolus, or of the dorsalis pedis artery, cannot be detected on physical examination.
name: Absent ankle pulse

desc: Increased amplitude (strength) of the pulse.
name: Bounding pulse

desc: Flow-mediated dilatation is a noninvasive tests of endothelial function that leverages ultrasound to measure arterial diameter and its response to an increase in shear stress, which normally causes endothelium-dependent dilatation. This term pertains to an abnormal reduction in the magnitude of dilatation. Flow-mediated dilatation is usually measured at the brachial artery.
name: Impaired flow-mediated arterial dilatation

desc: An anomaly of venous function.
name: Abnormality of venous physiology

desc: Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow at any level from the small hepatic veins to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with the right atrium, 1 and occurs in 1/100,000 of the general population worldwide. The most common presentation is with ascites, but can range from fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) to asymptomatic forms. Obstruction of hepatic venous outflow is mainly caused by primary intravascular thrombosis, which can occur suddenly or be repeated over time, accompanied by some revascularization, accounting for the variable parenchymal hepatic damage and histologic presentation. Budd-Chiari syndrome is thus a disease, but since it occurs as a manifestation of several other diseases, this term is kept for the present for convenience.
name: Budd-Chiari syndrome

desc: Blockage of venous return (flow of blood from the periphery back towards the right atrium) in a vein.
name: Venous occlusion

desc: An anomaly of the jugular venous pressure. The internal jugular veins, being continuous with the superior vena cava, provide a visible measure of the degree to which the systemic venous reservoir is filled. The vertical height above the right atrium to which they are distended and above which they are in a collapsed state provides an imperfect reflection of the right atrial pressure.
name: Abnormal jugular venous pressure

desc: Increased jugular venous pressure.
name: Elevated jugular venous pressure

desc: The examiner applies firm but persistent pressure over the liver for 10 seconds while observing the mean jugular venous pressure. Normally there is either no rise or only a transient (i.e., 2 to 3 sec) rise in mean jugular venous pressure. A sustained increase in the mean venous pressure until abdominal compression is released is abnormal and indicates impaired right heart function. This abnormal response is called hepatojugular reflux.
name: Hepatojugular reflux

desc: An abnormality of the function of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.
name: Abnormal vena cava physiology

desc: An anomaly of the pulse pressure, which is defined as the systolic pressured minus the diastolic pressure.
name: Abnormal pulse pressure

desc: Reduced amplitude of the pulse pressure (systolic blood pressure minus diastolic blood pressure).
name: Low pulse pressure

desc: Increased amplitude of the pulse pressure (systolic blood pressure minus diastolic blood pressure).
name: High pulse pressure

desc: A functional anomaly of that portion of the cardiosvascular system that carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs and returns oxygenated blood back to the heart.
name: Abnormality of pulmonary circulation

desc: An embolus (that is, an abnormal particle circulating in the blood) located in the pulmonary artery and thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung. Usually the embolus is a blood clot that has developed in an extremity (for instance, a deep venous thrombosis), detached, and traveled through the circulation before becoming trapped in the pulmonary artery.
layperson: Blood clot in artery of lung
name: Pulmonary embolism
synonyms: Blood clot in artery of lung

desc: The release of fat globules into the venous circulation, thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung.
name: Pulmonary fat embolism

desc: An abnormally elevated blood pressure in the circulation of the pulmonary artery.
name: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure

desc: Pulmonary hypertension is defined mean pulmonary artery pressure of 25mmHg or more and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15mmHg or less when measured by right heart catheterisation at rest and in a supine position.
layperson: Increased blood pressure in blood vessels of lungs
name: Pulmonary arterial hypertension
synonyms: Increased blood pressure in blood vessels of lungs

desc: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) above 15mmHg.
name: Increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

desc: An abnormal increase in pressure in the pulmonary veins, usually as a result of left atrial hypertension.
name: Pulmonary venous hypertension

desc: Blood flow through a region of the lung in which little or no ventilation takes place, resulting in reduced oxygenation of the blood leaving the lungs.
name: Intrapulmonary shunt

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in the vascular system.
name: Vascular neoplasm

desc: A hemangioma is a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma (in contrast to a hemangioma with small endothelial spaces, which is called capillary hemangioma).
name: Hemangioma

desc: The presence of a cavernous hemangioma. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma.
layperson: Collection of dilated blood vessels that forms mass
name: Cavernous hemangioma
synonyms: Collection of dilated blood vessels that forms mass

desc: The presence of a capillary hemangioma, which are hemangiomas with small endothelial spaces.
name: Capillary hemangioma

desc: A capillary hemangioma surrounding the eyeball but within the orbit.
name: Periocular capillary hemangioma

desc: The presence of multiple hemangiomas in the arachnoid.
name: Arachnoid hemangiomatosis

desc: A vascular tumor of the skin and subcutaneous tissues and characterized by slow angiomatous proliferation.
name: Tufted angioma

desc: A histologically distinctive, cutaneous, benign vascular tumor that is characterized by a solitary or multiple blue-red papules and histologically resembles renal glomeruli.
name: Glomeruloid hemangioma

desc: Hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the perineal region, i.e., the region between the anus and the genitals.
name: Perineal hemangioma

desc: A benign neoplasm that includes blood vessel proliferation and a dense eosinophilic inflammatory infiltrate, manifesting as flesh/plum-colored pruritic nodules and papules, most commonly affecting the ear and the periauricular area.
name: Epithelioid hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the airway, typically below the vocal chords, that can cause severe obstruction of the airway.
name: Subglottic hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the upper part of the larynx (voice box) including the epiglottis; the area above the vocal cords.
name: Supraglottic hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma arising from within visceral structures, the internal organs of the body.
name: Visceral hemangioma

desc: Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium.
name: Cardiac hemangioma

desc: A congenital vascular malformation in the liver composed of masses of blood vessels that are atypical or irregular in arrangement and size.
name: Hepatic hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, located in the intestines, which includes the bowel.
name: Intestinal hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the spleen.
name: Spleen hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the upper lip.
name: Labial hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the esophagus.
name: Esophageal hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the glottic or supraglottic regions.
name: Laryngeal hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the vulva.
name: Vulvar hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the retropharyngeal space, the portion of the peripharyngeal space that is located posterior to the pharynx.
name: Retropharyngeal hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the paraspinal muscular region, the muscles next to the spine.
name: Paraspinal hemangioma

desc: A spinal cord hemangioma located in the lumbosacral spine region.
name: Lumbosacral hemangioma

desc: A hemangioma, a benign tumor of the vascular endothelial cells, that is located in the intrathoracic or chest region.
name: Intrathoracic hemangioma

desc: An anomaly of the lymphatic system, a network of lymphatic vessels that carry a clear fluid called lymph unidirectionally towards either the right lymphatic duct or the thoracic duct, which in turn drain into the right and left subclavian veins respectively.
name: Abnormality of the lymphatic system

desc: An abnormality of the spleen.
name: Abnormality of the spleen

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the spleen.
name: Abnormal spleen morphology

desc: Simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen.
name: Hepatosplenomegaly

desc: Abnormal increased size of the spleen.
name: Splenomegaly

desc: Intermittently increased size of the spleen.
name: Fluctuating splenomegaly

desc: The presence of two or more accessory spleens.
name: Supernumerary spleens

desc: An accessory spleen is a round, iso-echogenic, homogenic and smooth structure and is seen as a normal variant mostly on the medial contour of the spleen, near the hilus or around the lower pole. This has no pathogenic relevance.
name: Accessory spleen

desc: Polysplenia is a congenital disease manifested by multiple small accessory spleens.
name: Polysplenia

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the spleen.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the spleen

desc: Absence (aplasia) of the spleen.
name: Asplenia

desc: Underdevelopment of the spleen.
name: Hypoplastic spleen

desc: An abnormal (non-anatomic) location of the spleen.
name: Ectopia of the spleen

desc: A breach of the capsule of the spleen.
name: Splenic rupture

desc: The fetal spleen is lobulated, and these lobules normally disappear before the birth. Lobulation of the spleen may persist into adult life and be typically seen along the medial part of the spleen. A persisting lobule results in a variation in shape of the spleen.
name: Multilobulated spleen

desc: A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the parenchyma of the spleen.
name: Splenic abscess

desc: Multiple abscess lesions in the spleen.
name: Multifocal splenic abscess

desc: Single (solitary) abscess in the spleen.
name: Unifocal splenic abscess

desc: A closed sac located in the spleen.
name: Splenic cyst

desc: Fusion of the pancreatic tail and spleen.
name: Splenopancreatic fusion

desc: Any anomaly of the function of the spleen.
name: Abnormal spleen physiology

desc: A malfunctioning of the spleen in which it prematurely destroys red blood cells.
name: Hypersplenism

desc: A lymph node abnormality.
name: Abnormality of the lymph nodes

desc: Enlargment (swelling) of a lymph node.
name: Lymphadenopathy

desc: Lymphadenopathy (enlargement of lymph nodes) owing to hyperplasia of follicular (germinal) centers.
name: Follicular hyperplasia

desc: A chronic form of lymphadenopathy that is not related to infection.
name: Chronic noninfectious lymphadenopathy

desc: A generalized form of lymphadenopathy.
layperson: Swollen lymph nodes affecting all regions of the body
name: Generalized lymphadenopathy
synonyms: Swollen lymph nodes affecting all regions of the body

desc: Enlarged lymph nodes in the neck.
layperson: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck
name: Cervical lymphadenopathy
synonyms: Swollen lymph nodes in the neck

desc: Swelling of lymph nodes within the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavities that contains the heart and the great vessels, the esophagus, and trachea and other structures including lymph nodes.
layperson: Swollen lymph nodes in center of chest
name: Mediastinal lymphadenopathy
synonyms: Swollen lymph nodes in center of chest

desc: Underdevelopment of the lymph nodes.
name: Lymph node hypoplasia

desc: Inflammation of a lymph node.
name: Lymphadenitis

desc: Absence of germinal centers in lymph nodes. Germinal centers are the parts of lymph nodes in which B lymphocytes proliferate, differentiate, mutate through somatic hypermutation and class switch during antibody responses.
layperson: Absence of lymph node germinal center
name: Absence of lymph node germinal center
synonyms: Absence of lymph node germinal centre

desc: A morphological anomaly of lymph nodes in the mesenteric root or throughout the mesentery.
name: Abnormality of mesenteric lymph nodes

desc: Increase in size of one or more mesenteric lymph nodes.
name: Enlarged mesenteric lymph node

desc: An abnormally elevated number of lymph nodes in an anatomical region.
name: Increased number of lymph nodes

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary lymphatic chain.
name: Abnormal pulmonary lymphatics

desc: Lymphangiomas are rare congenital malformations consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures. Lymphangioma is usually asymptomatic due to its soft consistency but compression of adjacent structures can be seen due to the mass effect of a large tumor.
name: Lymphangioma

desc: A lymphangioma (congenital malformation consisting of focal proliferations of well-differentiated lymphatic tissue in multi cystic or sponge like structures) located within the mediastinum, i.e., the central compartment of the thoracic cavity that is surrounded by loose connective tissue. Mediastinal lymphangioma is a slow growing mass with benign features, and accounts for 1% of all mediastinal tumors.
name: Mediastinal cystic lymphangioma

desc: An abnormality of the tonsils.
name: Abnormality of the tonsils

desc: An inflammation of the tonsils.
name: Tonsillitis

desc: Increase in size of the tonsils, small collections of lymphoid tissue facing into the aerodigestive tract on either side of the back part of the throat.
name: Enlarged tonsils

desc: Lack of observable tonsillar tissue.
name: Absent tonsils

desc: A phenomenon of orange colored oral tonsils. This feature is characteristic of Tangier disease and illustrated will by Figure 1 of PMID:19470903.
name: Orange discolored tonsils

desc: An abnormality of an infraorbital artery.
name: Abnormality of infraorbital artery

desc: An abnormality of the fetal circulation system or fetal echocardiogram.
layperson: Abnormality of the fetal cardiovascular system
name: Abnormality of the fetal cardiovascular system
synonyms: Abnormality of the fetal circulation system
Abnormality of the foetal cardiovascular system

desc: A first-trimester prenatal ultrasound finding of abnormal blood flow in the ductus venosus.
layperson: Abnormality of ductus venosus blood flow
name: Abnormality of ductus venosus blood flow

desc: Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.
name: Persistent fetal circulation

desc: Persistence of blood flow through the ductus venosus for longer than the normal time after birth.
name: Persistent patent ductus venosus

desc: A congenital defect of the vasculature such that there is a shunt (by-pass) of blood directly from the portal vein to the vena cava (i.e., the blood from the portal vein is not filtered through the liver).
name: Congenital portosystemic venous shunt

desc: Abnormal functionality of the cardiovascular system.
name: Abnormal cardiovascular system physiology

desc: Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow.
name: Syncope

desc: An exaggerated response to carotid sinus baroreceptor stimulation resulting in syncope from transient diminished cerebral perfusion.
name: Carotid sinus syncope

desc: Syncope following a quick change in position from lying down to standing.
name: Orthostatic syncope

desc: A loss of consciousness followed by stiffening and brief clonic movements affecting some or all limbs, often misinterpreted as an epileptic seizure.
name: Reflex asystolic syncope

desc: The presence of an abnormality of cardiac function that is responsible for the failure of the heart to pump blood at a rate that is commensurate with the needs of the tissues or a state in which abnormally elevated filling pressures are required for the heart to do so. Heart failure is frequently related to a defect in myocardial contraction.
name: Congestive heart failure

desc: A form of heart failure characterized by elevated cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure and hyperthyroidism, anemia, pregnancy, arteriovenous fistulae, and others.
name: High-output congestive heart failure

desc: A form of heart failure characterized by reduced cardiac output. This may be seen in patients with heart failure owing to ischemic heart disease, hypertension, cardiomyopathy, and other causes.
name: Low-output congestive heart failure

desc: Necrosis of the myocardium caused by an obstruction of the blood supply to the heart and often associated with chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, and anxiety as well as characteristic EKG findings and elevation of serum markers including creatine kinase-MB fraction and troponin.
name: Myocardial infarction

desc: Paroxysmal chest pain that occurs with exertion or stress and is related to myocardial ischemia.
name: Angina pectoris

desc: An abnormality detectable by sonography of the heart (echocardiography).
name: Abnormal echocardiogram

desc: A diminution of the volumetric fraction of blood pumped out of the ventricle with each cardiac cycle.
name: Reduced ejection fraction

desc: A small reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle. The normal range in adults is at least 50 percent, and a mild reduction is defined as 40-49 percent.
name: Mildly reduced ejection fraction

desc: A medium reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle.
name: Moderately reduced ejection fraction

desc: A large reduction in the fraction of blood pumped from the left ventricle with each cardiac cycle. The normal range in adults is at over 50 percent, and a severe reduction is defined as less than 30 percent.
name: Severely reduced ejection fraction

desc: An abnormal motion of a segment of the left ventricle during the cardiac cycle.
layperson: Regional left ventricular wall motion abnormality
name: Regional left ventricular wall motion abnormality

desc: A reduced ejection fraction and an enlarged left ventricle chamber, the latter by an increased resistance to filling with increased filling pressures. Systolic dysfunction is clinically associated with left ventricular failure in the presence of marked cardiomegaly.
name: Global systolic dysfunction

desc: An abnormality of blood circulation.
name: Abnormality of blood circulation

desc: Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system.
name: Cardiac shunt

desc: Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the right side of the heart to the left.
name: Right-to-left shunt

desc: Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from the left side of the heart to the right.
name: Left-to-right shunt

desc: Pattern of blood flow in the heart that deviates from the normal circuit of the circulatory system from both right side of the heart to the left and vice versa.
name: Bidirectional shunt

desc: The presence of hemorrhage within the body.
name: Internal hemorrhage

desc: Hemorrhage affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Gastrointestinal hemorrhage

desc: The vomiting of blood.
name: Hematemesis

desc: The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding.
name: Melena

desc: The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus.
name: Hematochezia

desc: Bleeding from the intestines.
name: Intestinal bleeding

desc: Bleeding from the small intestine.
name: Small intestinal bleeding

desc: Vomit that has the appearance of coffee grounds, which occurs due to the presence of coagulated blood in the vomit.
name: Coffee ground vomitus

desc: Significant maternal hemorrhage/bleed in the second half of pregnancy and prior to the birth of the baby.
name: Antepartum hemorrhage

desc: Pulmonary hemorrhage is a bleeding within the lungs. Older children and adults may spit blood or bloody sputum. Neonates, infants and young children usually do not spit up blood. Anemia, pulmonary infiltrates, increasingling bloody return on BAL and the presence of hemosiderin-laden macrophages in broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid or lung biopsy can diagnose lung bleeding. Alveolar macrophages contain phagocytosed red blood cells and stain positive for hemosiderin, a product of hemoglobin degradation, after about 48-72 hours following pulmonary hemorraghe. Previous or recurrent bleeding can thus be distinguished from fresh events. A differentiation into local or diffuse is of importance. Also differentiate if pulmonary hemorrhage is due to a primary lung disorder or a manifestation of a systemic disease.
name: Pulmonary hemorrhage

desc: A recurrent hemorrhage occurring within the lung.
name: Recurrent intrapulmonary hemorrhage

desc: A type of of pulmonary hemorrhage that originates from the pulmonary microcirculation, including the alveolar capillaries, arterioles, and venules. It presents with hemoptysis, anemia, diffuse lung infiltration, and acute respiratory failure. The diagnosis is confirmed by the observation of the accumulation of red blood cells, fibrin, or hemosiderin-laden macrophage in the alveolar space on pathologic biopsy. Hemosiderin, a product of hemoglobin degradation, appears at least 48-72 hours after bleeding and is helpful in distinguishing diffuse alveolar hemorrhage from surgical trauma. Mild interstitial thickening, organizing pneumonia, or diffuse alveolar damage can also be seen.
name: Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage

desc: Circumscribed pulmonary hemorrhage originating from a single bleeding site in the lungs. This can be due to infections, tumorigenesis, foreign bodies, or vascular abnormalities. Patient often feel the site of bleeding, contrast CT scan or angiography may localize the bleeder.
name: Localized pulmonary hemorrhage

desc: Bleeding occuring within a muscle
name: Muscle hemorrhage

desc: An abnormality in the amount of volume occupied by intravascular blood.
name: Abnormality of blood volume homeostasis

desc: An increase in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
name: Hypervolemia

desc: An decrease in the amount of intravascular fluid, particularly in the volume of the circulating blood.
name: Hypovolemia

desc: An abnormality of the function of the cardiac atria.
name: Abnormal cardiac atrial physiology

desc: An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the right atrium.
name: Elevated right atrial pressure

desc: An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the left atrium.
name: Elevated left atrial pressure

desc: An abnormality of the cardiac ventricular function.
name: Abnormal cardiac ventricular function

desc: An obstruction to the forward flow of blood in the outflow tract of the right ventricle.
name: Right ventricular outlet tract obstruction

desc: Reduced ability of the right ventricle to perform its function (to receive blood from the right atrium and to eject blood into the pulmonary artery), often leading to pitting peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.
name: Right ventricular failure

desc: Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.
name: Left ventricular dysfunction

desc: Abnormal function of the left ventricule during left ventricular relaxation and filling.
name: Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction

desc: Abnormality of left ventricular contraction, often defined operationally as an ejection fraction of less than 40 percent.
name: Left ventricular systolic dysfunction

desc: An abnormality of filling of a ventricle with blood during diastole.
name: Abnormal ventricular filling

desc: A wall motion abnormality observed upon left ventricular contraction that affects a specific region of the left ventricle.
name: Abnormal regional left ventricular contraction

desc: Reduced wall motion (contraction) of the apex of the left ventricle. This manifestation can be observed on echocardiography.
layperson: Reduced contraction of the left ventricular apex
name: Reduced contraction of the left ventricular apex

desc: Left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction can occur at the valvular, subvalvular, or supravalvular level. In general, there is an obstruction to forward flow which increases afterload, and if untreated, can result in hypertrophy, dilatation, and eventual failure of the left ventricle.
name: Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction

desc: An anomaly of the electrical conduction physiology of the heart.
name: Abnormality of cardiovascular system electrophysiology

desc: Abnormal rhythm of the heart.
name: Abnormal EKG

desc: An abnormality of the T wave on the electrocardiogram, which mainly represents the repolarization of the ventricles.
name: Abnormal T-wave

desc: An inversion of the T-wave (which is normally positive).
name: T-wave inversion

layperson: T-wave inversion in the right precordial leads
name: T-wave inversion in the right precordial leads

desc: A periodic beat-to-beat variation in the amplitude or shape of the T wave in an EKG.
name: T-wave alternans

desc: An electrocardiographic anomaly of the ST segment, which is the segment that connects the QRS complex and the T wave. The ST segment normally has a duration of 80 to 120 ms, is flat and at the same level (isoelectric) as the PR and TP segment.
name: Abnormal ST segment

desc: An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located inferior to the isoelectric line.
name: ST segment depression

desc: An electrocardiographic anomaly in which the ST segment is observed to be located superior to the isoelectric line.
name: ST segment elevation

desc: Any anomaly of the S wave, which is the third component of the QRS wave complex. The S wave signifies the final depolarization of the ventricles at the base of the heart.
name: Abnormal S wave

desc: Increased amplitude (0.1 mV or more) and/or duration (40 ms or more) of the S wave as measured in lead I of the electrocardiogram.
layperson: Prominent S wave in lead I
name: Prominent S wave in lead I

desc: Abnormal depth of the S wave in lead V5 of the electrocardiogram.
layperson: Deep S wave in lead V5
name: Deep S wave in lead V5

desc: The J wave is a positive convex deflection that occurs at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment, the J-point.
name: J wave

desc: An anomaly of the U wave of the electrocardiogram (EKG). The U wave is a small (0.5 mm) deflection immediately following the T wave, usually in the same direction as the T wave. It is best seen in leads V2 and V3.
name: Abnormal U wave

desc: Direction of the U wave opposite to the T wave (i.e., below baseline) in leads with upright T waves.
name: U wave inversion

desc: U wave inversion that is induced by exercise stress testing.
name: Exercise-induced U wave inversion

desc: Increased amplitude of the U wave, defined as an amplitude grerater than 1-2mm or 25 percent of the height of the T wave.
name: Prominent U wave

desc: An anomaly of the complex formed by the Q, R, and S waves, which occur in rapid succession on the electrocardiogram.
name: Abnormal QRS complex

desc: Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec.
name: Prolonged QRS complex

desc: Abnormal amplitude of the QRS complex of the electrocardiogram (EKG).
name: Abnormal QRS voltage

desc: Elevation of the voltage (height) of the QRS complex. There are several criteria in use, but the most common is the Sokolov-Lyon criterion (S wave depth in V1 + tallest R wave height in V5-V6 greater than 35 mm).
name: Increased QRS voltage

desc: Reduced amplitude (height) of the QRS complex of the electrocardiogram (EKG), defined as amplitudes of all the QRS complexes in the limb leads are less than 5 mm or amplitudes of all the QRS complexes in the precordial leads less than 10 mm.
name: Decreased QRS voltage

desc: The QRS complexes of the electrocardiogram alternate in height.
name: Electrical alternans

desc: Any anomaly of the time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).
name: Abnormal QT interval

desc: Increased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).
name: Prolonged QT interval

desc: A longer than normal interval (corrected for heart rate) between the Q and T waves in the heart's cycle. Prolonged QTc can cause premature action potentials during late phase depolarizations thereby leading to ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillations.
name: Prolonged QTc interval

desc: Decreased time between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).
name: Shortened QT interval

desc: An anomaly of the PR interval, which is the portion of the ECG from the end of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. A normal PR interval in adults is 0.12-0.2 seconds.
name: Abnormal PR interval

desc: Reduced time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex). In adults, normal values are 120 to 200 ms long.
name: Shortened PR interval

desc: Increased time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex).
name: Prolonged PR interval

desc: Any anomaly of the P wave of the EKG, which results from atrial depolarization. The P wave occurs when the sinoatrial node creates an action potential that depolarizes the atria.
name: Abnormal P wave

desc: V-shaped cut (notch) in the middle of the P wave.
name: Notched P wave

desc: A broad (120 ms or longer in duration) and bifid P-wave in EKG lead II.
name: P mitrale

desc: P wave below instead of above the baseline. P-wave inversion in the inferior leads may indicate a non-sinus origin of the P waves.
name: P wave inversion

desc: The presence of tall, peaked P waves in EKG lead II.
name: P pulmonale

desc: An anomaly of the PR segment, which begins at the endpoint of the P wave and ends at the onset of the QRS complex. The PR segment is normally flat and isoelectric.
name: Abnormal PR segment

desc: A reduction in voltage of the PR segment below baseline.
name: PR segment depression

desc: An increase in voltage of the PR segment above baseline.
name: PR segment elevation

desc: Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.
name: Arrhythmia

desc: A rapid heartrate that exceeds the range of the normal resting heartrate for age.
name: Tachycardia

desc: Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is an abnormally increased heart rate (over 100 beats per minute at rest) with origin above the level of the ventricles.
name: Supraventricular tachycardia

desc: An episodic form of supraventricular tachycardia with abrupt onset and termination.
name: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia

desc: A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node.
name: AV nodal tachycardia

desc: Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a unique type of supraventricular arrhythmia defined by narrow QRS complex and atrioventricular (AV) dissociation or retrograde atrial conduction in a 1:1 pattern.
name: Junctional ectopic tachycardia

desc: Accessory pathway-related atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) involves an abnormal electrical conduction of the accessory pathway. The accessory pathway connecting impulses between the atrium and the ventricle can be seen at any site in the AV groove.
name: Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia

desc: A type of atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) where the atrioventricular node is used for anterograde conduction and the accessory pathway for retrograde conduction.
name: Orthodromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia

desc: A type of atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) where the accessory pathway is used for anterograde conduction and the atrioventricular node for retrograde conduction.
name: Antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia

desc: Supraventricular tachycardia in which an accessory pathway connecting the atria and ventricles, apart from the AV node, participates as a necessary part of a reentrant mechanism.
layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
synonyms: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connexion mediated pathway

desc: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway that is called concealed becasue it is not seen on the ECG during sinus rhythm.
layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
synonyms: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connexion

desc: An incessant orthodromic tachycardia with anterograde conduction over the atrioventricular node and by retrograde conduction via an accessory pathway usually located in the posteroseptal region with slow and decremental conduction.
name: Permanent junctional reciprocating tachycardia

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall

layperson: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum
name: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum

desc: A tachycardia originating in the ventricles characterized by rapid heart rate (over 100 beats per minute) and broad QRS complexes (over 120 ms).
name: Ventricular tachycardia

desc: Episodes of ventricular tachycardia that have a sudden onset and ending.
name: Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia

desc: Polymorphic ventricular arrhythmias of varying morphologythat do not exist under resting conditions but appear only upon physical exercise or catecholamine administration.
name: Effort-induced polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

desc: A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid, hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance.
name: Ventricular flutter

desc: A ventricular tachycardia (VT) characterized by right bundle branch block (RBBB) and left axis deviation (LAD) on electrocardiogram (ECG).
name: Fascicular left ventricular tachycardia

desc: A type of ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by uniform QRS complexes within each lead (i.e., each QRS is identical or nearly so).
name: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia

desc: A type of ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by variable QRS complexes within each lead (i.e., QRS complexes may be different from beat to beat).
name: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia

desc: A slower than normal heart rate (in adults, slower than 60 beats per minute).
name: Bradycardia

desc: Bradycardia related to a mean resting sinus rate of less than 50 beats per minute.
name: Sinus bradycardia

desc: An abrupt loss of heart function.
name: Cardiac arrest

desc: The heart suddenly and unexpectedly stops beating resulting in death within a short time period (generally within 1 h of symptom onset).
name: Sudden cardiac death

desc: Cardiac arrest that would have led to rapid and unexpected death had an intervention not taken place to prevent it.
name: Aborted sudden cardiac death

desc: A sensation that the heart is pounding or racing, which is a non-specific sign but may be a manifestation of arrhythmia.
name: Palpitations

desc: Uncontrolled contractions of muscles fibers in the left ventricle not producing contraction of the left ventricle. Ventricular fibrillation usually begins with a ventricular premature contraction and a short run of rapid ventricular tachycardia degenerating into uncoordinating ventricular fibrillations.
name: Ventricular fibrillation

desc: A type of ventricular tachycardia characterized by polymorphioc QRS complexes that change in amplitue and cycle length, and thus have the appearance of oscillating around the baseline in the EKG.
name: Torsade de pointes

desc: An abnormality in which the cardiac ventricles depolarize too early as a result of an abnormality of cardiac conduction pathways such as an accessory pathway.
name: Ventricular preexcitation

desc: A disorder of the cardiac conduction system of the heart characterized by ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of an abnormal accessory atrioventricular electrical conduction pathway.
name: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

desc: A form of ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of multiple accessory pathways for cardiac conduction.
layperson: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways
name: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways

desc: A ventircular escape rhythm occurs whenever higher-lever pacemakers in AV junction or sinus node fail to control ventricular activation. Escape rate is usually 20-40 bpm, often associated with broad QRS complexes (at least 120 ms).
name: Ventricular escape rhythm

desc: Premature ventricular contractions (PVC) or ventricular extrasystoles are premature contractions of the heart that arise in response to an impulse in the ventricles rather than the normal impulse from the sinoatrial (SA) node.
name: Ventricular extrasystoles

desc: A type of arrhythmia that originates above the ventricles, whereby the electrical impulse propagates down the normal His Purkinje system similar to normal sinus rhythm.
name: Supraventricular arrhythmia

desc: A type of supraventricular tachycardia in which the atria are the principal site of electrophysiologic disturbance.
name: Atrial arrhythmia

desc: A type of atrial arrhythmia characterized by atrial rates of between 240 and 400 beats per minute and some degree of atrioventricular node conduction block. Typically, the ventricular rate is half the atrial rate. In the EKG; atrial flutter waves are observed as sawtooth-like atrial activity. Pathophysiologically, atrial flutter is a form of atrial reentry in which there is a premature electrical impulse creates a self-propagating circuit.
name: Atrial flutter

desc: Typical atrial flutter is an organised atrial tachycardia. It can also be defined as a macroreentrant tachycardia confined to the right atrium. This arrhythmia has a 200-260 ms cycle length, although it may fluctuate depending on patient's previous treatment or ablation, congenital heart disease, etc. Ventricular rate response will be limited by the atrioventricular node conductions, usually presenting a 2:1 or 3:1 response, during atrial flutter. Typical (counter clockwise) flutter is associated with the common flutter pattern: a regular continuous undulation with dominant negative deflections in inferior leads II, III and aVF, often described also as a saw tooth pattern, and flat atrial deflections in leads I and aVL. Atrial deflections in V1 can be positive, biphasic or negative.
name: Typical atrial flutter

desc: A type of atrial flutter associated with rounded or bimodal positive deflections in inferior leads II, III and aVF, and a very characteristic bimodal negative wave in the shape of a W is seen in lead V1.
name: Reverse typical atrial flutter

desc: An atrial arrhythmia characterized by disorganized atrial activity without discrete P waves on the surface EKG, but instead by an undulating baseline or more sharply circumscribed atrial deflections of varying amplitude an frequency ranging from 350 to 600 per minute.
layperson: Quivering upper heart chambers resulting in irregular heartbeat
name: Atrial fibrillation
synonyms: Quivering upper heart chambers resulting in irregular heartbeat

desc: AF that cannot be successfully terminated by cardioversion, and longstanding (more than 1 year) AF, where cardioversion is not indicated or has not been attempted, is termed permanent.
name: Permanent atrial fibrillation

desc: Episodes of atrial fibrillation that typically last for several hours up to one day and terminate spontaneously.
name: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation

desc: Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.
name: Automatic atrial tachycardia

desc: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a rare supraventricular arrhythmia in neonates and young infants that is characterized by multiple P waves with varying P wave morphology and is usually asymptomatic.
name: Multifocal atrial tachycardia

desc: A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites.
name: Premature atrial contractions

desc: Atrial standstill or silent atrium is a rare condition presenting with the absence of electrical and mechanical activity in the atria. It presents with the absence of P waves, bradycardia, and wide QRS complex in the electrocardiogram.
name: Atrial standstill

desc: An abnormality of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium. THe SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart.
layperson: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
name: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin

desc: Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.
name: Sinus tachycardia

desc: Inappropriate sinus tachycardia is a nonparoxysmal tachyarrhythmia characterized by an increased resting heart rate (HR) and/or an exaggerated HR response to minimal exertion or a change in body posture. HR is constantly above the physiological range with no appropriate relation to metabolic or physiological demands.
name: Inappropriate sinus tachycardia

desc: An abnormality involving the generation of the action potential by the sinus node and is characterized by an atrial rate inappropriate for physiological requirements. Manifestations include severe sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses or arrest, sinus node exit block, chronic atrial tachyarrhythmias, alternating periods of atrial bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias, and inappropriate responses of heart rate during exercise or stress.
name: Sick sinus syndrome

desc: Disturbance in the atrial activation that is caused by transient failure of impulse conduction from the sinoatrial node to the cardiac atria.
name: Sinoatrial block

desc: Any abnormality in the variability of the time interval between successive heartbeats.
name: Abnormal heart rate variability

desc: Reduced variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle.
name: Decreased heart rate variability

desc: Increased variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle.
name: Increased heart rate variability

desc: Any anomaly of the progression of electrical impulses through the heart.
name: Cardiac conduction abnormality

desc: An impairment of the electrical continuity between the atria and ventricles.
name: Abnormal atrioventricular conduction

desc: Delayed or lack of conduction of atrial depolarizations through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles.
layperson: Interruption of electrical communication between upper and lower chambers of heart
name: Atrioventricular block
synonyms: Interruption of electrical communication between upper and lower chambers of heart

desc: Third-degree atrioventricular (AV) block (also referred to as complete heart block) is the complete dissociation of the atria and the ventricles. Third-degree AV block exists when more P waves than QRS complexes exist and no relationship (no conduction) exists between them.
name: Third degree atrioventricular block

desc: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at a relatively low part of the conduction system (below the atrioventricular node), which produces a wide QRS complex.
layperson: Complete heart block with broad QRS complexes
name: Complete heart block with broad QRS complexes

desc: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at the atrioventricular node, which produces a narrow QRS complex.
layperson: Complete heart block with narrow QRS complexes
name: Complete heart block with narrow QRS complexes

desc: Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles.
name: First degree atrioventricular block

desc: An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction.
name: Second degree atrioventricular block

desc: Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals).
name: Mobitz I atrioventricular block

desc: A type of second degree atrioventricular (AV) block characterized by sudden failure to conduct an impulse through the AV node without a preceding change in the PR interval.
name: Mobitz II atrioventricular block

desc: Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is present if the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers. AV dissociation can occur in the absence of a primary AV conduction disturbance.
name: Atrioventricular dissociation

desc: A form of atrioventricular (AV) dissociation (i.e., the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers) with congenital onset.
name: Congenital atrioventricular dissociation

desc: Impaired conduction of cardiac impulse occurring anywhere along the conduction pathway.
name: Heart block

desc: Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.
name: Bundle branch block

desc: A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.
name: Right bundle branch block

desc: A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG.
name: Left bundle branch block

desc: Conduction block in the posterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.
name: Left posterior fascicular block

desc: Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.
name: Left anterior fascicular block

desc: Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue.
name: Trifascicular block

desc: A chronic deviation from normal pressure in the systemic arterial system.
name: Abnormal systemic blood pressure

desc: Low Blood Pressure, vascular hypotension.
name: Hypotension

desc: Abnormal decrease in diastolic blood pressure.
name: Decreased diastolic blood pressure

desc: A decrease in diastolic blood pressure (<60 mmHg) without a decrease in systolic blood pressure (> or = to 100 mmHg).
name: Isolated diastolic hypotension

desc: Abnormal decrease in systolic blood pressure.
name: Decreased systolic blood pressure

desc: An abnormal blood pressure discrepancy between the upper and lower extremities with the blood pressure measured in the legs being much higher than the blood pressure measure in the arms. In healthy individuals, ankle systolic blood pressures are only slightly higher than the systolic blood pressure measured in the arm.
layperson: Blood pressure substantially higher in legs than arms
name: Blood pressure substantially higher in legs than arms
synonyms: Blood pressure substantially lower in arms than legs
Blood pressure substantially lower in upper than lower extremities
Blood pressure substantially higher in lower than upper extremities

desc: An abnormal blood pressure discrepancy between the upper and lower extremities with the blood pressure measured in the arms being much higher than the blood pressure measure in the legs. In healthy individuals, ankle systolic blood pressures are only slightly higher than the systolic blood pressure measured in the arm.
layperson: Blood pressure substantially higher in arms than legs
name: Blood pressure substantially higher in arms than legs
synonyms: Blood pressure substantially higher in upper than lower extremities

desc: Abnormal increase in blood pressure. An individual measurement of increased blood pressure does not necessarily imply hypertension. In practical terms, multiple measurements are recommended to diagnose the presence of hypertension.
name: Increased blood pressure

desc: The presence of chronic increased pressure in the systemic arterial system.
name: Hypertension

desc: A type of hypertension associated with pheochromocytoma.
name: Hypertension associated with pheochromocytoma

desc: A positive response to the regitine blocking test consisting of a substantial reduction in blood pressure following administration of regitine, indicative of the presence of increased levels of epinephrine and norepinephrine in the circulation, which is seen in pheochromocytoma-associated hypertension.
name: Positive regitine blocking test

desc: Abnormal increase in systolic blood pressure.
name: Elevated systolic blood pressure

desc: Elevated systolic blood pressure without an elevated blood pressure.
name: Isolated systolic hypertension

desc: An abnormal increase in the average blood pressure in an individual during a single cardiac cycle.
name: Elevated mean arterial pressure

desc: Abnormal increase in diastolic blood pressure.
name: Elevated diastolic blood pressure

desc: The state in which profound and widespread reduction of effective tissue perfusion leads first to reversible, and then if prolonged, to irreversible cellular injury.
name: Shock

desc: Severely decreased cardiac output with evidence of inadequate end-organ perfusion (i.e., tissue hypoxia) in the presence of adequate intravascular volume.
name: Cardiogenic shock

desc: A state of shock characterized by decreased circulating blood volume in relation to total vascular capacity. This type of shock is characterized by a reduction of diastolic filling pressures.
name: Hypovolemic shock

desc: A hyperdynamic process resulting from excessive vasodilatation. Impaired blood flow causes inadequate tissue perfusion, which can lead to end-organ damage
name: Distributive shock

desc: A type of shock characterized by inadequate cardiac preload due to obstructed venous return (e.g. pericardial tamponade, tension pneumothorax, abdominal compartment) or obstruction of arterial blood flow (e.g. pulmonary embolism).
name: Obstructive shock

desc: Any functional abnormality of a cardiac valve.
name: Abnormal heart valve physiology

desc: Any functional defect of the mitral or tricuspid valve.
name: Abnormal atrioventricular valve physiology

desc: Any functional anomaly of the mitral valve.
name: Abnormal mitral valve physiology

desc: An abnormality of the mitral valve characterized by insufficiency or incompetence of the mitral valve resulting in retrograde leaking of blood through the mitral valve upon ventricular contraction.
name: Mitral regurgitation

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the orifice of the mitral valve.
name: Mitral stenosis

desc: Mitral stenosis with congenital onset.
name: Congenital mitral stenosis
