desc: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve (SAM) is a paradoxical motion of the anterior, and occasionally posterior, mitral valve leaflet towards the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) during systole.
layperson: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
name: Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve

desc: Any functional defect of the tricuspid valve.
name: Abnormal tricuspid valve physiology

desc: Failure of the tricuspid valve to close sufficiently upon contraction of the right ventricle, causing blood to regurgitate (flow backward) into the right atrium.
name: Tricuspid regurgitation

desc: A narrowing of the orifice of the tricuspid valve of the heart.
name: Tricuspid stenosis

desc: The presence of a stenosis (narrowing) of the aortic valve.
name: Aortic valve stenosis

desc: A pathological narrowing in the region above the aortic valve associated with restricted left ventricular outflow.
name: Supravalvular aortic stenosis

desc: An insufficiency of the aortic valve, leading to regurgitation (backward flow) of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.
name: Aortic regurgitation

desc: Any functional anomaly of the pumonary valve.
name: Abnormal pulmonary valve physiology

desc: A narrowing of the right ventricular outflow tract that can occur at the pulmonary valve (valvular stenosis) or just below the pulmonary valve (infundibular stenosis).
name: Pulmonic stenosis

desc: The retrograde (backwards) flow of blood through the pulmonary valve into the right ventricle during diastole.
name: Pulmonary insufficiency

desc: Any abnormal noise generated by the beating heart.
name: Abnormal heart sound

desc: An extra or unusual sound heard during a heartbeat caused vibrations resulting from the flow of blood through the heart.
name: Heart murmur

desc: A heart murmur limited to systole, i.e., between the first and second heart sounds S1 and S2.
name: Systolic heart murmur

desc: A systolic murmur that begins after S1 and ends before S2, typically with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern.
name: Midsystolic murmur

desc: A murmur that occurs in the latter phase of systole.
name: Late systolic murmur

desc: A heart murmur that occurs during the entire systolic phase from S1 to S2.
name: Holosystolic murmur

desc: A heart murmur that occurs during diastole, i.e., in the time between S2 and the subsequent S1.
name: Diastolic heart murmur

desc: A murmur that occurs in the middle of the diastolic phase.
name: Middiastolic murmur

desc: A murmur that occurs in both systole and diastole.
name: Continuous heart murmur

desc: The third heart sound (S3) is related to rapid filling in diastole. S3 can be a normal finding in children and adolescents but suggests heart failure in older patients.
name: Third heart sound

desc: Abnormally increased volume of the first heart sound.
name: Loud first heart sound

desc: Any anomaly of the second heart sound (S2), which is produced by aortic (A2) and pulmonic (P2) valve closure. The A2-P2 interval normally increases with inspiration and narrows with expiration.
name: Abnormal second heart sound

desc: Lack of variation in the splitting between the two components of the second heart sound with respiration. Normally, the aortic valve closure (A2) is followed by the pulmonic valve closure (P2) but the A2-P2 interval increases with inspiration and decreases with expiration.
layperson: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound
name: Fixed splitting of the second heart sound

desc: Normally, the aortic valve closure (A2) is followed by the pulmonic valve closure (P2) but the A2-P2 interval increases with inspiration and decreases with expiration. With paradoxical splitting, there is a delay in the closure of the aortic valve, so that A2 can follow P2; the individual components can be appreciated at the end of expiration and the interval narrows with inspiration (which is the oposite of the normal pattern).
layperson: Paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound
name: Paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound
synonyms: Reversed splitting of the second heart sound

layperson: Abnormally loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound
name: Abnormally loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound
synonyms: Accentuation of the pulmonic component of the second heart sound

desc: Presyncope is a state of lightheadedness, muscular weakness, blurred vision, and feeling faint. Presyncope is most often cardiovascular in cause.
name: Presyncope

desc: Any structural anomaly of the heart and great vessels.
name: Abnormality of cardiovascular system morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly of the heart.
name: Abnormal heart morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of the muscle layer of the heart wall.
name: Abnormal myocardium morphology

desc: A myocardial disorder in which the heart muscle is structurally and functionally abnormal, in the absence of coronary artery disease, hypertension, valvular disease and congenital heart disease sufficient to cause the observed myocardial abnormality.
name: Cardiomyopathy

desc: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is defined by the presence of increased ventricular wall thickness or mass in the absence of loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) sufficient to cause the observed abnormality.
name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

desc: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an asymmetrical pattern of hypertrophy, with a predilection for the interventricular septum and myocyte disarray.
name: Asymmetric septal hypertrophy

desc: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with an symmetrical and concentric pattern of hypertrophy.
name: Concentric hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

desc: Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (AHCM) is diastolic dysfunction due to abnormal stiffness of the left ventricle during diastole, with resultant impaired ventricular filling. In AHCM thickened apical segments produce a crowded, spade-shaped, small apical cavity.
name: Apical hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

desc: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is defined by the presence of left ventricular dilatation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction in the absence of abnormal loading conditions (hypertension, valve disease) or coronary artery disease sufficient to cause global systolic impairment. Right ventricular dilation and dysfunction may be present but are not necessary for the diagnosis.
name: Dilated cardiomyopathy

desc: Restrictive left ventricular physiology is characterized by a pattern of ventricular filling in which increased stiffness of the myocardium causes ventricular pressure to rise precipitously with only small increases in volume, defined as restrictive ventricular physiology in the presence of normal or reduced diastolic volumes (of one or both ventricles), normal or reduced systolic volumes, and normal ventricular wall thickness.
name: Restrictive cardiomyopathy

desc: A type of cardiomyopathy characterized pathologically by hamartomatous lesions of cardiac Purkinje cells.
name: Histiocytoid cardiomyopathy

desc: Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease.
name: Right ventricular cardiomyopathy

desc: Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation.
name: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

desc: A type of cardiomyopathy characterized anatomically by deep trabeculations in the ventricular wall, which define recesses communicating with the main ventricular chamber.
name: Noncompaction cardiomyopathy

desc: Left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC) is characterized by prominent left ventricular trabeculae and deep inter-trabecular recesses. The myocardial wall is often thickened with a thin, compacted epicardial layer and a thickened endocardial layer. In some patients, LVNC is associated with left ventricular dilatation and systolic dysfunction, which can be transient in neonates.
name: Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy

desc: A predominantly right ventricular variant of isolated noncompaction cardiomyopathy.
name: Right ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy

desc: Noncompaction cardiomyopathy that affects both ventricles.
name: Biventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy

desc: Any complex of structural, architectural, contractile or electrophysiological changes affecting the atria with the potential to produce clinically relevant manifestations.
name: Atrial cardiomyopathy

desc: Myocardial fibrosis is characterized by dysregulated collagen turnover (increased synthesis predominates over unchanged or decreased degradation) and excessive diffuse collagen accumulation in the interstitial and perivascular spaces as well as by phenotypically transformed fibroblasts, termed myofibroblasts.
name: Myocardial fibrosis

desc: A type of myocardial fibrosis characterized by excessive diffuse collagen accumulation concentrated in interstitial spaces.
name: Interstitial cardiac fibrosis

desc: Irreversible damage to heart tissue (myocardium) due to lack of oxygen after a heart attack (myocardial infarction).
name: Myocardial necrosis

layperson: Focal necrosis of right ventricular muscle cells
name: Focal necrosis of right ventricular muscle cells

desc: Inflammation of the myocardium.
name: Myocarditis

desc: Any structural anomaly of the muscular columns which project from the inner surface of the right and left ventricles of the heart (cardiac trabeculae, trabeculae carneae).
name: Abnormal morphology of myocardial trabeculae

desc: Any structural anomaly of the muscular columns which project from the inner surface of the left ventricle of the heart (cardiac trabeculae, trabeculae carneae).
layperson: Abnormal morphology of left ventricular trabeculae
name: Abnormal morphology of left ventricular trabeculae

desc: Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) is defined by 3 markers: prominent left ventricular (LV) trabeculae, deep intertrabecular recesses, and the thin compacted layer.
name: Left ventricular noncompaction

desc: An increased density (number and tightness) of the muscular columns which project from the inner surface of the left ventricles of the heart (cardiac trabeculae, trabeculae carneae).
layperson: Increased density of left ventricular trabeculae
name: Increased density of left ventricular trabeculae

desc: An increased number and density of the trabeculae in the apex (tip) of the left ventricle.
layperson: Apical hypertrabeculation of the left ventricle
name: Apical hypertrabeculation of the left ventricle

desc: Reduced thickness of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium.
name: Thin myocardium compact layer

desc: Any structural anomaly of the muscular columns which project from the inner surface of the right ventricle of the heart (cardiac trabeculae, trabeculae carneae).
layperson: Abnormal morphology of right ventricular trabeculae
name: Abnormal morphology of right ventricular trabeculae

desc: Extracellular deposition in cardiac tissue of a proteinaceous material that, when stained with Congo red, demonstrates apple-green birefringence under polarized light and that has a distinct color when stained with sulfated Alcian blue. Viewed with electron microscopy, the amyloid deposits are seen to be composed of a beta-sheet fibrillar material. These nonbranching fibrils have a diameter of 7.5 to 10 nm and are the result of protein misfolding.
name: Cardiac amyloidosis

desc: A type of cardiac amyloidosis related to deposition of an immunoglobulin light chain. The current gold standard of amyloid typing is to determine the precursor protein using laser microdissection mass spectrometry.
name: Monoclonal light chain cardiac amyloidosis

desc: A type of cardiac amyloidosis related to deposition of transthyretin (TTR), which is identified by immunohistochemical staining.
name: Transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis

desc: A structural anomaly of the muscle layer of the heart wall of a cardiac ventricle.
name: Abnormal ventricular myocardium morphology

desc: Presence of an increased amount of fat tissue within a cardiac ventricle with corresponding reduction of muscle tissue.
layperson: Fatty replacement of ventricular myocardial tissue
name: Fatty replacement of ventricular myocardial tissue

desc: A nonparallel arrangement of cardiac myocytes.
name: Myofiber disarray

desc: An increase in the number of immune cells in myocardial tissue (which can be assumed to have migrated into the myocardium).
name: Myocardial immune cell infiltration

desc: An increase in the number of lymphocytes in myocardial tissue.
name: Myocardial lymphocytic infiltration

desc: An increase in the number of eosinophils in myocardial tissue.
name: Myocardial eosinophilic infiltration

desc: The presence of extremely large cells with multiple nuclei. The so-called giant cells are thought to be of macrophage origin.
name: Myocardial multinucleated giant cells

desc: The presence of multiple granulomata (small nodular inflammatory lesions containing grouped mononuclear phagocytes) in the myocardium.
name: Myocardial granulomatous infiltrates

desc: An increase in the number of immune cells in myocardial tissue concentrated in the spaces surrounding blood vessels.
name: Perivascular myocardial immune cell infiltration

desc: Increased size of the heart.
name: Cardiomegaly

desc: Any structural abnormality of a cardiac valve.
name: Abnormal heart valve morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality of the pulmonary valve.
name: Abnormal pulmonary valve morphology

desc: Refers to the specific combination of defects with a severely dysplastic pulmonary valve and massively dilated branch pulmonary arteries.
name: Absence of the pulmonary valve

desc: Any defect in the valve connecting the heart and the pulmonary artery.
name: Pulmonary valve defects

desc: A congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
name: Dysplastic pulmonary valve

desc: A congenital disorder of the pulmonary valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
name: Pulmonary valve atresia

desc: Any structural anomaly of the pulmonary valve leaflets.
name: Abnormal pulmonary valve cusp morphology

desc: The presence of a bicuspid pulmonary valve.
name: Bicuspid pulmonary valve

desc: Any abnormality of the aortic valve.
name: Abnormal aortic valve morphology

desc: A congenital malformation of the aortic valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
name: Dysplastic aortic valve

desc: A congenital disorder of the aortic valve in which the orifice of the valve fails to develop.
name: Aortic valve atresia

desc: Aortic valve prolapse can be diagnosed when either or both of the right or non-coronary aortic valve cusps (seen in the cross sectional echocardiographic long axis view) show backward bowing towards the left ventricle beyond a line joining the points of attachment of the aortic valve leaflets to the annulus.
name: Aortic valve prolapse

desc: Any structural anomaly of the aortic valve leaflets.
name: Abnormal aortic valve cusp morphology

desc: The presence of an aortic valve with two instead of the normal three cusps (flaps). Bicuspid aortic valvue is a malformation of a commissure (small space between the attachment of each cusp to the aortic wall) and the adjacent parts of the two corresponding cusps forming a raphe (the fused area of the two underdeveloped cusps turning into a malformed commissure between both cusps; the raphe is a fibrous ridge that extends from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps).
layperson: Aortic valve has two leaflets rather than three
name: Bicuspid aortic valve
synonyms: Aortic valve has two leaflets rather than three

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) characterized by two equal-sized cusps, with no raphe and only two commissures. There is a lateral arrangement of the free edge of the cusps. Note that this differs from some other forms of BAV in which there are three commissures and two of the three cusps are joined by a raphe forming two functional leaflets. This type of BAV often is associated with aortic stenosis.
name: Purely bicuspid aortic valve

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valvue (BAV) characterized by the presence of a single raphe that extends from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps, resulting in two leaflets of unequal size.
name: Single raphe bicuspid aortic valve

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) characterized by a single raphe between the right and left cusps (RL fusion pattern). This results in two leaflefts with an anterior-posterior leaflet orientation (also called the typical pattern). There is thus one completely developed noncoronary cusp, two completely developed commissures, and one raphe between the underdeveloped left and right coronary cusps extending to the corresponding malformed commissure.
layperson: Bicuspid aortic valve with right-left cusp fusion
name: Bicuspid aortic valve with right-left cusp fusion

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) characterized by a single raphe between the right and noncoronary cusps (RN fusion pattern). This results in two leaflets with right-left leaflet orientation (also called the atypical pattern). There is thus one completely developed left cusp, two completely developed commissures, and one raphe between the underdeveloped right and noncoronary coronary cusps extending to the corresponding malformed commissure.
layperson: Bicuspid aortic valve with right-noncoronary cusp fusion
name: Bicuspid aortic valve with right-noncoronary cusp fusion

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) characterized by a single raphe between the left and noncoronary cusps (LN fusion pattern). There is thus one completely developed right cusp, two completely developed commissures, and one raphe between the underdeveloped left and noncoronary coronary cusps extending to the corresponding malformed commissure.
layperson: Bicuspid aortic valve with left-noncoronary cusp fusion
name: Bicuspid aortic valve with left-noncoronary cusp fusion

desc: A type of bicuspid aortic valvue (BAV) characterized by the presence of two raphes that each extend from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps. This type of BAV has developmental anlagen of three cusps, commissures, and sinuses, but two commissures are more or less malformed and obliterated, giving rise to a raphe, a fibrous ridge, which extends from the commissure to the free edge of the two underdeveloped, conjoint cusps. This type of BAV is typically associated with a high degree of aortic stenosis.
name: Two-raphe bicuspid aortic valve

desc: The presence of an aortic valve with one instead of the normal three cusps (flaps).
name: Unicuspid aortic valve

desc: An abnormally increased thickness of a leaflet of the aortic valve.
name: Thickened aortic valve cusp

desc: A developmental defect characterized by the lack of aortic valve cusps (leaflets). There may be remnants of the aortic valve in form of a nonobstructive fibrous ridge or rudimentary leaflets or sinuses of Valsalva.
name: Absent aortic valve cusps

desc: The presence of an aortic valve with four instead of the normal three cusps (flaps).
name: Quadricuspid aortic valve

desc: An abnormality of an atrioventricular valve.
name: Abnormal atrioventricular valve morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly of the mitral valve.
name: Abnormal mitral valve morphology

desc: One or both of the leaflets (cusps) of the mitral valve bulges back into the left atrium upon contraction of the left ventricle.
name: Mitral valve prolapse

desc: Myxomatous mitral valve is defined as the presence of excess leaflet tissue and leaflet thickening greater than 5 mm, resulting in a prolapse greater than 2 mm into the left atrium on parasternal long axis view.
name: Myxomatous mitral valve degeneration

desc: A congenital defect with failure to open of the mitral valve orifice.
name: Mitral atresia

desc: Anomalous mitral valve arcade is diagnosed based on the following features (1) An adequately sized mitral valve orifice; (2) short, thick, and poorly differentiated chordae with direct union of the papillary muscles to the anterior leaflet; (3) narrow or nearly nonexistent spaces between the abnormal chordae; and (4) greater differentiation of the chordae attached to the posterior papillary muscle.
name: Mitral valve arcade

desc: The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue.
name: Double orifice mitral valve

desc: A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve.
name: Supramitral ring

desc: A structural anomaly of the chordae tendinae of the mitral valve, whose main function is to transmit the contraction and relaxation of the papillary muscles during the cardiac cycle, thus ensuring the closing of the leaflets of the mitral valve.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the chordae tendinae of the mitral valve
name: Abnormal morphology of the chordae tendinae of the mitral valve

desc: Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles.
name: Parachute mitral valve

desc: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve.
layperson: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
name: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve

desc: Abnormal increased in length of the chordae tendinae of the mitral valve.
layperson: Elongated chordae tendinae of the mitral valve
name: Elongated chordae tendinae of the mitral valve

desc: Any structural anomaly of the annulus of the mitral valve. The annulus is a ring composed of fibrous and myocardial tissue and is the structure onto which the cusps of the valve attach.
name: Abnormal mitral valve annulus morphology

desc: An increase in the diameter of the ring (annulus) of the mitral valve.
name: Dilatation of the mitral annulus

desc: Any structural anomaly of the leaflets (also known as cusps) of the mitral valve.
name: Abnormal mitral valve leaflet morphology

desc: Cleft in the anterior mitral valve leaflet not associated with an atrioventricular canal defect.
name: Cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet

desc: Any structural anomaly of the tricuspid valve.
name: Abnormal tricuspid valve morphology

desc: One or more of the leaflets (cusps) of the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium upon contraction of the right ventricle.
name: Tricuspid valve prolapse

desc: Ebstein's anomaly refers to an abnormally placed and deformed tricuspid valve characterized by apical displacement of the septal and posterior tricuspid valve leaflets, leading to atrialization of the right ventricle with a variable degree of malformation and displacement of the anterior leaflet.
layperson: Ebstein anomaly of the tricuspid valve
name: Ebstein anomaly of the tricuspid valve
synonyms: Ebstein's anomaly of the tricuspid valve

desc: Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.
name: Hypoplastic tricuspid valve

desc: A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.
name: Imperforate tricuspid valve

desc: Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
name: Tricuspid atresia

desc: A form of agenesis of the tricuspid valve in which (although the normal orifice between the right atrium and right ventricle exists) there is no tricuspid valvular tissue.
name: Unguarded tricuspid valve

desc: A congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
name: Dysplastic tricuspid valve

desc: Any structural anomaly of the annulus of the tricuspid valve. The annulus is a ring composed of fibrous and myocardial tissue and is the structure onto which the cusps of the valve attach.
name: Abnormal tricuspid valve annulus morphology

desc: An increase in the diameter of the ring (annulus) of the tricuspid valve.
name: Dilatation of the tricuspid annulus

desc: Any structural anomaly of the chordae tendinae of the tricuspid valve. The chordae tendineae connect the papillary muscles to the tricuspid valve.
name: Abnormal tricuspid chordae tendinae morphology

desc: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve.
layperson: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
name: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve

desc: Any structural anomaly of the leaflets (also known as cusps) of the tricuspid valve.
name: Abnormal tricuspid valve leaflet morphology

desc: An atrioventricular valve that has failed to open (atretic).
name: Imperforate atrioventricular valve

desc: An anomaly of the intra-atrial or intraventricular septum.
name: Abnormal cardiac septum morphology

desc: A defect of the atrioventricular septum of the heart.
name: Atrioventricular canal defect

desc: A congenital heart defect characteizred by a specific combination of heart defects with a common atrioventricular valve, primum atrial septal defect and inlet ventricular septal defect.
name: Complete atrioventricular canal defect

desc: An ostium primum atrial septal defect is located in the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum. The ostium primum refers to an anterior and inferior opening (ostium) within the septum primum, which divides the rudimentary atrium during fetal development. The ostium primum is normally sealed by fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions around 5 weeks' gestation. Ostium primum defects result from a failure of the fusion of the embryologic endocardial cushion and septum primum.
name: Primum atrial septal defect

desc: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and inlet ventricular defect. There is one valve annulus and two valve orifices.
name: Intermediate atrioventricular canal defect

desc: A specific combination of heart defects including a primum atrial septal defect and cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet. There is not an inlet ventricular septal defect present. There are two valve annuluses and two valve orifices.
name: Partial atrioventricular canal defect

desc: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and an inlet ventricular septal defect. There are two valve annuli and two valve orifices.
name: Transitional atrioventricular canal defect

desc: Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced).
name: Unbalanced atrioventricular canal defect

desc: A structural abnormality of the interventricular septum.
name: Abnormal ventricular septum morphology

desc: A hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.
layperson: Hole in heart wall separating two lower heart chambers
name: Ventricular septal defect
synonyms: Hole in heart wall separating two lower heart chambers

desc: A type of ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium. This is anatomically possible because the normal tricuspid valve is more apically displaced than the mitral valve.
name: Gerbode ventricular septal defect

desc: A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus.
name: Inlet ventricular septal defect
synonyms: Atrioventricular canal type ventricular septal defect

desc: The trabecular septum is the largest part of the interventricular septum. It extends from the membranous septum to the apex and superiorly to the infundibular septum. A defect in the trabecular septum is called muscular VSD if the defect is completely rimmed by muscle.
name: Muscular ventricular septal defect

desc: A muscular ventricular septal defect located at the apex of the heart.
name: Apical muscular ventricular septal defect

desc: A type of muscular ventricular septal defect characterized by the presence of multiple small defects in the ventricular septum.
name: Multiple muscular ventricular septal defects

desc: A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum.
name: Subarterial ventricular septal defect

desc: A ventricular septal defect that is confluent with and involves the membranous septum and is bordered by an atrioventricular valve, not including the type 3 VSDs.
name: Perimembranous ventricular septal defect

desc: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is small enough to restrict flow across it such that a pressure gradient exists between the two sides of the VSD.
name: Restrictive ventricular septal defect

desc: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that does not restrict flow across it sufficiently to generate a pressure gradient between the two sides of the VSD.
name: Non-restrictive ventricular septal defect

desc: The dividing wall between left and right sides of the heart, thickens and bulges into the left ventricle.
name: Ventricular septal hypertrophy

desc: A bowing (bulging to one side) of the interventricular septum of more than 15 mm on either side in adults and 5 mm in children during normal cardiac motion.
name: Ventricular septal aneurysm

desc: Bowing (bulging out) of the membranous part of the interventricular septum of more than 10-15 mm into the cavity of an adjacent ventricle (usually into the right ventricle).
name: Membranous ventricular septal aneurysm
synonyms: Aneurysm of the membranous ventricular septum

desc: Bowing (bulging out) of the muscular part of the interventricular septum of more than 10-15 mm into the cavity of an adjacent ventricle (usually into the right ventricle).
name: Muscular ventricular septal aneurysm
synonyms: Aneurysm of the muscular ventricular septum

desc: An abnormality of the interatrial septum.
name: Abnormal atrial septum morphology

desc: Atrial septal defect (ASD) is a congenital abnormality of the interatrial septum that enables blood flow between the left and right atria via the interatrial septum.
layperson: Hole in heart wall separating two upper heart chambers
name: Atrial septal defect
synonyms: Hole in heart wall separating two upper heart chambers
An opening in the wall separating the top two chambers of the heart

desc: Failure of the foramen ovale to seal postnatally, leaving a potential conduit between the left and right cardiac atria.
name: Patent foramen ovale

desc: A kind of atrial septum defect arising from an enlarged foramen ovale, inadequate growth of the septum secundum, or excessive absorption of the septum primum.
name: Secundum atrial septal defect
synonyms: Atrial septal defect, ostium secundum type

desc: An interatrial communication caused by a deficiency of the common wall between the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right-sided pulmonary veins. SVASD is commonly associated with anomalous pulmonary venous connection (APVC) of some or all of the pulmonary veins, which produces additional left-to-right shunting.
name: Sinus venosus atrial septal defect

desc: Multiple defects in the atrial septum.
name: Swiss cheese atrial septal defect

desc: Unroofed coronary sinus (CS) is a rare congenital cardiac anomaly in which there is partial (either focal or fenestrated) or complete absence of the roof of the CS, which results in a communication between the CS and the LA. Unroofed CS is the rarest type of atrial septal defect. It is often associated with persistent left superior vena cava (LSVC) and other forms of complex congenital heart disease, usually heterotaxia syndromes. The morphological types have been classified into 4 groups: Type I, completely unroofed with persistent LSVC; type II, completely unroofed without persistent LSVC; type III, partially unroofed mid portion; and type IV, partially unroofed terminal portion.
name: Unroofed coronary sinus

desc: A bulging of the interatrial septum towards one side. In adults, atrial septal aneurysm can be defined as a protrusion of the aneurysm of >10 mm beyond the plane of the atrial septum as measured by transesophageal echocardiography.
name: Atrial septal dilatation

desc: An abnormality of the pericardium, i.e., of the fluid filled sac that surrounds the heart and the proximal ends of the aorta, vena cava, and the pulmonary artery.
name: Abnormal pericardium morphology

desc: Accumulation of fluid within the pericardium.
name: Pericardial effusion

desc: Accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac.
name: Hemopericardium

desc: Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct.
name: Chylopericardium

desc: Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac.
name: Serous pericardial effusion

desc: Inflammation of the sac-like covering around the heart (pericardium).
layperson: Swelling or irritation of membrane around heart
name: Pericarditis
synonyms: Swelling or irritation of membrane around heart

desc: Presence of a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that forms a non-compliant shell around the heart, and resulting from chronic inflammation of the pericardium.
name: Constrictive pericarditis

desc: Compression of the heart caused by rigid, thickened, or fused pericardial membranes.
name: Pericardial constriction

desc: A developmental defect of the pericardium with congenital onset.
name: Congenital defect of the pericardium

desc: No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy.
name: Total absence of the pericardium

desc: No pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.
name: Complete diaphragmatic absence of pericardium

desc: No pericardium is present on the righthand side of the heart. It is a congenital absence of pericardium rather than the result of a pericardectomy.
layperson: Complete right sided absence of pericardium
name: Complete right sided absence of pericardium

desc: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the righthand side of the heart.
layperson: Partial right sided absence of pericardium
name: Partial right sided absence of pericardium

desc: A congenital anomaly with complete lack of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.
layperson: Absent lining around of left side of heart
name: Complete left sided absence of pericardium
synonyms: Absent lining around of left side of heart

desc: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.
layperson: Partial left sided absence of pericardium
name: Partial left sided absence of pericardium

desc: Lack of a part of the pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.
name: Partial diaphragmatic absence of pericardium

desc: A Malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pericardium (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the heart).
name: Pericardial mesothelioma

desc: An abnormality of a cardiac ventricle.
name: Abnormal cardiac ventricle morphology

desc: An abnormality of the right ventricle of the heart.
name: Abnormal right ventricle morphology

desc: Right-sided heart failure resulting from chronic hypertension in the pulmonary arteries and right ventricle.
name: Cor pulmonale

desc: In this case the right ventricle is more muscular than normal, causing a characteristic boot-shaped (coeur-en-sabot) appearance as seen on anterior- posterior chest x-rays. Right ventricular hypertrophy is commonly associated with any form of right ventricular outflow obstruction or pulmonary hypertension, which may in turn owe its origin to left-sided disease. The echocardiographic signs are thickening of the anterior right ventricular wall and the septum. Cavity size is usually normal, or slightly enlarged. In many cases there is associated volume overload present due to tricuspid regurgitation, in the absence of this, septal motion is normal.
name: Right ventricular hypertrophy

desc: Underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart right ventricle, often due to a reduced number of cells.
name: Hypoplasia of right ventricle

desc: Enlargement of the chamber of the right ventricle.
name: Right ventricular dilatation

desc: An accessory (not normally present) muscle bundle in the right ventricle which obstructs the right ventricular outflow tract.
layperson: Anomalous muscle bundle of the right ventricle
name: Anomalous muscle bundle of the right ventricle

desc: Any structural abnormality of the left ventricle of the heart.
name: Abnormal left ventricle morphology

desc: Enlargement or increased size of the heart left ventricle.
name: Left ventricular hypertrophy

desc: An abnormality of the outflow tract of the left ventricle.
layperson: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology
name: Abnormal left ventricular outflow tract morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of the left ventricular outflow tract

desc: A fixed form of obstruction to blood flow across the left-ventricular outflow tract related to stenosis (narrowing) below the level of the aortic valve.
layperson: Narrowing of blood vessel below aortic heart valve
name: Subvalvular aortic stenosis
synonyms: Narrowing of blood vessel below aortic heart valve

desc: A type of subvalvular aortic stenosis resulting from thickening of the musculature of the interventricular septum, which results in obstruction to blood flow through the left-ventricular outflow tract.
name: Muscular subvalvular aortic stenosis

desc: Subvalvular stenosis is caused by a diaphragm-like membrane. The stenosis is clinically manifested like any other form of aortic stenosis but is often associated with some aortic insufficiency.
name: Membranous subvalvular aortic stenosis

desc: A localized hypertrophy of the subaortic segment of the ventricular septum has been frequently described in elderly persons, and variously termed subaortic ventricular septal bulge (VSB), sigmoid-shaped septum, localized or discrete upper septal hypertrophy.
name: Subaortic ventricular septal bulge

desc: A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.
name: Double outlet left ventricle

desc: Any structural anomaly of the papillary muscles of the left ventricle.
layperson: Morphological abnormality of the papillary muscles
name: Morphological abnormality of the papillary muscles

desc: A congenital malformation in which one or both of the papillary muscles (posteromedial or anterolateral) insert directly (that is, without interpositioned chordae tendineae) into the anterior mitral leaflet.
layperson: Anomalous insertion of papillary muscle directly into anterior mitral leaflet
name: Anomalous insertion of papillary muscle directly into anterior mitral leaflet

desc: Abnormal location of the insertion of a papillary muscle into the left ventricular wall.
name: Displacement of the papillary muscles

desc: Abnormally anterior location of the papillary muscles of the left ventricle.
layperson: Anterior displacement of the papillary muscles
name: Anterior displacement of the papillary muscles

desc: Abnormal location of the insertion of the anterolateral papillary muscle near to the apex of the left ventricle. This feature may be appreciated by noting that this muscle is usually not seen in the apical level of the parasternal short-axis echocardiographic view,
name: Apically displaced anterolateral papillary muscle

desc: Enlargement of the cardiac ventricular muscle tissue with increase in the width of the wall of the ventricle and loss of elasticity. Ventricular hypertrophy is clinically differentiated into left and right ventricular hypertrophy.
name: Ventricular hypertrophy

desc: Thickening of the heart walls in both ventricles.
name: Biventricular hypertrophy

desc: The presence of only one working lower chamber in the heart, usually with a virtual absence of the ventricular septum and usually present in conjunction with double inlet left or right ventricle.
name: Single ventricle

desc: The condition in which both atria are joined to the left ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually there is a hypoplastic right ventricle, which may be on the opposite side of the heart as usual.
name: Double inlet left ventricle

desc: The condition in which both atria are joined to the right ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. Usually, the left ventricle is hypoplastic.
name: Double inlet right ventricle

desc: The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve. The morphology of this ventricle does not allow one to determine if it corresponds to the left or right ventricle.
layperson: Double inlet to single ventricle of indeterminate morphology
name: Double inlet to single ventricle of indeterminate morphology

layperson: Double inlet to single ventricle with common atrioventricular orifice
name: Double inlet to single ventricle with common atrioventricular orifice

layperson: Double inlet to single ventricle with two atrioventricular valves
name: Double inlet to single ventricle with two atrioventricular valves

desc: Steatosis in the myocardium.
name: Myocardial steatosis

desc: A cardiac diverticulum is a rare congenital malformation which is either fibrous or muscular.
name: Cardiac diverticulum

desc: Underdevelopment of the left side of the heart. May include atresia of the aortic or mitral orifice and hypoplasia of the ascending aorta.
name: Hypoplastic left heart

desc: Underdevelopment of the right-sided structures of the heart.
name: Hypoplastic right heart

desc: An abnormality of the endocardium.
name: Abnormal endocardium morphology

desc: Diffuse thickening of the ventricular endocardium and by associated myocardial dysfunction
name: Endocardial fibroelastosis

desc: The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium.
name: Endocardial fibrosis

desc: An inflammation of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
name: Endocarditis

desc: A bacterial infection of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
name: Bacterial endocarditis

desc: Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve.
name: Libman-Sacks lesions

desc: Thickening of the left ventricle wall with congenital onset.
layperson: Abnormal anatomic location of the heart
name: Abnormal anatomic location of the heart

desc: The heart is located in the right hand sided hemithorax. That is, there is a left-right reversal (or "mirror reflection") of the anatomical location of the heart in which the heart is locate on the right side instead of the left.
layperson: Heart tip and four chambers point towards right side of body
name: Dextrocardia
synonyms: Heart tip and four chambers point towards right side of body

desc: A left-right reversal (or "mirror reflection") of the anatomical location of the major thoracic and abdominal organs.
layperson: All organs on wrong side of body
name: Situs inversus totalis
synonyms: All organs on wrong side of body

desc: Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and through the defect in the ventral wall.
name: Ectopia cordis

desc: Displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and into the abdomen.
name: Abdominal ectopia cordis

desc: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region and without a defect of the sternum.
name: Cervical ectopia cordis

desc: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region with a defect of the superior portion of the sternum.
name: Thoracocervical ectopia cordis

desc: Congenital malformation of the thoracic wall with partial or total displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity. This feature is associated with sternal cleft or absence of the sternum.
name: Thoracic ectopia cordis

desc: Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and displacement partially into the abdominal cavity.
name: Thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis

desc: Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.
name: Mesocardia

desc: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex. Left sided is normal.
name: Abnormal direction of ventricular apex

desc: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex towards the right. Left sided is normal.
name: Rightward direction of ventricular apex

desc: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex in the midline. Left sided is normal.
name: Midline direction of ventricular apex

desc: Any structural abnormality of a cardiac atrium.
name: Abnormal cardiac atrium morphology

desc: The presence of an additional membrane in the left or right cardiac atrium which results in the subdivision of the affected atrium (and thus in total three atria, whence the name).
name: Cor triatriatum

desc: A congenital anomaly with partitioning of the right atrium to form a triatrial heart caused by persistence of the right valve of the sinus venosus. Typically, the right atrial partition is due to exaggerated fetal eustachian and thebesian valves, which together form an incomplete septum across the lower part of the atrium. This septum may range from a reticulum to a substantial sheet of tissue.
name: Cor triatriatum dexter

desc: A developmental anomaly of the heart characterized by the presence of three atria because the left atrium is divided by an abnormal septum.
name: Cor triatrium sinister

desc: Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the atria to other components of the heart.
name: Abnormal atrial arrangement

desc: Mirror image atrial arrangement, with morphologic right atrium on the left hand side and morphologic left atrium on the right hand side.
name: Atrial situs inversus

desc: Common atrium without defining morphologic features.
name: Atrial situs ambiguous

desc: Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections.
name: Common atrium

desc: An abnormality of the coronary sinus, which is formed by the union of the great cardiac vein and the left marginal vein and terminates in the right atrium. The coronary sinus functions to o collect deoxygenated blood from the myocardium of the heart and drain it into the right atrium.
name: Abnormal coronary sinus morphology

desc: An atrial septal defect characterized by a deficiency in the tissue separating the coronary sinus from the left atrium (LA). This results in partial or complete unroofing of the coronary sinus leading to a predominantly left-to-right shunt through the coronary sinus (LA to coronary sinus to right atrium [RA]). The orifice of the ostium is frequently large because of the increased flow. From the RA side, the defect is located at the level of the coronary sinus ostium and may also include some deficiency in atrial tissue around the ostium. From the LA side, the size can be variable depending on the degree of unroofing of the coronary sinus.
name: Coronary sinus atrial septal defect

desc: A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus.
name: Coronary sinus diverticulum

desc: Abnormal increase in size of the coronary sinus.
name: Coronary sinus enlargement

desc: A developmental defect in which the coronary sinus fails to form.
name: Absent coronary sinus

desc: Any structural abnormality of the left atrium.
name: Abnormal left atrium morphology

desc: Underdeveloped, small left heart atrium
name: Hypoplastic left atrium

desc: Increase in size of the left atrium.
name: Left atrial enlargement

desc: Any structural abnormality of the right atrium.
name: Abnormal right atrium morphology

desc: Increase in size of the right atrium.
name: Right atrial enlargement

desc: Underdeveloped, small right heart atrium.
name: Hypoplastic right atrium

desc: An abnormal increase in the thickness of the atrial septum.
name: Atrial septal hypertrophy

desc: Abnormality of the spatial relationship of the cardiac segments to other components of the heart.
layperson: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments
name: Abnormal spatial orientation of the cardiac segments

desc: Crossing of the inflow streams of the two ventricles, due to an apparent twisting of the heart about its long axis.
name: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves

desc: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with a rare cardiac malformation characterized by the two ventricles lying one above the other instead of side by side.
layperson: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with superior-inferior ventricles
name: Criss-cross atrioventricular valves with superior-inferior ventricles

layperson: Superior-inferior ventricles without criss-cross atrioventricular valves
name: Superior-inferior ventricles without criss-cross atrioventricular valves

desc: Situs inversus of thoracic and abdominal viscera with the heart remaining normally situated on the left; usually associated with congenital cardiac abnormalities such as transposition of the great vessels and/or spleen defects including asplenia or polysplenia.
name: Situs inversus with levocardia

desc: A deviance in the normal connections between two cardiac segements.
layperson: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
name: Abnormal connection of the cardiac segments
synonyms: Discordant connection of the cardiac segments
Abnormal connexion of the cardiac segments

desc: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between atria and ventricles.
name: Abnormal atrioventricular connection

desc: A defect where there is no connection between the left atrium and left ventricle.
name: Absent left sided atrioventricular connection

layperson: Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connection
name: Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connection
synonyms: Univentricular heart with absent left sided atrioventricular connexion

layperson: Biventricular heart with straddling right sided atrioventricular valve and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
name: Biventricular heart with straddling right sided atrioventricular valve and absent left sided atrioventricular connection

layperson: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
name: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connection
synonyms: Right sided atrium to left ventricle and absent left sided atrioventricular connexion

desc: A defect where there is no connection between the right atrium and right ventricle.
name: Absent right sided atrioventricular connection

desc: With left or right cardiac isomerism in a biventricular, the atrioventricular connections are perforce ambiguous, in that one of the connections is concordant (e.g., right-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic right ventricle) and one of the connections is discordant (e.g., left-sided morphologic right atrium connected to a morphologic left ventricle).
name: Ambiguous atrioventricular connection

desc: Connection of the right atrium to the left ventricle and of the left atrium to the right ventricle in a biventricular heart.
name: Discordant atrioventricular connection

desc: The condition in which both atria are joined to a single ventricle each by its own atrioventricular valve.
name: Double inlet atrioventricular connection

desc: An atrioventricular valve that empties into both ventricles. The valve overrides the interventricular septum above a ventricular septum defect.
name: Overriding atrioventricular valve

desc: Anomalous insertion of the chordae tendinae or papillary muscles into the contralateral ventricle in the presence of a ventricular septum defect.
name: Straddling atrioventricular valve

desc: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between the ventricles and the pulmonary artery and aorta.
name: Abnormal ventriculoarterial connection

desc: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the right heart identifiable at birth.
layperson: Congenital malformation of the right heart
name: Congenital malformation of the right heart

desc: Uhl anomaly of the right ventricle refers to the almost complete absence of right ventricular myocardium, normal tricuspid valve, and preserved septal and left ventricular myocardium.
name: Uhl's anomaly

desc: Any structural anomaly of cardiomyocytes, which are terminally differentiated muscle cells in the heart that are interconnected end to end by gap junctions, which allows coordinated contraction of heart tissue.
name: Abnormal cardiomyocyte morphology

desc: An abnormal increase in the volume of cardiac myocytes.
name: Cardiomyocyte hypertrophy

desc: An abnormal increase in the number of mitochondria per cardiac myocyte.
name: Cardiomyocyte mitochondrial proliferation

desc: Deterioration of cardiomyocyte characterized by abnormal features such as loss of myofilaments, occurrence of cellular sequestration, decreased mitochondrial sizes and cellular debris.
name: Cardiomyocyte degeneration

desc: A disruption of the structure of the sarcomeres of cardiomyocytes. The sarcomere is the repeating unit between two Z lines comprised largely of myosin and actin that mediates contractility, and normally sarcomeres are aligned with the long axis of cells, with the Z bands being in register throughout the length of the cardiac myocytes.
name: Myocardial sarcomeric disarray

desc: Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of stainable substances within cardiomyocytes.
name: Cardiomyocyte inclusion bodies

desc: An anomaly of the structure of mitochondria within cardiomyocytes.
name: Abnormal cardiomyocyte mitochondrial morphology

desc: Abnormal localization of mitochondria within the nuclei of cardiomyocytes.
name: Intranuclear cardiomyocyte mitochondria

desc: Anomalous staining of Connexin43 in cardiomyocytes. Connexin43 (Cx43) is the primary gap junction protein in the working myocardium. Cx43 exhibits increased localization at the lateral membranes of cardiomyocytes in a variety of heart diseases.
name: Abnormal cardiomyocyte connexin43 staining

desc: Anomalous staining of plakoglobin in cardiomyocytes. Plakoglobin is a component of desmosomes in cardiomyocytes.
name: Abnormal cardiomyocyte plakoglobin staining

desc: Anomalous staining of dystrophin in cardiomyocytes.
name: Abnormal cadiomyocyte dystrophin staining

desc: Abnormal structure of the bulbus cordis, which is the single outflow tract of the heart during early embryogenesis.
name: Abnormal bulbus cordis morphology

desc: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the left heart identifiable at birth.
layperson: Congenital malformation of the left heart
name: Congenital malformation of the left heart

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the heart.
name: Neoplasm of the heart

desc: A benign tumor of cardiac striated muscle.
name: Cardiac rhabdomyoma

desc: A fibroma of the heart.
name: Cardiac fibroma

desc: A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origina and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber.
name: Cardiac myxoma

desc: A malignant soft tissue neoplasm that arises from the heart.
name: Cardiac sarcoma

desc: A non-neoplastic cardiac tumor characterized by calcification and eosinophilic amorphous material in the background of dense collagenous fibrous tissue.
layperson: Calcified amorphous tumor of the heart
name: Calcified amorphous tumor of the heart
synonyms: Calcified amorphous tumour of the heart

desc: Abnormal test result of cardiovascular physiology.
name: Abnormal cardiac test

desc: Abnormal results of a MRI for the heart.
name: Abnormal cardiac MRI

desc: Abnormal results from the diagnostic tests resulting from cardiac catheterization.
name: Abnormal cardiac catheterization

desc: Abnormal results of exercise on heart function.
name: Abnormal cardiac exercise stress test

desc: Resting energy expenditure (REE) can be measured with indirect calorimetry using a metabolic cart, which is used to measure the oxygen consumption (VO2) and carbon dioxide production (VCO2).
layperson: Abnormal resting energy expenditure from metabolic cart test
name: Abnormal resting energy expenditure from metabolic cart test

desc: Abnormal blood test results measuring creatine kinase (CK), CK-MB, troponin (TROPI), myoglobin, and/or cardiac enzymes.
name: Abnormal cardiac biomarker test

desc: An increased concentration of tropnin I in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
layperson: Increased troponin I level in blood
name: Increased troponin I level in blood

desc: An increased concentration of tropnin T in the blood, which is a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin. Raised cardiac troponin concentrations are now accepted as the standard biochemical marker for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction.
layperson: Increased troponin T level in blood
name: Increased troponin T level in blood

desc: An abnormality of the hematopoietic system.
layperson: Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues
name: Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues
synonyms: Abnormality of blood and blood-forming tissues

desc: An abnormality of platelets.
name: Abnormal thrombocyte morphology

desc: Any anomaly in the function of thrombocytes.
name: Abnormal platelet function

desc: An abnormality of adhesion of thrombocytes. Normally, platelets adhere to collagen in the vascular subendothelium within seconds of injury via a receptor made up of glycoprotein Ia and IIa and GPVI and to vWF via receptor GPIb/IX/V. The adherent platelets then release granules that lead to platelet activation and aggregation.
name: Impaired platelet adhesion

desc: Presence of reduced amount of a membrane protein on the cell membrane of platelets. This feature is typically measured by flow cytometry.
name: Abnormal platelet membrane protein expression

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of glycoprotein IIb-IIIa.
name: Decreased platelet glycoprotein IIb-IIIa
synonyms: Reduced level of platelet glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of the glycoprotein complex Ib-IX-V.
name: Decreased platelet glycoprotein Ib-IX-V

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of glycoprotein VI.
name: Decreased platelet glycoprotein VI

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of P2Y12 receptor.
name: Decreased platelet P2Y12 receptor

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of thromboxane A2 receptor that is stimulated by thromboxane A2 (TBXA2).
name: Decreased platelet thromboxane A2 receptor

desc: Decreased cell membrane concentration of alpha-2A adrenergic receptor that is stimulated by epinephrine.
name: Decreased platelet alpha-2A-adrenergic receptor

desc: Decreased platelet cell membrane concentration of glycoprotein Ib.
name: Decreased platelet glycoprotein Ib

desc: Platelets are replete with secretory granules, which are critical to normal platelet function. Among the three types of platelet secretory granules - alpha-granules, dense granules, and lysosomes - the alpha-granule is the most abundant. Granule contents must be released from their intracellular repository in order to achieve their physiologic function, and this term refers to a functional defect in granule secretion.
name: Abnormal platelet granule secretion

desc: Abnormal release of dense granules from platelets.
name: Abnormal platelet dense granule secretion

desc: Abnormal secretion of the platelet dense-granule content adenosine triphosphate (ATP).
layperson: Abnormal platelet ATP dense granule secretion
name: Abnormal platelet ATP dense granule secretion

desc: Abnormal release of alpha granule contents from platelets.
name: Abnormal platelet alpha granule secretion

desc: Abnormal release of lysosome contents from platelets.
name: Abnormal platelet lysosome secretion

desc: An abnormality in the rate and degree to which platelets aggregate after the addition of an agonist that stimulates platelet clumping. Platelet aggregation is measured using aggregometer to measure the optical density of platelet-rich plasma, whereby platelet aggregation causes the plasma to become more transparent.
name: Abnormal platelet aggregation

desc: An impairment in the rate and degree to which platelets aggregate after the addition of an agonist that stimulates platelet clumping. Platelet aggregation is measured using aggregometer to measure the optical density of platelet-rich plasma, whereby platelet aggregation causes the plasma to become more transparent.
name: Impaired platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal platelet response to ADP as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ADP.
name: Impaired ADP-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to epinephrine as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of epinephrine.
name: Impaired epinephrine-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to collagen or collagen-mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition collagen or collagen-mimetics.
name: Impaired collagen-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to arachidonic acid as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of arachidonic acid.
name: Impaired arachidonic acid-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ristocetin.
name: Impaired ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to thrombin or thrombin mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thrombin (or thrombin mimetics).
name: Impaired thrombin-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to thromboxane as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thromboxane A2 receptor agonists.
layperson: Impaired thromboxane A2 agonist-induced platelet aggregation
name: Impaired thromboxane A2 agonist-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to convulxin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of convulxin.
name: Impaired convulxin-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to collagen-related peptide (CRP) as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of CRP.
name: Impaired collagen-related peptide-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to phorbol myristate acetate (PMA) as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of PMA.
layperson: Impaired phorbol myristate acetate-induced platelet aggregation
name: Impaired phorbol myristate acetate-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Abnormal response to calcium Ionophore (such as A23187) as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of the ionophore.
name: Impaired calcium ionophore-induced platelet aggregation

desc: Clumping together of platelets in the blood in a platelet aggregation test without addition of agents normally used to induce aggregation.
name: Spontaneous platelet aggregation

desc: Increased platelet agglutination in response to low-dose ristocetin
name: Increased RIPA

desc: Platelets contain contractile proteins (actin and myosin) that induce clot retraction. As the platelets contract, they pull on the surrounding fibrin strands, squeezing serum form the mass, compacting the clot and drawing the ruptured edges of the blood vessel more closely together. Clot retraction is directly proportional to the platelet count and inversely proportional to the fibrinogen concentration.
name: Impaired clot retraction

desc: An abnormality of phosphatidylserine (PS) on activated platelets. PS is normally located on the cytoplasmic face of the resting platelet membrane but appears on the plasma-oriented surface of discrete membrane vesicles that derive from activated platelets. Thrombin, the central molecule of coagulation, is produced from prothrombin by a complex (prothrombinase) between factor Xa and its protein cofactor (factor V(a)) that forms on platelet-derived membranes. This complex enhances the rate of activation of prothrombin to thrombin by roughly 150,000 fold relative to factor X(a) in solution. The negatively charged surface of PS-containing platelet-derived membranes is at least partly responsible for this rate enhancement.
name: Abnormal platelet phosphatidylserine exposure

desc: Reduced binding of annexin V to platelet membrane, which is mediated by exposed phosphatidylserine. This can be measured by flow cytometry.
layperson: Impaired annexin V binding to platelet phosphatidylserine
name: Impaired annexin V binding to platelet phosphatidylserine

desc: Elevated binding of annexin V to platelet membrane, which is mediated by exposed phosphatidylserine. This can be measured by flow cytometry.
layperson: Increased annexin V binding to platelet phosphatidylserine
name: Increased annexin V binding to platelet phosphatidylserine

desc: Abnormal number of platelets per volume of blood. In a healthy adult, a normal platelet count is between 150,000 and 450,000 per microliter of blood.
name: Abnormal platelet count

desc: A reduction in the number of circulating thrombocytes.
name: Thrombocytopenia

desc: Thrombocytopenia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital thrombocytopenia

desc: The presence of thrombocytopenia in combination with detection of antiplatelet antibodies.
name: Autoimmune thrombocytopenia

desc: Low platelet count associated with maternal platelet-specific alloantibodies.
name: Neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia

desc: Sudden onset of thrombocytopenia (reduced platelet count) within 5-10 days of the transfusion of blood products. The clinical presentation is post-transfusion purpura (PTP), wigth severe thrmbocytopenia, epistaxis, and hemorrhages.
name: Post-transfusion thrombocytopenia

desc: Reduced platelet count that occurs sporadically, i.e., it comes and goes.
name: Intermittent thrombocytopenia

desc: Thrombocytopenia related to lack of or severe reduction in the count of megakaryocytes.
name: Amegakaryocytic thrombocytopenia

desc: Low platelet count following administration of unfractionated or (less commonly) low-molecular weight heparin.
name: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia

desc: Increased numbers of platelets in the peripheral blood.
layperson: Increased number of platelets in blood
name: Thrombocytosis
synonyms: Increased number of platelets in blood

desc: An anomaly in platelet form, ultrastructure, or intracellular organelles.
name: Abnormal platelet morphology

desc: An anomaly of alpha or dense granules or platelet lysosomes.
name: Abnormal platelet granules

desc: Defective structure, size or content of alpha granules, platelet organelles that contain several growth factors destined for release during platelet activation at sites of vessel wall injury.
name: Abnormal alpha granules

desc: An anomalous location and arrangement of platelet alpha granules.
name: Abnormal alpha granule distribution

desc: A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain hemostatic proteins such as fibrinogen, von Willebrand factor, and growth factors such as platelet-derived growth factor.
name: Abnormal alpha granule content

desc: A deviation from the normal count of alpha granules per thrombocyte.
name: Abnormal number of alpha granules

desc: A lack of platelet alpha granules. This typically results in the grey appearance of platelets in giemsa stained blood smears.
name: Absence of alpha granules

desc: Defective structure, size or content of dense granules, platelet organelles that contain granules proaggregatory factors such as adenosine diphosphate (ADP), adenosine triphosphate (ATP), ionized calcium , histamine and serotonin.
name: Abnormal dense granules

desc: A deviation from the normal contents of the platelet alpha granules, which normally contain adenosine triphosphate (ATP), adenosine diphosphate (ADP), serotonin, calcium, and pyrophosphate, which are secreted when platelets are activated.
name: Abnormal dense granule content

desc: A deviation from the normal count of dense granules per thrombocyte.
name: Abnormal number of dense granules

desc: Deviation from normal of the ratio of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) within platelets.
layperson: Abnormal platelet dense granule ATP/ADP ratio
name: Abnormal platelet dense granule ATP/ADP ratio

desc: An anomaly of the invaginations of the surface membrane that form the open canalicular system (OCS). The OCS serve as the pathway for transport of substances into the cells and as conduits for the discharge of alpha granule products secreted during the platelet release reaction.
name: Abnormal surface-connected open canalicular system

desc: An anomaly of the intracellular membrane complexes known as the dense tubular system.
name: Abnormal dense tubular system

desc: A deviation from the normal discoid platelet shape.
name: Abnormal platelet shape

desc: Abnormally increased variability in the size of platelets.
name: Platelet anisocytosis

desc: Anomalous size of platelets. Most normal sized platelets are 1.5 to 3 micrometers in diameter. Large platelets are 4 to 7 micrometers. Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers.
name: Abnormal platelet volume

desc: Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval.
name: Decreased mean platelet volume

desc: Average platelet volume above the upper limit of the normal reference interval.
name: Increased mean platelet volume

desc: Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers. The term giant platelet is used when the platelet is larger than the size of the average red cell in the field. (Description adapted from College of American Pathologists, Hematology Manual, 1998).
name: Giant platelets

desc: Any structural abnormality of erythrocytes (red-blood cells).
name: Abnormal erythrocyte morphology

desc: Polycythemia is diagnosed if the red blood cell count, the hemoglobin level, and the red blood cell volume all exceed the upper limits of normal.
name: Polycythemia

desc: The presence of an increased mass of red blood cells in the circulation.
name: Increased red blood cell mass

desc: A reduction in erythrocytes volume or hemoglobin concentration.
layperson: Low number of red blood cells or hemoglobin
name: Anemia
synonyms: Low number of red blood cells or hemoglobin

desc: A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation.
name: Transient erythroblastopenia
synonyms: Transient decrease in blood erythrocyte number

desc: A kind of anemia characterized by inadequate production of erythrocytes.
name: Anemia of inadequate production

desc: A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is normal.
name: Normocytic anemia

desc: Anemia with varying degrees of erythrocytic hypoplasia without leukopenia or thrombocytopenia.
name: Hypoplastic anemia

desc: A type of hypoplastic anemia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital hypoplastic anemia

desc: A type of hypoplastic anemia in which the erythrocytes have a normal cell volume (the mean corpuscular volume is within normal limits).
name: Normocytic hypoplastic anemia

desc: Sideroblastic anemia results from a defect in the incorporation of iron into the heme molecule. A sideroblast is an erythroblast that has stainable deposits of iron in cytoplasm (this can be demonstrated by Prussian blue staining).
name: Sideroblastic anemia

desc: A type of sideroblastic anemia that is not responsive to treatment.
name: Refractory sideroblastic anemia

desc: A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment.
name: Pyridoxine-responsive sideroblastic anemia

desc: A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes.
name: Hypochromic anemia

desc: A type of anemia characterized by an abnormally low concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.
name: Hypochromic microcytic anemia

desc: A kind of anemia in which the volume of the red blood cells is reduced.
name: Microcytic anemia

desc: A type of anemia characterized by an normal concentration of hemoglobin in the erythrocytes and lower than normal size of the erythrocytes.
name: Normochromic microcytic anemia

desc: A type of anemia characterized by increased size of erythrocytes with increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH).
name: Macrocytic anemia

desc: Anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal (megaloblasts).
name: Megaloblastic anemia

desc: A type of megaloblastic anemia that improves upon administration of pyrimidine supplements such as uridylic acid and cytidylic acid.
name: Pyrimidine-responsive megaloblastic anemia
synonyms: Anemia corrected by uridylic acid and cytidylic acid

desc: A type of megaloblastic anemia that does not improve upon administration of folate. Since vitamin B12 acts by promoting recycling of folate, administration of vitamin B12 also does not improve this type of anemia.
name: Folate-unresponsive megaloblastic anemia

desc: A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of folate.
name: Folate-responsive megaloblastic anemia

desc: A type of megaloblastic anemia (i.e., anemia characterized by the presence of erythroblasts that are larger than normal) that improves upon the administration of thiamine.
name: Thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia

desc: A type of anemia characterized by abnormally large erythrocytes with abnormally high amounts of haemoglobin.
name: Hyperchromic macrocytic anemia

desc: A type of anemia related to a reduction in the average life span of red blood cells in the peripheral circulation, which is normally around 120 days.
layperson: Anemia due to reduced life span of red cells
name: Anemia due to reduced life span of red cells
synonyms: Anaemia due to reduced life span of red cells

desc: A type of anemia caused by premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis).
name: Hemolytic anemia

desc: An autoimmune form of hemolytic anemia.
name: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

desc: A form of hemolytic anemia that occurs in repeated episodes.
name: Episodic hemolytic anemia

desc: A form of hemolytic anemia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital hemolytic anemia

desc: A kind of hemolytic anemia that is induced by the ingestion of fava beans.
name: Fava bean-induced hemolytic anemia
synonyms: Hemolytic anemia following ingestion of fava beans

desc: A form of hemolytic anemia that is triggered by ingestion of certain drugs.
name: Drug-sensitive hemolytic anemia

desc: A type of hemolytic anemia in which the Coombs test is positive.
name: Coombs-positive hemolytic anemia

desc: An chronic form of hemolytic anemia.
name: Chronic hemolytic anemia

desc: Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.
name: Heinz body anemia

desc: A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion.
name: Exercise-induced hemolysis

layperson: Increased red cell hemolysis by shear stress
name: Increased red cell hemolysis by shear stress

desc: A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by cold temperatures.
name: Cold-induced hemolysis

desc: A qualitative impression that red blood cells have less color than normal when examined under a microscope, usually related to a reduced amount of hemoglobin in the red blood cells.
name: Hypochromia

desc: A reticulocyte abnormality.
name: Abnormal reticulocyte morphology

desc: A reduced number of reticulocytes in the peripheral blood.
name: Reticulocytopenia

desc: An elevation in the number of reticulocytes (immature erythrocytes) in the peripheral blood circulation.
layperson: Increased number of immature red blood cells
name: Reticulocytosis
synonyms: Increased number of immature red blood cells

desc: The presence of abnormally shaped erythrocytes.
name: Poikilocytosis

desc: Acanthocytosis is a type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence of spikes on the cell surface. The cells have an irregular shape resembling many-pointed stars.
name: Acanthocytosis

desc: The presence of an abnormal number of fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) in the blood.
name: Schistocytosis

desc: The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped.
name: Spherocytosis

desc: The presence of erythrocytes that are sphere-shaped and reduced in size.
name: Microspherocytosis

desc: The presence of elliptical, cigar-shaped erythrocytes on peripheral blood smear.
name: Elliptocytosis

desc: The presence of erythrocytes with a mouth-shaped (stoma) area of central pallor on peripheral blood smear.
name: Stomatocytosis

desc: A type of poikilocytosis characterized by the presence in the blood of erythrocytes of varying sizes and abnormal shapes.
name: Anisopoikilocytosis

desc: A form of severe hemolytic anemia characterized by erythrocyte morphology reminiscent of that seen in patients after a thermal burn.
name: Pyropoikilocytosis

desc: A form of poikilocytosis in which the abnormally shaped erythrocytes have notches that results in projections that look like horns.
name: Red blood cell keratocytosis
synonyms: Distorted red blood cells resembling keratocytes

desc: Red blood cells that appear to have parts of them bitten away.
name: Bite cells

desc: An irreversible distortion of the morphology of an erythrocyte such that the cells are elongated and curved, resembling the blade of a sickle (the hand-held agricultural tool traditionally used to harvest grains).
name: Sickled erythrocytes

desc: Presence of teardrop-shaped red blood cells.
name: Dacryocytosis

desc: Enlarged, oval-shaped erythrocytes (red blood cells).
name: Oval macrocytosis

desc: An abnormality of an erythrocyte cell surface molecule.
