name: Blood group antigen abnormality

desc: Absence of the Lutheran antigen (a type I integral membrane glycoprotein) from the surface of red blood cells.
layperson: Absence of Lutheran antigen on erythrocytes
name: Absence of Lutheran antigen on erythrocytes

desc: Abnormally increased variability in the size of erythrocytes.
layperson: Unequal size of red blood cells
name: Anisocytosis
synonyms: Unequal size of red blood cells

desc: Anomaly in the level or the function of hemoglobin, the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes.
name: Abnormal hemoglobin

desc: Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues.
name: Hemoglobin Barts

desc: Normal hemoglobin synthesis is characterized by production of equal amounts of alpha and beta globins. This term refers to a deviation from this pattern and is the main characteristic of the various forms of thalassemia.
name: Imbalanced hemoglobin synthesis

desc: A reduction in the ratio of production of beta globin to that of alpha globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of beta thalassemia.
name: Reduced beta/alpha synthesis ratio

desc: A reduction in the ratio of production of alpha globin to that of beta globin. This is the major abnormality in the various forms of alpha thalassemia.
name: Reduced alpha/beta synthesis ratio

desc: Hemoglobin H (HbH) contains four beta-globin chains. It is normally not present at all in blood, but may make up about 1-40 percent of all hemoglobin in HbH disease, a subform of alpha thalassemia.
name: HbH hemoglobin

desc: Hemoglobin F (HbF) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin gamma chains. It is the main form of hemoglobin in the fetus during the last seven months of intrauterine development and in the half year of postnatal life. In adults it normally makes up less than one percent of all hemoglobin. This term refers to an increase in HbF above this limit. In beta thalassemia major, it may represent over 90 percent of all hemoglobin, and in beta thalassemia minor it may make up between 0.5 to 4 percent.
name: Persistence of hemoglobin F

desc: Hemoglobin A (HbA) contains two globin alpha chains and two globin beta chains. HbA is normally the main adult hemoglobin, representing about 96-98 percent of all hemoglobin. This term represents a decreased in the proportion of HbA below this limit, and can be seen in various forms of thalassemia.
name: Reduced hemoglobin A

desc: Abnormally increased levels of methemoglobin in the blood. In this form of hemoglobin, there is an oxidized ferric iron (Fe +3) rather than the reduced ferrous form (Fe 2+) that is normally found in hemoglobin. Methemoglobin has a reduced affinity for oxygen, resulting in a reduced ability to release oxygen to tissues.
name: Methemoglobinemia

desc: Presence of an abnormal type of hemoglobin characterized by the subsitution of a glutamic acid residue at position 7 following the initial methionine residue by a lysine (6GAG>6AAG). The presence of HbC can be determined by hemoglobin electrophoresis.
name: HbC hemoglobin

desc: An increased concentration of hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), which is the product of nonenzymatic attachment of a hexose molecule to the N-terminal amino acid of the hemoglobin molecule. This reaction is dependent on blood glucose concentration, and therefore reflects the mean glucose concentration over the previous 8 to 12 weeks. The HbA1c level provides a better indication of long-term glycemic control than one-time blood or urinary glucose measurements.
name: Elevated hemoglobin A1c

desc: Presence of an abnormal type of hemoglobin characterized by the subsitution of a glutamic acid residue at position 7 following the initial methionine residue by a valine (the mutation causative of sickle cell disease). The mutation promotes the polymerization of the HbS under conditions of low oxygen concentration. HbS can be identified by multiple methodologies including hemoglobin electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography.
name: HbS hemoglobin

desc: An elevated concentration in the blood of hemoglobin A2 (HbA2), which is a normal variant of hemoglobin A that consists of two alpha and two delta chains and is normally present at low levels in adults but may be increased in beta thalassemia.
name: Increased HbA2 hemoglobin

desc: A deviation from the normal count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
name: Abnormal number of erythroid precursors

desc: Increased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
name: Erythroid hyperplasia
synonyms: Bone marrow smear shows erythroid hyperplasia
Bone marrow biopsy shows erythroid hyperplasia

name: Megaloblastic erythroid hyperplasia
synonyms: Bone marrow biopsy shows megaloblastic erythroid hyperplasia

desc: Decreased count of erythroid precursor cells, that is, erythroid lineage cells in the bone marrow.
name: Erythroid hypoplasia
synonyms: Erythroid hypoplasia in the bone marrow

desc: A type of anemia resulting from suppression of erythropoiesis with little or no abnormality of leukocyte or platelet production. Erythroblasts are virtually absent in bone marrow; however, leukocyte and platelet production show little or no reduction.
name: Pure red cell aplasia

desc: Any deviation from the normal number of red blood cells per volume in the circulation.
name: Abnormal red blood cell count

desc: An abnormal elevation above the normal number of red blood cells per volume in the circulation.
name: Increased red blood cell count

desc: An abnormal reduction below the normal number of red blood cells per volume in the circulation.
name: Decreased red blood cell count

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of hemoglobin in the blood.
name: Abnormal hemoglobin concentration

desc: An abnormal reduction below normal hemoglobin concentration in the circulation.
name: Decreased hemoglobin concentration

desc: An abnormal elevation above normal hemoglobin concentration in the circulation.
name: Increased hemoglobin concentration

desc: Nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of substances in red blood cells.
name: Erythrocyte inclusion bodies

desc: A type of erythrocyte inclusion characterized by basophilic stippling of erythrocytes, that is, by numerous very small coarse or fine blue granules within the cytoplasm with the additional stipulation that the stippled particles are due to iron granules (demonstrable by the Prussian blue stain).
name: Pappenheimer bodies

desc: A type of erythrocyte inclusion composed of denatured hemoglobin.
name: Heinz bodies

desc: Howell-Jolly bodies are small, intra-erythrocytic remnants of erythrocyte nuclei. These inclusions are solitary in each erythrocyte and strongly basophilic. These are often confused with overlying platelets, but can be distinguished by the presence of a halo around overlying platelets.
name: Howell-Jolly bodies

desc: A deviation from normal of the mean corpuscular volume, or mean cell volume (MCV) of red blood cells, usually taken to be 80 to 100 femtoliters.
name: Abnormal mean corpuscular volume

desc: Larger than normal size of erythrocytes.
name: Increased mean corpuscular volume

desc: A reduction from normal of the mean corpuscular volume, or mean cell volume (MCV) of red blood cells (usually defined as an MCV below 80 femtoliters).
name: Decreased mean corpuscular volume

desc: A deviation from the normal range of the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell (27 to 31 picograms/cell). A reduced mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) may indicate a hypochromic anemia, but the MCH may be normal if both the total hemoglobin and the red blood cell count are reduced.
name: Abnormal mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration

desc: A reduction from the normal range of the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell (27 to 31 picograms/cell). A reduced mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) may indicate a hypochromic anemia, but the MCH may be normal if both the total hemoglobin and the red blood cell count are reduced.
name: Decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration

desc: An elevation over the normal range of the average amount of hemoglobin per red blood cell (27 to 31 picograms/cell).
name: Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration

desc: This term refers to an inappropriate low 2,3-DPG concentration in erythrocytes. 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) controls the movement of oxygen from red blood cells to tissues. Anemia is usually accompanied by an increased level of 2,3-DPG in order to promote tissue oxygenation.
name: Reduced erythrocyte 2,3-diphosphoglycerate concentration

desc: An altered level of any enzyme to act as catalysts within erythrocytes. This term includes changes due to altered activity of an enzyme.
name: Abnormal erythrocyte enzyme level

desc: Decrease in the level of pyruvate kinase (PK) within erythrocytes. PK catalyzes the reaction: ATP + pyruvate = ADP + phosphoenolpyruvate.
layperson: Reduced red cell pyruvate kinase level
name: Reduced red cell pyruvate kinase level

desc: Increase in the level of adenosine deaminase (ADA), an enzyme involved in purine metabolism, within erythrocytes. ADA is involved in the catabolism of adenosine.
layperson: Elevated red cell adenosine deaminase level
name: Elevated red cell adenosine deaminase level

desc: Decrease in the level of adenosine deaminase (ADA), an enzyme involved in purine metabolism, within erythrocytes. ADA is involved in the catabolism of adenosine.
layperson: Reduced red cell adenosine deaminase level
name: Reduced red cell adenosine deaminase level

desc: Any deviation from the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.
name: Abnormal hematocrit

desc: An elevation above the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.
name: Increased hematocrit

desc: A reduction below the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.
name: Reduced hematocrit

desc: Increased amount of stacking of erythrocytes into long chains. Rouleaux (singular: rouleau) is derived from a French word that can refer to a stack of coins put into a cylindircal paper roll. Rouleaux formation is observed with increased serum proteins, particularly fibrinogen and globulins, and represents the cause of increased erythrocte sedimentation rate because rouleaux sediment more readily than isolated red blood cells.
name: Rouleaux formation

desc: Red blood cell distribution width (RDW) is a simple parameter of the standard full blood count and a measure of heterogeneity in the size of circulating erythrocytes. It is provided by automated hematology analyzers and it reflects the range of the red cell size. It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of erythrocyte volume by the mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and multiplied by 100 to convert to a percentage.
name: Increased RBC distribution width
synonyms: Increased red blood cell distribution width

desc: Burr cells, also known as echinocytes, have a speculated border over the entire cell surface. Burr cells are commonly found in both end-stage renal disease and liver disease. Small numbers of Burr cells are commonly found in healthy individuals.
name: Increased Burr cell count

desc: An abnormality of leukocytes.
name: Abnormal leukocyte morphology

desc: A cancer of the blood and bone marrow characterized by an abnormal proliferation of leukocytes.
name: Leukemia

desc: A clonal (malignant) hematopoietic disorder with an acute onset, affecting the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. The malignant cells show minimal differentiation and are called blasts, either myeloid blasts (myeloblasts) or lymphoid blasts (lymphoblasts).
name: Acute leukemia

desc: A form of leukemia characterized by overproduction of an early myeloid cell.
name: Acute myeloid leukemia

desc: An acute leukemia characterized by the proliferation of both neutrophil and monocyte precursors.
name: Acute myelomonocytic leukemia

desc: A type of acute myeloid leukemia in which abnormal promyelocytes predominate.
name: Acute promyelocytic leukemia

desc: The accumulation of transformed primitive hematopoietic blast cells, which lose their ability of normal differentiation and proliferation.
name: Acute monocytic leukemia

desc: A type of actue leukemia with features characteristic of both the myeloid and lymphoid lineages. These leukemias are for this reason are designated mixed-lineage, hybrid or biphenotypic acute leukemias.
name: Biphenotypic acute leukemia

desc: A form of acute leukemia characterized by excess lympoblasts.
name: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

desc: A type of ALL characterized by elevated levels of B-cell lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and the blood.
name: B Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

desc: A subset of acute lymphoblastic leukemia that results from a reciprocal translocation between the ABL-1 oncogene and a breakpoint cluster region (BCR), resulting in a fusion gene, BCR-ABL, that encodes an oncogenic protein with constitutively active tyrosine kinase activity.
name: Ph-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia

desc: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia of T-cell origin. It comprises about 15% of childhood cases and 25% of adult cases. It is more common in males than females.
name: T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemias

desc: A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts.
name: Acute megakaryocytic leukemia

desc: A malignant lymphocytic neoplasm of B-cell or T-cell lineage involving primarily the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. This category includes precursor or acute lymphoblastic leukemias and chronic leukemias.
name: Lymphoid leukemia

desc: A form of lymphoid leukemia or lymphoma in which too many T-cell lymphoblasts are found in the blood, bone marrow, and tissues. Leukemia or lymphoma classification depends on which feature is more prominent.
name: T cell chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/leukemia

desc: Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential.
name: Myeloproliferative disorder

desc: A unique clonal neoplastic disorder that is linked to trisomy 21, is restricted to neonatal period, and spontaneously regresses. It often has characteristics of megakaryocytic lineage and is associated with GATA1 mutations in myeloblasts.
name: Transient myeloproliferative syndrome

desc: A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.
name: Chronic leukemia

desc: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate.
name: Chronic myelogenous leukemia

desc: A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.
name: Chronic lymphatic leukemia

desc: A leukemia that originates from a myeloid cell, that is the blood forming cells of the bone marrow.
name: Myeloid leukemia

desc: Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is a lethal myeloproliferative disease of young childhood characterized clinically by overproduction of myelomonocytic cells and by the in vitro phenotype of hematopoietic progenitor hypersensitivity to granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor.
name: Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia

desc: A myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm which is characterized by persistent monocytosis, absence of a Philadelphia chromosome and BCR/ABL fusion gene, fewer than 20 percent blasts in the bone marrow and blood, myelodysplasia, and absence of PDGFRA or PDGFRB rearrangement.
name: Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia

desc: An abnormality of lymphocytes.
name: Abnormal lymphocyte morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of cells of the lymphoid lineage

desc: The presence of clear, sharply defined vacuoles in the lymphocyte cytoplasm.
name: Vacuolated lymphocytes

desc: An abnormality of T cells.
name: Abnormal T cell morphology

desc: A deviation from the normal count of T cells.
name: Abnormal T cell count

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion T cells subsets relative to the total number of T cells.
name: Abnormal T cell subset distribution

desc: An elevated proportion of T cells that express human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DR. HLA-DR is an MHC class II cell surface receptor that presents antigens (peptides of at least 9 amino acids), thereby constituting a ligand for the T-cell receptor. HLA-DR can be upregulated in response to immune stimulation.
layperson: Increased proportion of HLA DR+ T cells
name: Increased proportion of HLA DR+ T cells

desc: A deviation from the normal proportion of CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cells in circulation, relative to another population of cells.
layperson: Abnormal CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cell proportion
name: Abnormal CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cell proportion

desc: An abnormally increased proportion of CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cells in circulation, relative to another population of cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells
name: Increased proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells
Elevated proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells

desc: An abnormally decreased proportion of CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cells in circulation, relative to another population of cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of CD4+CD25+ Treg cells
Reduced proportion of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of central memory CD4+ T cells. These are memory cells that are located in the secondary lymphoid organs. These cells may have a CD3/CD4/CD62L+/CD45RA- phenotype.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD4+, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of effector memory CD4+ T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These are memory cells that are short-lived cells that migrate to the site of an infection and attempt to eliminate the pathogen. These cells have the phenotype CD3-positive, CD4-positive, CD62L-negative, CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD4+ effector memory cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD4+ effector memory cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive effector memory cells
Abnormal proportion of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally decreased proportion of effector memory CD4+ T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These are memory cells that are short-lived cells that migrate to the site of an infection and attempt to eliminate the pathogen. These cells have the phenotype CD3-positive, CD4-positive, CD62L-ngative, CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Reduced proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
name: Reduced proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
Decreased proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
Decreased proportion of CD4-positive effector memory T cells

desc: An abnormally increased proportion of effector memory CD4+ T cells. These are memory cells that are short-lived cells that migrate to the site of an infection and attempt to eliminate the pathogen. These cells may have a CD3/CD4/CD62L-/CD45RA phenotype.
layperson: Elevated proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
name: Elevated proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of CD4+ effector memory T cells
Increased proportion of CD4-positive effector memory T cells
Increased proportion of effector CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of CD4-positive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
Abnormal proportion of CD4+ T cells

desc: A reduction in the proportion of CD4-positive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An elevation in the proportion of CD4-positive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of CD4-positive T cells
name: Increased proportion of CD4-positive T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of CD4+ T cells
Elevated proportion of CD4-positive T cells
Increased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of CD8 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of CD8+ T cells
Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: A decreased proportion of circulating CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells relative to total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of CD8+ T cells
Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells
name: Absence of CD8-positive T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the relative amount of CD4+ and CD8+ T lymphocytes.
name: Abnormal CD4:CD8 ratio

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of naive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of naive T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of naive T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of naive thymus-derived, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally decreased proportion of naive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of naive T cells
name: Decreased proportion of naive T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of naive thymus-derived, alpha-beta T cells
Reduced proportion of naive T cells

desc: An abnormally reduced proportion of naive CD8 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of naive CD8 T cells
name: Decreased proportion of naive CD8 T cells
synonyms: Reduced proportion of naive CD8 T cells
Reduced proportion of naive thymus-derived CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally reduced proportion of naive CD4 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of naive CD4 T cells
name: Decreased proportion of naive CD4 T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
Reduced proportion of naive CD4 T cells

desc: An abnormally increased proportion of naive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of naive T cells
name: Increased proportion of naive T cells
synonyms: Elevated proportion of naive T cells
Increased proportion of naive thymus-derived, alpha-beta T cells

layperson: Increased proportion of naive CD4 T cells
name: Increased proportion of naive CD4 T cells
synonyms: Elevated proportion of naive CD4 T cells
Increased proportion of naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally increased proportion of naive CD8 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Increeased proportion of naive CD8 T cells
name: Increeased proportion of naive CD8 T cells
synonyms: Elevated proportion of naive CD8 T cells
Elevated proportion of naive thymus-derived CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of naive CD4 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of naive CD4 T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of naive CD4 T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of naive thymus-derived CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of naive CD8 T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of naive CD8 T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of naive CD8 T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative (double negative or DN) alpha-beta regulatory T cells (Tregs) as compared to total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of double-negative alpha-beta regulatory T cell
name: Abnormal proportion of double-negative alpha-beta regulatory T cell
synonyms: Abnormal double-negative alpha-beta regulatory T cell distribution
Abnormal CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cell distribution

desc: An abnormally increased proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative (double negative or DN) alpha-beta regulatory T cells (Tregs) as compared to total number of T cells.
layperson: Elevated proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cells
name: Elevated proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cells
synonyms: Increased number of CD4-/CD8- T cells expressing alpha/beta T-cell receptors

desc: An abnormally decreased proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative (double negative or DN) alpha-beta regulatory T cells (Tregs) as compared to total number of T cells.
layperson: Reduced proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cells
name: Reduced proportion of CD4-negative, CD8-negative, alpha-beta regulatory T cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of exhausted T cells (Tex) among circulating T cells. T cell exhaustion is a distinct differentiation state that can be distinguished from naive, effector, and memory T cells. Compared to effector (TE) and memory (TMEM) T cells, exhausted T cells (TEX) display impaired effector functions (e.g., rapid production of effector cytokines, cytotoxicity). TEX have limited proliferative potential, especially compared to some subsets of TMEM and naive T cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of exhausted T cells
name: Increased proportion of exhausted T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. Memory T cells have previously encountered and responded to their cognate antigen and upon a repeated encounter with the antigen can mount a faster and stronger response.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of memory T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of memory T cells

desc: An abnormally reduced proportion of memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood.
layperson: Decreased proportion of memory T cells
name: Decreased proportion of memory T cells

desc: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. A CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype is CD45RO and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: A reduced proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta central memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Decreased proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Decreased proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: A reduced proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta effector memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Decreased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Decreased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Decresaed proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: A reduced proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Decreased proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Decreased proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
synonyms: Reduced proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
Decreased proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
Decreased proportion of central memory CD4+, alpha-beta T cell
Decreased proportion of CD4-positive central memory cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood.
layperson: Increased proportion of memory T cells
name: Increased proportion of memory T cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Increased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Increased proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Increased proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Increased proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of central memory CD4+, alpha-beta T cell
Increased proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
Elevated proportion of CD4+ central memory cells
Elevated proportion central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Increased proportion of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Increased proportion of effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormally elevated proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CD45RO and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Increased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Increased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: An increased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Increased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Increased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An increased proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Increased proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Increased proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. A CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype is CD45RO and CD127-positive. This cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta effector memory RA TEMRA T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CD45RA-positive, CD45RO-negative, and CCR7-negative.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells, terminally differentiated

desc: An increased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta effector memory RA TEMRA T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CD45RA-positive, CD45RO-negative, and CCR7-negative.
layperson: Increased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
name: Increased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells, terminally differentiated

desc: An decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta effector memory RA TEMRA T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CD45RA-positive, CD45RO-negative, and CCR7-negative.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta TEMRA T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells, terminally differentiated

desc: An abnormal proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype of CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: An abnormal proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells compared to the total number of T cells in the blood. These cells have the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RA-negative, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

desc: Presence of a predominant T cell clone. In PCR-based assays, this finding is inferred on the basis of one or two prominent bands within a valid size range. In NGS-based assays, this finding is inferred on the basis of a high number of reads that map to a single T cell receptor clone.
name: Clonal T cell receptor rearrangement

desc: Abnormal proportion of helper T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
name: Abnormal helper T cell proportion
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of circulating T-helper cells

desc: Reduced proportion of helper T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
name: Decreased helper T cell proportion

desc: Increased proportion of helper T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
name: Increased helper T cell proportion

desc: An abnormal proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells

desc: A decreased proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells

desc: Abnormal proportion of gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of gamma-delta T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of gammadelta T cells
Abnormal proprotion of gamma-delta T lymphocytes

desc: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T cells
name: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of gamma-delta T lymphocytes
Elevated proportion of gamma-delta T cells
Increased proportion of gammadelta T cells

desc: Decreased proportion of gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of gamma-delta T cells
name: Decreased proportion of gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Reduced proportion of gamma-delta T cells
Decreased proportion of gammadelta T cells
Decreased proportion of gamma-delta T lymphocytes

desc: Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
name: Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T-cells
Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T-lymphocytes
Abnormal proportion of immature gamma-delta T lymphocytes

desc: Increased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
name: Increased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Elevated proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
Increased proportion of immature gamma-delta T-cells
Increased proportion of immature gamma-delat T lymphocytes
Increased proportion of immature gamma-delta T-lymphocytes

desc: Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
name: Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T-cells
Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T-lymphocytes
Decreased proportion of immature gamma-delta T lymphocytes
Reduced proportion of immature gamma-delta T cells

desc: Reduced level of T cell receptor excision circle (TRECs) as measured by the TREC assay. Late in maturation, 70% of thymocytes that will ultimately express alpha/beta-T cell receptors form a circular DNA TREC from the excised TCRdelta gene that lies within the TCRalpha genetic locus. The circles are stable but do not increase following cell division and, therefore, become diluted as T cells proliferate. A quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) reaction across the joint of the circular DNA provides the TREC copy number, a marker of newly-formed, antigenically-naÃ¯ve thymic emigrant T cells.
layperson: Abnormally low T cell receptor excision circle level
name: Abnormally low T cell receptor excision circle level

desc: An abnormal increase in the total number of T cells detected in the blood.
name: Increased T cell count

desc: A structuraly anomaly of T cells that express an alpha-beta T cell receptor.
name: Abnormal alpha-beta T cell morphology

desc: A structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta T cell. These cells are regulatory T cells.
layperson: Abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell morphology
name: Abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell morphology

desc: A deviation from the normal count of CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cells.
layperson: Abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell count
name: Abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell count

desc: Lack of CD4+CD25+ T regulatory cells.
layperson: Absence of CD4-positive, CD25-positive regulatory T cells
name: Absence of CD4-positive, CD25-positive regulatory T cells
synonyms: Absence of CD4+CD25+ T regulatory cells

desc: An increased number of CD4-positive, CD25-positive regulatory T cells.
layperson: Elevated CD4-positive, CD25-positive regulatory T cell count
name: Elevated CD4-positive, CD25-positive regulatory T cell count

desc: A structural abnormality of B cells.
name: Abnormal B cell morphology

desc: A deviation from the normal count of B cells, i.e., the cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells.
name: Abnormal B cell count

desc: An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells.
name: Increased B cell count

desc: A deviation in the normal proportion of naive B cells (CD19+/CD27-/IgD+/IgM+) relative to the total number of B cells. Naive B cells represent one of the subtypes of B cells in the peripheral blood, and are B cells that have not been exposed to antigen.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of naive B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of naive B cells

desc: An elevation above the normal proportion of naive B cells (CD19+/CD27-/IgD+/IgM+) relative to total number of B cells. Naive B cells represent one of the subtypes of B cells in the peripheral blood, and are B cells that have not been exposed to antigen.
layperson: Increased proportion of naive B cells
name: Increased proportion of naive B cells

desc: A reduction below normal proportion of naive B cells (CD19+/CD27-/IgD+/IgM+) relative to total number of B cells. Naive B cells represent one of the subtypes of B cells in the peripheral blood, and are B cells that have not been exposed to antigen.
layperson: Decreased proportion of naive B cells
name: Decreased proportion of naive B cells

desc: A deviation of the normal proportion of memory B cells in circulation relative to total number of B cells. Memory B cells develop from naive B cells. Upon antigen rechallenge, memory B cells rapidly expand and differentiate into plasma cells under the cognate control of memory Th cells (Phase IV).
layperson: Abnormal proportion of memory B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of memory B cells

desc: A reduction in the normal proportion of memory B cells (CD19+/CD27+) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. Memory B cells develop from naive B cells. Upon antigen rechallenge, memory B cells rapidly expand and differentiate into plasma cells under the cognate control of memory Th cells (Phase IV).
layperson: Decreased proportion of memory B cells
name: Decreased proportion of memory B cells

desc: An elevation in the proportion of memory B cells (CD19+/CD27+) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. Memory B cells develop from naive B cells. Upon antigen rechallenge, memory B cells rapidly expand and differentiate into plasma cells under the cognate control of memory Th cells (Phase IV).
layperson: Increased proportion of memory B cells
name: Increased proportion of memory B cells

desc: A deviation of the normal proportion of marginal zone B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM+/IgD+) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of marginal zone B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of marginal zone B cells

desc: A reduction in the normal proportion of marginal zone B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM+/IgD+) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of marginal zone B cells
name: Decreased proportion of marginal zone B cells

desc: An elevation in the normal proportion of marginal zone B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM+/IgD+) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of marginal zone B cells
name: Increased proportion of marginal zone B cells

desc: A deviation of the normal proportion of class-switched memory B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM-/IgD-) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. Marginal zone B cells undergo limited somatic hypermutation and produce high-affinity IgM and some IgG, whereas class-switched memory B cells synthetize IgG, IgM, and IgA.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of class-switched memory B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of class-switched memory B cells

desc: An increase in the normal proportion of class-switched memory B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM+/IgD+) relative to the total number of B cells. Marginal zone B cells undergo limited somatic hypermutation and produce high-affinity IgM and some IgG, whereas class-switched memory B cells synthetize IgG, IgM, and IgA.
layperson: Increased proportion of class-switched memory B cells
name: Increased proportion of class-switched memory B cells

desc: A reduction in the normal proportion of class-switched memory B cells (CD19+/CD27+/IgM+/IgD+) relative to the total number of B cells. Marginal zone B cells undergo limited somatic hypermutation and produce high-affinity IgM and some IgG, whereas class-switched memory B cells synthetize IgG, IgM, and IgA.
layperson: Decreased proportion of class-switched memory B cells
name: Decreased proportion of class-switched memory B cells

desc: A deviation of the normal proportion of unswitched memory B cells in circulation relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of unswitched memory B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of unswitched memory B cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of non-class-switched memory B cells

desc: An increase above the normal proportion of non-class-switched memory B cells relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of unswitched memory B cells
name: Increased proportion of unswitched memory B cells
synonyms: Elevated proportion of unswitched memory B cells
Increased proportion of non-class-switched memory B cells

desc: A reduction below the normal proportion of non-class-switched memory B cells relative to the total number of B cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of unswitched memory B cells
name: Decreased proportion of unswitched memory B cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of non-class-switched memory B cells
Reduced proportion of unswitched memory B cells

desc: A deviation from normal proportion immature B cells (CD19+/ CD21low) in circulation relative to total number of B cells. Immature B cells (IgM+) are still in final stages of development within the bone marrow. Naive B cells are those which have left the bone marrow, before they bind to the antigen for which they're specific (IgM+/IgD+).
layperson: Abnormal proportion of immature B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of immature B cells
synonyms: Abnormal proportion of CD19+/CD21low B cells

desc: An elevation in the proportion above normal of immature B cells (CD19+/ CD21low) in circulation relative to total number of B cells. Immature B cells (IgM+) are still in final stages of development within the bone marrow. Naive B cells are those which have left the bone marrow, before they bind to the antigen for which they're specific (IgM+/IgD+).
layperson: Increased proportion of immature B cells
name: Increased proportion of immature B cells
synonyms: Increased proportion of CD19+/CD21low B cells

desc: A reduction in normal proportion of immature B cells (CD19+/ CD21low)in circulation relative to total number of B cells. Immature B cells (IgM+) are still in final stages of development within the bone marrow. Naive B cells are those which have left the bone marrow, before they bind to the antigen for which they're specific (IgM+/IgD+).
layperson: Decreased proportion of immature B cells
name: Decreased proportion of immature B cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of CD19+/CD21low B cells

desc: A deviation in the normal proportion of transitional B cells (CD19+/CD38high/IgMhigh) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. B cells originate from precursors in the bone marrow, and the first cells which migrate to the peripheral blood have been classified as transitional B cells.
layperson: Abnormal proportion of transitional B cells
name: Abnormal proportion of transitional B cells

desc: A reduction in the normal proportion of transitional B cells (CD19+/CD38high/IgMhigh) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. B cells originate from precursors in the bone marrow, and the first cells which migrate to the peripheral blood have been classified as transitional B cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of transitional B cells
name: Decreased proportion of transitional B cells

desc: An elevation in the normal proportion of transitional B cells (CD19+/CD38high/IgMhigh) in circulation relative to the total number of B cells. B cells originate from precursors in the bone marrow, and the first cells which migrate to the peripheral blood have been classified as transitional B cells.
layperson: Increased proportion of transitional B cells
name: Increased proportion of transitional B cells

desc: A deviation from the normal proportion of plasmablasts in circulation relative to total number of B cells. Plasmablasts are antibody-secreting cells that originate after infection or vaccination.
name: Abnormal plasmablast proportion

desc: An elevation above the normal proportion of plasmablasts in circulation relative to total number of B cells.
name: Increased proportion of plasmablasts

desc: A reduction below the normal proportion of plasmablasts in circulation relative to total number of B cells.
name: Decreased proportion of plasmablasts

desc: An abnormal number of plasma cells in the blood circulation. Plasma cells are the the effector cells dedicated to the production of a high amount of antibodies.
name: Abnormal plasma cell count

desc: An abnormally low number of plasma cells in the blood circulation. Plasma cells are the the effector cells dedicated to the production of a high amount of antibodies.
name: Reduced plasma cell count

desc: An abnormally high number of plasma cells in the blood circulation. Plasma cells are the the effector cells dedicated to the production of a high amount of antibodies.
name: Elevated plasma cell count

desc: Absence of the fingerlike protrusive, actin-dependent structures found on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes.
layperson: Absent microvilli on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes
name: Absent microvilli on the surface of peripheral blood lymphocytes

desc: Normal peripheral blood lymphocytes, when stimulated by phytohemagglutinin (PHA) are cytotoxic for homologous and heterologous cells but not for autologous cells in monolayer culture. The cytotoxic effect is thought to be indicative of the immunological competence of the lymphocytes.
name: Impaired lymphocyte transformation with phytohemagglutinin

desc: An anomaly of the natural killer cell, which is a lymphocyte that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors. It also regulates immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells.
name: Abnormal natural killer cell morphology

desc: Any deviation from the normal overall count of natural killer (NK) cells in the circulation or a deviation from the normal distribution of NK cell subtypes.
name: Abnormal natural killer cell count
synonyms: Abnormal number of natural killer cells
Abnormality of natural killer cell count

desc: Less than normal number of natural killer cells, a type of lymphocyte in the innate immune system with an ability to mediate cytotoxicity and produce cytokines after the ligation of a germline-encoded activation receptor.
name: Reduced natural killer cell count

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion natural killer subsets relative to the total number of natural killer cells.
name: Abnormal natural killer subset distribution

desc: An abnormal distribution in the number of CD56 bright NK cells, as measured by flow cytometry. CD56, an adhesion molecule mediating homotypic adhesion, is used as a functional marker for NK cells.
layperson: Abnormal distribution of CD56 bright/dim natural killer cells
name: Abnormal distribution of CD56 bright/dim natural killer cells
synonyms: Abnormal distribution of CD56 bright/dim NK cells

desc: Lack of natural killer cells, a type of lymphocyte in the innate immune system that contains cytoplasmic granzymes, i.e., small granules with perforin and proteases that allow natural killer cells to form pores in the cell membrane of the target cell through which the granzymes and associated molecules can enter, inducing apoptosis.
name: Absent natural killer cells

desc: An abnormally increased number of plasma cells in tissues, exudates, or blood
name: Plasmacytosis

desc: Any abnormality in the total number of lymphocytes in the blood.
name: Abnormal lymphocyte count

desc: A reduced number of lymphocytes in the blood.
name: Lymphopenia

desc: An abnormally low count of T cells.
name: Decrease in T cell count
synonyms: Decreased numbers of circulating T cells

desc: Any abnormality in the proportion of CD3-positive T cells relative to the total number of T cells.
layperson: Decreased proportion of CD3-positive T cells
name: Decreased proportion of CD3-positive T cells
synonyms: Decreased proportion of CD3+ T cells

desc: An abnormal decrease from the normal count of B cells.
name: B lymphocytopenia

desc: A severe form of B lymphocytopenia in which the count of B cells is very low or absent.
name: Severe B lymphocytopenia

desc: Complete lack of mature B cells, that is, of B cells that have left the bone marrow.
name: Absence of mature B cells

desc: Complete lack of memory B cells, that is, of mature B cell type that is long-lived, readily activated upon re-encounter of its antigenic determinant, and has been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin.
name: Absence of memory B cells

desc: Increase in the number or proportion of lymphocytes in the blood.
name: Lymphocytosis

desc: An abnormality of myeloid leukocytes.
name: Abnormal myeloid leukocyte morphology

desc: Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of granulocytes.
name: Abnormal granulocyte morphology

desc: A neutrophil abnormality.
name: Abnormality of neutrophils

desc: A functional abnormality of neutrophils.
name: Abnormality of neutrophil physiology

desc: An abnormal reduction of the cell motility of neutrophils.
name: Reduction of neutrophil motility

desc: An impairment of the migration of neutrophils towards chemoattractants as part of the innate immune response
name: Impaired neutrophil chemotaxis

desc: A reduction in the ability of neutrophils to kill bacteria.
name: Impaired neutrophil bactericidal activity

desc: In the NBT test, neutrophils change the colorless compound NBT into a compound with a deep blue color. If this test is negative (i.e., no blue color is produced), then this indicates a defect in superoxide-generating NADPH oxidase activity with inability to efficiently kill phagocytized bacteria.
name: Impaired oxidative burst

desc: A reduction in the ability of neutrophils to kill the gram-positive bacteria, staphylococcus, which is commonly known as staph.
name: Impaired neutrophil killing of staphylococci

desc: An abnormality in the cleavage of L-selectin during the process of guiding neutrophils to the site of infection. Proteolytic cleavage of L-selectin results in rapid shedding from the cell surface, which has a role in neutrophil rolling and accumulation at the site of infection.
name: Abnormal L-selectin shedding

desc: A deviation from the normal range of neutrophil cell counts in the circulation.
name: Abnormal neutrophil count

desc: An abnormally low number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.
name: Neutropenia

desc: A type of neutropenia that is observed in the presence of granulocyte-specific antibodies.
layperson: Neutropenia in presence of anti-neutropil antibodies
name: Neutropenia in presence of anti-neutropil antibodies

desc: Recurrent episodes of abnormally low levels of neutrophils in the body (neutropenia).
name: Cyclic neutropenia

desc: Cyclic neutropenia arising from an impaired proliferation and maturation of myeloid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.
layperson: Cyclic neutropenia in myeloid maturation arrest in bone marrow
name: Cyclic neutropenia in myeloid maturation arrest in bone marrow

desc: Neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 1,500,000,000/L lasting for more than 3 months.
name: Chronic neutropenia

desc: Chornic neutropenia arising from an impaired proliferation and maturation of myeloid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.
layperson: Chronic neutropenia in myeloid maturation arrest in bone marrow
name: Chronic neutropenia in myeloid maturation arrest in bone marrow

desc: A transient reduction in the number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood. Transient neutropenia is most commonly associated with viral infections, but other causes include drugs and autoimmunity.
name: Transient neutropenia

desc: Transient neutropenia caused by an infection, such as with a virus, bacteria or protozoan.
name: Infection associated neutropenia

desc: Increased number of neutrophils circulating in blood.
name: Neutrophilia

desc: An increased number of neutrophils circulating in the blood during an infection, such as with a bacteria, virus or fungus.
name: Neutrophilia in presence of infection

desc: An increased number of neutrophils circulating in the blood in the absence of an infection. Factors contributing to neutrophilia could include inflammation or congenital disorders.
name: Neutrophilia in absence of infection

desc: An abnormally increased number of immature neutrophils in the peripheral blood circulation.
name: Increased circulating immature neutrophil count

desc: An abnormally increased number of myelocytes in the peripheral blood circulation. Myelocytes are immature neutrophils with a size of 12-18 micrometers, a round or oval nucleus with no nucleoli, bluish-pink staining cytoplasm with primary and seconday granules, and a nucleus:cytoplasm ratio of 2:1.
name: Increased circulating myelocyte count

desc: An abnormally increased number of metamyelocytes in the peripheral blood circulation. Metamyelocytes are immature neutrophils with a size of 10-18 micrometers, an indented or kidney-shaped nucleus, pinkish-blue staining cytoplasm with seconday granules, and a nucleus:cytoplasm ratio of 1.5:1.
name: Increased circulating metamyelocyte count

desc: An abnormally increased number of band cells in the peripheral blood circulation. Band cells are immature neutrophils with a size of 10-18 micrometers, a horseshoe-shaped nucleus with no nucleoli, light-pink staining cytoplasm with many small seconday granules, and a nucleus:cytoplasm ratio of 1:2.
name: Increased circulating band cell count

desc: An abnormal form or size of neutrophils.
name: Abnormality of neutrophil morphology

desc: An excessive division of the lobes of the nucleus of a neutrophil.
name: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei
synonyms: Hypersegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in peripheral blood

desc: The presence of intracellular inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in neutrophils. Cytoplasmic neutrophil inclusions (oval, basophilic) are also known as Doehle bodies.
name: Neutrophil inclusion bodies

desc: The presence of intraceullar inclusion bodies (aggregates of stainable substances, usually proteins) in leukocytes.
name: Leukocyte inclusion bodies

desc: Hyposegmented (hypolobulated) or bilobed neutrophil nuclei.
name: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei
synonyms: Hyposegmentation of neutrophil nuclei in peripheral blood

desc: Lack of specific granules in neutrophils.
name: Absent neutrophil specific granules

desc: The absence of lactoferrin in neutrophil granules, which could be caused by either an isolated failure of synthesis of this protein (or the production of an antigenically unrecognizable form of lactoferrin) or a complete deficiency of specific granule production.
name: Absent neutrophil lactoferrin

desc: Presence of an elevated number of projections from nuclei of neutrophils. These projections can have the shape of hooks, tags, or clubs.
name: Increased neutrophil nuclear projections

desc: Nuclear lobes of neutrophils in the bone marrow are thickened and condensed, and individual lobes are connected by unusually long chromatin filaments.
name: Pyknotic bone marrow neutrophils

desc: The presence of abnormally large granules in neutrophils. This finding can be appreciated on a peripheral blood smear. The finding is characteristic of Chediak Higashi syndrome. The giant granules are derived from azurophil granules, whereas peroxidase-negative granules are not involved in their formation.
name: Giant neutrophil granules

desc: An increased number of mitochondria detected in neutrophils.
name: Increased neutrophil mitochondria

desc: An increased number of ribosomes detected in neutrophils.
name: Increased neutrophil ribosomes

desc: An abnormal count or structure of eosinophils.
name: Abnormal eosinophil morphology

desc: Any deviation from the normal number of eosinophils per volume in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal eosinophil count

desc: Increased count of eosinophils in the blood.
name: Eosinophilia

desc: A severely increased count of eosinophils in the blood defined as a blood eosinophil count of 1.5 Ã 10e9/L or greater (one and a half billion cells per liter).
name: Hypereosinophilia

desc: Recurrent episodes of marked eosinophilia that resolve spontaneously.
name: Episodic eosinophilia

desc: Abnormal reduction in the count of eosinophils in the blood per volume.
name: Decreased eosinophil count

desc: Any structural abnormality or abnormal count of basophils.
name: Abnormal basophil morphology

desc: Any deviation from the normal number of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal basophil count

desc: An abnormally increased count of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.
name: Increased basophil count

desc: An abnormally reduced count of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased basophil count

desc: Any deviation from the normal cell count per volume of granulocytes in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal granulocyte count

desc: An abnormally reduced number of granulocytes in the blood.
name: Granulocytopenia

desc: Marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
name: Agranulocytosis

desc: Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
name: Congenital agranulocytosis

desc: A type of agranulocytosis related to ingestion of a specific medication.
name: Drug-induced agranulocytosis

desc: An increased count of granulocytes in the peripheral blood circulation.
name: Granulocytosis

desc: Any structural anomaly of mast cells, which are found in almost all tissues and contain numerous basophilic granules and are capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation.
name: Abnormal mast cell morphology

desc: An increased proportion of mast cells are positive for the cell surface marker CD25 (also called interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain).
layperson: Increased proportion of CD25+ mast cells
name: Increased proportion of CD25+ mast cells

desc: The presence of an increased number of mast cells and CD34+ mast cell precursors in the body.
name: Mastocytosis

desc: Liver mast cell infiltration.
name: Hepatic mastocytosis

desc: An abnormality of macrophages.
name: Abnormal macrophage morphology

desc: An abnormality of histiocytes, in which the cells take on a sea blue appearance due to abnormally increased lipid content. Histiocytes are a type of macrophage. Sea-blue histiocytes are typically large macrophages from 20 to 60 micrometers in diameter with a single eccentric nucleus whose cytoplasm if packed with sea-blue or blue-green granules when stained with Wright-Giemsa.
name: Sea-blue histiocytosis

desc: A granulomatous inflammation leading to multiple granuloma formation, which is a specific type of inflammation. A granuloma is a focal compact collection of inflammatory cells, mononuclear cells predominating, usually as a result of the persistence of a non-degradable product and of active cell mediated hypersensitivity.
name: Granulomatosis

desc: The presence of multiple granulomas in the liver as based on pathological examination. Granulomas are small 0.5 to 2 mm collections of modified macrophages called epithelioid cells usually surrounded by lymphocytes.
name: Hepatic granulomatosis

desc: The presence of multiple epithelioid cell granulomas consist of highly differentiated mononuclear phagocytes (epithelioid cells and giant cells) and lymphocytes, not exhibiting caseation (a form of necrosis in which the tissue changes into a dry, amorphous mass said to resemble cheese).
name: Non-caseating epithelioid cell granulomatosis

desc: Yellow nodules of lipoid material are deposited in the skin and mucosae. This gives rise to granulomatous reactions.
name: Lipogranulomatosis

desc: The presence of foam cells in the bone marrow, generally demonstrated by bone-marrow aspiration or biopsy. Foam cells have a vacuolated appearance due to the presence of complex lipid deposits, giving them a foamy or soap-suds appearance.
name: Bone-marrow foam cells
synonyms: Large vacuolated foam cells ('NP cells') on bone marrow biopsy
Large vacuolated foam cells on bone marrow biopsy

desc: Phagocytosis by macrophages of erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets, and their precursors in bone marrow and other tissues.
name: Hemophagocytosis

desc: An anomaly in the number of macrophages.
name: Abnormal macrophage count

desc: An anomaly in the number of osteoclasts, bone-resorbing cells that develop from macrophages.
name: Abnormal osteoclast count

desc: Decreased number of osteoclasts.
name: Decreased osteoclast count

desc: An excessive number of histiocytes (tissue macrophages).
name: Histiocytosis

desc: Multiple subcutaneous non-fragile and skin-coloured papules characterized by interstitial infiltrate of spindle and epithelioid histiocytes, and mucin. There are well circumscribed aggregates of epithelioid histiocytes and mucin in the upper and middle dermis,with the histiocytes arranged between collagen bundles and separated from the epidermis by a Grenz zone.
name: Mucinous histiocytosis

desc: Any structural anomaly of a myeloid mononuclear recirculating leukocyte that can act as a precursor of tissue macrophages, osteoclasts and some populations of tissue dendritic cells.
name: Abnormality monocyte morphology

desc: An anomaly in the number of monocytes, which are myeloid mononuclear recirculating leukocyte that can act as a precursor of tissue macrophages, osteoclasts and some populations of tissue dendritic cells.
name: Abnormal monocyte count

desc: An increased number of circulating monocytes.
name: Monocytosis

desc: An decreased number of circulating monocytes.
name: Monocytopenia

desc: Number of leukocytes per volume of blood beyond normal limits.
name: Abnormal leukocyte count

desc: An abnormal decreased number of leukocytes in the blood.
name: Leukopenia

desc: An abnormal increase in the number of leukocytes in the blood.
name: Leukocytosis

desc: A deviation from the normal count of dendritic cells in the peripheral blood circulation. Dendritic cells are of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation. These cells are lineage negative (CD3-negative, CD19-negative, CD34-negative, and CD56-negative).
name: Abnormal dendritic cell count

desc: An increased count in the peripheral blood of cells that are precursors to mature circulating blood cells such as neutrophiles, monocytes, lymphocutes, and erythrocytes. Blasts are not usually found in significant numbers in the peripheral blood circulation, but can be observed in hematopoietic neoplasms such as leukemia, severe infections, and as a result of certain medications.
name: Increased peripheral blast count

desc: An abnormal susceptibility to bleeding, often referred to as a bleeding diathesis. A bleeding diathesis may be related to vascular, platelet and coagulation defects.
name: Abnormal bleeding

desc: Prolongation of the time taken for a standardized skin cut of fixed depth and length to stop bleeding.
name: Prolonged bleeding time

desc: Abnormal bleeding of the umbilical stump following separation of the cord at approximately 7-10 days after birth.
name: Abnormal umbilical stump bleeding

desc: Bleeding sufficiently severe as to require red cell transfusion (WHO Grade 3 or 4).
name: Bleeding requiring red cell transfusion

desc: Significant bleeding or hemorrhage without significant precipitating factor.
name: Bleeding with minor or no trauma
synonyms: Bleeding with minor or no trauma

desc: Prolonged or protracted bleeding following an invasive procedure or intervention.
name: Prolonged bleeding following procedure

desc: Bleeding that persists longer than the normal time following a surgical procedure.
name: Prolonged bleeding after surgery

desc: Prolonged bleeding post dental extraction sufficient to require medical intervention.
name: Prolonged bleeding after dental extraction

desc: Significant maternal haemorrhage/blood loss following deilvery of a child.
name: Post-partum hemorrhage

desc: Bleeding that persists for a longer than usual time following circumcision.
name: Prolonged bleeding following circumcision

desc: An abnormally increased degree of bleeding following a superfical injury to the surface of the skin.
name: Excessive bleeding from superficial cuts

desc: An abnormal high amount of bleeding following the procedure of taking a blood sample.
name: Excessive bleeding after a venipuncture

desc: Abnormal bleeding related to a procedure or trauma which does not start at the time of the initial insult, but after delay by at least 24 hours.
name: Delayed onset bleeding

desc: An abnormality of the process of blood coagulation. That is, altered ability or inability of the blood to clot.
name: Abnormality of coagulation

desc: An abnormality of the coagulation cascade, which is comprised of the contact activation pathway (also known as the intrinsic pathway) and the tissue factor pathway (also known as the extrinsic pathway) as well as cofactors and regulators.
name: Abnormality of the coagulation cascade

desc: An abnormality of the extrinsic pathway (also known as the tissue factor pathway) of the coagulation cascade.
name: Abnormality of the extrinsic pathway

desc: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of antithrombin-III.
name: Reduced antithrombin III activity

desc: Reduced activity of coagulation factor VII. Factor VII is part of the extrinsic coagulation pathway, which is initiated at the site of injury in response to the release of tissue factor (fIII). Tissue factor and activated factor VII catalyze the activation of factor X.
name: Reduced factor VII activity

desc: An abnormality of the intrinsic pathway (also known as the contact activation pathway) of the coagulation cascade.
name: Abnormality of the intrinsic pathway

desc: Decreased activity of coagulation factor XI. Factor XI, also known as plasma thromboplastin antecedent, is a serine proteinase that activates factor IX.
name: Reduced factor XI activity

desc: Decreased activity of coagulation factor XII. Factor XII (fXII) is part of the intrinsic coagulation pathway and binds to exposed collagen at site of vessel wall injury, activated by high-MW kininogen and kallikrein, thereby initiating the coagulation cascade.
name: Reduced factor XII activity

desc: Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade.
name: Reduced kininogen activity

desc: Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa.
name: Reduced factor IX activity

desc: A deviation from the normal activity of coagulation factor VIII. Factor VIII (fVIII) is a cofactor in the intrinsic clotting cascade that is activated to fVIIIa in the presence of minute quantities of thrombin. fVIIIa acts as a receptor, for factors IXa and X.
name: Abnormal factor VIII activity

desc: Reduced activity of coagulation factor VIII. Factor VIII (fVIII) is a cofactor in the intrinsic clotting cascade that is activated to fVIIIa in the presence of minute quantities of thrombin. fVIIIa acts as a receptor, for factors IXa and X.
name: Reduced factor VIII activity

desc: Increased activity of the coagulation factor VIII. Factor VIII (fVIII) is a cofactor in the intrinsic clotting cascade that is activated to fVIIIa in the presence of minute quantities of thrombin. fVIIIa acts as a receptor, for factors IXa and X.
name: Increased factor VIII activity

desc: An abnormality of blood coagulation, common pathway.
layperson: Abnormality of the common coagulation pathway
name: Abnormality of the common coagulation pathway

desc: Reduced activity of coagulation factor X. The extrinsic and intrinsic pathways converge at factor X (fX). The extrinsic pathway activates fX by means of d factor VII with its cofactor, tissue factor. The intrinsic pathway activates fX by means of the tenase complex (Ca2+ and factors VIIIa, IXa and X) on the surface of activated platelets. Factor Xa in turn activates prothrombin (factor II) to thrombin (factor IIa).
name: Reduced factor X activity

desc: Reduced ability to transform factor X into its activated form factor Xa.
name: Factor X activation deficiency

desc: Decreased activity of coagulation factor XIII (also known as fibrin stabilizing factor). Activated Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers solidifying the clot.
name: Reduced factor XIII activity

desc: Deficiency of factor XIII subunit A, leading to a reduced factor XIII activity. Activated Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers solidifying the clot.
name: Factor XIII subunit A deficiency

desc: Deficiency of factor XIII subunit B, leading to a reduced factor XIII activity. Activated Factor XIII cross-links fibrin polymers solidifying the clot.
name: Factor XIII subunit B deficiency

desc: An abnormality of the level of activity of circulating fibrinogen.
name: Abnormality of circulating fibrinogen

desc: Increased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood.
name: Hyperfibrinogenemia

desc: Decreased concentration of fibrinogen in the blood.
name: Hypofibrinogenemia

desc: Qualitatively abnormal fibrinogen.
name: Dysfibrinogenemia

desc: Any deviation from the activity of coagulation factor V.
name: Abnormal coagulation factor V activity

desc: Decreased activity of coagulation factor V.
name: Reduced coagulation factor V activity

desc: Increased activity of coagulation factor V, Factor V, which is activated to factor Va by means of minute amounts of thrombin (and inactivated by larger amounts of thrombin). Activated factor V (fVa) is a cofactor in the formation of the prothrombinase complex.
name: Elevated coagulation factor V activity

desc: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of heparin co-factor II
layperson: Decreased level of heparin co-factor II
name: Decreased level of heparin co-factor II

desc: Decrease of these levels result in increased inhibition of fibrinolysis and reduced inhibition of coagulation
name: Decreased level of histidine-rich glycoprotein

desc: A decreased level of Plasminogen
name: Decreased level of plasminogen

desc: Thrombomodulin is a cofactor in the thrombin induced activation of Protein C. In the case of deficiency there will be less Protein C and tendency to clot
name: Decreased level of thrombomodulin

desc: The tPA protein catalyzes the conversion of plasiminogen to plasmin, and thus break down of clots. When there is a deficiency there will be an increase of thrombosis
layperson: Decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator
name: Decreased level of tissue plasminogen activator

desc: Increased plasma vitamin K epoxide after vitamin K supplementation is present in VKCFD (vitamin K-dependent clotting factor deficiency) type 2, but not in VKCFD type 1.
layperson: Increased plasma vitamin K epoxide after vitamin K supplementation
name: Increased plasma vitamin K epoxide after vitamin K supplementation

desc: Increased time to coagulation in the Russell's viper venom assay
name: Prolonged Russell's viper venom time

desc: Reduced activity of alpha-2-antiplasmin. This protein inactivates the protease plasmin that drives fibrinolysis.
name: Reduced alpha-2-antiplasmin activity

desc: Reduced antithrombin antigen. A reduced level of antithrombin may lead to an increased risk of thrombus formation.
name: Reduced antithrombin antigen

desc: Decreased quantity or activity of von Willebrand factor. Von Willebrand factor mediates the adhesion of platelets to the collagen exposed on endothelial cell surfaces.
name: Abnormality of von Willebrand factor

desc: Decreased activity of von Willebrand factor. Von Willebrand factor mediates the adhesion of platelets to the collagen exposed on endothelial cell surfaces.
name: Reduced von Willebrand factor activity

desc: Decreased quantity of von Willebrand factor.
layperson: Reduced quantity of Von Willebrand factor
name: Reduced quantity of Von Willebrand factor

desc: Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ristocetin to platelet-poor plasma.
name: Impaired ristocetin cofactor assay activity

desc: Reduced ability of von Willibrand factor (vWF) to bind collagen. Abnormal response to collagen as manifested by reduced or lacking ability of plasma von WIllebrand Factor to bind collagen. An ELISA-based assay is typically used; the test is sensitive to loss of von Willebrand Factor high molecular weight multimers.
layperson: Impaired von Willibrand factor collagen binding activity
name: Impaired von Willibrand factor collagen binding activity

desc: Deviation from the normal von Willebrand factor multimer pattern.
