layperson: Abnormal von Willebrand factor multimer distribution
name: Abnormal von Willebrand factor multimer distribution

desc: Absence of large von Willebrand Factor multimers on gel electrophoresis.
layperson: Absence of large von Willibrand factor multimers
name: Absence of large von Willibrand factor multimers

desc: Detection of abnormal ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers.
layperson: Abnormal presence of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers
name: Abnormal presence of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers

desc: Complete absence of all von Willebrand factor multimers.
layperson: Total absence von Willebrand factor multimers
name: Total absence von Willebrand factor multimers

desc: Lack of intermediate von Willebrand Factor multimers on gel electrophoresis.
layperson: Absence of intermediate von Willibrand factor multimers
name: Absence of intermediate von Willibrand factor multimers

desc: A decrease in high molecular weight von Willebrand factor multimers.
layperson: Decrease in high molecular weight von Willebrand factor Multimers
name: Decrease in high molecular weight von Willebrand factor Multimers

desc: Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by increased aggregation of platelets upon addition of low-dose ristocetin to platelet-rich plasma.
name: Enhanced ristocetin cofactor assay activity

desc: Impaired binding of factor VIII to von Willebrand Factor. This is determined using a modified ELISA assay.
layperson: Impaired binding of factor VIII to VWF
name: Impaired binding of factor VIII to VWF
synonyms: Von Willebrand Disease Type II Normandy

desc: An increased VWF propeptide to VWF antigen indicates that deficiency of VWF is not due to impaired synthesis but due to rapid clearance. The VWF propeptide is measured by ELISA.
layperson: Increased ratio of VWF propeptide to VWF antigen
name: Increased ratio of VWF propeptide to VWF antigen

desc: An anomaly of clotting factor II, which is known as prothrombin, a vitamin K-dependent proenzyme that functions in the blood coagulation cascade.
name: Abnormality of prothrombin

desc: The prothrombin consumption test measures the formation of intrinsic thromboplastin by determining the residual serum prothrombin after blood clotting is complete. If there is a defect in the process, less prothrombin will be converted to thrombin than normal (less prothrombin is consumed). This test may be abnormal with conditions including deficiency of factors VIII or IX, with circulating anticoagulants, thrombocytopenia.
name: Reduced prothrombin consumption

desc: Any deviation from the normal amount of time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT.
name: Abnormal prothrombin time

desc: Increased time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT.
name: Prolonged prothrombin time

desc: Abnormally short time to coagulation in the prothrombin time test, which is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. The results of the prothrombin time test are often expressed in terms of the International normalized ratio (INR), which is calculated as a ratio of the patient's prothrombin time (PT) to a control PT standardized for the potency of the thromboplastin reagent developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) using the formula: INR is equal to Patient PT divided by Control PT.
name: Decreased prothrombin time

desc: Reduced prothrombin antigen as measured by ELISA assay. Prothrombin is a vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor that is proteolytically cleaved to form thrombin.
name: Reduced prothrombin antigen

desc: An anomaly of the protein C anticoagulant pathway, which serves as a major system for controlling thrombosis, limiting inflammatory responses, and potentially decreasing endothelial cell apoptosis in response to inflammatory cytokines and ischemia. A natural anticoagulant system denoted the protein C pathway exerts its anticoagulant effect by regulating the activity of FVIIIa and FVa. The vitamin K-dependent protein C is the key component of the pathway. Activated protein C (APC) cleaves and inhibits coagulation cofactors FVIIIa and FVa, which result in downregulation of the activity of the coagulation system. The endothelial protein C receptor stimulates the T-TM-mediated activation of protein C on the endothelial cell surface. The two cofactors, protein S and the intact form of FV, enhance the anticoagulant activity of APC.
layperson: Abnormality of the protein C anticoagulant pathway
name: Abnormality of the protein C anticoagulant pathway

desc: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein S. Protein S is a cofactor of protein C.
name: Reduced protein S activity

desc: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va.
name: Reduced protein C activity

desc: Poor anticoagulant response to activated protein C. A plasma is termed 'APC resistant' when the addition of exogenous APC fails to prolong its clotting time in an activated partial thromboplastin time assay.
name: Resistance to activated protein C

desc: Increased time to coagulation in the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) test, a measure of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways. Phospholipid, and activator, and calcium are mixed into an anticoagulated plasma sample, and the time is measured until a thrombus forms.
name: Prolonged partial thromboplastin time

desc: An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot.
name: Prolonged whole-blood clotting time

desc: An abnormally increased duration of the reptilase time. Reptilase time is a functional plasma clotting assay, which is based on the enzymatic activity of batroxobin. By specifically cleaving fibrinogen A from fibrinogen, batroxobin leads to the formation of a stable fibrin clot. The time, starting from the addition of batroxobin to the plasma sample, until clot formation is the reptilase time and is given in seconds.
name: Prolonged reptilase time

desc: Clincial phenotype characterized by delayed bleeding accelerated break down of blood clot (fibrinolysis)
name: Abnormality of fibrinolysis

desc: Increased degradation of fibrin, associated with clot instability and bleeding
name: Hyperfibrinolysis

desc: Abnormally increased length of time required for an in vitro clot to dissolve in the absence of the normal plasmin inhibitors. This test is a clinical assay used to measure fibrinolysis. The euglobulin fraction of plasma is precipitated and used to form clot by addition of thrombin; after clot forms the rate of clot breakdown (fibrinolysis) can be monitored.
name: Prolonged euglobulin clot lysis time

desc: Abnormally decreased length of time required for an in vitro clot to dissolve in the absence of the normal plasmin inhibitors. This test is a clinical assay used to measure fibrinolysis. The euglobulin fraction of plasma is precipitated and used to form clot by addition of thrombin; after clot forms the rate of clot breakdown (fibrinolysis) can be monitored.
name: Reduced euglobulin clot lysis time

desc: Reduced activity of plasminogen activator inhibitor 1. This protein down-regulates fibrinolysis in the circulation by inhibiting the two major plasminogen activators: tissue-plasminogen activator and urokinase-plasminogen activator.
name: Reduced plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 activity

desc: Reduced level of plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 antigen.
name: Reduced plasminogen activator inhibitor 1 antigen

desc: An abnormality of coagulation associated with an increased risk of thrombosis.
name: Hypercoagulability

desc: Venous or arterial thrombosis (formation of blood clots) of spontaneous nature and which cannot be fully explained by acquired risk (e.g. atherosclerosis).
name: Abnormal thrombosis

desc: The formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel that subsequently travels through the blood stream from the site where it formed to another location in the body, generally leading to vascular occlusion at the distant site.
name: Thromboembolism

desc: A cerebrovascular accident (stroke) that occurs because of thromboembolism.
name: Thromboembolic stroke

desc: Repeated episodes of obstruction of blood flow due to an embolus, i.e., blood clot that has traveled from its point of origin within the blood stream.
name: Recurrent thromboembolism

desc: The formation of a blood clot inside an artery.
name: Arterial thrombosis

desc: Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
name: Venous thrombosis

desc: Formation of a blot clot in a deep vein. The clot often blocks blood flow, causing swelling and pain. The deep veins of the leg are most often affected.
layperson: Blood clot in a deep vein
name: Deep venous thrombosis
synonyms: Blood clot in a deep vein

desc: Repeated episodes of the formation of a blot clot in a deep vein.
name: Recurrent deep vein thrombosis

desc: Inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
name: Thrombophlebitis

desc: Inflammation of a superficial vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
name: Superficial thrombophlebitis

desc: Repeated episodes of inflammation of a vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).
name: Recurrent thrombophlebitis

desc: Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
name: Cerebral venous thrombosis

desc: The term splanchnic vein thrombosis encompasses Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis), extrahepatic portal vein obstruction (EHPVO), and mesenteric vein thrombosis; the word splanchnic is used to refer to the visceral organs (of the abdominal cavity).
name: Splanchnic vein thrombosis

desc: Thrombosis of the portal vein and/or its tributaries, which include the splenic vein and the superior and inferior mesenteric veins.
name: Portal vein thrombosis

desc: An obstruction in the veins of the liver caused by a blood clot (thrombosis).
name: Hepatic vein thrombosis

desc: A clot that obstructs blood flow in a mesenteric vein (the superior and the inferior mesenteric vein drain blood from the small and large intestine).
name: Mesenteric venous thrombosis

desc: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels.
name: Disseminated intravascular coagulation

desc: A chronic form of disseminated intravascular coagulation in which a persistent weak or intermittent activating stimulus is present and destruction and production of coagulation factors and platelets are balanced.
name: Chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation

desc: An acute form of disseminated intravascular coagulation. Acute DIC can occur following sudden exposure of blood to procoagulants, with the compensatory hemostatic mechanisms becoming overwhelmed.
name: Acute disseminated intravascular coagulation

desc: The process of hematopoiesis occurring outside of the bone marrow (in the liver, thymus, and spleen) in the postnatal organisms.
name: Extramedullary hematopoiesis

desc: Neoplasms located in the blood and blood-forming tissue (the bone marrow and lymphatic tissue).
name: Hematological neoplasm

desc: A cancer originating in lymphocytes and presenting as a solid tumor of lymhpoid cells.
name: Lymphoma

desc: Lung parenchymal involvement with lymphoma.
name: Pulmonary lymphoma

desc: A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
name: Hodgkin lymphoma

desc: A type of lymphoma characterized microscopically by the absence of multinucleated Reed-Sternberg cells.
name: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

desc: A type of lymphoma that originates in T-cells.
name: T-cell lymphoma

desc: A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas.
name: T-cell lymphoma/leukemia

desc: A type of T-cell lymphoma that exhibits malignant infiltration of the skin.
name: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma

desc: A type of T-cell lymphoma that is characterized by so-called hallmark cells with a pleomorphic appearance that express the CD30 antigen, are lobulated, and have indented nuclei.
name: Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma

desc: A type of lymphoma that originates in B-cells.
name: B-cell lymphoma

desc: A form of extranodal, high-grade non-Hodgkin B-cell neoplasm, usually large cell or immunoblastic type that originates in the brain, leptomeninges, spinal cord, or eyes and typically remains confined to the CNS.
name: Primary central nervous system lymphoma

desc: A form of undifferentiated malignant lymphoma commonly manifested as a large osteolytic lesion in the jaw or as an abdominal mass.
name: Burkitt lymphoma

desc: Lymphoma that originates in the stomach itself.
name: Gastric lymphoma

desc: Clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorders characterized by dysplasia (ineffective production) in one or more hematopoietic cell lineages, leading to anemia and cytopenia.
name: Myelodysplasia

desc: Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two or more of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic.
name: Multiple lineage myelodysplasia

desc: Myelodysplasia with dysplastic changes in two of the myeloid lineages: erythroid, granulocytic, megakaryocytic.
name: Bilineage myelodysplasia

desc: Abnormality/dysplasia of a single myeloid cell (erythroid, granulocytic, or megakaryocytic).
name: Single lineage myelodysplasia

desc: A type of myelodysplastic syndrome characterized by less than 5% myeloblasts in the bone marrow, but with 15% or greater red cell precursors in the marrow being abnormal iron-stuffed cells called ringed sideroblasts.
name: Refractory anemia with ringed sideroblasts

desc: Presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin M protein in the serum.
name: Monoclonal immunoglobulin M proteinemia

desc: A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton.
name: Multiple myeloma

desc: A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location.
name: Plasmacytoma

desc: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow.
layperson: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
name: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
synonyms: Anomaly of the bone marrow cells

layperson: Abnormality of bone marrow stromal cells
name: Abnormality of bone marrow stromal cells

desc: An anomaly of cells involved in the formation of a granulocytes, that is, of the granulocytopoietic cell.
name: Abnormal granulocytopoietic cell morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of cells of the granulocytic lineage

desc: Decreased number of granulocyte precursors in the bone marrow.
name: Granulocytic hypoplasia

desc: Impaired egress of mature neutrophils from bone marrow causing neutropenia.
name: Myelokathexis

desc: Any structural anomaly of megakaryocytes. Mature blood platelets are released from the cytoplasm of megakaryocytes, which are bone-marrow resident cells.
name: Abnormal megakaryocyte morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of cells of the megakaryocyte lineage

desc: Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow.
name: Increased megakaryocyte count

desc: A reduced count of megakaryocytes.
name: Megakaryocytopenia

desc: The presence of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow whose nuclei are less lobulated than expected for the size of the nucleus.
name: Megakaryocyte nucleus hypolobulation

desc: The presence of abnormally high numbers of micromegakaryocytes in the bone marrow. Micromegakaryocytes are mononuclear diploid cells, with a nucleus similar in size to that of a myeloblast or promyelocyte with the cell being less than 30 micrometers in diameter.
name: Increased micromegakaryocyte count

desc: The presence of abnormally high numbers of multinucleated megakaryocytes in the bone marrow.
name: Increased multinucleated megakaryocyte count

desc: The presence of megakaryocytes in the bone marrow whose nuclei are more lobulated than expected for the size of the nucleus.
name: Megakaryocyte nucleus hyperlobulation

desc: The presence of micro-megakaryocytes, hypo-lobed, or non-lobed nuclei in megakaryocytes of all sizes and multiple, widely-separated nuclei.
name: Megakaryocyte dysplasia

layperson: Abnormality of multiple cell lineages in the bone marrow
name: Abnormality of multiple cell lineages in the bone marrow

desc: An abnormal reduction in numbers of all blood cell types (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets).
name: Pancytopenia

desc: Aplastic anemia is defined as pancytopenia with a hypocellular marrow.
name: Aplastic anemia

desc: Abnormal increased number of megaloblasts in the bone marrow.
name: Megaloblastic bone marrow

desc: A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat.
name: Bone marrow hypocellularity

desc: Replacement of bone marrow by fibrous tissue.
name: Myelofibrosis

desc: A larger than normal amount or percentage of hematopoietic cells relative to marrow fat.
name: Bone marrow hypercellularity

desc: A reduction in the numbers of pro-B cells (defined by coexpression of CD34 and CD19). Earlier B-cell precursors are defined by expressing surface CD34 and cytoplasmic TdT in the absence of CD19.
name: Reduced bone-marrow pro-B cell count

desc: Any structural anomaly of a cell of the monocyte, granulocyte, mast cell, megakaryocyte, or erythroid lineage.
name: Abnormal myeloid cell morphology

desc: An anomaly of erythroid lineage cells, that is, of the erythropoietic cells in the lineage leading to and including erythrocytes.
name: Abnormal erythroid lineage cell morphology
synonyms: Abnormality of cells of the erythroid lineage

desc: Abnormal form of the progenitor cells committed to the erythroid lineage.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of erythroid progenitor cell
name: Abnormal morphology of erythroid progenitor cell

desc: Anomalous form of the proerythroblast, i.e., the immature, nucleated erythrocyte occupying the stage of erythropoeisis that follows formation of erythroid progenitor cells. This cell is CD71-positive, has both a nucleus and a nucleolus, and lacks hematopoeitic lineage markers.
name: Abnormal proerythroblast morphology

desc: Dysplasia in the erythroid lineage, which presents with a variety of morphological changes in the bone marrow, including nuclear budding or irregular nuclear contour in erythroblasts.
name: Erythroid dysplasia

desc: Any functional abnormality of erythrocytes (red-blood cells).
name: Abnormal erythrocyte physiology

desc: An abnormal increase in the binding affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.
name: Increased hemoglobin oxygen affinity

desc: Presence of elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
name: Ketosis

desc: Acidosis resulting from accumulation of ketone bodies.
name: Ketoacidosis

desc: Intermittent episodes of ketoacidosis.
name: Episodic ketoacidosis

desc: An increased level of acetone in the blood circulation. Acetone is one of the predominant ketone bodies.
name: Elevated circulating acetone

desc: An increase in the level of ketone bodies in the blood.
layperson: Increased level of ketone bodies in blood
name: Hyperketonemia
synonyms: Increased level of ketone bodies in blood

desc: An abnormality of a nucleobase metabolic process.
name: Abnormal circulating nucleobase concentration

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a purine in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal circulating purine concentration

desc: An abnormally high level of uric acid in the blood.
name: Hyperuricemia

desc: An increased level of xanthine in the blood circulation.
name: Hyperxanthinemia

desc: An abnormally low level of uric acid in the blood.
name: Hypouricemia

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a pyrimidine in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal circulating pyrimidine concentration

desc: An abnormality in a cellular process.
name: Abnormal cellular physiology

desc: An abnormality of chromosome segregation.
name: Abnormality of chromosome segregation

desc: An increase in the number of chromosome sets per cell in bone marrow cells.
layperson: Endopolyploidy on chromosome studies of bone marrow
name: Endopolyploidy on chromosome studies of bone marrow

desc: The presence of premature sister chromatid segregation.
name: Premature chromatid separation

desc: The intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent storage material.
layperson: Intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
name: Intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material

desc: An intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material in a curved pattern.
layperson: Curvilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material

name: Intraaxonal accumulation of curvilinear autofluorescent lipopigment storage material

desc: An intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material in a trabecular or fingerprint-like pattern.

name: Fingerprint intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material

desc: An intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material in a straight or rectilinear pattern.
layperson: Rectilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
name: Rectilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material

desc: A type of chromosomal aberration characterised by reduced resistance of chromosomes to change or deterioration.
name: Abnormality of chromosome stability

desc: An increase in the number of spontaneous sister chromatid exchanges observed in cell culture of lymphocytes or other cells.
layperson: Increased susceptibility to spontaneous sister chromatid exchange
name: Increased susceptibility to spontaneous sister chromatid exchange

desc: Elevated rate of chromosomal breakage or interchanges occurring either spontaneously or following exposure to various DNA-damaging agents. This feature may be assayed by treatment of cultured lymphocytes with agents such as chemical mutagens, irradiation, and alkylating agents.
name: Chromosome breakage
synonyms: High frequency of chromosome breaks in lymphocytes

desc: Increased amount of chromosomal breaks in cultured blood lymphocytes or other cells induced by treatment with DNA cross-linking agents such as diepoxybutane and mitomycin C.
layperson: Chromosomal breakage induced by crosslinking agents
name: Chromosomal breakage induced by crosslinking agents
synonyms: Chromosomal breakage induced by mitomycin C

desc: The presence of a folate sensitive fragile site at chromosome Xq28.
name: Folate-dependent fragile site at Xq28

desc: Increased amount of chromosomal breaks in cultured blood lymphocytes or other cells induced by treatment with ionizing radiation.
layperson: Chromosomal breakage induced by ionizing radiation
name: Chromosomal breakage induced by ionizing radiation
synonyms: Chromosomal breakage induced by ionising radiation

layperson: Increased cellular sensitivity to UV light
name: Increased cellular sensitivity to UV light

desc: An abnormality of the process of DNA repair, that is, of the process of restoring DNA after damage.
name: Abnormality of DNA repair

layperson: Defective DNA repair after ultraviolet radiation damage
name: Defective DNA repair after ultraviolet radiation damage

layperson: Deficient excision of UV-induced pyrimidine dimers in DNA
name: Deficient excision of UV-induced pyrimidine dimers in DNA

desc: An increased cellular sensitivity to the DNA cross-linking agent, mitomycin C (MMC). In the presence of increased sensitivity, MMC causes increased cell death, chromosome breakage, and accumulation in the G2 phase of the cell cycle.
name: Cellular hypersensitivity to mitomycin C

desc: An increased cellular sensitivity to the DNA cross-linking agent, diepoxybutane (DEB). In the presence of increased sensitivity, DEB causes cell death, chromosome breakage, and accumulation in the G2 phase of the cell cycle.
name: Cellular hypersensitivity to diepoxybutane

desc: A defect in the of the process of interstrand cross-link repair: removal of a DNA interstrand crosslink (a covalent attachment of DNA bases on opposite strands of the DNA) and restoration of the DNA. DNA interstrand crosslinks occur when both strands of duplex DNA are covalently tethered together (e.g. by an exogenous or endogenous agent), thus preventing the strand unwinding necessary for essential DNA functions such as transcription and replication.
name: Defective interstrand cross-link repair

desc: An increased concentration of cystine within cells. This finding can be demonstrated on leukocytes, but is not specific to blood cells.

desc: An increased concentration of cystine within white blood cells.
name: Elevated leukocyte cystine

desc: An abnormally increased sodium concentration in the cytosol.
name: Increased intracellular sodium

desc: Abnormality of glycosaminoglycan metabolism.
name: Abnormality of glycosaminoglycan metabolism

desc: An abnormality of the metabolism of mucopolysaccharide.
name: Abnormality of mucopolysaccharide metabolism

desc: Metachromasia (also known as metachromacy) is a characteristic color change which certain aniline dyes exhibit when bound to particular substances or when concentrated in solution. For example, the basic dye toluidine blue becomes distinctly pink when bound to cartilage matrix. In the sense used here, the metachromasia refers to a change in color not observed with normal tissues, anomalous staining with the cationic dyes toluidine blue O and Alcian blue resulting from excessive amounts of the polyanionic glycosaminoglycans.
name: Cellular metachromasia

desc: Increased cytoplasmic staining of fibroblasts with toluidine blue.

desc: An abnormality of the cell cycle.

layperson: Prolonged G2 phase of cell cycle
name: Prolonged G2 phase of cell cycle

desc: An abnormality of chromosome condensation.
name: Abnormality of chromosome condensation

desc: An increased rate of premature chromosome condensation.
layperson: Increased rate of premature chromosome condensation
name: Increased rate of premature chromosome condensation

desc: An abnormally increased sensitivity to the effects of ionizing radiation.
name: Increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation

name: Deficiency or absence of cytochrome b(-245)

name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial respiratory chain
synonyms: Decreased activity of mitochondrial respiratory complexes

name: Decreased activity of mitochondrial complex II

desc: A reduction in the activity of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex IV, which is part of the electron transport chain in mitochondria.

name: Increased activity of mitochondrial respiratory chain

desc: An abnormal reduction in mitochondrial DNA content of cells.

synonyms: Medium and short-chain L-3-hydroxyacyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase deficiency
Long chain 3 hydroxyacyl coA dehydrogenase deficiency

desc: Any structural anomaly of the mitochondria.
name: Abnormal mitochondrial morphology

desc: An anomaly in the surface contour of mitochondria.
name: Abnormal mitochondrial shape

desc: The mitochondrial matrix refers to the substance occupying the space enclosed by the inner membrane of a mitochondrion, which contains enzymes, DNA, granules, and inclusions of protein crystals, glycogen, and lipid. Mitochondrial swelling refers to an increase in size of the mitochondrial matrix. This phenomenon is thought to be related to a permeabilized inner membrane that originates a large swelling in the mitochondrial matrix. Mitochondrial swelling may distend the outer membrane until it ruptures.
name: Mitochondrial swelling

desc: A deviation from the normal number of mitochondria per cell.
name: Abnormal mitochondrial number

desc: An abnormality of the processes that maintain the redox environment of a cell or compartment within a cell, that is, the balance between reduction and oxidation chemical reactions.
name: Abnormality of redox activity

desc: An accumulation of free radical groups in the body inadequately neutralized by antioxidants, which creates a potentially unstable and damaging cellular environment linked to tissue damage.

name: Reduced reactive oxygen species production in neutrophils

desc: Any abnormality in the multiplication or reproduction of cells, which may result in the expansion of a cell population.

name: Decreased lymphocyte proliferation in response to anti-CD3

desc: An abnormality of the physiological functioning of B cells.
name: Abnormality of B cell physiology

desc: Impaired production of memory cells, the B cells that persist for years or an entire lifetime and which confer rapid and enhanced response to secondary challenge.
name: Impaired memory B cell generation

desc: An impairment of the class-switch recombination process that normally leads B lymphocytes to produce IgG, IgA, or IgE.
name: Impaired Ig class switch recombination

desc: A reduced ability of a B cell to become activated, i.e., the change in morphology and behavior of
name: Defective B cell activation

desc: Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity.

desc: At birth, newborns are endowed with maternal antibodies. IgG production normally begins at the age of two months. A delay in recovery from this physiological hypogammaglobulinemia between the 3rd and the 6th month of life, and of recovery period between 18 and 36 months defines transient newborn hypogammaglobulinemia.

name: Partial absence of specific antibody response to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine

desc: An abnormal level of isohemagglutinin in the blood. An isohemagglutinin refers to the naturally occurring antibodies in the ABO blood group system (i.e., anti-A in a group B person, anti-B in a group A person, and anti-A, anti-B, and anti-A,B in a group O person).

layperson: Increased anti-plant product IgE antibody level
name: Increased anti-plant product IgE antibody level

desc: Increased level of IgE antibody against galactose-alpha-1, 3 galactose (alpha-gal), a carbohydrate found in mammalian meat.
name: Increased anti-alpha-gal IgE antibody level
synonyms: Increased anti-galactose-alpha-1, 3 galactose IgE antibody level

desc: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgA immunoglobulin in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating IgA level

desc: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgE immunoglobulin in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating IgE level

desc: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgG immunoglobulin in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating IgG level

desc: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgM immunoglobulin in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating IgM level

desc: An abnormal deviation from normal levels of IgD immunoglobulin in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating IgD level

desc: A functional anomaly of T cells.
name: Abnormality of T cell physiology

desc: Delay in cutaneous immune reaction to specific antigens mediated not by antibodies but by cells. The delayed hypersensitivity test is an immune function test measuring the presence of activated T cells that recognize a specific antigen and is performed by injecting a small amount of the antigen into the skin. The area of the injection is examined 48-72 hours thereafter.
name: Abnormal delayed hypersensitivity skin test

desc: Inability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test.
name: Cutaneous anergy
synonyms: Lack of delayed skin hypersensitivity reaction
Absence of delayed hypersensitivity skin test

desc: Decreased ability to react to a delayed hypersensitivity skin test.
name: Reduced delayed hypersensitivity
synonyms: Decreased reactivity to skin test antigens

desc: Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
name: Lack of T cell function

desc: Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
name: Impaired T cell function

desc: The presence of a population of T cells with a restricted T cell receptor (TCR) repertoire derived from a limited number of TCR clones.
name: Oligoclonal T cell expansion

desc: Any abnormality in the activation of T cells, i.e. the change in morphology and behavior of a mature or immature T cell resulting from exposure to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
name: Abnormal T cell activation

desc: Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
name: Decreased T cell activation

desc: Any abnormality in the upregulation of CD69 on T cells after activation via the T cell receptor (TCR). Upregulation of CD69 is one of the earliest and most sensitive measures of antigen recognition in the periphery, and transient expression of CD69 is associated with positive selection in the thymus.
layperson: Abnormal CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation
name: Abnormal CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation

desc: Reduced or impaired upregulation of CD69 on T cells after activation via the T cell receptor (TCR).
layperson: Decreased CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation
name: Decreased CD69 upregulation upon TCR activation

desc: Any abnormality in the upregulation of CD25 on T cells after activation via the T cell receptor (TCR). CD25 is the alpha chain of the IL2 receptor. Ligation of the T cell antigen receptor leads to the induction of CD25 expression.
layperson: Abnormal CD25 upregulation upon TCR activation
name: Abnormal CD25 upregulation upon TCR activation

desc: Decreased or impaired upregulation of CD25 on T cells after activation via the T cell receptor (TCR).
layperson: Decreased CD25 upregulation upon TCR activation
name: Decreased CD25 upregulation upon TCR activation
synonyms: Reduced IL2RA upregulation upon TCR activation
Poor CD25 upregulation upon TCR activation

desc: A functional anomaly of the natural killer cell.
name: Abnormal natural killer cell physiology

desc: Reduced ability of the natural killer cell to function in the adaptive immune response.
name: Reduced natural killer cell activity

desc: A anomaly in the rate of apoptosis in lymphocytes.
name: Abnormal lymphocyte apoptosis

desc: A reduction in the rate of apoptosis in lymphocytes.
name: Decreased lymphocyte apoptosis

desc: A elevation in the rate of apoptosis in lymphocytes.
name: Increased lymphocyte apoptosis

desc: An increase in death of oocytes, the female germ cell (egg cell), which can be observed clinically in the setting of in vitro fertilization.
name: Increased oocyte death

desc: Intracellular accumulation of the lipid-linked oligosaccharide intermediate Man5GlcNAc2-PP-dolichol.
name: Intracellular accumulation of Dol-PP-GlcNAc2Man5

desc: The presence of amyloid deposition in one or more tissues. Amyloidosis may be defined as the extracellular deposition of amyloid in one or more sites of the body.
name: Amyloidosis

desc: A diffuse form of amyloidosis.
name: Generalized amyloid deposition

desc: Amyloid deposition in the walls of leptomeningeal and cortical arteries, arterioles, and less often capillaries and veins of the central nervous system.
name: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy

desc: A form of amyloidosis that affects the liver.
name: Hepatic amyloidosis

desc: The presence of amyloid deposition in the superficial dermis.
name: Cutaneous amyloidosis

desc: Lichen amyloidosis presents with multiple localized or rarely generalized, hyperpigmented grouped papules with a predilection for the shins, calves, ankles, and dorsa of the feet and thighs.
name: Cutaneous lichen amyloidosis

desc: A type of cutaneous amyloidosis that is characterized by hyperpigmented patches with indefinite margins composed of grayish brown macules, often with a reticulated or rippled appearance. Lesions may present as a hyperpigmented patch composed of small brown macules in a rippled or reticulated pattern.
name: Cutaneous macular amyloidosis

desc: A type of cutaneous amyloidosis that is characterized clinically by waxy, purpuric plaques and nodules and histologically by amyloid deposits in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.
name: Cutaneous nodular amyloidosis

desc: An anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium.
name: Abnormal homeostasis

desc: An abnormality of the balance or maintenance of the balance of acids and bases in bodily fluids, resulting in an abnormal pH.
name: Abnormality of acid-base homeostasis

desc: Abnormal acid accumulation or depletion of base.
name: Acidosis

desc: Acid accumulation or depletion of base in the body due to buildup of metabolic acids.
name: Metabolic acidosis

desc: Longstanding metabolic acidosis.
name: Chronic metabolic acidosis

desc: Repeated transient episodes of metabolic acidosis, that is, of the buildup of acid or depletion of base due to accumulation of metabolic acids.
name: Episodic metabolic acidosis

desc: Abnormally increased level of blood lactate (2-hydroxypropanoic acid). Lactate is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase during normal metabolism. The terms lactate and lactic acid are often used interchangeably but lactate (the component measured in blood) is strictly a weak base whereas lactic acid is the corresponding acid. Lactic acidosis is often used clinically to describe elevated lactate but should be reserved for cases where there is a corresponding acidosis (pH below 7.35).
name: Increased serum lactate
synonyms: Higher than normal levels of lactate in blood

desc: Abnormally increased level of blood lactate following a meal.
name: Postprandial hyperlactemia

desc: An abnormal buildup of lactic acid in the body, leading to acidification of the blood and other bodily fluids.
name: Lactic acidosis

desc: A form of lactic acidemia that occurs in relation to stress or infection.
name: Stress/infection-induced lactic acidosis

desc: A continuous form of lactic acidemia.
name: Persistent lactic acidosis

desc: A severe form of lactic acidemia.
name: Severe lactic acidosis

desc: A form of lactic acidemia that occurs following exercise or exertion.
name: Exercise-induced lactic acidemia

desc: A form of lactic acidemia with congenital onset.
name: Congenital lactic acidosis

desc: An intermittent (discontinuous) form of lactic acidemia.
name: Intermittent lactic acidemia

desc: A chronic form of lactic acidemia.
name: Chronic lactic acidosis

desc: Acidosis because of respiratory retention of carbon dioxide.
name: Respiratory acidosis

desc: Longstanding impairment in ventilation such that the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) is elevated above the upper limit of the reference range (more than 45 mm Hg), with a normal or near-normal pH secondary to renal compensation and an elevated serum bicarbonate levels (more than30 mEq/L).
name: Chronic respiratory acidosis

desc: Sudden onset of impairment in ventilation such that the removal of carbon dioxide by the respiratory system is less than the production of carbon dioxide in the tissues, leading to an elevation of the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) above the normal limits (more than 45 mm Hg) with an accompanying acidemia (pH less than 7.35).
name: Acute respiratory acidosis

desc: Longstanding abnormal acid accumulation or depletion of base.
name: Chronic acidosis

desc: Depletion of acid or accumulation base in the body fluids.
name: Alkalosis

desc: Alkalosis due to excess loss of carbon dioxide from the body.
name: Respiratory alkalosis

desc: Any deviation from the normal value of the serum anion gap, which is calculated from the electrolytes measured in the chemical laboratory, is defined as the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration.
name: Abnormal serum anion gap

desc: An abnormally high value of the serum anion gap (the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration).
name: Elevated serum anion gap

desc: An abnormally low value of the serum anion gap (the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration).
name: Decreased serum anion gap

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of bicarbonate, HCO3[-], in the circulation.
name: Abnormal serum bicarbonate concentration

desc: An abnormal reduction of the concentration of bicarbonate, HCO3[-], in the circulation.
name: Decreased serum bicarbonate concentration

desc: An abnormal increase in the concentration of bicarbonate, HCO3[-], in the circulation.
name: Elevated serum bicarbonate concentration

desc: Deviation from the normal quantity of base excess, defined as the amount of strong acid (in millimoles per liter) that needs to be added in vitro to 1 liter of fully oxygenated whole blood to return a blood sample to standard conditions (pH of 7.40, Pco2 of 40 mm Hg, and temperature of 37 degrees C).
name: Abnormal base excess

desc: An abnormally low blood pH (usually defined as less than 7.35).
name: Acidemia

desc: Increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the blood.
name: Methylmalonic acidemia

desc: An increased concentration of glutaric acid in the blood.
name: Glutaric acidemia

desc: An abnormally high blood pH (usually defined as 7.41 or above).
name: Alkalemia

desc: An abnormal increase in the molar ratio of lactate to pyruvate in the blood circulation.
name: Elevated lactate:pyruvate ratio

desc: An abnormality of temperature homeostasis.
name: Abnormality of temperature regulation

desc: Elevated body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.
name: Fever

desc: Periodic (episodic or recurrent) bouts of fever.
name: Recurrent fever

desc: Episodic fever that recurs at regular intervals.
name: Periodic fever

desc: Episodic fever that recurs at irregular intervals.
name: Non-periodic recurrent fever

desc: Episodes of fever for which no infectious cause can be identified.
name: Unexplained fevers

desc: Mild fever that does not exceed 38.5 degree centrigrade.
name: Low-grade fever

desc: Reduced body temperature due to failed thermoregulation.
name: Hypothermia

desc: Episodes of reduced body termperature.
name: Intermittent hypothermia

desc: The inability to maintain a comfortably body temperature in warm or hot weather.
name: Heat intolerance

desc: Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by a rapid increase in temperature to 39-42 degrees C in response to inhalational anesthetics such as halothane or to muscle relaxants such as succinylcholine.
name: Malignant hyperthermia

desc: Disordered thermoregulation characterized by an impaired ability to maintain a balance between heat production and heat loss, with resulting instability of body temperature.
name: Temperature instability

desc: Abnormality of glucose homeostasis.
name: Abnormal glucose homeostasis

desc: Increased resistance towards insulin, that is, diminished effectiveness of insulin in reducing blood glucose levels.
layperson: Body fails to respond to insulin
name: Insulin resistance
synonyms: Body fails to respond to insulin

desc: Glucose intolerance (GI) can be defined as dysglycemia that comprises both prediabetes and diabetes. It includes the conditions of impaired fasting glucose (IFG) and impaired glucose tolerance (IGT) and diabetes mellitus (DM).
name: Glucose intolerance

desc: An abnormal resistance to glucose, i.e., a reduction in the ability to maintain glucose levels in the blood stream within normal limits following oral or intravenous administration of glucose.
name: Impaired glucose tolerance

desc: An abnormal resistance to glucose, i.e., a reduction in the ability to maintain glucose levels in the blood stream within normal limits following oral administration of glucose.
name: Abnormal oral glucose tolerance

desc: An impairment of gluconeogenesis.
name: Impaired gluconeogenesis

desc: Decreased sensitivity toward insulin.
name: Insulin insensitivity

desc: An abnormality of the concentration of glucose in the blood.
name: Abnormal blood glucose concentration

desc: A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
name: Hypoglycemia

desc: A decreased concentration of glucose in the blood associated with a reduced concentration of ketone bodies.
name: Hypoketotic hypoglycemia

desc: Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood.
name: Recurrent hypoglycemia

desc: Recurrent episodes of decreased concentration of glucose in the blood occurring during the infantile period.
layperson: Recurrent low blood sugar in infant
name: Recurrent infantile hypoglycemia
synonyms: Recurrent low blood sugar in infant

desc: Hypoglycermia following a meal (or more generally, after intake of glucose).
layperson: Low blood sugar after a meal
name: Reactive hypoglycemia
synonyms: Low blood sugar after a meal

desc: Low blood glucose is accompanied by elevated levels of ketone bodies in the body.
name: Ketotic hypoglycemia

desc: An increased concentration of glucose in the blood.
name: Hyperglycemia

desc: An increased concentration of glucose in the blood following a meal.
name: Postprandial hyperglycemia

desc: An elevated concentration of proinsulin (the prohormone precursor to insulin) to mature insulin in the circulation.
name: Increased proinsulin:insulin ratio

desc: An abnormality of the regulation of body fluids.
name: Abnormality of fluid regulation

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
name: Edema

desc: Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.
layperson: Swelling caused by excess lymph fluid under skin
name: Lymphedema
synonyms: Swelling caused by excess lymph fluid under skin

desc: Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system, affecting mainly the legs.
name: Predominantly lower limb lymphedema

desc: Fluid retention and edema in the intestine caused by a compromised lymphatic system.
name: Intestinal lymphedema

desc: The presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the pleural cavity.
name: Pleural effusion

desc: Accumulation of excessive amounts of lymphatic fluid (chyle) in the pleural cavity.
name: Chylothorax

desc: Accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity.
name: Pleural empyema

desc: A type of pleural effusion with a transudate (extravascular fluid with low protein content and a low specific gravity). Pleural effusions can be classified as transudates or exudates based on Light's criteria, which classify an effusion as exudate if one or more of the following are present: (1) the ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5, (2) the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH is greater than 0.6, or (3) the pleural fluid LDH level is greater than two thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.
name: Transudative pleural effusion

desc: A type of pleural effusion with a exudate (extravascular fluid that has exuded out of a tissue or its capillaries due to injury or inflammation). Pleural effusions can be classified as transudates or exudates based on Light's criteria, which classify an effusion as exudate if one or more of the following are present: (1) the ratio of pleural fluid protein to serum protein is greater than 0.5, (2) the ratio of pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH is greater than 0.6, or (3) the pleural fluid LDH level is greater than two thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.
name: Exudative pleural effusion

desc: Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
name: Intestinal edema

desc: Generalized abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body.
name: Generalized edema

desc: An extreme form of generalized edema with widespread and massive edema due to effusion of fluid into the extracellular space.
name: Anasarca

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the hands.
layperson: Edema of the dorsum of hands
name: Edema of the dorsum of hands
synonyms: Oedema of the dorsum of hands

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body because of decreased osmotic pressure of plasma (hypoproteinemia).
name: Hypoproteinemic edema

desc: An abnormal accumulation of excess fluid in the lower extremity resulting in swelling of the feet and extending upward to the lower leg.
name: Pedal edema

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin on the back of the feet.
layperson: Edema of the dorsum of feet
name: Edema of the dorsum of feet
synonyms: Oedema of the dorsum of feet

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin of the arms.
name: Edema of the upper limbs

desc: An abnormal accumulation of fluid and swelling in the tissues of the larynx.
name: Laryngeal edema

desc: An abnormal accumulation of interstitial fluid in the soft tissues of the limbs.
name: Peripheral edema

desc: A buildup of fluid that causes swelling in the soft tissues of the genital area.
name: Genital edema

desc: Fluid accumulation in the lungs.
name: Pulmonary edema

desc: Any anomaly in the utilization of energy (calories).
name: Abnormal energy expenditure

desc: An increase in the number of calories used per unit time.
name: Increased resting energy expenditure

desc: A reduction in the number of calories used per unit time.
name: Decreased resting energy expenditure

desc: A detrimental reaction to a food, beverage, food additive, or compound found in foods that produces symptoms in one or more body organs and systems that is not mediated by an immune reaction.
name: Food intolerance

desc: A detrimental reaction to the presence of gluten in food, which may include abdominal pain, fatigue, headaches and paresthesia, or celiac disease.
name: Gluten intolerance

desc: An abnormality of the composition of sweat or the levels of its components.
name: Abnormal sweat homeostasis

desc: An increased concentration of chloride in the sweat.
name: Elevated sweat chloride

desc: An altered ability of any enzyme or their cofactors to act as catalysts. This term includes changes due to altered levels of an enzyme.
name: Abnormal enzyme/coenzyme activity

desc: An abnormality of the tricarboxylic acid cycle.
name: Abnormality of Krebs cycle metabolism

desc: A decreased rate of pyruvate carboxylase activity.
name: Decreased pyruvate carboxylase activity

desc: An abnormality of Krebs cycle metabolism that is characterized by a decreased rate of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase activity.
name: Decreased methylmalonyl-CoA mutase activity

desc: An abnormality of Krebs cycle metabolism that is characterized by a decreased rate of fumarate hydratase activity.
name: Decreased fumarate hydratase activity

desc: A reduction in aldehyde oxidase level.
name: Aldehyde oxidase deficiency

desc: An abnormal decrease in orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase level.
name: Reduced orotidine 5-prime phosphate decarboxylase level

desc: Reduced level of the enzyme glutathione synthetase, which catalyzes the last step in the synthesis of glutathione and a deficiency results in low levels of glutathione. Acidosis is due to reduced feedback inhibition of gamma-glutamyl cysteine synthetase in the gamma-glutamyl cycle, which ultimately leads to overproduction and accumulation of 5-oxoproline.
name: Reduced glutathione synthetase level

desc: A reduction in the rate of cholesterol esterification.
name: Low cholesterol esterification rate

desc: An abnormality of amino acid metabolism characterized by a decreased level of propionyl-CoA carboxylase.
name: Propionyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency

desc: A reduction in methionine synthase activity.
name: Decreased methionine synthase activity

desc: Decreased level of acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (ADH). ADH and alcohol dehydrogenase (ALDH) are the primary enzymes involved in alcohol metabolism.
name: Reduced acetaldehyde dehydrogenase level

desc: An abnormal reduction in xanthine dehydrogenase level.
name: Reduced xanthine dehydrogenase level

desc: An increased level of iduronate-2-sulfatase activity in the blood.
name: Increased serum iduronate sulfatase level

desc: A decreased level of glucose-6-phosphate isomerase.
name: Decreased glucosephosphate isomerase level

desc: Absence of molybdenum cofactor(2-), a cofactor for enzymes including sulfite oxidase, xanthine oxidoreductase, and aldehyde oxidase.
name: Molybdenum cofactor deficiency

desc: An abnormal reduction in 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase level.
name: Reduced 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase level

desc: Abnormally reduced sulfite oxidase level.
name: Sulfite oxidase deficiency

desc: Abnormality of glycoside metabolism.
name: Abnormality of glycoside metabolism

desc: Abnormality of galactoside metabolism. A galactoside is a glycoside (a suger moiety bound to some other moiety) containing galactose.
name: Abnormality of galactoside metabolism

desc: Abnormally decreased rate of beta-galactosidase activity. Beta-galactosidase activity can be measured in leukocyte, fibroblast, or plasma.
name: Decreased beta-galactosidase activity
synonyms: Beta-galactosidase deficiency in fibroblasts and white blood cells

desc: An abnormal reduction in dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (NADP+) level.
name: Reduced dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase level

desc: An abnormality of glycoprotein metabolism related to a decreased level of alpha-1,6-mannosylglycoprotein 2-beta-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase activity.
name: Reduced level of N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase II

desc: Reduced level of the enzyme beta-glucosidase, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucosylceramide into ceramide and glucose.
name: Decreased beta-glucocerebrosidase level

desc: An abnormality of alkaline phosphatase level.
name: Abnormality of alkaline phosphatase level

desc: Abnormally increased serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity.
name: Elevated alkaline phosphatase

desc: Increased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes.
name: Elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
name: Elevated tissue non-specific alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally increased level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
layperson: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
name: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin

desc: An abnormally increased level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
name: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
synonyms: Elevated alkaline phosphatase of bone origin

desc: An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, intestinal type in the blood.
name: Elevated intestinal alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally increased level of alkaline phosphatase, placental type in the blood.
name: Elevated placental alkaline phosphatase

desc: Abnormally reduced serum levels of alkaline phosphatase.
name: Low alkaline phosphatase

desc: Decreased alkaline phosphatase measured within leukocytes.
name: Reduced leukocyte alkaline phosphatase

desc: Alkaline phosphatase levels measured within leukocytes is below detectable levels.
name: Absent leukocyte alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, tissue-nonspecific isozyme in the blood.
name: Low tissue non-specific alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally reduced level of bone isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood.
layperson: Low alkaline phosphatase of bone origin
name: Low alkaline phosphatase of bone origin

desc: An abnormally reduced level of liver isoforms of alkaline phosphatase in the blood.
layperson: Low alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin
name: Low alkaline phosphatase of hepatic origin

desc: An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, intestinal type in the blood.
name: Low intestinal alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase, placental type in the blood.
name: Low placental alkaline phosphatase

desc: An abnormally reduced level of alkaline phosphatase in neutrophils, which could be due to absence of enzyme or the production of defective enzyme.
name: Low neutrophil alkaline phosphatase

desc: A reduction in phenylalanine 4-monooxygenase level.
name: Reduced phenylalanine hydroxylase level

desc: Reduced carnitine O-palmitoyltransferase level, leading to a reduced activity of the reaction: palmitoyl-CoA + L-carnitine = CoA + L-palmitoylcarnitine.
name: Reduced carnitine O-palmitoyltransferase level

desc: An abnormal concentration of aldolase in the serum. Aldolase is an enzyme responsible for converting fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into the triose phosphates dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate.
name: Abnormal aldolase level

desc: An increased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum.
name: Elevated aldolase level

desc: An decreased concentration of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate aldolase in the serum.
name: Reduced aldolase level

desc: An abnormally decreased amount of catalase level.
name: Reduced catalase level

desc: A decreased amount of cholinesterase in the blood circulation.
name: Reduced cholinesterase level

desc: Lactase is produced in the small intestine in humans, Lactase is a member of the beta-galactosidase family of enzymes, and hydrolyzes D-lactose to form D-galactose and D-glucose, which can be absorbed by the small intestine. There are many ways of assessing lactase activity. In one test, an endoscopic biopsy from the postbulbar duodenum is incubated with lactose on a test plate, and a color reaction develops within 20 min as a result of hydrolyzed lactose (a positive result) in patients with normolactasia, whereas no reaction (a negative result) develops in patients with severe hypolactasia. Other, less direct, tests include the hydrogen breath test, and blood tests following lactose challenges.
layperson: Decreased small intestinal mucosa lactase level
name: Decreased small intestinal mucosa lactase level

desc: Reduced level of the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase.
layperson: Decreased lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase level
name: Decreased lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase level

desc: Increased level of the enzyme gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT). GGT is mainly present in kidney, liver, and pancreatic cells, but small amounts are present in other tissues.
name: Elevated gamma-glutamyltransferase level

desc: Reduction in the activity of lysosomal acid lipase (LAL) in the blood. Lysosomal lipase activity is measured. LAL hydrolyzes cholesteryl esters derived from cell internalization of plasma lipoproteins.
name: Reduced lysosomal acid lipase activity

desc: Reduction in the level of lipoprotein lipase in the blood.
name: Decreased lipoprotein lipase level

desc: Altered level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.
name: Abnormal hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level

desc: Abnormally increased level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.
name: Elevated hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level

desc: Abnormally decreased level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.
name: Reduced hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level

desc: An abnormal level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.
name: Abnormal superoxide dismutase level

desc: Increased level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.
name: Increased superoxide dismutase level

desc: Decreased level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.
name: Decreased superoxide dismutase level

desc: Any deviation from the normal circulating concentration of mast cell beta-tryptase concentration.
layperson: Abnormal serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration
name: Abnormal serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration

desc: An abnormally elevated circulating concentration of mast cell beta-tryptase concentration.
layperson: Increased serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration
name: Increased serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration

desc: An abnormally reduced circulating concentration of mast cell beta-tryptase concentration.
layperson: Decreased serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration
name: Decreased serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration

desc: Any deviation from the normal level of the enzyme phosphoribosyl pyrophosphatesynthetase, which catalyzes the synthesis of PP-ribose-P from ATP and ribose-5-phosphate.
name: Abnormal phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase level

desc: Abnormally elevated level of the enzyme phosphoribosyl pyrophosphatesynthetase, which catalyzes the synthesis of PP-ribose-P from ATP and ribose-5-phosphate.
name: Increased phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase level

desc: Abnormally reduced level of the enzyme phosphoribosyl pyrophosphatesynthetase, which catalyzes the synthesis of PP-ribose-P from ATP and ribose-5-phosphate.
name: Decreased phosphoribosylpyrophosphate synthetase level

desc: Reduced level of succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase (SSADH).
name: Decreased succinic semialdehyde dehydrogenase level

desc: An increased level of triacylglycerol lipase in the blood circulation (can be measured in serum or plasma).
layperson: Increased circulating pancreatic triacylglycerol lipase level
name: Increased circulating pancreatic triacylglycerol lipase level
synonyms: Elevated circulating pancreatic triacylglycerol lipase activity

desc: Decreased level of the reaction 5-oxo-L-proline + ATP + 2 H(2)O = L-glutamate + ADP + 2 H(+) + phosphate.
name: Reduced 5-oxoprolinase level

desc: Reduced level of platelet-activating factor acetylhydrolase.
name: Platelet-activating factor acetylhydrolase deficiency

desc: A deviation from the normal serum concentration/activity of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), which catalyzes the reduction of pyruvate to form lactate.
name: Abnormal lactate dehydrogenase level

desc: An elevated level of the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase in serum.
name: Increased lactate dehydrogenase level

desc: A decreased or reduced level of the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase in serum.
name: Reduced lactate dehydrogenase B level

desc: An abnormality in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.
name: Abnormal biotinidase level

desc: A decrease in the biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.
name: Decreased biotinidase level

desc: An increase in biotinidase level, an enzyme that releases biotin from biocytin, the product of biotin-dependent carboxylases degradation.
name: Increased biotinidase level

desc: An abnormality in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level, an enzyme that catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.
name: Abnormal uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level

desc: An abnormality in uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase level in plasma. Uridine diphosphate glucose-4-epimerase catalyzes the reaction: UDP-glucose = UDP-galactose.

desc: An anomlous response to a medication related to individual variation in metabolic or immune response to drugs varying from potentially from potentially life-threatening adverse drug reactions to alteration of therapeutic efficacy.
name: Abnormal drug response

desc: High plasma concentration of a drug as compared to previously measured thresholds given the expected concentration for the applied dosage regime.
name: Increased blood drug concentration

desc: Low plasma concentration of a drug as compared to previously measured thresholds given the expected concentration for the applied dosage regime.
name: Decreased blood drug concentration

desc: An unpleasant or harmful reaction resulting from treatment with a drug.
name: Adverse drug response

desc: Decreased response to a drug intervention in comparison to the expected response.
name: Reduced drug efficacy

desc: Absent or significantly reduced efficacy of drug intervention characterized by lack of measurable benefit or deterioration of disease course.
name: Refractory drug response

desc: A deviation from normal range of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), a test that measures the distance that erythrocytes have fallen after one hour in a vertical column of anticoagulated blood under the influence of gravity. The ESR is a nonspecific finding. An elevation may indicate inflammation or may be caused by any condition that elevates fibrinogen. A decreased ESR may be seen in polycythemia or in certain blood diseases in which red blood cells have an irregular or smaller shape that causes slower settling.
name: Abnormal erythrocyte sedimentation rate

desc: An increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The ESR a test that measures the distance that erythrocytes have fallen after one hour in a vertical column of anticoagulated blood under the influence of gravity. The ESR is a nonspecific finding. An elevation may indicate inflammation or may be caused by any condition that elevates fibrinogen.
name: Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate

desc: A reduced erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The ESR is a test that measures the distance that erythrocytes have fallen after one hour in a vertical column of anticoagulated blood under the influence of gravity. The ESR is a nonspecific finding. A decreased ESR may be seen in polycythemia or in certain blood diseases in which red blood cells have an irregular or smaller shape that causes slower settling.
name: Decreased erythrocyte sedimentation rate

desc: Presence of a chemical substance found within an individual that is not naturally produced or expected to be present in human tissues or bodily fluids.

A high TIBC corresponds to a high transferrin concentration. The latent (or free) iron binding capacity is the difference between the TIBC and the measured serum iron, corresponding to the transferrin not bound to iron, i.e., free iron binding capacity.

desc: Any abnormality in the serum transferrin saturation, which is calculated by dividing the serum iron level by total iron-binding capacity.

desc: An abnormal concentration of an HDL subfraction, which can be determined by methods such as electrophoresis followed by densitometric determination of the areas under the peaks. Small HDL subfractions are defined as HDL3a (8.2-8.79 nm), HDL3b (7.8-8.19 nm), and HDL3c (7.20-7.79 nm).
name: Abnormal HDL subfraction concentration

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of haptoglobin in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal haptoglobin level

desc: An abnormally high concentration of haptoglobin in the blood circulation. Haptoglobin is an acute-phase reactant whose levels can become elevated in the presence of infection and inflammation.
name: Elevated haptoglobin level

desc: An abnormally low concentration of haptoglobin in the blood circulation. Decreased haptoglobin in conjunction with increased reticulocyte count and anemia may indicate hemolysis. Decreased haptoglobin levels can also occur in the absence of hemolysis, due to cirrhosis of the liver, disseminated ovarian carcinomatosis, pulmonary sarcoidosis, and elevated estrogen state.
name: Reduced haptoglobin level

desc: A measurable change in circulating levels of Atrial natriuretic peptide hormone, a protein which plays an important role in the regulation of body fluid volume and blood pressure.
layperson: Abnormal A-type atrial natriuretic peptide level
name: Abnormal A-type atrial natriuretic peptide level

desc: A measurable elevation in circulating levels of Atrial natriuretic peptide hormone, a protein which plays an important role in the regulation of body fluid volume and blood pressure.
layperson: Increased circulating A-type natriuretic peptide level
name: Increased circulating A-type natriuretic peptide level

desc: A measurable reduction in circulating levels of Atrial natriuretic peptide hormone, a protein which plays an important role in the regulation of body fluid volume and blood pressure.
layperson: Decreased circulating A-type natriuretic peptide level
name: Decreased circulating A-type natriuretic peptide level

desc: An increased concentration of prostate specific antigen (PSA) in the circulation.
name: Elevated prostate-specific antigen level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration in blood of an apolipoprotein, i.e., of a protein that binds lipids to form lipoprotein and is thereby responsible for the transport of lipids in the blood and lymph circulation.
name: Abnormal apolipoprotein level

desc: An increased concentration in blood of apolipoprotein A-IV, a major component of HDL and chylomicrons that has a role in VLDL secretion and catabolism and is required for efficient activation of lipoprotein lipase by ApoC-II.
name: Elevated apolipoprotein A-IV level

desc: Increased circulating level of apolipoprotein B, which is the main apolipoprotein of chylomicrons and low density lipoproteins. It occurs in plasma as two main isoforms, apoB-48 and apoB-100.
name: Elevated apolipoprotein B level

desc: Reduced criculating level of apolipoprotein AI, which is the major protein component of high density lipoprotein (HDL) in plasma. Defects in this gene are associated with HDL deficiencies, including Tangier disease.
name: Decreased apolipoprotein AI level

desc: An increased concentration in blood of apolipoprotein A-II, a major component of HDL particles, associated with triglyceride and glucose metabolism.
name: Elevated apolipoprotein A-II level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of thyroglobulin, a protein produced in the thyroid gland that acts as a precursor to thyrroid hormones.
name: Abnormal circulating thyroglobulin level

desc: An abnormal elevation of the concentration of thyroglobulin, a protein produced in the thyroid gland that acts as a precursor to thyrroid hormones.
name: Increased circulating thyroglobulin level

desc: Absence of ceruloplasmin in the blood.
name: Aceruloplasminemia

desc: An anomolous circulating concentration of the connecting (C) peptide, which links the insulin A and B chains in proinsulin, providing thereby a means to promote their efficient folding and assembly in the endoplasmic reticulum during insulin biosynthesis. After cleavage of proinsulin, C-peptide is stored with insulin in the soluble phase of the secretory granules and is subsequently released in equimolar amounts with insulin, providing a useful independent indicator of insulin secretion.
name: Abnormal C-peptide level

desc: A decreased concentration of C-peptide in the circulation. Since C-peptide is secreted in equimolar amounts to insulin, this feature correlates with reduced insulin secretion.
name: Reduced C-peptide level

desc: An elevated concentration of C-peptide in the circulation. Since C-peptide is secreted in equimolar amounts to insulin, this feature correlates with increased insulin secretion.
name: Increased C-peptide level

desc: An increased blood concentration of the carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA). CEA is a member of the immunoglobulin supergene family. The human CEA gene family is clustered on chromosome 19q and comprises 29 genes. CEA is highly expressed in embryonic tissue and in some cancers, and is a widely used tumor marker.
name: Elevated carcinoembryonic antigen level

desc: An increased blood concentration of carcinoma antigen 125 (CA-125). CA-125, also known as mucin 16, can exhibit increased blood levels in certain types of cancer.
name: Elevated carcinoma antigen 125 level

desc: A deviation from normal blood concentration of retinol-binding protein (RBP). The most commonly used indicator of vitamin A status is the serum retinol concentration (retinol is one of the several compounds known as vitamin A). The serum RBP concentration is used as a surrogate measure for serum retinol.
name: Abnormal retinol-binding protein level

desc: A reduced blood concentration of retinol-binding protein. This finding predicts vitamin A deficiency with high sensitivity and specificity.
name: Decreased retinol-binding protein level

desc: A deviation from the normal blood concentration of the insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit (IGFALS; Entrez Gene ID 3483). The acid-labile subunit (IGFALS) acts in the insulin-like growth (IGF) system by binding circulating IGF1 in a ternary complex with binding protein (IGFBP)-3 to prevent IGF1 from crossing the endothelial barrier.
layperson: Abnormal insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level
name: Abnormal insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level

desc: Blood concentration of insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level below normal limits.
layperson: Reduced insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level
name: Reduced insulin like growth factor binding protein acid labile subunit level
synonyms: Decreased levels of acid labile subunit

desc: A decreased blood concentration of growth hormone binding protein.
name: Reduced growth-hormone binding protein level

desc: Blood concentration of insulin-like factor 3 (ILF3) is below normal limits.
name: Reduced insulin-like factor 3 level

desc: A reduced concentration of prealbumin in the blood. Prealbumin, also known as transthyretin, has a half-life in plasma of about 2 days, much shorter than that of albumin. Prealbumin is therefore more sensitive to changes in protein-energy status than albumin, and its concentration closely reflects recent dietary intake rather than overall nutritional status.
name: Decreased prealbumin level

desc: A deviation from the normal circulating concentration of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP).
name: Abnormal B-type natriuretic peptide level

desc: An elevated level of circulating N-terminal part of the prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP).
name: Increased NT-proBNP level

desc: An elevated concentration of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) in the blood.
name: Increased circulating thyroxine-binding globulin level

desc: A decreased concentration of sex-hormone binding protein in the circulation.
name: Reduced sex -hormone binding protein level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of beta-C-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen in the blood circulation, a marker of the rate of bone turnover.
name: Abnormal circulating beta-C-terminal telopeptide level

desc: A abnormal elevation above the normal concentration of beta-C-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen in the blood circulation.
name: Increased circulating beta-C-terminal telopeptide level

desc: A reduction from the normal concentration of beta-C-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased circulating beta-C-terminal telopeptide level

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal hepcidin level

desc: An abnormally reduced concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation.
name: Decreased hepcidin level

desc: An abnormally increased concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation.
name: Elevated hepcidin level

desc: A reduced concentration of circulating alpha-1 antitrypsin, which is a 52-kDa glycoprotein mainly synthesised and secreted by hepatocytes into the bloodstream. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a serine-proteinase inhibitor that it is crucial in maintaining protease-antiprotease homeostasis in the lungs.
name: Reduced serum alpha-1-antitrypsin

desc: An increased concentration of a surfactant protein in the blood circulation. Pulmonary surfactant is a highly surface-active mixture of proteins and lipids that is synthesized and secreted onto the alveoli by type II epithelial cells. The protein part of surfactant constitutes of four types of surfactant proteins (SP), SP-A, SP-B, SP-C and SP-D. SP-A and SP-D are hydrophilic proteins that regulate surfactant metabolism and have immunologic functions. These two proteins are detectable in the bloodstream and an elevated level may reflect idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
name: Increased circulating surfactant protein level

desc: An abnormal concentration of globulins in the blood. Albumin makes up more than half of the total protein present in serum. The remaining blood proteins except albumin and fibrinogen (which is not in serum) are referred to as globulins. The globulin fraction includes hundreds of serum proteins including carrier proteins, enzymes, complement, and immunoglobulins. Most of these are synthesized in the liver, although the immunoglobulins are synthesized by plasma cells. Globulins are divided into four groups by electrophoresis. The four fractions are alpha1, alpha2, beta and gamma, depending on their migratory pattern between the anode and the cathode.
name: Abnormal circulating globulin level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of beta globulin. The beta globulins are a group of globular (globe-shaped) proteins in blood.
name: Abnormal circulating beta globulin level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of beta-2-microglobulin in the blood.
name: Abnormality of circulating beta-2-microglobulin level
synonyms: Abnormality of circulating beta2 microglobulin level

desc: Elevated concentration of beta-2-microglobulin in the blood.
name: Increased circulating beta-2-microglobulin level

desc: Reduced concentration of beta-2-microglobulin in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating beta-2-microglobulin level

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration of properdin in the blood.

desc: A deviation from the normal concentration in the circulation of sex hormone-binding globulin, a circulating glycoprotein that transports testosterone and other steroids in the blood.
