desc: A deviation from the normal concentration in the circulation of angiostatin, an endogenous angiogenesis inhibitor, which blocks the growth of new blood vessels.

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of transferrin in the blood circulation.

desc: Absence of transferrin, a protein that transports iron, in the blood.

desc: An abnormally elevated concentration of globulins in the blood.

desc: An abnormally increased level of circulationg alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant.
name: Increased alpha-globulin

desc: An abnormally reduced concentration of globulins in the blood.
name: Decreased circulating globulin level

desc: Galectin-3 is a member of the family of beta-galactoside-binding endogenous lectins. It is a multifunctional factor that binds to distinct ligands and triggers production of matrix metalloproteinases, and thereby plays a role in cardiac fibrosis and remodelling.

synonyms: An increased circulation of galectin-3 in the blood circulation.

name: Increased fecal coproporphyrin 3

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of a metabolite in saliva.
name: Abnormal salivary metabolite concentration

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of cortisol in saliva.
name: Abnormal salivary cortisol level

desc: Abnormally reduced concentration of cortisol in saliva.
name: Decreased salivary cortisol level

desc: Abnormally elevated concentration of cortisol in saliva.
name: Increased salivary cortisol level

desc: An abnormality of the respiratory system, which include the airways, lungs, and the respiratory muscles.
name: Abnormality of the respiratory system

desc: Respiratory difficulty as newborn.
name: Neonatal respiratory distress

desc: Respiratory failure in the newborn.
name: Neonatal asphyxia

layperson: Decreased lung function due to weak breathing muscles
name: Respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness
synonyms: Decreased respiratory function due to muscle weakness
Decreased lung function due to weak breathing muscles
Respiratory failure due to muscle weakness
Respiratory distress due to muscle weakness

layperson: Intermittent episodes of respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness
name: Intermittent episodes of respiratory insufficiency due to muscle weakness

desc: A severe form of respiratory insufficiency characterized by inadequate gas exchange such that the levels of oxygen or carbon dioxide cannot be maintained within normal limits.
name: Respiratory failure

desc: A state of respiratory distress that requires a life saving intervention in the form of gaining airway access and instituting positive pressure ventilation.
name: Respiratory failure requiring assisted ventilation

layperson: Ventilator dependence with inability to wean
name: Ventilator dependence with inability to wean

layperson: Respiratory insufficiency due to defective ciliary clearance
name: Respiratory insufficiency due to defective ciliary clearance

desc: Difficult or labored breathing.
name: Dyspnea

desc: Difficulty in breathing. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea.
name: Respiratory distress

desc: Widening of the nostrils upon inhalation as a manifestation of respiratory distress.
name: Nasal flaring

desc: A pulling inward of the soft tissues between the ribs upon inhalation. This is a sign of increased use of the chest muscles for breathing and is a manifestation of respiratory distress.
name: Intercostal retractions

desc: A sudden attack of dyspnea that occurs while the affected person is at rest.
name: Paroxysmal dyspnea

desc: A sensation of breathlessness in the recumbent position, relieved by sitting or standing.
name: Orthopnea

desc: Asthma is characterized by increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to multiple stimuli, leading to narrowing of the air passages with resultant dyspnea, cough, and wheezing.
name: Asthma

desc: A type of asthma in which aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) that inhibit cyclooxygen-ase 1 (COX-1) exacerbate bronchoconstriction.
name: Aspirin-induced asthma

desc: Asthma attacks following exercise.
name: Exercise-induced asthma

desc: Severe asthma unresponsive to repeated courses of beta-agonist therapy such as inhaled albuterol, levalbuterol, or subcutaneous epinephrine.
name: Status asthmaticus

desc: Increased resistance to the passage of air in the upper airway.
name: Upper airway obstruction

desc: Intermittent episodes of increased resistance to the passage of air in the upper airway.
name: Episodic upper airway obstruction

desc: An abnormal reduction on the vital capacity, which is defined as the total lung capacity (volume of air in the lungs at maximal inflation) less the residual volume (i.e., volume of air in the lungs following maximal exhalation) of the lung.
name: Reduced vital capacity

desc: An anomaly of the rhythm or depth of breathing.
name: Abnormal pattern of respiration

desc: Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event.
name: Apnea

desc: Apnea resulting from depression of the respiratory centers in the medulla oblongata. There is a lack of respiratory effort rather than obstruction of airflow.
name: Central apnea

desc: Recurrent episodes of apnea that are precipitated by factors such as illness, fatigue, or stress.
layperson: Apneic episodes precipitated by illness, fatigue, stress
name: Apneic episodes precipitated by illness, fatigue, stress
synonyms: Episodic apnea induced by febrile illness or stress

desc: Recurrent bouts of sudden, severe apnea that may be life-threatening.
name: Sudden episodic apnea

desc: Recurrent episodes of apnea occurring during infancy.
name: Apneic episodes in infancy

desc: Very rapid breathing.
layperson: Increased respiratory rate or depth of breathing
name: Tachypnea
synonyms: Increased respiratory rate or depth of breathing

desc: Episodes of very rapid breathing.
name: Episodic tachypnea

desc: A reduction in the amount of air transported into the pulmonary alveoli by breathing, leading to hypercapnia (increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide).
name: Hypoventilation

desc: Hyperventilation refers to an increased pulmonary ventilation rate that is faster than necessary for the exchange of gases. Hyperventilation can result from increased frequency of breathing, an increased tidal volume, or both, and leads to an excess intake of oxygen and the blowing off of carbon dioxide.
name: Hyperventilation

desc: Episodic hyperventilation.
name: Intermittent hyperventilation

desc: Uneven rhythm of breathing.
name: Irregular respiration

desc: An abnormal pattern of respiration characterized by cycles of respiration that are increasingly deeper then shallower with possible periods of apnea. Affected patients may display a 10 to 20 second episode of hypoventilation or apnea, followed by respiration of increased depth and frequency over the course of about one minute. The cycle repeats every 45 seconds to 3 minutes.
name: Cheyne-Stokes respiration

desc: Breathing movements in which the chest wall moves in on inspiration and out on expiration, in reverse of the normal movements. It may be seen in children with respiratory distress of any cause, which leads to indrawing of the intercostal spaces during inspiration. Patients with chronic airways obstruction also show indrawing of the lower ribs during inspiration, due to the distorted action of a depressed and flattened diaphragm. Crush injuries of the chest, with fractured ribs and sternum, can lead to a severe degree of paradoxical breathing.
name: Paradoxical respiration

desc: Waking up at night gasping for breath.
name: Night gasping

desc: Hypopnea is referring to breathing that is abnormally shallow.
name: Hypopnea

desc: Bradypnea is referring to breathing that is abnormally slow.
name: Bradypnea

desc: Inspiration of a foreign object into the airway.
name: Aspiration

desc: Reduced function of the muscles required to generate subatmospheric pressure in the thoracic cavity during breathing: the diaphragm, the external intercostal and the interchondral part of the internal intercostal muscles.
name: Weakness of muscles of respiration

desc: A decrease in the maximum amount of negative pressure a person can generate during an inhalation.
name: Reduced maximal inspiratory pressure

desc: A decrease in the maximum amount of pressure of expired air achieved by a person after a full inspiration.
name: Reduced maximal expiratory pressure

desc: Reduced tendency to respond to a reduced concentration of oxygen in the blood by increasing respiration.
name: Decreased sensitivity to hypoxemia

desc: Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung.
name: Pulmonary obstruction

desc: An anomaly that is characterized progressive airflow obstruction that is only partly reversible, inflammation in the airways, and systemic effects or comorbities.
name: Chronic pulmonary obstruction

desc: Abnormally low FEV1/FVC (FEV1 - forced expiratory volume in 1 second; FVC forced vital capacity).
name: Reduced FEV1/FVC ratio
synonyms: Obstructive deficit on pulmonary function test
Obstructive deficit on pulmonary function testing

desc: Any functional anomaly of the respiratory motile cilia.
name: Abnormal respiratory motile cilium physiology

desc: Any anomaly of the normal motility of motile cilia. Evaluation of ciliary beat frequency and ciliary beat pattern requires high-speed videomicroscopy of freshly obtained ciliary biopsies that are maintained in culture media under controlled conditions.
name: Abnormal ciliary motility

desc: A deviation from the normally well coordinated pattern of intracellular and intercellular synchrony of motile cilia. Dyskinetic cilia usually beat out of synchrony relative to neighboring cilia.
name: Ciliary dyskinesia

desc: An abnormality of the partial pressure of oxygen or carbon dioxide in the arterial blood.
name: Abnormal blood gas level

desc: An abnormality of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the arterial blood.
name: Abnormal blood carbon dioxide level

desc: Abnormally elevated blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
name: Hypercapnia

desc: Abnormally reduced blood carbon dioxide (CO2) level.
layperson: Reduced carbon dioxide in the blood
name: Hypocapnia
synonyms: Reduced carbon dioxide in the blood

desc: An abnormality of the partial pressure of oxygen in the arterial blood.
name: Abnormal blood oxygen level

desc: An abnormally low level of blood oxygen.
name: Hypoxemia

desc: Oxygen saturation less than 95% on exertion or arterial partial pressure of oxygen falling by more than 1kPa.
name: Oxygen desaturation on exertion

desc: An abnormally high level of blood oxygen.
name: Hyperoxemia

desc: A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation.
name: Cough

desc: A cough that produces phlegm or mucus.
name: Productive cough

desc: A cough that does not produce phlegm or mucus.
name: Nonproductive cough

desc: A type of cough characterized by a burst of numerous and rapid coughs followed by a long inhaling effort that is accompanied by a high-pitched whooping sound produced by the inhalation of air.
name: Whooping cough

desc: Downward movement of the trachea during inspiration due to downward traction on the tracheobronchial tree.
name: Tracheal tug on inspiration

desc: A sudden violent, spasmodic, audible expiration of breath through the nose and mouth.
name: Sneeze

desc: Unprovoked explosive pathological sneezing.
name: Paroxysmal sneezing

desc: Any anomaly of the function of the bronchi.
name: Abnormal bronchus physiology

desc: A spasm (sudden, involuntary constriction) of the bronchioles.
name: Bronchospasm

desc: An anomalous (adventitious) sound produced by the breathing process.
name: Abnormal breath sound

desc: Stridor is a high pitched sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the upper airway.
name: Stridor

desc: Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.
name: Inspiratory stridor

desc: A high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing.
name: Wheezing

desc: Squawks are short inspiratory wheezes of less than 200 ms duration and are also known as squeaks. Acoustic analysis shows the fundamental frequency varying between 200 and 300 Hz. Squawks usually occur in late inspiration and are often preceded by late inspiratory crackles.
name: Squawks

desc: Crackles are discontinuous, explosive, and nonmusical adventitious lung sounds normally heard in inspiration and sometimes during expiration. Crackles are usually classified as fine and coarse crackles based on their duration, loudness, pitch, timing in the respiratory cycle, and relationship to coughing and changing body position.
name: Crackles

desc: Crackles that are heard during the inspiratory phase.
name: Inspiratory crackles

desc: Crackles that appear at the beginning of inspiration and end before mid-inspiration.
name: Early inspiratory crackles

desc: Crackles that appear any time after the beginning of inspiration and last till the end of inspiration.
name: Late inspiratory crackles

desc: Crackles that occur during expiration.
name: Expiratory crackles

desc: Abnormal breath sounds characterized by low-pitched, snoring or rattle-like sounds.
name: Rhonchi

desc: Bronchial breath sounds contain much higher frequency components than normal breath sounds due to alteration of the low pass filtering function of the alveoli, as occurs in consolidation. It is loud, hollow, and high pitch. Expiratory phase is longer than inspiratory phase with the inspiratory-expiratory ratio (I:E) changing from normal 3:1 to 1:2. There is distinct pause between inspiration and expiration due to absent alveolar phase. It is associated with whispering pectoriloquy.
name: Bronchial breath sound

desc: An abnormal breath sound that is nonmusical, short and explosive. It is grating, rubbing, creaky, or leathery in character and present in both phases of respiration. Typically the expiratory component mirrors the inspiratory component. It occurs due to inflamed pleural surface rubbing each other during breathing. Clinically, it is important to differentiate it from crackles
name: Pleural rub

desc: Any anomaly measure by pulmonary function testing, which includes spirometry, measures of diffusing capacity, and plethysmography.
name: Abnormality on pulmonary function testing

desc: An abnormal spirometry test result. In this test, the individual being tested exhales into a tube connected to a machine called a spirometer, which measures the volume of air expired against time. Patients are asked to take a maximal inspiration and then to forcefully expel air for as long and as quickly as possible.
name: Abnormal spirometry test

desc: A functional defect characterized by reduced total lung capacity (TLC) not associated with abnormalities of expiratory airflow or airway resistance. Spirometrically, a restrictive defect is defined as FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) less than 80 per cent. Restrictive lung disease may be caused by alterations in lung parenchyma or because of a disease of the pleura, chest wall, or neuromuscular apparatus.
layperson: Stiff lung or chest wall causing decreased lung volume
name: Restrictive ventilatory defect
synonyms: Stiff lung or chest wall causing decreased lung volume
Restrictive deficit on pulmonary function tests
Restrictive deficit on pulmonary function testing

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of air a person can expel following maximal insipiration.
name: Reduced forced vital capacity

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of air a person can expel following maximal insipiration, with the test being performed before the administration of a bronchodilating medication.
name: Decreased pre-bronchodilator forced vital capacity
synonyms: Decreased pre bronchodilator forced vital capacity

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of air a person can expel following maximal insipiration, with the test being performed after the administration of a bronchodilating medication.
name: Decreased post-bronchodilator forced vital capacity
synonyms: Decreased post bronchodilator forced vital capacity

layperson: Reduced forced expiratory volume in one second
name: Reduced forced expiratory volume in one second
synonyms: An abnormal reduction in the amount of air a person can forcefully expel in one second.

desc: An abnormal reduction in the amount of air a person can forcefully expel in one second, with the test being performed after the administration of a bronchodilating medication.
layperson: Decreased post-bronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second
name: Decreased post-bronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second
synonyms: Decreased postbronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second
Decreased post bronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second

desc: A reduction in the maximum expiratory flow per minute, which can be used to measure how fast a subject can exhale as well as to judge the strength of the expiratory muscles and the condition of the large airways.
name: Decreased peak expiratory flow

desc: A reduction compared to the predicted value of the forced expiratory flow over the middle one-half of the FVC; the average flow from the point at which 25% of the FVC has been exhaled to the point at which 75% of the FVC has been exhaled.
name: Decreased forced expiratory flow 25-75%

desc: A reduction compared to the predicted value of the forced expiratory flow over the middle one-half of the FVC; the average flow from the point at which 25% of the FVC has been exhaled to the point at which 75% of the FVC has been exhaled. Here, the test is performed before the administration of a bronchodilating medication.
name: Decreased pre-bronchodilator forced expiratory flow 25-75%
synonyms: Decreased pre bronchodilator forced expiratory flow 25-75%

desc: A reduction compared to the predicted value of the forced expiratory flow over the middle one-half of the FVC; the average flow from the point at which 25% of the FVC has been exhaled to the point at which 75% of the FVC has been exhaled. Here, the test is performed after the administration of a bronchodilating medication.
name: Decreased post-bronchodilator forced expiratory flow 25-75%
synonyms: Decreased post bronchodilator forced expiratory flow 25-75%

desc: An abnormal amount of oxygen passes into the blood from the lungs and/or an abnormal amount of carbon dioxide passes from the blood into the lungs.
name: Abnormal DLCO
synonyms: Abnormal transfer factor of the lung for carbon monoxide

desc: Increased ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inspired air to the bloodstream as measured by the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) test.
name: Increased DLCO

desc: Reduced ability of the lungs to transfer gas from inspired air to the bloodstream as measured by the diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) test.
name: Decreased DLCO

desc: Pulmonary vasodilator testing is performed during right-heart catheterization and involves a short-acting vasoactive agent such as adenosine, epoprostenol, or inhaled nitric oxide. The current definition of a normal (positive) response is a drop in mean pulmonary artery pressure of at least 10 mm Hg (or 20 percent) to below 40 mm Hg.
layperson: Abnormal response to short acting pulmonary vasodilator
name: Abnormal response to short acting pulmonary vasodilator

desc: No fall in mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) falls by at least 10 mmHg to an absolute value less than 40 mmHg without a degradation in cardiac output (CO) in response to a short-acting vasoactive agent such as adenosine, epoprostenol, or inhaled nitric oxide.
layperson: Insufficient response to short acting pulmonary vasodilator
name: Insufficient response to short acting pulmonary vasodilator

desc: Any deviation from the normal quantity of secretion of nasal mucus, a thick viscous liquid produced by the mucous membranes of the nose.
name: Abnormal nasal mucus secretion

desc: Increased discharge of mucus from the nose.
name: Rhinorrhea

desc:
An anomaly in the system of mucociliary transport, which functions to transport the mucous layer lining the respiratory epithelium by ciliary 
beating.
name: Abnormal mucociliary clearance

desc: An abnormally increased amount of time required to clear mucus (and substances contained in the mucus) from the nasal mucosa. The nasal mucociliary clearance (NMC) system functions to transport the mucous layer lining the nasal epithelium towards the naso pharynx by ciliary beating in a metachronous fashion at a frequency of 7-16 Hz. NMC depends upon two principal components: physicochemical qualities and quantities of mucus and the properties of cilia that propel it. NMC is considered to be representative of pulmonary clearance. normal NMC time is determined to be up to 20 minutes. Duration of 30 minutes is considered as the cutoff point that discriminates normal subjects from subjects with impaired NMC. NMC can be measured by determination of the transport time of markers that are placed on the nasal mucosa including saccharine, radioactive markers, and dyes.
name: Impaired nasal mucociliary clearance

desc: An increased sensitivity of the airways to an inhaled constrictor agonist, a steeper slope of the dose-response curve, and a greater maximal response to the agonist.
name: Airway hyperresponsiveness

desc: A contraction of the diaphragm that repeats several times per minute. In humans, the abrupt rush of air into the lungs causes the epiglottis to close, creating a hic sound. Also known as synchronous diaphragmatic flutter (SDF), or singultus, from the Latin singult, the act of catching one's breath while sobbing. The hiccup is an involuntary action involving a reflex arc.
name: Recurrent singultus

desc: A structural anomaly of the respiratory system.
name: Abnormal respiratory system morphology

desc: An abnormality of the upper respiratory tract.
layperson: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract
name: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract
synonyms: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract

desc: An abnormality of the larynx.
name: Abnormality of the larynx

desc: Any anomaly of the structure of the larynx.
name: Abnormal larynx morphology

desc: Laryngomalacia is a congenital abnormality of the laryngeal cartilage in which the cartilage is floppy and prolapses over the larynx during inspiration.
name: Laryngomalacia

desc: Stricture or narrowing of the larynx that may be associated with symptoms of respiratory difficulty depending on the degree of laryngeal narrowing.
name: Laryngeal stenosis

desc: An abnormality of the epiglottis.
name: Abnormal epiglottis morphology

desc: A midline anterior-posterior cleft of the epiglottis that involves at least two-thirds of the epiglottic leaf. It is a useful feature for clinical diagnosis because it appears to be very rare in syndromes other than Pallister-Hall-Syndrome and is also rare as an isolated malformation.
name: Bifid epiglottis

desc: This term applies if the Epiglottis is absent or hypoplastic.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the Epiglottis

desc: Hypoplasia of the epiglottis.
name: Hypoplasia of the epiglottis

desc: Absence of the epiglottis.
name: Aplasia of the epiglottis

desc: Blockage of the upper airway at the level of the larynx often accompanied by respiratory distress.
name: Laryngeal obstruction

desc: A membrane-like structure that extends across the laryngeal lumen close to the level of the vocal cords.
name: Laryngeal web

desc: Abnormal shortening of the larynx in the anteroposterior (front to back) axis.
name: Anteroposteriorly shortened larynx

desc: An abnormality of the aryepiglottic fold.
name: Abnormal aryepiglottic fold morphology

desc: Ossification affecting the set of cartilages of larynx.
name: Cartilaginous ossification of larynx

desc: Underdevelopment of the larynx.
name: Laryngeal hypoplasia

desc: Congenital absence of the lumen of the larynx.
name: Laryngeal atresia

desc: Presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus.
name: Laryngeal cleft

desc: A malformation of the laryngeal cartilage.
name: Laryngeal cartilage malformation
synonyms: Vocal impairment, severe, due to laryngeal cartilage abnormalities

desc: An abnormality of the vocal cord.
name: Abnormal vocal cord morphology

desc: Bowing (abnormal curvature) of the vocal folds.
name: Bowing of the vocal cords

desc: A small growth on a vocal cord that may appear as pedunculated or sessile and have varying size, shape, and color.
name: Vocal cord polyp

desc: Narrowing of the larynx, commonly occuring during viral respiratory tract infections, in particular in children, leads to symptoms such as hoarseness, a barking cough, stridor, and sometimes dyspnea and respiratory failure.
name: Subglottic laryngitis

desc: Presence of a cyst (sac-like structure) located in the larynx.
name: Laryngeal cyst

desc: Any anomaly of the function of the larynx.
name: Abnormal larynx physiology

desc: An abnormal high-pitched noisy sound, occurring during inhalation or exhalation caused by the incomplete obstruction in the throat.
name: Laryngeal stridor

desc: A spasm (involuntary contraction) of the vocal cords that can make it difficult to speak or breathe.
name: Laryngospasm

desc: A carcinoma of the larynx.
name: Laryngeal carcinoma

desc: A wart-like lesion (papilloma, i.e., benign epithelial tumors that are caused by infection with the human papilloma virus) located on the larynx.
name: Laryngeal papilloma

desc: A structural anomaly of the trachea.
name: Abnormal trachea morphology

desc: An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea.
name: Tracheoesophageal fistula
synonyms: Abnormal connection between trachea and esophagus

desc: A congenital absence or considerable underdevelopment of the trachea such that communication between the larynx proximally and the alveoli of the lungs distally is lacking.
name: Tracheal atresia

desc: Weakness of the cartilage in the trachea and the bronchi, resulting in a floppy (non-rigid) airway. Affected persons may have difficulties to maintain patency of the airways.
name: Tracheobronchomalacia

desc: An abnormality of the C-shaped rings of hyaline cartilage, normally 16 to 20 in number, that occupy the anterior two-thirds of the circumference of the trachea (the posterior portion of the ring is completed by fibrous and smooth muscle tissue).
name: Anomalous tracheal cartilage

desc: Marked widening of the trachea.
name: Tracheomegaly

desc: Marked widening of the trachea and major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection.
name: Tracheobronchmegaly

desc: A cyst in the trachea, whose wall is made up by tissue similar to the bronchial tree, including cartilage and smooth muscle, and is lined by secretory respiratory epithelium composed of cuboid or columnar ciliated epithelium.
name: Tracheal duplication cyst

desc: A neoplasm of the trachea.
name: Neoplasm of the trachea

desc: A wart-like lesion (papilloma, i.e., benign epithelial tumors that are caused by infection with the human papilloma virus) located on the trachea.
name: Tracheal papilloma

desc: Any anomaly of the morphology of the bronchi.
name: Abnormal bronchus morphology

desc: Persistent abnormal dilatation of the bronchi owing to localized and irreversible destruction and widening of the large airways.
layperson: Permanent enlargement of the airways of the lungs
name: Bronchiectasis
synonyms: Permanent enlargement of the airways of the lungs

desc: Weakness or softness of the cartilage in the walls of the bronchial tubes.
name: Bronchomalacia

desc: Marked widening of the major bronchi that may be predispose to chronic respiratory tract infection.
name: Bronchomegaly

desc: A tumor originating in a bronchus.
name: Bronchial neoplasm

desc: A wart-like lesion (papilloma, i.e., benign epithelial tumors that are caused by infection with the human papilloma virus) located on a bronchus.
name: Bronchial papilloma

desc: A developmental anomaly characterised by focal obliteration of the proximal segment of a bronchus. The bronchial pattern is entirely normal distal to the site of stenosis.
name: Bronchial atresia

desc: Distortion of the bronchial airways due to mechanical traction on the bronchi resulting from fibrosis of the surrounding lung parenchyma. CT findings represent irregular bronchial dilatation caused by surrounding retractile pulmonary fibrosis. Dilated airways are usually identifiable as such but may be seen as cysts.
name: Traction bronchiectasis

desc: Saccular dilatation of the terminal bronchioles.
name: Bronchiolectasis

desc: Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus.
name: Alveolar cell carcinoma

desc: A rare cancer originating in the lung or pleural cavity that occurs most often in infants and young children but also has been reported in adults. Pleuropulmonary blastoma is regarded as malignant.
name: Pleuropulmonary blastoma

desc: Any structural anomaly of the lung.
name: Abnormal lung morphology

desc: Pulmonary bullae are rounded focal regions of emphysema with a thin wall which measure more than 1 cm in diameter. They are often subpleural in location and are typically larger in the apices. In some cases, bullae can be very large and result in compression of adjacent lung tissue. A giant bulla is arbitrarily defined as one that occupies at least one third of the volume of a hemithorax. When large, bullae can simulate pneumothorax. The most common cause is paraseptal emphysema but bullae may also be seen in association with centrilobular emphysema.
name: Pulmonary bulla

desc: A bleb is a small gas-containing space within the visceral pleura or in the subpleural lung, not larger than 1 cm in diameter. CT findings show a bleb as a thin-walled cystic air space contiguous with the pleura.
name: Pulmonary bleb

desc: Interstitial emphysema is characterized by air dissecting within the interstitium of the lung, typically in the peribronchovascular sheaths, interlobular septa, and visceral pleura. It is most commonly seen in neonates receiving mechanical ventilation. It is rarely recognized radiographically in adults and is infrequently seen on CT scans. It appears as perivascular lucent or low attenuating halos and small cysts.
name: Interstitial emphysema

desc: A type of emphysema characterized by destroyed centrilobular alveolar walls and enlargement of respiratory bronchioles and associated alveoli. This is the commonest form of emphysema in cigarette smokers. CT findings are centrilobular areas of decreased attenuation, usually without visible walls, of nonuniform distribution and predominantly located in upper lung zones.
name: Centrilobular emphysema

desc: Panacinar emphysema involves all portions of the acinus and secondary pulmonary lobule more or less uniformly. It predominates in the lower lobes and is the form of emphysema associated with1-antitrypsin deficiency. CT scans show a generalized decrease of the lung parenchyma with a decrease in the caliber of blood vessels in the affected lung. Severe panacinar emphysema may coexist and merge with severe centrilobular emphysema. The appearance of feature less decreased attenuation may be indistinguishable from severe constrictive obliterative bronchiolitis.
name: Panacinar emphysema

desc: Defects in the formation of pulmonary lobes.
name: Abnormal lung lobation

desc: Both lungs have three lobes. Normally, the left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three lobes.
name: Bilateral trilobed lungs

desc: The presence of a piece lung tissue which is not attached to the pulmonary blood supply and does not communicate with the other lung tissue (not connected to the standard bronchial airways and not performing a function in respiration).
name: Pulmonary sequestration

desc: A type of pulmonary sequestration that is completely enclosed in its own pleural sac, occurring above, within, or below the diaphragm, and without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
name: Extrapulmonary sequestrum

desc: A type of pulmonary sequestration that occurs within the visceral pleura of normal lung tissue, usually without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
name: Intrapulmonary sequestration

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary pleura, the thin, transparent membrane which covers the lungs and lines the inside of the chest walls.
name: Abnormal pleura morphology

desc: Inflammation of the pleura.
layperson: Inflammation of tissues lining lungs and chest
name: Pleuritis
synonyms: Inflammation of tissues lining lungs and chest

desc: The presence of blood in the pleural space.
name: Hemothorax

desc: A closed sac-like structure originating from the pleura that contains a liquid, gaseous, or semisolid substance.
name: Pleural cyst

desc: An increase in the thickness of the pleura, generally related to scarring of the pleural tissue.
name: Pleural thickening

desc: An abnormal form or number of the pulmonary fissures.
name: Abnormal pulmonary fissure morphology

desc: An abnormal form or location of a pulmonary fissure.
name: Abnormal pulmonary fissure architecture

desc: A deviation from the normal number of pulmonary fissures.
name: Abnormal pulmonary fissure count

desc: Presence of a lung fissure that does not exist normally. Supernumerary fissures include the superior accessory fissure, the medial basal fissure, the left horizontal fissure, and the azygos fissure form supernumerary lobes.
name: Supernumerary pulmonary fissure

desc: Lack of one or more of the normal pulmonary fissures.
name: Decreased pulmonary fissure count

desc: A malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the pleura (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the lungs). Pleural mesothelioma is the most common form of mesothelioma.
name: Pleural mesothelioma

desc: Accumulation of air in the pleural cavity leading to a partially or completely collapsed lung.
name: Pneumothorax

desc: Pneumothorax occurring without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.
name: Spontaneous pneumothorax

desc: Pneumothorax occurring neonatally without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.
name: Spontaneous neonatal pneumothorax

layperson: Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations
name: Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations

desc: Replacement of normal lung tissues by fibroblasts and collagen.
name: Pulmonary fibrosis

desc: It is a bilateral reticular pattern of linear or lineonodular densities that are most pronounced in basilar portions of the lungs on standard chest x-ray. It is the third minor criterion for scleroderma diagnosis.
name: Bilateral basilar pulmonary fibrosis

desc: Abnormal accumulation of surfactant-like, periodic acid-schiff-positive lipoproteinaceous material in macrophages within the alveolar spaces and distal bronchioles. This results in gas exchange impairment leading to dyspnea and alveolar infiltrates.
name: Alveolar proteinosis

desc: According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities.
name: Chronic lung disease

desc: Abnormality of the lung parenchyma extending to the pulmonary interstitium and leading to diffuse pulmonary fibrosis.
layperson: Abnormality in area between air sacs in lung
name: Interstitial pulmonary abnormality
synonyms: Abnormality in area between air sacs in lung

desc: Diffuse filling of the distal airsspaces of the lungs, the alveoli, with macrophages. Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present.
name: Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis
synonyms: Filling of the alveoli with alveolar macrophages

desc: A lymphocyte-predominant infiltration of the lungs characterized by bibasilar pulmonary infiltrates with dense interstitial accumulations of lymphocytes and plasma cells.
name: Lymphoid interstitial pneumonia

desc: Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) is and interstitial lung abnormalitiy characterized histopathologically by plugs of granulation tissue lying within small airways, alveolar ducts, and alveoli and by chronic inflammatory cell infiltration in alveolar walls. Patients with BOOP generally present with subacute illness, including shortness of breath, fever, malaise, and weight loss.
name: Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia

desc: Inflammation and fibrosis of the bronchioles leading to partial or complete obstruction of these airways.
name: Bronchiolitis obliterans

desc: Extensive interstitial fibrosis with alveolar disruption and bronchiolectasis.
name: Honeycomb lung

desc: A fine reticular pattern on high-resolution computeed tomography, with the visible lines separated by a few millimeters. Regions of the lung with intralobular interstitial thickening characteristically show a fine lacelike or netlike appearance.
name: Intralobular interstitial thickening

desc: Thickening of the peribronchovascular interstitium, a connective tissue sheath that surrounds the central bronchi and pulmonary arteries. The peribronchovascular interstitium extends from the level of the pulmonary hila into the peripheral lung. This feature may be ascertained on high-resolution computer tomography.
name: Peribronchovascular interstitial thickening

desc: High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) can distinguish findings that characterize characterise interstitial lung diseases in a way not possible with other modalities.
layperson: Pulmonary interstitial high-resolution computed tomography abnormality
name: Pulmonary interstitial high-resolution computed tomography abnormality

desc: A descriptive term that is applied to computer tomography imaging and that refers to a hazy area of increased attenuation in the lung with preserved bronchial and vascular markings.
name: Ground-glass opacification on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A hazy area of increased attenuation in centrilobular areas of the lung with preserved bronchial and vascular markings seen on a computer tomography scan. Centrilobular refers to a location that is central within secondary pulmonary lobules.
layperson: Centrilobular ground-glass opacification on pulmonary HRCT
name: Centrilobular ground-glass opacification on pulmonary HRCT

desc: CT finding of ground-glass opacity surrounding a nodule or mass. It was first described as a sign of hemorrhage around foci of invasive aspergillosis. The halo sign is nonspecific and may also be caused by hemorrhage associated with other types of nodules or by local pulmonary infiltration by neoplasm.
name: Computed tomographic halo sign

desc: CT finding of central ground-glass opacity surrounded by denser consolidation of crescentic shape (forming more than three-fourths of a circle) or complete ring of at least 2 mm in thicknes. A rare sign, it was initially reported to be specific for cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, but was subsequently described in patients with paracoccidioidomycosis.
name: Atoll sign

desc: On pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography, reticular pattern is characterised by innumerable interlacing shadows suggesting a mesh.
name: Reticular pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: The so-called crazy paving pattern is characterised on HRCT by the presence of thickened interlobular septae and intralobular lines superimposed on a background of ground-glass opacity, resembling irregularly shaped paving stones.
layperson: Crazy paving pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Crazy paving pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A nodular pattern is characterised on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography by the presence of numerous rounded opacities that range from 2 mm to 1 cm in diameter, with micronodules defined as smaller than 3 mm in diameter.
name: Nodular pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A nodular pattern on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography that has a perilymphatic distribution.
name: Nodular-perilymphatic pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A nodular pattern on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography that displays a tree-in-bud pattern, representing centrilobular branching structures that resemble a budding tree.
layperson: Nodular-centrilobular with tree-in-bud pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Nodular-centrilobular with tree-in-bud pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A nodular pattern on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography that has an apparently random pattern.
name: Nodular-random pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A nodular pattern on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography which are anatomically located centrally within secondary pulmonary lobules. Centrilobular nodules may be dense (i.e., solid) and of homogeneous opacity or ground-glass opacity, and may range from a few millimeters to about 1 cm in size. Because of the similar size of secondary lobules, centrilobular nodules often appear to be evenly spaced. Centrilobular nodules are usually separated from the pleural surfaces, fissures, and interlobular septa by a distance of at least several millimeters. They may appear patchy or diffuse in different diseases.
layperson: Nodular-centrilobular without tree-in-bud pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Nodular-centrilobular without tree-in-bud pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Co-occurrence of reticular and micronodular patterns on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography.
name: Reticulonodular pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: On pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography, the cystic pattern is composed by well-defined, round and circumscribed air-containing parenchymal spaces with a well-defined wall and interface with normal lung. The wall of the cysts may be uniform or varied in thickness, but usually is thin (less than 2 mm) and occurs without associated emphysema.
name: Cystic pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Co-occurrence of the cystic pattern and the ground-glass pattern on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography,
layperson: Combined cystic and ground-glass pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Combined cystic and ground-glass pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Areas of low density corresponding to parenchymal destruction and reduced perfusion, and attenuation of the pulmonary vasculature, as visualized on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography.
layperson: Decreased attenuation pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Decreased attenuation pattern on pulmonary HRCT
synonyms: Black lung pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: A patchwork of intermingled areas of increased and decreased attenuation visualized on pulmonary high-resolution computed tomography.
layperson: Mosaic attenuation pattern on pulmonary HRCT
name: Mosaic attenuation pattern on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Presence of thickening of the interlobular septa of the lungs as seen on a CT scan.
layperson: Interlobular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT
name: Interlobular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Thickening of the interlobular septa of the lungs as seen on a high-resolution computed tomography scan with a smooth appearance of the interlobular septa.
layperson: Smooth septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT
name: Smooth septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Thickening of the interlobular septa of the lungs as seen on a high-resolution computed tomography scan with a nodular or beaded appearance of the interlobular septa.
layperson: Nodular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT
name: Nodular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Thickening of the interlobular septa of the lungs as seen on a high-resolution computed tomography scan with an irregular appearance of the interlobular septa. THis feature is often associated with distortion of lung architecture.
layperson: Irregular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT
name: Irregular septal thickening on pulmonary HRCT

desc: Temporal and spatial heterogeneity in lungs based on presence of fibrosis and honeycombing.
name: Usual interstitial pneumonia

desc: Bilateral lack of development of the lungs.
name: Bilateral lung agenesis

desc: Lack of development of one lung.
name: Unilateral lung agenesis

desc: The presence of microscopic cystic masses of nonfunctioning pulmonary tissue that lack an obvious communication with the tracheobronchial tree.
name: Bronchopulmonary sequestration

desc: A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is incorporated into the normal surrounding lung.
name: Intralobar sequestration

desc: A kind of bronchopulmonary sequestration that is completely discrete from the normal lung and is surrounded by separate pleura.
name: Extralobar sequestration

desc: An infection of the upper or lower respiratory tract.
name: Respiratory tract infection

desc: Inflammation of any part of the lung parenchyma.
name: Pneumonia

desc: An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia.
name: Recurrent pneumonia

desc: Pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.
name: Aspiration pneumonia

desc: Increased susceptibility to aspiration pneumonia, defined as pneumonia due to breathing in foreign material, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonia.
name: Recurrent aspiration pneumonia

desc: An acute episode of pneumonia due to the aspiration (breathing in) of food, liquid, or gastric contents into the upper respiratory tract.
name: Acute aspiration pneumonia

desc: An increased susceptibility to respiratory infections as manifested by a history of recurrent respiratory infections.
name: Recurrent respiratory infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to lower respiratory tract infections as manifested by a history of recurrent lower respiratory tract infections.
name: Recurrent lower respiratory tract infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to respiratory infections in early life, as manifested by recurrent episodes of respiratory infections.
name: Respiratory infections in early life

desc: Increased susceptibility to infections due to aspiration, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infections due to aspiration.
name: Recurrent infections due to aspiration

desc: Increased susceptibility to streptococcus pneumoniae infections as manifested by a history of recurrent infections by streptococcus pneumoniae.
name: Recurrent streptococcus pneumoniae infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to infections involving both the paranasal sinuses and the lungs, as manifested by a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
name: Recurrent sinopulmonary infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to bronchopulmonary infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchopulmonary infections.
name: Recurrent bronchopulmonary infections
synonyms: Recurrent infections in bronchi and lungs

desc: A history of repeated acute infections of the upper or lower respiratory tract.
name: Recurrent acute respiratory tract infection

desc: Acute inflammation of the lung due to an infection.
name: Acute infectious pneumonia

desc: Inflammation of the bronchioles.
name: Bronchiolitis

desc: Inflammation of the large airways in the lung including any part of the bronchi from the primary bronchi to the tertiary bronchi.
name: Bronchitis

desc: Chronic inflammation of the bronchi.
name: Chronic bronchitis

desc: Inflammation of the large airways of the lung with rapid onset and short course usually associated with cough, mucus production, shortness of breath, wheezing, and chest tightness.
name: Acute bronchitis

desc: A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in lung parenchyma, which leads to a cavity, and after formation of bronchopulmonary fistula, can manifest as an air-fluid level inside the cavity.
name: Lung abscess

desc: The presence of multiple granulomata (small nodular inflammatory lesions containing grouped mononuclear phagocytes) in the lung.
name: Pulmonary granulomatosis

desc: Any lesion observed on an imaging study of the lung that is associated with increased density (usually showing as increased whiteness in the image).
name: Pulmonary opacity

desc: Any structural anomaly located between the pleura and the chest wall.
name: Abnormal subpleural morphology

desc: Increase in thickness of the subpleural interstitium.
name: Subpleural interstitial thickening

desc: So-called honeycombs (variably sized cysts in a background of densely scarred tissue) located in the subpleural space.
name: Subpleural honeycombing

desc: This term groups terms representing abnormal findings derived from chest X-ray investigation of the lung. In general, lung abnormalities can manifest as opacities (areas of increased density) or as regions with decreased density.
name: Abnormal pulmonary thoracic imaging finding

desc: A crescent of air surrounding a soft-tissue mass in a pulmonary cavity and can be seen in both plain X-ray and CT scan.
name: Air crescent sign

desc: This sign is seen in pneumomediastinum in which air accumulates between the lower border of the heart and the superior part of the diaphragm, which results in complete visualization of the diaphragm in chest X-ray, hence named continuous diaphragm sign.
name: Continuous diaphragm sign

desc: The tree-in-bud pattern represents centrilobular branching structures that resemble a budding tree. The pattern reflects a spectrum of endo- and peribronchiolar disorders, including mucoid impaction, inflammation, and/or fibrosis (See Figure 70 of PMID:18195376).
name: Tree-in-bud pattern

desc: This finding is composed of a ring-shaped opacity representing a dilated bronchus in cross section and a smaller adjacent opacity representing its pulmonary artery, with the combination resembling a signet (or pearl) ring. It is the basic sign of bronchiectasis in pulmonary computed tomography imaging.
name: Signet ring sign

desc: An apical cap is a caplike lesion at the lung apex, usually caused by intrapulmonary and pleural fibrosis pulling down extrapleural fat or possibly by chronic ischemia resulting in hyaline plaque formation on the visceral pleura. The prevalence increases with age. It can also be seen in hematoma resulting from aortic rupture or in other fluid collection associated with infection or tumor, either outside the parietal pleura or loculated within the pleural space.
name: Apical pulmonary opacity

desc: Consolidation refers to an exudate or other product of disease that replaces alveolar air, rendering the lung solid (as in infective pneumonia).
name: Parenchymal consolidation

desc: Abnormal retention of gas within a lung or part of a lung, as a result of airway obstuction of abnormalities in lung compliance. In the classic presentation, the lung will appear normal at inspiration, but on exhalation, the diseased portions of the lung which have lost connective tissue recoil will remain lucent while the healthy portions of the lung will become more dense due to atelectasis. This helps distinguish it from mosaic attenuation due to patchy fibrosis, as occurs with nonspecific interstitial pneumonia, and in early usual interstitial pneumonitis (the hallmark imaging diagnosis of interstitial lung disease) in which there is no change with inspiration and expiration.
name: Expiratory air trapping

desc: The presence of eosinophils in lung tissue, generally as detected by tissue biopsy, with or without blood eosinophilia.
name: Pulmonary eosinophilic infiltration

desc: A round circumscribed space within a lung that is surrounded by an epithelial or fibrous wall of variable thickness. A cyst usually has a thin and regular wall (less than 2 mm) and contains air, although some may contain fluid.
name: Pulmonary cyst

desc: The presence of multiple lung cysts.
name: Multiple pulmonary cysts

desc: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM) can be diagnosed prenatally if ultrasound shows a cystic or solid lung tumor. A CCAM does not have systemic arterial blood supply (in contrast to bronchopulmonary sequenstration). It is a cystic area within the lung that originates from abnormal embryogenesis.
layperson: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation of the lung
name: Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation of the lung
synonyms: Congenital cystic disease of the lung

desc: An air-filled cystic space within a lung.
name: Pulmonary pneumatocele

desc: A rare congenital cystic lesion of the lungs in the mediastinum.
name: Bronchogenic cyst

desc: Abnormal type or counts of nucleated immune cells and acellular components in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid. BAL us performed with a fiberoptic bronchoscope in the wedged position within a selected bronchopulmonary segment. BAL is commonly used to inform the differential diagnosis of interstitial lung disease or to monitor therapeutic interventions.
name: Abnormal bronchoalveolar lavage fluid morphology

desc: Deviation from the commonly in healthy people observe cellular distribution. Normal ranghes are macrophages over 80%, lymphocytes less than 15%, neutrophils less than 3%, eosinophils less than 0.5%, mast cells less than 0.5%.
layperson: Abnormal cellular composition of bronchoalveolar fluid
name: Abnormal cellular composition of bronchoalveolar fluid
synonyms: Abnormal cell differential of broncho-alveolar fluid

desc: Usually, Lymphoycytes make up less than 15% of all cells found in the bronchoalveloar lavage fluid. This elevated cell proportion can be induced by virus or drugs, or is associated with specific diseases.
layperson: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid lymphocyte proportion
name: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid lymphocyte proportion

desc: Usually, Neutrophils make up less than 3% of all cells found in the broncho-alveloar lavage fluid. In children, standard value of neutrophils is higher depending on their age (children under the age of 5 show a maximum value of 10%). This elevated cell proportion is a sign for acute and chronic infections (HP:0012387, HP:0006538) and can be associated to specific diseases.
layperson: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid neutrophil proportion
name: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid neutrophil proportion
synonyms: Elevated level of neutrophils in broncho-alveolar lavage fluid

desc: Alveolar macrophages usually make up the majority of cells in the bronchoalveolar space (over 80%). The may contain intracellular material depending on underlying diseases or due to exposition to inhaled particles.
name: Abnormal alveolar macrophage morphology

desc: Accumulation of lipids in alveolar macrophages with droplet-shaped fat inclusions.
name: Lipid-laden macrophages in bronchoalveolar fluid

desc: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (HLM) in bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid were originally known as adiagnostic biomarker of alveolar hemorrhage, but have also been observed in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) with histopathological pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
name: Hemosiderin-laden macrophages in bronchoalveolar fluid
synonyms: Accumulation of hemosiderin laden alveolar macrophages

desc: Accumulation of inhaled, nondigestable particles in macrophages.
layperson: Dust particle inclusion in alveolar macrophages
name: Dust particle inclusion in alveolar macrophages

desc: In otherwise healthy smokers, characteristic so called smoker-inclusion can be found within the macrophages in the bronchoalveolar fluid. These blue/ black/ round/ oval cytoplasmic inclusions consist of pigmented lipid deposits.
name: Smoker-inclusions in alveolar macrophages

desc: Usually, eosinophils make up less than 0.5% of all cells found in the broncho-alveloar lavage fluid. But in eosinophilic lung disease, the eosinophil cell proportion typically represents more than 25%. Comment: An elevated level of eosinophil cells are also a result of infections, or an allergic reaction or can be drug-induced.
layperson: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid eosinophil proportion
name: Elevated bronchoalveolar lavage fluid eosinophil proportion

desc: Any deviation from the normal concentration of protein in the bronchoalveolar fluid.
name: Abnormal bronchoalveolar fluid protein level
synonyms: Abnormal biochemical composition of broncho-alveolar fluid
Abnormal level of proteins in the broncho-alveolar fluid

desc: Significantly decreased level or failed detection of surfactant protein C in broncho-alveolar lavage fluid. Comment: Pulmonary surfactant is a highly surface-active mixture of proteins and lipids that is synthesized and secreted onto the alveoli by type II epithelial cells. The protein part of surfactant constitutes of four types of surfactant proteins (SP), SP-A, SP-B, SP-C and SP-D. SP-A and SP-D are hydrophilic proteins that regulate surfactant metabolism and have immunologic functions, whereas SP-B and SP-C are hydrophobic molecules, which play a direct role in the organization of the surfactant structure in the interphase and in the stabilization of the lipid layers during the respiratory cycle. Lack of SP-C may result of surfactant metabolism dysfunction and is also observed in patients with other diffuse parenchymal lung diseaes, pathogenetically related to the alveolar surfactant region.
name: Absent bronchoalveolar surfactant-protein C

desc: Significantly decreased level or failed detection of surfactant protein B in broncho-alveolar lavage fluid.
name: Absent bronchoalveolar dimeric surfactant-protein B

desc: In the space betweem alveolar macrophages, amorphous PAS-positive material, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis.
name: Intraalveolar phospholipid accumulation
synonyms: Detection of PAS-positive extracellular material in broncho-alveolar lavage

desc: Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) describes a comon histologic injury pattern of the lung. The early stages are characterized by epithelial cells necrosis and sloughing, fibrous exsudate, edema, and hyaline membranes made of surfactant and proteins, filling the alveoli. This results in impaired gas exchange. In later stages, type II cells and myofibroblasts proliferate within the interstitium and airspaces. The corresponding clinical entity is acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). DAD may result from pulmonary drug toxicity, occurs in immunosuppressed, severe viral infections, acute interstial pneumonitis and crack cocaine inhalation.
name: Diffuse alveolar damage

desc: Architectural distortion is characterized by abnormal displacement of bronchi, vessels, fissures, or septa caused by diffuse or localized lung disease, particularly interstitial fibrosis. This is visible in lung biopsy and CT scans in a distorted appearance and is usually associated with pulmonary fibrosis and accompanied by volume loss.
name: Architectural distortion of the lung

desc: Tumor of the lung.
name: Neoplasm of the lung

desc: The presence of a lung fibroma, a benign neoplasm that can present as a mass causing airway obstruction, cough, and hemoptysis, or present without symptoms as a solitary pulmonary nodule.
name: Lung fibroma

desc: Small cell lung cancer (SCLC) is a type of highly malignant lung cancer that is composed of small ovoid cells. In the past, SCLC was called oat cell carcinoma because the microscopic appearance of the cells was felt to resemble oats. SLCLC usually originates near the bronchi and in many cases may grow and metastasize quickly.
name: Small cell lung carcinoma

desc: A type of non-small cell lung carcinoma that is derived from stratified squamous epithelial cells.
name: Squamous cell lung carcinoma

desc: A type of non-small cell lung carcinoma that is derived from undifferentiated malignant neoplasms originating from transformed epithelial cells in the lung, and which is differentiate from small-cell lung carcinoma by the larger size of the anaplastic cells, a higher cytoplasmic-to-nuclear size ratio, and a lack of salt-and-pepper appearance of the chromatin.
name: Large cell lung carcinoma

desc: A benign cartilaginous tumors of the lung.
name: Pulmonary chondroma

desc: Collapse of part of a lung associated with absence of inflation (air) of that part.
layperson: Partial or complete collapse of part or entire lung
name: Atelectasis
synonyms: Partial or complete collapse of part or entire lung

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, which is defined by characteristics such as the number of lobes per lung and the relationship of the pulmonary arteries to their bronchi.
name: Abnormal pulmonary situs morphology

desc: Mirror image arrangement of the mainstem bronchi with the right pulmonary artery posterior to the right upper lobe bronchus and the left pulmonary artery anterior to the left upper lobe bronchus.
name: Pulmonary situs inversus

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same.
name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a right lung.
layperson: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs
name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs

desc: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a left lung.
layperson: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs
name: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs

desc: Any structural anomaly of the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium that lines much of the conducting portion of the airway, including part of the nasal cavity and larynx, the trachea, and bronchi.
name: Abnormal respiratory epithelium morphology

desc: Abnormal arrangement of the structures of the motile cilium.
name: Abnormal respiratory motile cilium morphology

desc: An anomaly of the dynein arms of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.
layperson: Dynein arm defect of respiratory motile cilia
name: Dynein arm defect of respiratory motile cilia

desc: Absence of the outer dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, which normally are situated outside of the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.
name: Absent outer dynein arms

desc: Complete absence of the dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, that is, absence of the inner and the outer dynein arms, which normally are situated inside and outside of the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.
layperson: Absent inner and outer dynein arms
name: Absent inner and outer dynein arms

desc: Absence of the inner dynein arms of respiratory motile cilia, which normally are situated within the peripheral microtubules of motile cilia. This feature is usually appreciated by electron microscopy.
name: Absent inner dynein arms
Absent/shortened outer dynein arms
synonyms: Respiratory cilia have shortened or absent outer dynein arms

desc: Abnormal arrangement of the structures of the axoneme, which is the cytoskeletal structure that forms the inner core of the motile cilium and displays a canonical 9 + 2 microtubular pattern of motile cilia studded with dynein arms.
layperson: Abnormal axonemal organization of respiratory motile cilia
name: Abnormal axonemal organization of respiratory motile cilia
synonyms: Abnormal axonemal organisation of respiratory motile cilia

desc: A structural anomaly of the two central microtubules of motile cilia with a 9+2 microtubuluar configuration.
layperson: Abnormal central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia
name: Abnormal central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia

desc: Absence of the two central microtubules of motile cilia with a 9+2 microtubuluar configuration.
layperson: Absent central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia
name: Absent central microtubular pair morphology of respiratory motile cilia

desc: Absence of the radial spokes of the axoneme of the respiratory cilium.
layperson: Absent respiratory ciliary axoneme radial spokes
name: Absent respiratory ciliary axoneme radial spokes

desc: Ectopic respiratory epithelium presenting as a superficial lesion in the skin usually localised unilateral in the skin of the forearm and associated with ipsilateral hand malformations.
name: Ectopic respiratory mucosa

desc: Abnormal appearance of material expectorated (coughed up) from the respiratory system and that is composed of mucus but may contain other substances such as pus, blood, microorganisms, and fibrin.
name: Abnormal sputum

desc: Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs.
name: Hemoptysis
synonyms: Coughing up blood or blood-stained mucus

desc: An increased proportion of eosinophils in sputum in the differentiated cell count.
name: Sputum eosinophilia

desc: Expectoration (coughing up) of a broncholith. Broncholithiasis is defined as the presence of calculi in the tracheobronchial tree. It is a rare disease but can be characterized by clinical and radiological findings of a calcified lymph node eroding bronchial wall and opening into the bronchial lumen.
name: Lithoptysis

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the respiratory system.
name: Neoplasm of the respiratory system

desc: An organ or organ-system abnormality that consists of uncontrolled autonomous cell-proliferation which can occur in any part of the body as a benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour).
name: Neoplasm

desc: Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.
name: Neoplasm by histology

desc: The presence of a melanoma, a malignant cancer originating from pigment producing melanocytes. Melanoma can originate from the skin or the pigmented layers of the eye (the uvea).
name: Melanoma

desc: A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates from immature liver precursor cells and macroscopically is composed of tissue resembling fetal or mature liver cells or bile ducts.
name: Hepatoblastoma

desc: A disordered proliferation of mature tissues that is native to the site of origin, e.g., exostoses, nevi and soft tissue hamartomas. Although most hamartomas are benign, some histologic subtypes, e.g., neuromuscular hamartoma, may proliferate aggressively such as mesenchymal cystic hamartoma, Sclerosing epithelial hamartoma, Sclerosing metanephric hamartoma.
name: Hamartoma

desc: Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas. These can occur throughout the gastrointestinal tract. Hamartomatous polyps are composed of the normal cellular elements of the gastrointestinal tract, but have a markedly distorted architecture.
name: Hamartomatous polyposis

desc: The presence of multiple juvenile polyps in the stomach and intestine. The term juvenile polyps refer to a special histopathology and not the age of onset as the polyp might be diagnosed at all ages. The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands. Juvenile polyps are a specific type of hamartomatous polyps.
name: Juvenile gastrointestinal polyposis

desc: Polyp-like protrusions which are histologically hamartomas located in the stomach.
name: Hamartomatous stomach polyps

desc: The presence of more than 5 juvenile polyps of the colon. The term juvenile polyps refer to a special histopathology and not the age of onset as the polyp might be diagnosed at all ages. The juvenile polyp has a spherical appearance and is microscopically characterized by overgrowth of an oedematous lamina propria with inflammatory cells and cystic glands.
name: Juvenile colonic polyposis

desc: A hamartoma (tissue malformation consisting of an abnormal mixture of constitutive components) originating in the skin.
name: Cutaneous hamartoma

desc: A benign focal growth composed of vascular tissue.
name: Vascular hamartoma

desc: A rare, benign soft tissue tumor that typically occurs within the first two years of life.
name: Fibrous hamartoma

desc: Any neoplasm composed of fibrous tissue.
name: Fibrous tissue neoplasm

desc: Benign tumors that are composed of fibrous or connective tissue. They can grow in all organs, arising from mesenchyme tissue. The term "fibroblastic" or "fibromatous" is used to describe tumors of the fibrous connective tissue. When the term fibroma is used without modifier, it is usually considered benign, with the term fibrosarcoma reserved for malignant tumors.
name: Fibroma

desc: Angiofibroma consist of many often dilated vessels.
name: Angiofibromas

desc: A benign central bone tumor composed of fibrous connective tissue within which bone is formed.
name: Ossifying fibroma

desc: A benign central bone tumor of the jaw composed of fibrous connective tissue within which bone is formed.
name: Ossifying fibroma of the jaw

desc: Benign, slow-growing tumors without any metastatic potential. Despite their benign nature, they can damage nearby structures causing organ dysfunction. Histologically they resemble low-grade fibrosarcomas, but they are very locally aggressive and tend to recur even after complete resection. There is a tendency for recurrence in the setting of prior surgery and the most common localisation of these tumors is intraabdominal from smooth muscle cells of the instestine.
name: Desmoid tumors

desc: A neoplasm containing histiocytes.
name: Histiocytoma

desc: A benign tumor made up of mostly myofibroblasts that appears almost exclusively on the digits of the hands and feet, rarely involving the thumb or big toe. The lesion displays a proliferation of bland intradermal spindle cells arranged in whorls, fascicles, or a storiform pattern in a collagenous background of varying degrees. Also usually present are perpendicular tumor cell fascicles that extend to the epidermis. The small intracytoplasmic inclusions are said to appear similar to red blood cells. The inclusion bodies have been shown to be made up of densely packed vimentin and actin filaments. The tumor often causes a dome-shaped elevation of the overlying structures, forming a protuberant or polypoid nodule. The overlying epidermis can display a host of changes, including acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, rete ridge flattening, entrapment of adnexal structures, and, rarely, ulceration.
name: Inclusion body fibromatosis

desc: A neoplasm derived from nervous tissue (not necessarily a neoplasm located in the nervous system).
name: Nervous tissue neoplasm

desc: A neoplasm arising in the neuroectoderm, the portion of the ectoderm of the early embryo that gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems, including some glial cells.
name: Neuroectodermal neoplasm

desc: A benign pituitary-region neoplasm that originates from Rathke's pouch. Craniopharyngiomas are benign slow growing tumours that are located within the sellar and para sellar region of the central nervous system.
name: Craniopharyngioma

desc: A neoplasm composed of neural epithelium, not necessarily a neoplasm located in the neural epithelium or neuroepithelium.
name: Neuroepithelial neoplasm

desc: A benign brain tumor composed of neural elements which most often arise from the septum pellucidum and the walls of the lateral ventricles.
name: Neurocytoma

desc: A tumor that originates in cells from the primitive neural crest. This group of tumors is characteirzed by the presence of primitive cells with elements of neuronal and/or glial differentiation.
name: Primitive neuroectodermal tumor

desc: A primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm that occurs extracranially in soft tissue and bone.
name: Peripheral primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm

desc: A primitive neuroectodermal neoplasm that occurs in the central nervous system.
name: Central primitive neuroectodermal tumor

desc: A highly malignant embryonal tumor of infancy and young childhood characterized by neuroectodermal elements organized in distinctive multilayered rosettes. Ependymoblastomas are large lesions that occur in the supratentorial compartment, typically displaying a physical connection to the ventricular system.
name: Ependymoblastoma

desc: A primitive neuroectodermal tumor that originates from the cells of the embryonic medullary canal.
name: Medulloepithelioma

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from and is composed of epithelial cells. This category include adenomas, papillomas, and carcinomas [NCIT:C3709].
name: Epithelial neoplasm

desc: A malignant tumor arising from epithelial cells. Carcinomas that arise from glandular epithelium are called adenocarcinomas, those that arise from squamous epithelium are called squamous cell carcinomas, and those that arise from transitional epithelium are called transitional cell carcinomas (NCI Thesaurus).
name: Carcinoma

desc: A tumor that arises from a gland cell.
name: Glandular cell neoplasm

desc: Ovarian mucinous neoplasms consist of borderline tumors (tumors of low malignant potential, or LMP tumors), intraepithelial (non-invasive) carcinoma, and invasive carcinoma.
name: Ovarian mucinous tumor

desc: Mucin-producing and septated cyst-forming epithelial neoplasia of the pancreas with a distinctive ovarian-type stroma.
layperson: Mucinous cystic neoplasm of the pancreas
name: Mucinous cystic neoplasm of the pancreas

desc: A subtype of colorectal carcinoma with mucin lakes.
name: Mucinous colorectal carcinoma

desc: A poorly differentiated type of gastric carcinoma with a substantial amount of extracellular mucus (over 50% of tumor volume) within the tumor.
name: Mucinous gastric carcinoma

desc: An epithelial neoplasm originating in the appendix and often associated with cystic dilation of the appendix due to accumulation of gelatinous material, morphologically referred to as mucoceles.
name: Appendiceal mucinous neoplasm

desc: A connective tissue neoplasm formed by proliferation of mesodermal cells. Bone and soft tissue sarcomas are the main types of sarcoma. Sarcoma is usually highly malignant.
name: Sarcoma

desc: A malignant tumor of the bone which always arises in the medullary tissue, occurring more often in cylindrical bones.
name: Ewing sarcoma

desc: A type of sarcoma (A connective tissue neoplasm formed by proliferation of mesodermal cells) that develops from soft tissues like fat, muscle, nerves, fibrous tissues, blood vessels, or deep skin tissues.
name: Soft tissue sarcoma

desc: A mesenchymal tumour that is considered to be the commonest primary orbital malignancy in children. Histologically, it may be differentiated into embryonal, alveolar, and pleomorphic types. It is usually intraconal or within the superior orbit.
name: Orbital rhabdomyosarcoma

desc: A type of soft tissue sarcoma with a histological appearance reminiscent of alveoli because of its reticulated fibrous stroma enclosing groups of sarcoma cells, which resemble epithelial cells and are enclosed in alveoli walled with connective tissue.
name: Alveolar soft part sarcoma

desc: A type of mesenchymal tissue cell tumor that exhibits epithelial differentiation, which most frequently arises in the extremities.
name: Synovial sarcoma

desc: A smooth muscle connective tissue tumor, which is rare type of cancer that is a malignant neoplasm of smooth muscle. When such a neoplasm is benign, it is called a leiomyoma.
name: Leiomyosarcoma

desc: A fibroblastic sarcoma is a malignant tumor derived from fibrous connective tissue and characterized by immature proliferating fibroblasts or undifferentiated anaplastic spindle cells.
name: Fibrosarcoma

desc: A form of malignant cancer of the connective tissue surrounding nerves. Given its origin and behavior, it is classified as a sarcoma.
name: Neurofibrosarcoma

desc: Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm.
name: Neoplasm by anatomical site

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the pancreas.
name: Neoplasm of the pancreas

desc: The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic adenocarcinoma

desc: A subtype of ductal pancreatic carcinoma that is thought to originate from squamous metaplasia of pancreatic ductal epithelium.
name: Pancreatic squamous cell carcinoma
synonyms: Squamous cell carcinoma of the pancreas

desc: A rare pediatric carcinoma of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatoblastoma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Neoplasm of the gastrointestinal tract

desc: A condition in which there is increased production of gastrin by a gastrin-secreting tumor (usually located in the pancreas, duodenum, or abdominal lymph nodes) that stimulates the gastric mucosa to maximal activity, with consequent gastrointestinal mucosal ulceration.
name: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the liver.
name: Neoplasm of the liver

desc: A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates in hepatocytes and presents macroscopically as a soft and hemorrhagic tan mass in the liver.
name: Hepatocellular carcinoma

desc: A benign tumor of the liver of presumably epithelial origin.
name: Hepatocellular adenoma

desc: A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
name: Intestinal polyp

desc: A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the small intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.
name: Small intestinal polyp

desc: A non-malignant sessile or pedunculated polyp in the colon and rectum that displays a cap of inflammatory granulation tissue with fibrinopurulent exudate that covers the polyp.
name: Inflammatory cap polyp

desc: The presence of multiple polyps in the intestine.
name: Intestinal polyposis
synonyms: Growths in inner lining of intestine

desc: The presence of multiple polyps in the large intestine.
name: Large intestinal polyposis

desc: Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon.
name: Adenomatous colonic polyposis

desc: Presence of multiple hyperplastic polyps in the colon. Hyperplastic polyps are generally about 5 mm in size and show hyperplastic mucosal proliferation.
name: Hyperplastic colonic polyposis

desc: The presence of multiple rectal hyperplastic/adenomatous polyps.
name: Rectal polyposis

desc: Multiple abnormal growths that arise from the lining of the large intestine (colon or rectum) and protrude into the intestinal lumen.
name: Colorectal polyposis

desc: The presence of multiple polyps in the small intestine.
name: Small intestinal polyposis

desc: Presence of multiple polyps in the duodenum.
name: Duodenal polyposis
