desc: The presence of multiple serrated polyps in the intestine. Unlike conventional adenomas, which are uniformly dysplastic, the vast majority of serrated lesions contain no dysplasia. The serrated class includes the hyperplastic polyps, which are not considered precancerous; sessile serrated polyps (also called sessile serrated adenomas); and traditional serrated adenomas. Sessile serrated polyps are larger on average and more often located in the proximal colon. Sessile serrated polyps have a more irregular surface, a pattern to the surface that has been called cloudlike, and indistinct edges compared with hyperplastic polyps. Sessile serrated polyps also have large open pits on the surface (type O pits) when viewed with magnification.
name: Serrated intestinal polyps

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the intestines.
name: Adenocarcinoma of the intestines

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the small intestine.
name: Adenocarcinoma of the small intestine

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum.
name: Duodenal adenocarcinoma

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the jejunum.
name: Jejunal adenocarcinoma

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the ileum.
name: Ileal adenocarcinoma

desc: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the large intestine.
name: Adenocarcinoma of the large intestine

desc: An adenoma carcinoma that originates in the anal canal.
name: Anal canal adenocarcinoma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach.
name: Neoplasm of the stomach

desc: A cancer arising in any part of the stomach.
name: Stomach cancer

desc: A malignant neoplasm of the stomach that grows submucosally in the gastric wall. Necrosis and hemorrhage may be visible radiologically. Histologically, spindle cells with abnormal mitotic activity may be visible.
name: Gastric leiomyosarcoma

desc: A type of cancer that originates in the peritoneum. It is to be distinguished from metastatic cancer of the peritoneum. Peritoneal cancer can occur anywhere in the abdominal space, and affects the surface of organs contained inside the peritoneum.
name: Primary peritoneal carcinoma

desc: A carcinoma originating in the ampulla of Vater (also known as the hepatopancreatic duct), which is formed by the union of the pancreatic duct and the common bile duct.
name: Ampulla of Vater carcinoma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the biliary system.
name: Biliary tract neoplasm

desc: Multiple biliary hamartomas are a rare clinicopathologic entity, consisting of small (less than 1.5cm), usually multiple and nodular cystic lesions in the liver.
name: Multiple biliary hamartomas

desc: Cholangiocarcinoma is a primary cancer originating in the biliary epithelium i.e., the cholangiocytes, of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary ducts. It is extremely invasive, develops rapidly, often metastasizes, and has a very poor prognosis. They are slow growing tumors which spread longitudinally along the bile ducts with neural, perineural and subepithelial extension.
name: Cholangiocarcinoma

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the gallbladder.
name: Neoplasm of the gallbladder

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal neoplasm

desc: The presence of a carcinoma of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal carcinoma

desc: A rare benign epithelial tumor that is usually asymptomatic but can present with pyrosis and epigastric discomfort with or without dysphagia. Histopathologically, esophageal squamous papilloma has fingerlike projections lined with acanthotic stratified squamous epithelium with conservation of normal cellular with or without cellular atypia.
name: Esophageal squamous papilloma

desc: An abnormal change (metaplasia) in the cells of the inferior portion of the esophagus. The normal squamous epithelium lining of the esophagus is replaced by metaplastic columnar epithelium. Columnar epithelium refers to a cell type that is typically found in more distal parts of the gastrointestinal system.
name: Barrett esophagus

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the small intestine.
name: Neoplasm of the small intestine

desc: The presence of a neoplasm of the large intestine.
name: Neoplasm of the large intestine

desc: A squamous cell carcinoma that originates in the anal canal.
name: Anal canal squamous cell carcinoma

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm (tumour) originating in striated muscle, either skeletal muscle or cardiac muscle.
name: Neoplasm of striated muscle

desc: A benign tumor of striated muscle.
name: Rhabdomyoma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the head and neck region with origin in the lip, oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, or larynx.
name: Neoplasm of head and neck

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the face.
name: Facial neoplasm

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the mouth.
name: Mouth neoplasm

desc: A benign but highly vascular nasopharyngeal neoplasm. The tumor originates from the sphenopalatine foramen and involves both the pterygopalatine fossa and the posterior nasal cavity.
name: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) that arises from the soft tissue. The most common types are lipomatous (fatty), vascular, smooth muscle, fibrous, and fibrohistiocytic neoplasms.
name: Soft tissue neoplasm

desc: A mesenchymal neoplasm characterized by solitary or multiple nodules involving the skin, striated muscles, bones and, sometimes, viscera. It usually appears as a subcutaneous nodule, but can also appear as an ulcer, pedunculated lesion, or similar to a hemangioma. Histology shows well-circumscribed tapered cell lobes, resembling smooth muscle cells. At its center, perivascular round cells (hemangiopericitoides) are usually observed, giving a biphasic appearance.
name: Myofibromatosis

desc: A benign mesenchymal neoplasm arising from smooth, skeletal, or cardiac muscle tissue [NCIT:C4882].
name: Benign muscle neoplasm

desc: A benign tumor that is usually solitary, painless, palpable mass that is firm in consistency and slightly movable and often fluctuant. It can occur in any location, but tends to involve the muscles of the thighs, buttocks, and shoulders. On microscopic examination, there is abundant mucoid material and relative hypo cellularity and loose reticulin fibers. Vascular structures are sparse. The cells have a stellate shape with small hyper chromatic pyknotic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm. Some myxomas may show focal areas of hyper cellularity. However absence of nuclear atypia, mitotic figures or necrosis helps to rule out malignancy.
name: Intramuscular Myxoma

desc: Malignant mesothelioma is a form of cancer that originates from the cells of the mesothelium, a thin tissue layer surrounding the body's internal organs. Malignant mesothelioma is almost exclusively caused by asbestos exposure, pleural mesothelioma beeing the most common form, affecting the lining of the lungs called the pleura. Other forms such as perioneal-, percardial- or testicular- mesothelioma are much rarer.
name: Malignant mesothelioma

desc: A Malignant mesothelioma originating from cells of the peritoneum (the thin layer of mesothelium lining the abdomen). Peritoneal mesothelioma is the second most common form of mesothelioma after pleural mesothelioma.
name: Peritoneal mesothelioma

desc: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of adipose tissue.
name: Neoplasm of fatty tissue

desc: The presence of multiple lipomas (a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue).
name: Multiple lipomas

desc: Benign neoplasia derived from lipoblasts or lipocytes of white or brown fat. May be angiomatous or hibernomatous.
name: Lipoma

desc: Presence of a lipoma in the region of the sacrum.
name: Sacral lipoma

desc: Malignant neoplasms which probably originate in primitive mesenchymal stem cell populations differentiating down a lipomatous pathway.
name: Liposarcoma

desc: A liposarcoma that contains myxomatous tissue.
name: Myxoid liposarcoma

desc: An abnormality of the immune system.
name: Abnormality of the immune system

desc: A functional abnormality of the immune system.
name: Abnormality of immune system physiology

desc: Failure of the immune system to protect the body adequately from infection, due to the absence or insufficiency of some component process or substance.
name: Immunodeficiency

desc: A general term referring to a defect in immunity resulting from impaired antibody production.
name: Humoral immunodeficiency

desc: An immunodeficiency characterized by defective cell-mediated immunity or humoral immunity.
name: Cellular immunodeficiency

desc: A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms.
name: Severe T-cell immunodeficiency

desc: A group of phenotypically heterogeneous genetic disorders characterized by profound deficiencies of T- and B-cell function, which predispose the patients to both infectious and noninfectious complications.
name: Combined immunodeficiency

desc: A combined immunodeficiency primary immune deficiency that is characterized by a more severe defect in both the T- and B-lymphocyte systems.
name: Severe combined immunodeficiency

desc: Altered immune function characterized by lymphoid proliferation, immune activation, and excessive autoreactivity often leading to autoimmune/inflammatory complications.
name: Immune dysregulation

desc: The occurrence of an immune reaction against the organism's own cells or tissues.
name: Autoimmunity

desc: A chronic, relapsing, inflammatory, and often febrile multisystemic disorder of connective tissue, characterized principally by involvement of the skin, joints, kidneys, and serosal membranes.
name: Systemic lupus erythematosus

desc: The presence of an antibody in the blood circulation that is directed against the organism's own cells or tissues.
name: Autoimmune antibody positivity

desc: The presence in the serum of an autoantibody directed against the Fc portion of IgG.
name: Rheumatoid factor positive

desc: The presence in serum of antibodies against smooth muscle.
name: Smooth muscle antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against neutrophils.
name: Antineutrophil antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against proteins predominantly expressed in perinuclear region of neutrophils.
name: Perinuclear antineutrophil antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against proteins predominantly expressed in cytoplasmic granules of neutrophils.
name: Cytoplasmic antineutrophil antibody positivity

desc: The presence in the serum of autoantibodies directed against thrombocytes.
name: Platelet antibody positive

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against nuclei or nuclear components.
name: Antinuclear antibody positivity

desc: A type of antinuclear antibody (ANA) positivity revealed by indirect immunofluorescence (IFL). The multiple nuclear dots (MND) pattern is immunomorphologically characterized by the staining of 3-20 dots of variable size distributed all over the cell nucleus, but sparing the nucleoli, and, in contrast to the anticentromere pattern, MND reactivity does not stain the chromosomes in mitotic cells.
name: Anti-multiple nuclear dots antibody positivity

desc: The presence of circulating autoantibodies to phospholipids.
name: Antiphospholipid antibody positivity

desc: The presence of circulating IgG autoantibodies to cardiolipin.
name: Anticardiolipin IgG antibody positivity

desc: The presence of circulating IgM autoantibodies to cardiolipin.
name: Anticardiolipin IgM antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react against granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor.
layperson: Anti-granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor antibody positivity
name: Anti-granulocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against DNA.
name: Anti-DNA antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against glutamic acid decarboxylase.
name: Anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody positivity

desc: Presence of lupus anticoagulant (LA) autoantibodies. LA represent a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies, IgG, IgM, or a mixture of both classes, that interfere with standard phospholipid-based coagulant tests (this is only an in vitro phenomenon, LA do not cause reduction of coagulation in vivo). The antibodies are directed against plasma proteins which also bind to phospholipid surfaces.
name: Lupus anticoagulant

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against thyroid peroxidase.
name: Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody positivity

desc: Circulating antipituitary antibodies (APA) are markers of autoimmune hypophysitis, which may cause deficient pituitary function.
name: Anti-pituitary antibody positivity

desc: Warm reactive autoantibodies are RBC-directed immune responses that are maximally reactive at 37 degrees C.
name: Warm reactive autoantibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG).
name: Anti-myelin-associated glycoprotein antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against mitochondria.
name: Antimitochondrial antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against the acetylcholine receptor.
name: Acetylcholine receptor antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against voltage-gated calcium channels.
name: Calcium channel antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against muscle specific kinase (anti-MuSK Ab).
name: Muscle specific kinase antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against topoisomerase I.
name: Topoisomerase I antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against the centromeres or centromere components.
name: Anticentromere antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against C3 convertase (C3bBb).
name: C3 nephritic factor positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against P450 2D6, a cytochrome P450 mono-oxygenase. Anti-LKM-1 antibodies are considered to be a diagnostic marker of autoimmune hepatitis type 2 (AIH2).
layperson: Liver kidney microsome type 1 antibody positivity
name: Liver kidney microsome type 1 antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against a 60-kd peptide contained in the liver cytosolic fraction.
layperson: Anti-liver cytosolic antigen type 1 antibody positivity
name: Anti-liver cytosolic antigen type 1 antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against the insulin receptor.
name: Insulin receptor antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react to gangliosides.
name: Anti-ganglioside antibody positivity

desc: The presence of M2 anti-mitochondrial antibody (immunoglobulins) in the serum.
name: Anti-mitochondrial M2 antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react to thyroglobulin.
name: Anti-thyroglobulin antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against the La/Sjogrens syndrome antigen.
name: Anti-La/SSA antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react against the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate)-type glutamate receptor.
name: Anti-NMDA receptor antibody positivity
synonyms: Presence of anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate Receptor antibody in blood
Presence of anti-NMDAR antibody in blood

desc: A positive result of the direct antiglobulin test (DAT), a method of demonstrating the presence of antibody or complement bound to red blood cell (RBC) membranes by the use of anti-human globulin to form a visible agglutination reaction.
name: Positive direct antiglobulin test

desc: Presence of antibodies against beta 2 glycoprotein I in the circulation. Beta-2 glycoprotein I (beta2GPI) is the principal target of autoantibodies in the antiphospholipid syndrome (APS).
name: Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein I antibody positivity

desc: Presence of autoantibodies against the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGPR) in the blood circulation.
name: Anti-asialoglycoprotein receptor antibody positivity

desc: Presence of antibodies in the serum that react against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein.
name: Anti-myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies in the serum that react to the histidyl-tRNA-synthetase.
name: Anti-Jo-1 antibody positivity

desc: The presence of an antibody in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that is directed against the organism's own cells or tissues.
name: CSF autoimmune antibody positivity

desc: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that react against the NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate)-type glutamate receptor.
name: CSF anti-NMDA receptor antibody positivity
synonyms: Presence of anti-NMDAR antibody in cerebrospinal fluid
Presence of anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate Receptor antibody in CSF
Presence of NMDAR antibody in CSF

desc: An abnormality of the humoral immune system, which comprises antibodies produced by B cells as well as the complement system.
name: Abnormality of humoral immunity

desc: An abnormality of the complement system.
name: Abnormality of complement system

desc: An immunodeficiency defined by the absent or suboptimal functioning of one of the complement system proteins.
name: Complement deficiency

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C8 in circulation.
name: C8 deficiency

desc: A reduced level of the complement component Factor I in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement factor I

desc: A reduced level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement factor H

desc: A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
name: Partial complement factor H deficiency

desc: A reduced level of the complement component factor B in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement factor B

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement C3

desc: A partial reduction in level of the complement component Factor D in circulation.
layperson: Partial functional complement factor D deficiency
name: Partial functional complement factor D deficiency

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C9 in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement C9

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C4 in the circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement C4

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C4a in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement C4a

desc: A reduced level of the complement component C4b in circulation.
name: Decreased serum complement C4b

desc: A deviation in any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
layperson: Abnormality of the alternative complement pathway
name: Abnormality of the alternative complement pathway

desc: An abnormal reduction in the components of the alternative complement pathway, such as the C3 protein or its cleavage products.
layperson: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
name: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway

desc: An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
name: Dysfunctional alternative complement pathway

desc: A diminished activity of the classical complement pathway as measured by the assay for 50% haemolytic complement (CH50) activity of serum.
name: Reduced hemolytic complement activity

desc: Any deviation from the normal total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.
name: Abnormal total hemolytic complement activity

desc: An abnormally elevated total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.
name: Increased total hemolytic complement activity

desc: An abnormally reduced total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.
name: Decreased total hemolytic complement activity

desc: Persistence of immune complexes in the blood circulation.
name: Circulating immune complexes

desc: Increased level of cryoglobulins in the blood. Cryoglobulins are abnormal immunoglobulins, especially IGG or IGM, that precipitate spontaneously when serum is cooled below 37 degrees Celsius.
name: Cryoglobulinemia

desc: An abnormal functioning of phagocytosis. Phagocytosis is an elegant but complex process for the ingestion and elimination of pathogens, but it is also important for the elimination of apoptotic cells and hence fundamental for tissue homeostasis. Phagocytosis can be divided into four main steps: (i) recognition of the target particle, (ii) signaling to activate the internalization machinery, (iii) phagosome formation, and (iv) phagolysosome maturation.
name: Abnormal phagocytosis

desc: An absence of the phase of elevated metabolic activity, during which oxygen consumption increases, that occurs in neutrophils, monocytes, and macrophages shortly after phagocytosing material. An enhanced uptake of oxygen leads to the production, by an NADH dependent system, of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), superoxide anions and hydroxyl radicals, which play a part in microbiocidal activity.
layperson: Absence of bactericidal oxidative respiratory burst in phagocytes
name: Absence of bactericidal oxidative respiratory burst in phagocytes

desc: An abnormality of the concentration or function of circulating immune proteins.
layperson: Abnormality of immune serum protein physiology
name: Abnormality of immune serum protein physiology

desc: Abnormality of the cytokine levels in the blood, i.e., an abnormality of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells.
name: Abnormality of serum cytokine level

desc: Abnormal levels of interferon in the blood.
name: Abnormal serum interferon level

desc: Abnormal levels of interferon gamma measured in the blood circulation.
name: Abnormal serum interferon-gamma level

desc: An elevation in the concentration of interferon gamma measured in the blood circulation.
name: Increased serum interferon-gamma level

desc: An abnormal amount of any of the interleukins, a class of cytokines, in the circulation.
name: Abnormal serum interleukin level

desc: An increased concentration of interleukin-6 in the circulation.
name: Increased serum interleukin-6

desc: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a cytokine (i.e., any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells).
name: Abnormality of cytokine secretion

desc: An impairment in the production by leukocytes of NFKB1-dependent cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interferon-alpha.
name: Defective production of NFKB1-dependent cytokines

desc: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of a chemokine (a class of cytokines).
name: Abnormality of chemokine secretion

desc: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of interferons (a class of cytokines).
name: Abnormality of interferon secretion

desc: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of interleukins (a class of cytokines).
name: Abnormality of interleukin secretion

desc: An abnormality in the production or cellular release of tumor necrosis factor.
layperson: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
name: Abnormality of tumor necrosis factor secretion
synonyms: Abnormality of tumour necrosis factor secretion

desc: Any abnormality in the series of molecular signals initiated by the binding of a cytokine to a receptor on the surface of a cell, and ending with regulation of a downstream cellular process, e.g. transcription.
name: Abnormal cytokine signaling

desc: A defect or impairment in the series of molecular signals initiated by the binding of a cytokine to a receptor on the surface of a cell, and ending with regulation of a downstream cellular process, e.g. transcription.
name: Impaired cytokine signaling

desc: Any anomaly of the inflammatory response, a response to injury or infection characterized by local vasodilation, extravasation of plasma into intercellular spaces and accumulation of white blood cells and macrophages.
name: Abnormal inflammatory response

desc: An abnormal reduction in the inflammatory response to injury or infection.
name: Decreased inflammatory response

desc: A abnormal increase in the inflammatory response to injury or infection.
name: Increased inflammatory response

desc: The presence of inflammation in the pancreas.
name: Pancreatitis

desc: A acute form of pancreatitis.
name: Acute pancreatitis

desc: A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification.
name: Chronic calcifying pancreatitis

desc: A chronic form of pancreatitis.
name: Chronic pancreatitis

desc: A recurrent form of pancreatitis.
name: Recurrent pancreatitis

desc: Inflammation of the alimentary part of the gastrointestinal system.
name: Gastrointestinal inflammation

desc: Inflammation, or an inflammatory state in the large intestine.
name: Inflammation of the large intestine

desc: Colitis refers to an inflammation of the colon and is often used to describe an inflammation of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum). Colitides may be acute and self-limited or chronic, and broadly fit into the category of digestive diseases.
name: Colitis

desc: A chronic inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
name: Chronic colitis

desc: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores, in the colon. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset and intermittent periods of exacerbated symptoms contrasting with periods that are relatively symptom-free. In contrast to Crohn's disease this special form of colitis begins in the distal parts of the rectum, spreads continually upwards and affects only mucose and submucose tissue of the colon.
name: Ulcerative colitis

desc: An acute and self-limited inflammatory disease of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum).
name: Acute colitis

desc: An inflammation of the colon and small intestine. However, most conditions are either categorized as Enteritis (inflammation of the small intestine) or Colitis (inflammation of the large intestine).
name: Enterocolitis

desc: An excess of eosinophilic cells in colonic tissue, i.e., eosinophilic infiltration in the colon.
name: Colonic eosinophilia

desc: A chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease of the intestines that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea which may be bloody, vomiting, or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside of the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is thought to be an autoimmune disease, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract, causing inflammation.
name: Crohn's disease

desc: Inflammation of the esophagus.
name: Esophagitis

desc: Infiltration of numerous eosinophils (usually greater than 15 per high power field) into the squamous epithelium of the esophagus, and layering of eosinophils on the surface layer of the esophagus.
name: Eosinophilic infiltration of the esophagus

desc: The formation of small localized collection of eosinophiles (an eosinophilic microabscess) in the esophagus. Usually clusters of greater than or equal to 4 eosinophils are seen, that appear as exudates or white spots or white plaques.
layperson: Eosinophilic microabscess formation in the esophagus
name: Eosinophilic microabscess formation in the esophagus
synonyms: Eosinophilic micro-abscess formation in the esophagus
Eosinophilic microabscess formation in the oesophagus

desc: Inflammation of the liver.
name: Hepatitis

desc: Acute hepatitis complicated by acute liver failure with hepatic encephalopathy occurring less than 8 weeks after the onset of jaundice.
name: Fulminant hepatitis

desc: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus.
name: Viral hepatitis

desc: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with enterovirus.
name: Enteroviral hepatitis

desc: Inflammation of the liver characterized by a mononuclear cell infiltrate whereby portal inflammatory cells extend through the limiting plate between the portal tract and liver parenchyma.
name: Interface hepatitis

desc: Chronic hepatitis characterized by parenchymal inflammation with formation of large multinucleated hepatocytes in response to a variety of insults to the liver.
name: Giant cell hepatitis
synonyms: Giant cell hepatitis on liver biopsy
Giant cell hepatitis shown on biopsy

desc: Acute hepatic injury resulting from inflammation typically accompanied by increased serum alanine transaminase activity. Etiologies include viral hepatitis, drugs, toxins, and autoimmune disorders.
name: Acute hepatitis

desc: Hepatitis that lasts for more than six months.
name: Chronic hepatitis

desc: Chronic hepatitis associated with recurrent clinical exacerbations, extrahepatic manifestations, and progression to cirrhosis.
name: Chronic active hepatitis

desc: Chronic hepatitis associated with infection by cryptosporidia, as demonstrated (for example) by immunohistochemistry of liver tissue.
layperson: Chronic hepatitis due to cryptosporidium infection
name: Chronic hepatitis due to cryptosporidium infection
synonyms: Hepatitis, chronic, due to cryptosporidium infection

desc: Inflammation of adipose tissue.
name: Panniculitis

desc: Inflammation of the biliary ductal system, affecting the intrahepatic or extrahepatic portions, or both.
name: Cholangitis

desc: Cholangitis characterized by the presence of numerous polymorphonuclear cells around and within the wall as well as within the lumen of the ducts. This may involve ducts of any size and is occasionally associated with abscess formation (cholangitic abscess).
name: Suppurative cholangitis

desc: Cholangitis characterized by the accumulation of granulomas. Granulomas are aggregates of modified macrophages (epithelioid cells) and other inflammatory cells that accumulate after chronic exposure to antigens. The underlying trigger may be exposure to noxious agents that cannot be biochemically degraded or to immune dysfunction. The ultimate result is a release of a variety cytokines that stimulate mononuclear cells that fuse to form multinucleated giant cells with a surrounding rim of lymphocytes and fibroblasts.
name: Granulomatous cholangitis

desc: Cholangitis characterized by a close association between duct branches, usually interlobular bile ducts, and lymphocytic aggregates, which may show a follicular arrangement.
name: Lymphoid cholangitis

desc: Cholangitis associated with mixed inflammatory infiltrates and the presence of fibrosis or sclerosis of the biliary tree.
name: Pleomorphic cholangitis

desc: Cholangitis associated with evident ductal fibrosis that develops as a consequence of long-standing bile duct inflammatory, obstruction, or ischemic injury; it can be obliterative or nonobliterative.
name: Sclerosing cholangitis

desc: Inflammation in any serous cavity.
name: Serositis

desc: Inflammation of the peritoneum.
name: Peritonitis

desc: Peritonitis caused by intrauterine intestinal rupture and spillage of fetal meconium into the fetal peritoneal cavity. Intra-peritoneal meconium usually calcifies, sometimes within 24 hours. Ultrasound findings may include intraabdominal calcifications.
name: Meconium peritonitis

desc: Inflammation of fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle.
name: Fasciitis

desc: Inflammation and thickening (localized fibrosis) of the fascia, the tissue under the skin and over the muscle, typically associated with a build up of eosinophils in the muscles and tissues.
name: Eosinophilic fasciitis

desc: A general term for inflammation of the muscles without respect to the underlying cause.
name: Myositis

desc: Abnormal amount of a protein that is normally present on the cell surface of lymphocytes.
name: Abnormal lymphocyte surface marker expression

desc: A reduction in the expression of CD43 on the cell surface of lymphocytes.
layperson: Reduced lymphocyte surface expression of CD43
name: Reduced lymphocyte surface expression of CD43
synonyms: Cd43 defectively expressed on surface of blood cells
Reduced lymphocyte surface expression of sialophorin

desc: A deficiency in the expression of the CD40 ligand on the surface of activated T-lymphocytes.
name: Reduced T cell CD40 expression

desc: A deviation from the normal level of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules expressed at the cell surface.
name: Abnormal MHC II surface expression

desc: A reduction from the normal level of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules expressed at the cell surface.
name: Reduced MHC II surface expression

desc: An increase above the normal level of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules expressed at the cell surface.
name: Elevated MHC II surface expression

desc: An impaired immune response mediated by cells expressing specific receptors for antigen produced through a somatic diversification process, and allowing for an enhanced secondary response to subsequent exposures to the same antigen (immunological memory).
name: Impaired antigen-specific response

desc: Impaired response of CD8 T cells to pathogens. CD8 T cells direct the killing of a target cell through the release of granules containing cytotoxic mediators or through the engagement of death receptors.
name: Impaired pathogen-specific CD8 cytoxicity

desc: A type of infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection. There are five general subtypes. (i) Opportunistic infection, meaning infection by a pathogen that is not normally able to cause infection in a healthy host (e.g., pneumonia by Pneumocystis jirovecii or CMV); (ii) Unusual location (focus) of an infection (e.g., an aspergillus brain abscess); (iii) a protracted course or lack of adequate response to treatment (e.g., chronic rhinosinusitis); (iv) Unusual severity or intensity of an infection; and (v) unusual recurrence of infections.
name: Unusual infection

desc: Increased susceptibility to infections.
name: Recurrent infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of bacterial infection.
name: Recurrent bacterial infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to infection by gram-negative bacteria, as manifested by a medical history of repeated or frequent infections by these agents.
name: Recurrent gram-negative bacterial infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to infections with Escherichia coli, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent.
name: Recurrent E. coli infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to Serratia marcescens infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Serratia marcescens infection.
name: Recurrent Serratia marcescens infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to Klebsiella infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Klebsiella infection.
name: Recurrent Klebsiella infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to infections with Burkholderia cepacia, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection with this agent.
name: Recurrent Burkholderia cepacia infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae infections as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by Haemophilus influenzae.
name: Recurrent Haemophilus influenzae infections

desc: Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).
name: Recurrent Neisserial infections

desc: Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
layperson: Increased susceptibility to neisseria meningitidis infections
name: Recurrent meningococcal disease
synonyms: Increased susceptibility to neisseria meningitidis infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to systemic pyogenic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of systemic pyogenic infections.
name: Recurrent systemic pyogenic infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to staphylococcal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of staphylococcal infections.
name: Recurrent staphylococcal infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to Staphylococcus aureus infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of Staphylococcus aureus infection.
name: Recurrent Staphylococcus aureus infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.
name: Recurrent mycobacterial infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to mycobacterial avium complex infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of mycobacterial infection.
name: Recurrent mycobacterium avium complex infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to streptococcal infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of streptococcal infections.
name: Recurrent streptococcal infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to abscess formation, as manifested by a medical history of recurrent abscesses.
name: Recurrent abscess formation

desc: Increased susceptibility to fungal infections, as manifested by multiple episodes of fungal infection.
name: Recurrent fungal infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to Aspergillus infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of Aspergillus infections.
name: Recurrent Aspergillus infections

desc: An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections.
name: Recurrent candida infections

desc: A fungal infection of the toenails or fingernails that tends to cause the nails to thicken, discolor, disfigure, and split.
name: Onychomycosis

desc: A history of repeated fungal infections located between the fingers or toes, usually manifested by scaling, maceration, and itching. The toes are more commonly affected than the fingers.
name: Recurrent interdigital mycosis

desc: A history of repeated fungal infections located on the sole of the foot, usually manifested by scaling, maceration, and itching.
name: Recurrent plantar mycosis

desc: Increased susceptibility to viral infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of viral infection.
name: Recurrent viral infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to enteroviral infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of enteroviral infection.
name: Recurrent enteroviral infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to herpesvirus, as manifested by recurrent episodes of herpesvirus.
name: Recurrent herpes

desc: Recurrent episodes of genital herpes, typically characterized by stages of erythema, papules, short-lived vesicles, painful ulcers, and crusts on the skin of the genitals and surrounding area, and that typically resolve over a period of 2 to 3 weeks.
name: Recurrent genital herpes

desc: Repeated episodes of a localized, painful cutaneous eruption related to reactivation of varicella zoster virus (VZV) and characterized by a characteristic rash in one or two adjacent dermatomes.
name: Recurrent shingles

desc: Recurrent episodes of oral herpes, typically characterized by blisters or ulcers on the gums, lips and/or tongue caused by herpes virus.
name: Recurrent oral herpes

desc: Increased susceptibility to chicken pox, as manifested by recurrent episodes of chicken pox.
name: Susceptibility to chickenpox

desc: Increased susceptibility to coronavirus 229e, as manifested by recurrent episodes of coronavirus 229e.
name: Susceptibility to coronavirus 229e

desc: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract
synonyms: Recurrent infection of the gastrointestinal tract
Recurrent infection of the GI tract

desc: A recurrent infection of the GI tract with helicobacter pylori, a gram-negative, microaerophilic bacterium usually found in the stomach.
name: Helicobacter pylori infection

desc: Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection.
name: Frequent Giardia lamblia infestation

desc: Increased susceptibility to gastroenteritis, an infectious inflammationof the stomach and small intestines manifested by signs and symptoms such as diarheas and abdominal pain, as manifested by recurrent episodes of gastroenteritis.
name: Recurrent gastroenteritis

desc: Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.
name: Recurrent protozoan infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to infection by the protozan parasite of the genus Leishmania.
name: Tegumentary leishmaniasis susceptibility

desc: Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.
name: Recurrent opportunistic infections

desc: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood.
layperson: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
name: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood

desc: Increased susceptibility to parasitic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of parasitic infection.
name: Recurrent parasitic infections

desc: Increased susceptibility to ear infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of ear infections.
name: Recurrent ear infections

desc: A severe virus infection of the central nervous system by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
name: Herpes simplex encephalitis

desc: An infection resulting from live attenuated vaccines (LAV), that is, a vaccine prepared from living viruses or bacteria that have been weakened under laboratory conditions. LAV vaccines will replicate in a vaccinated individual and produce an immune response but usually cause mild or no disease. are derived from disease-causing pathogens.
name: Infection following live vaccination

desc: Local or regional infection with Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) following vaccination.
name: BCGitis

desc: Distant, or disseminated infection with Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) following vaccination.
name: BCGosis

desc: Infection with the measles virus of the live-attenuated vaccine. This is an extremely rare event and may indicate immunocompromise in some cases.
name: Post-vaccination measles

desc: Infection with the rubella virus of the live-attenuated vaccine.
name: Post-vaccination rubella

desc: Infection with live attenuated polio vaccine following vaccination. This is an extreemely rare event that may indicate immunocompromise.
name: Post-vaccination polio

desc: Infection with live attenuated rotavirus vaccine following vaccination.
name: Post-vaccination rotavirus infection

desc: An unusual fungal infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection by a fungal agent.
name: Unusual fungal infection

desc: Fungal infection characterized by invasion of host tissues.
name: Invasive fungal infection

desc: Infection of the lungs with aspergillus. In the respiratory mucosa, the spores may germinate into hyphae, which in turn can invade the mucosa leading to invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
name: Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis

desc: An infection that is caused by a fungus that would generally not be able to cause an infection in a host with a normal immune system. Such fungi take advantage of the opportunity, so to speak, that is provided by a weakened immune system.
name: Opportunistic fungal infection

desc: An opportunistic disease caused by invasion of unicellular fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii. Transmission of P. jirovecii cysts takes place through the airborne route, and usually, its presence in lungs is asymptomatic. However, people with impaired immunity, especially those with CD4+ T cell count below 200/microliter, are still at risk of the development of Pneumocystis pneumonia due to P. jirovecii invasion. Symptoms induced by this disease are not specific: progressive dyspnoea, non-productive cough, low-grade fever, arterial partial pressure of oxygen below 65 mmHg, and chest radiographs demonstrating bilateral, interstitial shadowing.
name: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

desc: Infection by a Coccidioides species fungus. These are dimorphic, soil-dwelling, fungi known to cause a broad spectrum of disease, ranging from a mild febrile illness to severe pulmonary manifestations or disseminated disease. The genus Coccidioides is comprised of two genetically distinct species: Coccidioides immitis and C. posadasii.
name: Coccidioidomycosis

desc: Histoplasmosis is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum and is consider to be an opportunistic infection in immunosuppressed persons.
name: Histoplasmosis

desc: Histoplasmosis infection involving multiple sites of the body. Disseminated histoplasmosis can involve various organs, including reticuloendothelial organs, gastrointestinal tract, adrenal glands, central nervous system, endovascular structures, kidney, and skin. It typically presents with systemic symptoms like fever, generalized fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, and the symptoms related to the specific organ involved. Severe disseminated disease can manifest as septic shock, multi organ failure, and ARDS.
name: Disseminated histoplasmosis

desc: Infection of the lungs with Histoplasma capsulatum. Symptoms may include fever, headache, weakness, chest pain and dry cough. When imaging is done, chest radiographs may show patchy pneumonia involving one or more lobes with adenopathy of the mediastinum or hilum.
name: Pulmonary histoplasmosis

desc: An unusual protozoan infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection by a protozoal agent.
name: Unusual protozoan infection

desc: Toxoplasmosis is a widespread parasitic infection that is frequently asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients. However, this obligate intracellular protozoan parasite can evade the immune system and persist for the life of its host in cyst form, predominantly in the brain, retina, and muscles. Reactivation of latent cysts may occur when the immune system fails to maintain cytokine pressure, which mainly relies on gamma interferon (IFN-gamma). Toxoplasmosis is a life-threatening infection in immunocompromised patients (ICPs).
name: Severe toxoplasmosis

desc: An unusually severe infection due to Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis or Giardia intestinalis, which is a protozoan parasite of the small intestine that causes extensive morbidity worldwide.
name: Severe giardiasis

desc: Failure to contain infection by a protozoan of the genus Cryptosporidium, leading to spread to many parts of the body.
name: Disseminated cryptosporidium infection

desc: An unusual helminthic infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection by a worm (helminth).
name: Unusual helminthic infection

desc: An unusual parasitic infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection by a parasite.
name: Unusual parasitic infection

desc: A parasitic infection whereby the parasite invades (migrates through) tissues of the infected host.
name: Invasive parasitic infection

desc: Presence of a protracted or persistent infection by a pathogen potentially related to an underlying abnormality of the immune system that is not able to clear the infection.
name: Chronic infection

desc: Chronic active Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection is an uncommon outcome of EBV infection and may present as a waxing and waning or fulminant syndrome. Unlike acute infectious mononucleosis, wherein EBV establishes lifelong infection and survives by maintaining a delicate balance with the host as a latent infection, in chronic active EBV infection the host-virus balance is disturbed.
name: Chronic active Epstein-Barr virus infection

desc: The term tinea means fungal infection, whereas dermatophyte refers to the fungal organisms that cause tinea. This term refers to a tinea infection that is chronic or recalcitrant to treatment and may be reflective of an immune defect.
name: Chronic tinea infection

desc: An infection that is caused by a pathogen that would generally not be able to cause an infection in a host with a normal immune system. Such pathogens take advantage of the opportunity, so to speak, that is provided by a weakened immune system.
name: Opportunistic infection

desc: A viral infection that fails to be contained by the immune sytem and spreads throughout the body.
name: Disseminated viral infection

desc: A dissemination viral infection caused by a live attenuated vaccine virus.
layperson: Disseminated infection with live vaccine virus
name: Disseminated infection with live vaccine virus

desc: An infection that is caused by a bacterium that would generally not be able to cause an infection in a host with a normal immune system. Such bacteria take advantage of the opportunity, so to speak, that is provided by a weakened immune system.
name: Opportunistic bacterial infection

desc: An infection by an encapsulated bacterial agent. Isolates which cause invasive disease are usually surrounded by a polysaccharide capsule, which is a major virulence factor and the key antigen in protective protein-polysaccharide conjugate vaccines.
name: Infection due to encapsulated bacteria

desc: Mycobacterium abscessus complex comprises a group of rapidly growing, multidrug-resistant, nontuberculous mycobacteria that are responsible for a wide spectrum of skin and soft tissue diseases, central nervous system infections, bacteremia, and ocular and other infections.
name: Mycobacterium abscessus abscessus infection

desc: An infection by Acinetobacter baumannii, a Gram-negative bacillus that is aerobic, pleomorphic and non-motile. An opportunistic pathogen, A. baumannii has a high incidence among immunocompromised individuals, particularly those who have experienced a prolonged (over 90 d) hospital stay.
name: Acinetobacter infection

desc: Failure to contain thebacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) following vaccination leading to spread of BCG to many sites in the body. The tuberculosis vaccine BCG contains live attenuated Mycobacterium bovis.
name: Disseminated Bacillus Calmette-Guerin infection

desc: An infection of the lung caused by environmental mycobacteria. Such infections can occur in individuals with predisposing lung disease or immune disease.
name: Nontuberculous mycobacterial pulmonary infection

desc: A lung infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis a slightly curved non-motile, aerobic, non-capsulated and non-spore forming strains of mycobacteria.
name: Pulmonary tuberculosis

desc: A type of tubercular infection located outside of the lung, which is the most common location of tuberculosis. There are two types of clinical manifestation of tuberculosis (TB) are pulmonary TB (PTB) and extrapulmonary TB (EPTB). The former is most common. EPTB refers to TB involving organs other than the lungs (e.g., pleura, lymph nodes, abdomen, genitourinary tract, skin, joints and bones, or meninges). A patient with both pulmonary and EPTB is classified as a case of PTB.
name: Extrapulmonary tuberculosis

desc: An infection with nontuberculous mycobacteria that affects multiple body sites. Such infections can occur in individuals with immune disease.
name: Disseminated nontuberculous mycobacterial infection

desc: Infection with staphylococcus aureus resistant to the antibiotic methicillin (MRSA). MRSA can infect any individual but is more common among hospitalized patients, and can also occur as an opportunistic infection.
name: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection

desc: An unusual infection classified by the affected body part.
name: Unusual infection by anatomical site

desc: A type of infection that is regarded as a sign of a pathological susceptibility to infection because of unusual severity or intensity of the infection.
name: Severe infection

desc: Repeated episodes of the formation of abscesses in organs. An abscess is a circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the parenchyma or an organ.
name: Recurrent deep organ abscess formation

desc: Clinical assessment of a requirement to treat with intravenous antibiotics over an unusually prolonged period of time.
layperson: Prolonged need of intravenous antibiotic therapy
name: Prolonged need of intravenous antibiotic therapy

desc: An unusually severe course of infection with Human norovirus, previously known as Norwalk virus. Norovirus, an RNA virus of the family Caliciviridae, is a human enteric pathogen. Norovirus infection-associated illness may also be more prolonged and severe in immunocompromised individuals and may be associated with remarkably persistent viral excretion in some of these individuals.
name: Severe norovirus infection

desc: Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are small oncogenic viruses. HPV has been shown to cause a variety of lesions and malignancies, which predominantly affect the anogenital region. Low-risk, non-oncogenic HPV types are associated with anogenital warts and recurrent respiratory papillomatosis while high-risk, oncogenic types are associated with cervical, penile, anal, vaginal, vulvar, and oropharyngeal cancers. Infection with anogenital HPV is usually asymptomatic and resolves spontaneously without consequences in the immunocompetent host. When disease does occur, the most common manifestation is genital warts, which may be small papules, or flat, smooth or pedunculated lesions. This resolution of HPV lesions is not generally seen in the immunosuppressed, resulting in severe, persistent and extensive manifestations of HPV disease.
name: Persistent human papillomavirus infection

desc: An unusually severe viral infection.
name: Severe viral infection

desc: An unusually severe infection by cytomegalovirus.
name: Severe cytomegalovirus infection

desc: An unusually severe Epstein Barr virus (EBV) infection.
name: Severe Epstein Barr virus infection

desc: An unusually severe adenovirus infection.
name: Severe adenovirus infection

desc: An unusually severe infection by a parainfluenza virus.
name: Severe parainfluenza infection

desc: An unusually severe form of varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection. In the majority of the cases, especially in children, varicella is a very mild infection characterised by skin lesions, low grade fever and malaise. Severe infection is characterized by manifestions including VZV pneumonia, hepatitis, meningitis, and disseminated varicella.
name: Severe varicella zoster infection

desc: Immunological states where the immune system produces harmful responses upon reexposure to sensitising antigens.
name: Immunologic hypersensitivity

desc: Celiac disease (CD) is an autoimmune condition affecting the small intestine, triggered by the ingestion of gluten, the protein fraction of wheat, barley, and rye. Clinical manifestations of CD are highly variable and include both gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal features. The hallmark of CD is an immune-mediated enteropathy. This term is included because the occurence of CD is seen as a feature of a number of other diseases.
name: Celiac disease

desc: An allergy is an immune response or reaction to substances that are usually not harmful.
name: Allergy

desc: Allergy to iodine contrast media used in radiological studies.
name: Iodine contrast allergy

desc: An allergy experienced at a particular time of year when trees or grasses pollinate and elicit an allergic reaction.
name: Seasonal allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against alpha-gal.
name: Alpha-gal allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against animal proteins.
name: Animal protein allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against animal dander.
name: Animal dander allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against bacteria.
name: Bacteria allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against drugs.
name: Drug allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against dust mites.
name: Dust mite allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against house dust mites.
name: House dust mite allergy
synonyms: Immunoglobulin E-mediated house dust mite allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against feathers.
name: Feather allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against fungus.
name: Fungi allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against insects.
name: Insect allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against insect venom.
name: Venom allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against insect bites.
name: Insect bite allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against parasites.
name: Parasite allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against plant products.
name: Plant product allergy

desc: Primary food allergies primarily occur as a result (most likely) of gastrointestinal sensitization to predominantly stable food allergens (glycoproteins). A secondary food allergy develops after primary sensitization to airborne allergens (e. g., pollen allergens) with subsequent reactions (due to cross-reactivity) to structurally related often labile allergens in (plant) foods.
name: Food allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against dairy.
name: Dairy allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against cow milk protein.
name: Cow milk allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against eggs.
name: Egg allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against gluten.
name: Gluten allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against allergens contained in meat products.
name: Meat allergen allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against plant based food allergens.
name: Plant based food allergy
synonyms: Allergy to plant based food allergens
Immunoglobulin E-mediated plant based food allergen allergy
IgE-mediated plant based food allergen allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against nut food products.
name: Nut food product allergy
synonyms: Immunoglobulin E-mediated nut food product allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity in form of an adverse immune reaction against seafood.
name: Seafood allergy

desc: Latex allergy is an IgE-mediated immediate hypersensitivity response to natural rubber latex (NRL) protein with a variety of clinical signs ranging from contact urticaria, angioedema, asthma, and anaphylaxis.
name: Latex allergy

desc: Hypersensitivity that is observed within 1 hr of exposures. A variety of adverse reactions can occur within minutes to hours of exposure to a drug. Some can be related to the pharmacological action of the drug (WHO Adverse Reaction Terminology type A for augmented) and usually have a low mortality. Others are not readily predictable based on the structure and pharmacological action of the drug and have a relatively high mortality risk (Type B for bizarre). The most serious form of immediate onset drug hypersensitivity reaction, anaphylaxis. Other reactions including itching,dizziness/light-headedness, nausea, chest discomfort but without any objective skin features, physical signs or physiological compromise. Skin only reactions include generalized erythema, urticaria or angioedema without any sentinel features (see below) of other organ involvement.
name: Immediate-type hypersensitivity drug reaction

desc: An abnormally increased sensitivity to airborn particles. This can be diagnosed on the basis of the medical history, taking into account seasonality or a relationship to the concentration of airborn particles in the environment of the affected individual. Aerosol challenge is a gold standard of establishment of the symptom. There exist particle hypersensitivity (diesel exhaust, metals, inorganic material) vs. allergen (including pollen dander, etc) hypersensitivity. The responses are usually different and testing for allergen hypersensitivity is done in concert with serum IgE and or skin testing to the suspected allergen.
name: Airborn particle hypersensitivity

desc: An acute hypersensitivity reaction due to exposure to a previously encountered antigen.
name: Anaphylactic shock

desc: Anaphylaxis after physical activity.
name: Exercise induced anaphylaxis

desc: A rare form of anaphylaxis for which triggers cannot be identified despite a detailed history and careful diagnostic assessment.
name: Idiopathic anaphylaxis

desc: A form of anaphylaxis that is triggered by intake of drugs or medications.
name: Drug-induced anaphylaxis

desc: Food-induced anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially fatal, systemic allergic reaction that occurs suddenly after contact with an allergy-causing food.
name: Food-induced anaphylaxis

desc: A form of anaphylaxis that is triggered by exposure to venom.
name: Venom-induced anaphylaxis

desc: Systemic inflammatory response to infection.
name: Sepsis

desc: Systemic inflammatory response to infection in newborn babies.
name: Neonatal sepsis

desc: An abnormality of the morphology or counts of the cells that make up the immune system.
name: Abnormal cellular immune system morphology

desc: A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
name: Rectal abscess

desc: A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the parenchyma of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic abscess

desc: An abscess not caused by infection with pyogenic bacteria. Operationally, a sterile abscess is inferred if investigations of an abscess fail to reveal evidence of pathogenic organisms.
name: Sterile abscess

desc: The presence of an abscess of the liver.
name: Liver abscess

desc: The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum.
name: Peritoneal abscess

desc: A compact, organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes, which may be but is not necessarily accompanied by accessory features such as necrosis.
name: Granuloma

desc: A type of granuloma characterized morphologically by the predominance of Langerhans cells with characteristic grooved, folded, indented nuclei in the appropriate milieu that includes variable numbers of eosinophils and histiocytes including multinucleated forms, often appearing similar to osteoclasts or touton like giant cells, neutrophils and small lymphocytes. The concentration of the eosinophilic infiltrate varies from scattered mature cells to sheet-like masses of cells. Occasionally, areas of bone necrosis may interrupt the cellular infiltrate. The foamy cells may also be amassed in clumps, which are of no clinical significance because these clumps represent phagocytosis of lipid debris.
name: Eosinophilic granuloma

desc: Abnormality originating in one or more muscles, i.e., of the set of muscles of body.
name: Abnormality of the musculature

desc: A functional abnormality of a skeletal muscle.
name: Abnormal muscle physiology

desc: A condition characterized by intermittent involuntary contraction of muscles (spasms) related to hypocalcemia or occasionally magnesium deficiency.
name: Tetany

desc: Reduced strength of muscles.
name: Muscle weakness

desc: Decreased strength of the neck musculature.
name: Neck muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the muscles involved in neck flexion (sternocleidomastoid, longus capitus, longus colli, and scalenus anterior).
name: Neck flexor weakness

desc: Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting.
name: Poor head control

desc: Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.
name: Distal muscle weakness
synonyms: Muscle weakness, distal limbs, due to neuronopathy
Distal limb muscle weakness due to peripheral neuropathy

desc: Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the arms.
name: Distal upper limb muscle weakness

desc: Reduced strength of the distal musculature of the legs.
name: Distal lower limb muscle weakness
synonyms: Distal muscle weakness in lower limbs

desc: Muscle weakness affecting the tibialis anterior muscle.
name: Tibialis muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the peroneal muscles.
name: Peroneal muscle weakness

desc: Progressively reduced strength of the distal musculature.
name: Progressive distal muscle weakness

desc: Lack of strength of the proximal muscles that becomes progressively more severe.
name: Progressive proximal muscle weakness

desc: Generalized weakness or decreased strength of the muscles, affecting both distal and proximal musculature.
name: Generalized muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the limb-girdle muscles (also known as the pelvic and shoulder girdles), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders and the pelvis.
name: Limb-girdle muscle weakness

desc: The shoulder, or pectoral, girdle is composed of the clavicles and the scapulae. Shoulder-girdle weakness refers to lack of strength of the muscles attaching to these bones, that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the shoulders.
name: Shoulder girdle muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the muscles of the pelvic girdle (also known as the hip girdle), that is, lack of strength of the muscles around the pelvis.
name: Pelvic girdle muscle weakness

desc: Reduced ability to flex the femur, that is, to pull the knee upward.
name: Hip flexor weakness

desc: Reduced strength of the axial musculature (i.e., of the muscles of the head and neck, spine, and ribs).
name: Axial muscle weakness

desc: Reduced strength and weakness of the muscles of the arms and legs.
name: Limb muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the muscles of the arms.
name: Upper limb muscle weakness

desc: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the arms.
layperson: Proximal muscle weakness in upper limbs
name: Proximal muscle weakness in upper limbs

desc: A lack of strength in the triceps muscle, which normally is responsible for extending (straightening) the elbow and mediating certain shoulder movements.
name: Triceps weakness

desc: A condition in which the affected individual cannot extend the wrist, which hangs flaccidly.
name: Wrist drop

desc: Weakness of the muscles of the legs.
name: Lower limb muscle weakness

desc: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles of the legs.
layperson: Proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs
name: Proximal muscle weakness in lower limbs

desc: Weakness of the quadriceps muscle (that is, of the muscle fasciculus of quadriceps femoris).
name: Quadriceps muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot, that is, of the movement of the toes towards the shin. The foot dorsiflexors include the tibialis anterior, the extensor hallucis longus, the extensor digitorum longus, and the peroneus tertius muscles.
name: Foot dorsiflexor weakness

desc: A lack of strength of the proximal muscles.
layperson: Weakness in muscles of upper arms and upper legs
name: Proximal muscle weakness
synonyms: Weakness in muscles of upper arms and upper legs

desc: A phenomenon whereby patients are not able to stand up without the use of the hands owing to weakness of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs.
name: Gowers sign

desc: Lack of strength of the proximal musculature occurring late in the clinical course.
name: Late-onset proximal muscle weakness

desc: Decreased strength of the abdominal musculature.
name: Abdominal wall muscle weakness

desc: Weakness of the inferior portion of the rectus abdominal muscle, which is ascertained clinically as follows. When a patient sits up or raises the head from a recumbent position, the umbilicus is displaced toward the head. This is the result of paralysis of the inferior portion of the rectus abdominal muscle, so that the upper fibres predominate pulling upwards the umbilicus.
name: Beevor's sign

desc: A decrease in the strength of the diaphragm.
name: Diaphragmatic weakness

desc: A type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching, which results from loss of all or practically all peripheral motor nerves that innervated the muscle. Muscle tone is reduced and the affected muscles undergo extreme atrophy within months of the loss of innervation.
name: Muscle flaccidity

desc: Recurrent episodes of muscle flaccidity, a type of paralysis in which a muscle becomes soft and yields to passive stretching.
name: Episodic flaccid weakness

desc: Increased muscle weakness upon exposure to cold temperatures.
name: Cold paresis

desc: Reduced strength of the muscles that lift or otherwise move the foot at the ankle.
name: Ankle weakness

desc: An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation.
name: Myotonia
synonyms: Delayed relaxation of muscle fibers after contraction

desc: Spontaneous, repetitive electrical activity demonstrated by electromyography (EMG).
name: EMG: myotonic runs

desc: Myotonia that occurs after a period of rest and decreases with continuing exercise.
name: Myotonia with warm-up phenomenon

desc: A localized myotonic contraction in a muscle in reaction to percussion (tapping with the examiner's finger, a rubber percussion hammer, or a similar object).
name: Percussion myotonia
synonyms: Transient swelling of muscle induced by percussion

desc: Mechanical percussion (i.e., striking a muscle with a reflex hammer) leads to spreading waves of muscle contractions that begin proximally and spread laterally across the muscle.
name: Percussion-induced rapid rolling muscle contractions

desc: A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.
name: Paradoxical myotonia

desc: Difficulty releasing one's grip associated with prolonged first handgrip relaxation times.
name: Handgrip myotonia

desc: Slowed relaxation of muscles in the face.
name: Myotonia of the face

desc: Slowed relaxation of muscles in the jaw.
name: Myotonia of the jaw

desc: Slowed relaxation of muscles in the leg.
name: Myotonia of the lower limb

desc: Slowed relaxation of muscles in the arm.
name: Myotonia of the upper limb

desc: An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation that is induced by exposure to cold.
name: Cold-sensitive myotonia

desc: Decreased strength of the muscle layer of stomach, which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction.
name: Gastroparesis

desc: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles.
name: Muscle spasm

desc: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles brought on by exposure to cold temperatures.
name: Cold-induced muscle cramps

desc: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles brought on by physical exertion.
name: Exercise-induced muscle cramps

desc: Sudden and involuntary contractions of one or more muscles of the leg brought on by physical exertion.
name: Exercise-induced leg cramps

desc: History of repeated intermittent involuntary muscle contractions that were painful.
name: Intermittent painful muscle spasms

desc: A sudden involuntary contraction of the musculature surrounding the mouth.
name: Perioral spasm

desc: Abnormal results of investigations using electromyography (EMG).
name: EMG abnormality

desc: The presence of characteristic findings of denervation on electromyography (fibrillations, positive sharp waves, and giant motor unit potentials).
name: EMG: neuropathic changes

desc: Evidence of chronic denervation on electromyography.
name: EMG: chronic denervation signs

desc: The presence of abnormal electromyographic patterns indicative of myopathy, such as small-short polyphasic motor unit potentials.
name: EMG: myopathic abnormalities

desc: Electromyographic (EMG) findings characteristic of axonal neuropathy, with normal or slightly decreased nerve conduction velocities, normal or slightly prolonged distal latencies, but significantly reduced motor potentials and sensory amplitudes. There may be spontaneous activity upon needle EMG studies, such as increased insertional activity, positive sharp waves, and fibrillation potentials.
name: EMG: axonal abnormality

desc: These are spontaneous firing action potentials stimulated by needle movement of an injured muscle fiber. There is propagation to, but not past, the needle tip. This inhibits the display of the negative deflection of the waveform.
name: EMG: positive sharp waves

desc: Abnormality observed upon electromyography when nerve studied is electrically stimulated six to ten times at 2 or 3 Hertz.
name: EMG: repetitive nerve stimulation abnormality

desc: Abnormality in single fiber EMG recording, a technique that allows identification of action potentials (APs) from individual muscle fibers.
name: Single fiber EMG abnormality

desc: The variation in the time interval between the two action potentials of the same motor unit is called jitter. This term therefore applies to increased variability in the interval between successive action potentials of the same motor unit, which is measured by electromyography (EMG).
layperson: Increased jitter at single fiber EMG
name: Increased jitter at single fiber EMG
synonyms: Increased jitter at single fibre EMG
Increased jitter at single fibre electromyography

desc: Continuous electromyographic activity of motor units at rest, i.e., without voluntary movement of the muscles.
layperson: EMG: continuous motor unit activity at rest
name: EMG: continuous motor unit activity at rest

desc: High frequency discharges in electromyography (EMG) that vary in amplitude and frequency, waxing and waning continuously with firing frequencies ranging from 150/second down to 20/second and producing a sound that has been referred to as a dive bomber sound.
name: EMG: myotonic discharges

desc: An electromyographic finding associated with erratic or absent neuromuscular transmission with erratic, moment-to-moment changes in the shape of the motor unit potential (MUP).
name: EMG: impaired neuromuscular transmission

desc: A compound muscle action potential (CMAP) is a type of electromyography (EMG). CMAP refers to a group of almost simultaneous action potentials from several muscle fibers in the same area evoked by stimulation of the supplying motor nerve and are recorded as one multipeaked summated action potential. This abnormality refers to a greater than normal decrease in the amplitude during the course of the investigation.
layperson: EMG: decremental response of compound muscle action potential to repetitive nerve stimulation
name: EMG: decremental response of compound muscle action potential to repetitive nerve stimulation
synonyms: EMG: decremental response of CMAP to repetitive nerve stimulation

desc: A compound muscle action potential (CMAP) is a type of electromyography (EMG). CMAP refers to a group of almost simultaneous action potentials from several muscle fibers in the same area evoked by stimulation of the supplying motor nerve and are recorded as one multipeaked summated action potential. This abnormality refers to an abnormal increase in the amplitude during the course of the investigation.
layperson: EMG: incremental response of compound muscle action potential to repetitive nerve stimulation
name: EMG: incremental response of compound muscle action potential to repetitive nerve stimulation

desc: The presence of reduced conduction velocity of motor nerves on electromyography.
name: EMG: slow motor conduction

desc: A condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm.
name: Muscle stiffness

desc: Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature.
name: Axial muscle stiffness

desc: Stiffness of the limbs (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) occurring in an asymmetric pattern.
name: Asymmetric limb muscle stiffness

desc: A type of muscle stiffness that occurs following physical exertion.
name: Exercise-induced muscle stiffness

desc: An abnormal, increased fatiguability of the musculature.
name: Increased muscle fatiguability

desc: An abnormally increased tendency towards muscle fatigue induced by physical exercise.
name: Exercise-induced muscle fatigue

layperson: Muscle abnormality related to mitochondrial dysfunction
name: Muscle abnormality related to mitochondrial dysfunction

desc: An abnormally increased number of mitochondria in the cytoplasma adjacent to the sarcolemma (muscle cell membrane), whereby the mitochondria also possess an abnormal morphology.
layperson: Subsarcolemmal accumulations of abnormally shaped mitochondria
name: Subsarcolemmal accumulations of abnormally shaped mitochondria

desc: An abnormally reduced activity of the enzyme cytochrome C oxidase in muscle tissue.
name: Cytochrome C oxidase-negative muscle fibers
synonyms: Decreased skeletal muscle cytochrome c oxidase activity
Decreased activity of cytochrome C oxidase in muscle tissue
Cytochrome c oxidase deficiency in skeletal muscle

desc: A type of myopathy associated with mitochondrial disease and characterized by findings on biopsy such as ragged red muscle fibers.
name: Mitochondrial myopathy

layperson: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in muscle tissue
name: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in muscle tissue
synonyms: Depletion of mitochondrial dna in skeletal muscle tissue

desc: The presence of multiple deletions of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA).
name: Multiple mitochondrial DNA deletions

desc: Muscular hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle), often involving reduced muscle strength. Hypotonia is characterized by a diminished resistance to passive stretching.
name: Muscular hypotonia

desc: Generalized muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone).
name: Generalized hypotonia

desc: The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia.
name: Episodic generalized hypotonia

desc: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.
layperson: Low muscle tone, in neonatal onset
name: Neonatal hypotonia
synonyms: Low muscle tone, in neonatal onset
