desc: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period and affecting the entire musculature.
layperson: Generalized low muscle tone in neonate
name: Generalized neonatal hypotonia
synonyms: Generalized low muscle tone in neonate

desc: A severe degree of muscular hypotonia characterized by markedly reduced muscle tone.
name: Severe muscular hypotonia

desc: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk.
name: Muscular hypotonia of the trunk

desc: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) affecting the musculature of the trunk and with onset in infancy.
name: Infantile axial hypotonia

desc: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in infancy.
name: Infantile muscular hypotonia

desc: Muscular hypotonia of one or more limbs.
name: Appendicular hypotonia

desc: Reduced muscle tone of oral musculature. In infants, this feature may be associated with difficulties in breast feeding, and may affect the latch, jaw motions, tongue placement, lip seal, suck/swallow/breathe pattern and overall feeding behavior.
name: Oral motor hypotonia

desc: A type of rest posture in an infant that indicated a generalized reduction in muscle tone. The hips are flexed and the legs are abducted to an extent that causes the lateral thigh to rest upon the supporting surface. This posture is said to resemble the legs of a frog.
name: Frog-leg posture

desc: A functional motor deficit where individuals whose responses to the challenges of exercise fail to achieve levels considered normal for their age and gender.
name: Exercise intolerance

desc: Reduced ability to climb stairs.
name: Difficulty climbing stairs

desc: Reduced ability to run.
name: Difficulty running

desc: A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle.
name: Abnormal skeletal muscle morphology

desc: Any abnormality of the diaphragm, the sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the thoracic cavity from the abdominal cavity.
name: Abnormality of the diaphragm

desc: The presence of a hernia of the diaphragm present at birth.
name: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

desc: Congenital absence of the left half of the diaphragm.
name: Aplasia of the left hemidiaphragm

desc: A posterolateral defect in the diaphragm, commonly referred to as a Bochdalek hernia, which is often accompanied by herniation of the stomach, intestines, liver, and/or spleen into the chest cavity.
name: Posterolateral diaphragmatic hernia

desc: An anterior retrosternal or parasternal hernia that can result in the herniation of liver or intestines into the chest cavity.
name: Morgagni diaphragmatic hernia

desc: A congenital diaphragm defect involving the central tendinous (e.g., amuscular) portion of the diaphragm, whereby the entire rim of diaphragmatic musculature is present.
name: Central diaphragmatic hernia

desc: Congenital absence of the right-sided diaphragm.
name: Aplasia of the right hemidiaphragm

desc: Interruption of the innervation of the diaphragm.
name: Denervation of the diaphragm

desc: A congenital failure of muscular development of part or all of one or both hemidiaphragms, resulting in superior displacement of abdominal viscera and altered lung development.
name: Diaphragmatic eventration

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the diaphragm.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the diaphragm

desc: Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm.
name: Agenesis of the diaphragm

layperson: Abnormal morphology of the pelvis musculature
name: Abnormal morphology of the pelvis musculature
synonyms: Abnormality of the musculature of the pelvis

desc: Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles that attach to the pelvic girdle (the gluteal muscles, the lateral rotators, adductor magnus, adductor brevis, adductor longus, pectineus, and gracilis muscles).
name: Pelvic girdle muscle atrophy

desc: Muscular atrophy affecting the muscles of the pelvis.
layperson: Amyotrophy of the musculature of the pelvis
name: Amyotrophy of the musculature of the pelvis
Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the musculature of the pelvis

desc: Absence of the musculature of the pelvis.
layperson: Aplasia of the musculature of the pelvis
name: Aplasia of the musculature of the pelvis

desc: Underdevelopment of the musculature of the pelvis.
layperson: Hypoplasia of the musculature of the pelvis
name: Hypoplasia of the musculature of the pelvis

desc: A disorder of muscle unrelated to impairment of innervation or neuromuscular junction.
name: Myopathy

desc: Myofibrillar structural changes characterized by abnormal intracellular accumulation of the intermediate filament desmin and other proteins.
name: Myofibrillar myopathy

desc: Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in muscle fibers.
name: Minicore myopathy

desc: Multiple small zones of sarcomeric disorganization and lack of oxidative activity (known as minicores) in type 1 and type 2 muscle fibers.
layperson: Type 1 and type 2 muscle fiber minicore regions
name: Type 1 and type 2 muscle fiber minicore regions
synonyms: Type 1 and type 2 muscle fibre minicore regions

desc: Chronic muscle inflammation accompanied by muscle weakness.
name: Inflammatory myopathy

desc: Breakdown of muscle fibers that leads to the release of muscle fiber contents (myoglobin) into the bloodstream.
name: Rhabdomyolysis

desc: Rhabdomyolysis induced by a viral infection.
name: Viral infection-induced rhabdomyolysis

desc: An acute form of rhabdomyolysis.
name: Acute rhabdomyolysis

desc: Rhabdomyolysis induced by exercise.
name: Exercise-induced rhabdomyolysis

desc: Rhabdomyolysis induced by anesthesia.
name: Anesthetic-induced rhabdomylosis

desc: Rhabdomyolysis induced by intake of alcohol.
name: Alcohol-induced rhabdomyolysis

desc: The term dystrophy means abnormal growth. However, muscular dystrophy is used to describe primary myopathies with a genetic basis and a progressive course characterized by progressive skeletal muscle weakness and wasting, defects in muscle proteins, and histological features of muscle fiber degeneration (necrosis) and regeneration. If possible, it is preferred to use other HPO terms to describe the precise phenotypic abnormalities.
name: Muscular dystrophy

desc: Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders).
name: Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy

desc: Formation of calcium deposits in any soft tissue.
layperson: Calcium buildup in soft tissues of body
name: Calcinosis
synonyms: Calcium buildup in soft tissues of body

desc: Any abnormality of the skeletal muscle cell. Muscle fibers are subdivided into two types. Type I fibers are fatigue-resistant and rich in oxidative enzymes (they stain light with the myosin ATPase reaction), and type II fibers are fast-contracting, fatigue-prone, and rich in glycolytic enzymes (these fibers stain darkly). Normal muscle tissue has a random distribution of type I and type II fibers.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber morphology

desc: An abnormal appearance of muscle fibers observed on muscle biopsy. Ragged red fibers can be visualized with Gomori trichrome staining as irregular and intensely red subsarcolemmal zones, whereas the normal myofibrils are green. The margins of affect fibers appear red and ragged. The ragged-red is due to the accumulation of abnormal mitochondria below the plasma membrane of the muscle fiber, leading to the appearance of a red rim and speckled sarcoplasm.
name: Ragged-red muscle fibers

desc: Fiber splitting or branching is a common finding in human and rat skeletal muscle pathology. Fiber splitting refers to longitudinal halving of the complete fiber, while branching originates from a regenerating end of a necrotic fiber as invaginations of the sarcolemma. In fiber branching, one end of the fiber remains intact as a single entity, while the other end has several branches.
name: Muscle fiber splitting

desc: An abnormality in which the nuclei of sarcomeres take on an abnormally central localization (or in which this feature is found in an increased proportion of muscle cells).
name: Centrally nucleated skeletal muscle fibers

desc: Abnormal cell death involving muscle fibers usually associated with break in, or absence of, muscle surface fiber membrane and resulting in irreversible damage to muscle fibers.
name: Muscle fiber necrosis

desc: The lysosomal-vacuolar pathway has a role in the controlled intracellular digestion of macromolecules such as protein complexes and organelles. This feature refers to the presence of an abnormally increased number of autophagic vacuoles in muscle tissue.
name: Autophagic vacuoles

desc: An abnormal predominance of type I muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).
name: Type 1 muscle fiber predominance

desc: Presence of abnormal vacuoles (membrane-bound organelles) in the sarcolemma. On histological staining with hematoxylin and eosin, rimmed vacuoles are popcorn-like clear vacuoles with a densely blue rim. The vacuoles are often associated with cytoplasmic and occasionally intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions.
name: Rimmed vacuoles

desc: An abnormal accumulation of lipids in skeletal muscle.
name: Increased muscle lipid content

desc: An abnormal increase in intracellular lipid droplets In a muscle. The number and size of these drops can increase with somd disorders of lipid metabolism affecting muscle. See PMID 20691590 for histological images.
name: Increased intramyocellular lipid droplets

desc: An abnormal predominance of type II muscle fibers (in general, this feature can only be observed on muscle biopsy).
name: Type 2 muscle fiber predominance

desc: Any abnormality of the size of the skeletal muscle cell.
layperson: Abnormality of skeletal muscle fiber size
name: Abnormality of skeletal muscle fiber size
synonyms: Abnormality of skeletal muscle fibre size

desc: An abnormally high degree of muscle fiber size variation. This phenotypic feature can be observed upon muscle biopsy.
layperson: Increased variability in muscle fiber diameter
name: Increased variability in muscle fiber diameter
synonyms: Increased variability in muscle fibre diameter
Increased variability in muscle fiber size
Increased variation in muscle fiber size

desc: The presence of abnormal muscle fiber size such that type 1 fibers are smaller than type 2 fibers.
layperson: Type 1 fibers relatively smaller than type 2 fibers
name: Type 1 fibers relatively smaller than type 2 fibers
synonyms: Type 1 fibres relatively smaller than type 2 fibres

desc: Any anomaly in the amount of glycogen in muscle tissue.
name: Abnormal muscle glycogen content

desc: An increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue.
name: Increased muscle glycogen content

desc: An increased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue found specifically in lysosomes.
layperson: Glycogen accumulation in muscle fiber lysosomes
name: Glycogen accumulation in muscle fiber lysosomes
synonyms: Glycogen accumulation in muscle fibre lysosomes

desc: Elevated glycogen content in the sarcoplasm (cytoplasm) of muscle fibers.
name: Increased sarcoplasmic glycogen

desc: A decreased amount of glycogen in muscle tissue.
name: Decreased muscle glycogen content

desc: Any structural anomaly of the sarcomere, which is unit of a myofibril in a muscle cell, composed of an array of overlapping thick and thin filaments between two adjacent Z discs.
name: Abnormal sarcomere morphology

desc: Any structural anomaly of the Z disc, which is the platelike region of a muscle sarcomere to which the plus ends of actin filaments are attached.
name: Abnormal Z disc morphology

desc: Streaming or smearing of the Z band, which is then no longer confined to a narrow zone which bisects the I band. The Z disc may extend across the I band or the entire sarcomere in a zigzag manner. Focal thickening, smudging, and blurring of the Z band takes place concurrently. Myofibrillar disorganization is a frequent but not invariable accompanying change.
name: Z-band streaming

desc: Abnormally increased width of the Z-disk of the sarcomere, resulting from splitting or opening of the Z-disc (c.f., Figure 2 of PMID:28732005).
name: Increased Z-disc width

desc: An abnormality in which the nuclei of sarcomeres take on an abnormally internal localization (or in which this feature is found in an increased proportion of muscle cells).
name: Internally nucleated skeletal muscle fibers

desc: An anomalous amount of protein present in or on the surface of muscle fibers. This feature may be appreciate upon immunohistochemical investigation of muscle biopsy tissue.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber protein expression

desc: An anomalous amount of merosin in muscle fibers. Merosin is a basement membrane-associated protein found in placenta, striated muscle, and peripheral nerve.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber merosin expression

desc: Lack of merosin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber merosin
synonyms: Absent merosin staining in muscle biopsy

desc: A reduced amount of merosin in muscle fibers. This feature is usually assessed by immunohistochemical examination of muscle biopsy tissue.
name: Reduced muscle fiber merosin

desc: A deviation from normal of the amount of laminin beta 1 in muscle fiber tissue. Laminin 2 is a major component of the basal lamina of skeletal muscle cells. It is a heterotrimer composed of 3 chains: merosin (laminin alpha 2 chain), beta 1, and gamma 1.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber laminin beta 1

desc: A reduced amount of laminin beta 1 in muscle fiber tissue. Laminin 2 is a major component of the basal lamina of skeletal muscle cells. It is a heterotrimer composed of 3 chains: merosin (laminin alpha 2 chain), beta 1, and gamma 1.
name: Reduced muscle fiber laminin beta 1

desc: A decreased amount of collagen VI in muscle tissue. Collagen VI is a primarily associated with the extracellular matrix of skeletal muscle.
name: Reduced muscle collagen VI

desc: A deviation from normal in the amount of dystrophin in muscle fiber tissue. Dystrophin is located at the muscle sarcolemma in a membrane-spanning protein complex that connects the cytoskeleton to the basal lamina.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber dystrophin expression

desc: Lack of dystrophin in muscle tissue. Immunohistochemistry reveals absent dystrophin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle dystrophin expression

desc: A decreased amount of dystrophin in muscle fiber tissue.
name: Reduced muscle dystrophin expression

desc: Deviation from normal in the amount of alpha sarcoglycan in muscle. The alpha, beta, gamma, and delta sarcoglycans are components of the dystrophin-complex. They are all N-glycosylated transmembrane proteins with a short intra-cellular domain, a single transmembrane region and a large extra-cellular domain containing a cluster of conserved cysteines.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber alpha sarcoglycan

desc: Lack of alpha sarcoglycan in muscle. Immunohistochemistry reveals absent alpha sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber alpha sarcoglycan

desc: A decreased amount of alpha sarcoglycan in muscle. Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced alpha sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Reduced muscle fiber alpha sarcoglycan

desc: Deviation from normal in the amount of beta sarcoglycan in muscle. The alpha, beta, gamma, and delta sarcoglycans are components of the dystrophin-complex. They are all N-glycosylated transmembrane proteins with a short intra-cellular domain, a single transmembrane region and a large extra-cellular domain containing a cluster of conserved cysteines.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber beta sarcoglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows complete lack of beta sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber beta sarcoglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced beta sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Reduced muscle fiber beta sarcoglycan

desc: Deviation from normal in the amount of gamma sarcoglycan in muscle. The alpha, beta, gamma, and delta sarcoglycans are components of the dystrophin-complex. They are all N-glycosylated transmembrane proteins with a short intra-cellular domain, a single transmembrane region and a large extra-cellular domain containing a cluster of conserved cysteines.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber gamma sarcoglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced gamma sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Reduced muscle fiber gamma sarcoglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows complete lack of gamma sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber gamma sarcoglycan

desc: Deviation from normal in the amount of delta sarcoglycan in muscle. The alpha, beta, gamma, and delta sarcoglycans are components of the dystrophin-complex. They are all N-glycosylated transmembrane proteins with a short intra-cellular domain, a single transmembrane region and a large extra-cellular domain containing a cluster of conserved cysteines.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber delta sarcoglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows complete lack of delta sarcoglycan protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber delta sarcoglycan

desc: Abnormally reduced amount of delta sarcoglycan in muscle.
name: Reduced muscle fiber delta sarcoglycan

desc: A deviation from normal of muscle alpha-dystroglcan expression. Alpha-dystroglycan is a heavily glycosylated peripheral-membrane component of the dystrophin-associated glycoprotein complex (DAPC), which, in addition to laminin alpha2, binds perlecan and agrin in the extracellular matrix, whereas beta-dystroglycan, derived from the same gene, is a transmembrane protein that links to dystrophin intracellularly.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber alpha dystroglycan

desc: A reduction in the degree of glycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan in muscle tissue.
name: Hypoglycosylation of alpha-dystroglycan

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced alpha dystroglycan protein in the muscle biopsy. Alpha-dystroglycan is a heavily glycosylated peripheral-membrane component of the dystrophin-associated glycoprotein complex (DAPC), which, in addition to laminin alpha2, binds perlecan and agrin in the extracellular matrix, whereas beta-dystroglycan, derived from the same gene, is a transmembrane protein that links to dystrophin intracellularly.
name: Reduced muscle fiber alpha dystroglycan

desc: A deviation from normal in the expression of dysferlin in muscle tissue. Dysferlin is an ubiquitous 230-KDa transmembrane protein involved in calcium-mediated sarcolemma resealing.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber dysferlin

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows complete lack of dysferlin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber dysferlin

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced dysferlin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Reduced muscle fiber dysferlin

desc: A deviation from normal of the amount of the inner nuclear membrane protein emerin in muscle tissue.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber emerin

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows complete lack of emerin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Absent muscle fiber emerin

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced emerin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Reduced muscle fiber emerin

desc: A deviation from normal in the amount of calpain-3 in muscle tissue. Calpains are intracellular nonlysosomal cysteine proteases modulated by calcium ions. A typical calpain is a heterodimer composed of two distinct subunits, one large (over 80 kDa) and the other small (30 kDa). While only one gene encoding the small subunit has been demonstrated, there are many genes for the large one. CAPN3 is similar to ubiquitous Calpain 1 and 2 (m-calpain and micro-calpain), but contains specific insertion sequences (NS, IS1 and IS2). Calpains cleave target proteins to modify their properties, rather than breaking down the substrates.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber calpain-3

desc: Western blot shows complete lack of calpain-3 protein in the muscle biopsy tissue.
name: Absent muscle fiber calpain-3

desc: Western blot reveals reduced calpain-3 protein in the muscle biopsy tissue.
name: Reduced muscle fiber calpain-3

desc: Immunohistochemistry reveals reduced perlecan protein in the muscle biopsy. Perlecan is a basement membrane-specific heparan sulfate proteoglycan core protein (HSPG) also known as heparan sulfate proteoglycan 2 (HSPG2).
name: Reduced muscle fiber perlecan

desc: A deviation from the normal amount of lamin A/C in muscle tissue. The LMNA gene gives rise to at least three splicing isoforms including the two main isoforms, lamin A and lamin C. These are constitutive components of the fibrous nuclear lamina and have different roles, ranging from mechanical nuclear membrane maintenance to gene regulation.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber lamin A/C

desc: A decreased amount of lamin A/C in muscle tissue. This feature can be shown by immunohistochemistry of Western blotting of muscle tissue.
name: Reduced muscle fiber lamin A/C

desc: A deviation from normal in the expression of desmin in muscle tissue. Desmin is an 53-KDa protein.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber desmin

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows accumulation of desmin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Accumulation of muscle fiber desmin

desc: A deviation from normal in the expression of myotilin in muscle tissue. Myotilin is a 57kD cytoskeletal protein.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber myotilin

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows accumulation of myotilin protein in the muscle biopsy.
name: Accumulation of muscle fiber myotilin

desc: A deviation from normal in the expression of valosin-containing protein in muscle tissue. Valosin-containing protein is an ubiquitously expressed multifunctional 100-kD protein that is a member of the AAA+ (ATPase associated with various activities) protein family.
name: Abnormal muscle fiber valosin-containing protein

desc: Immunohistochemistry shows accumulation of valosin-containing protein in the muscle biopsy.
layperson: Accumulation of muscle fiber valosin-containing protein
name: Accumulation of muscle fiber valosin-containing protein
synonyms: Accumulation of muscle fibre valosin-containing protein

desc: The presence of disorganized areas called cores in the center of muscle fibers. There is a typical appearance of the biopsy on light microscopy, where the muscle cells have cores that are devoid of mitochondria and specific enzymes. Cores are typically well demarcated and centrally located, but may occasionally be multiple and of eccentric.
layperson: Central core regions in muscle fibers
name: Central core regions in muscle fibers
synonyms: Central core regions in muscle fibres

desc: A histological alteration of muscle fibers that resembles a necklace (necklace fibers). A substantial proportion of fibers (4-20% in PMID:19084976) show internalized nuclei aligned in a basophilic ring (necklace) at 3 micrometers beneath the sarcolemma. Ultrastructurally, such necklaces consist of myofibrils of smaller diameter, in oblique orientation, surrounded by mitochondria, sarcoplasmic reticulum and glycogen granules.
name: Necklace skeletal muscle fibers

desc: Muscle fibers contain one or more vacuoles (membrane-bound cavity) associated with collections of membranes arranged in a whorl-like (spiral or circular) manner.
name: Myelin-like whorls in vacuolated fibers

desc: Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 2 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
name: Type 2 muscle fiber atrophy

desc: Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.
name: Type 1 muscle fiber atrophy
Muscle fiber actin filament accumulation
synonyms: Accumulation in muscle cells of filaments composed of actin.

desc: The presence of inclusion bodies within the cytoplasm of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.
name: Muscle fiber cytoplasmatic inclusion bodies

desc: Nemaline rods are abnormal bodies that can occur in skeletal muscle fibers. The rods can be observed on histological analysis of muscle biopsy tissue or upon electron microscopy, where they appear either as extensions of sarcomeric Z-lines, in random array without obvious attachment to Z-lines (often in areas devoid of sarcomeres) or in large clusters localized at the sarcolemma or intermyofibrillar spaces.
name: Nemaline bodies

desc: Unusual regions of densely packed membranous tubules known as tubular aggregates which present as membranous inclusions, derived from membranes of sarcoplasmic reticulum and mitochondria, containing miscellaneous proteins with a variety of enzymatic activities.
name: Muscle fiber tubular inclusions

desc: The presence of inclusion bodies within the nucleus of muscle cells. Inclusion bodies are aggregates (deposits) or stainable material, usually misfolded proteins.
name: Muscle fiber intranuclear inclusion bodies

desc: Ring fibers are formed by a bundle of peripheral myofibrils which are circumferentially oriented such that they encircle the internal portion of the sarcoplasm which is normal in structure and orientation.
name: Ring fibers

desc: An abnormal increase in the amount of intramuscular fat tissue.
name: Increased intramuscular fat
Abnormality of the musculature of the limbs
synonyms: Muscle issues in the arms and/or legs

layperson: Abnormality of the musculature of the lower limbs
name: Abnormality of the musculature of the lower limbs

desc: Enlargement of the muscles of the calf due to their replacement by connective tissue or fat.
name: Calf muscle pseudohypertrophy

desc: Underdevelopment of the muscuklature of the calf.
name: Calf muscle hypoplasia

desc: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the calf muscles.

desc: Atrophy of the peroneous muscles, peroneus longus (also known as Fibularis longus), Peroneus brevis (also known as fibularis brevis, and Peroneus tertius (also known as fibularis tertius).

desc: An anomaly of the musculature of foot.

desc: Limitation of the ability to bend the toes.

desc: Atrophy of the muscles of the ankle.
name: Amyotrophy of ankle musculature

name: Toe extensor amyotrophy

desc: Muscular atrophy affecting proximally located muscles of the legs, i.e., of the thigh.

desc: Muscular atrophy involving the quadriceps muscle.

Rectus femoris muscle atrophy

desc: Absence or underdevelopment involving the musculature of the thigh.

desc: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the thighs.

desc: The presence of an asymmetrical gluteal crease, the horizontal crease formed by the inferior aspect of the buttocks and the posterior upper leg.

Abnormality of the musculature of the hand

name: Weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles

desc: Atrophy of the intrinsic muscle groups of the hand, comprising the thenar and hypothenar muscles; the interossei muscles; and the lumbrical muscles.

desc: An abnormality of the hypothenar eminence, i.e., of the muscles on the ulnar side of the palm of the hand (i.e., on the side of the little finger).

desc: Reduced muscle mass on the ulnar side of the palm, that is, reduction in size of the hypothenar eminence.

desc: Reduced strength of the musculature of the hand.

layperson: Weakness of long finger extensor muscles
name: Weakness of long finger extensor muscles

desc: Reduced ability to flex (bend) the fingers. This can manifest as incomplete closure of the hand due to weakness in finger flexion.

name: Abnormality of the musculature of the thorax

Small pec muscle on one side

desc: An abnormality of the abdominal musculature.
layperson: Abnormal morphology of the abdominal musculature

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.

desc: Absence of the abdominal musculature.

name: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature

desc: Underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.

name: Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature

name: Fatty replacement of skeletal muscle

desc: Abnormalities of the overall muscle bulk based on clinical observation.

Distal muscle atrophy, upper and lower limbs

desc: Muscular atrophy affecting the lower limb.

desc: Progressive spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
name: Progressive spinal muscular atrophy

desc: Muscular atrophy that does not display a progression in severity with time.

name: Generalized muscle hypertrophy

desc: Muscle hypertrophy affecting the scapular muscles.

desc: Eosinophil infiltration of skeletal muscle.

desc: A structural anomaly of the muscles of the trunk and head.

desc: Any abnormality of the chest muscles.

name: Abnormal morphology of the chest musculature

desc: Any abnormality of the shoulder muscles.

desc: The presence of an abnormally increased amount of connective tissue.

desc: An increase in adipose tissue mass by hyperplastic growth (increase in the number of adipocytes) or by hypertrophic growth (increase in the size of adipocytes occurring primarily by lipid accumulation within the cell).

desc: An abnormal increase in the amount of intraabdominal fat tissue.

The lesions represent visceral sterile collections of mature neutrophils that do not respond to antibiotics but regress quickly when treated with corticosteroids, but relapses occur frequently.

desc: An abnormal enlargement or swelling in the abdomen.
