layperson: Slowed or blocked flow of bile from liver
name: Cholestasis
synonyms: Slowed or blocked flow of bile from liver

desc: Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in the small bile ducts within the liver.
name: Intrahepatic cholestasis
synonyms: Impaired release of bile from liver

desc: Clay colored stools lacking bile pigment.
name: Acholic stools

desc: Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in large bile ducts outside the liver.
name: Extrahepatic cholestasis

desc: An abnormality of the gallbladder.
name: Abnormality of the gallbladder

desc: A structural anomaly of the gallbladder.
name: Abnormal gallbladder morphology

desc: Hard, pebble-like deposits that form within the gallbladder.
name: Cholelithiasis

desc: Gallstones composed primarily of cholesterol, usually about 2-3 cm in length with an oval form and a yellow or green/brown color.
name: Cholesterol gallstones

desc: Gallstones composed primarily of bilirubin and calcium salts (calcium bilirubinate) with a low cholesterol concentration.
name: Pigment gallstones

desc: A type of pigment gallstone that is hard and black, containing calcium carbonate and calcium phosphates.
name: Black pigment gallstones

desc: A type of pigment gallstone that is brown, containing calcium fatty acids. These stones are softer than black pigment gallstones.
name: Brown pigment gallstones

desc: The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.
name: Bilobate gallbladder

desc: Absence or underdevelopment of the gallbladder.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the gallbladder

desc: The presence of a hypoplastic gallbladder.
name: Hypoplasia of the gallbladder

desc: A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form.
name: Absent gallbladder

desc: Failure of formation of the lumen of the gallbladder, often associated with gallbladder hypoplasia.
name: Atretic gallbladder

desc: Rupture of the wall of the gallbladder.
name: Gallbladder perforation

desc: Presence of a pseudoaneurysm in the artery that supplies the gallbladder and cystic duct with blood. A pseudoaneurysm, also known as a false aneurysm, forms when blood leaks through a breach of the arterial wall but is contained by the adventitia or surrounding perivascular soft tissue.
name: Cystic artery pseudoaneurysm

desc: Cellular infiltrate confirmed by a cellular infiltrate comprised of mainly eosinophils in the gallbladder wall on histological examination.
name: Eosinophilic gallbladder infiltration

desc: A functional anomaly of the gallbladder.
name: Abnormal gallbladder physiology

desc: The presence of inflammatory changes in the gallbladder.
name: Cholecystitis

layperson: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate
name: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

desc: Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.
name: Portal fibrosis

desc: Any functional anomaly of the liver.
name: Abnormal liver physiology

desc: Any structural anomaly of the bile-secreting organ that is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage.
name: Abnormal liver morphology

desc: A chronic disorder of the liver in which liver tissue becomes scarred and is partially replaced by regenerative nodules and fibrotic tissue resulting in loss of liver function.
layperson: Scar tissue replaces healthy tissue in the liver
name: Cirrhosis
synonyms: Scar tissue replaces healthy tissue in the liver

desc: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of small regenerative nodules.
name: Micronodular cirrhosis

desc: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules.
name: Macronodular cirrhosis

desc: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of regenerative nodules of a variety of sizes.
name: Mixed cirrhosis

desc: The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the liver. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.
name: Hepatic fibrosis

desc: The presence of fibrosis affecting the interlobular stroma of liver.
name: Periportal fibrosis

desc: The presence of fibrosis of that part of the liver with congenital onset.
layperson: Excessive buildup of connective tissue and scarring of liver at birth
name: Congenital hepatic fibrosis
synonyms: Excessive buildup of connective tissue and scarring of liver at birth

desc: Hepatic fibrosis that reaches from a portal area to another portal area.
name: Hepatic bridging fibrosis

desc: The presence of cell death (necrosis) affecting the liver.
name: Hepatic necrosis

desc: A type of hepatic necrosis that is concentrated around the necrosis of hepatocytes localized around the intrahepatic branch of portal vein.
name: Hepatic periportal necrosis

desc: Elevations of the levels of SGOT and SGPT in the serum. SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) are transaminases primarily found in the liver and heart and are released into the bloodstream as the result of liver or heart damage. SGOT and SGPT are used clinically mainly as markers of liver damage.
name: Elevated hepatic transaminase

desc: Elevations of the levels of SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) and SGPT (serum glutamic pyruvic transaminase) that occur during infections.
name: Elevated serum transaminases during infections

desc: An abnormally high concentration in the circulation of aspartate aminotransferase (AST).
name: Elevated serum aspartate aminotransferase

desc: An abnormally high concentration in the circulation of alanine aminotransferase (ALT), which is an enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of amino groups to form the hepatic metabolite oxaloacetate. ALT is found abundantly in the cytosol of the hepatocyte. ALT activity in the liver is about 3000 times that of serum activity. Thus, in the case of hepatocellular injury or death, release of ALT from damaged liver cells increases measured ALT activity in the serum. Although it is generally thought to be specific to the liver, it is also found in the kidney, and, in much smaller quantities, in heart and skeletal muscle cells.
name: Elevated serum alanine aminotransferase

layperson: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy
name: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy
synonyms: Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy
Abnormal liver function tests during pregnancy, resolves postpartum

desc: The presence of degenerative changes of the liver.
name: Degenerative liver disease

desc: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes.
layperson: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
name: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver

desc: Diffuse benign transformation of the hepatic parenchyma into small regenerative nodules with minimal or no fibrosis.
name: Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver

desc: A structural anomaly of the liver located predominantly in the hepatocytes as opposed to stromal cells.
name: Abnormal liver parenchyma morphology

desc: Cellular infiltration of the liver parenchyma with a preponderance of eosinophils.
name: Eosinophilic liver infiltration

desc: The engulfing of lymphocytes by hepatocytes, which typically occurs in the interface hepatitis area.
name: Periportal emperipolesis

desc: Formation of abnormal lobules (small masses of tissue) in the liver.
name: Abnormal liver lobulation

desc: Ectopic liver is a rare developmental anomaly in which liver tissue is situated outside the liver. Thus, ectopic liver refers to autonomous islands of normal liver parenchyma located outside the liver. The term ectopic liver is also used, to include liver appendices attached to the native liver by a thin stalk although being fully separated from the latter.
name: Ectopic liver

desc: Hepatocytes (liver parenchymal cells) exhibit a bloated appearance because of expansion of the cytoplasm by accumulated material.
name: Storage in hepatocytes

desc: The presence of steatosis in the liver.
name: Hepatic steatosis

desc: A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of large, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.
name: Macrovesicular hepatic steatosis

desc: A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of small, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.
name: Microvesicular hepatic steatosis

desc: A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis.
name: Diffuse hepatic steatosis

desc: An acute form of hepatic steatosis.
name: Acute hepatic steatosis

desc: An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes.
name: Increased hepatocellular lipid droplets

desc: An abnormal appearance of the liver or any of its components on sonography (ultrasound).
name: Abnormal liver sonography

desc: Any deviation from the normal degree of echogenicity of the liver on sonography. Echogenicity refers to the ability of a tissue to reflect or transmit ultrasound waves in the context of surrounding tissues. Whenever there is an interface of structures with different echogenicities, a visible difference in contrast will be apparent on the screen. Based on echogenicity, a structure can be characterized as hyperechoic (white on the screen), hypoechoic (gray on the screen) and anechoic (black on the screen).
name: Abnormal hepatic echogenicity

desc: Increased echogenicity of liver tissue on sonography, manifested as an increased amount of white on the screen of the sonography device.
name: Increased hepatic echogenicity

desc: Reduced echogenicity of liver tissue on sonography, manifested as an increased amount of black on the screen of the sonography device.
name: Decreased hepatic echogenicity

desc: The appearance of the liver in sonographic images is normally uniform. This term applies when there is an irregular or non-uniform appearance of the liver parenchyma in liver sonography.
name: Coarsened hepatic echotexture

desc: An abnormal echotexture visible in liver ultrasound manifesting as a diffuse hyperechoic liver echotexture with multiple, small hypoechoic lesions. The appearance is said to resemble a starry sky (multiple white spots on a dark background).
layperson: Starry sky appearance on hepatic sonography
name: Starry sky appearance on hepatic sonography

desc: Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop.
name: Hepatic agenesis

desc: Fusion of the liver with the lung.
name: Hepatopulmonary fusion

desc: Change in normal glycogen storage content.
name: Abnormal hepatic glycogen storage

desc: An increase in the amount of glycogen stored in hepatocytes compared to normal.
name: Increased hepatic glycogen content

desc: An abnormality of the pancreas.
name: Abnormality of the pancreas

desc: A congenital anomaly in which the pancreas completely (or sometimes incompletely) encircles the second portion of duodenum and occasionally obstructs the more proximal duodenum.
name: Annular pancreas

desc: A cyst of the pancreas that possess a lining of mucous epithelium.
name: Pancreatic cysts

desc: Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis.
name: Pancreatic pseudocyst

desc: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic dysplasia

desc: The presence of pancreatic tissue outside the normal pancreas, in many cases along the foregut and proximal midgut.
name: Ectopic pancreatic tissue

desc: A deviation from the normal size of the pancreas.
name: Abnormal pancreas size

desc: Hyperplasia of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic hyperplasia

desc: A congenital underdevelopment (aplasia or hypoplasia) of the pancreas.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the pancreas

desc: Hypoplasia of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic hypoplasia

desc: Aplasia of the pancreas.
name: Pancreatic aplasia

desc: Any structural anomaly of the pancreatic duct, which is the tubular structure that collects exocrine pancreatic secretions and transports them to the duodenum.
name: Abnormal pancreatic duct morphology

desc: A congenital anomaly characterized by the presence of two separate pancreatic ducts.
name: Duplication of pancreatic duct

desc: A congenital anomaly of the pancreas that results from failed fusion of the dorsal and ventral ducts during embyological development. Three variants have been described: type 1 or classical divisum in which there is total failure of fusion; type 2 in which dorsal drainage is dominant in the absence of the duct of Wirsung; and type 3 or incomplete divisum where a small communicating branch is present.
name: Pancreas divisum

desc: An anomaly of the function of the pancreas.
name: Abnormality of pancreas physiology

desc: A functional anomaly of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes.
name: Abnormality of exocrine pancreas physiology

desc: Impaired function of the exocrine pancreas associated with a reduced ability to digest foods because of lack of digestive enzymes.
layperson: Inability to properly digest food due to lack of pancreatic digestive enzymes
name: Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency
synonyms: Inability to properly digest food due to lack of pancreatic digestive enzymes

desc: An abnormality of the peritoneum.
name: Abnormality of the peritoneum

desc: Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage.
name: Hemoperitoneum

desc: An increase in the amount of fluid present in the peritoneal cavity (between the layers of the peritoneum that lines the abdomen).
name: Peritoneal effusion

desc: Folds of membranous tissue (peritoneum, mesothelium) attached to the wall of the abdomen and enclosing viscera. Examples include the mesentery for the small intestine; the transverse mesocolon, which attaches the transverse portion of the colon to the back wall of the abdomen; and the mesosigmoid, which enfolds the sigmoid portion of the colon. Cells of the same embryologic origin also surround the other organs of the body such as the lungs (pleura) or the heart (pericardium).
name: Abnormality of mesentery morphology

desc: A closed fluid filled sac originating from the mesentary.
name: Mesenteric cyst

desc: A type of mesenteric cyst that is lined with a thin endothelium or mesothelium and filled with chylous and lymphatic fluid.
name: Chylolymphatic mesenteric cyst

desc: The presence of any abnormality affecting the abdominal wall.
name: Abnormality of the abdominal wall
synonyms: Abnormality of external features of the abdomen

desc: An abnormality of the structure or appearance of the umbilicus.
name: Abnormal umbilicus morphology

desc: Abnormally prominent umbilicus (belly button).
name: Prominent umbilicus
Superiorly positioned umbilicus
synonyms: The position of the umbilicus (belly button) is abnormally high (superior).

desc: The position of the umbilicus (belly button) is abnormally low (inferior).
name: Inferiorly positioned umbilicus

desc: A kind of congenital defect of the anterior abdominal wall in which the intestines are evident through the thin, lax, and protruding abdominal wall in affected infants.
name: Prune belly

desc: An incomplete closure of the abdominal wall.
name: Abdominal wall defect

desc: A type of congenital ventral incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which the intestines and sometimes other organs extend freely into the amniotic fluid space through a small opening in the abdomen, usually to the right of the umbilicus.
name: Gastroschisis

desc: Eversion of a hollow organ and exposure, inside out, and protruded through the abdominal wall.
name: Exstrophy

desc: An abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract

desc: Abnormal structure of the gastrointestinal tract.
layperson: Abnormal shape of the digestive system
name: Morphological abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
synonyms: Morphological abnormality of the GI tract
Abnormal shape of the digestive system
Morphological anomaly of the digestive system

desc: A structural abnormality of the esophagus.
name: Abnormal esophagus morphology

desc: A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the esophagus such that the esophagus ends in a blind pouch rather than connecting to the stomach.
layperson: Birth defect in which part of esophagus did not develop
name: Esophageal atresia
synonyms: Birth defect in which part of esophagus did not develop

desc: Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the lower portion of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal varix

desc: Defect in the epithelium of the esophagus, essentially an open sore in the lining of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal ulceration

desc: The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
name: Spontaneous esophageal perforation

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the lumen of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal stenosis

desc: A pathological narrowing of the esophagus that is caused by the development of a ring of scar tissue that constricts the esophageal lumen.
layperson: Narrowing of esophagus due to inflammation and scar tissue
name: Esophageal stricture
synonyms: Narrowing of esophagus due to inflammation and scar tissue

desc: A condition characterized by necrosis of the mucosal and submucosal layers of the esophagus not related to ingestion of caustic or other injurious agents. Endoscopically, there is a dark lesion ('black esophagus') distributed in a circumferential manner in the distal one-third of the esophagus with or without exudates. There is involvement of the distal esophagus ending sharply at the gastroesophageal junction.
name: Acute esophageal necrosis

desc: A white patch or plaque occurring on the surface of the esophageal mucous membranes that cannot be rubbed off and cannot be characterized clinically as any other disease.
name: Esophageal leukoplakia

desc: Longitudinal grooves in the surface of the esophagus arranged in a longitudinal fashion (from top to bottom of the esophagus).
name: Esophageal furrows

desc: A piece of food that has gotten stuck in the esophagus and prevents further swallowing.
name: Esophageal food impaction

desc: An exudate is a mass of fluid and cells that has seeped out of blood vessels or an organ, usually related to inflammation. In the esophagus, exudates usually present as whitish plagues on the surface of the esophageal mucosa.
name: Esophageal exudate

desc: Vomiting-induced mucosal laceration at the esophago-gastric junction.
name: Mallory-Weiss tear

desc: Thin (2-3mm) membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa that can be congenital or acquired. Congenital webs commonly appear in the middle and inferior third of the esophagus, and they are more likely to be circumferential with a central or eccentric orifice. Acquired webs are much more common than congenital webs and typically appear in the cervical area (postcricoid). Clinical symptoms of this condition are selective (solid more than liquids) dysphagia, thoracic pain, nasopharyngeal reflux, aspiration, perforation and food impaction (the last two are very rare).
name: Esophageal web

desc: The presence of a diverticulum of the esophagus.
name: Esophageal diverticulum

desc: A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication of a portion of the muscle and submucosa of the esophagus without epithelial duplication.
name: Esophageal duplication

desc: An abnormality of the intestine. The closely related term enteropathy is used to refer to any disease of the intestine.
name: Abnormal intestine morphology

desc: Impaired ability to absorb one or more nutrients from the intestine.
name: Malabsorption

desc: Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Fat malabsorption

desc: Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats.
name: Steatorrhea

desc: An inability to digest lactose.
name: Lactose intolerance

desc: An inability to digest starch.
name: Starch intolerance

desc: An abnormality of the small intestine.
name: Abnormality of the small intestine

desc: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum.
name: Meckel diverticulum

desc: An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the ileum.
name: Ileal atresia

desc: An erosion of the mucous membrane in a portion of the ileum.
name: Ileal ulcer

desc: Inflammation of the ileum.
name: Ileitis

desc: Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Protein-losing enteropathy

desc: An abnormality of the duodenum, i.e., the first section of the small intestine.
name: Abnormality of the duodenum

desc: A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum.
layperson: Absence or narrowing of first part of small bowel
name: Duodenal atresia
synonyms: Absence or narrowing of first part of small bowel

desc: An erosion of the mucous membrane in a portion of the duodenum.
name: Duodenal ulcer

desc: Wasting or decrease in size of all or part of the duodenum.
name: Duodenal atrophy

desc: Dilation and elongation of the duodenum with hypertrophy of all layers of the duodenum.
name: Megaduodenum

desc: The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the duodenum.
name: Duodenal stenosis

desc: Underdevelopment of the small intestine.
name: Hypoplasia of the small intestine

desc: A deviation from the normal rotation of the midgut during embryologic development with mislocalization of the small bowel.
name: Malrotation of small bowel

desc: An abnormality of the jejunum, i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
name: Abnormality of the jejunum

desc: A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
name: Jejunal atresia

layperson: Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology
name: Abnormality of small intestinal villus morphology
synonyms: Abnormal shape of small intestinal villus

desc: The enteric villi are atrophic or absent.
name: Villous atrophy
synonyms: Small intestine biopsy shows villous atrophy

desc: Failure to develop of the small intestine.
name: Agenesis of the small intestine

desc: The narrowing or partial blockage of a portion of the small intestine.
name: Small intestinal stenosis

desc: Abnormal small intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
name: Small intestinal dysmotility

desc: A structural anomaly of the mucous lining of the small intestine.
name: Abnormal small intestinal mucosa morphology

desc: Substantially shortened length of the small intestine as a result of a developmental defect.
name: Congenital shortened small intestine

desc: Any abnormality of the large intestine.
name: Abnormal large intestine morphology

desc: An abnormaltiy of the rectum, the final segment of the large intestine that stores solid waste until it passes through the anus.
name: Abnormality of the rectum

desc: Protrusion of the rectal mucous membrane through the anus.
name: Rectal prolapse

desc: A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the rectum. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the rectum.
name: Rectal atresia

desc: An abnormal dilation of the rectum. There is a large filled rectum as a result of underlying innervation or muscular abnormalities, which remains after disimpaction of the rectum.
name: Megarectum

desc: Enlarged, bulging blood vessels in and around the anus often associated with rectal bleeding, itching, and pain.
name: Hemorrhoids

desc: The presence of multiple diverticula of the colon.
name: Colonic diverticula

desc: An anatomical anomaly that results from an abnormal rotation of the gut as it returns to the abdominal cavity during embryogenesis.
name: Malrotation of colon

desc: A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the lumen of the colon. That is, there is an abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the colon.
name: Colonic atresia

desc: An ulcer of the colon due to pressure and irritation from retained fecal masses.
name: Stercoral ulcer

desc: The presence of varices (enlarged and convoluted blood vessels) in the colon.
name: Colonic varices

desc: A narrowing of a segment of colon whereby bowel continuity is maintained.
name: Colonic stenosis

desc: A structural anomaly of the mucous lining of the large intestine.
name: Abnormal large intestinal mucosa morphology

desc: Abnormally increased intraepithelial lymphocyte count. This finding may be appreciated as large numbers of surface intraepithelial lymphocytes as seen (for instance) with hematoxylin and eosin staining of a colonic biopsy sample taken during colonoscopy.
layperson: Lymphocytic infiltration of the colorectal mucosa
name: Lymphocytic infiltration of the colorectal mucosa

desc: Lymphoid nodular hyperplasia (LNH) of the terminal ileum and colon has been considered a mucosal response to nonspecific stimuli, most often infections, and consequently has been regarded as a pathophysiologic phenomenon during infancy and childhood. LNH can be ascertained by colonoscopy, whereby a lymphoid nodule is defined as an extruding follicle with a diameter of not more than 2 mm, and LNH is defined as a cluster of not more than 10 of such extruding lymphoid nodules (see Figure 1 of PMID:17368236).
name: Lymphoid nodular hyperplasia

desc: Congenital absence or underdevelopment of the colon.
name: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the colon

desc: A colon of abnormally small caliber.
name: Microcolon

desc: Underdevelopment of the colon.
name: Hypoplastic colon

desc: Congenital absence of the colon
name: Aplastic colon

desc: An abnormality of the intestinal rotation and fixation that normally occurs during the development of the gut. This can lead to volvulus, or twisting of the intestine that causes obstruction and necrosis.
name: Intestinal malrotation

desc: An abnormality of the intestine in which part of the intestine invaginates (telescopes) into another part of the intestine.
name: Intussusception

desc: Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue.
name: Volvulus

desc: A functional rather than mechanical obstruction of the intestines, associated with manifestations that resemble those caused by an intestinal obstruction, including distension, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea, in an individual in whom a mechanical blockage has been excluded.
name: Intestinal pseudo-obstruction

desc: Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.
name: Intestinal obstruction

desc: Acute obstruction of the intestines preventing passage of the contents of the intestines.
name: Ileus

desc: Obstruction of the intestine due to abnormally thick meconium.
name: Meconium ileus

desc: The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
name: Bowel diverticulosis

desc: Developmental hypoplasia of the intestine.
name: Intestinal hypoplasia

desc: An abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the intestine.
name: Intestinal atresia

desc: The presence of multiple areas of atresia affecting the small intestine.
name: Multiple small bowel atresias

desc: A lymphoproliferative abnormality of the intestine characterized by numerous visible mucosal nodules measuring up to, and rarely exceeding, 0.5 cm in diameter Histologically, hyperplastic lymphoid follicles with large germinal centres are seen in the lamina propria and superficial submucosa. There is enlargement of the mucosal B cell follicles caused by hyperplasia of the follicle centres; surrounded by a normal appearing mantle zone. Disease may involve the stomach, the entire small intestine, and the large intestine.
name: Intestinal lymphoid nodular hyperplasia

desc: A structural anomaly of the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the intestine.
layperson: Abnormality of intestinal smooth muscle morphology
name: Abnormality of intestinal smooth muscle morphology

desc: Partial or complete wasting (loss) of muscularois propria tissue that was once present. The atrophy may involve a marked vacuolar degeneration of myocytes, loss of muscle fibers and some cases a highly characteristic honeycomb fibrosis.
name: Atrophic muscularis propria

desc: Abnormal layering of the intestinal muscularis propria into three layers; (1) inner circular; (2) additional oblique; and (3) outer longitudinal layer.
name: Abnormal layering of muscularis propria

desc: The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the muscularis propria of the intestine. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.
name: Fibrotic muscularis propria

desc: A hole (perforation) in the wall of the intestine.
name: Intestinal perforation

desc: A hole (perforation) in the wall of the colon.
name: Colon perforation

desc: A hole (perforation) in the wall of the small intestine.
name: Small intestinal perforation

desc: A hole (perforation) in the wall of the rectum.
name: Rectal perforation

desc: A developmental disorder in which there is a duplication the entire intestine or of a portion of the intestine.
name: Intestinal duplication

desc: An abnormal connection between the gut and another hollow organ, such as the bladder, urethra, vagina, or other regions of the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Intestinal fistula

desc: An abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and the perianal skin.
name: Anal fistula

desc: An abnormality of the stomach.
name: Abnormality of the stomach

desc: A condition in which the stomach contents leak backwards from the stomach into the esophagus through the lower esophageal sphincter.
name: Gastroesophageal reflux

desc: An abnormality of the gastric mucous membrane.
layperson: Abnormality of the mucous membrane layer of stomach
name: Abnormality of the gastric mucosa
synonyms: Abnormality of the mucous membrane layer of stomach

desc: An ulcer, that is, an erosion of an area of the gastric mucous membrane.
name: Gastric ulcer

desc: The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
name: Gastritis

desc: A chronic form of gastritis.
name: Chronic gastritis

desc: A form of chronic gastritis associated with atrophic gastric mucous membrane.
name: Chronic atrophic gastritis

desc: A type of gastritis characterized by excessive proliferation of the gastric mucosa and diffuse thickening of the gastric mucosal folds.
name: Giant hypertrophic gastritis

desc: Infiltration of eosinophils in the stomach mucosa, that is diagnosed by an upper endoscopy and microscopy that shows more than 20 eosinophils per high-power field in association with peripheral eosinophilia and the absence of secondary cause of eosinophilia.
layperson: Eosinophilic infiltration in the stomach mucosa
name: Eosinophilic infiltration in the stomach mucosa

desc: An abnormality of the pylorus.
name: Abnormality of the pylorus

desc: An abnormal narrowing of the pylorus.
name: Pyloric stenosis

desc: Congenital atresia of the pylorus.
name: Congenital pyloric atresia

desc: Hypertrophy of the stomach.
name: Gastric hypertrophy

desc: Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
name: Absence of intrinsic factor
synonyms: Intrinsic factor absent from gastric juice

desc: Gastric duplication is a usually cystic malformation of gastrointestinal tract, usually attached to the greater curvature of the stomach and has no communication with the stomach.
name: Gastric duplication

desc: Extreme dilation of the submucusoal veins in the stomach.
name: Gastric varix

desc: Abnormal anatomical location of the stomach. This feature may be due to intestinal malrotation.
name: Malposition of the stomach

desc: An outpouching of the gastric wall.
name: Gastric diverticulum

desc: A developmental anomaly wtih a small tubular or saccular midline stomach.
name: Microgastria

desc: A spherical hollow structure with a smooth muscle coat, lined by a mucous membrane, and attached to any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the base of the tongue to the anus.
name: Gastrointestinal duplication

desc: An abnormality of the anus or rectum.
name: Anorectal anomaly

desc: Abnormality of the anal canal.
name: Abnormality of the anus

desc: Congenital absence of the anus, i.e., the opening at the bottom end of the intestinal tract.
name: Anal atresia

desc: Abnormal narrowing of the anal opening.
name: Anal stenosis

desc: Abnormal displacement or malposition of the anus.
name: Ectopic anus

desc: Anterior malposition of the anus.
name: Anteriorly placed anus

desc: Posterior malposition of the anus.
name: Posteriorly placed anus

desc: Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
name: Anal mucosal leukoplakia

desc: The presence of a rash (change of color and texture) of the perianal skin.
name: Perianal rash

desc: A small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. It appears as a crack or slit in the mucous membrane of the anus.
name: Anal fissure

desc: A tumor of the anal margin.
name: Anal margin neoplasm

desc: An intraepithelial adenocarcinoma originating in the anal margin and characterized by presence of typical Paget's cells, appearing as large rounded vacuolated cells.
name: Anal margin Paget's disease

desc: A squamous cell carcinoma that originates in the skin of the anal margin.
name: Anal margin squamous cell carcinoma

desc: A basal cell carcinoma that originates in the anal margin.
name: Anal margin basal cell carcinoma

desc: A melanoma that originates in the anal margin.
name: Anal margin melanoma

desc: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the anal canal or anal margin.
name: Anal neoplasm

desc: Anal intraepithelial neoplasia (AIN) is a premalignant lesion of the anal mucosa that is a precursor to anal cancer.
name: Anal intraepithelial neoplasia

desc: Eosinophilic infiltration of one or more gastrointestinal organs. Gastrointestinal eosinophilia is a broad term for abnormal eosinophil accumulation in the GI tract, involving many different disease identities. These diseases include primary eosinophil associated gastrointestinal diseases, gastrointestinal eosinophilia in HES and all gastrointestinal eosinophilic states associated with known causes. Each of these diseases has its unique features but there is no absolute boundary between them.
name: Gastrointestinal eosinophilia

desc: Abnormal functionality of the gastrointestinal tract.
layperson: Functional abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
name: Functional abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract
synonyms: Functional abnormality of the GI tract

desc: An ulcer of the gastrointestinal tract.
layperson: Sore in the lining of gastrointestinal tract
name: Peptic ulcer
synonyms: Sore in the lining of gastrointestinal tract

layperson: Death of digestive organ tissue due to poor blood supply
name: Gastrointestinal infarctions
synonyms: Death of digestive organ tissue due to poor blood supply

desc: Any physiological abnormality of the esophagus.
name: Abnormality of esophagus physiology

desc: Involuntary contractions of the esophagus that are irregular, uncoordinated, and painful.
name: Esophageal spasms

desc: An anomaly of the muscular contractions that propel food though the gastrointestinal tract.
name: Abnormal gastrointestinal motility

desc: Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.
name: Gastrointestinal dysmotility

desc: An anomaly of the wave-like muscle contractions of the digestive tract.
name: Abnormal peristalsis

desc: Excessively active peristalsis (wave of contraction of the tubular organs of the gastrointestinal tract) marked by excessive rapidity of the passage of food through the stomach and intestine.
name: Hyperperistalsis

desc: Reduced or inadequate peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the digestive tract.
name: Hypoperistalsis

desc: Reduced or inadequate esophageal peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the esophagus.
name: Ineffective esophageal peristalsis

desc: A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus.
name: Achalasia

desc: A deviation from the normal amount of time required for food to pass through the intestines.
name: Abnormal gastrointestinal transit time

desc: A reduction in the length of time required for food to pass through the intestines.
name: Decreased intestinal transit time

desc: An increase in the length of time required for food to pass through the intestines.
name: Increased intestinal transit time

desc: Pain experienced with swallowing.
name: Odynophagia

desc: An infection of the small intestine (enteritis) by clostridium difficile.
name: Clostridium difficile enteritis

desc: An infection of the colon (colitis) by clostridium difficile.
name: Clostridium difficile colitis

desc: A condition in which production of hydrochloric acid in the stomach is absent.
name: Achlorhydria

desc: A functional anomaly of the digestive system.
name: Abnormality of digestive system physiology

desc: Abnormally increased frequency of loose or watery bowel movements.
name: Diarrhea

desc: The presence of chronic diarrhea, which is usually taken to mean diarrhea that has persisted for over 4 weeks.
name: Chronic diarrhea

desc: Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
name: Secretory diarrhea

desc: Passage of many stools containing blood.
name: Bloody diarrhea

desc: Passage of many stools containing blood and mucus.
name: Bloody mucoid diarrhea

desc: Forceful ejection of the contents of the stomach through the mouth by means of a series of involuntary spasmic contractions.
name: Vomiting

desc: Paroxysmal, recurrent episodes of vomiting.
name: Episodic vomiting

desc: Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force.
name: Projectile vomiting

desc: Vomiting of material that is of fecal origin.
name: Feculent vomiting

desc: A sensation of unease in the stomach together with an urge to vomit.
name: Nausea

desc: Infrequent or difficult evacuation of feces.
name: Constipation

desc: Constipation for longer than three months with fewer than 3 bowel movements per week, straining, lumpy or hard stools, and a sensation of anorectal obstruction or incomplete defecation.
name: Chronic constipation

desc: Constipation of sudden onset and lasting for less than three months.
name: Acute constipation

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the abdomen.
name: Abdominal pain

desc: An intermittent form of abdominal pain.
name: Episodic abdominal pain

desc: A type of abdominal pain that comes and goes in waves, most often starting and ending suddenly and being of severe intensity.
name: Abdominal colic

desc: A type of abdominal pain characterized by a feeling of contractions and typically fluctuating in intensity.
name: Abdominal cramps

desc: Involuntary tightening of the abdominal musculature that occurs in response to touching the abdomen to avoid pain. Rigidity can occur in the presence of abdominal inflammation and usually involves only the inflamed area.
name: Abdominal rigidity

desc: A voluntary contraction of the abdominal wall musculature to avoid pain.
name: Abdominal guarding

desc: A heterogeneous group of symptoms that are localized in the epigastric region. Typical dyspeptic symptoms include postprandial fullness, early satiation, epigastric pain and epigastric burning, but other upper gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, belching or abdominal bloating often occur.
name: Dyspepsia

desc: A lack or loss of appetite for food (as a medical condition).
name: Anorexia

desc: Distention of the abdomen.
name: Abdominal distention

desc: A thrusting or bulging out of the abdomen.
name: Protuberant abdomen

desc: Impaired ability to eat related to problems gathering food and getting ready to suck, chew, or swallow it.
name: Feeding difficulties

desc: Impaired feeding performance of an infant as manifested by difficulties such as weak and ineffective sucking, brief bursts of sucking, and falling asleep during sucking. There may be difficulties with chewing or maintaining attention.
name: Feeding difficulties in infancy

desc: An inadequate sucking reflex, resulting in the difficult of newborns to be breast-fed.
name: Poor suck

desc: Regurgitation of milk through the nose.
name: Nasal regurgitation

desc: Feeding problem necessitating nasogastric tube feeding.
name: Nasogastric tube feeding in infancy

desc: Feeding problem necessitating gastrostomy tube feeding.
name: Gastrostomy tube feeding in infancy

desc: Feeding problem necessitating gastrojejunal tube feeding.
name: Gastrojejunal tube feeding in infancy

desc: A delay in the development of skills required to feed oneself in the toddler period (between one and three years of age).
name: Delayed self-feeding during toddler years

desc: The condition of inability to eat normally treated by placement of a thin tube through the nose into the stomach that is then used to carry food.
name: Nasogastric tube feeding

desc: The anterior abdominal wall is sunken and presents a concave rather than a convex contour.
name: Scaphoid abdomen

desc: An anomaly of the amount or nature of abdominal sounds. Abdominal sounds (bowel sounds) are made by the movement of the intestines as they promote passage of abdominal contents by peristalsis.
name: Abnormal bowel sounds

desc: An increased amount of bowel sounds.
name: Hyperactive bowel sounds

desc: An decreased amount of bowel sounds.
name: Hypoactive bowel sounds

desc: Complete lack of abdominal sounds as assayed by examination of the abdomen with a stethoscope.
name: Lack of bowel sounds

desc: A functional anomaly of the large intestine.
name: Abnormal large intestine physiology

desc: Involuntary fecal soiling in adults and children who have usually already been toilet trained.
name: Bowel incontinence

desc: The inability of the colon to modify stool to an acceptable consistency and move the stool from the cecum to the rectosigmoid area at least once every three days.
name: Colonic inertia

desc: A sudden, irresistible need to have a bowel movement.
name: Bowel urgency

desc: A repeated, painful urge to defecate without excreting stool.
name: Tenesmus

desc: A functional anomaly of the hepatobiliary system
name: Abnormality of hepatobiliary system physiology

desc: Reduced ability of the liver to perform its functions.
name: Decreased liver function

desc: Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
name: Acute hepatic failure

desc: Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as fulminant if there is onset of encephalopathy within 4 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
name: Fulminant hepatic failure

desc: Decreased activity of complex III of the mitochondrion in the liver.
layperson: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
name: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue

desc: Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure.
name: Reye syndrome-like episodes

desc: Inability to be weaned from intravenous (parenteral) nutrition, as judged by the hydration status (urine output, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, urine sodium concentration), ability to maintain weight, stool output, and serum electrolyte status.
name: Dependency on intravenous nutrition

desc: A structural anomaly of the digestive system.
name: Abnormality of digestive system morphology

desc: An abnormally elevated amount of alpha1-antitrypsin in the feces.
name: Increased stool alpha1-antitrypsin concentration

desc: Abnormal concentration of urobilinogen present in the stool.
name: Abnormal stool urobilinogen concentration

desc: An increased amount of urobilinogen present in the stool.
name: Increased stool urobilinogen concentration

desc: A symptom or manifestation indicating a systemic or general effect of a disease and that may affect the general well-being or status of an individual.
name: Constitutional symptom

desc: A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
name: Fatigue

desc: Intermittent and recurrent bouts of a subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation.
name: Episodic fatigue

desc: Subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation that persists for six months or longer.
name: Chronic fatigue

desc: A subjective feeling of tiredness characterized by a lack of energy and motivation and that is induced by exertion or exercise.
name: Postexertional malaise

desc: An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage, or described in terms of such damage.
name: Pain

desc: Joint pain.
name: Arthralgia

desc: Pain in muscle.
name: Myalgia

desc: The occurrence of an unusually high amount of muscle pain following exercise.
name: Exercise-induced myalgia

desc: Pain of the gastrocnemius muscle.
name: Gastrocnemius myalgia

desc: Persistent pain, usually defined as pain that has lasted longer than 3 to 6 months.
name: Chronic pain

desc: Pain due to a stimulus that does not normally provoke pain.
name: Allodynia

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the flank.
name: Flank pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the shoulder.
name: Shoulder pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the hip.
name: Hip pain

desc: Pain in the vulvar area
name: Vulvodynia

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the groin region.
name: Groin pain

desc: Recurrent episodes of redness, burning pain, and warmth of the extremities following exposure to heat or exercise with symptoms predominantly involving the feet.
name: Erythromelalgia

desc: Intermittent pain, i.e., pain that occurs occasionally and at irregular intervals.
name: Episodic pain

desc: A episode of severe pain that breaks through (i.e., temporarily exacerbates) a period of persistent pain.
name: Breakthrough pain

desc: Excruciating burning pain in the rectal area that may be triggered by defecation.
name: Paroxysmal rectal pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the urinary bladder. Bladder pain may be more pronounced with a full bladder and relieved upon urination, but this is not always the case.
name: Bladder pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to a tendon.
name: Tendon pain

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the jaw.
name: Jaw pain

layperson: Pain in head and neck region
name: Pain in head and neck region

desc: An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the neck.
name: Neck pain

desc: Pain that is localized to the region of the upper abdomen immediately below the ribs.
name: Epigastric pain

desc: Pain in and around the anus or rectum (perianal region).
name: Anal pain

desc: A sudden sensation of feeling cold.
name: Chills

desc: Severe chills with violent shivering. A rigor is an episode of shaking or exaggerated shivering which can occur with a high fever.
name: Rigors

desc: Involuntary contraction or twitching of the muscles.
name: Shivering

desc: A state characterized by a feeling of weakness and loss of strength leading to a generalized weakness of the body.
name: Asthenia

desc: Occurence of excessive sweating during sleep.
name: Night sweats

desc: Difficulty in performing one or more activities normally performed every day, such as eating, bathing, dressing, grooming, work, homemaking, and leisure.
layperson: Impairment of activities of daily living
name: Impairment of activities of daily living

desc: This term applies to an individual who requires help to bathe more than one part of the body, get in or out of the tub or shower, or who requires total bathing.
name: Impaired ability to bathe oneself

desc: This applies to an individual who needs help with dressing or needs to be completely dressed.
name: Impaired ability to dress oneself

desc: This term applies to an individual who requires help transferring to the toilet, cleaning self or who uses bedpan or commode.
name: Impaired toileting ability

desc: Applies to an individual who needs help in moving from bed to chair or requires a complete transfer.
name: Impaired transferring ability

desc: Applies to an individual who needs partial or total help with feeding or requires parenteral feeding.
name: Impaired feeding ability

desc: Partial or total incontinence of bowel or bladder.
name: Impaired continence

desc: Sudden feelings of warmth that are generally most pronounced over the face, neck and chest.
name: Hot flashes

desc: An unpleasant sensation of tightness or pressure in the chest.
name: Chest tightness

desc: A serious and potentially life-threatening condition that arises when a considerable mass of body tissue dies (necrosis).
layperson: Death of body tissue due to lack of blood flow or infection
name: Gangrene
synonyms: Death of body tissue due to lack of blood flow or infection

desc: A perceived unpleasant smell given off by the body.
name: Body odor

desc: Body odor characterized by an offensive body odor and the smell of rotting fish due to the excessive excretion of trimethylamine (TMA) in the urine, sweat, and breath of affected individuals.
name: Fish odor

desc: A fish odor in the vaginal area, that is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV), and is due to trimethylamine (TMA).
name: Vaginal fish odor

desc: Pungent body odor.
name: Musty odor

desc: An anomaly of cellular morphology or physiology.
name: Abnormal cellular phenotype

desc: Any anomaly of cell structure.
name: Abnormal cell morphology

desc: An abnormal structure of the female germ cell (egg cell).
name: Abnormal oocyte morphology

desc: Abnormal structure of the oocyte extracellular matrix region known as teh zona pellucida.
name: Abnormal zona pellucida morphology

desc: Reduced thickness of the zona pellucida.
name: Thin zona pellucida

desc: A structural anomaly of lysosomes, membrane-enclosed organelles that contain an array of enzymes capable of catabolizing proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and lipids.
name: Abnormal lysosomal morphology

desc: Intralysosomal, osmiophilic, lamellated and sometimes concentric cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of broad transversely-stacked myelinoid membranes and said to resemble a zebra in electron microscopic images.
name: Zebra bodies

desc: Any structural anomaly of a chromosome, which is a thread like molecule consisting of DNA and proteins (chromatin) that contains DNA sequences for genes and other genetic elements in linear order.
name: Abnormal chromosome morphology

desc: An abnormal reduction in telomere length. Telomeres are non-coding, repetitive sequences of DNA at the ends of the chromosomes of eukaryotic cells which become shorter as cells divide, and when telomere attrition reaches its limit, cell proliferation arrest, senescence, and apoptosis can occur.
name: Short telomere length

desc: Any structural anomaly of the cells of the mucosa of the oral cavity in the region of the cheek (buccal mucosa cells).
name: Abnormal buccal mucosa cell morphology

desc: Any functional anomaly of Langerhans cells, which are dendritic cells in the epidermis and some other locations. Langerhans cells play roles in immune surveillance and homeostasis.
name: Abnormal Langerhans cell morphology

desc: Birbeck granules (BG) are cytoplasmic organelles that are only found in Langerhans cells (LC). The function of BG is still not completely understood, although most studies point toward an active role in receptor-mediated endocytosis and participation in the antigen-processing/presenting function of LC. This feature refers to the absence of BG in LC, a feature that can be documented by means of electron microscopy.
layperson: Absent Birbeck granules in Langerhans cells
name: Absent Birbeck granules in Langerhans cells

desc: A halo or spoke-wheel arrangement of cells surrounding a central core or hub. The central hub may consist of an empty-appearing lumen or a space filled with cytoplasmic processes. The cytoplasm of each of the cells in the rosette is often wedge-shaped with the apex directed toward the central core; the nuclei of the cells participating in the rosette are peripherally positioned and form a ring or halo around the hub.
name: Rosette

desc: A type of rosette in which the central lumen or hub is filled with fiber-like processes.
name: Homer Wright rosette

desc: The tumor cells that form the Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette circumscribe a central lumen that contains small cytoplasmic extensions of the encircling cells; however, unlike the center of the Homer Wright rosette, the central lumen does not contain the fiber-rich neuropil.
name: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette

desc: A type of rosette in which a halo of cells surrounds an empty lumen.
name: True ependymal rosette

desc: A type of rosette in which a spoke-wheel arrangement of cells with tapered cellular processes radiates around a wall of a centrally placed vessel.
name: Perivascular pseudorosette

desc: A type of rosette that is similar to the Homer Wright rosette, but the central fiber-rich neuropil island is larger and more irregular.
name: Neurocytic rosette

desc: Any abnormal result of flow cytometry, a method that suspends cells in a stream of fluid and passes them through an electronic detection apparatus in order to assess cell count or measure biomarkers or surface molecules.
name: Abnormal flow cytometry test result

desc: Reduced level of a protein that is normally present on the cell surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced cell surface marker level

desc: Reduced level of a protein that is normally present on the fibroblast surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced fibroblast surface marker level

desc: Reduced level of CD55 on the fibroblast surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced fibroblast CD55 level

desc: Reduced level of CD59 on the fibroblast surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced fibroblast CD59 level

desc: Reduced level of CD16 on the fibroblast surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced fibroblast CD16 level

desc: Reduced level of a protein that is normally present on the granulocyte surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced granulocyte surface marker level

desc: Reduced level of CD55 on the granulocyte surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced granulocyte CD55 level

desc: Reduced level of CD59 on the granulocyte surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced granulocyte CD59 level

desc: Reduced level of CD16 on the granulocyte surface as assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced granulocyte CD16 level

desc: Reduced level of CD18 on the granulocyte surface. This feature can be assessed by flow cytometry.
name: Reduced granulocyte CD18 level

desc: A decrease in the protein expression fo GPI-anchor proteins, such as CD55 and CD59, at the cell surface, which suggests a defect in GPI-anchor biosynthesis.
layperson: Decreased expression of GPI-anchored proteins on the cell surface
name: Decreased expression of GPI-anchored proteins on the cell surface

desc: Spontaneous detachment (amputation) of an appendage from the body.
name: Autoamputation

desc: Spontaneous detachment of a foot from the body.
name: Autoamputation of foot

desc: An abnormality of the leg.
name: Abnormality of the lower limb

desc: An abnormality of the skeleton of foot.
name: Abnormality of the foot

desc: The presence of an unusually high plantar arch. Also called high instep, pes cavus refers to a distinctly hollow form of the sole of the foot when it is bearing weight.
name: Pes cavus

desc: The development of Pes cavus that is progressive with age.
name: Progressive pes cavus

desc: A foot where the longitudinal arch of the foot is in contact with the ground or floor when the individual is standing; or, in a patient lying supine, a foot where the arch is in contact with the surface of a flat board pressed against the sole of the foot by the examiner with a pressure similar to that expected from weight bearing; or, the height of the arch is reduced.
name: Pes planus

desc: A type of flat-foot characterized by hindfoot abductovalgus, metatarsus adductus, and Achilles tendon shortening. The predominant radiographic findings include forefoot adduction with lateral subluxation of the navicular on the talus and heel valgus. Very abnormal shoe wear is noted on the medial side. Calluses occurunder the metatarsal heads and thehead of the plantar-flexed talus.
name: Skewfoot

desc: A foot for which the measured width is above the 95th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately wide for its length.
name: Broad foot

desc: A foot for which the measured width is below the 5th centile for age; or, a foot that appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
name: Narrow foot

desc: Increased back to front length of the foot.
name: Long foot

desc: A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.
name: Positional foot deformity

desc: A deformity of foot and ankle that has different subtypes that are talipes equinovarus, talipes equinovalgus, talipes calcaneovarus and talipes calcaneovalgus.
name: Talipes

desc: Talipes equinovarus (also called clubfoot) typically has four main components: inversion and adduction of the forefoot; inversion of the heel and hindfoot; equinus (limitation of extension) of the ankle and subtalar joint; and internal rotation of the leg.
name: Talipes equinovarus

desc: Bilateral clubfoot deformity (see HP:0001762).
name: Bilateral talipes equinovarus

desc: A deformity of foot and ankle in which the foot is bent down and outwards.
name: Talipes equinovalgus

desc: Talipes calcaneovalgus is a flexible foot deformity (as opposed to a rigid congenital vertical talus foot deformity) that can either present as a positional or structural foot deformity depending on severity and/or causality. The axis of calcaneovalgus deformity is in the tibiotalar joint, where the foot is positioned in extreme hyperextension. On inspection, the foot has an "up and out" appearance, with the dorsal forefoot practically touching the anterior aspect of the ankle and lower leg.
name: Talipes calcaneovalgus

desc: A congenital deformity characterized by a dorsiflexed, inverted, and adducted foot, i.e., a combination of talipes calcaneus and talipes varus.
name: Talipes calcaneovarus

desc: An outward deviation of the foot at the talocalcaneal or subtalar joint.
name: Pes valgus

layperson: Medial rotation of the medial malleolus
name: Medial rotation of the medial malleolus

desc: A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the bones of the foot (as well as muscle and soft tissue). In contrast if only the muscle and soft tissue are affected the term positional foot deformity applies.
name: Structural foot deformity

desc: A difference in size or shape between the left and right foot.
name: Foot asymmetry

desc: Abnormally increased prominence of the fat pad underneath the heal. This feature can be appreciated in figure 1 of PMID:26769062.
name: Prominent subcalcaneal fat pad

desc: An abnormality resulting from a defect or disruption of dorsoventral patterning that normally happens during early development of the limbs. A disruption of the normal development of the dorsoventral axis may lead to a variable spectrum of different phenotypic abnormalities that may affect the nails and or palmar and dorsal side of the hands and/or feet, ultimately changing the normal dorsoventral appearance of the affected limbs.
layperson: Abnormality of dorsoventral patterning of the limbs
name: Abnormality of dorsoventral patterning of the limbs

desc: An abnormality of the calf, i.e. of the posterior part of the lower leg.
name: Abnormality of the calf

desc: Abnormal increase in size of the lower limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells).
name: Hypertrophy of the lower limb

desc: A developmental defect in which the legs are fused together.
name: Sirenomelia

desc: An abnormality of the arm.
name: Abnormality of the upper limb

desc: An abnormality affecting one or both hands.
name: Abnormality of the hand

desc: An abnormal hand position characterized by hyperextension of the fourth and fifth fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the same fingers such that they are curled towards the palm.
name: Ulnar claw

desc: Any structural anomaly of the hand.
name: Abnormal hand morphology

desc: An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints.
name: Hand clenching

desc: Fusion of the hands and feet by a thin membrane of skin (scarring) seen in forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa and leading to a "mitten" hand deformity.
name: Mitten deformity

desc: Displacement of the hand or of fingers of the hand from their normal position.
layperson: Displaced hand or fingers of the hand
name: Deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
synonyms: Displaced hand or fingers of the hand

layperson: Ulnar deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
name: Ulnar deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand

desc: Divergence of the longitudinal axis of the hand at the wrist in a posterior (ulnar) direction (i.e., towards the little finger).
name: Ulnar deviation of the hand

layperson: Radial deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
name: Radial deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand

desc: An abnormal position of the hand in which the wrist is bent toward the radius (i.e., toward the thumb).
name: Radial deviation of the hand

desc: An abnormality of the palm, that is, of the front of the hand.
name: Abnormality of the palm

desc: For children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 SD above the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length.
name: Broad palm

desc: For children from birth to 4 years of age, the palm width is more than 2 SD below the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is below the 5th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately narrow for its length.
name: Narrow palm

desc: For children from birth to 16 years of age the length of the palm is more than the 97th centile; or, the length of the palm appears relatively long compared to the finger length or the limb length.
name: Long palm

desc: An abnormality of the lower arm.
name: Abnormality of the forearm

desc: A descriptive term for a forearm bone that appears to have an additional bone within it on radiography.
name: Bone-in-a-bone appearance of forearm

desc: Deposition of calcium salts in the fibrous sheet that connects the radius and the ulna.
layperson: Calcification of the interosseus membrane of the forearm
name: Calcification of the interosseus membrane of the forearm

layperson: Duplication of bones involving the upper extremities
name: Duplication of bones involving the upper extremities
synonyms: Duplication of bones involving the upper extremities

desc: Abnormal increase in size of the upper limbs (due to an increase of the size of cells).
name: Hypertrophy of the upper limb

desc: A deviation from normal of the length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle)
name: Abnormal arm span

desc: Decreased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
name: Reduced arm span

desc: Increased length of the arm span (length from one end of an individual's arms measured at the fingertips to the other when raised parallel to the ground at shoulder height at a one-hundred eighty degree angle).
name: Increased arm span

desc: The presence of free air in the mediastinum.
name: Pneumomediastinum
